column2: SOME things undermine one's confidence in the management of the theatre. For three long months Gotham play goers have been twisting and squirming through a succession of stupid dramas on feeble-minded topics, as if suddenly no one in the theatre had an intelligent idea.

Beneath spreading shade trees wildebeeste will kick and parade across the open. Zebras will gather at a "water hole" not 200 feet away from lions placidly sun-bathing on rock ledges.

IT is not necessary to go to the West Indies, to Central America or to far away Tahiti in the South Seas in search of the wild tropical beauty of coconut groves. PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 (UP)--Duquesne University closed a successful football season today by defeating its city rival, Carnegie Tech, 14 to 7, before 19,907 fans in Pitt Stadium. Reilly, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, sold for the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company, in liquidation, the two-story brick building at 158-60 Montgomery Street and the twostory building 270-72 Henderson Street, Jersey City. The parcels, valued for taxation at $46,900, were

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--A resolution opposing "anti-strike" legislation on the ground that compulsion would "introduce ill-will and suspicion in the place of cooperation" was adopted today by the Seventh National Conference on labor legislation after speakers had asserted that no new legislation was required at this time to adjust industrial disputes.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 (AP)--It wasn't only what he did but the way he did it that apparently made the nation's turf writers name Challedon as the first thoroughbred to win the "horse of the year" championship for two years in a row.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Proposed amendments to the Federal-State milk marketing order for the New York metropolitan market, which will be submitted by mail to milk producers for their approval or rejection, were announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Appointment of Rear Admiral Ernest J. King to command the Atlantic Patrol Force of the Fleet was announced today by the Navy Department. Admiral King, who succeeds Rear Admiral Hayne Ellis, is a member of the General Board. He was formerly chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics and in 1938 and 1939 commanded the aircraft units of the Battle Force of the Fleet.

From Argyrokastron, in Albania, after its capture by the Greeks, came the story of a Greek woman who had seen the bodies of the young Italian dead left lying in the streets, and who wept as she made bandages for the wounded who still lived. "They're too young to die," an American reporter heard her saying. She said it "over and

Ten days ahead of time this city will receive its biggest Christmas gift--a magnificent new Sixth Avenue subway. All the intricate burrowing under a thousand miles of buried pipe and wire is finished, the last gleaming tile is in place and the forty-six noiseless phone booths wait only to exclude the roar of passing trains. Mayor La, Guardia yesterday called upon the taxpayers of the city to insist that the State Legislature adopt a more cooperative attitude in working out a sounder fiscal program for New York City and suggested new methods of taxation to put Federal and State levies on a "more intelligent and more unified" basis.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing here into the accuracy and completeness of Transamerica Corporation's stock registration reports came to a halt today.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 11-- Miss Genevieve Eda Phipps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Eugene Phipps of this community, has completed plans for her marriage to William Mustin Huggins, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Huggins of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, which...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--A formal agreement between the United States and Canada, providing for reciprocal treatment in the operation of air services between the two countries, was announced by the State Department today.

Disciplinary action, including dismissal, can be taken against teachers or faculty members in the New York City public schools and colleges who refuse to testify before the legislative committee investigating educational activities, William C. Chanter, Corporation Counsel, declared in an opinion yesterday.
VICHY, France, Dec. 11--A survey of the Winter food and supply situation has resulted in government orders to tighten all reatrictions in force since September.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11--The ambition of Larry MacPhail to keep right on swinging deals for the Dodgers in the face of an astonishing lull in the market went into reverse today.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Dec. 11--When Private Raymond Aloysius Murphy of the Puerto Rican Murphys, now of The Bronx, was discovered singing with a Spanish accent on Sunday in the Jewish Welfare Board's recreation center, it seemed likely that there was much more to him than was apparent on the surface.
Tenement property deals on the East Side formed the bulk of realty activity yesterday in Manhattan. Two of the parcels were sold by banks.

Further excavation by Commissioner Herlands into the affairs of the Board of Elections has unearthed a method of examination which for simplicity and charm is not surpassed by any system now in use. The statutes require that the qualifications of election inspectors be established by test. The board complied with the statutes by devising a test under which no candidate can fail...

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith risked arrest yesterday when, without a license, he mounted the auction block at the Christmas sale sponsored by the New York State Commission for the Blind in the old Tiffany Building, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

After being pronounced dead by a Fordham Hospital interne, and then apparently having started to revive, Mrs. Rebecca Silverman, 39 years old, who had inhaled illuminating gas in her home at 1845 Hobart Avenue, the Bronx, at 10 A.M. yesterday, was declared dead four and a half hours later in Fordham Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Five corporations engaged primarily in the manufacture and sale of beet sugar had in 1939 combined net sales of $103,939,719, compared with $87,422,223 in 1938, the Federal Trade Commission announced today. The sales of these concerns

Fielding and miscellaneous records of the International League just released revealed that Gus Suhr, long a Pirate first-sacker and with Montreal this year, was the loop's leading first baseman, with a mark of .992.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 city of Boston, Mass., temporary loan notes. The bankers bid 100, plus a premium of $40, stipulating the rate of interest as 0.22 per cent. The notes are dated Dec. 13, 1940, and will mature on Nov. 4, 1941. Peoffering is being made at a price to yield 0.1875 per cent.

For the first time in their almost six-year relationship, the New York Stock Exchange defied yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission. It refused to rescind its rule forbidding its members to maintain markets in New York stocks on other exchanges, despite requests by the SEC that it do so.

Jean Schlumberger, jewelry and accessory designer who fashioned the rococo cupids made famous by Mme. Elsa Schiaparelli, gave a fashion show yesterday afternoon at Chez Ninon, 9 East Fifty-fifth Street, for members of the fashion press and some of the store's chic clientele. Among those attending were Lady Mendl, Mrs. J. Borden Harriman and Mme. Aimee Lopez.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11--Harl McDonald, manager of the Philadelphia Orchestra, was empowered by the board of directors of the orchestra association today to negotiate with Leopold Stokowski about a contract for 1941-42, but the board established "certain limitations" that were not publicly defined.
LONDON, Dec. 11--The speech of the Marquess of Lothian, the British Ambassador, in the United States today is taken here as constituting a definite turning point in Anglo-American relations.

Gregorio Obregon, Colombian Minister to France for the last two years, arriving here yesterday on the Spanish liner Magallanes from Bilbao, Spain, described Marshal Henri Philippe Petain as "mentally and physically strong," although spparently "sad and worried."

RABAT, French Morocco, Dec. 5 (Delayed)--General Maxime Weygand feels his role as the delegategeneral of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain to French Africa is being misrepresented purposely in Great Britain and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The annual report of Norman Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, was as follows:

One of the largest subscription parties of the season thus far, the "Gay Thirties" Dinner Dance, was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. An annual event that derives its name from the average age of the subscribers and their guests, the party this year was a benefit for the Boys...

OTTAWA, Dec. 11--A decline in the butter stock reserves followed by a sharp increase in price has forced consideration in Canada of the choice of pegging prices, permitting the market to continue uncontrolled with an automatic price restriction on consumption, or importing new stocks and possibly oleomargarine.

The city's unified transit lines, operated by the Board of Transportation as the New York City Transit System, produced an income $3,574,470 in excess of operating costs in the two months ended Aug. 31, according to a report made public yesterday by the board.

Coach Jim Crowley sent his Fordham football squad through another rather light practice yesterday on Rose Hill, but heavier work looms in the near future for the Rams, who are preparing to meet Texas A, and M. in the Cotton Bowl at Dallas on Jan. 1. Crowley figures that the team has limbered up sufficiently since the lay-off after the N.Y.U. game and is now ready for some contact sessions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11--November men's clothing sales shook off conscription tears and showed a good gain over 1939, holiday sales are running ahead and 1941 is expected to be a better year than 1940, the monthly survey of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Purnishers showed today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11--The issue of victory or defeat in the war against the revolutionary aggression of Nazi Germany "now depends largely" on the decision of the United States regarding the part it should play in the conflict, the Marquess of Lothian, British Ambassador to Washington, said...

That whispering campaign against or rather about, City College's basketball strength was brought to Nat Holman's attention yesterday. The Beaver court coach admitted he had heard some of the flattering comments and quite naturally hoped they would prove true, but opined that perhaps all those rave notices were a bit premature. His attitude appeared to be one of "let's wait and see what develops."

HOLI-YWOOD, Fla., Dec. 11--The ever-increasing tendency of the Federal Government to centralize all taxing powers and is efforts to remove the tax immunity from public securities seriously threatens the sovereign independence of all States and local governments, Governor John W. Bricher of Ohio today told members of the Investment Bankers Association of America, who are here for their annual convention.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 (AP)--Authorized sources expressed grave disappointment today over the reaction in the United States to Adolf Hitler's speech yesterday to munitions workers. They said it had been interpreted as if Germany wanted to lick the world.

Britain's Middle East Command reported yesterday that after three days of fierce desert fighting British forces had recaptured Sidi Barrani, advanced base of Italian forces in Western Egypt, and had taken three Italian generals and quantities of military material.

The General Motors Corporation has received $400,000,000 in national dafense orders from the British, Canadian and American governments, of which $164,800,000 is for Allison airplane engines for the British and United States Army Air Corps, it wan announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation.

The Rev. T. Lief Gulbrandsen, director of the Norwegian Seamen's Church in Brooklyn, has appealed to Americans to furnish several thousand Christmas packages for Norwegian seamen who will be in New York and other Atlantic ports over the Christmas season. The appeal was issued yesterday through Norwegian Relief, Inc., 580 Fifth Avenue.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11--The British forces striking in the Western Desert have captured the Italian base of Sidi Barrani, the major advanced point of the Italian invasion of Egypt, and taken great numbers of prisoners, including three generals, it was announced officially tonight.
Former Supreme Court Justice Burt Jay Humphrey of Queens died of a heart attack early yesterday in his home, 172-60 Henley Road, Jamaica Estates, at the age of 74.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The Navy Department announced tonight that the German freighter Rhein, which slipped out of Tampico, Mexico, on Nov. 29 to run the British blockade, was "in possession of the Dutch destroyer Van Kinsbergen this morning off the coast of Cuba."

Residential quarters consisting of eight rooms and three baths in the building at 1125 Park Avenue have been leased by Mrs. Edward Rubin from the Tishman Realty and Construction Company through Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

BERLIN, Dec. 11--To further resettlement in the eastern provinces won in the war against Poland, Adolf Hitler has decreed far-reaching reductions in taxes as well as increased bonuses for children for all settlers, present and potential, in these districts.

ATHENS, Thursday, Dec. 12-- Italian forces have launched "violent" counter-attacks along the Albanian front, but have failed to halt the Greek advance surging upon a half dozen key positions, a High Command communique reported early today.

Opposition to the proposal for a vehicular tunnel connecting the Lincoln Tunnel and the proposed new $4,000,000 central bus terminal at Forty-second Street and Ninth Avenue was expressed yesterday when the finance committee of the City Council held its first public hearing in City Hall on the capital outlay budget.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP)--The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) today signed an agreement which will give 60,000 Chrysler employee an increase is hourly wages and vacation allowances estimated by union officials at a total of $6,744,000 a year.

The city authorities are taking steps to protect New York against possible aerial bombing attacks, Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday. Study of the methods to be followed in case of war, particularly to meet the hazard of incendiary bombs, was started here "just after Munich," the Mayor said.

The educational committee of the Dressmakers Union is sponsoring an exhibition of paintings and drawings by members of the Local 22 Art Workshop opening tomorrow afternoon at the headquarters of the union, 218 West Fortieth Street. The art class for members of the union opened last February with Seth Hoffman as instructor.

There is a possibility that this country may be controlled by labor within a decade, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly Review of Business which will be sent out to members today. He added that if labor did gain control he hoped it could avoid the pitfalls of labor governments in other countries.

Mayor La Guardia's optimistic hope of getting draft deferments for members of the Police and Fire Departments as groups continued, it developed yesterday, to be subject to the same regulations that have governed the selection of drafted men since the Selective Service Act went into operation.

LONDON, Dec. 11--Lord Vestey, managing director of the Union Cold Storage Company and head of the Blue Star Line, died today at the age of 81 at Gerrard's. Cross, Bucks.
CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 11--Captain Ewart Johaston's Royal Business, clubbed "Queen of the smaller tracks," came back after two defeats to win the Shenandoah Handicap today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11--Mrs. Hannah Kent Schoff, honorary president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, editor and author, who had devoted much time to the cause of underprivileged children, died at her home here yesterday. Her age was 87.

MADRID, Dec. 11--"We aspire to be the spiritual axis of the Hispanic world," General Francisco Franco declared today in a cordial speech welcoming the new Argentine Ambassador, Dr. Adrian C. Escobar. ROME, Dec. 11--Many Polish Bishops and hundreds of priests are being held in concentration camps in Germany, the Osservatore Romano states in a very strong editorial, which paints a gloomy picture of what it asserts to be the plight of the Catholics in Germanoccupied Poland.

The refusal of this nation to enter the war would probably bring about "a negotiated peace in the Spring," General R.E. Wood, chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co., declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Board of Trade, held at the Hotel Astor.

There is something irresistibly vital and communicative in the playing of the two-piano team of Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin, whose program last night was the third event in the eleventh annual Town Hall endowment series. Benefited by a nine-day rest, the New York Americans will seek to improve their hockey fortunes tonight when they oppose the Chicago Black Hawks in a National League game at Madison. Square Garden. The meeting will be the third of the season between the sextets, the local skaters having beaten the Hawks. 1 to 0, and tied them. 2 to 2.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 12-- Japan's treaty of amity with Thailand (Siam), signed Dec. 6, has now been recommended for ratification by the Japanese Privy Council. The change in the Japanese Government in July and the uncertainties introduced into its foreign policy by the decision to join the Axis account for the delay.

With the closing of the subscription books last night by the Treasury on its new issue of $500,000,000 of five-year per cent fully taxable notes, the gossip in bond circles is that the issue has been heavily oversubscribed. Guesses range from five to as much as ten times oversubscribed.

Forty-six seniors at Hunter College were inducted into the Nu Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa yesterday afternoon at a special assembly for upper classmen is the Assembly Hall. The principal speaker was Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia University.

Moved by a common compassion for the lonely, ill and destitute folk whose sad stories were revealed in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, 380 contributors united yesterday to send $9,501.05 to the Neediest Cases Fund, and thereby bring the total that has been received in response to this twenty-ninth annual appeal to $50,256.89.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 11--The Duchess of Windsor is recovering satisfactorily from yesterday's dental operation, but, on advice of her doctors, will not start back to the Bahamas "before Monday and possibly later."

LONDON, Dec. 11--Concern over merchant shipping losses was reflected again in Parliament today. Once more favorable comparisons were sought with the heavier losses of the World War, but as usual in such cases, the country's position only seemed more dismal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--The State Department intends to rush plans for sending food to the destitute in unoccupied France, Spain and other neutral countries but will acquiesce in the decision reported last night by the Marquess of Lothian, British Ambassador, not to permit food to go through the British blockade to German-occupied regions.

The Swedish-American Line quietly celebrated its twenty fifth anniversary in the transatlantic trade yesterday with as exchange of cable messages between the New York and Stockholm offices and an expression of hope that the present virtual immobilization of the company's passenger and freight fleet would not last for long.

The Ice Follies of 1941 closed last night at Madison Square Garden after ten performances which were attended by 110,000 spectators.

MANTEO, N.C., Dec. 11--This area offers the visiting sportsman several varieties of hunting and if, by some chance, he happens to tire of carrying a gun, he can just take a rod and get a few striped bass for dinner. Hare these fish are known as rock, but the only difference is the name.

Six members of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra gathered outside Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall yesterday afternoon and played "Happy Birthday to You" to give the Mayor a surprise on his fifty-eighth birthday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 11 (AP)--The Chattanooga News-Free Press and two of its officers were convicted in United States District Court today of charges of conspiring to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by writing contracts giving to their newspaper exclusively certain advertising in the afternoon field.

ONE day in the Summer of 1939 a Congressman got in touch with Hallie Flanagan by telephone. He was a nice, conscientious Congressman, eager to do what he could for the voters who had sent him to Washington. He wanted to find out how things were going with the Federal Theatre performances back home.

Mr. and Mrs. William Vail Martin of the Plaza gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Sir George Bettesworth Piggott and Lady Piggott, Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Siebert, the Duchess Renee Carafa D'Andrea and Hjalmar Kinberg.

LONDON, Dec. 11--Military reports from Egypt and Albania made the stock markets cheerful today. Actual business, however, still was rather small and selective and, in some cases, prices finished below their best levels. Details of the War-Damage Bill did not provide a market factor, since they had not been studied up to the time the House closed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Jan. 7 was set today as the last day when manufacturers may safely file applications for certificates which permit special deductions from taxes to amortize the outlay for facilities built to handle defense contracts.
Boston College became the first New England institution to receive the Lambert Trophy for football prowess when the annual award was made at a dinner at Toots Shor's restaurant last night.

The chief duty of the Secretary of War is to serve as a "living symbol" of the supremacy of civil authority over military authority in the United States in accordance with the democratic way of life, Robert P. Patterson, Assistant Secretary of War, declared yesterday at a luncheon of Columbia University Law School alumni in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

IT was the day before the late lamented National Football League championship play-off and George Preston Marshall's scalp was still attached firmly to his head. The chief of the Redskins was asked which coach in the league had turned in the best job during the season.

The Columbia University Club's 4-1 triumph over the Crescent A.C. on the letter's courts, coupled with Bayside's first setback of the season at the hands of the Yale players, 3-2, on the Eli courts, last night sent the Columbians into a second-place tie with Bayside in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Learaue.

A leading Great Lakes producer of merchant pig iron has begun selling basic, foundry, malleable and bessemer grades of iron for the first quarter at an advance of $1 a ton for shipment from its furpaces in four districts, Iron Age reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)--The Bureau of Mines reported today that stocks of all oils decreased 3,123,000 barrels in October and on Oct. 31 were 573,696,000 barrels, or a 137-day supply, against 576,819,000, or 145 days, on Sept. 30. The supplies, however, were 46,780,000 barrels more than the year before.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 11 (AP)--The army tightened its control over nearly every phase of Rumanian life today with a series of emergency decrees by Premier Ion Antonescu.

The proposed merger of the PepsiCola Company and Loft, Inc., which was to have been acted upon by stockholders at a meeting adjourned to Dec. 18, was abandoned yesterday at meetings of the respective boards of directors owing to insuperable tax difficulties.

The Western Union Telegraph Company had a net income of $2,719,276 after all charges in the first ten months of this year, Roy B. White, president of the company, reported yesterday. This net was equal to $2.60 a share on the concern's 1,045,592 shares of capital

A group of independent coal dealers who drive their own trucks went into Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to resist a drive to force them to join an American Federation of Labor drivers' union, but they got little sympathy from Justice Thomas J. Cuff.

One of skiing's grandest figures, Hjalmar Andersen, was buried yesterday at the Evergreen Cemetery in Brooklyn following services by Edward C. Halvorsen, another of the sport's veteran figures. Known to untold thousands as just "Doc," Andersen succumbed to a heart attack while fulfilling his voluntary duties as hill tramper at the Bear Mountain jump last Sunday.
VICHY, France, Dec. 11--A sweeping reform planned to eliminate municipal politics and electoral strife from the urban centers of France was announced tonight by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

Mrs, Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday bought herself a Christmas gift. She described it as one of those "things I've always wanted." It is a Christmas creche to go under the White House Christmas tree, and will be moved upstairs and down, she declared, "wherever we have a tree."

Samuel Seabury, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, has appointed a committee on national defense, whose duty it will be to study the problem in its various aspects and make recommendations to the association, Charles H. Strong, secretary of the association, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Unless President Roosevelt himself directs another course, the question of financial aid to Great Britain will be put squarely up to the new Congress some time after it convenes on Jan. 3.

Citing the vital part played by labor in the government of England and the contribution being made by the British trade union movement in the war, President William Green of the American Federation of Labor demanded last night that American labor be given similar representation in the task of national defense.

The National Committee on Food for the Five Small Democracies, of which former President Hoover is honorary chairman, issued a statement yesterday saying that the British refusal to raise the blockade on food shipments to Europe had "deferred" solution of the problem, but that the committee would keep on trying to find an answer acceptable to the British Government.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 12-- Planes came over London and other parts of England last night. Guns boomed and cracked. Tickers tapped out their tale of bombs dropped--in one district of London, in Midlands cities, in a little village. The drone of planes was heard over Liverpool and South Wales.

A carefully prepared performance of Charpentier's "Louise," with Grace Moore in the title part, packed the Metropolitan Opera House last night. MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 11--Agents of German concerns that failed to make deliveries to South America in October--the time they had set for the end of the war--now are informing their customers that the war will be over by the end of December and urging them to place orders for delivery then.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses delivered a brisk and colorful series of criticisms yesterday to the City Planning Commission as it held public hearings in City Hall on its tour-phase proposal for changes in the master plan of the city.
The Cincinnati Reds, successors to the Yankees as baseball's world champions, inherited another former Yankee property today when they were voted the outstanding team of the year.

Queens College, latest addition to metropolitan basketball circles, continues to be treated outlandishly by its neighbors. Beaten in their first two starts by Cooper Union and Brooklyn College, the Knights tried to recoup their fortunes last night against New York University at the Heights Gymnasium only to suffer a 47-17 setback.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Exploring the union labor fee situation in this area, as recommended yesterday by Mrs. Roosevelt, the Tolan committee, which is investigating the problems of destitute migrants, heard two witnesses today confirm previous testimony that a $300 initiation fee was imposed on new electrical workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP)-- Senate investigators of wiretapping heard testimony today that Robert C. La Borde, who operates conversation-recording devices, sought to "shadow" an attorney who appeared in a suit against the Columbia Gas and Electric Company for $42,000,000.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company will hold a preview of its 1941 refrigerators, ranges and air conditioners on Dec. 19 in the Hotel Pennsvlvania.

On behalf of the National Association of Manufacturers, one of the largest industrial organizations of the country, H.W. Prentis Jr., as president, publicly summoned the government yesterday to "develop a clear definition of our defense objectives."

BOSTON, Dec. 11--Dr. Fletcher G. Watson, executive secretary of the Harvard Observatory, said tonight that the recently discovered Cunningham's Comet, which is expected to stage, late this month, the most spectacular astronomical show in thirty years, has come within vision range of the naked eye and is flaring toward its peak of brilliance right on schedule.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Nathaniel Barksdale Dial, United States Senator from 1918 to 1925, died tonight at his home here of a heart attack, after a five-day illness. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--An executive order defining non-combatant military service for conscientious objectors as any service which did not require the actual bearing of arms or training in the use of arms was issued today by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Congressional leaders planned today to call their colleagues back into full session either Dec. 17 or 18 for a vote upon sustaining or overriding an expected Presidential veto of the Logan-Walter bill. The measure would subject governmental agency rules and regulations to judicial review.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 11--The Chilean Foreign Office firmly denied today assertions contained in an article on communism in Chile, printed last week in THE NEW YORK TIMES and reproduced here today, according to which "the [Chilean] government is controlled by Communists."

LONDON, Dec. 11--A plan of compensation for war damage to real estate and business and personal chattels was proposed in the House of Commons today. The proposal calls for government participation as well as that of private ownership and covers the period from the outbreak of the war until next Aug. 31.

Dividends for 1941 on Savings Bank Life Insurance policies have been declared at most ages from two to three times the amounts paid in 1940, Judge Edward A. Richards, president of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund, announced yesterday.
THIS evening thousands of persons will swarm through the lighted marquees of amazing Madison Square Garden. Not so many hours ago, the rasping crunch of steel blades on ice formed the main music.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday morning that the note of joy need not be absent this Christmas, even from a world at war, if we have the joy of the Lord. RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 15--Metropolitan skiers who have cut fancy capers on Pico Peak for three seasons--and their number is legion-- will find this expansive Green Mountain development completely transformed this Winter. The New York City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, directed by Leopold Prince, will hold a musical program at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, Dec. 28, for the benefit of the American Friends of Britain, it was announced yesterday.

GEORGETOWN, S.C., Dec. 15 (AP)--A unit of hastily mobilized State militia mounted a machine gun on the second-story porch of the Georgetown county jail today and held back a mob of 300 men, armed with shotguns, rifles and pistols, bent on finding a Negro alleged to have attacked a young white woman last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 15 --Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York this afternoon dedicated the William Henry Hall Memorial, a new, $125,000 boys' division of the St. Agnes Hospital for Crippled Children on North Street.

After easing moderately at the beginning of last week, cotton prices subsequently turned firmer as selling pressure lessened. They failed, however, to recover all of their earlier losses. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active future deliveries closed the week with net losses of 2 to 6 points.

The Welfare Department will put in the mails today 1,605,000 green stamps intended to provide 1,605,000 quarts of free milk for 107,000 children under the age of 16 in 40,000 home-relief families. The mailing will mark the formal opening of the free-milk program financed by the Federal, State and City governments for the benefit of relief children.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, at Nibeiwa, Egypt, Dec. 15 (AP)--An Italian officer, captured here last week when the British opened their offensive, said today that the battle that raged for an hour around Nibeiwa was "the nearest thing to hell ever seen on this earth."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--Nearly 750,000 acres of scenic, recreational and historic land was added to the Federal Park System in the year which ended June 30 and the parks were being used more than ever in their history, the National Park Service said today in its annual report.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 15-- A letter bristling with criticism of the Hudson County political machine of Mayor Frank Hague was sent today by William E. Sewell, Republican Superintendent of Elections, to John F. O'Neill, Democratic County Supervisor.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, on Albanian Northern Front, Dec. 14 (delayed) (AP)--Greek peasant women, their faces wrapped in shawls, wielded big snow shovels in the mountain passes here today to clear the way for the steady push of Greek infantry forces against the Italian Army.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 15-- In hazy, damp and cold going thirty-one craft competed today in the Winter dinghy sailing races at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Skippers and crews had their worst chill of the season, although the thermometer has been lower.

VICHY, Dec. 15--Numerous interesting statements have been made officially recently regarding the economic situation. It appears that unemployment is diminishing. Coal transports, too, have markedly improved. The number of carloadings is increasing steadily and now has attained 70 per cent of the average in 1938.

CORAL CABLES, Fla., Dec. 15-- The Duke of Windsor and his party will sail from Miami for Nassau aboard the yacht Southern Cross Tuesday afternoon, Captain Vyvyan Drury, aide-de-camp to the former King, announced here today.

LONDON, Dec. 15--Mme. Blanche Marchesi, famous opera and concert singer, died at her home in Lancaster Gata today at the age of 77. Her last appearance was at Wigmore Hall two years ago. She had sung all over Europe.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 15--A majority of the homes of this resort and all the hotels and clubs are now open for the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15-- Metro announced that Robert Young will play the male lead opposite Laraine Day in the recently scheduled remake of "The Trial of Mary Dugan." Norman McLeod will direct the Bayard Veiller play, which was filmed originally in 1933 with Norma Shearer, Lewis Stone and the late Lilyan Tashman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15--Liquidation last week by holders of December and January lard contracts carried the price of that commodity down to the lowest level since April, 1933 While the break disclosed good support at times, most of the buying was credited to cash interests, as there was little or no investment buying.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15--Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner last week, but sufficient selling developed in the December delivery at around 90 cents a bushel to limit upturns, and late in the week there was a sharp recession on scattered liquidation and in sympathy with soy beans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--Edward M. Barrows, a writer who for many years was a student of youthful gangs' activities in New York, died in Alexandria Hospital, Alexandria, Va., yesterday after a brief illness. He was born fifty-three years ago in Columbus, Ohio.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 15--Last week's Continental European markets failed to show uniform trends. The general impression is that unless major military or diplomatic changes occur, each separate market will continue to be scarcely affected...

ALBANY, Dec. 15--By a vote of 95 to 30, the Hi-Y model Assembly at its closing session today adopted a proposal to "prohibit" in this State strikes in rearmament plants used by the National Government in the defense program. The "bill," which brought one of the liveliest debates of the students' convention, was introduced by James Amore and Jay Smith of Central Valley.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will revive Donizetti's "La Fille du Regiment" next week with Lily Pons in the title role. The production, which has not been in the repertoire for twenty-one years, will be the fourth revival of the season.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that briefs were being prepared for filing before the Interstate Commerce Commission on its petition to equalize transportation rates on Great Lakes grain to bring back to the Port of New York a considerable volume of this traffic which has been lost in recent years.

Though only moderately active, last week's markets were distinctly firm, especially toward the weekend. The bond market attracted more attention than usual; its "averages" going on Friday not only to the highest of the war but to the best since November, 1937.

Aided by a handicap of twentyseven seconds, Miss Celine Yingling of the People's Palace captured the 200-yard breast-stroke swimming race at the Women's Swimming Association yesterday. The event was one of the highlights on the program conducted by the W.S.A.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Dec. 15--After a long telephone conversation with Secretary Hull in Washington, President Roosevelt today told patients of the foundation for the victims of infantile paralysis here that he hoped to return for a two-week stay in the Spring "if the world survives."

LONDON, Dec. 15--Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor and member of the inner War Cabinet, tangled with Communists again today when he addressed a meeting o 4,000 trade union delegates at Glasgow. Speaking again later in the day, he warned Soviet Russia on a policy that led to interference with Britain's affairs.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Dec. 15--On Christmas Eve, as the colored lights flash on, flying squads of Twenty-seventh Division men will fan out of Fort McClellan in a great circle. R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics at Princeton, was re-elected president at the closing session of the fifty-eighth annual convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP) --Stanford University will not avail itself of the new Pacific Coast Conference rule which permits compensation to Rose Bowl football players for time lost from regular jobs, Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, university president, said today.

"Hi-Ya, Gentlemen!" the musical with a book by Fred F. Finklehoffe, John Monks Jr. and Sid Silvers and a score by Johnny Green and Harold Adamson, was withdrawn Saturday night in Boston by the producer, Robert Ritchie.

Democracy today is facing the "last desperate stand" of the totalitarian forces that seek to overthrow it, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 15--With the American Football Association championship at stake, the Jersey City Giants overcame the Wilmington Clippers, 17--7, before 15,245 persons at Roosevelt Stadium yesterday, regaining the crown the Little Giants had captured in 1938.

Robert H. Addison, 28-year-old flier, who received his pilot's license last Friday, the 13th, made a dramatic forced landing with a passenger yesterday in a swamp near the Bronx end of the Whitestone Bridge. Although the plane overturned as it came to rest in three feet of water, neither the flier nor his passenger was injured.

Sharply defined types of dresses sold well at various levels last week, including black-and-whites, two-tone models, high shades and formals, but reaction to volume was generally one of disappointment. Special groups of dressy coats were bought for January promotions and merchants anticipated good response to sports types for these events.

Supporters of both Commissioner David B. Costuma and Gabriel L. Kaplan, rival candidates for designation for Commissioner of Elections by the New York County Republican Committee, claimed commitments from a majority of committee members last night. The meeting will be held tonight at the Yorkville Casino.

Unable to rouse themselves from their slump, the New York Rovers dropped their sixth straight Eastern Hockey League game yesterday. With 11,714 enthusiasts looking on, the Red Shirts went down to their second setback in as many days, succumbing to the pace-setting Washington Eagies, 3 to 1, in the star contest of an amateur twin-bill at Madison Square Garden.

The final round of competition in the Diamond Belt amateur boxing tournament, conducted by The New York Journal and American, will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight, with a total of twenty-four contests scheduled. Profits from the event will go to the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is chairman.

A six-story elevator apartment house will be erected on the north side of Eighty-ninth Avenue, 150 feet west of 150th Street, in Jamaica, where a plot of 175 by 211 feet has been purchased by the Pinecone Realty Corporation from the Glen Park Corporation.

Dr. Charles Turchin of Washington declared yesterday that trainees conscripted into the Army may be placed in classifications 1A or 1B although suffering from one or several of sixteen serious foot deformities.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 15-- Many indications that show how the underground Communist party, under Moscow's orders, continued to run against German interests, and that the Nazis and the Gestapo recently fought against the Soviet, are furnished by Czech refugees who are passing through the Balkans en route to the Near East.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 16--With a thick mist reported prevailing over German-occupied France and a solid blanket of fog blotting out the Strait of Dover, Nazi raiders gave London and many other parts of this country a comparative rest from their bombing attacks again during the past night.

Some salve for the humiliation suffered by Washington at the hands of the Chicago Bears in the National Football League championship play-off is offered to the Redskins in the league's final team statistics released for publication today.

Although shorn of most of their former high honors last season, the Yankees retained the distinction of being a top-ranking defensive team, for in the official American League averages, released for publication today, the dethroned world champions are shown to be joint leaders with the Indians in team fielding.

LONDON, Dec. 15--One can almost come to believe the people here--and opinion is close to being unanimous--when they say: "Oh, we are not short of food. We have everything we want, at least all we need."
With the formal induction of fifteen new members, the congregation of St. John's Lutheran Church, 81 Christopher Street, yesterday morning celebrated the eighty-fifth anniversary of its founding.

ROME, Dec. 15--The High Command announced today that Sidi Barrani was evacuated yesterday by the Italians and that British troops, breaking through the frontier defenses along the coast, advanced into Libya up as far as the zone of Bardia, a town about eight miles from the border.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15--Acceleration of the national defense program by a declaration of a state of emergency and the enactment of legislation that "will be equivalent to full industrial, military and naval mobilization" is advocated in a statement issued today by thirtyfour educators and research scientists of institutions here.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 15--Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, conceded by most of his fellow-professionals to be the world's greatest golfer, won the $10,000 Miami open tournament today with a 271, nine strokes under par for the seventy-two holes.

Gifts to the 1940 Neediest Cases Fund fell off yesterday to $3,975.75, the smallest amount that has been received in any single day since THE NEW YORK TIMES launched its twenty-ninth annual appeal for the most unfortunate folk in New York, a week ago yesterday.

Mark Rosenberg Bros., manufacturers of men's overcoats, after fourteen years at 130 Fifth Avenue will locate at 98-100 and 102-4 Fifth Avenue, where they have leased a floor containing 17,000 square feet.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 15--H. Sherman Hooves of Boston annexed the ninth annual Ardsley invitation squash racquets tournament today by defeating Charles W. Brinton, Princeton senior, in five exciting games, 15--8, 6--15, 15--6, 13--15, 15--8.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 15--One of the survivors, a journalist, and the captain of the vessel, who has now been arrested, today gave a moving account of the inhuman treatment of refugees who were herded aboard the tiny and unseaworthy sailing vessel Salvator, which was wrecked last week near Istanbul with a total loss of 223 lives.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15--The volume of incoming steel business last week was fully as heavy as the corresponding week in November, which period incidentally was one of the most active in the steel industry's history.

The French Republic is dead, but it cannot rest. The familiar figures who kept turning up in the rotating system of French government, like numbers on a roulette wheel, still weave in and out on the shadowed scene at Vichy, uneasy ghosts condemned to haunt the dark and empty stage where they once performed.

Scoring three goals before their rivals made one, the Rangers registered an easy triumph over the Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. With Bryan Hextall achieving the "hat trick," the bluejerseyed skaters repulsed their rivals by 6 to 3.

Harry Thoens was the major winner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the high-over-all scratch cup with a card of 99 out of 100 targets, and in the monthly events won a leg on the doubles scratch cup with 21 out of 24. He finished the day with top honors in the scratch and the handicap events at 149 targets with a card of 142-2144.

LONDON, Dec. 15--Success of the British operations against the Italians in Egypt was received as an encouraging sign last week in financial circles here, although the full implications of the advance are, as yet, not assessable. Herbert S. Thomson, senior member of the firm of H.S. Thomson Son, civil engineers and city surveyors with offices at 56 Bay Street, St. George, S.I., and veteran of the Spanish-American War, died yesterday at his home, 263 Fiske Avenue, Westerleigh, S.I., after a long illness, at the age of 67.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--The reorganization of the French Government of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain with the elimination of Pierre Laval may be expected to accelerate action in the so-called Riom trials and also to widen the scope of the prosecutions by the inclusion of many other Republican leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--Rain beat down on Arlington National Cemetery today as the ashes of the Marquess of Lothian, the British Ambassador who died here last week, were placed in the receiving vault at the base of the monument to the battleship Maine.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 16--A British merchant marine captain told today of 134 days as a captitve of a Nazi sea raider. "The Germans were human enough," he said, "but the sausage--it was terrible."

Ed Barrow and Larry MacPhail, presidents of the Yankees and Dodgers, respectively, conferred yesterday at the former's office regarding a rumored deal between the clubs. Nothing was settled, but more news is expected today or tomorrow concerning Monte Pearson and Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, one of whom has been reported going to Brooklyn.

FORT DIX, N. J., Dec. 16--The soldiers of 1917 and 1918 have their tales of mud but the soldiers of 1940, in training at this camp, are prepared to match them story for story. Rain last night and this morning forced abandonment of field training and drove the men into the mess halls for lectures. It turned the company streets and training fields into khaki-colored mud as sticky as fly paper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--Retail sales in the United States totaled $42,028,818,000 in 1939, or an increase of 28 per cent over the 1935 total of $32,791,212,000, the Census Bureau announced today. The figure was a preliminary one pending completion of the final detailed report ...
A tragic tale of life as it is being endured these days in Western Europe, from Denmark to the border of Portugal, was revealed yesterday when the American Export Line's Excalibur docked here.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 16--As Highlanders charged into Sidi Barrani during the early stages of the battle in the Western Desert, Italian resistance crumpled rapidly and many groups of Italians and Libyans threw up their hands in surrender, but among a group charged by one ...

The military training camp bands may now go on the air as the result of an agreement reached yesterday by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and representatives of the three major broadcasting chains.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 16-- John F. O'Neill, Hudson County Supervisor, was not on a tropical cruise today, as charged by a political opponent, although he admitted wistfully that it was an excellent time to be in a sunnier climate. Mr. O'Neill was at his desk at the county courthouse here.

TOKYO, Dec. 16--The German and Italian war in Europe and Japan's war in China were closely linked today by Admiral Nobumasa Suetsugu, former Cabinet Minister, when he opened a three-day conference of Japan's new unitary political organization.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16--Officially announced only three weeks ago and given its first public flight last Friday, the Martin B-26, the Army's newest and most advanced medium bomber, is now moving down the production line of the Glenn L. Martin factory here, it was learned today.

Until the New York University basketball team is forced to show its poise and overcome a lead, Coach Howard G. (Jake) Cann prefers not to go out on a limb in making predictions for it other than to concede it is a "good club." If and when the Violets fall ...

Hope of a peaceful settlement in the row between the radio industry and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers increased yesterday as the Department of Justice confirmed in Washington that negotiations with the society were proceeding on a ...

SIDI BARRANI, Egypt, Dec. 16 (London Times Dispatch)--The British drive from Matruh to the Libyan frontier will undoubtedly be known as the Battle of Sidi Barrani. In a series of engagements that lasted four days the fighting round Sidi Barrani itself undoubtedly was the stiffest.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press)--Two assists that Boston's Billy Cowley picked up last week kept him perched at the top of the National Hockey League scoring race, according to official league figures released tonight.

The Downtown Renting Company, Elias A. Cohen, president, has added to its recent purchases in the neighborhood of the downtown civic center a third property, the fourteen-story office building at 305-9 Broadway, on the northwest corner of Duane Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16--The history of the Midamerica Corporation in the nineteen months when it controlled several of the country's largest railroads with only a $15,000 investment shows the need of legislation to place such holding companies under Federal regulation, a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16--For the second time within the past few weeks efforts of the Army to obtain bids on 10,000,000 yards of 4.8ounce khaki jean cloth failed today when only 4,755,000 of a requested 7,242,445 yards were subscribed by the twelve concerns submitting bids under Invitation 375.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16--Under the spotlight of national defense needs, the American Vocational Association, concerned with the training and educating of American youth, opened its most significant national convention here today. Never since World War days has the nation been so in need of trained workers, it was stressed in a score of papers read before the 2,000 delegates.

The present defense organization of the nation, which has been criticized from within and without as lacking coordinated planning, coordinated procurement and coordinated operations--the three essentials to sound defense--is generally admitted to be one of the reasons for delay in our defense program, a survey of that program shows.

A committee of ten to develop plans for promotion of the New York dress industry and to help make New York City the world's style center was set up at a joint conference held yesterday by representatives of the Dress Joint Board, International Ladies Garment Workers Union and five employer associations at the Hotel Commodore.
Several large apartments in the Park Avenue section were included in the list of residential rentals reported yesterday.

Wendell L. Willkie, former Republican Presidential nominee, conferred for about an hour yesterday with Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. on the selection of a successor to the latter as Republican National Chairman. The conference took place in Mr. Willkie's campaign headquarters in the Hotel Commodore.
ALBANY, Dec. 17--Less than half of the 979 applicants for admission to the bar were successful in the October examination, only 447 names being certified today by the State Board of Law Examiners,...

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 17--Bulgaria's claims on that part of Macedonia now in Yugoslav hands were brought up in the National Assembly for the second time in two weeks today, when the most proNazi Deputy of the majority group put a stiffly worded question to the Foreign Minister which included an accusation that Yugoslavia had assumed a provocative attitude.

The City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission and its president, Paul J. Kern, delved yesterday at its hearing in the New York County Court House into the affairs of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station.
LONDON, Dec. 17--Lord Lloyd, the Colonial Secretary, informed the House of Lords today that Britain was giving French and Belgian colonies "direct, definite support."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 17 (AP)-- A miracle man of scholastic football gained prominent attention tonight in speculation over a successor to Head Coach Francis A. Schtmidt at Ohio State University.

The Port of New York Authority sold yesterday an issue of $27,750,000 of general and refunding 3 per cent bonds, sixth series, to a syndicate of fifty-seven underwriters headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. at a...

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 17--Mrs. w. Robinson's County Cork made it two victories in a row over this track and Apprentice Herb Claggett rode the second of his three winners today in the Aviation Handicap. Installed an evenmoney favorite, County Cork was...

The first change in the operating schedule of the new Sixth Avenue subway was put into effect in the rush hour period last night as Bronx express trains were stepped up to run under a two-minute headway instead of two and a half minutes, and with ten cars instead of eight.

A holiday dance atmosphere pervaded the Ritz Oval Room at a luncheon fashion show yesterday when Lord Taylor exhibited a collection of evening gowns. Four dance numbers were introduced to illustrate the purpose of as many...

LONDON, Dec. 17--Sir William Davison, Unionist member of Parliament, said today that he would ask Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, to ban a meeting to be held in Manchester Jan. 11 and 12, by an organization known as the People's Convention, which proposes among other things "a people's peace" and friendship with Russia.

ATHENS, Dec. 17--Over the whole of the Albanian fighting area today the cold has been nearly insupportable. Stiffened hands have clung to rifles and frigid legs have carried men forward. Miracles of human endurance have been performed.

Forward passing was the major theme of yesterday's Fordham practice on Rose Hill, where Coach Jim Crowley sent his boys through their eighth drill for the Cotton Bowl game with the Texas Aggies at Dallas on New Year's Day.

IT does beat all, as the saying goes, what staggering phenomena one runs into once one gets a few thousand miles away from the skyscrapers of New York. Take the case of Hassoldt Davis. Mr. Davis is a novelist, book reviewer and traveler. Early in 1939 he left his apartment on lower Fifth Avenue to travel with the Armand DenisLeila Roosevelt Asiatic Expedition to Nepal, the "Land of the Eye."*

New York City will furnish 3,663 men to the Army during the next induction period, Jan. 6 to 17, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, selective service director for the city, announced yesterday. This is almost twice as many men as were provided by the five boroughs in the first call, Nov. 25 to 30, when 1,917 were called up.

At the suggestion of Charles Cain of Flushing, Queens, airline flight superintendent, twenty-six employes of the Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., met yesterday morning at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1919 Madison Avenue, to donate a pint of blood each to be sent to Great Britain.

Irwin Shaw has some droll notions in mind. In a town that has become tone deaf from listening too long to wisecracks it is hard to make people listen to drolleries without convincing them that they are bored. Mr. Shaw has not made the situation any easier by writing an inconclusive and meandering play.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 18-The Royal Air Force carried out threefold attacks on Germany Monday night and by daylight yesterday. The heaviest was directed against Mannheim, important industrial center in Southwestern Germany at the confluence of the Neckar and Rhine Rivers.
Macmillan will publish on Jan. 28 a work in four volumes that has been more than twenty years in preparation. It is "The Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature,"...

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, launched yesterday his church's nation-wide drive to raise $300,000 to aid Church of England missionary work jeopardized by war conditions. Bishop Manning announced the formation of a committee of prominent clergymen and laymen to carry on the campaign.

Alice Duer Miller, who in recent years has directed her efforts so much toward Hollywood that she thinks of herself as a scenario writer rather than as an author, wrote a long poem during the quiet months of war "to tell a story."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17.-- Columbia borrowed Jane Withers from Twentieth-Century Fox today to play opposite Jackie Cooper in "Her First Beau," formerly "June Mad," an unproduced play by Florence Ryerson and Colin Clement. Cooper was borrowed from Paramount, and Columbia also obtained from that studio the services of ...

The $1,500,000 of 3 per cent debentures of National Oil Products Company will be offered to the public at 101, and the 35,965 shares of common stock, both to stockholders and to the public, will be priced at...

CINCINNATI, Dec. 17 (AP)--A blast which destroyed an old downtown tenement house before dawn today killed thirteen men, women and children, among them a baby born to Mrs. Lillian Schnetzer, 42, while she lay buried in wreckage. Mrs. Schnetzer, her husband, Frank, and four other children in the family also perished.

Any move by the Nazis to take over unoccupied France as a result of the ousting of Pierre Laval from the Vichy government will "solidify" the French Empire, including French North Africa, which is under the command of General Maxime Weygand, and will produce a...

A movement to strip Kenneth F. Simpson of most of his powers as New York County Republican chairman, including the right to speak for the county in conference with other county and State leaders, was started yesterday. It came after the county committee had repudiated by a vote of 2,445 to 1,163 his plan to replace David B. Costuma as a Commissioner of Elections with Gabriel L. Kaplan.

LONDON, Dec. 17--For the first time since June, dealings took place in transatlantic securities today in the stock markets. There was a brisk business in Canadian Pacific common, Brazil Traction, International Nickel and British-controlled...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The thirty-seventh anniversary of the airplane flight of the Wright Brothers at Kitty Hawk, N.C., was celebrated today in several observances.

Walker L. Trammell, member of the Deepdale Country Club on Long Island, last night was elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association for 1941. He succeeds Max B. Kaesche of the Ridgewood Club of New Jersey.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 (AP)--Federal Judge Robert N. Wilkin approved today the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan for reorganization of the Erie Railroad.
LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 18-- Nazi airmen baffled millions in this country this morning and last night by failing to show up on their hitherto regular nighttime bombing attacks.

New York University's veteran basketball team, generally regarded as the class of the city, had to go all out to pass its first major test last night as the Violets turned back Brooklyn College, 40--39, before more than 2,000 spectators at...

Production of crude oil in the United States last week averaged 3,578,950 barrels daily, a decrease of 33,650 from the 3,612,600 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 18,950 barrels more than...

LONDON, Dec. 17--A 42-year-old housewife, short, dark and wearing glasses, was sentenced to death this afternoon at the Hampshire assizes in Winchester after a secret trial. She was convicted of drawing a map within a restricted area, cutting a military telephone line and having in her possession questionable documents.

Bishop Cameron J. Davis of Buffalo was elected president of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church at the annual meeting of the trustees yesterday in the fund office, 20 Exchange Place. He succeeds William Fellowes Morgan Sr., who will remain as a trustee.

Mrs. A. Willing Ribblesdale gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. David K. E. Bruce, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rogers Winthrop, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Huntington Astor, Baron Le Jeune and Lauder Greenway.

THERE have been too many loose words, both written and spoken, flying around for more than a week since the massacre of the Redskins by the Bears in the pro football play-off. The subject should have exhausted itself long ago, but it seems that skeptics still are waylaying observers of the scalping with variations of "was it really on the level?"

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Wednesday, Dec. 18--German troops are in Italy, it was learned here today. German troop concentrations at Bari and Naples were reliably reported this morning. The troops were said to be accompanied by huge quantities of war materiel.
The East Side was well represented in the realty trading announced yesterday, with several properties in Murray Hill and East Harlem going into new hands. Two of the deals involved all-cash payments.

The progress of the armament program has been leading to the rapid education of the American public--and this includes Congressmen and governmental officials--in some basic economic facts and principles. In its first and most naive stage Washington thought it had done its duty when it voted huge sums for defense; when it...

LONDON, Dec. 17--Reports received here tonight that President Roosevelt was planning to lease or mortgage war equipment to Britain aroused a favorable reaction in political circles here. The proposal was said to be a practical scheme for economic cooperation whereby the United States might play a tangible part in the fight for democracy without involving itself in war.
Mrs. Ellwood Beatty of Philadelphia was responsible for the first major upset of the Dorothy Gray women's invitation squash racquets handicap tournament when she eliminated Mrs. Stewart Iglehart,...

The United States can become the "workshop" of the world and assure itself of more than a century of leadership in export trade if we follow a consistent program of Latin-American development, Phillips R. Nelson, vice president of Ruffner McDowell Burch, Inc.,...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Contracts calling for construction as soon as possible of forty more destroyers than were previously contemplated have been signed by the Navy Department. They increase to 365 the number of such naval units either afloat or projected.

Columbia's football team of 1940 came together once more last night when the men who gave the Blue and White a record of five victories, two defeats and two ties were honored by a gathering of 250 persons at the first annual Columbia...

Daniel M. Alperin of Textile High School was re-elected president of the high schools games committee at that body's monthly meeting held at the Hotel Astor yesterday. Other officers chosen to continue in office...
Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, city head of the Selective Service Administration, voiced another warning yesterday against expecting blanket deferments covering specialized groups of men in any field.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17--Scattered liquidation and a little pressure from professional traders dropped wheat prices a small fraction of a cent a bushel in the early trading today, but a rally got under way later which disclosed a lack of...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Harry Bridges, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, arrived here today by plane from the West Coast to appear before the C.I.O.'s appeals committee tomorrow in connection with a jurisdictional dispute with the United Retail and Wholesale Clerks Union.

Dr. Robert P. Wadhams, Professor of Clinical Surgery at the New York University College of Medicine since 1933, died Monday evening after a heart attack in his home at the Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue. He was 61 years old.

More than twenty paintings from the John F. Braun collection of American art have been placed on view at the Douthitt Galleries, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, where they will continue to be shown until Feb. 1. Mr. Braun, widely known as a collector and as a patron of music, died in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Several hours before President Roosevelt disclosed the outlines of his new scheme for continuing aid to Britain, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, told a House appropriations subcommittee that British Treasury officials had warned that their nation could not...

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 17--The Duke of Windsor would accept the post of British Ambassador to the United States if he was appointed, he said this evening just before sailing for Nassau with the American-born Duchess on the yacht Southern Cross.

J. Stirling Getchell, founder and head of the advertising firm of his name, with offices in the Chrysler Building, died yesterday afternoon in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center of a streptococcus infection which developed last March. He was 41 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--President Roosevelt revealed today that he was considering a plan for the United States to finance production in this country of armaments and munitions for Great Britain, these to be either lent or sold on a mortgage basis.

On the basis of using 10,000 lines yearly, one line of national advertising copy in 209 daily and Sunday newspapers in cities of 25,000 to 50,000 population will cost the advertiser nearly one-third more than...

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 17-- Charles Arthur Reed, former State Senator and a practicing lawyer in New Jersey for more than fifty years, died here today at the Park Hotel after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 17--Wang Ching-wei's new Nanking "government," together with its sponsoring Japanese authorities, is facing a financial crisis. Chinese bankers and financiers are refusing to cooperate with the new "government" as long as Mr. Wang controls and directs the financial structure of the new "government."

The Massachusetts type of compulsory automobile liability insurance law versus the New Hampshire "persuasive" type was debated yes terday at a public hearing held by the Joint Legislative Committee on Recodification of the Insurance Law at the State Office Building on a mandatory measure proposed for this State.

President Roosevelt announced yesterday that his Administration was considering several ways of increasing aid to Britain. One of these, he said, would be American financing of armaments and the lending of them to Britain or their sale on a mortgage basis, with the British returning or replacing such materiel after the war.

A substantial number of voters-- nearly one half--favors the idea of training women now for wartime work, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

Columbia University's Christmas festivities will begin this afternoon at 5 o'clock when Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, officiates at the lighting of the Yule log in the lounge of John Jay Hall, men's dormitory. Dr. Butler will greet Columbia College students and their guests, who will hold a tea dance after the traditional ceremony.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES in Libya, Dee. 17 (AP)--Fresh Australian troops, chafing to get into battle with the Italians, pressed on toward the Libyan base of Bardia today at such a pace that one of their commanders complained, "We can't hold them back."

ROME, Dec. 17-Rome passed a day of high excitement and hope today which was rudely ended by the official Italian war bulletin and warnings in the evening newspapers and radio not to believe rumors whether they were optimistic or pessimistic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The request of the Princess Stefanie Hohenlohe Waldenburg-Schillingsfurst for a renewal of her temporary visitor's permit has been denied, and unless she leaves the United States by next Saturday deportation proceedings will be started, the Department of Justice said today.
All employes of Lord Thomas earning less than $5,000 a year will receive a Christmas bonus of a half month's salary, Edward Lasker, first vice president and general manager, announced yesterday.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 17-- Trainees from the Seventy-first, 174th and 113th Regiments took a long stride today on their road to becoming soldiers. They spent the day on the rifle range, firing Army Springfields for the first time and had their first meal in the field. Although most of the men had not handled a gun until a week ago...

An event expected to have farreaching results in the ski world will start Saturday and continue through Tuesday at Lake Placid, where Otto (Eugen) Schniebs, former Dartmouth coach and founder of the American Ski School, will...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17--The Army Quartermaster opened bids today on 1,350,000 yards of 36-inch wind-resistant poplin cloth, and six bidders offered a total of 2,469,000 yards at prices ranging from 50.25 to 55.32 cents per yard.

This country may have to decide within a week or ten days what it is going to do about the war in Europe, Clare Boothe, playwright and wife of Henry Luce, publisher, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel St. Regis given by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the British War Relief Society.

Representatives of leading banks in the New York Federal Reserve District met yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and formulated plans to increase the assistance of banks in this district in financing national defense.

Details of the consent decree settling the major issues in the radio music row are expected to be completed today in Washington when Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti and Milton Diamond, serving as counsel to the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, confer with officials of the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice, it was learned here yesterday.

Full floor units and stores were taken in many of the business leasing transactions reported yesterday. A firm of European art dealers joined the art center in the East Fifties, and several restaurant enterprises contracted for street floor space.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced yesterday, in a statement of operations covering the first eleven months of the current year, a net profit of $7,295,920 after Federal income taxes and estimated excess profits taxes and other charges.

The specifications for three more apartment projects, two in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn, were filed yesterday. The former two are to rise on Bennett Avenue, and the cost is estimated at $310,000 each, while the Brooklyn building is to...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)--The government has directed that 300 Nazi sailors who escaped from the German liner Columbus after her crew had scuttled her be transfered from Angel Island in San Francisco Bay to an abandoned CCC camp near Fort Stanton, N.M.

LONDON, Dec. 17--Lord NoelBuxton, Laborite, in the House of Lords today tried to tie down the government to making a statement on suggestions purporting to be aimed at terms of peace made to Great Britain by the German Government since the entry of Italy into the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Early action by the Prorities Board of the National Defense Advisory Commission to permit resumption of deliveries of airplanes to civil air lines is expected in informed quarters. A decision as early as tomorrow is probable.

LONDON, Dec. 17--British merchant shipping has had a bad time lately, for figures released today by the Admiralty show that in the two-week period ended Dec. 8, 182,848 tons of merchant shipping was sunk.

Dr. Elias Lieberman, associate superintendent of the New York City school system, has been elected president of the Associate Alumni of City College for 1941, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dr. Henry Neumann, president of the Brooklyn Ethical Cultural Society.

In two reports on the Board of Elections Commissioner of Investigation Herlands has shown the continuance in that bipartisan body of the amicable division of the spoils that so long characterized the relations of the two major parties in this city. Nevertheless, having transacted their business according to the rules, the four Commissioners were recommended for reappointment...

A very interesting feature of the concert given by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was the singing of excerpts from Louis Gruenberg's "Emperor Jones" and Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" by Paul Robeson, the Negro actor and singer, whose reputation has gone far in both musical and dramatic fields.

Melio Bettina of Beacon, N.Y., a former light heavyweight champion, successfully launched his campaign for recognition as a challenger for the title he once held last night at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn,...

Murray Gabaeff, who, according to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, knows the whereabouts of three fugitive leaders in the racket of shaking down retail milk dealers, was committed yesterday by Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions to the House of Detention, in default of $20,000 bail, as a material witness. The high bail was fixed at the request of Assistant...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, with the approval of the C.I.O.'s six vice presidents, today put the blame of the lagging defense program on the shoulders of industry.
Daniel J. Lyon, president of the Stock Exchange in Valparaiso, Chile, and his son, Daniel Lyon Jr., were guests yesterday of William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange.

The extent of the astounding British triumph in Egypt can be measured only in relation to the fears that were openly expressed in London three months ago. At that time the British were afraid that they might lose the Suez Canal, and Mr. Churchill himself hinted that Hitler might yet stand "at the gates of India" before losing the...

Vigorous opposition to any permanent subsidy on cotton to writing paper manufacturers by the Department of Agriculture was expressed yesterday by Charles M. Haskins, managing director of the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, Inc., in a brief filed with the department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--What the President did today, when he outlined one suggested plan for full aid to Great Britain that is under consideration, was to put all accent on materiel instead of money. Mr. Roosevelt said it is armament and not money by which wars are lost or won.

Mayor La Guardia summoned City Hall reporters to his office at 5 P.M. yesterday and rebuked all of them for a story in an afternoon newspaper that reported confusion in the handling of milk under the new plan to provide a pint a day for every child under 16 in home relief families.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Dec. 17--Repelling simulated attacks by dive bombers and a tank were part of the day's work for the 105th Infantry today. The tank, being made of paper, succumbed to a mild dose of 22-caliber bullets from the anti-tank platoon at a range of 1,000 inches.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 16-- The largest industrial X-ray unit in the world, which can look into metals and detect their inner structures with a speed forty times faster than any apparatus of its kind now in existence, was demonstrated today before a distinguished group of scientists and industrialists. It will be put to work at once in the service of the national defense as a super-detective of possible hidden flaws.

The government's presentation of evidence against Howard C. Hopson and his two lawyer co-defendants virtually was ended in Federal court yesterday after six weeks of testimony. During the day a witness placed the cost to the Associated Gas and Electric system of the frauds attributed to Hopson at $19,519,792.

Whether Billy Jurges will be able to resume his shortstop job with the Giants next year still is an open question. But today there is more reason for optimism about his baseball future than at any time since he was hit in the head by a Bucky Walters pitch on June 23 at the Polo Grounds.

The people of this city seem to have developed a definite instinct about subways. Any visitor to our newest one, below Sixth Avenue, can testify that it is not easy to navigate these bewildering inter-burrows with any certainty of arriving at a specified destination.
