BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 17-- Otto Abetz, Reich High Commissioner in Paris, who went to Vichy yesterday seeking information on the events leading up to the present political situation, has left the French capital for Paris to report to his superiors.
Although the Yankees tumbled quite a distance from their once lordly estate, there was still no stopping their ace performer, Joe DiMaggio, in the 1940 American League pennant campaign.

The directors of the Todd Shipyards Corporation authorized yesterday a dividend of $2.50 a share. This year-end declaration will increase 1940 dividend distribution to $8 a share. In 1939 stockholders received a total of $2.50 in dividends.

Ten "rolling soup wagons," or mobile kitchens, consigned to Britain for the use of civilian populations in bombed areas, were inspected by Mayor La Guardia and blessed by Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday morning.

Miss Phyllis Bertrand Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bertrand Wright, was married yesterday afternoon to Lancelot Warwick Armstrong 3d in the home of her parents at 1120 Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis A. McQuade of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.
Considerable end-of-the-year sales activity in Brooklyn was indicated by reports received yesterday from brokers operating in that borough.
The most important current trend in sports is the increasing emphasis on offense in football, declared the sports writers of the country in replying to the annual Associated Press poll.

Paced by Johnny Kravetz, who tallied 22 points, Manhattan's basketball team breezed to a 42-to-28 victory over St. Peter's last night at the Kelly-Green Gymnasium, before 700 spectators. It was the Jaspers' fourth straight triumph.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, declared in an address at Columbia University last night that "a group of appeasers in the making" had appeared in the United States. He said that the group consisted of isolationists, Nazi sympathizers, "soft sentimentalists" and profit-seeking business men who would sacrifice preparedness to "business as usual."

Events tonight: "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Down Town Glee Club, Channing Lefebvre, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Farbman String Symphonietta, Harry Farbman, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30; Greenwich House String Orchestra, with Ruth Levine, soprano, as soloist,...

Sammy Baugh of Washington and Davey O'Brien of Philadelphia, each of whom established three new records, were the leading forward passers in the National Football League during the 1940 campaign, according to the final official statistics released yesterday.

VICHY, France, Dec. 17--Following the visit to Vichy of Otto Abetz, German High Commissioner in Paris, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today received former Vice Premier Pierre Laval, whose dismissal from the Vichy Cabinet was announced Saturday night.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17--Britain's army in Africa reported today the capture of three more Italian frontier forts and rolled on toward the important Fascist base of Bardia in the counter-invasion of Italian Libya.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave the first State reception of the season, entertaining in honor of the Judiciary. Before the reception they gave a dinner for the ranking honor guests, the Chief Justice and Mrs. Charles E. Hughes and Attorney General and Mrs. Robert H. Jackson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 14 were 1 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year and in the four-weeks period ended Dec. 14 were 4 per cent higher than for the similar period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--A contract for airplane propellers headed a list of contract awards totaling almost $100,000,000 made today by the War Department as it continued the expansion of its operations in the defense program.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20--Frank J. Wetzel, a director of the Pennsylvania Railroad since 1928 and prominent in banking, business and civic affairs here for many years, died tonight at his home after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
LONDON, Dec. 20--The stock markets again were very quiet today but toward the close the tone was brighter.

The metropolitan senior A.A.U. indoor track and field championships, left up in the air by the New York State ruling against the use of armories for other than military purposes, were set yesterday for the New York Coliseum in the Bronx on the night of Saturday, Jan. 18.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Dec. 20--Mrs. Adah Sawyer Gould Skilton, the first woman to climb Mount Popocatepetl in Mexico, having made the ascent in 1874, died here last night at her home. She would have been 92 years of age in another week.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 20--Price reductions as much as 20 per cent on electric ranges and washers and the introduction of a new completely automatic washer were announced today by General Electric Company to New York, New Jersey and New England distributors at the General Electric Institute here.

Changes in New York Stock Exchange member firms, the last which can be made before the new year, have been proposed to the committee on admissions and are printed in the current issue of the weekly bulletin.

Information from travelers from Italy arriving at various points in neutral European countries, as received by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, would seem to lend unofficial confirmation to reports from other capitals of the presence of large numbers of German troops in Italy.

Approximately one-third of the total yardage, some 4,225,000 yards, went to the American Woolen Company.
LONDON, Dec. 20--There was little evidence of Christmas in the streets of England today as the holiday season approaches. Outwardly one would not know that Christmas was coming.
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 20--An explosion early this afternoon in an apartment at 156 Park Avenue, here, disclosed the suicide of Mrs. Florence Brevoort Eickemeyer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 7 was 3,380,620 shares, compared with 3,528,300 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 20--Recall was a welcome bugle sound to the soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division here this afternoon, for it marked the end of training until after the Christmas holidays.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 20 (AP)-- Robert Williams Daniel, State Senator, financier, sportsman and owner of historic Brandon-on-the James, Virginia showplace, died in a Richmond hospital tonight of a circulatory ailment after an illness of eight weeks. His age was 58.

IT'S tally-ho today for Greentree and two days of royal sport in that king of games and game of kings, court tennis. The occasion is unique. There is nothing like it anywhere else in America; probably anywhere else in the world.

Continuing the leisurely trading pace characteristic in the last week or longer, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday 3 to 5 points and then eased, to close unchanged to 1 point net decline. Selling from the South, which came into the market after the run-up before noon, was apparent until the close.

The largest bonus for employes ever distributed by Bonwit Teller was distributed yesterday by William M. Holmes, president of the Fifth Avenue store. The bonus, which this year totals $40,000, was carried out along lines established by the firm in the last few years.

Cap'n Walt Willis, who has just returned from an experiment in Florida, in which he tried to determine whether the ducks there flew as fast as those on Great South Bay, reports that it is almost a dead heat between the two, except that the Southern ducks quack with a drawl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20--The average American family now has 3.8 members, according to a preliminary analysis of the figures from the last census, made public by the Bureau of the Census today. In 1890 the average family numbered 4.9 persons; in 1900, 4.7; in 1910, 4.5; in 1920, 4.3, and in 1930, 4.1 persons.

Recent developments in the knowledge of the electrical properties of plastics and other compounds that are constantly becoming more important as substitutes for rubber and other natural products were described yesterday at the fifth annual symposium of the division of physical and inorganic chemistry of the American Chemical Society at Columbia University.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 30--A resolution opposing conscription, which condemned "the elements of reaction found in conscript Army camps," was unanimously adopted by the National Youth Anti-War Congress in its final session today.

The row between the nation's broadcasters and songwriters will reach its climax at midnight tonight when 648 stations throughout the country ban the vast catalogue of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, embracing most of the music written in the last fifty-six years.
FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 30--Officers and enlisted men of the Fortyfourth Division remaining in camp tomorrow evening prepared today to celebrate arrival of the New Year in proper fashion.

LONDON, Dec. 30--Standing amid the ruins littering the ancient "City" of London after German bombs had all but wrecked it, Prime Minister Winston Churchill today snapped a grim rebuke to a woman who shouted, "What about peace?"

James B. Schafer, leader of the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians, appeared voluntarily yesterday before Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall of the State Bureau of Securities, 80 Center Street, who questioned him for two hours regarding the financial affairs of his organization.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, political foe of President Roosevelt for years, gave "hearty approval" yesterday to the President's address calling for a policy of "dynamic non-belligerence" and greater aid to Britain.

London's famous Guildhall, or Council Hall of the Corporation of the City of London, destroyed by fire set by Nazi incendiary bombs Sunday night, was originally built in the period from 1411 to 1439 for the sittings of the magistrates and municipal corporation.

Speculation on the filling of various college coaching posts attracted close attention from most of those who attended the session of the American Football Coaches Association yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 31-- President Roosevelt's speech Sunday night has overshadowed the Nazis' fire raid on London the same night as a topic of conversation. This is not a generalization but the sum of reports of official "morale tasters."
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP)--Boston theatregoers viewed premiere performances tonight of two shows which starred actresses returning to the field which brought them their first successes.

Eager to avoid overtraining, Tami Mauriello, young Bronx middleweight star, yesterday confined himself to a short sparring session in preparation for his ten-round battle Friday night against Billy Soose of Farrell, Pa., in Madison Square Garden.
Business in 1941 probably will be better than in the several years preceding, J.M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30-- Merle Oberon will play the feminine lead in "Affectionately Yours," a scenario by Edward Kaufman from a story by Aleen Leslie and Fanya Foss, Warner Brothers announced today. The picture will go before the cameras Monday with Dennis Morgan playing opposite Miss Oberon and Lloyd Bacon directing.

President Roosevelt, reported greatly encouraged by the reaction to his address Sunday night, talked for more than an hour at the White House yesterday with Arthur B. Purvis, head of the British War Purchasing Commission in the United States.
Among those reported yesterday as having taken apartment space was Gilbert Seldes, writer, who leased quarters in the oHtel Alrae, 37 East Sixty-fourth Street, through Talman Bigelow, Inc., brokers.
The 1940 Neediest Cases Fund received $3,526 yesterday from ninetynine contributors, bringing its total on this last day of the old year to $216,244.74.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 31--London was free of aerial raiders last night and early today after Sunday night's unprecedented assault, in which fires ruined countless historic landmarks and less famous structures in what the British officially charged was a "deliberate attempt" by German bombers to wipe out the ancient City district.

Fencing was added to the roster of National Collegiate Athletic Association championships yesterday as members of the organization's executive committee held a special meeting at the Hotel New Yorker and approved the dates and places for ten title competitions during 1941.

Twenty-one officers and members of the crew of the American Pioneer Line freighter City of Rayville, which sank the night of Nov. 8 six miles off Cape Otway, Victoria, Australia, after an explosion believed to have been caused by a nine, testified yesterday that they had seen no evidences of " unAmerican activities" aboard the ship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Sales of wholesalers, based on reports from 2,793 concerns in all parts of the country, were 7 per cent greater in November than during the corresponding month of last year, it was announced today by the Census Bureau.

BUFFALO, Dec. 30 (AP)--Norton Lowrey Upson, pioneer oil producer, Civil War veteran and a campaigner under General George Custer against Indians, died yesterday of a heart attack in the home of his son, Henry T. Upson, president of the Pease Oil Company. His age was 93.

The Rev. Dr. Dwight Witherspoon Wylie, pastor emeritus of Central Presbyterian Church, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Regent Nursing Home, l15 East Sixty-first Street, where he had been taken alter having been stricken an hour earlier on a Lexington Avenue bus.

BERLIN, Dec. 30--Authoritative German reaction to President Roosevelt's broadcast was not forthcoming tonight. From what few hints were available it appeared likely that further time would be spent in careful study of the President's utterances before Berlin took a definitive stand.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30 (AP)-- A surprisingly strong Princeton University team beat off a desperate Michigan rally tonight to defeat the Wolverines, 30 to 29, in an intersectional basketball game.
ROME, Dec. 30--President Roosevelt's speech has done nothing fundamental to aggravate Italo-American relations, judging from the first reactions to it today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--In next to their last assembling in the longest Congressional session on record both House and Senate met per functorily today to go through the motions required by the Constitution--that neither House can recess for more than three days without consent of the other.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 30--The Sun will print tomorrow morning the following dispatch from Paul W. Ward of its Washington Bureau:

He had retired ten years ago. During the World War he served as lieutenant colonel and military assistant to Benedict Crowell, Assistant Secretary of War.

Purchases by operators on Eighth Avenue and on the parkside continuation of that artery, Central Park West, and the acquisition of vacant land by builders who plan to erect three six-story apartments featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Monte of 123 East Thirty-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss May Clementine Monte, to Cadet James Matthew McLaughlin, son of the late Mr. and Mrs, Joseph I. McLaughlin of Boston, Mass.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30--The heavy work is over, and only one more light practice tomorrow confronts the Boston College and Tennessee football players until their Sugar Bowl meeting before 73,000 on Wednesday. The Eagles drilled today at Bay St. Louis, Miss., and the Vols at Edgewater Park, Miss., both points on the Gulf, but these were little more than tune-up sessions.

Pleased by Christmas trade results and optimistic regarding prospects for the coming year, the vanguard of merchants began to arrive in the wholesale markets here yesterday to fill in stocks for January selling and to place commitments for some Spring marchandise.

ALBANY, Dec. 30--Details of the State printing inquiry started last Spring were disclosed today by Frederick E. Crane, Moreland Commissioner, and Bernard Botein, counsel to the commissioner, in a final report presented to Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--An average rate of return of 2.8 per cent on stockholders' investment in seven cane-sugar refining corporations which turn out 71.5 per cent of the products of this industry is shown by a report by the Federal Trade Commission today. The rate was after provision for income taxes.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $13,235,075 for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, compared with a net of $13,232,865 in the corresponding period a year ago.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30--Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Guest, who leave tomorrow for a few days in Washington, were guests of honor of the Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest at a dinner at Villa Artemis tonight. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Gene Tunney, Mr. and Mrs. Howell Van Gerbig, Mrs. Henry Dunsmeure, Mrs. Diana Guest and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30-Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 14 was 4,578,980 shares, compared with 3,380,620 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP)--The C.I.O.'s United Auto Workers announced tonight that a strike had been authorized in the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln plant. The organization alleged that Ford intended to ignore a rehiring agreement and asked the Department of Labor to intervene.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30--It was with the feeling that they are already doing their full duty air Americans and as members of the British Commonwealth that Canadians of all classes listened last evening to President Roosevelt's appeal to his countrymen to take heed for that "American civilization which has never before been in such danger as now."

Football fatalities are on the decrease, according to a report by Dr. Mal Stevens, N.Y.U. coach, and Professor Floyd Eastwood of Purdue, presented yesterday before the American Football Coaches Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 31-- Heavy bombers of the Middle East Command of the British Royal Air Force carried out a raid on Naples Sunday night, according to an Air Ministry summary of reports from Cairo yesterday.

Peter J. McGarry, former State Senator, Assemblyman and Sheriff of Queens County, died on Sunday at his home, 425 Beach 138th street, Belle Harbor, Queens, after an illness of four days. He was 69 years old.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30--Undismayed by this morning's reports that central London was a mass of flames following Nazi attacks with incendiary bombs, Air Chief Marshal Sir Hugh Dowding, who reached Ottawa today, told newspaper men confidently that "by the Spring we shall have taken the sting out of night bombing."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 30-- With Germany pouring soldiers into Rumania at top speed, Hungary called more men to her army today in what some circles viewed as another phase of the vast Nazi preparations for war or any other outbreak in the Balkans.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30--In recognition of her clinical research work on the control of cancer, Dr. Catharine Macfarlane, Professor of Gynecology in the Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania, received today the annual Gimbel award, given to the woman whose services were adjudged to have helped Philadelphia most in the year.

ATHENS, Dec. 30 (U.P.)--Crowds in the streets of Athens today cheered President Roosevelt's speech as proof that "America will never let us down!" and officials said it had fired the Greek people with new confidence of a final victory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Continental Air Lines, Inc., filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 100,000 shames of common stock, $1.25 par value.

Operating utility properties of the Standard Gas and Electric Company system will spend approximately $53,807,000 on new construction and plant expansions in 1941, according to an announcement yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of standard's board and president of the concern.
Long Island University won, but St. John's lost, as the holiday program of intersectional college basketball games was concluded before 17,082 persons at Madison Square Garden last night.

Two educational promotions have been scheduled by the American Meat Institute to run in newspapers and magazines during January. The first will feature the presence in meat of B-group vitamins and other essentials, including compete proteins and iron, copper and phosphorous, while the second has been designed to push sales of bacon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Adopting the thesis that America should solve its own problems before undertaking to settle those of other powers, Senator Burton K. The New York Americans will undertake tonight in Madison Square Garden to see the old year out in approved fashion. Red Dutton's skaters are to tackle the Canadiens for the fourth time in the National Hockey League campaign, ...

Plans for the transportation of 1,000 Jewe fro mwhat was formerly Lithuania to Palestine via Siberia, Japan and India have been completed by the United Palestine Appeal, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, national chairman of the appeal, The cost will be $175,000.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30-- Walter Lee Taylor, with just one winner at Tropical Park today, ran his year's total to 286 in a long-distance duel with Earl Dew for the 1940 American riding championship. The jockeys started the day all square at 285 each, and they remained tied going into the final day, for Dew also rode one victor at Santa Anita Park, Arcadia, Calif.

Because of a reduced home relief load the biennial appropriation voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate for the first half of 1941 showed a drop of $1,362,666 from the preceding six-month allotment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30--Henry F. Grady, one of the key figures in the reciprocal trade agreements program, resigned as Assistant Secretary of State today and will assume the presidency of the American President Lines in San Francisco.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30--You will have to follow this closely or else you will get com pletely lost. This is a tale from the Sugar Bowl city about the Rose Bowl exploits of Sleepy Jim Crowley, who is today awaiting the Cotton Bowl game in Dallas.

And so to bat, with many thanks to the fellows who filled this space while this regular borer-from-within was trying to track down burrowing owls in the Arizona desert with Clarence Budington Kelland, who used to be a golfer but put away his clubs and is now leading a better life.

It is the season when colleges publish lists of outstanding students. Medals and scrolls of honor -- and in Britain titles and other awards -- are bestowed on outstanding citizens in many walks of life.

New York City's 280 local Selective Service Boards must be prepared to furnish 66,651 men for military service by June 30, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, city director of selective service, announced yesterday. In giving the quota for each board up to the end of next June, Colonel McDermott said that this knowledge would permit the boards to plan activities ahead.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 -- Details were telephoned tonight from Slovenia of the appearance of German troops in southern Hungary, near the Yugoslav frontier. More than two divisions of German troops also are reported in the Rumanian Banat, along the Yugoslav frontier, and east of Turnu-Severin, opposite the North Serbian bank of the Danube.

Work is to begin within a few weeks on a face-lifting operation for Coney Island that will involve expansion of the beachfront, extension of the Boardwalk and the replacement of the present dark brown, dirty looking sand with new white sand, it was announced yesterday at the Park Department.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- In the midst of a serious world situation, officials of the Government were able today to summarize these definite advances within a year toward the goal of total defense:

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- Vice President-elect Henry A. Wallace on his return to Mexico City today called on President Manuel Avila Camacho and other members of the government to say farewells. He intends to start for the United States by automobile before the end of the week.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers today petitioned the National Labor Relations Board for a collective bargaining election at the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln car plant, where the union alleges discriminatory discharge of members.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- Testimony that Daniel Gimbel, department store executive, was entirely competent when he executed his will, disposing of a $3,800,000 estate, was, given at a contest hearing today by Joseph S. Conwell Sr., Mr. Gimbel's personal attorney, and Joseph S. Conwell Jr., his son, who is also a member of the bar.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 31 -- Known throughout the country for its Summer appeal, the State of Maine has taken full cognizance of its Winter sports prospects, particularly in the feild of skiing, and is prepared for a record-breaking snow and ice season in 1941.
ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Lawrence W. Cramer, who recently resigned as Governor of the Virgin Islands, suffered serious injuries today in a fall over a twenty-foot embankment.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- America has today the potential ability to build the world's most powerful type of fighting plane, one which would make obsolete both our own and all current European types, Dr. Jerome C. Hunsaker, head of the Aeronautical Engineering Department of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

About 5,000 Twenty-seventh Division men ending their Christmas furloughs left for Fort McClellan, Ala., yesterday with many of them speculating on how soon world conditions would permit them to benefit from another mass leave period. Mothers, wives and sweethearts crowded the Pennsylvania Station to see them off.

With the volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month shrinking to the second smallest for any December in nineteen years, the stock market ended its poorest business year since 1921 and its second dullest since 1918.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 31 (AP) --Western Reserve University of Cleveland and Arizona State Teachers of Tempe put the finishing touches on the timing of their offensive plays today for tomorrow's sixth annual Sun Bowl football game.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- Bearing the distinction of being the only one of the New Year's Day classics presenting unbeaten teams, the Sugar Bowl will send Tennessee against Boston College tomorrow before a capacity gathering of 73,000 spectators.

Protestant clergymen and laymen of the editorial board of The Protestant Digest challenged yesterday the reported assertion of Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh that Protestantism as a Christian influence in the United States was almost dead.

ATHENS, Wednesday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Greek Army pounced on enemy reinforcements and captured 500 prisoners in dislodging Italians from heights near the key town of Klisura, in Central Albania, a spokesman declared early today.
DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 31 -- Fordham's long-awaited hour of destiny is near at hand.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will start the new year by abolishing all admission fees. Since the museum moved to its permanent home in Fifth Avenue at Eighty-second Street in 1880, admission fees have been charged on one or more days a week. In late years admission fees of twenty-five cents have been charged on Mondays and Fridays.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Dec. 31 -- The men of the Twenty-seventh Division who have been on furlough began to return today. Many officers and men of the more than 8,500 home for the holidays, not wishing to spend New Year's Eve traveling, came in twenty-four hours ahead of time.

With employment and payrolls at peak and the immediate outlook supporting the continuation of current high levels, the Buick division of General Motors Corporation ended the year with a record output of 311,403 cars, Harlow H. Curtice, president and general manager, said yesterday.

Gains in all forms of group insurance protection carrying employer-employe plans to record levels were announced yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in releasing the annual group honor roll.

Edward S. Finegan, son of the late Justice James E. Finegan of Special Sessions, denied that his father had been "kicked downstairs" from the Municipal Civil Service Commission in a letter to Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday at City Hall.

The bulk of music written in the last half century was withdrawn last midnight from three-quarters of the nation's radio stations, including the three major networks. As the old year passed, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the National Association of Broadcasters formally severed contractual relations and prepared to do battle with words and lawsuits over the method and amount of future payment for songs heard on the air.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- Italy turns the New Year with a good deal of her attention centered on Washington, waiting to see what policy President Roosevelt is going to announce in his message to Congress. Meanwhile, the President's anti-Axis speech is being officially ignored.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- A private ball was given tonight at the Hotel Bellevue-Stratford by Honorary Captain Effingham B. Morris Jr., Honorary Andrew E. Porter and Mrs. Porter, Honorary Edmund Thayer and Mrs. Thayer and Honorary R. Ellison Thompson and Mrs. Thompson for the active roll of the First Troop Philadelphia City Cavalry, which has served the United States in all wars since before the Revolution.

The National Maritime Union, a tC.I.O. affiliate, announced yesterday that for the first time in the history of American labor it would seek to organize all seamen on foreign-flag ships operating as subsidiaries of American concerns.

Although the backlogs of orders of steel companies are extremely large, unwarranted conclusions have been drawn from that fact, according to Iron Age. "A great deal of the material on order is not wanted until the last half of the year, or even as far away as 1942," it says.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Among those who received baronetcies in King George's New Year honors list, issued today were Sir William Coxen, former Lord Mayor of London who raised 5,000,000 pounds sterling for war charities and Hugh Lett, president of the Royal College of Surgeons.

Reflecting a sharp gain in corporate earnings, a larger total of dividends went to shareholders in the last twelve months than in any calendar year since 1937. Many special payments authorized in the last two months of 1940 raised the total of dividends declared to $3,927,629,933, compared with $3,566,061,025 in 1939; $3,241,586,078 in 1938, and $4,550,460,671 in 1937.

The city's fiscal experts find it necessary every now and then to trim Park Department appropriations, along with allotments for other departments, in the interests of economy, but Park Commissioner Moses generally manages to salvage something tangible in the interests of our recreation-seeking millions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Festoons of laurel adorned the orange gardens and dining hall of the Everglades Club for the traditional dinner dance with which members welcomed the New Year. Guests entered through a corridor of blossoming poinsettias.

In a review of realty trading in the Scarsdale section of Westchester County during 1940, the Scarsdale Realty Board yesterday reported that residential sales during the year were the highest in several years.

Security and commodity marts generally will be closed today throughout the nation and the world. A hopeful sign of the season here is that the different exchanges appear to be fitting into the regulatory scheme of things, although much remains to be discussed with the Securities and Exchange Commission as to the minutiae of rules.
H.O. (Fritz) Crisler of Michigan was elected president of the American Football Coaches Association in the final session of the organization yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3l -- Sale of The Evening Public Ledger, effective tomorrow, by the trustees of the Cyrus H.K. Curtis estate to a company headed by Robert Cresswell, former treasurer of The New York Herald Tribune, was announced at The Ledger offices tonight.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31 -- In a New Year's message delivered over the radio to the Mexican nation this evening President Manuel Avila Camacho urged his countrymen to reflect upon the blessings of peace that they enjoy and to pray for a prompt ending of "all conflicts."

Dean Christian Gauss, chairman of Princeton University's council on athletics, yesterday urged the end of athletic scholarships and branded those who receive board, room and tuition as "professionals." The occasion of Dean Gauss's remarks was a luncheon of the National Collegiate Athletic Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Eight of the more important machine-tool manufacturers in the United States had combined sales of $79,045,896 in 1939, or slightly over 36 per cent of the total value of machine tools manufactured in that year, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

An appeal for the United States to expedite the sale of needed merchantmen to Great Britain from the expanding American merchant marine was voiced here yesterday by Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire in a statement released through William Allen White's Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 31 -- The appointment of Dr. Edgerton M. Howard of Cambridge as an assistant on the medical staff of the Austen Riggs Foundation, effective early in January, was announced today by the Austen Riggs Associates.

Patrolman Joseph Reinis of the Simpson Street station, the Bronx, swam about 200 feet in the chilly water of the East River yesterday to rescue a 15-year-old boy who was clinging to a stake in the river after a canvas boat in which he and another boy had set out had collapsed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- Leaders of American scientific thought, representing nearly 1,000,000 members of societies affiliated with the American Association for the Advancement of Science, moved today to do their part in trying to save democracy from its enemies in most parts of the world.

AS rapidly as possible we are becoming members of a vast construction gang, hired out to build a bomb-proof shelter over England. No goal but the completion of this steel shell has been offered to us by the President or by lesser leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged Food Service Equipment Industry, Inc., of Chicago, its officers and directors, and a number of manufacturers with combining to unlawfully restrict competition in the sale of their products.

Accepting President Roosevelt's declaration that American industry is the "arsenal" of democracy, Walter D. Fuller, in his first act as mew president of the National Association of Manufacturers. called upon the association's 7,000 members yesterday to do "their patriotic best" to speed defense production.

Negotiations between Queens officials and private aviation units looking toward the establishment in Queens of a municipal airport for private fliers were announced yesterday in a letter from Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens to Mayor La Guardia.

Net profit of the National-Standard Company, manufacturer of wire products and steel cables used in the automobile industry, and its Canadian subsidiary amounted to $934,450 for the year ended on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday. The profit, which is after depreciation, foreign-exchange adjustments, Federal and Canadian income and excess-profits taxes, is equal to $3.48 each on 268,340 shares of $10-par-value capital stock.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The first big honors list of the war published tonight -- and in this country they mean a good deal -- reflected the way in which Britain is swinging to a war basis.

The United States must join with the other American republics in a movement to defend democracy by giving all possible aid, "short of engaging in military war," to the peoples fighting in its cause, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in his annual New Year's message as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 1 -- Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison in a broadcast to the nation last night announced that the government is planning to invoke all its compulsory powers to provide fire watchers and incendiary bomb fighters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- In a New Year's greeting to King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy, President Roosevelt expressed the hope that the Italian people may be enabled to enjoy the "blessing of a righteous peace" during the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Separate pledges of cooperation with the government in the national defense emergency were made today by William Green, president of the A.F. of L., and Phillip Murray, president of the C.I.O., in New Year's statements.

About 30,000 persons from out of town will come to New York in January to attend seventy-eight conventions and trade expositions that have been scheduled, C.N. Nichols, executive director of the New York convention and visitors bureau of the Merchants' Association, announced yesterday.

Approving the action of the National Student Federation of America in withdrawing from the American Youth Congress, Murray Plavner, nations director of the National Foundation for American Youth, called on Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday to clarify her position on the Youth Congress and its alleged radical tendencies.

Operating under a voluntary production control program promulgated by Governor Arthur H. James of Pennsylvania in cooperation with the United Mine Workers and the mine operators, the Pennsylvania anthracite industry achieved a reasonable balance between production and demand last year, according to the Anthracite Institute.

George L. Harrison, whose resignation from the presidency of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York became effective as of the close of business yesterday, becomes president and chief executive officer today of the New York Life Insurance Company.
The thousands of bulbs and miles of neon lights in Times Square glittered and blinked down last night on one of the largest and most pleasure-bent crowds that ever greeted a new year.

The forty-seven family apartment house at 254 East Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Sam-Bal Realty Corporation to Henry Kaplan through Feinberg Ehlich, brokers. The structure is on an irregular plot, 100 by 120 feet, and is assessed for $23,000. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

The five-story office and loft building on a plot 50 by 61.6 feet at 74-76 Edison Place, Newark, N.J., was sold by the Howard Savings Institution to the Irving Investment Corporation. Leslie Blau, Inc., were the brokers.

Indications that Latin-American nations have seized upon the idea of building up greater inter-American trade as a result of the European war and are making considerable headway in that direction is seen in reports cabled to the Argentine Information Bureau here yesterday from Buenos Aires. Argentina's

"Break the News," an English film produced and directed by Rene Clair, is the new arrival this morning at the Bryant, Maurice Chevalier, Jack Buchanan and June Knight are featured in the farce, which has music and lyrics by Cole Porter. . . . Columbia's "The Lone Wolf Keeps a Date," the latest in the series, is the new holiday attraction at the Rialto.

Closing the old year with a further rush in the disposal of old business, the Yankees yesterday lopped two more familiar names from their roster as part of the Bronx Bombers' rehabilitation program for 1941.

A very large majority of Americans agree with the President that the Axis powers must be defeated, and many of the millions who listened to his address must have thought, as I did: What can I do to help make this country an "arsenal" for Britain?

VICHY, France, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Authorities reported tonight after a truce along the Mekong frontier serious fighting had been resumed between the forces of French Indo-China and Thailand [Siam], mainly along the northern frontier of Cambodia, where the regular Thai army was engaged.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- More than 3,500 Axis planes were shot down over Great Britain, the surrounding seas and the French coast in 1940, "the year of the greatest air fighting the world has ever known," the British Air Ministry news service announced tonight in a year-end review.
Colonel V. Clement Jenkins, president of the Sixth Avenue Association, presided yesterday during ceremonies marking the completion of a program of landscaping in the new "Village Square."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- Army contracts for the following firms were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today.
BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- President Roosevelt's Sunday broadcast finally drew fire along a wide front today.

SINGAPORE, Wednesday, Jan. 1 -- Five hundred men, women and children who had been landed by German commerce raiders Dec. 21 on Emirau Island, in the Bismarck Archipelago, northeast of New Guinea, have been rescued by an Australian ship and taken to Australia, it was announced officially today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A Presidential veto having nullified the adoption of the Walter-Logan bill by a majority of Congress, those interested in regulating and reforming government by Federal agency and commission have been casting about for proposals to the next Congress which can weather the legislative and executive processes.

Verne Marshall, head of the No Foreign War Committee, hotly repeated yesterday his challenge to the Administration to make public the "agenda" brought to the United States from Germany in October, 1939, by William Rhodes Davis, oil man. This "agenda," Mr. Marshall contended in an interview in Washington on Monday, might have served as the instrument for a White House conference to end the war in Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Lionel Barrymore and Edward Arnold, last seen together in Frank Capra's "You Can't Take It With You" at Columbia, will be reunited by Metro in Martin Berkeley's play "Roosty," which will go before the cameras Thursday, the studio announced today.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Three hundred persons attended one of the gayest New Year's Eve parties held here in years at a costume dance tonight at the Tuxedo Club. Guests included young people from all parts of the metropolitan area and a few cadets from West Point.

The Metropolitan Opera Company seldom presents operas here on Tuesday since that is the evening it generally plays in Philadelphia, but last night it made an exception to its rule and gave a special New Year's Eve performance of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor."

The first of the three long-range Boeing Clippers bought from Pan American Airways by Great Britain probably will be delivered early next month, with the other two following at short intervals, it was learned yesterday. In all probability the planes will be flown to England, but no information as to departure or arrival points or the course to be taken was available.

Adoption of resolutions concerning international sports competition, the amateur code and America's defense, coupled with the election of Professor Philip O. Badger of N.Y.U. as president, high-lighted the closing sessions of the thirty-fifth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association convention yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Roosevelt said today the United States was not negotiating with or planning to ask Eire to throw open in ports and bases to Great Britain as a suggested means of protecting Britain's Atlantic lifeline.

A committee for the promotion of fair trade practices, having as its chief objective the discouragement and elimination of the sale of merchandise below cost by manufacturers, will shortly be appointed by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, it was stated yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union.

Bound for Africa, where they will serve as ambulance drivers with the British Army, seven young Americans, all members of the American Field Service, left La Guardia Field yesterday aboard Miami-bound planes of the Eastern Air Lines. Six of the young men left together on a plane at 10:30 A.M., while the seventh, Oscar C. Sewall of Dublin, N.H., second in command, departed on an afternoon flight.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- The New Year was ushered in tonight with many of the country clubs in Westchester having dinner dances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Completion early in 1941 of some 50,000 units built by public and private agencies to house workers called to man defense industries was predicted today in a report issued by C.F. Palmer, defense housing coordinator of the National Defense Advisory Commission.
Here are the selections in the New Year's Bowl games made by twenty-one prominent coaches attending the American Football Coaches Association convention that ended in New York yesterday:

ROME, Dec. 31 -- The ground was cleared for further rationing in Italy today when the Official Gazette published a decree empowering Minister of Corporations Renato Ricci to control Italian industry and regulate the distribution and consumption of all domestic and imported industrial materials during the war period.

Antoine de Saint Exupery, the 40-year-old French aviator-phisopopher, whose "Wind, Sand and Stars" has been one of the best sellers here, said on his arrival from France yesterday that his country lost the war because French war leaders failed utterly to recognize the nature of modern warfare and because the country was pitifully unable to organize.

Two million boys and girls of school age were active last year in building and flying mode] airplanes, with results of considerable significance to the airplane industry, Winthrop Rockefeller, chairman of Air Youth, said yesterday in a year-end review of the organization's work.

John Steuart Curry's painting, "John Brown," which was shown in last year's annual at the Whitney Museum, is featured in the group exhibition, current until the end of this week, at the Walker Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- An increase of slightly more than 1 per cent in imports into the United States of Mexican oil was authorized by President Roosevelt in a proclamation issued through the State Department today setting the import quotas for crude petroleum and fuel oil during the calendar year 1941 under the reciprocal trade agreement of Nov. 6, 1939, with Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Thirty children ranging in age from Franklin D. Roosevelt 3d, aged 2, to Diana Hopkins, 8-year-old daughter of Harry L. Hopkins, former Secretary of Commerce, took possession of the White House at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- For the first time in more than twenty years the United States Fleet will not engage in large-scale manoeuvres this year. Instead the fleet is being held as a unit in Hawaiian waters and, according to good information, will remain there until the existing international situation is definitely improved.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Thomas L. Wrenn and Albert E. Forster, examiners of the Civil Aeronautics Board, recommended today that American Airlines receive a certificate of convenience and necessity to operate a new air route between Buffalo and Toronto, and that the Trans-Canada Airlines be authorized for flights between Toronto and New York.

The Neediest Cases Fund starts the New Year with $220,017.59 in hand as the result of the receipt yesterday of contributions aggregating $3,772.85 from 197 contributors, who took this way of endeavoring to brighten the coming twelve months for the most unfortunate members of the community.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The Boston Bruins and the New York Rangers enlivened a wide-open National Hockey League battle with three lusty fistic outbreaks as they fought to a 2-2 overtime tie tonight before more than 16,000 at the Boston Garden.

The good and pleasant custom that requires us to be hopeful on the first day of the new year can do harm if it blinds us to unhappy facts or makes us think that we can assure good luck by wishing for it. So today let us face the facts and see what we can do about them.

New low records in infant and puerperal mortality, as well as in death rates from tuberculosis, diphtheria, pneumonia and typhoid fever, were set in New York City during 1940, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, told Mayor La Guardia in his annual report handed to the Mayor at City Hall late yesterday afternoon.

The police were perfectly willing to investigate a bomb scare by sifting coal for more than three hours yesterday. But when they realized that the only way to get to the bottom of dark mystery was to sift coal for thirty-six hours more they decided they could solve the problem in conference.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 31 (AP) Booth Tarkington, the novelist, took a backward glance at 1940 today and expressed the view that democracy, both at home and abroad, would survive the new year. He pictured Great Britain's war effort as one to save free government.

Cow, lamb and fresh pork supplies were normal or more abundant yesterday. Other classes were moderate to light. Demand was fair for beef and veal, slow on lamb, fairly active on pork. Most classes of traefer meats were strong to higher. Demand for kosher meats was slow at the opening, but veal prices were strong and other classes about steady.

"The Hard Way," the first venture of the new producing firm of Allen Boretz and Morris Helprin, will be withdrawn for some tinkering after tonight's performance in Boston, where it started a preparatory engagement on Dec. 26. It had been slated to remain there through Saturday night and open here Jan. 7.

During the past year most of us spent many long days in the field, either hunting or fishing. Some of those days were disappointing, for they failed to produce a full creel or heavy game bag. We have complained, all of us, that things were not as they should be, or could be, during this year that is gone.

VICHY, France, Dec. 31 -- The year ends on a less gloomy note for France than might have been feared five or six weeks ago. Not that the outlook is bright by any means, but the fact remains that its every possibility has now been envisaged with calmness and that the French nation is determined that it must not disappear despite the worst defeat in its history.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 31 -- Two Italian merchantmen were sunk in the Adriatic today by unidentified warships, according to word reaching here.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 31 -- With only 3,400 men of the 18,000 stationed here remaining in camp tonight, a sparsely occupied Fort Dix celebrated the arrival of the New Year with formal and informal parties which were not interrupted by the usual sounding of taps at 11 P.M., and the boys will not have to get up early tomorrow.

ALBANY, Calif., Dec. 31 (UP) -- The $10,000 added New Year's Handicap, opening feature at Golden Gate Park tomorrow, attracted only six horses today as several owners chose to let their stars race in the established Santa Anita feature.

Social progress in many fields in the United States, despite the threatening crisis in Europe, was noted by Dr. Harry W. Laidler, executive director of the League for Industrial Democracy, in a report on political and economic trends during the past year made public yesterday.

As the site for two six-story apartment houses which will contain about 500 rooms, a plot of 38,450 square feet on the south side of West 190th Street, running from Fort Washington Avenue through to Overlook Terrace, has been purchased by a client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- While pre-holiday dullness prevailed in the wheat market today there was an undercurrent of strength. At no time was there any material pressure and spreaders bought the July and sold the May on a fair scale, resulting in the new crop months advancing around 1 cent a bushel from the early low and the finish was near the top for the day with gains of 3/4 cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A proposed executive order has been drafted which would make William S. Knudsen chief of the nation's entire defense program instead of one of the four members of the new Office of Production Management for Defense.

T.J. Carlyle Gifford, special agent of the British Treasury in New York, who since last February has been charged with the responsibility of liquidating British holdings of United States corporate securities, announced yesterday that fifty-seven of the stock issues and eleven of the bond issues have been sold out in their entirety.

A re-endorsement of the current physical education program of the major American colleges, as a means of training the youth of America for a possible national war emergency, was contained yesterday in a report adopted by the College Physical Education Association in its annual meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.
YAPHANK, L.I., Dec. 31 -- With about half of the 2,000 men attached to Camp Upton, here, away on holiday leave, the remainder greeted the New Year with parties at the camp.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Injury to Walter Lee Taylor put a dramatic eleventh-hour end today to the most sensational race in turf history for the American jockey championship.

Julius Brickman, specialist in American Cyanamid Company B stock on the New York Curb Exchange, was suspended yesterday for six months, fined $500 and ordered to pay $75 which a brokerage house customer might have lost through his allegedly irregular handling of the market.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Frank E. Gimlett, 74, whiskered and booted prospector, came from the Colorado Rockies to Washington today to find out what we are going to use for money.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The value of the products of the printing and publishing industry in 1939 amounted to $2,170,968,706, making it one of the first five industries in the nation in value of products, the Department of Commerce made known today.

AIKEN, S.C., Dec. 31 -- The Winter season was inaugurated officially tonight when the annual New Year's Eve masquerade ball was held at the Palmetto Golf Club. Hundreds of colonists arrived this week to attend the event, which was headed by G. Macculloch Miller.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 31 -- Tremendous enthusiasm is shown throughout the Turkish press in its comments today on President Roosevelt's speech, which is called "The Death Sentence on the Axis." Only the Tasviri Efkar has a slightly critical note, saying, "The words are good enough provided they are translated into action."
BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- Today's Boerse closed the year generally firm, with most issues rising fractionally.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- This is Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Year's resolution, and wish, for 1941, as given today by request at her press conference:...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Senator Lee of Oklahoma charged today that the story of the formation of the No Foreign War Committee was a tale of "the diabolically cunning betrayal of the American people." He was referring to a statement by Verne Marshall that William R. Davis, an oil merchant, carried German peace terms to the State Department.

New securities offered to the public here in December aggregated $513,179,000, of which $473,999,000 represented forty-seven bond issues, and $39,180,000 by sixteen stock issues. The flotations of bonds last month were the largest for any month since December, 1936, when $534,637,000 in seventy-one issues were sold.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Fat steer trade was slow today, with prices ranging from weak to 25 cents lower. Most of the loss was on medium to good grades. Hogs were 15-20 cents lower and sheep were steady. Prime steers topped at $15.25, but the bulk sold between $9.50 and $13. Heifers ran counter to the general trend and ruled strong to 25 cents higher, with other classes unchanged.

Tomorrow may be just the second day of the new year, but to the book world it is the end of the period of self-enforced restraint between seasons when few new books were published and when those brought out earlier stood, fell and, in some happy cases, climbed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- During the year the American Red Cross gave $16,690,000 in cash and supplies to the war victims and refugees of nine countries, it announced today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 31 -- Reaffirmation of Brazil's hemisphere solidarity and her neutrality in the European war were coupled by President Getulio Vargas with a warning to other nations not to interfere with Brazil in his New Year's address to the nation and a speech this noon at a luncheon given in his honor by army and navy officers.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Jumpers from the stables of Mrs. George W. Johnson of New York and Mrs. William J. Kennedy of Boston captured the feature hunter classes today in the Southern Pines New Year's Eve Horse Show.

Stocks ended 1940 yesterday with a good volume of transfers, but prices only flickered, except in a few groups, and the closing was firm. Trading consisted mainly of evening up operations for the year, while the largest blocks traded were cash sales, although such operations were less in amount than in previous years,

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The Chicago Eastern Illinois became today the first of the railroads involved in the 1930 financial troubles to emerge from court control under bankruptcy action and return once more to private management.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Gloom and uncertainty about what 1941 will bring predominates in Japanese statesmen's New Year messages. Ordinarily these messages are bromides written by secretaries.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 31 -- "If really America's first lines of defense are in England, it would seem to be logical that the United States participate actively in the defense of the British Isles," says this morning's Tribune de Lausanne, commenting on President Roosevelt's speech.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Fit as the hands of coaches and the prayers of alumni can make them, Stanford's unbeaten Indians and Nebraska's Cornhuskers rested today in preparation for their New Year's Day clash in the Rose Bowl.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 31 -- A revamped Wisconsin basketball team defeated Princeton's travel-tired Tigers before a crowd of 5,500 tonight. The score was 52 to 40 and the issue was never in doubt.

As one of his first acts as Republican chairman of New York County, Thomas J. Curran visited City Hall yesterday with Samuel S. Koenig, a former Republican county leader, and paid a New Year's call on Mayor La Guardia. Earlier in the day he had taken possession of his offices in county headquarters at the National Republican Club.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 31 (AP) -- P.D. Houston, president of the American Bankers Association, warned today against the possibilities of inflation and government-controlled prices that he said would arise from decreased production of peace-time goods as a result of the national defense program.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The production of American planes will greatly influence the war in 1941, a high Royal Air Force officer said today in reviewing the air war in 1940 and taking a look into the new year.

Howard C. Hopson, founder of the billion-dollar Associated Gas and Electric System, has been found by a jury in a Federal court guilty of a charge that he had robbed his stockholders of about $20,000,000. Thus the law catches up with one more of that small but powerful group of utility magnates who by their sharp practices and out-right dishonesty brought discredit upon a great industry.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- New Hampshire's skiers added victory in the cross-country race today to their triumph in yesterday's jump and maintained their lead in the twentieth annual college men's skiing meet of the Lake Placid Club. Placing second, third, fourth and sixth, the winners piled up a team margin of almost three minutes over Dartmouth, which finished second, as fresh snow returned to the Adirondacks.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Ten footsore but optimistic pilgrims, five of whom walked 170 miles from Lancaster, Pa., to arouse public sentiment for the feeding of "37,000,000 threatened with starvation in Europe's conquered nations," arrived here tonight en route to New York, where they will culminate their demonstration tomorrow with a meeting in the Broadway Tabernacle.

Pat Egan came through with an iron-man stunt at Madison Square Garden last night. The durable defenseman of the New York Americans, playing almost the entire third period, sparked his team to a well-earned 4-to-2 triumph over the Canadiens of Montreal, and in so doing brought considerable gratification to an enthusiastic gathering of 14,378.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- East meets West in Kezar Stadium tomorrow with the East, led by the brilliant Tom Harmon of Michigan, a 10-to-7 favorite to win the annual Shrine charity football game.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., announced yesterday that it does not recommend to holders of Republic of Colombia bonds the acceptance of a plan announced on Monday by the Republic, in conjunction with the State and Treasury Departments and the Federal Loan Administration, for settlement of the external Colombian Government dollar debt.

Professor Arsene d'Arsonval is dead at the ripe age of 89. With him passes one of the great figures in medicine -- the man who not only introduced electrotherapy into medicine but also invented much of the apparatus used by physiotherapists for half a century. We speak glibly of diathermy nowadays, when tissues are to be heated in the treatment of arthritis, arteriosclerosis and other ailments.

Writers and editors whom the American First Committee is trying to enlist in its movement "to keep us out of all foreign wars" in many cases have surprised workers of the committee with the sharpness of their replies, it was disclosed yesterday when Edna Ferber released her reply.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Squadrons of German bombers, in a daylight attack on blasted London "from great height," today wrecked an important arms factory just northeast of the British capital and saw an entire section of it collapse, the official D.N.B. agency said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- More than twenty milk cooperatives of New York State demanded today a Federal Court injunction to stop the Department of Agriculture from holding a second referendum on amendments to the government order regulating handling of milk for the New York metropolitan market, and to check any attempt by the department to lift the present regulations.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- With special praise for Walter O. Briggs Sr., owner and president of the American League champion Detroit Tigers, the Sporting News announced today its list of No. 1 men of baseball for 1940.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its Jan. 1 monthly review of credit and business conditions points out that the money market in December was characterized on the one hand by a sharp temporary reduction in excess reserves of member banks and on the other by a further expansion in member bank credit.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Orange Bowl football squads snapped through final dress rehearsals on the scene of battle today and their coaches pronounced them in peak condition for the ninth annual New Year's Day game.

In a sermon delivered last night to 2,000 persons gathered at the midnight services at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Rev. Thomas A. Sparks of the staff of the cathedral declared that "peace to be permanent must be followed by a moral victory with the greatest possible justice for the greatest possible number of men."

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore for the first eleven months of this year, made public yesterday by Herbert A. Wagner, president of the company, shows a net income of $5,708,528 after all expenses and charges.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Harry Maione and Frank Abbandando, principals in the Brooklyn murder ring inquiry, will receive a new trial under terms of a four-to-three decision handed down today by the Court of Appeals, which reversed the trial courts.
ROME, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Increased revenues, which, however, still are far short of expenditures, were shown today in Treasury returns for the first nine months of the current fiscal year.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- This community of 18,000 inhabitants, which terminated its century-old status as a village in July to become the fifth city of Westchester County, began levying its first full-year city taxes today under a 1941 budget amounting to $909,471 gross and $747,766 net.
Spectacular and unusually gay New Year's Eve celebrations marked the advent of 1941 in New York's leading hotels, restaurants and night clubs last night.

The Westinghouse Merchandising Division will increase its 1941 advertising schedule on appliances 10 to 15 per cent over 1940 figures, Roger H. Bolin, manager of advertising and sales promotion, announced yesterday. The increase applies to key city newspapers and national magazines.

The cotton market ended 1940 on a strong note, with both the futures and the spot markets at the highest levels of the season. Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 to 7 points net higher than on Monday. As had been announced, trading on the Exchange was suspended at 1 o'clock for the usual New Year's party.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Earl Dew, baby-faced Sac City, Iowa, youth, won the American jockey title of 1940 today after one of the closest battles in turf history, but he wished the competition could have ended in a tie with Walter Lee Taylor of Houston, Texas.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Gen. Henry Maitland Wilson, who commanded the British armies around Sidi Barrani during the battle in Egypt, in an interview today gave much credit for the surprise factor in the attacks to the efficiency of the British patrols, which for weeks before the battle drove every Italian patrol back to camp, often inflicting heavy losses.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, Jan. 1 (UP) -- General Chiang Kai-shek and other Chinese leaders, in New Year addresses broadcast last night, praised President Roosevelt and the United States for assistance to China in her "war of resistance" against Japan and pledged they would not fail those nations that had given assistance.

The City of Dallas, Texas, will be in the market on Jan. 15 with an issue of $1,100,000 of street, sewer, airport and school bonds, for which bidders are asked to specify the rate of interest. The bonds, to be dated Feb. 1, 1941, will mature serially in twenty years.

The average daily production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,385,500 barrels daily, a drop of 235,700 from the 3,621,200 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 174,500 barrels below the calculation of 3,560,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for December.
NOTES at the end of another busy book year, very random:

City College's varsity basketball team wound up the old year in a blaze of glory last night, vanquishing the powerful Geneva College quintet at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium, 41 -- 35. City led at the half, 19-16.

The number of buyers reported in the market last week was 212, as against 198 in the preceding week and 456 in the like period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Yesterday's arrivals totaled ninety-six, as against twelve for a week ago.

The Chinese military mission seeking American airplanes in Washington has been told that we have every desire to help, but unfortunately there are simply not enough planes to go around at present. However, there has been apparently no direct refusal of the mission's request, and there is clearly a saving grace in the time qualification attached to the reply.

ROME, Dec. 31 (UP) -- The High Command today reported heavy Italian blows by land, sea and air on the Albanian and North African fronts. The day's communique was more encouraging than any in several weeks and followed authoritative Fascist predictions that "the moment is at hand" when reorganized Italian forces will strike back at the British and Greek armies holding Italian soil in Albania and Libya.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Gold received in the United States in the week to Dec. 25 amounted to $8,125,788, the smallest weekly import total in more than a year, the Department of Commerce made known today. In the previous week imports of the metal were valued at $36,318,361.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Social Security program, now in its sixth year, has proved a vital factor in conserving the morale of workers and their families, Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, states in a year-end survey issued today.

Emphasizing the critical situation confronting this nation in 1941 and the readiness of organized labor to cooperate fully in solving the problems, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, declared in a New Year's statement yesterday that the creation of a National Defense Labor Board similar to the War Labor Board of the World War period was essential to make the defense program a success.
A fourteen-room apartment with six baths at 625 Park Avenue has been leased to Frederick T. Frelinghuysen through William A. White Sons, brokers, it was announced yesterday.

It is true, as your editorial on the President's speech stated, that the overwhelming majority of the American people agree with the President's central thesis that a victory by the Axis powers would mean a "new and terrible era in which the whole world would be run by threats of brute force."

Beyond reasonable argument the war that Britain is fighting is a war also in our defense. Her victory will save us the later expenditure of billions of dollars in military measures, large sums in commercial losses and in all probability a war on our own account with its accompanying losses of life as well as of fortune.

The President's address sounded like a strong, clear bugle-call ringing through the confusion of stubborn prejudice and loose and unintelligent controversy. It was an unmistakable blast against the provincial views of our isolationists, whose policy is actually the real road to getting us into this war.

The methods followed by Howard C. Hopson in puffing up the Associated Gas and Electric system to the billion-dollar organization it was before its collapse in bankruptcy were branded fraudulent yesterday by a jury in Federal court, which found him guilty of having cheated the system of nearly $20,000,0.00.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command at Cairo issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Ford Motor Company asked the Supreme Court today to decide whether an employer could legally discharge members of a union when that union was committed to a sit-down strike policy, "or whether he must sit idly by and permit the union to attempt the seizure of his plant by force and violence."
St. Patrick's Cathedral was nearly filled last night by 3,000 men and women who attended two Holy Hours, with Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presiding over the first.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 1 -Scarred by thousands of bombs, London hailed the New Year with jubilance and confidence this morning.
BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- Adolf Hitler, in a New Year's proclamation to the "National Socialist Armed Forces," declared today:

BUFFALO, Jan. 1 -- Double-header basketball returned to Buffalo tonight with a pair of collegiate contests played before 4,228 spectators in Memorial Auditorium. The College of the City of New York defeated Canisius, 43 -- 42, in the feature after Wake Forest had beaten Buffalo State Teachers, 42 -- 39, in the opener.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 1 -- Comments yesterday by the morning press -- which does not appear on Mondays -- in editorials analyzing the subject from different viewpoints, all applauded President Roosevelt's message, even though their comments were couched in careful wording due to Brazil's wish to maintain strict neutrality.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Trade, industry and employment in Chicago and the Seventh Federal Reserve District showed broad gains over 1939. In general, it may be said that the pick-up in Chicago proper was not quite as sharp as in other sections in the district, where defense spending was more liberal and more direct throughout the last eight months.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- After being held on even terms for most of the first period, Boston College smothered Colgate, 11 to 4, on the Play-land Casino ice tonight as the annual holiday intercollegiate hockey series opened.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -Elbert T. Gallagher of Mount Kisco took office today as District Attorney of Westchester County and Harold Mercer of White Plains began a second term as County Clerk, while several new local officials in the towns, cities and villages of the county began elective and appointive terms of office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The anti-inflation recommendations of the Federal Reserve Board to Congress today came so suddenly, and politically seemed so bold, that the immediate and general expectation was of a bitter battle over the proposals between the board and the Treasury. This was prophesied in several places.

MONTREAL, Dec. 31 -- The war, into which Canada has entered with every determination to carry through to the utmost of its power, has had a twofold effect upon the railways of the country, according to Sir Edward Beatty, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Coach Frank Leahy, with a bewildered look in his eyes from having his hand pumped by a hundred strangers, stood in the steaming dressing room and admitted guardedlythat this was the happiest day in his life -- athletically.

On completion of its expansion program, which is expected to cost $150,000,000, the ingot output of the Aluminum Company of America will exceed 700,000,000 pounds yearly by July, 1942, compared with the 1939 level of 327,000,000 pounds, according to I.W. Wilson, vice president in charge of operations.

United States trade with Latin-American nations this year should be better than last, despite the many difficulties from which those countries suffer through the loss of European markets. General agreement on the need for Western Hemisphere economic and political solidarity this year has given fresh incentive to intelligent study of the internal economies of the South and Central American nations.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The first "stay-in" test of the strength of General Charles de Gaulle's "Free French" movement in occupied and unoccupied France passed today without a clear decision.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force issued this communique today:
MADRID, Jan. 1 -- Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner today sought to explain to Spain why he suddenly liquidated the international administration of Tangier.

The increase in business activity, which has accompanied the national defense program, the placing of foreign war orders and the buying by private business for inventory purposes, was reflected last year in a considerably enlarged demand for electricity.
A holiday crowd of 3,500 saw the New York Americans defeat their local rival, Brookhattan, 3 -- 2, in a soccer game at Starlight Park yesterday.

Defense procurement methods and policies already have gone through numerous changes and further transition to a system approaching wartime basis is probable, according to the opinion of trade association leaders and selling agents.
ROME, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

Those who got their first taste of camp life in the World War, even if only in American cantonments, still remember a certain refinement of cruelty invariably inflicted under Army regulations. A rookie named Irving Berlin wrote a song about it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Fourteen members of the faculty of the Harvard Graduate School of Education asserted today in a statement that there was a "danger" that a National Association of Manufacturers' analysis of social study textbooks might be done "with bias."

Alfie Pike's "gift" goal enabled the Canadiens of Montreal to subdue the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. With the teams tied at 1-all late in the third period, Pike attempted to clear a shot by Tony Graboski of the visitors but accidentally batted the rubber past Davey Kerr into his own net to give the Frenchmen the lead.

All indications are that retail trade will increase during 1941, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by W.M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller Co. "A big stimulating factor," he said, "will be the tremendous defense program now being carried out as, with many more men put to work, purchasing power will increase.

Hitler has added another promise to the record. This time it is the disavowal of any desire for world conquest. In what is unquestionably a direct reply to President Roosevelt's accusation, the master of the Third Reich declares that to charge Germany with such intentions is to utter "a dumb and infamous lie."

ALBANY, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Declaring existence of an "unprecedented period of readjustment and emergency," the State Conference of Mayors and Other Municipal Officials today cautioned the Legislature, which is to convene on Wednesday, against increasing local government costs or reducing State aid.

The thanks of London's Boy Scouts for a New Year's greeting sent to them in behalf of New York's Scouts and volunteer Scout workers were received yesterday in a cablegram from Sir John Shea, Scout County Commissioner of London, to William H. Pouch, Scout Commissioner of Greater New York.

Production of chemicals of virtually every sort was at the highest levels on record in 1940, and the industry held itself able and ready to supply the vastly greater needs anticipated by the stepping up of national defense and British requirements in 1941.

Prices of United States Government securities have approached the highest levels which may obtain for some time and already have reached a point where a change in the direction of this seven-year upward trend can be visualized, in the opinion of C.J. Devine of C.J. Devine Co.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Bette Davis, motion-picture star, and Arthur Farnsworth of Boston were married last night at the home of friends in Arizona, she made known today.
