MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Mrs. Nelson Lloyd White of Morristown gave a large tea dance at her home this afternoon to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Jeanne Perry White. Christmas greens decorated the house.

In a New Year's Day radio program directed at the warring nations of Europe, Dorothy Thompson, the writer, made a plea to the German people not to lose their faith in democracy; Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, sent a message of encouragement to England; Hendrik Van Loon, the author, spoke to Holland, and a message of appreciation was sent to Greece.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Florence Kerr, Assistant Works Progress Commissioner, proposed tonight that millions of women join in a voluntary mobilization for home defense.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- Prosperity second only to the boom year of 1925 came to Dallas during 1940, substantially supported by defense expenditures and industrial expansion of Texas. Over the entire Eleventh Federal Reserve District conditions were similar.

Virtually every New York Stock Exchange subject which entered 1940 under the head of "Unfinished Business" came into 1941 under the same classification. Among them were and are the question of multiple trading, the question of raising commissions and (perhaps) splitting them with outsiders, the problem of revising the Securities Acts, the problem of fidelity insurance as an added safeguard for customers and the problem of bringing the books of the trading place into balance.

Despite the large volume of security issues placed privately and the absence of any great amount of "new money" borrowing, the total of new securities offered to the public in this market in 1940 was the largest for several years, Flotations of bonds, exclusive of government loans, were the heaviest since 1936, while offerings of stock issues were the largest since 1937.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Mioland, owned by Charles S. Howard, won the $10,000 added New Year Handicap at Santa Anita Park today, with Gen'l Manager second and Sweepida third.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Holland R. Foster of Owego was elected chairman of the Dairy Farmers Union this afternoon, succeeding Archie Wright, who resigned last Friday. At the first meeting of the new general organization committee Sam Schou of South New Berlin was elected to Mr. Wright's place on the committee.

VICHY, Dec. 29 -- Throughout the first months of the present year and up to the German offensive of May the tone of the Paris market was satisfactory, with the Bourse steady and money plentiful. The government was able to meet its war expenses, using only a small part of the advances which had been authorized by the agreement with the Bank of France.

In the second program of their "Festival Series" at their new studio-theatre in West Sixteenth Street, Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman last night offered as the chief novelty a revival of Mr. Weidman's "Atavisms," and in so doing restored to the repertory a distinctly important work.

Five foot-weary though spirited peace disciples ended a 170-mile pilgrimage from Lancaster, Pa., yesterday afternoon. They walked here to demonstrate their sympathy for the plight of Europe's hungry civilians in German-occupied blockaded nations.

The volume of long-term financing by States and their political subdivisions in 1941 probably will be less than in the last several years, according to John S. Linen, vice president of the Chase National Bank. In a special article for this edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Mr. Linen lists two principal reasons for his view.

With nearly 1,400,000 Boy Scouts in this country the Chief Scout Executive has quite a job on his hands. Dr. James E. West has filled that job for the last thirty years. Today the organization is celebrating the anniversary of his generation of service. It is a generation which has brought the Boy Scouts from a weak alliance of unimportant groups into the outstanding youth organization of America and the world.

As plans looking toward Western Hemisphere solidarity take definite shape, United States radio men are looking to 1941 as a year of further expansion in service to the south. Improved technical facilities and better Latin-American program service will be in effect.

Verne Marshall, head of the No Foreign War Committee, in a fifteen-minute broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System last night, outlined the committee's objectives, roundly denounced "interventionist publications" and called again upon the Administration to release "agenda" brought from Berlin in October, 1939, by W.R. Davis, oil merchant.

Stimulated by war orders and the national rearmament program, industrial activity of the United States at the close of last year reached the highest level since 1929. Although the full extent of this gain was not transferred into net profits because of the impact of additional taxes, the earnings of every major industry were substantially above those of 1939.

Men in the nation's defense forces were urged yesterday to look to religion for the spiritual and moral strength that will make them better defenders of democracy. The plea was contained in a New Year's message by spokesmen of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths and the Chief of Chaplains of the United States Army.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- New Hampshire's skiers assured themselves of the title in the twentieth annual college men's ski meet of the Lake Placid Club by capturing the slalom honors today and thus sweeping all three of the events which snow conditions made it possible to hold this year.

Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, says in a year-end statement that adequate supply of sulphur for thousands of operations vital to the arming of the nation, far from being the major worry that that it was in 1918, today is a solved problem.

Mayor La Guardia described New York City yesterday as living proof of the success of democracy when he said in a New Year's speech over WNYC that the community of 7,500,000 persons lived in peace despite the wide variety of its racial components.

Although the domestic consumption of cotton is at the highest rate on record, exports of the staple are at the lowest level in several decades and consequently the domestic stock to be carried forward at the end of the current season probably will be a new high record, according to Robert J. Murray, president of the New York Cotton Exchange.

Full capacity employment for most lines of business was predicted for the year by John Lowry, president of the Merchants Association of New York, in a survey published yesterday by the association giving opinions of its directors as to the business prospect for the new year and ways and means of meeting the economic problems of the new emergency.

PALM BEACH, Jan. 1 -- Celebrating the host's eighty-fourth birthday and the New Year, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr., entertained with their traditional open house today at Casa Del Pastor. Receiving with them were Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Shepard of Providence, R.I.
The Rome radio last night vehemently denied that Italy was interested in a separate peace.

The plentiful supply of bank credit in 1940 was reflected in the regularly quoted rates on bankers' acceptances, commercial paper and other trade instruments. Prime commercial paper running for three to four months was quoted at a discount of one-half of 1 per cent as 1940 ended, compared with five- eighths of 1 per cent at the end of 1939.

The national defense program and the unusual strain imposed on our economy by a changing world have created a greater need for efficient distribution today than in any previous era of our history, John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, declared in a year-end statement.

There seems to be misapprehension regarding the master plan which is now being considered by the City Planning Commission. Some believe that when the plan has been adopted by the Planning Commission it becomes the official plan of the city, that all improvements must be checked against it and those in conflict may be adopted only by a three-fourths vote of the Board of Estimate.

The distilled spirits industry in 1940 took its place among the major industries to which the United States looks for heavy economic contributions and employment stability in times of national stress, Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman of the board of Schenley Distillers Corporation, said in a year-end statement in which he called attention to the fact that the distilled spirits industry had disbursements of about $1,200,000,000 last year.

Employes designated unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor as their sole bargaining representative in 109 State Labor Relations Board elections last year, Edward J. Kelly, the board's examiner in charge of employe balloting, reported yesterday.
The increase in machine efficiency and in the productivity of labor since the last war has more than doubled production per man-hour, according to data compiled by the Conference Board.

Twenty-five leading cigar manufacturers, representing more than 70 per cent of the industry's sales volume, have combined to form the Cigar Institute of America, with temporary offices at 200 Fifth Avenue, for the purpose of carrying on a four-year program to increase cigar consumption.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. William du Pont of Newtown Square, Pa., and Bellevue, Del., gave a ball tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford to introduce to society their debutante daughter, Miss Jean Ellen du Pont.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Savings to farm and city buyers of Tennessee Valley Authority power in the fiscal year 1940 came to about $9,000,000, the TVA estimated in its annual report to Congress, made public today.
PEARL BUCK has gathered about a dozen of the stories she wrote for magazines during the past few years into "Today and Forever: Stories of China."*

The combined forces of finance and industry have shifted into high speed to do a $17,000,000,000 job on national defense in 1941. Throughout the nation the vast banking and industrial machinery is being stepped up to top officiency as the answer to the challenge against the continued existence of democracy.

After five years in which successive all-time records were established in hosiery shipments, the industry slipped back in 1940, on the basis of incomplete figures, and this was to have been expected in view of the fact that 1939 was regarded as a new plateau from which some recession was natural, according to Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.
An important realty transaction linked to the expanding national defense program and involving an industrial tract of about forty acres fronting on New York Bay was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 -- In a series of raids over a vast area extending from lower Italy to Libya and to the southern gate of the Red Sea, British pilots have bombed half a dozen points vital to the Fascist war machine, the Royal Air Force announced today.

In a comparison of its activities in the first eleven months of 1940 with the same period in 1939, the American Merchant Marine Library Association announced in a report yesterday that the organization's services increased 40 per cent last year and that the goal of placing a new stock of books every three months for seamen on every American ship was closer than ever before.

The second part of the series, "Forty Years of American Film Comedy," will begin showings at the Museum of Modern Art Film Library on Monday. The series, which will consist of twenty-four films arranged in eleven programs, will be shown in rotation through March 30.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- December trade in the Chicago wholesale district made the best record in several months, the report of the Chicago Wholesale Market Council showed today. Gains over 1939 ran as high as 25 per cent, with the wholesale dry goods houses at the top of the list.

Everything points to our defense program proceeding at an accelerating rate during 1941 and beyond, according to a statement by Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Incorporated. This plus the continued sale of war supplies to Great Britain will inevitably speed up the tempo of our general industry, he declared.

Small business is ready to do its part in national defense and has a detailed program laid out for 1941, according to Albert W. Churman, executive secretary of the Smaller Business Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. He listed the objectives of the small business program as follows:

A majority of radio listeners in the metropolitan area noticed little difference in the music offered over the air yesterday, the first day that three-quarters of the country's stations did without the catalogue of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, according to the results of an informal poll.

Having been inactive since "An International Incident" of last April, Guthrie McClintic will offer for approval this evening at Maxine Elliott's a combined ghost and murder thriller entitled "The Lady Who Came to Stay." It is based on the R.E. Spencer novel of the same title and has been dramatized by Kenneth White.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- There was a new indication today that Britain is tightening up her economic pressure against a wayward member of her family of nations, namely Eire [Ireland], which is the only part of the empire remaining neutral in the mother country's death struggle against the Axis powers.

During his ten years as chief law officer of New York State, completed at midnight last Tuesday, Attorney General John J. Bennett has recovered about $25,000,000 for the public from stock swindlers and loan sharks in penalties, judgments, compensation awards and taxes due under the law, according to a survey issued yesterday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 1 (UP) -- A government spokesman announced tonight that the National Herrerista party had withdrawn its opposition to the construction of Pan-American defense bases in Uruguay and had accepted a 1941 political truce, which will be announced to the nation in several days.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- A 158-pound bundle of dynamite exploded in the faces of a startled Tennessee eleven in the dying minutes of a magnificently fought Sugar Bowl football game before a record gathering of 73,181 today as unbeaten Boston College took the measure of the hitherto undefeated Volunteers, 19 to 13.

Emphasizing that the oil industry is prepared to tackle whatever part it may be called upon to play in the national defense effort, Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, in a year-end statement, says that "with good management, unimpeded, it can fill any likely demand for petroleum products for military operations without seriously restricting supplies to the civilian population."

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 1 -- With Christmas and New Year furloughs over, 14,600 soldiers of the Forty-fourth Division began returning to Fort Dix tonight to resume their training programs at 5:45 o'clock tomorrow morning when reveille is sounded.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Military men expressed belief today that the British had developed a way to equip their warplanes with a detector for locating enemy aircraft in the dark.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- According to estimates of neutral observers, the Reich's wartime expenditure averages four milliard to five milliard marks monthly. Slightly less than one-half of this is met from tax revenue and more than one-half through borrowing, facilitated by large idle purchasing power of the German populations.
Spencer Trask Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, will take over today the Albany business of Parker, McElroy Co. John E. McElroy will become manager of the new Albany office.

Maintenance of quality standards on a rising market and the prevention of a spiraling of prices, among the outstanding problems of retailers during the year just closed, will be multiplied and intensified during 1941 with the increasing expenditures by the government for national defense, according to a highlight of the reports made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the executives managing the various groups of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- During 1940 179 new ships for the merchant marine of the United States were built or under construction at a cost of $450,000,000, all of them capable of quick transformation into efficient naval auxiliaries, the Maritime Commission stated today in its annual report.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The second-place Detroit Red Wings advanced to within four points of the lead in the National Hockey League tonight with a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -Mayor Frank Hague of this city announced officially today at his New Year's Day reception in City Hall that he and his four colleagues on the City Commission would run for re-election in the May municipal election.

Provision for arbitration is being written into defense contracts in increasing numbers, and this marks one of the most important developments in commercial arbitration in 1940, Cornelius V. Whitney, president of the American Arbitration Association, asserted in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The first consideration of every American business man in 1941 will be to put the national defense program into effect, according to Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation. "Upon the foundations now being prepared by the men in charge of the project," he said, "we are assured of an adequate defense on land, water and in the air.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A snowslide roared down a steep slope in the Wasatch Mountains near here today. Watchers said that four skiers were in its path.

Machine tool requirements of producers of normal peace-time goods, as well as of those handling national defense contracts can be met through 1941 if manufacturers will cooperate with tool builders in working out delivery schedules based upon actual needs, Charles J. Stillwell, president of the Warner Swasey Co. of Cleveland, said in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

When complete data on domestic corporate bond and note emissions for 1940, excluding railroad financing, are written into the record, they will reveal, according to conservative estimates, that about 56 1/2 per cent of the total was sold by the "private placement" route.

Preliminary estimates put retail installment sales volume for last year at $5,000,000,000 to $5,250,000,000, compared with $4,200,000,000 in 1939, according to an analysis prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Malcolm L. Merriam, chief of the Credit Analysis Unit of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce.

Lack of time in which to prepare a correlated production and training plan makes it inevitable that the urgent demands of the huge armament program will force some curtailment in peacetime goods output and give priority in the country's manufacturing plants to guns over butter, according to opinions expressed by leading economists.

Having opened its 1941 model year with the largest volume of retail sales for any Fall in history, the automotive industry now enters a new calendar year with prospects of eclipsing 1940's mark of some 4,400,000 cars and trucks by at least 15 per cent, which would give the industry its second 5,000,000-vehicle year.

As the demands of the huge national defense program became insatiable in the latter part of 1940, the production and shipment of durable goods, whose low estate for the last decade had been widely lamented, reached new all-time records. In percentage gains, they far outstripped consumer or non-durable goods, which enjoyed a brisk year.

Most of us have heard of the man who boasted to his friends that he was going to capture a wildcat with his bare hands and, when he had grabbed the animal, cried out for some one to help him let it go. Well, Angus Cameron of New York has a story of a man who killed two moose up in Canada last Fall.

During 1940 eleven new school Buildings, providing 17,785 additional seats for children and costing $14,582,426, were completed and opened in this city, James Marshall, President of the Board of Education, announced yesterday. Eleven more buildings, providing seats for 24,799 and costing $19,644,250, are now under construction.

The textile industry generally stood in a strong position as it closed 1940. Cotton mills were operating at or near the highest levels in their history and had heavy unfilled-order backlogs. Wool-goods mills, substantially supported by defense contracts, had backlogs comparable to those of the war boom of lat 1939 and were operating on a profitable basis.

Estimating department store sales as 6 per cent ahead for the year just closed, Frank M. Mayfield, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and head of Scruggs-Vandervoort-Barney, Inc., predicted an accelerated rate of sales increase this year.

Wide support of a general Federal sales tax to meet the cost of the national defense program was reported yesterday in a nation-wide survey of public opinion completed for the National Association of Manufacturers by the Elmo Roper Organization.

A far-reaching plan calculated to stimulate interest in athletic activities and provide them on a greater scale than ever before throughout the country was announced yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union through its secretary-treasurer, Daniel J. Ferris.

Confidence in the future of American industry financed by private funds will return, in the opinion of George P. Rea, president of the New York Curb Exchange. "When that time comes, as it will," he said, "exchanges will demonstrate their great importance in bringing the public to share in a new and, as I believe, a more enduring prosperity than we have seen in the good times of the past."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 1 -- St. David's islanders, about 200 of whom will have to find new homes to make way for the United States air and naval base, are not relishing the idea of moving away from the east end of the islands to a more westerly one of the colony's nine parishes.

Although the enactment of retroactive Federal tax legislation affecting earnings of a preceding year would not be without precedent, having occurred as to 1918, it seems hardly likely that the present emergency would justify such legislation in respect to 1940.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 31 (Australian Associated Press) -- On the outbreak of war New Zealand had her supply organization geared for instant action on a war basis. This involved controls in all major spheres of economic life. Subsequently emergency regulations were passed to provide for all-in effort so that the whole of the industrial and economic life of the community could be directed to enabling New Zealand to provide a maximum war effort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- With President Roosevelt's plan for lending war equipment to England and the whole question of American policy toward the European conflict providing a seething controversy, the Seventy-seventh Congress will convene formally on Friday.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 1 -- Two quick touchdowns, coming with stunning suddenness in the early minutes of the third quarter, enabled the mighty Texas Aggies to turn back Fordham, 13 to 12, today in the Cotton Bowl football game before a crowd of 45,500 that set a record for the classic.

Equalization of rules governing the registered Exchanges and the over-the-counter market would be welcomed warmly by the regional Stock Exchanges of the country, according to a questionnaire recently sent out by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 1 -- A powerful and tricky band of Redcats from Western Reserve University overcame the speed merchants of Tempe, Ariz., State Teachers, 26 to 13, in the Sun Bowl today. Spectacular running attacks by both elevens kept 14,000 fans on their feet.

A stringent curb on speculation is necessary to insure the successful completion of the defense program and continued building of inventories by industry beyond protective quantities should be avoided, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, declared in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The most effective method of meeting the Axis plans for a revolutionized world that will pay tribute to a "Greater Germany," is to unfold before the world America's alternative for bringing about universal economic order, E.P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, held in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Early in June the Germans continued their advance into France. The French Government left Paris. On June 10 Italy declared war on France and England; on June 14 Paris was occupied by the Germans and on June 17 Marshal Petain, who succeeded Reynaud as Premier, surrendered to Germany. At home the Republican National Convention opened on the 24th, and unexpectedly nominated Wendell L. Willkie with great enthusiasm on the 26th.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 -- A sharp-shooting Mississippi State football team banged over a pair of first-half touchdowns and then staved off Georgetown's desperate comeback to win the ninth annual Orange Bowl football game, 14 to 7, before an overflow crowd of 35,101 today.

The naval and merchant marine expansion programs present to the shipbuilding industry of the United States the greatest task it has ever had except for the World War shipbuilding program, according to the annual survey of conditions in the industry prepared by H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A forestalling of the threat of inflation inherent in the nation's monetary and fiscal policies was recommended to Congress and the Administration today in a special report by the Federal Reserve System.

Six hundred social science textbooks used in the public school systems of the United States have been abstracted and the abstracts will be available for distribution soon, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Mathews gave an afternoon reception yesterday at their home, 1088 Park Avenue, to introduce their daughter, Miss F. Mary C. Mathews, to some of the older friends of the family. Miss Mathews, who was graduated from the Brearley School last Spring, was one of the debutantes who attended the Autumn Ball in Tuxedo Park in October.

Available information points to a slight increase in the dollar value of millinery sales in 1940 as compared with 1939, according to M.P. Hyland, president of Jay-Thorpe Hats and treasurer of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Seventy-sixth Congress, which has been marking time for several weeks while technically remaining in session, expires by statutory limitation at noon on Friday unless it votes to adjourn sine die before that time. This it is not expected to do.

The European war will be the principal factor affecting the cosmetic industry in 1941, according to a special statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Hugo Mock, counsel to the Toilet Goods Association. The war has accelerated a trend which, happily for the industry, had already started twenty years ago -- namely, to manufacture cosmetics, perfumes and toilet preparations generally in the United States rather than import them from Europe.

With the defense program in full swing, the domestic copper industry is anticipating an unprecedented demand for its output in 1941. Because of the opposition to higher prices by the United States Government indications are that the price of copper in the home market will be held around its prevailing level of 12 cents a pound.

After an over-all gain of about 26 per cent in 1940, which exceeded expectations, the electrical appliance industry is looking for a 15 to 20 per cent increase in 1941, "although there are a large number of factors that bring to bear considerable uncertainty to these prospects," according to W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, in a year-end statement.

Avoidance of speculation by merchants and a willingness on the part of the consumer to face possible temporary shortages calmly are key factors in keeping retail prices stable and thus eliminating the need for the price-fixing of the first World War period, Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman of the Retailers Advisory Committee, composed of fifty-two retail trade organizations, declares in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Chicago bankers tonight praised the action taken by the Federal Reserve System in its monetary and fiscal policy recommendations. They said adoption of the measures should strengthen the nation's monetary system.

Reporting that in 1940 the National Consumer-Retailer Council had by far its most successful year, Harold W. Brightman, vice president of L. Bamberger Co. and chairman of the council, said in a special statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES that the store program committee plans to issue within the next few weeks a manual entitled "Informative Selling -- A Store Guide for Consumer Cooperation."

Enlightened food manufacturers in the coming months will refuse to ride the "sellers' market tide," but instead will try harder to advertise and sell high-quality products at the lowest prices consistent with their obligations to their employes, investors, distributors and the nation's welfare, Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, held in a statement prepared especially for THE TIMES.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 -- German raiders, disguised as the Japanese freighters Tokyo Maru and Manyo Maru, still hold survivors of the destroyed Turakina, Ringwood and Notou, Navy Minister W.M. Hughes announced tonight in reporting the arrival of 496 persons from seven other ships sunk by the Nazis in the South Pacific.

Defense contracts placed by the Army and Navy through Nov. 30 reached $9,589,182,000, but there were indications that the monthly volume was tapering off, according to data compiled by the Conference Board. Awards in the first half of November were $921,000,000 and they dropped to $416,000,000 in the second half of that month and to about $300,000,000 in the first half of December.

TOPEKA, Dec. 29 -Labor is having a honeymoon in building defense projects, high wages luring thousands. To some extent it softens the relief burden, but that of course is not permanent. Stimulation of industry by defense spending generally is expected to continue through the next year, and trade which has lagged has a prospect of betterment.

Development and use of standards in the national defense program, in industry and in the consumer goods field will be vitally important this year, according to a statement prepared by P.G. Agnew, secretary of the American Standards Association.

Coincident with declining volume on the stock markets, prices of Hew York Stock Exchange and New York Curb Exchange memberships also declined last year. On the Stock Exchange, with the year's turnover the lowest since 1921, seat prices hit the lowest since 1899.

HONOLULU, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Fresno State College snatched a 3-to-0 football victory from the University of Hawaii today when Dale Mickelwait, substitute guard, was sent into the Pineapple Bowl game in the final quarter and kicked a field goal in a stiff, cold wind.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- High praise for the rival Rose Bowl teams came from both dressing rooms after Stanford's victory over Nebraska today.

TOKYO, Jan. 1 -- The Ministry of Finance has announced that publication of foreign trade figures henceforth will be suspended. Such business information as Japanese traders may require will be issued in special sheets to approved applicants only.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Foreign Policy Association has drawn up a "balance sheet" of Great Britain's war needs, listing ships and airplanes, iron and steel, other minerals, food and money as essentials to the successful continuance of the war against Germany, and adding that these can be supplied only by the United States.

The three-story and basement factory building containing 45,000 square feet of space at 1535-39 Sixty-third Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company to Joseph Aronauer, Inc., manufacturer of bed springs. The property is assessed for $95,000.

In Robert S. Bird's special article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Dec. 31 the statement is made that the National Student Federation of America "refused to affiliate with the International Student Service, an organization that offered to give financial aid to the distressed N.S.F.A. if the two groups were merged.

Rising 7 per cent to an estimated total of $45,000,000,000, retail trade last year made the best dollar showing in a decade. In point of physical units of goods, volume exceeded that of 1929 by a substantial margin owing to the difference of 15 per cent or more in the retail price level of the two years.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 2 -- The air-raid sirens were wailing at the dinner hour last night in London and reports of German activity over scattered parts of Great Britain brought home to the people that although it is a new year it is not yet a different world.

Several developments last year clearly indicated rising opposition toward resale price fixing, now legalized under the so-called Fair Trade Acts and the Tydings-Miller amendment to the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, according to a review prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Q.F. Walker, economist for R.H. Macy Co., Inc.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The 35,101 spectators packing the Orange Bowl today provided almost as much color as the Mississippi State and Georgetown football teams.

Fighting continued in Europe, being again made up of intensive bombing by the Germans, sometimes in London, sometimes in provincial English cities. The Italians gave ground to the British in North Africa and to the Greeks in Albania, but the Italian resistance appeared to be somewhat stronger. Continuous rumors as to the action of Germany circulated, including reports that German troops were moving down the Balkans and into Italy; but these were not clearly verified.
Winthrop Rockefeller, one of the five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr., confirmed yesterday reports that he intends to volunteer for a year of training under the Selective Service Act.

The electric power and light industry of the United States -- particularly that portion of it falling under the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission by virtue of the terms of the Public Utility Holding Company Act -- enters 1941 in a somewhat confused state.

American foreign traders challenge the widespread story that high production costs in the United States put this country at a disadvantage in meeting competition for foreign markets. Opinions expressed by exporters here indicate confidence regarding the future and include the prediction that in the post-war world American goods will more than hold their own in all markets where open competition is permitted.

Although 1940 purchases of leather goods for the defense program were about 6,000,000 pairs of shoes and 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 pairs of gloves, government orders were relatively minor in comparison with commercial demand, according to Merrill A. Watson, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Paul Christman's high looping passes for two touchdowns and Jimmy Johnson's spectacular 53-yard end run for a third gained the West a well-earned 20-to-14 victory today over an Eastern football team that snatched its two scores on Tommy Harmon's passes.

The Adriatic Sea is an arm of the Mediterranean shaped roughly like a keyhole. It is indeed the keyhole to Italy's back door. Mussolini's seizure of Albania was largely an effort to seal that keyhole and shoot a bolt across it from both sides of the Strait of Otranto.

VICHY, France, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Tension noticeably increased in official circles tonight as the government awaited, amid rumors of ruptured negotiations, Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's reply to the proposals of Marshal Petain for limited French-German collaboration.

Despite the sharp curtailment in export markets the domestic oil industry has just completed its best year from the standpoint of demand, and the prospects are that another record for consumption will be established in 1941. Because of low prices, earnings of the industry as a whole were not considered satisfactory, although in the first half of 1940 most companies reported very favorable profits.

United States exports last year passed the $4,000,000,000 level for the first time since 1929. Despite the impressive total, however, foreign traders are not pleased with the showing because it gives evidence of what they term an "unhealthy concentration" of sales in a comparatively few commodities.

William P. Witherow, president of the Blaw-Knox Company, says in his year-end statement that "to continue drifting through 1941, with reservations in our determination, with laxity in the nation's planning, with misunderstanding by the public, is to practice 'blackouts' in our patriotism.

The year 1940 was the second twelve months of intense activity in the aircraft industry, according to the annual summary of Eugene E. Wilson, president of the United Aircraft Corporation, who said that the trebling of floor space and doubling of output by the company was an unprecedented achievement, purely from the point of view of rapidity of expansion.

Widespread public interest in American design creation following the loss of inspiration from abroad has had a stimulating effect upon the fashion trades and should prove helpful in the further acceleration of demand this year, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc.
While Canada has raised 350,000 men for her military forces, her most notable contribution to the war has been economic, according to the Royal Bank of Canada.

VICHY, France, Jan. 1 -- In lieu of an annual budget, which is impossible to estimate by reason of the disruption of French finances and related services as a result of the war, the government today published a provisional budget for the first four months of 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations urged upon member unions today support of a ten-point program to liberalize unemployment compensation benefits, warning that such benefits were facing "a critical stage" because of a drive on the part of employers "to reduce taxes and oppose liberalization of benefits."

Poor merchandising, in which price-cutting plays a major role, is responsible for the fact that 160 retail food stores go out of business every day and an additional 133 food outlets change hands every business day, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., asserted in a statement prepared specially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Domestic cotton consumption in 1940 set a new record at just over 8,000,000 bales, a gain of more than 7.5 per cent compared with the previous (1937) record, and per capita consumption of cotton cloth was 73.4 square yards, a new high mark, according to Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Britain's many vicissitudes of the past year have found impressive and at times painful reflection in financial markets. As war unfolded itself, the hopefulness which existed a year ago gave place to gloom and disillusionment, but never to despair.

New York City closed the year 1940 in a sound credit position, although the year marked the sale of the largest amount of long-term bonds ever issued in a twelve-month period, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick said yesterday in a New Year's report to the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Dies Committee, which is investigating the activities of un-American organizations, made public today a translation of what it called an "official confidential manual" of the German-American Bund, and commented that this proved "conclusively" that the Bund is "an absolutely militarized organization, patterned after the ruthlessly efficient military set-up which characterizes Hitler's machine in Germany."

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, Before Bardia, Libya, Dec. 30 (Delayed) (UP) -- British armored-car patrols have penetrated to a point a few miles south of Tobruk, more than seventy miles inside Libya, and spent a day observing the defenses of that important Italian base and reconnoitring an airfield south of Tobruk.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 -- Having broken all records for raw and finished steel production in the past six months, the steel industry sees definite evidence at the close of this year that this extensive tempo will be continued for at least the first five or six months of 1941.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in 1940 was in the smallest volume in twenty-three years. The turnover amounted to $1,671,598,875, compared with $2,048,237,875 in 1939, and $4,098,696,000 in 1922, the record year.

Renewed confidence in investment trust management is gradually developing, according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation. "I expect," he said, "that the year 1941 will see this confidence growing and the gap between asset value and market value narrowing."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Policing of radio communications has been sharply increased by the Federal Communications Commission to guard against subversive activity, the agency made known today in its annual report to Congress.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 1 -- Along the Indiana shore of the Ohio River, seventeen miles from here, the United States Army and the du Pont powder people are racing against time to eliminate another bottleneck in the defense program about which little has thus far been said.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Morris Brown of Atlanta, a swift-striking football machine, rolled over Wilberforce University, 19 to 3, today in the first annual Steel Bowl game and claimed the national Negro title.

So closely does our own economic and financial outlook depend on the course and duration of the European war that prediction is necessarily modified by that consideration. Prediction regarding the war itself has changed repeatedly during 1940, and the obscurity of judgment on that point has to a large extent permeated even year-end forecasts of our own trade and industry.

The building material industry is entering 1941 with prospects bright for a sharp gain in sales, unless prices get out of hand or the exigencies of the defense program demand a curtailment of private residential construction, according to executives in the field.

The floor coverings trade wound up the year with an increase of about 15 per cent over the preceding year and a total business exceeding that of any year since 1929, according to reports by dealers and manufacturers. The end of the period found both retail and wholesale inventories in an unusually healthy condition, which led manufacturers to expect even further increases this year.

Outstanding in the consumer cooperative movement last year was the rapid construction of refineries, mills and factories to produce an increased amount of the goods now distributed by the cooperatives to 2,000,000 members who are estimated to purchase about $600,000,000 worth of goods a year through consumer cooperatives, according to a special review prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by The Cooperative League of the U.S.A.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Income payments to individuals in November continued the steady rise that began in the Spring of last year, lifting the index of such payments to 93.4 from 92.5 in October, the Department of Commerce announced today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 31 -- Business optimism permeates Brazil. War influences have brought new money flooding into the country. Foreign exchange tangles are almost entirely unraveled. Manufacturing and real estate are booming.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A message to Congress definitely pitting the United States against the aims of the Rome-Berlin-Tokyo Axis and projecting the urgent need of expanding short-of-war aid to Great Britain, was being prepared tonight by President Roosevelt in the quiet of his study.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 1 -- "We had 'em going until that long pass gave them a lift," Sleepy Jim Crowley, Fordham football coach, said as he walked from the Cotton Bowl today, where Texas A. and M. had gained a 13-to-12 triumph.
The six-story apartment house at 1150 Vyse Avenue, in the Bronx, containing 192 rooms divided into fifty-six suites, has been sold by Jay-San Properties, Inc., to a client of Hyman Leff, broker.

Yesterday marked the beginning of the fourth month of operation for the new Inter-American Coffee Quota Agreement, signed on Nov. 28 by representatives of the United States and fourteen coffee-producing countries of Latin America. The agreement, made retroactive to Oct. 1, needs for its completion only formal ratification by the governments of the signatory nations.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The British and United States Governments are considering a plan whereby American merchant ships would take over British shipping routes over an extensive Pacific area, releasing British ships for urgent war

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 1 -- The disappearance of a score of foreigners from their usual rendezvous -- a small cafe at Pera -- is the only indication the public has so far received of a big coup by the Turkish political police.

New highs all along the line were recorded for New York racing in the year just closed, it is shown by the report of the State Racing Commission released yesterday by Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope. Official figures establish that the betting with the advent of parimutuel machines was $103,259,359, with total taxes of one kind or another accruing to the State of $5,998,953.03.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- No one at Federal Reserve headquarters would say today whether the board's proposals had Administration approval. However, Lauchlin Currie, President Roosevelt's personal economic adviser, attended a meeting Tuesday with Chairman Eccles and Secretary Morgenthau on the subject.

NORTHEASTERN FRONT, Albania, Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- Snow has bound up everything here tighter than a rubber ball. The whole north-east front is frozen and there is no sign of a thaw. The fighting is limited to localized attack and counter-attack.

The national executive board of the German American Congress for Democracy, 122 East Forty-second Street, has sent a telegram to President Roosevelt endorsing his policy as expressed in the fireside chat Sunday night, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Reuther plan for utilizing automotive industry facilities to turn out 500 warplanes a day was reluctantly termed impracticable today by high defense production experts.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- Conditions which have prevailed in the southern cotton States during 1940 and which from all indications promise to continue through the whole or greater part of 1941, have been dominated, shaped and to a full extent controlled by the ruinous war in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, one of the leading isolationists in Congress, would have the United States guarantee a negotiated European peace, provided it met the approval of American public opinion as just and durable, or he would have the United States go to war against Germany if Chancellor Hitler refused to negotiate such a peace, according to an interview published in today's issue of Foreign Correspondence.

C.F. Palmer, defense housing coordinator of the National Defense Advisory Commission, reports that some 50,000 dwelling units built by public and private agencies to house workers called to man defense industries will be completed early this year. By March an equal number is expected to be under construction.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 1 -- Bulgarian Premier Bogdan Philoff, accompanied by his wife and secretary, left Sofia at five minutes past 2 this afternoon for Vienna. Baron Herbert yon Richthofen, the German Minister, was traveling on the same train, bound for Berlin.

Uncertain world conditions and the constant demand for flexibility on the part of advertisers kept advertising volume in 1940 from achieving more than a moderate gain of approximately 4 per cent over 1939. Whereas other business indices, such as production and retail sales of all types, either exceeded or came close to the 1929 peak, advertising linage in measurable media continued to lag somewhat behind the boom year.

The Custom Tailors Guild of America, whose 156 members probably noticed on Dec. 27 that a group of comparable experts on women's clothes had chosen the year's ten "best dressed," announced its own list yesterday, as follows:

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 -- Faced with the worst economic crisis in its history, Argentina is looking to the United States as the only probable source of help and cooperation during the year that threatens to be difficult. This year closes with a large unfavorable trade balance and an even worse deficit in the international balance of payments.

The commercial banking system of the United States faces the new year, with its huge task of rearmament, eager to participate in the financing program. At the year-end, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System -- deposit balances with the Federal Reserve Banks over and above legal requirements -- approximated $6,500,000,000.

Commercial bankruptcies can be expected to rise during 1941, as better business will bring an inevitable increase in new business ventures, some of them launched by incompetents and others by shoe-string operators, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in a statement prepared exclusively for THE TIMES.

Efforts to discover substitutes for vital imported materials and to develop here products formerly imported from countries now occupied were highlights of industrial research during 1940, according to Maurice Holland, director of the division of engineering and industrial research of the National Research Council, in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Time, the weekly magazine, announced yesterday that it had selected Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Great Britain as "man of the year" in 1940. The designation is given annually by the magazine's editors to the man or woman who, in their opinion, has effected the most dramatic change in the course of history during the year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Here are the chief items of expense in the adoption of the defense program by the present session:

The bombing of London by German airplanes continued through September, but with British resistance stiffer and with bombing of Channel ports and German cities by British R.A.F. There were rumors that actual physical invasion of England by the German army would be undertaken; but this did not happen.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- With national defense the theme, Uncle Sam the chief character, and red, white and blue the predominating colors, 18,000 followers of Momus, god of ridicule, pranced up Broad Street today in the annual Mummers' parade, this city's annual contribution to the new year.

Revision of Federal and State social security laws to make all drafted men eligible for six months' unemployment insurance when they complete their military service was recommended yesterday by the board of directors of the American Association for Social Security.
Amid cackles, crows, gobbles and other barnyard sounds, the New York Poultry Show opened yesterday for a five-day stay at the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

PEIPING, Jan. 1 -- Colonel Allen H. Turnage, commander of United States Marines here, was understood today to be preparing to demand a formal apology from the Japanese for asserted maltreatment of five marines after a cabaret fracas.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- German recognition of the unequivocal standpoints of the United States in this war is made clear tonight in an inspired review of the last year, which says: "With the exception of the enemy, England, the official policy of the United States of America constitutes the only other hostile factor for the Axis powers."
Another new apartment house will be erected in the Washington Square area as a result of a deal reported yesterday.

The bombing duel between Germany and England continued almost unremittingly through October. Washington warned Vichy government against surrendering French possessions in this hemisphere, and advised Americans in Far East to return. Registration for the draft began.

Investment bankers can look back over 1940 with satisfaction over their progress and accomplishments toward obtaining some relief from the stringent regulations that, for seven years, have tended to strangle their industry. They look forward to 1941 with greater hope and expectations that many of their technical problems will be alleviated by Congressional action than at any time since the great "reform" movement began in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Ortiz Echague, Paris correspondent for La Nacion of Buenos Aires for twenty years, has just arrived in the United States and will leave tomorrow for a tour of the Western Hemisphere to investigate for his newspaper the possibilities of continental solidarity during the present crisis.

ATLANTA, Jan. 1 -- Business in general in the Sixth Federal Re serve District during 1940 experienced one of its best years since 1929. It is estimated that retail trade for the year was from 8 to 12 per cent over 1939.

A $300,000 mosquito-control and marsh-drainage program will be carried on in eight Queens communities during the next three months by 3,000 WPA workers, Oliver A. Gottschalk, Acting Work Projects Administrator for New York City, announced yesterday.

Last year United States industry received its greatest assignment -- to help, intensively and quickly, in the national defense program -- and the electrical industry, according to Guy Bartlett of the General Electric Company, was "particularly conspicuous" in its response.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve System's plan to prevent inflation kept the monetary experts in Washington busy today explaining some of its technical aspects. Here are some of their answers:

Railroad preparations for defense consist primarily in anticipating the future volume of traffic and in putting properties in shape to move it efficiently, in the opinion of John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 1 -- The official Swedish reaction to President Roosevelt's comparison of United States help to Britain with Swedish shipments to Germany is given in a Foreign Office statement that since the beginning of the war "Sweden has carefully abstained from exporting war materials to any of the belligerents except Finland."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (Australian Associated Press) -- Because of Australia's dependence on overseas markets, it has been held commonly that business conditions throughout Australia merely reflect the world situation. However, experience in recent years tends to refute this view.

While there has been little change in the time required to turn a green apprentice into an expert craftsman, training specialists have devised methods for rapidly increasing the available time of skilled workers that can be devoted to defense production, it was reported among personnel executives.
The New York Rovers had it impressed harshly upon them yesterday afternoon that Christmas really does come but once a year.

BALBOA, C.Z., Dec. 31 -- While Central America's prospects for 1941 are not cheerful, yet they are not cheerless, compared with what appears to be in store for less favored regions. The European war has ruined the coffee market, which provided the surplus that meant profit and prosperity for these countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt was rated today as the third best American public speaker in the past century.

The debut of Stella Roman, the long awaited Rumanian soprano, in the title part, and the appearance of Karin Branzell as Amneris after an interval of eight years, were the distinguishing features of the cast of Verdi's "Aida," performed last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association.
New Year's Day contributions amounting to $1,972.10 from 127 donors lifted the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to a total of $221,989.69.

Export competition among nations surviving in the post-war world will be keener than ever before and American exporters are going to need all their ingenuity to maintain sales near normal levels, Alexander N. Gentes, assistant manager of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, widely known as an authority on foreign trade matters, predicted in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The annual Debutantes New Year's Ball was held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Presented as a dinner dance, the event drew a large group of debutantes from Manhattan, Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey, and was opened with a grand march led by Miss Aimee G. Russell, daughter of Mrs. Marie Johnson Russell of New York and Florence, Italy.

Last year United States industry received its greatest assignment -- to help, intensively and quickly, in the national defense program -- and the electrical industry, according to Guy Bartlett of the General Electric Company, was "particularly conspicuous" in its response.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve System's plan to prevent inflation kept the monetary experts in Washington busy today explaining some of its technical aspects. Here are some of their answers:

Railroad preparations for defense consist primarily in anticipating the future volume of traffic and in putting properties in shape to move it efficiently, in the opinion of John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 1 -- The official Swedish reaction to President Roosevelt's comparison of United States help to Britain with Swedish shipments to Germany is given in a Foreign Office statement that since the beginning of the war "Sweden has carefully abstained from exporting war materials to any of the belligerents except Finland."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (Australian Associated Press) -- Because of Australia's dependence on overseas markets, it has been held commonly that business conditions throughout Australia merely reflect the world situation. However, experience in recent years tends to refute this view.

While there has been little change in the time required to turn a green apprentice into an expert craftsman, training specialists have devised methods for rapidly increasing the available time of skilled workers that can be devoted to defense production, it was reported among personnel executives.
The New York Rovers had it impressed harshly upon them yesterday afternoon that Christmas really does come but once a year.

BALBOA, C.Z., Dec. 31 -- While Central America's prospects for 1941 are not cheerful, yet they are not cheerless, compared with what appears to be in store for less favored regions. The European war has ruined the coffee market, which provided the surplus that meant profit and prosperity for these countries.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt was rated today as the third best American public speaker in the past century.

MONEY, money, money. The horse racing game churns it up in great quantities. There has come to hand a chart of the mutuel handle through the full seasons in the sixteen States that allow the parking of the "iron men" on turf premises. The chart makes marvelous reading.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 1 -- Peter Vasilyvitch Roshdesvadenski, the Russian journalist trapped by the Yugoslav secret police during Christmas week in a plot to seize the plans of Yugoslav frontier fortifications, was secretly removed from the Sofia Express on Tuesday morning and is still held within Yugoslavia, according to reliable information from political sources here tonight.

Chemists in the industrial and institutional research laboratories of the nation enter 1941 prepared to implement national defense by making available vitally needed materials formerly obtainable only from foreign countries, it was said in a review of the achievements of chemical science and industry during the last year made public yesterday by the American Chemical Society.

With increased admission scales prevailing in many instances the New Year's Eve performances brought in the highest nightly receipts of the year, a survey showed yesterday. Some of the more expensive tickets had to be disposed of at lower prices at the last minute, but no one seemed to mind.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a sales increase during 1940 of between 4 and 5 per cent over the preceding year. This was less than the national average gain for department stores, but the closing months of the year brought improvement here that narrowed the disparity.

Huge governmental expenditures for national defense, coupled with industry's ability to work out some of its own problems, made 1940 a satisfactory year so far as general business activity was concerned, H S. Wherrett, president of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, said yesterday in his annual review.

Henry Hobart Knox, in his letter published Dec. 28, points out the need for taking a stand on one side or the other on the question of aid to Britain, and at the same time leaves no question of his own choice, which is full aid to Britain. To that I heartily subscribe.

Now that the holidays are over, Columbia University Press comes along with the learned "Discussions of Holidays in the Later Middle Ages." Its author is Edith Cooper-rider Rodgers, who notes that in the thirteenth century, in addition to Sundays, there were at one time as many as forty holy days.

Negotiations looking toward collaboration of the Petain government with Germany have been in a virtual stalemate since Dec. 14, when the Marshal ousted Pierre Laval, his Vice Premier and Foreign Minister. Until then M. Lava had been the chief negotiator with the Germans.

Six Queens College instructors have been promoted to the rank of assistant professor, it was announced yesterday by President Paul Klapper. Taking effect as of Feb. 1, 1941, the advancements were approved at a recent meeting of the Board of Higher Education.

A substantial increase in America's stock of materials listed as "strategic" and "critical" for national defense took place during 1940, with imports in some instances rising to an annual average as much as five times greater than that of 1939.

Two sets of identical twins, each having almost the same name as his counterpart and so similar in appearance to their brothers that Navy recruiting officers could not tell them apart when they applied for enlistment, will be sworn into the service today at 2 P.M. at district headquarters, 90 Church Street.

Securities sold by railroads in the New York market expanded sharply in volume in 1940, reaching the highest total since 1936. Large orders for rolling stock provided a good volume of sales of equipment-trust certificates, while several railroads took advantage of conditions to refund senior issues at lower rates of interest.

ATHENS, Jan. 1 -- The Greek Army today began to infiltrate into the main Italian defensive positions in the Klisura region, taking over a series of fortifications protected by double lines of barbed-wire entanglements and concrete works, connected with each other by underground passages and defended not only by machine guns and automatic rifles, but by mortars and field artillery.

Of all the disruptions in the financial markets last year as the result of the war in Europe, the effects were probably the most paralyzing in the foreign-exchange market. In the first three months of the year all of the world's leading currencies, except the German mark, were active, as capital sought to flee from nations apparently threatened by German invasion.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 -- In the tenth annual New Year dinghy regatta begun today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club twenty-nine craft competed and the top scorers were Eddie Maxwell with his B Class boat Tu Tung Tu, Allan Clark with his D named Penguin and Forbes Morse with his Penguin Class craft Puck.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Governor M. Clifford Townsend offered the services of Indiana's labor division today to expedite settlement of a strike which is keeping 3,300 workers idle at the truck plant here of the International Harvester Company.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Hundreds of soldiers -- sappers or Royal Engineers and their junior corps, the Pioneers -- were drafted in London today to deal with destruction in the city done by German raids Sunday night.

BRIDGTON, Me., Jan. 1 -- A bright, cold day with a warm sun, providing a granular or corn surface on slopes and trails, gave the large throng of holiday skiers from the Eastern Slope area of New Hampshire to the Pleasant Mountain district here good sport today.

Department store and specialty shop credit results for 1940 were most satisfactory and credit executives look forward to this year with confidence, A.B. Buckeridge, executive manager of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, says in a special report for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Engineering construction awards for the week ending today amounted to more than $82,000,000, which is 54 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of last year and 10 per cent above last week, according to Engineering News-Record. It was the eighteenth consecutive week this year in which awards topped their respective volumes of a year ago.

Not long after the end of the World War a new crime appeared in the American calendar. It was a crime that could be committed only by the middle-aged and elderly. It consisted in not "sympathizing" with "youth." For two decades mature persons, of ripe experience, skill and judgment, have been cowed and browbeaten by the young.

MONTREAL, Que., Jan. 1 -- Canadian stocks registered sharp losses in 1940, as the markets were able to regain in the second half of the year only a small part of the ground lost in the first six months when prices broke sharply on that series of Allied reverses that had their climax in the collapse of France.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Paramount will resume film production in Great Britain early this year with two pictures, "Hatters Castle," by A.J. Cronin, and Sir James Barrie's "The Admirable Crichton," the studio has announced.

ATHENS, Thursday, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A government Spokesman said today that Greek troops had driven the Italians from strongly fortified positions in the mountains around Klisura, Southwest Albania, and seized great stores of war material.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 1 -- While defense spending turned to the interior in volume not until late in 1940, several thousands were added to payrolls with much larger increases indicated for arms plants and other government activities in 1941.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 31 -- The economic and financial outlook of Chile for 1941, like that of other Latin-American raw-material producing countries, is very indefinite and after fifteen months of war in Europe is dependent more than ever on the development or the results of the conflict which has already severely shaken the economic structure of South American nations.

Department store and specialty shop credit results for 1940 were most satisfactory and credit executives look forward to this year with confidence, A.B. Buckeridge, executive manager of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, says in a special report for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Engineering construction awards for the week ending today amounted to more than $82,000,000, which is 54 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of last year and 10 per cent above last week, according to Engineering News-Record. It was the eighteenth consecutive week this year in which awards topped their respective volumes of a year ago.

It consisted in not "sympathizing" with "youth." For two decades mature persons, of ripe experience, skill and judgment, have been cowed and browbeaten by the young.

MONTREAL, Que., Jan. 1 -- Canadian stocks registered sharp losses in 1940, as the markets were able to regain in the second half of the year only a small part of the ground lost in the first six months when prices broke sharply on that series of Allied reverses that had their climax in the collapse of France.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Paramount will resume film production in Great Britain early this year with two pictures, "Hatters Castle," by A.J. Cronin, and Sir James Barrie's "The Admirable Crichton," the studio has announced.

ATHENS, Thursday, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A government Spokesman said today that Greek troops had driven the Italians from strongly fortified positions in the mountains around Klisura, Southwest Albania, and seized great stores of war material.

Reviewing what it termed the gains and losses to civil liberties in the past year, the American Civil Liberties Union, in a statement issued yesterday, predicted widespread attempts by the forty-three State Legislatures meeting this year to restrict the rights of minorities and labor "in the alleged interest of national defense."

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Stanford University's magicians of the gridiron swept to victory for the tenth consecutive time today as the Palo Alto eleven reached the peak of a spectacular comeback campaign with a stunning triumph over Nebraska in another stirring chapter in Rose Bowl football history.

British and Allied successes, coupled with the United States policy of supplying required materials of war, are likely to stimulate market psychology, in the opinion of Raymond Allen, chairman of the Montreal Stock Exchange. These factors, he believes, "may shake the market out of the inertia which has characterized it since the evacuation of Dunkerque.

Both in defense requirements and in fields far removed from defense, plastics entered a vast number of new uses in 1940, and research and production experts predicted even further expansion of their use in the years to come. Defense requirements found the industry in good productive capacity both despite and because of a swift acceleration in adoption of plastics to new uses in domestic fields.

War uncertainties and fluctuating political fronts in a dozen countries "present perplexities for owners of securities which cannot help but find reflection in market prices and activities," William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange declared in a year-end statement.
The Southern big game fishing season is getting under way with a rush, and with the opening of the annual Metropolitan Miami Fishing Tournament the season will be officially launched.

"The Philadelphia Story" established the second highest attendance record for a week at the Radio City Music Hail, where it was seen by 183,435 persons during the week ending Wednesday night. The record mark was made by "Top Hat," which, during the Labor Day week in 1935, played to 186,069 persons.

Contributions totaling $1,339 reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from 189 donors, thereby bringing the amount that has been received in response to this twenty-ninth annual appeal for the most needy persons in New York to $223,328,69.
Some pertinent information furnished by the China Emergency Relief Committee tells the story of a nation that is building for the future even while it meets today's dreadful emergency of the war.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 2 -- A bitter attack on President Roosevelt has been made by the German Ambassador to Turkey, Franz von Papen, in his latest speech to the German colony, although higher German official circles at home have so far maintained reserve concerning the President's address.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Lone Star Gas Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration and application under the Holding Company Act regarding the proposed borrowing of $26,000,000 from eight banks and trust companies.

The Public Service Commission reserved decision yesterday after a stormy public hearing during which it learned that 550 tenants of the Parkchester housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the Bronx could not obtain telephone service because of a jurisdictional war between two labor unions.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 2 -- The most rugged isolationist in the country would prefer to see the United States guarantee a negotiated peace in Europe rather than have the country involved in the war, Senator Vandenberg of Michigan said today, but he added that he believed such a choice does not yet confront the country.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 2 -- The line from the old World War song, "Oh! How I hate to get up in the morning," was meaningful to the 18,000 members of the Forty-fourth Division here today, when reveille at 5:45 o'clock this morning marked the resumption of the training period after the holiday recess.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 -- Survivors of the ship sunk by German raider in the Pacific today complained of shocking conditions on board. The Misses M.R. Black and Flora McDonald, who had been on the liner Rangitane, said they and thirteen other women were kept for three days in a room below the waterline only twelve feet by ten, though suffering from shrapnel wounds.

Operations of the International Shoe Company in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 resulted in net earnings of $6,473,612 after taxes and other charges, or the equivalent of $1.93 a share on 3,350,000 common shares. In the previous year the company earned $6,588,209, or $1.97 a share.

FOOTBALL went into the end zone on New Year's Day and the hockey fans, fight followers, basketball boosters, track and field addicts and baseball rooters fervently hope it will stay there quietly and keep out of the way until next September. But the gridiron game certainly went over the goal line in a blaze of glory. And where there was so much fire, there is still some smoke lingering over the field.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Britons received notice today that they will have to tighten their belts another notch because there is a shortage of meat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Vice President Garner returned today to the capital minus his wide-brimmed sombrero and went almost immediately to see President Roosevelt. The White House said the meeting was arranged by request of both the President and Mr. Garner.
The Harlem Savings Bank filed yesterday plans for a two-story bank and store building at 700-702 West 181st Street to cost $400,000. Cross Cross are the architects.

Scoring 16 points late in the first period while holding its opponent to 4 and assuming a 28-13 lead at half time, the unbeaten Long Island University basketball team defeated Davis-Elkins, 54 to 42, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night. It was the ninth victory for the Blackbirds.

MADRID, Spain, Jan. 2 -- Britain and Spain have reached an understanding covering the safeguarding of extensive British interests in Tangier, it was learned today. The British Consul General in Tangier came here a few days ago and it is understood a convention will be initialed as soon as Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner recovers from his present illness.
BIG SPRING, Texas, Jan. 2 -- A Navy patrol bomber carrying two men was unreported tonight hours after five crew men leaped from the plane in a storm, one to his death. Three others were injured.
Trading was only fair yesterday. Non-kosher meats were steady to higher and kosher meats steady to slightly lower. Supplies were liberal to light.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 3 -- The great shipyards and factories of Bremen from which come the warships, submarines and long-range bombers with which the Nazis harass Great Britain's seaborne commerce were showered with bombs and turned into a blazing inferno on Wednesday night in one of the most devastating raids of the war, the Air Ministry announced last night.

Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, appealed for the extension of this work as an aid to democracy at a luncheon yesterday in honor of the thirtieth anniversary of his service as an executive in the organization.

VICHY, France, Jan. 2 -- Fourteen former French leaders awaiting trial on "war guilt" and other charges today were removed to Southern France from a prison hotel at Pellevoisin because the latter was "too uncomfortable and less than twenty-five miles from the nearest German troops."
PANAMA, Jan. 2 -- Panama's new Constitution became effective today and at a monster meeting in the National Stadium the ceremony of allegiance was led by President Arnulfo Arias.

The telephone subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation operating in ten foreign countries gained during 1940 the largest number of telephones in any one year in their history, obtaining a net increase estimated to be more than 87,000 telephones, compared with one of 73,532 in 1939, the corporation has reported.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

The recent Associated Press dispatch from Washington showing that strikes in the United States during the last six months of 1940 were fewer than during the corresponding period of 1939 and far fewer than during 1917, when we were actually at war, is a sufficient answer to the outcry of labor baiters for legislation to outlaw strikes and curb the valuable work being done by the National Labor Relations Board.

Although the country's merchant marine is expanding at a rate far in excess of that of any period except the World War, the future of the industry is uncertain because it depends on the course of the present war, according to Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, who reviewed activities of shipping in a report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said at a press conference today that work by the Ordnance Cord was already beginning to turn this country into the "arsenal of democracy" which President Roosevelt demanded in his radio address Sunday night.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Dartmouth's hockey team scored its third victory of the season, defeating Colgate, 2 to 0, at the Playland Casino tonight. Part of a round-robin which has Boston College as the third contender, the game opened a three-night program here for the Hanover Indians.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 2 -- Puerto Rico is awaiting three major Presidential appointments early in the new year and reports from Washington are that Mr. Roosevelt without consulting island leaders already has selected a Governor to succeed Admiral Leahy.

In their various speeches and messages on New Year's Eve Reichsfuehrer Hitler and his lieutenants boasted that final victory was within their grasp, that the British Isles and the British Empire would crumble at their own selected moment.

PEIPING, Jan. 2 (AP) -- An apology by the Japanese gendarmerie for their "unlawful arrest" of five United States marines in a cabaret incident last Monday was demanded tonight by Colonel Allen H. Turnage, the marine commander here.
