Nine factory buildings on a tract of about sixteen acres at Elmwood, Conn., in the Hartford industrial area, have been sold by General Motors to a syndicate headed by Irwin S. and Henry I. Chanin. They were occupied by the New Departure Company of Hartford, a General Motors subsidiary and makers of ball bearings and coaster brakes, before its removal to Bristol, Conn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Bill Tobin, president of the Black Hawk hockey team, said tonight he would file a report to the National League president, Frank Calder, regarding last night's incident in which a spectator was felled by the fists of Jimmy Orlando, Detroit defense player.

"We are not directly or indirectly feeding the Nazi war machine," Mrs. Frederick H. Ecker, president of the American-French War Relief, Inc., 1 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared yesterday in a statement of policy intended "to dispel false rumors and confusion linking our group with the Vichy government.
The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company announced yesterday a new employees' pension plan, superseding a retirement allowance plan in effect since Jan. 1, 1915.

Not the least interesting fact emphasized in the dispatches in THE TIMES'S Annual Financial Review yesterday was their description of the course of Europe's financial markets during and after the French surrender. It might have been imagined that, while France had become a helpless captive and Britain's fate remained undecided, speculative and investment markets in those countries would have closed the year around 1940's lowest prices.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Aircraft Production, today announced that United States bombers are being flown across the Atlantic "in a steady stream."

Documents published by the Dies committee yesterday show that the German-American Bund has maintained a private police force, each member of which is required "within the limits of the law * * * to render absolute obedience and unreserved loyalty to his Fuehrers."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 2 -- The announcement made by the Italian Stefani news agency that German air contingents had arrived in Italy to participate in the Mediterranean struggle was welcomed by the Bulgarian press today as good news. Political and diplomatic circles considered it a valuable New Year's present from Reichsfuehrer Hitler to Premier Mussolini.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Roosevelt, in a letter to Representative Cole of Maryland, made public today, requested Congress to enact legislation assuring protection of this country's oil supply as an adjunct to defense efforts. Mr. Cole is chairman of the subcommittee of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

Nicolas Nabokoff's "Sinfonia Biblica" was played for the first time anywhere at last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Dimitri Mitropoulos guest conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. The symphony is dedicated to Mr. Mitropoulos, who conducted the work, as all else on his programs, without score.

The Civil Liberties Union, reporting on events in its field during 1940 and looking ahead into 1941, is afraid that State Legislatures this year will violate the rights of labor unions and other minorities "in the alleged interest of national defense."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- Bertrand Russell began his work today as a member of the faculty of the Barnes Foundation in Merion, a suburb, but a distinction was drawn as to what newspaper reporters and photographers should be admitted to his opening lecture.

"Our people are not gullible," says Senator Wheeler. Why then does he try to beguile us? We are not deceived by those who proclaim that the avoidance of war is now our chief aim. Of course, we hate war. So do the English, yet the avoidance of war is not their chief aim. Theirs is the defeat of the Axis powers, the destruction of Hitler. That aim is also ours.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:
DUBLIN, Jan. 2 -- The new year has been ushered into neutral Ireland (Eire) with a baptism of bombs that has created public anxiety concerning the days ahead.

Five ambulances of the British-American Ambulance Corps, 420 Lexington Avenue, which were formally named the "Thumbs Up Cavalcade," will leave today for San Francisco on a tour to raise funds for medical supplies and airplane ambulances for the R.A.F. and Great Britain's Allies.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- No photo finish ever unchained more confusion than the announcement today, just as New Orleans racing was being smashed under an auctioneer's hammer, that a group of "civic minded" men had stepped in at the twenty-fifth hour to save the Fair Grounds track.

Pointing out that 1940 closed with industrial operations in the United States at the highest rate ever reached, and with the clear prospect that they will move still higher in 1941, the National City Bank, in its January survey of business and financial conditions, estimates that 1940 will show an industrial output exceeding 1939 by 13 per cent, and 1929, the previous record year, by 10 per cent.

The first patients in the new $3,500,000 Triboro Tuberculosis Hospital, Parsons Boulevard and Grand Central Parkway, Jamaica, Queens, were two men transferred yesterday from Queens General Hospital and ten men from Kings County Hospital.

In recent months, the outstanding characteristic of the steel industry has been the consistently high rate of operations, ranging from around 70 per cent of rated ingot capacity in the first quarter of 1940 to more than 90 per cent in the last quarter, with an average ingot production for the year slightly in excess of 80 per cent of rated capacity, according to Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation.
Count won Luckner, Germany's "Sea Devil," who was credited with sinking twenty-five Allied merchant vessels in the World War, said that his success had not caused the loss of a single life.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that the President hopes that after this war "we shall have the sense to say there shall be no more armaments."

BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- An official report of the German High Command reviewing military events since the signing of the armistice with France on June 25 states that since that day the combined actions of the German Navy and air force have sunk 190,000 tons of British ships of war, while the total merchant tonnage sunk in that period is estimated at more than 3,900,000 tons.

In view of the Administration's previous monetary policies the special report of the Federal Reserve System might fairly be described as a bombshell. But it is a bombshell that explodes to excellent purpose, that will destroy an unhealthy situation; and it is accompanied by a full set of plans for reconstruction.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The tone of the stock markets was firm today and the first working day of the new year saw a slight improvement in the volume of business. The gilt-edge section once again was the best feature. War Loan 3 1/2s closing at the wartime peak of 103 3-16.

Mrs. Catherine Watson, 63 years old, wife of a shipyard executive, was beaten to death about noon yesterday in her apartment on the fourth floor of 404 Sixty-first Street, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, after she had attempted to fight off her atttacker.

Thirty students at Brooklyn College and other city colleges have been subpoenaed to appear before private hearings of the Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local school system, it became known yesterday. Many of those called are members of the American Student Union.

President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Frank C. Walker will be petitioned to include Henry Bergh, founder in 1866 of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, among the noted Americans whose portraits are to appear on postage stamps in the year 1941, by a resolution adopted unanimously at the society's annual meeting yesterday at its headquarters, 50 Madison Avenue.

To acquaint the public with the extent to which it serves the aircraft industry and the defense program, the Bendix Aviation Corporation will resume its national magazine advertising, Herbert L. Sharlock, director of public relations, announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 -- At the close of 1940 business in the Pittsburgh district was at record high levels, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The seasonally adjusted index of business in the week ended Dec. 28 stood at 142.3 per cent of the 1923-25 average, unchanged from the preceding week.

Early discovery of best-sellers will be highly important for Spring in order to forestall possible delivery delays which may come about with expansion of the national defense program, according to merchandisers here. Most stores are planning to gear Spring orders to probable sales increases of 5 to 10 per cent.

Jacob (Jack) Bernoff, 34 years old, an ex-convict, former partner and stooge for Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro in the garment industry racket of a few years ago, and before that of Larry Fay in the old milk industry shakedown racket, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday by Judge Streit in General Sessions as a long-missing grand jury material witness.

Bank clearings of twenty-three leading cities of the nation in the five-day week ended on Wednesday declined 6 per cent to $5,761,046,000 from $6,128,036,000 for the corresponding week of the previous year, according to Dun ]radstreet, Inc. The latter, although a five-day period also, ended with Jan. 3 and therefore had the benefit of firstof-the-month and year-end payments for two days.

Few parts of the London of his time can appear in the headlines without calling up mental footnotes from Dickens. No part of the metropolis is so redolent of him as the City on which the Nazi bombs rained down.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 -- The first punt blocked on Tennessee in six years proved to be the wedge that opened the way for a Boston College victory in yesterday's magnificent Sugar Bowl battle.

VICHY, Jan. 2 -- Although conversations still are proceeding between the German authority and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's government -- and incidentally giving rise to the wildest rumors -- it nevertheless seems clear that, despite all talk of "collaboration," intercourse between France's occupied and unoccupied zones is more than ever strewn with obstacles.

BERNE. Switzerland, Jan. 2 -- After having temporarily died down over the holidays, reports are once again beginning to reach informed diplomatic observers here of further military developments in the Balkans.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- Units of the German Air Force have come to Italy to join the campaign against the British, while the Italian corps on the English Channel has been called back to help in the struggle, it was announced today.

An appeal for "the mobilization of America for war" in the form of "an open letter to Congress" was made public yesterday by Dean G. Acheson, Washington lawyer; Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York; and James P. War-New York banker and author.

"Battle of Angels," the Theatre Guild's production of the Tennessee Williams play, starring Miriam Hopkins and directed by Margaret Webster, will close for repairs in Boston on Saturday night of next week.

Prizes were awarded yesterday in several classifications of large poultry, bantams and pigeons at the annual New York Poultry Show, which opened on the preceding day at the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

ATHENS, Jan. 2 -- The news from the front tonight is not sensational, since bad weather has again developed to slow Greek manoeuvres. Despite this, it is announced that new villages have been occupied in the northern sector and that renewed Italian counter-offensives had been checked over the entire front. Some prisoners and machine guns were captured.

Robert N.E. Megaw, 20-year-old Duke University student and son of the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, pastor of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, 174th Street and Wadsworth Avenue, returned to his home, 884 Riverside Drive, Wednesday night, following a two-month disappearance, during which the youth believed he was dying of cancer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of four rules under the Investment Company Act of 1940 and two rules under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 regarding the filing of annual reports with the commission and the transmission of reports to stockholders by investment companies registered under the Investment Company Act.

A British vessel giving the name Galgora reported at 5:10 P.M., Eastern standard time, yesterday, that she had been torpedoed in the Atlantic at Lat. 22.30 N., Long. 21.00 W., according to Mackay Radio.

The adoption by the New York Academy of Medicine of a five-year fund-raising program, to increase the endowment fund of the academy by $1,250,000 to carry on without curtailment its multifarious projects in the fields of public health and medical education, was announced last night by Dr. Malcolm Goodridge, president of the academy, in his inaugural address commencing his second two-year term.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) Triumphant Stanford and vanquished Nebraska headed home tonight from the twenty-sixth edition of the Rose Bowl football series.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Savings deposits in Canadian chartered banks amounted to $1,625,878,000 on Nov. 30, compared with $1,599,464,000 on Oct. 31 and $1,734,837,000 on Nov. 30, 1939, according to the monthly bank statement issued today by the Finance Department.

MADRID, Jan. 2 -- Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, retired, United States Ambassador to France, was the guest of honor tonight at a dinner given by his colleague, Ambassador Alexander W. Weddell, with whom he is staying. Spanish Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner, who is ill, was unable to attend, but Francois Pietri, the French Ambassador, was among the guests.

Although loans of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city increased $28,000,000 in the week ended on Dec. 31 to a new high level on the movement at $3,121,000,000, on the basis of figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the combined figure of loans and investments dropped $25,000,000 to $10,298,000,000.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- In the final compilation announced today by the officials of the college week ski tournament of the Lake Placid Club, C. Allison Merrill of New Hampshire was the high individual scorer and New Hampshire captured the team trophy with a score of 837.4 points. Dartmouth was second with 787.9.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of Rule N-6 C-7 under the Investment Company Act of 1940, temporarily exempting certain registered investment companies from the requirement that their independent public accountants be selected by those directors of the company who are not directly concerned in its management.

The showing presented yesterday afternoon by B. Altman to the fashion press was unusual in that it dealt with the designs of one man and but a single theme. About a dozen variations on a new pajama-skirt, the invention of Charles James, well-known designer in London.

Judge Parker of the United States Court of Appeals is chairman of the Special Committee of the American Bar Association on Improving the Administration of Justice. In his address to the Nebraska State Bar Association he makes many wise recommendations and suggestions.

Forty-six new members of the Nu Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa at Hunter College will be initiated formally into the national honor fraternity at 6:30 o'clock this evening in the college's assembly hall at 695 Park Avenue. The principal speaker will be Dr. Jacob Hammer, Associate Professor of Classics, who will talk on "Cassiodorus, the Savior of Western Civilization."
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Smashing British bombing raids on Italian objectives in Africa, including besieged Bardia, were reported today by the Royal Air Force Command.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Britain was said reliably tonight to be urgently seeking additional United States destroyers for convoy duty and to use as anti-submarine patrols on her transatlantic lifelines.

An itinerant ragpicker and scavenger who for the past five months lived in a dingy store at 614 East Eleventh Street was found dead there yesterday amid its squalor, with a handful of coins in his pockets. But beneath a battered iron bureau the police found five bankbooks that showed the recluse had $26,098 on deposit under various names in four banks.

A suggestion that the wine and liquor industry develop an educational and promotional program this year to win back the public confidence and respect it has lost through recurrent price wars, was made here yesterday by Harold J. Grossman, educational and sales promotion manager of Julius Wile Sons Co., and author of "Grossman's Guide to Wines, Spirits and Beers."

A survey to determine whether business here benefited in the Christmas shopping season by the advance in the Thanksgiving Day observance has been undertaken at Mayor La Guardia's order and a comprehensive report will be available within a few weeks, George A. Sloan, City Commissioner of Commerce, announced yesterday.

Carrying only one transatlantic passenger and 1,819 pounds of mail, the Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways landed at the marine terminal of La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon at 1:24 o'clock, completing a much-delayed trip from Lisbon. The plane was under the command of Captain Robert Ford.
DUBLIN, Friday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A single unidentified plane bombed this capital of neutral Ireland before dawn today, injuring at least twelve persons and damaging houses.

The principle that the workers in a dress factory have the right to demand efficient management as a condition of employment will be written into the collective agreement covering 85,000 unionized dressmakers in this city if five employer associations accept the proposals put before them yesterday by Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L.

VICHY, France, Jan. 2 -- France's 40,000,000,000-franc budget for the first quarter of 1941 is so bulky a document of fifty finely printed pages that it takes much study for any comprehension. An analysis, however, reveals many interesting items.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Wholesale prices showed a marked advance in the week ended on Dec. 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 79.9, compared with 79.7 on Dec. 21 and 79.4 the year before.

The Brooklyn Adolescent Court, 31 Snyder Avenue, believed to be the only tribunal of its kind in the country, handled 1,699 cases during 1940, or 229 fewer than in 1939, according to preliminary figures, made public yesterday, from the annual report of James Monahan, chief clerk.

Verne Marshall, head of the No Foreign War Committee, apparently incensed over printed versions of Mexican oil deals in which William Rhodes Davis participated, announced yesterday that the committee had asked Mr. Davis to explain publicly the background of these ventures in detail.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- George Raft's four-month suspension from salary at Warners will end in four weeks, when he returns to the studio to star in "Danger Zone," reportedly a remake of the 11937 "Slim," the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Beardsley Ruml will be chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for 1941 and Frank J. Lewis will be chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System announced.

Applications to list the following securities are pending before the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange: 325,189 additional $2 par common shares of the Hayes Manufacturing Corporation; $55,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent debentures of the National Dairy Products Corporation, due 1960; $20,000,000 convertible 1 3/4 per cent debentures of the Phillips Petroleum Company, due 1951; and 75,575 no par capital shares of Vanadium Corporation of America.

The paper industry in 1940 had the most productive period in its history, according to a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by E.W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association. Total paper and paperboard production last year, estimated by the association at over 14,200,000 tons, was in excess of 1939 production by over 5 per cent, and for the fourth time since 1929 exceeded all previous productive records.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved the joint application of the Wisconsin Securities Company of Delaware, the Columbia Construction Company, the Marion Finance Company and the Terrace Finance Corporation for approval of plans for the divestment of their present control and their ownership of securities of the Mississippi Valley Public Service Company and the Eastern Oregon Light and Power Company, electric utility operating subsidiaries.

Traffic on the interstate bridges and tunnels under its control reached a new high of 27,395,000 in 1940, the New York Port Authority announced yesterday. Gross revenues from these crossings exceeded by $702,000 the highest previous totals. This was announced at the annual Port Authority meeting, at which Frank C. Ferguson was re-elected chairman and Howard S. Cullman vice president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Washington was awaiting today the return from London of two United States Maritime Commission officials before proceeding further with the proposal for American ships to take over some British routes in the Pacific so that vessels serving the latter might be diverted to supplying England.

A motion to dismiss a damage suit brought against Adelphi College by a former department head was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadlen Jr. As a result, this suit and two others involving $61,000 are set for trial Monday morning before a jury in the Nassau County Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Organized labor's status in some of the defense industries which came to the fore in the closing weeks of 1940 will be a subject of outstanding moment in 1941.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Bulgaria will be forced to allow German troops to move across Bulgarian territory if such a demand should be made, official quarters said tonight following reports of increased Nazi pressure aimed at reducing Bulgaria's ties with Russia.

Thomas J. Curran, the newly elected chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, made a beginning yesterday in reshaping his organization by securing the resignation of Gabriel L. Kaplan as chairman of the law committee of the county committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The United States made $56,000,000 worth of "political" loans last year to European countries and decided to lend $95,000,000 to China. Of the European borrowers, one country, Finland, was attacked by Russia; two, Norway and Denmark, have been occupied by Germany, and another, Ireland, is being held by Canadian troops.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, West Africa, Jan. 2 -- A submarine which came upon us in mid-afternoon on Dec. 21 fired two torpedoes without he slightest warning, despite the fact that Panama flags were painted on both sides of our ship, and left the Charles Pratt a blazing, sinking hulk.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers charged yesterday the initial infringement of its catalogue by the broadcasters. It alleged that on the regular Wednesday night program of Fred Allen, comedian, the song entitled "Wintergreen for President," with music by the late George Gershwin and lyrics by Ira Gershwin, had been used at the start and finish of the broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Among the firms reported yesterday as having taken new commercial quarters were the Standard Aircraft Products Company, Inc., and the Jefferson-Travis Radio Manufacturing Corporation, who leased 16,000 square feet each in the building at 374-80 Second Avenue.
All-Americans who place great store by their press clippings were strangely missing from The United Press's All-Bowl team named yesterday.

Compulsory use of government grades on all beef, pork, veal and lamb sold in the city, and the licensing of retail butcher stores, issues once hotly debated and then dropped, are being revived by the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Department of Markets.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The British had no confirmation tonight of reports that the Bulgarians had consented to a German demand for passage of troops.
BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- Negotiations between the Reich and the Czech-Moravian Protectorate over tribute to be levied for the second year of occupation have concluded, it was learned here today.

The biography of William Henry Welch, the pathologist and bacteriologist who became the first dean of Johns Hopkins Medical School, has finally been completed. Dr. Welch died in 1934 in his eighty-fifth year. One of his early students at Johns Hopkins, Simon Flexner, director emeritus of the Rockefeller Institute, and his son, James Thomas Flexner, are the authors of the life study of the great medical figure.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 -- Thoughts of things that might have been were still running through the minds of the Fordham football players and the rest of the party today as they made the first stop on their round-about trip home from their Cotton Bowl game with the Texas Aggies at Dallas yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Belief is growing here that the President will soon appoint an Assistant Secretary of War for Aviation, to energize American airplane production in the same way that Lord Beaverbrook stepped up British airplane production.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx announced yesterday that he would ask the March, 1940, grand jury, when it reconvenes today, to return first degree murder indictments against three men for the fatal shooting of Irving Penn, 42-year-old music publisher, on July 28, 1939.

The defense emergency has directed attention to the possible retarding effects that State barriers to trade may have on the movement of military equipment and supplies, according to a special summary on "Interstate Trade Barriers -- Today and Tomorrow," prepared exclusively for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Frank Bane, executive director of the Council of State Governments.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Friday, Jan. 3 -- Differences between Germany and Soviet Russia over their interests in Bulgaria appeared to offer the main hope to this country for retaining its independence, informed sources declared today.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year.

Two hundred and twenty-five classes are to be dropped in the New York City school system starting with the Spring term, Feb. 3, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. One hundred of this number will be in the high school division, the rest in the elementary department.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Slammin' Sam Snead of Hot Springs, Va., is regarded by many players as the man to beat in the Los Angeles $10,000 open golf tournament, starting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Psychiatrists from half a dozen States met here today at the invitation of Dr. Clarence A. Dykstra, director of the Selective Service System, to help in setting standards designed to keep out of the new Army all who are mentally disqualified to serve.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Local authorities on things mammalogical were still discussing with scientific amazement today the case of Frankie the Fox -- henceforth to be known as Frankie the Marvel of Mammalian Mnemonics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The record-breaking Seventy-sixth Congress virtually came to a close tonight, passing to the Seventy-seventh Congress, which will convene at noon tomorrow, big problems of taxation, defense, foreign policy and monetary legislation.

One hundred prints selected by the Society of American Etchers will be shown, beginning on Tuesday, at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries. This show constitutes the thirteenth annual exhibition of its kind. The prints were chosen from the recently closed twenty-fifth annual exhibition of the society at the National Arts Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Roosevelt had full advance knowledge of the recommendations of the Federal Reserve Board for extensive Congressional revision of monetary legislation, Stephen Early, White House secretary, said today, but he has not given his approval to the proposals.
R.E. Crummer Co. Inc., announced yesterday the offering of $14,000,000 of noncallable 4 per cent refunding bonds of four counties in Florida.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- What American diplomats insist was merely a friendly and casual reference to Sweden in the President's radio speech last Sunday night has nevertheless increased the belief in Swedish circles that the plight of their country and the determined measures it has taken to maintain democracy with neutrality are not understood in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Federal Trade Commission, in its annual report for the fiscal year 1939-40 published today, repeats its warning of last year that the concentration of economic power in the United States, in which corporate consolidations have been an important factor, threatens fundamental alteration in our economic structure and has already created far-reaching social maladjustments reflected by "increasing unemployment and narrowing markets."

After gains of 3 to 6 points had been registered in the early trading prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary yesterday and closed a point higher to 5 points lower than on Tuesday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Henry Friedberg's Montsin, a mare that scored with ease in her last outing here, today began her campaign as a 5-year-old by winning the Sunny Isles Purse, feature of the Tropical Park program, on which seven of the eight favorites were beaten.

Renewed demands for a real home rule for New York City were made upon the State Legislature by Mayor La Guardia last night as he taxed the last Legislature with having failed to meet a single problem vital to the city.

Any hopes that the Eastern ski fraternity entertained for good sport this week-end will be frustrated unless the weather man gives a helping hand starting today. And the prospects for a sudden change are not too encouraging, either, for the forecast calls for snow mixed with rain and also freezing temperatures.

Horace E. Dunham, chairman of the nominating committee of the New York Curb Exchange, announced yesterday the nomination of Fred C. Moffatt to be chairman of the Exchange for a one-year term, to be elected at the annual meeting of the Exchange on Feb. 10.

The National Society of Professional Engineers is composed of practitioners in all branches of the engineering profession. It has chapters in most States, and there are five chapters in New York City. Among its membership are engineers who have designed and supervised the construction of bridges, buildings, foundations, mechanical and electrical equipment, sanitation and housing plants, roads, and all other works composing the mechanized basis of our intricate civilization.
Painters and others of artistic temperament seem to show much greater stability as tenants than the average New York family.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 2 -- Unconfirmed reports from fishermen at Ulcen, on the Adriatic, late today described the sinking of three more Italian merchantmen by a submarine. The fishermen told the authorities how the merchantmen had been attacked Tuesday at dusk outside coastal waters northwest of Ulcen.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Circulation of the Bank of England was reduced 1,049,000 as the holiday demand for currency subsided, the bank's weekly statement showed today.

Two points regarding the pilot training program of the Civil Aeronautics Board are raised in a letter printed elsewhere on this page: Are those who enter the course required to enter the military service? And how good is the safety record of the project?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Export-Import Bank, that recently created branch of government which in addition to promoting United States foreign trade makes political loans to further good-will abroad and with it security at home, authorized some $300,000,000 of new advances in 1940.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Lighter supplies of live hogs and more active buying by all interests imparted strength to that market today and prices ran up 10 to 15 cents over Tuesday's average. The practical top was $7.15, attempts to push it up another nickel failing. Cattle were strong and sheep 15 to 25 cents higher.
A visiting Illinois Wesleyan basketball team will face undefeated N.Y.U. at the University Heights gym tonight in the Violets' seventh game of the season.

Once more, either as diversion or portent, the spotlight in this kaleidoscopic war shifts southward. Rome admits that German units are reinforcing the Italian air fleet. This may be another move on Hitler's part to regain the prestige his ally has lost. It may herald a two-pronged and two-dimensional expedition to renew the attack on Greece.

They are doing the best they can to scare the innocent theatregoer at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. Using an old ghost story by R.E. Spencer as his source-book, Kenneth White has written a nightmare and Guthrie McClintic has directed and produced it as if he believed in it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- While plans were being completed for conferences between Walter P. Reuther, divisional chief of the United Automobile Workers of America (Congress of Industrial Organizations), and government officials in connection with the union's proposal for mass production of airplanes in automobile plants, some management engineers and economists attached to the National Defense Advisory Commission said today that they differed with criticisms of the Reuther plan made yesterday by other Defense Commission attaches.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Prices of wheat held within narrow limits today and, while the expected demand for flour failed to materialize, there was a little buying of the May by brokers who frequently act for mill and cash interests. Favorable weather conditions in the main producing area over the holiday led to some selling of the June early.

The expulsion of one active member of the Association of Foreign Press Correspondents on the basis of allegations in the Dies committee "White Paper" that he was an unregistered German propaganda agent, the resignation of another while under similar charges, and the resignation as an associate member of Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General in New York City, were revealed yesterday in the association's official bulletin.

The first business session of the new year failed yesterday to give any evidence that the stock market would alter its course presently in any major fashion. Gone again was the better interest manifest toward the end of 1940, with trading volume the smallest in a month and a return of nervousness.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of Selective Service, announced tonight a call for 7,826 registrants to report Jan. 20 to 24 and Jan. 27 to 31, inclusive. New York City will supply 4,623 of the registrants and up-State, 3,203.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Higgins of 166 East Seventy-fourth Street gave a dinner with dancing last night on the balcony of the Iridium Room of the St. Regis to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Anita van Lennep Higgins.

We must now face the truth, with the knowledge, as the old proverb says, that the truth will make us free. In order to arrive at this truth let us leave out of consideration that American public opinion overwhelmingly supports our national policy that we will not let England die. For this crisis that confronts us is not alone an English crisis. It is an American crisis.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 3 -- Although most of Britain was comparatively quiet during the past night, one town in South Wales received major attention from German bombers.
If you will amplify two of the statements in your editorial on civilian pilot training it will probably result in an increase in applications for this training service.

The year-end statements of condition of commercial banks were issued yesterday and showed that many institutions had established further new record highs in deposits and in total resources in their respective histories. The continued movement of foreign funds into New York figured importantly in the increased deposits.

The first point of the eight suggested by Senator Wheeler as a working basis for a just peace" is interesting. It proposes restoration of Germany's 1914 boundaries, with an autonomous Poland and Czecho-Slovakia.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 -- The Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs announced tonight that Mexico would not send a special delegation to Washington for President Roosevelt's third inauguration. It is presumed that the Mexican Ambassador in Washington will represent President Manuel Avila Camacho.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- Contracts for the manufacture of 180,000 mackinaw coats, 584,000 pairs of khaki trousers with finished bottoms and 665,000 flannel shirts were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today. The original quantities sought by the government on these negotiated contracts were 200,000 mackinaw coats, 1,000,000 pairs of trousers and 650,000 flannel shirts.
Wall Street discussed the program of monetary legislation proposed by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, with considerable reserve yesterday.

The second and final Junior Assembly of this season will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dance will be attended by the majority of the debutantes of the Winter, as well as by some of the young women who made their debuts last season.

ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Texas Ranger, a liver and white pointer, turned Wildfair Plantation into a happy hunting ground and whisked to the $1,000 inaugural quail championship of the Southern Field Trial Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Luzerne County Gas and Electric Corporation of Kingston, Pa., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $7,500,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds due on Jan. 1, 1966.

Families living in the city-financed section of Vladeck Houses on the lower East Side show a much higher average income than those who are tenants in the Federally financed units, according to statistics contained in a booklet on this project just issued by the New York City Housing Authority.

William Allen White announced in Emporia, Kan., yesterday his resignation as chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies. He said he would retain the post until a successor was chosen. The new chairman may be selected within a few days.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, when informed yesterday that a report was current that he intended to resign before the close of the Winter, announced he had no intention of quitting his term of office, which expires at the end of this year.
E. Francis Whelan has been elected president of the United Profit-Sharing Corporation to replace William T. Posey, who has retired to devote himself to private interests.

The first trade on the New York Stock Exchange this year was 200 shares of Radio Corporation of America common stock at 4 5/8, unchanged from the last price of 1940. A year ago Coty International started the ball rolling. From a volumn standpoint, Radio appears to have more right to the rail position; it was the eleventh most active stock last year, trading 1,944,300 shares; Coty International traded 141,000 shares in 1940.
Win, lose or draw, tonight will be a big event in the life of Tami Mauriello, "Fordham Flash" of the boxing world.

Wagner's 'Die Walkuere" received its third presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a cast which differed essentially from that of the previous performances of the work this Winter. Kirsten Flagstad, who had appeared as Bruennhilde at the earlier hearings, sang Sieglinde.

The future security of this nation depends on England's winning the war, a substantial majority of American voters believe, and their views are heartily in accord with those of President Roosevelt that the defense of America is closely linked with the defense of Britain, a new survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Army prepared today to ask the new Congress for an additional $3,000,000,000 to further its armament program.

The new Congress that convenes today meets at a critical moment in this nation's history. Decisions of far-reaching importance must be made by it. Not often in the lifetime of the American people has any Congress assembled under circumstances which compelled it to accept a heavier responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- About 70,000 railroad employes whose minimum wages will be increased to 36 cents an hour on trunk lines and 33 cents on short lines March 1 will benefit by more than $7,000,000 annually, Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Law, said today.

Mr. and Mrs. Orson D. Munn of the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria gave a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the hotel. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Alex J. Pagel, Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Noyes, Mrs. Vanderbilt Fair, John Warburton and Giuseppe Russo.

A single oil painting by the late F. Luis Mora constitutes an exhibition that will open with a preview today and to the public tomorrow at the Grand Central Galleries in the Hotel Gotham. This work will continue to be shown through Jan. 11.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 2 -- With more than 8,500 men back from Christmas furloughs, the Twenty-seventh Division was back in training harness today, taking to the muddy drill fields in a rain which did not let up until this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Housing facilities at Fort Dix, N.J., for the Forty-Fourth Division, composed of New York and New Jersey National Guardsmen, will be completed on or before Jan. 10, and other emergency construction there is moving, rapidly, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said today.

Sutton House, the fifteen-story apartment structure at 327-337 East Fifty-seventh Street, was sold at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday for $600,000 to the Presidents and Directors of the Manhattan Company. The parcel, including the 122-by-100-foot plot, was put on the block pursuant to foreclosure proceedings brought by the Manhattan Company against 333 East Fifty-seventh Street, Inc., in which the judgment was $765,646.

The "Christian Front" indictment against the five remaining defendants of the seventeen charged with a conspiracy to overthrow the government and seize its property was nolle prossed in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday before Judge Mortimer W. Byers.

The flotation of $15,000,000 of Crucible Steel Company of America 3 1/4 per cent debentures lifted the total volume of new bonds offered to the public this week to $30,528,250. This compares with only $9,500,000 marketed last week, and with $22,494,000 floated during this week a year ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- The Air Defense Command, which was organized a year ago from units of the United States Army Signal Corps, Air Corps and Coast Artillery, announced here today detailed arrangements for a test Jan. 21 to 24 of a new defense against bombing attacks on communities between New York and Boston.

A collection of rare water-color paintings of reptiles of British Guiana made in the field during the William Beebe expeditions of 1916-24 into the jungle region surrounding the headwaters of the Mazaruni River will be placed on view at 10 A.M. tomorrow in the Head and Horns Building of the Bronx Zoological Gardens, it was announced yesterday by Allyn R. Jennings, general director of the park and Aquarium.

To every division and bureau of the Department of Justice, the Attorney General says in his annual report of its activities, the needs of national defense have brought new business. Formal and informal opinions on many ramifications of this cardinal matter have been given.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The official Tass agency tonight branded as "pure invention" a report that the Soviet press had published a New Year's message from Joseph Stalin analyzing the international situation.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- An authoritative German economist told foreign correspondents this morning that for the outcome of this war Canada could not be expected to play a role that in any way may be viewed as decisive.
AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Thomas Cefalo, who escaped from an Auburn prison road camp in 1927 and "made good" in the intervening years, came back today to face the music.

On New Year's Eve the Police Department tried out new signal boxes in Times Square. More are now to be installed, and the experiment will be watched with interest. For these boxes are intended to control the movement, not of vehicles, but of pedestrians. Designed to supplement the traffic lights, they blaze out the brilliantly illuminated admonitions "stop" and "walk," as traffic movement makes appropriate.

Rogers Guillory, 28 years old, a Negro was puzzled yesterday when he was leaving General Sessions, escorted by two deputy sheriffs, about how he was going to serve three possible life terms that just had been imposed on him by Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A defense of the National Labor Relations Board and its administration of the Labor Relations Act, and condemnation of the report made several days ago by the majority of the House Committee investigating the board, was made today in a statement by the minority of the committee, Arthur D. Healey of Massachusetts and Abe Murdock of Utah.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- Jimmy Thomson's long range siege guns stood the field on its head today as he blasted out a sub-par 68 over one of America's toughest golf courses to move into a two-stroke lead at the end of the first round of the $10,000 Los Angeles open tournament.

Underwriters are preparing for an exceptionally active January in respect to new bond financing. More than $200,000,000 in new corporate loans is "on the fire" and, with the aid of accelerated registration periods, most of this material is expected to reach the market this month.

John Steinbeck has completed a new book tentatively called "Sea of Cortez," an account of a long cruise the author took about the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico. It will be a Viking Press book and will be out "some time this year."

Panama Al Brown, the slender, spunky Negro boxer who reigned for years as recognized bantamweight champion, found himself in a spot yesterday where he couldn't fight, and for probably the first time in his life he didn't even try.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- All classes of cattle sold actively at prices ranging from strong to 15 and 25 cents higher today. Fresh receipts were small and all interests were purchasing. Hogs were 10 to 25 cents higher and fat Iambs steady. Choice steers were wanted in the cattle pens but were not available.

Samuel Cooperman, 42 years old, owner of the Cooperman Dress Shop, 637 Madison Avenue, plunged eleven stories to his death yesterday morning from the observation roof of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, seventy floors above the street, after he had bought tickets that he did not use to the tower there and to that of the Empire State Building for more than a week.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- A "Ball for Britain and Her Allies in England" was given tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford under the patronage of Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the Honorable Arthur H. James, Governor of Pennsylvania; Miss Dorothy James, daughter of the governor; Hon. Robert E. Lamberton, mayor of Philadelphia and Mrs. Lamberton, with the British Consul General of Philadelphia, L.M. Robinson and Mrs. Robinson.

VICHY, France, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Navy Ministry announced tonight that the French submarine Sfax and the naval tanker Rhone were torpedoed Dec. 19 by a warcraft of undetermined nationality while en route from Casablanca, French Morocco, to Dakar, French West Africa.

Captain Harold V. McKittrick, recently appointed captain of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, arrived here yesterday to take over his new post, which will be vacated Monday when Captain Laurance N. McNair, its present holder, leaves for Washington for a new assignment.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Three nephews of Daniel Gimbel withdrew today after a three-day hearing their contest of his will disposing of an estimated $3,800,000.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3 -- United States Vice President-elect Henry A. Wallace's private secretary James D. Le Cron, and the Naval Attache of the United States Embassy, Commander Wallace M. Dillon, narrowly missed a serious accident today when the engine of the airplane in which they were taking off from the military airfield near Mexico City Airport failed at a critical moment.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Australian troops storming the Italian fortress of Bardia, Libya, already have taken more than 5,000 prisoners, or one-fourth of the garrison, the British Army Command reported tonight in a special communique.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- During the week ended Dec. 28 sales by department stores showed an exceptionally large increase of 59 per cent over the corresponding week of 1939, largely because of the two Christmas shopping days not likewise present in the week of Dec. 30, 1939, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

An offering on Tuesday of $6,911,000 of water-works bonds of Oklahoma City, Okla., bids for which were rejected last March because of litigation, will bring new municipal issues scheduled for sale next week to $21,814,765, compared with $12,949,196 this week.

More than 3,000 reserve enlisted men of the Regular Army will be called from this area for active duty by Feb. 15, it was announced here yesterday at the headquarters of Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, Second Corps Area commander, at Governors Island.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 3 -- An all-round technical reaction occurred on today's Bourse. Hesitancy by buyers was mainly due to New York's overnight dullness. Americans -- especially armament shares, which dropped as much as $2.50 -- were affected. United States Steel closed at 71 7-16.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 3 -- Conflict between early reports that victims of German raiders in the Pacific received humane treatment and the stories of suffering told yesterday were explained by the fact that the first arrivals were confined on the raider going by the name of the Manyo Maru, on which conditions were much better than on the supply ship Tokyo Maru and the raider Narvik.

"Many a Slip," the fifty-second annual production of the Princeton Triangle Club, had its first New York presentation last night before 1,500 persons at the Al Jolson Theatre, Seventh Avenue at Fifty-eighth Street. Its stand here will be rounded out today with a matinee at 2:30 P.M. and an evening performance at 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Chicago Great Western Railway today to issue new securities to carry out a plan of reorganization for the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company, its predecessor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issue of $28,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first-mortgage bonds series C, due on Jan. 1, 1961.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Negotiations reached final stages today for John Kruger to produce a screen version of Leonard Q. Ross's "Adventures in Washington" under the title "Washington Correspondent" for United Artists release.
BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Leading all the way, the Boston Olympics defeated the New York Rovers, 3 to 2 tonight in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game before 9,500 fans at the Boston Garden.

DUBLIN, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Troops of neutral Ireland tonight were manning highway barricades thrown up against any invasion as the government sent an "energetic protest" to Germany against the bombing of Irish towns and countryside.

Retail trade here showed a post-holiday let-down this week. Department-store volume was estimated as running about 5 per cent under the like week of last year. Poor sales on Thursday, particularly during the night opening, were a major factor in the decline.

Muriel Kerr, who had not appeared on the local concert stage since 1934, was heard in a piano recital last night at Town Hall which attracted a large and responsive gathering. Miss Kerr, who was born in Canada and came to this city as a young child, made her debut on a Schubert Memorial, Inc., program in 1928 in Carnegie Hall.

Charged with practices "inimical to democracy," the New York Teachers Union, consisting of 6,000 public and private school teachers, was called upon yesterday by the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers to show cause why its charter should not be revoked.
In your recent editorial entitled "College Budget" you say "the time may soon come when students will have to pay more than they do now toward the cost of their education."

Detectives investigating the death of Hyman Weinberg in his junk shop at 614 East Eleventh Street discovered yesterday that his name had figured on both the city and Federal relief rolls while he owned bank deposits of more than $26,000. Officials of the Department of Public Welfare announced that suit would be brought against his estate to recover relief money paid him by the city in November and December, 1935.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 4 -- Widespread enemy air activity struck Britain during the past night.

The performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House saw Lawrence Tibbett's first operatic appearance of the present season in the title part. An indisposition had obliged Mr. Tibbett to cancel engagements of some weeks.

Thorough understanding between Britain and the United States is vital in the present crisis, and the task of the British Ambassador in Washington is heavy. It would be unfortunate should the understanding be clouded and the task made heavier by a lack of sympathetic attitude toward the Ambassador, especially if this be due to misinformation or false assumptions.

Manchester, largest manufacturing city of Lancashire, the premier industrial county in England, after undergoing sporadic bombing has recently been treated to a dose of Hitler's concentrated Blitzkrieg, as were Coventry and Birmingham somewhat earlier. But do the German bombers perceptibly divert the thoughts of its citizens from accustomed channels?

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Andover Academy and Northwood School played overtime tonight to reach the final round of the fifth annual Northwood invitation prep school hockey tournament. Andover staved off at determined bid to beat Milton Academy, 5 -- 4, and the host school barely edged out Choate, 2 -- 1.

WITH THE GREEK ARMY, In Northern Albania, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Greece's outnumbered airmen, who dive on Italian infantrymen in these wild mountain passes, "throw sticks and stones and even old boots" at the Italians when they run out of bombs and machine-gun ammunition.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Tension was mounting steadily tonight in the Balkans. In an atmosphere already charged with fear and apprehension created by the new German troop movements into Italy and Rumania, the Reich has reopened with increasing force its diplomatic offensive against the South Slav States of Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.

Officials of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers said yesterday that it had received many complaints -- possibly upward of a thousand -- that its music had been played over various radio stations in violation of copyright regulations.

In large and small amounts, 124 new gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund, amounting to $3,718.53, were received yesterday, raising the total of contributions to the twenty-ninth annual appeal in behalf of the most distressed individuals and families known to exist in New York City to $227,047.22.

CAIRO, Egypt, Saturday, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Britain's Army of the Nile has opened its final assault on Bardia, whose "fate is about to be sealed," it was stated officially today after Australian troops and swarming tanks had broken through the defenses of Italy's encircled Libyan base.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Rescued from a terrible grave and reconditioned for fighting purposes the powerful British submarine formerly known as the Thetis and rechristened the Thunderbolt, has torpedoed and probably sunk an Italian undersea craft, according to an Admiralty announcement today.

Retail trade was off this week, but the drop was much less pronounced than usual as consumer interest shifted from holiday goods to January sales and clearances, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale activity also held up better than was to be expected, while industry returned quickly to pre-holiday production levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A House committee, headed by Representative Tolan, which has been investigating interstate migration reported today that new streams of migrant workers were flowing to centers where the rearmament program was creating new jobs.

With metropolitan teams holding a 5-to-4 edge over visitors in competition to date, another intersectional college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight will send Fordham against North Carolina and Long Island University against Michigan State.

With all but one classification registering a gain, total advertising linage in eight New York newspapers for December increased 2.9 per cent over the like month of 1939, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

They're at it again. We mean the anti-firearms group, and this time the rumor has it that they have the Department of Justice all excited about what the Fifth Columnists will do if firearms aren't registered.

SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Pluma Louise Palmer today recorded a deed conveying to her father-in-law for $2,389 all her "property title rights, interest and claims" under wills of her late husband's grandparents.

Air raiders do not scatter bombs by mistake for two successive days on a neutral island. They do not return to the same beat by accident, dropping fresh loads of explosives at strategic points. The towns of Ireland are lighted at night and the sea separating its strongly defined coasts from the blacked-out and bigger island alongside is wider at the narrowest point than the English Channel.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Net profit of the British-American Tobacco Company for the year ended on Sept. 30 showed a drop of 300,012, according to announcement today. Although no reason was advanced for the drop, it was believed that one cause was the trade agreement by which Great Britain has been buying large stocks of tobacco grown in Turkey.

Burton Roger Walker is 37 years old, but still the "spoiled child" his indulgent parents pampered, Irving W. Halpern, General Sessions Probation Bureau head, told Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. yesterday in a report that preceded Walker's sentence to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years on a petit larceny charge.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two British towns, one in the Western Midlands and another in Southwest England, were assaulted heavily last night with explosives and fire bombs and raiding German planes flew repeatedly over London for targets beyond the metropolis.

Finding expected resistance in an old rival, Manhattan's basketball team swept to a 56-38 conquest of Cooper Union with a late rally last night at the Jaspers' gymnasium. It was the sixth victory in seven starts.

WHAT this observer doesn't know about current basketball society would fill a big basket, but Irish eyes are smiling, indicating that everything is well with what Bo McMillin, the football man, calls "the round ball game." Ned Irish is the fellow who puts on the college double-headers in Madison Square Garden and makes a good thing of it for all concerned.

Mrs. Alma Clayburgh and her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Hooper Grew, gave a reception with music last night at Sherry's for Mr. and Mrs. Andre Maurois. During the evening there was a musical program by Pierre Luboshutz and Gina Nemenoff, pianists, who presented compositions by Mozart, Bach, Handel and Rimsky-Korsakoff.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A great shipbuilding program aimed at the construction of 200 additional merchant vessels at a cost of $300,000,000 to $350,000,000 was announced today by President Roosevelt.

Physicians all over the country are well aware of the important function that the New York Academy of Medicine serves in the city's and nation's life. But the city itself does little more than admire the fine building at 103d Street and Fifth Avenue in which the Academy conducts its affairs.

More than 100 members of the American Peace Mobilization group left Pennsylvania Station at 6:30 P.M. yesterday for Washington, where they will protest to members of Congress against loans to Britain, the "no strike bills" and "discrimination" against Negro draftees.
Taking first place in six out of nine events, the City College swimming team scored an easy 50-24 victory over Scranton University in the Beavers' pool last night.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey announced yesterday that more than $28,000,000 would be spent for new construction, equipment and replacements in 1941 throughout its subsidiary operating properties. Of this sum more than $17,000,000 has been allocated to the electric division of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, making a toal of about $70,000,000 appropriated since January, 1937, for that end of the business.

No further information was available yesterday from the No Foreign War Committee or from W.H. Davis, independent oil operator, regarding the peace "agenda" which Verne Marshall said Mr. Davis had brought back from Germany a year ago and turned over to the State Department.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- W.L. Brann's Challedon and Charles S. Howard's Kayak II -- both now racing in California -- have been allotted top weights for the $50,000 added Widener Cup at Hialeah Park March 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Dies committee is investigating the transfer of money by the Central Bank of the U.S.S.R. to Germany and other Axis powers, and says that preliminary evidence would show that at least $15,000,000 was transferred from the Soviet bank to the Reichsbank in the past two months.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Elttaes Stables' Lavengro, 6-year-old black gelding, won today's feature event at Santa Anita, a sixfurlong sprint for $2,500.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 4 -- Despite freezing weather and blizzards that swept the Channel, the Royal Air Force returned to the attack on Germany Thursday night and last night, rekindling old fires in Bremen and lighting new ones in Emden and Amsterdam, where Nazi oil is stored.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Fort Dix received its official Army hostesses today. They arrived a little bit uncertain about what their duties will be, somewhat bewildered at the fuss and stir the occasion created. Hostesses are a new development in this present-day streamlined Army.

The consecration of the Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, as Titular Bishop of Cyrene and Auxiliary Bishop of New York, will be solemnized at 10 A.M. Wednesday, at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

After opening 5 to 8 points net lower, prices of futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered, and final quotations were unchanged to 3 points higher. The initial decline was attributed to heavy offerings by Bombay. When this had spent itself prices began a moderate recovery under steady buying by the trade.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Mrs. Dorothy Leary entertained with a dinner tonight at her villa.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Don Meade, who finally broke loose from a slump yesterday and scored his first victory of the Tropical Park meeting, continued the winning habit today when he booted Dorimar to a two-length triumph in the featured Daytona Purse of a mile and seventy yards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Declaring such action to be in the interest of national defense, Attorney General Jackson again asked Congress today to permit wire tapping to cope with saboteurs and foreign spies.

Grade labeling will be applied to the full line of canned fruits and vegetables put out by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Company, it was announced yesterday. The step was taken following a series of conferences with the National Consumer-Retailer Council.

Allan Nevins, Professor of American History at Columbia University, the author of many books on history and biography, has been called to Oxford University as Harold Vyvyan Harmsworth Professor of American History. He plans to sail this morning on the American-Export steamer Siboney, it became known yesterday.

Plans for a "little theatre movement" to create outlets in school and club producing groups for the works being written by American composers for the lyric stage will be formulated at a meeting to be held by more than thirty leading writers of serious music, constituting a National Composers Committee, today at 2:30 P.M., in the Town Hall Club, under the auspices of the League of Composers.

It would surprise few of us if any day it is announced that the Park Department is preparing to put a new and greatly improved ocean off Coney Island. Pretty nearly everything else that can be imagined in the way of beauty treatment for popular beaches has been applied to Coney Island.
ROME, Jan. 3 -- British attacks in the Bardia sector of Libya were stemmed yesterday by the guns of the Italian troops entrenched in the city and by the air force, the High Command stated today.

Participation in the East-West all-Star football game at San Francisco last Wednesday made forty-three college athletes ineligible for further amateur competition as far as the Amateur Athletic Union is concerned, Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National A.A.U., announced yesterday.

Boris de Vadetzky, who married Hilda Jane Lehman, 19-year-old daughter of Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, at Elkton, Md., on Dec. 1, was a WPA actor and research worker from Nov. 6, 1938, to Nov. 24. 1939, the records of the Work Projects Administration in this city disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Abbey Hickey, 52 years old, of 514 West Fiftieth Street, went to West Side Court yesterday to plead leniency for her 18-year-old son, charged with malicious michief, but was herself arrested for felonious assault when a detective who had been searching for her for seven weeks recognized her in the complaint room.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Dartmouth suffered its first ice-hockey defeat of the season before 1,200 fans at the Playland Casino tonight, bowing to a smooth-functioning Boston College sextet, 4 to 3. The contest decided a round-robin in which Colgate was beaten twice.

Again we "Speak softly and carry a Big Stick." We are a modest people. We say nothing and saw wood. The skies are filled with airplanes and our streets resound to the rumble of armored tanks. Our factories, our arsenals for Britain, are working on 24-hour shifts.

A survey of Manhattan's "express streets" on their third anniversary yesterday showed parked trucks as principle beneficiaries. Moving traffic, little aided, was forced into midstreet lanes by commercial vehicles at the curb and occasional double parking.
VICHY, France, Jan. 3 -- Indo-China is to receive dominion status. A decree that will be published tomorrow provides that the French colony is to have an autonomous government.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Bids were opened at the Marine Corps Quartermaster Depot here today on 40,000 yards of 13-ounce, 54-inch green flannel; 190,000 yards of 16-ounce, 54-inch, and 75,000 yards of 22-ounce, 54-inch green kersey, all quantities being well oversubscribed by five participating bidders.

The dollar volume of the wholesale lingerie business for 1940 approximated the 1937 total of $91,000,000, the most recent available figure, according to Fareed N. Kiamie, president of Kiamie-Rosamond Manufacturing Co., Inc., while 1941, with more favorable piece goods prices and a rising curve of general business, should prove one of the best the industry has known for some time, he said.

John Taylor Arms, president of the American National Committee of Engraving, has announced the arrival in New York of a collection of fifty prints from Uruguay which are to go on a countrywide tour under the auspices of the committee.

Miss Emma Willets, 99 years old, a spinster, who lived with her brother, Leander, 90 years old, in a four-room apartment at 681 Lincoln Place Brooklyn, was found dead yesterday sitting in a chair beside her bed. She had been dead for more than four days.

The selection of Charles Chaplin by the New York Film Critics as the best screen actor of 1940 for his performance in "The Great Dictator" apparently does not meet with the approval of Mr. Chaplin himself. A formal invitation, sent to the actor at the Waldorf Towers, where he is staying, to receive the award at the critics' annual party tomorrow afternoon in the Rainbow Room has not been acknowledged.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- The predicted assault on Bardia began just after dawn today when Australian forces supported by tanks blasted through the outer defenses southwest of the Libyan town. More than 5,000 of the Italian garrison of 20,000 already have been captured, it was officially reported by the British.
Hirshon Co. have been organized as a New York Stock Exchange firm by Adolph B. Lichtenstein and Walter Hirshon.

A nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicates that American voters are no more satisfied with the present rate of defense production than defense leaders are themselves, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

Today's events: "Tannhaeuser," 2 P.M., and "Don Pasquale," 8:30 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Albert Spalding, lecturer, free lecture series, Carnegie Hail, 11 A.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra in a concert for young people, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 3 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Jerome Rappaport, piano, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; free orchestral concert, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8 P.M.; Georgette Nyrielle, soprano, Charles LaGourge Studios, 35 West Fifty-seventh Street, 8:45 P.M.
ROME, Jan. 3 -- Italian newspapers promised their readers today that German assistance, now forthcoming, would help transform military developments in Africa, in the Mediterranean and in Albania.

One of the principal factors in the 1941 program of the Continental Can company, Inc., will be inauguration of a $25,000,000 capital expenditure for expansion and improvement of manufacturing facilities in the next three years, J. F. Hartlieb, president of the company, says.

The recent reference to William F. Hoppe and Charles Peterson by John Drebinger in "Sports of THE TIMES" was especially interesting to one who has been closely identified with billiards for more than four decades.

The general business outlook for 1941 is good and the electrical manufacturing industry will experience gains at least equal to those of the durable goods lines, according to a survey by E.O. Shreve, president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, made among the organization's board of directors.

At a recent meeting of the New York County Medical Society Dr. Ramsey Spillman charged that the government, in order to save $135,000 in X-ray expenses, has sent 300,000 National Guardsmen to camps without adequate chest examinations, and has thereby assumed a risk of at least $36,000,000 in future liabilities.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Five French steamers lying idle here since the fall of France will sail soon for Marseille with cargoes of foodstuffs and other supplies, it was announced today, possibly in defiance of the British blockade.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Some British sources suggested tonight, in the light of the series of bombings in Ireland, that the Germans were trying to bring Ireland into the war on Britain's side.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The majority of the debutantes of this Winter, and several young women who made their debuts last season, gathered in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night with many of their young men friends for the second and final Junior Assembly of this season.

CHICAGO, Jan 3 -- Buying of wheat futures attributed to a milling concern was a feature of the trading on the Board of Trade here today and led to a belief that the long anticipated improvement in the flour demand had finally developed.

MADRID, Spain, Jan. 3 -- The Arriba, which, like other Madrid newspapers, has devoted much attention to the offering for sale in New York of William Randolph Hearst's collection of art and other works, served notice today on "all the Hearsts of the world" that never again would a whole Spanish monastery be packed and shipped out of the country.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The rise of British Government securities continued today and brokers were able to report a larger volume of business in this group. War loans took the lead, 3 1/2s going ahead to a new high level of 103 1/4. Several other issues advanced to new high levels since the Munich action.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- While the British are pleased with every expression from the United States promising "all aid short of war," they sometimes are disappointed in the performance although generally too polite or fearful of the consequences to say so bluntly.

William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks, yesterday formally notified all banks under his jurisdiction that official statements of condition were to be as of Dec. 31. His action was accompanied by similar bank calls by the banking supervisors of most of the other States of the Union.

Colors taken from the natural beauties of Nassau keyed the fashion presentation held yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Oval Room of the Ritz. The costumes were chosen from among the season's large output for their adaptability to the cruise season and to a visit to the Bahamas.

CLEMENTON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The National Collegiate Football Rules Committee gave the game's offense a break today with three major rule changes affecting substitutions, behind-the-line ball-passing and forward passes.

Tonight the orchestra under the direction of David Mannes will begin its twenty-third annual "season" of four January concerts in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is sustained by private generosity for public enjoyment. Instituted in 1918 for the relaxation of soldiers and sailors, it will hold overtones for those who are sickened and distraught by the cymbals of martial strains abroad.

The bronze weather-vane, emblematic of "the grand champion" of the New York Poultry Show being held this week at the Hotel Capitol, will decorate the barns of Henry P. McKean in Beverly Farms, Mass., following the decision of the judges yesterday at this display.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Johnson of California was sworn in for a fifth term today after refusing to allow Senator Downey, his Democratic colleague from California, to escort him to the well of the chamber for the ceremony.

The only third-term inaugural gown in the history of the United States is a scarlet sheer wool tailored daytime dress. It made its first public appearance yesterday when Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, having completed her final fitting on a trio of costumes for the occasion, posed at Arnold Contable for still and motion picture cameramen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Senate Campaign Investigating Committee listed today eight New Jersey officials and political leaders to be called at a post-election hearing here Wednesday, but did not include Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City among them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The new shipbuilding program announced today by President Roosevelt will call for ocean-going cargo vessels totaling 1,500,000 tons.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- Russo-German tension is seen in informed diplomatic quarters here as rapidly approaching the breaking point over the Balkans in general and over Germany's policy in Rumania and Bulgaria in particular.

The Giants lightened the load which they will take to the starting line of the 1941 National League pennant race by some 200 pounds when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced yesterday that Hy Vandenberg, tall right-handed pitcher, had been sold outright to the Cardinals.

A good cast and a little imagination will go far to bring new vitality even to an opera that is half dead. When these ingredients are mixed with a work that remains as fresh and as charming as Puccini's "La Boheme," you have a delightful afternoon in the opera house.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Barracks scheduled for occupancy on Dec. 17 are still uncompleted here, and the first movement of men of the Forty-fourth Division into wooden, centrally heated barracks is now set for "early next week."

Fog that had hung heavy over the city during daylight hours yesterday lifted somewhat at 7:30 P.M., enough to allow a partial resumption of air service in and out of La Guardia Field half an hour later.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A mysterious gray steamship, of unrevealed nationality and flying no flag, was reported off the Alaskan coast today.

VIENNA, Jan. 3 -- The visit to Vienna of the Bulgarian Premier, Bogdan Philoff, has caused many rumors in diplomatic and political quarters. Today he visited a stomach specialist, Professor Hans Eppinger. His illness includes acute stomach pains following grip.

IN "This Is the Schoolroom"* Nicholas Monsarrat says farewell to the Europe that Vincent Sheean charted with memorable clarity in "Not Peace But a Sword." It is a novel of one man's quest for certainties through a world sliding into chaos, and it is written in a way to suggest a medley of the age's styles, from Compton Mackenzie to William Gerhardi to Christopher Isherwood to Michael Arlen to Aldous Huxley.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 3 -- A signed agreement on the St. Lawrence power and seaway project will be ready for presentation to the United States Congress by the end of this month, it was predicted, following a second day meeting of the Canadian and United States members of the temporary committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Repeal of the export tax of $6 per ton on raw sugar and enactment of legislation to transfer to the Treasury of the Virgin Islands excise taxes collected on island products shipped to the United States are recommendations made by Governor Lawrence W. Cramer in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior made public today.
