The comeback W. Tilden P. Hazard, son of the late William A. Hazard, sportsman and salt mine owner, attempted a year ago when he turned his back upon more genteel occupations in Wall Street and went to work in a Third Avenue grocery, ended Thursday when he succumbed to illness in the LeRoy Sanitarium, 40 East Sixty-first Street.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Henry A. Wallace, Vice President-elect, just back from a long visit to Mexico, expressed a desire in an interview today to go to other Latin-American nations. Asked which ones he had in mind, he re plied: "All of them."
Extending its consecutive victories to seven, New York University's unbeaten basketball team turned back Illinois-Wesleyan at the University Heights gymnasium last night by 55 -- 39.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 3 -- Arrival of about 7,000 New York trainees to fill the ranks of the Twenty-seventh Division has been set for "immediately after Jan. 25." This was disclosed today when the staff and line officers designated to train the civilian increment met to complete plans.
EDINBURG, Texas, Jan. 3 -- Two naval airmen rode out a blind snowstorm last night in an ice-weighted bomber after five other members of the crew had bailed out, one of these falling to his death.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Princeton defeated Harvard, 10 -- 4, in the opening game of the annual "social hockey series" on Baker Rink tonight. The teams will meet again tomorrow night.

A plan to reorganize the executive group of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies by the election of several vice chairmen from various sections of the country and establishment of a policy board will be discussed at a meeting today of the executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), asserted in an address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System that some sections of the airplane and automobile industries were "secretly" attempting to prevent adoption of the proposal for mass production of aircraft in the automobile industry.

"Larceny Street," a Film Alliance picture produced in England, will open at the Central Theatre today, and is the sole arrival on Broadway screens over the week-end. Jack Buchanan and Elsie Randolph are starred in the melodrama. . . . "Night Train" enters its second week today at the Globe, as does "Hotel du Nord," the French film at the Little Carnegie Playhouse.

Thomas J. Curran, newly elected New York County Republican chairman, received yesterday the resignation of Gabriel L. Kaplan as chairman of the law committee of the county committee. Mr. Curran is expected to apoint Louis J. Lefkowitz, former Assemblyman, to replace Mr. Kaplan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Between Aug. 1 and Dec. 26, 1940, the United States shipped 140,000 bales of cotton to the Soviet Union via Vladivostok.

Final briefs in the contempt proceedings against five Brooklyn College professors were filed in Supreme Court yesterday with Justice Benedict D. Dineen by Paul Windels, counsel for the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the schools, and William G. Mulligan, Teachers Union attorney.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 3 -- The Fordham football squad tonight was speeding toward Jacksonville, Fla., where the Rams will spend tomorrow before resuming their homeward trip.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- As the Seventy-seventh Congress began its two-year life today at noon Speaker Rayburn told the House that American democracy must justify itself, in these days when democracy is on trial throughout the world, by achieving unanimity on the national defense and the national security.
Tami Mauriello's remarkable string of boxing victories came to an end last night in Madison Square Garden in his most important battle.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge William H. Holly denied today a series of defense motions in a civil anti-trust law case against seven companies engaged in the home insulation business.

DUBLIN, Jan. 3 -- The government of Ireland (Eire) announced tonight that a protest was being made to the German Government over the bombings of Irish territory over the last three days. The announcement followed a meeting of the Cabinet.

ATHENS, Jan. 3 -- The Greek campaign in Southern Albania is beginning to develop definite tactical advantages despite repeated Italian counter-attacks. Troops moving forward in the direction generally northwest of Khimara have forced a bulge in the Italian lines toward the Tepeleni-Valona road, and other units, pushing due west from positions north of Klisura, menace the road leading from that town to Berat.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe and Jake Schaefer, who have been dueling over the green baize for two decades, will unlimber their cues next week for a three-cushion billiard match which promises to be one of the most hotly contested battles in the history of the sport.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Roosevelt suspended today the eight-hour day for workers employed by the government in constructing naval and air bases on sites leased from Great Britain.

In his account of a recent basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden Louis Effrat had occasion to recall the feat of Pick Dehner of Illinois who two years ago set a court record for individual scoring by making 25 points against Manhattan.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The Babcock Wilcox Co. plant at Hobart Avenue and Fourth Street, here, was shut down today after 450 employes went on strike after a breakdown in contract negotiations between the company and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate.

VICHY, France, Jan. 3 -- Developments in the situation created on Dec. 13 by the dismissal of Pierre Laval from all his high offices in Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's government are beginning to be discerned. Four points stand out tonight:

Trading yesterday in fresh meats was considerably improved over Thursday. Prices were steady to higher. Supplies were uneven. Early kosher business was good and prices were strong to higher on beef; strong on veal and steady on lamb.

Improvements in ski conditions were reported from the North Country yesterday, the result of the wet to powder snowfall throughout the night. Points which had good bases, naturally reported that the added cover made for fair to good skiing.

M. Baudoin was the original Foreign Minister in the government of Marshal Petain. He held the post until Oct. 26, when he resigned to be replaced by M. Laval, and not long after became Secretary of State for the Presidency of the Council.

The President announced yesterday a program for building a fleet of 200 merchant ships of approximately 7,500 tons each, to be all of one design and prefabricated as far as possible. Owing to their method of construction they will be "eyesores," he fears, but this method will save as much as six to eight months in actual construction time.

A summons, packed in a neatly wrapped red and green holiday gift box, found its way back to Harlem Court yesterday after the Western Union Telegraph Company had failed, despite its gaudy trimmings, to serve it on the man to whom it was addressed.

Fordham's football team will be greeted more in the manner of a victorious group than a vanquished one tomorrow evening at 6 o'clock when it reaches Pennsylvania Station on its return from the New Year's Day Cotton Bowl game in Dallas, Texas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Roosevelt is sending Harry L. Hopkins, former Secretary of Commerce and former Administrator of Federal Work Relief, to Great Britain as his personal envoy to serve until a successor to Ambassador Kennedy is nominated and approved by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Officials said today they were not yet acquainted in detail with the labor situation in the British colonies involved, but that they expected the workers would be employed about ten hours a day and be paid time and one-half rates for work in excess of eight hours.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Orders from Second Corps Area Headquarters at Governors Island, it was announced here today, set forth that no Negroes would be included among men to be chosen this month for selective service.

Policies favoring quick action as the national defense program expands this year will be surveyed by merchandising executives of department and specialty stores at the thirtieth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania during the week of Jan. 13.

Lord Beaverbrook's announcement that American bombers are being flown across the Atlantic "in a steady stream" serves to emphasize once more the fact that if there is one branch of our defense program that is more important than any other it is the mass production of long-range bombers.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The General Motors Corporation filed today in Federal Court a third equity suit against the city of Linden, its assessors and the Union County Tax Board, asking that 1940 municipal taxes against its property be declared unjust.

For her professional debut at Madison Square Garden Monday night Miss Alice Marble yesterday was rated a slight favorite over her English opponent, Miss Mary Hardwick, while Bill Tilden, despite his long years of campaigning, still was conceded an excellent chance to upset Don Budge -- on his record the world's foremost tennis player.
One must be impressed by the plain statement of facts made by Bishop Cannon in his letter appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 22 under the heading "All-Out Aid to Britain."

In my opinion the brand of basketball played by New York teams suffers because of the habit of the local colleges of sprinkling their schedules liberally with set-ups. Most of the local schools play from five to ten easy games on schedules that average twenty games in length.

The railroads increased their orders for equipment substantially in 1940. This was in response to increased traffic and also was in conformity with the policy of the carriers to keep prepared for the needs of rearmament.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- The State Banking Department has issued an authorization to Brown Brothers Harriman Co., 59 Wall Street, New York, to continue to transact business as private bankers. The new certificate, issued under date of Jan. 1, was occasioned by the retirement of Robert A. Lovett, a partner.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Treasury spent about $9,800,000,000 in 1940, the largest amount in any year since the World War.

Germaine Lubin, French dramatic soprano, whose engagement for this season at the Metropolitan Opera House was announced before the season began, will be unable to leave her country to sing here, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday that his predecessor, George L. Harrison, who is now president and chief executive officer of the New York Life Insurance Company, has been selected by the bank's board of directors to serve the bank as a member of the Federal Advisory Council from the Second Federal Reserve District.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Democratic National Committee expended $2,438,091 and the Republican National Committee $2,812,003 in the Presidential campaign, they reported to the Clerk of the House today.

John Golden is gradually recruiting a cast of imposing caliber for his next offering, "Claudia," Rose Franken's dramatic conception of her own stories, due here early next month after a preliminary whirl out of town. Frances Starr, who last acted here in "The Good" (1938), and Donald Cook, who appeared under the Golden banner in "Skylark," just have been signed for the company, which also includes Dorothy McGuire in the title role.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

When you call something the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, you can depend upon it that the public will find a shorter title. The C.D.A.A.A. therefore became the White Committee. Strictly speaking, it is that no longer, for its chairman, William Allen White, though remaining in an honorary capacity, has given up his active leadership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The extent of American aid to Great Britain and her Allies in arms and munitions drawn from surplus stocks of Army material, was shown today in a report to Congress by Secretary Stimson. The Army sold for $22,929,438 guns, tanks, ammunition and other equipment in the year ended Oct. 15.

TUITION-FREE communications or radio classes have been arranged for four colleges in line with the policy of training men for national defense. The classes are part of the 250 short, intensive courses planned to meet the shortage of engineers for service as designers, inspectors and supervisors with the industries and government agencies engaged in the defense program.

Columbia's Winter sports campaign moves into high gear this week with the basketball, swimming and wrestling squads opposing traditional rivals, all on the Lions' campus. The quintet will meet Fordham on Wednesday night and Navy on Saturday night.

LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- American correspondents touring three factories in the North of England saw thousands of workers turning odd strips of metal into heavy-long-distance night bombers at a speed that would have seemed incredible a few short months ago.

DENVER, Col. -- From the border of Montana to the border of New Mexico a different kind of sportsman is on the trail -- the American who in years gone by tested his skis upon the paths of the Bavarian Alps.

There was just one thing lacking in President Roosevelt's heartening speech last Sunday. When he said we couldn't have business as usual and prepare adequately for defense and aid to Britain, he should have pointed out how every individual in our population of 131,000,000 could help.

NOTABLE for many new ideas in radio, the past twelve months was outstanding in the broadcast opportunities it brought to young American conductors and composers. More contemporary music was performed, much of it for the first time on the air.
SO full and in most ways so favorable is R.L. Duffus's review of "The Great American Myth" that I trust I my not appear ungracious in seeking to correct one or two impressions it is likely to create.
There was no discernible criticism among Yale alumni in New York yesterday of the end of the football tradition at New Haven that an Eli graduate should occupy the place of head coach.

The Netherlands people cannot be driven to accept a place of dependence in the Third Reich and they will free themselves from German rule as soon as the chance arises, E.N. van Kleffens, Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Netherlands Government at London, predicts in "Juggernaut Over Holland," a book on the invasion of his country, to be published Jan. 13 by the Columbia University Press.

TOKYO, Jan. 4 -- New Year's Day is the Japanese people's greatest holiday and they did not read their newspapers very carefully, which is a pity because on New Year's Day morning two items of great interest concerning the year's outlook were printed side by side.

The American home is the most democratic institution of all times and the American family is of the very essence of democracy, Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, United States Minister to Norway, said yesterday in a talk broadcast by the NBC Blue network between acts of "Tannhaeuser" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

This is the annual season that is January outdoors but June, July and August inside the Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue. This is the week, beginning on Friday night and continuing until Jan. 18, when upward of 150,000 will crowd into the National Motor Boat Show to have a longing and a yearning for those vacations and week-ends when they can cut wakes of foal across America's coves, rivers and lakes in their yachts.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Acting on the theory that the world needs a peace award most in wartime, the Guild of Former Pipe Organ Pumpers has decided to make up for the lack of a 1940 Nobel peace prize by conferring one of its own.

FORT DEX, N. J., Jan. 4 -- After weeks of "dry-firing," problems of reconnaissance, observation and position, the artillery men of the Sixty-ninth Brigade of the Forty-fourth Division next week will have the thrill of hearing the crash of high-explosive shells.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- With more than ninety organizations already scheduled to hold conventions here during 1941 and negotiations being completed with thirty others, Atlantic City looks forward to one of the greatest convention years in its history.

In the jacket blurb of this book reference is made to the "deft and dogged sleuthing" of Jack Jordan. You may take that with several grains of salt. Jack does a lot of sleuthing, but it does not get him anywhere until his wife, Trudy, makes a discovery which shows how the murder was committed.

The New York Community Trust made philanthropic grants totaling $222,964 last year, the largest annual total in its history, the organization announced yesterday. The amount compares with $205,028 in 1939. The trust's charitable disbursements in the last ten years aggregate $4,020,454.

THE technical division of the WPA Art Project is making a broad survey to find domestic sources and substitutes for imported art materials. The importation of these materials has been cut by the war and will face further restrictions.

Sparked by Claude Phillips, sharp-shooting red-headed sophomore, the City College basketball team bagged its third victory of the week by conquering Springfield College, 44 to 37, in the Beavers' gymnasium last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 4 -- The state of general apprehension continued in foreign diplomatic circles here tonight as the uncertainty of the Bulgarian situation wore on the nerves of Yugoslavs and foreigners alike.

In an attempt to foster in psychology students at Queens College an objective attitude toward their own reactions and those of their associates, the psychology department has been developing a program aimed at bringing them into close touch with the actual conditions influencing human behavior.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- One of the most difficult problems confronting British officials is the seemingly insoluble one of combating unseen German air raiders flying at great heights -- sometimes five to seven miles up -- under cover of darkness and far beyond effective range of anti-aircraft fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Harry L. Hopkins conferred with Secretary Hull on Anglo-American relations for forty-five minutes today prior to undertaking his assignment as President Roosevelt's personal representative at London.

DYNAMIC MAPS -- If S. Whitte-more Boggs, geographer of the Department of State, had his way maps would be devised to portray more effectively the great changes that have taken place throughout the world in the last century, largely as the result of improvements in transportation and communication.

PROFESSOR HOOTON'S studies of human behavior seem to have taught him, among other things, that provocative titles attract attention, and that the public rather likes than otherwise to be called bad names.

Rentals that are "too high" for La Guardia Field hangars are forced on the city by an "unbusinesslike" State law requiring amortization of the cost of the structures in twenty instead of forty years, Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday in dedicating the city airport's newest hangar.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 (British Official Wireless) -- A special Britisl .4rmy commuziqu today stated: Bardia -- Operations are proceeding satisfactorily and over 8,000 prisoners are now in our hands.

Johnny Fletcher and his stooge, Sam Cragg, are usually just about two jumps ahead of dire disaster. Sometimes it is nothing worse than lack of money that troubles them. Sometimes it is the police, who have a nasty habit of suspecting these two comparatively innocent book salesmen of every crime on the calendar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Edward J. Flynn as chairman announced today a reorganization of the administrative machinery of the Democratic National Committee. The step, he said, was forced by the Hatch "clean politics" law and similar State laws.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, New York, has reported to the Clerk of the House that it received contributions totaling $425,295 in 1940.

Add one more to the growing roster of alcoholic detectives. His name is Joseph South, and he doesn't like to be called Joey. Neither does he like to have his employers hold out information, which is what Stuyvesant Van Pelt does when he hires Joey to be Richard Raleigh's bodyguard.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 4 -- The outstanding result of the speech delivered a week ago by President Roosevelt as applied to public thought in this section is that it has regained for him the moral leadership of the nation as against the spokesmen for the isolationist point of view.

ROME, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Fascist Cabinet, meeting today under the chairmanship of Premier Mussolini, announced approval of a plan for more efficient control of Italy's foreign trade, both imports and exports. Details were withheld.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The defense program should break the back of unemployment by the end of 1941, according to Secretary Perkins, who made public her annual report today. The Secretary estimated that 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 jobs would be available in the next eighteen months for those now idle.

AS the new year begins, eyes are focused on the shoulders, which are giving the silhouette its 1941 cachet. The Chinese pagoda upward tilt is out -- you know, the one with the sleeve jutting beyond the seam and wads of padding under it.

THE year 1941 is getting off to a good start with carnivals and racing meets, sports events and other festivities, starring the days from now until the first Spring flowers. From Quebec's snowfields to Argentina's pampas, from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific, travel trails are filling up with skiers seeking the snow, swimmers chasing the sun and just plain travelers who aim to miss nothing along the special paths they have chosen.

With Mrs. Marshall Heminway as chairman, a junior committee has just been organized to assist with plans for the benefit performance of "The Daughter of the Regiment" on the night of Jan. 25 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over in the interests of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc.

BEFORE closing the ledger on 1940, this corner would like to dwell for a few paragraphs on some of the old year's more interesting pronunciamentos and to inquire rather wistfully what ever became of them after the first flushes of excitement subsided.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 -- A variety of subjects, including a young woman's part in the activities of a democratic government, will be presented at the second New England Junior Conference of the Federation of Women's Clubs here on Saturday.

ALTHOUGH vaudeville is on the way to becoming no more than an old-timer's remembrance, the Mauve Decade, one of its most febrile periods, once more is showing what made the Gay Nineties gay, as the theme of a broadcast both novel and entertaining.

A scientific study of the contents of newspapers published in twenty-eight cities indicates that for most of the press of the United States the common claim that today's newspapers are purely commercial enterprises, single-mindedly devoted to profit-seeking, "is a slander,'' Professor Edward L. Thorndike of the Institute of Educational Research, Teachers College, Columbia University, declares in a report made public yesterday.

The status of women in the world today will become the subject of a university course next term when the American University Graduate School in Washington, D.C., will include this topic in its curriculum.

PEIPING, Jan. 4 (AP) -- United States and Japanese officials stood firm tonight in their wrangle over blame for a cabaret incident Monday, each holding the other's forces responsible for the clash that ended in the arrest of five United States Marines by Japanese police.

"PLAYGOER" is justified in complaining of the "take it or leave it" attitude of many boxoffice attendants. My husband and I have not yet seen "Gone With the Wind" because of the almost insolent treatment we received at one of the foremost movie houses in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON -- In conjunction with the defense program attention has been turned recently to the training of unskilled workers, especially women, to step into specialized employment should the need arise. As an agency offering country-wide organization and established contact with unemployed persons available for this training, the Federal Relief Bureau is already functioning toward this end.

BELLEAIR, Fla. -- The Belleview Biltmore, on the west coast of Florida, will open for the forty-fifth season on Tuesday with supper dance. On the sports calendar will be golf, tennis, skeet and trapshooting, horseback riding swimming in the warm salt-water pool, sea bathing in the Gulf, boating and deep-sea fishing.

On his way to Rome after five months "sick leave," William Phillips, United States Ambassador to Italy, denied yesterday that he had "special instructions" for his embassy and declined to link plans for his wife to join him in "several months" with any expected change in the European war picture.

Jack Doyle, the Broadway oracle whose business is betting that the other fellow is wrong, predicted yesterday before departing on his annual jaunt to Miami that the Yankees and the Reds will win the major league pennants in 1941 according to The United Press.

BAYONNE, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Charles J. Post, Department of Labor conciliator, conferred here today with Lieut. Comdr. Davis, United States naval inspector at the local Babcock Wilcox Company boiler manufacturing plant, in an effort to learn the extent of national defense work under way in the factory, where a strike of 450 workers entered its second day.
Written from London by a well-known English author:

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 4 -- A bill was introduced in Parliament yesterday that will cause a big increase in the number of men under arms in Turkey. It provides for a year's extension of the period of service for conscripts of all armed forces.

DETROIT -- By and large, the automotive industry has abandoned its earlier ideas of "business as usual" in spite of defense work. Year-end statements by K.T. Keller and A.P. Sloan Jr., heads of Chrysler and General Motors, indicate clearly that these companies will place defense ahead of all other considerations in the months ahead.

Past and present events have shown that in times of political stress difficulties between administration, faculties and students are bound to arise. This points to a fundamental fault in our system based on diametrically opposed conceptions of the character and function of a university. "

CONTEMPORARY leaders of the Ecole de Paris are shown, frequently to particular advantage, in an exhibition that will remain current until Jan. 25 at the Pierre Matisse Gallery. "Landmarks in Modern Art," Mr. Matisse calls this show.

Why bats can fly through pitch-black caves without striking walls has been one of the major mysteries of science. Drs. Robert Galambos and Donald R. Griffin (Harvard) think they have solved it. Their experiments have convinced them that bats are warned of obstacles by hearing echoes of high-pitched sounds of their own making.

ANNOUNCEMENT has just been made of the result of the sixth annual Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship competition. The two winning contestants are A. Fleming MacLiesh of New York City and Mary Benton of Seattle. Wash., each of whom receives an award of $1,500.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Old Boston, starved for a major champion since Prizefighter Jack Sharkey fell before the haymakers of Primo Carnera and went into the business of mixing Tom Collinses, gave a riotous welcome to Boston College's Sugar Bowl victors tonight as 100,000 persons milled in and about South Railroad station.
OOLAGAH, Okla., Jan. 4 -- The Oolagah Oozings, "the world's most unusual weekly newspaper," the five-star final of the hot stove league, has ceased publication.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Senator Wheeler told a New York delegation of the American Peace Mobilization today that he would rather see the United States give war supplies to Great Britain than to lease or lend them. "Whene'er you lend, you lose a friend," he recalled.

Many patrons of Albert Morris Bagby's Musical Mornings have subscribed to the annual benefit concert of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, which will be given on the afternoon of Jan. 20 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

IF Eddy Duchin achieves all he has set himself out to do in the next ten years, he will become the ace of America's entertainment world. In his spare hours the 30-year-old conductor has found time to play classical concertos and Chopin's mazurkas, study dramatics, change the register of his voice and learn how to sing.

Friday, Jan. 31, has been selected as the date for the annual New York Hound Show, which will return this year to the ring of the Riding and Polo Club at 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, the scene of its early exhibitions. Recently the event was given in the Squadron A Armory.

TORONTO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Detroit's headlong rush in the National Hockey League race continued tonight when the Red Wings beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1, by the sheer tenacity of their attack. The victory moved Jack Adams's club to within two points of the league-leading and injury-riddled Leafs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Miss Elizabeth Stewart-Richardson, daughter of Major and Mrs. Robert M. Stewart-Richardson, and a granddaughter of the late Alexander M. Stewart of New York, was presented to society at a tea dance given this afternoon by her parents at the 1925 F Street Club.

One of the first French musician to be allowed to leave his country since its surrender to Germany in Zino Francescatti, violinist, who was a soloist with the Philharmonic last season. His task of getting here was anything but easy. His first problem was to obtain French, American and Spanish visas. This took weeks.

Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, spoke of present negotiations for revision of the Securities Acts in a round-table broadcast last night over the stations of the Columbia Broadcasting System. He spoke from Washington with Kenneth C. Hogate, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, and E.A. Pierce, a partner in Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt. in a program on "Present-Day Safeguards for the Investor in Listed Securities."

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- New concepts of the underlying idea and scope of social work demand that preparation in colleges for graduate study in this field be readjusted, with greater emphasis on government, Miss Katharine Hardwick, director of the Simmons College School of Social Work, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator, reported today that the USHA program would reach a peak of activity in 1941.

Despite assertions that the over-the-counter market has benefited greatly at the expense of listed markets, 1940 was not a good year for the unlisted field, according to Frank Dunne, president of the New York Security Dealers Association.

GERTRUDE LAWRENCE and Miriam Hopkins helped Boston to mark the arrival of the new year. Miss Lawrence is at the Colonial in Moss Hart's elaborate "Lady in the Dark." Miss Hopkins, returning to the footlights after a long absence in Hollywood, has taken up temporary residence at the Wilbur in the Theatre Guild's "Battle of Angels."

The largest number of passengers to come to New York from the Continent within a three-day period since last Summer will arrive here between tomorrow and Wednesday on four transatlantic liners from Portugal and Spain. More than 1,000 persons, including natives of Europe and citizens of the United States, are scheduled to be landed from the ships, two of which are of Portuguese registry.

On the final Sunday of the appeal in behalf of the most distressed persons known to exist in New York City, the 1940 Neediest Cases Fund reached a grand total of $229,084.22 today. The receipt yesterday of seventy-one contributions, amounting to $2,037, raised the total of the twenty-ninth annual appeal to that sum.

Now that the sciences have become, ironically enough, man's chief comforter in a world of stress, geology in particular may be shown to perform a valuable psychological function. Like history, geology is a study in perspective; it is, in fact, the longest perspective man is able to achieve on his past and probable future on the earth.

A NEW American singer recently appeared at the Metropolitan Opera House in a revival of Donizetti's old work, "The Daughter of the Regiment." But the small, sprightly, dark-haired soprano was no stranger to the audience. Ten years ago almost to the day an unknown French girl turned the Golden Horseshoe into a bedlam and was compelled to take sixteen curtain calls after the mad scene in "Lucia."

EMPORIA, Kan., Jan. 4 (UP) -- William Allen White figures that at 73 he does not have much time left to write a book or two and get at a few other little things which he has had in mind for a good many years.

THOSE who have been impressed with Miss Taylor Caldwell's "The Eagles Gather" and "Dynasty of Death," powerful novels dealing with the rise of modern munition makers, will no doubt be astonished to learn that in her latest novel Miss Caldwell harks back to "Emperor of All Men, Genghis Khan, the Mighty Ruler, the Rider of Heaven."

IN the very selection of the six names that form the subtitle for this volume the author reveals, despite some assurances to the contrary, that he has a thesis of "development'' to sustain as he surveys writers "who are broadly representative of certain characteristic tendencies in the Scandinavian novel of the past half century."

The thirteenth pig was the runt but he could get through any fence in the world even though it were hog-tight, horse-high, and bull-strong, and he was as slick as greased lightning -- hence his name, and hence his adventures. Zeke, aged nine, knew he was the best of the litter, but Zeke's father didn't think so and Zeke spent most of his time trying to save his "best friend" from his father's wrath.

A GENTLEMAN'S gentleman, heeding the demands of his calling, recently took farewell of his twelve-room house, stable of racing horses and assortment of motor cars, and sped here by plane from the West Coast to be at his master's side. The break with such surroundings is not easily made, but Eddie "Rochester" Anderson, Gentleman of the Second Part, is no ordinary valet.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- Visitors to California bring along good appetites. They spent $42,643,648 for meals in Southern California alone in the year 1939, according to figures collected by the leading tourist bureau of the State. In as much as Northern California is even more famous than this section for gustatory de-I lights, that would appear to mean that visitors to California expended almost $100,000,000 for food in one year.

The New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, is presenting as its free illustrated lecture this week a talk on "The Beauty of the Diatom World" by Joseph F. Burke, honorary curator of the organization, Saturday, at 3 P.M., in the Museum Building.

Tomorrow this country will witness a ceremony which has grown rare in this topsy-turvy modern world: a freely elected President going before a freely elected Legislature to recommend a program, which program the freely elected and freely acting Legislature may accept, reject or modify.

The Brooklyn College basketball team broke the team scoring record for the Brooklyn College gym last night, rolling up a 63-22 victory over the University of Newark five. The proceeds of the game went to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Petain government has put the new Syrian High Commissioner, General Henri Dentz, under the direct orders of General Maxime Weygand, apparently as a move to assure unity of action by the French Empire, come what may.

THE changes in the football rules are not hard to take. For instance, one of the reasons for making it legal to hand a ball forward in the football backfield was that the boys were getting away with it anyhow, and no officials were tooting their horns or whistles and penalizing the play.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Of unusual interest in connection with the thirteenth annual all-American air manoeuvres to be held in Miami on Friday, Saturday and Sunday will be a mock bombing competition.
A resident in the East Indies for many years, I read Hallett Abend's dispatch in your Dec. 30 issue with much interest. It may need clarifying.

An elaborate Spring training campaign was mapped for the Newark Bears yesterday together with the announcement of the 1941 exhibition schedule which reveals that the junior world champions have booked twenty-six games. Seven of these contests will be played with four major league clubs, the parent Yankee club appearing in two of these, while the Tigers, Red Sox and Phillies will provide the opposition in the remaining five.

A BELATEDLY issued 1940 stamp received last week commemorates the tenth anniversary, last Oct. 24, of the inauguration of Getulio Vargas as President of Brazil. This 400-reis gray-violet illustrates two Brazilian flags and the head of Liberty, and inscribed is "Pelo Brasil Uno e Forte!" (For Brazil One and Strong!) against the rays of a sun rising from the sea.

"AMERICAN FISHERMEN" is a book mainly of pictures, with text down to the minimum. Albert Cook Church has made thousands of marine photographs, over two hundred and fifty of which are here reproduced; and as the name of James B. Connolly is too well known to require comment, the value of the book as recorded maritime history is obvious.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- Bardia's defenses were reported to be falling fast today under the mighty shock of every weapon in the British arsenal -- warships, dive-bombers, artillery, tanks and grenades -- and British military headquarters declared that the end was near for that Libyan base.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Few, if any, of President Roosevelt's recommendations to the new Congress, not even excepting specific proposals for enlarging the Army and Navy, will be plastered more thoroughly and more properly with the label of "national defense" than the budget for the fiscal year of 1942 (from July 1, 1941, to June 30, 1942) which he will submit sometime early next week.

North American Newspaper Alliance The Germans have established a curious kind of model town of their own in a strategic location in Yugoslavia across the Danube from Belgrade, the capital city. The town's ostensible purpose is to act as a way station for German expatriates from the strip of land in Bessarabia taken over by Russia.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday that he was recommending the restoration in the new Board of Education budget for 1941-42 of the adult day classes in English and citizenship, discontinued a year ago because of the economy drive.

The National Association of Broadcasters contended yesterday that the American radio public had shown "no worry to date" over the absence of music of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers from the air since midnight, Dec. 31.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Mill buying and short-covering carried wheat prices up around 3/4 cent a bushel early today on the Board of Trade, the May selling at the highest level since Dec. 2. Some fairly large orders on the buying side were filled at and soon after the opening, and the trade assumed that mills had been able to make further liberal sales of flour overnight.

OF all the recent films to raise inkwell tempests certainly none has been the center of so much extravagant praise, critical spleen and sheer nonsense as "Fantasia," that film making experiment for which its two joint creators receive the New York Film Critics' Special Award today.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- All along the coast of Europe, from Bordeaux to Narvik, in big harbors and little ones, behind and beneath every sort of camouflage human ingenuity can think of, Reichsfuehrer Hitler's generals have made their concentrations of barges ready for "Der Tag" when he may give little England a nice New Year's present.

The rise of 573,000 in the number of unemployed in November, as estimated by the Industrial Conference Board, need not cast doubt on the current trend of industry and the progress of the defense program. The increase was much more than accounted for by reduced employment in agriculture, such as usually marks this season of the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The War Department and the National Defense Advisory Commission, through conferences held in the past twenty-four hours, have accelerated the program for utilization of the nation's resources of idle tools and idle man-power

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Achieving a dramatic comeback, Bull Reigh won the $10,000-added San Felipe Stakes at Santa Anita Park today after having been beaten earlier in the week by a colt that had run in cheap claiming races. After Dawn was second, Porter's Cap third and Valdina Groom fourth.

New records for arrivals of buyers in the wholesale markets here are expected this week and next as retailers from all sections of the country begin active purchasing of Spring merchandise. Initial buying budgets have been stepped up about 7 per cent or more over a year ago to take care of the additional sales volume expected to develop from the national defense program.
DUBLIN, Jan. 4 -- Ireland (Eire) today is as much determined to adhere to her policy of neutrality as she was when the war broke out some sixteen months ago.

With Miss Sarah Jane Fraser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Fraser, as chairman, a large debutante committee has been organized in the interests of the fourth annual opera benefit of the Children's Aid Society -- the performance of "Louise" on the night of Jan. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 5 -- For the third successive night British bombers unloaded destruction from incendiary bombs and heavy explosives upon Bremen Friday night, causing what the Air Ministry described as the worst devastation accomplished by either side in this war.

PLAINSBORO, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Celebrating his seventieth birthday today, Henry William Jeffers Sr., inventor of the rotolactor -- "cow merry-go-round" -- one of the world's pioneers in dairy sanitation and nutrition, reaffirmed his belief in the principle of "individual incentive" as one of the most important elements needed for progress in American business and industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Senator Carter Glass, Democrat, of Virginia, celebrated his eighty-third birthday anniversary today by asserting that the United States Navy should be sent "over to blast hell out of Germany."

WITH the award of some $4,500,000 in contracts for the construction of the new Brooklyn elevated parkway last week, it is expected that this three-mile link will be ready for traffic within some ten months.

Elsewhere in this issue a report is made on the fund raised at the Christmas season for the Hundred Neediest Cases. Our thanks, and the gratitude of the Neediest themselves, go to many generous contributors. Once more the immediate needs of deserving individuals and families will be alleviated by the donations of thousands to whom fortune has been more kind.

Men and women prominent in the theatrical profession, with the assistance of several members of society, are now arranging an after-theatre supper dance in behalf of the American Theatre Wing of the British War Relief Society, Inc. The party will be given on Jan. 15 in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center and will embrace several features of entertainment.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians will play 33 exhibition games -- 25 of them with major league opponents -- during the 1941 Spring training season, Business Manager Frank Kohlbecker announced tonight.

DIMITRI MITROPOULOS will make his final appearance as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony for this season next Sunday afternoon. He will be followed by Bruno Walter, who will direct from Jan. 16 through Feb. 9.

THE Original Ballet Russe today begins its final eight days at the Fifty-first Street Theatre. When it closes next Sunday evening it will have played seventy-nine performances, which is the longest consecutive engagement any ballet company has played here.

The election last week of Thomas J. Curran as New York County Republican chairman to succeed Kenneth L. Simpson has aroused particular interest because of its possible effects on the political fortunes of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Mayor F.H. La Guardia.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 4 -- After a side trip to St. Augustine, where many points of historic interest were visited, the Fordham University football squad left late today on the last lap of its Cotton Bowl trip to Dallas, Texas, and return.

It must be that the men of America have embraced the true faith of Epicurus -- the faith which finds the greatest good in the use, in the anticipation, in the remembrance of the fine things of life, with the accent upon fine food. Certainly more and more American men are taking to the range -- not the one in the song, but the one in the kitchen.

Tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden the United States Lawn Tennis Association will bid farewell to one more in the succession of world-famous players whom it reared to stardom, only to lose them to professional tennis at the height of their box-office appeal.

NEVER m the history of the novel has the novelist who tries to write honestly and unflinchingly about the world he lives in been confronted by a situation which equals in complexity that of today. He lives in a time when human life has been inexpressibly cheapend.

YOUR review of "Cabin in the Sky" did us a good turn, and country parsons need good turns and tips on plays lest they go astray in the big city. The opening songs of Ethel Waters will sing away in our hearts for a long time, maybe until we die.

A strong plea for international cooperation, with specific approval of repeal of the Johnson and Neutrality Acts, are among the points embodied in a final report of the commission on peace through world organization, formed by the Woman's Centennial Congress.

In each of the two tales included, in this volume Inspector Maigret of the Police Judiciaire makes progress so slowly that it seems that he is making no progress at all. He appears to be merely loitering about, waiting for something to happen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Administration leaders in Congress moved today toward the formulation of a tentative program for the first session of the Seventy-seventh Congress, which convened yesterday, but precise details were not disclosed pending receipt on Monday of President Roosevelt's annual message and his budget message which will be presented on Wednesday.

NAURU, the Pacific island which was shelled by a raider which the Australian Government announced last week was a Nazi vessel, entered the family of stamp-issuing governments in 1916. It had been captured by Australian naval forces shortly after the outbreak of the World War.

Paula, who grew up in a smoky mill-town outside Chicago in the changing years of the 'Nineties, is nearly fifteen now and happily learning about music and life in boarding school. Different as is her new background, she still has plenty of opportunity to apply the lessons in sympathy and understanding learned in her friendships with the "new pioneers" among the mill-workers at home.

"MY life here has been one of stirring adventure, and I have just time for one more adventure in the same cause." With these words Frank Aydelotte bade farewell in 1939 to students of Swarthmore College, where he had been president for nearly twenty years, and embarked upon his new role as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton.

WEBSTER, Mass., Jan. 4 (AP) -- By completing purchase of a factory building as the culmination of a plan to provide employment, the Webster Independent Shoe Workers Union has become landlord to the employer of 900 members.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- The slogan under which the militant Third Reich marches into the year 1941, as given by Reichsfuehrer Hitler in his New Year's proclamation to the German armed forces, is "Consummation of the greatest victory in our history" within the next twelve months.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Public requests for Winter sports facilities this season have reached an all-time high in the Bear Mountain State Park's thirty-year history, it was disclosed today by A.K. Morgan, new general manager.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 4 -- With an entry of 268, the largest in its history, the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today held its eleventh annual New Year indoor horse show in the club's riding ring. As in past years, the exhibition was made up of classes for hunters and jumpers and horsemanship competitions.

A series of three subscription supper dances entitled the Post-Debutante Assemblies had its inception last night when the first of the dances was held on the St. Regis Roof. Under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller, with Miss Barbara R. Whipple as dance chairman, the parties are designed for young women who were introduced to society within the past two years, and their escorts.
AT intervals a "new and original'' composition is announced for its first American performance. On Dec. 29 it was "Sinfonietta," by Zemlinsky.

At its concert in Radio City last night, Alfred Wallenstein led the NBC Symphony Orchestra in the first of the four concerts he is scheduled to direct during the absence of Arturo Toscanini, the organization's regular conductor, who is on a month's vacation,

Viewed from any angle, the ring debut here of Billy Soose, Farrell (Pa.) middleweight, in Madison Square Garden last Friday night was a howling success. Developments yesterday indicated the clever Pennsylvanian may be the medium of clearing up the muddled situation which now involves the world middleweight title.

THE village was in the Sarthe Valley, hard by Normandy. One does not know what its fate may have been, but in the Summer of 1939 it lived its busy, contented life against the background of its apple orchards and low hills, in its houses clustered about the old church spire, as it had done for centuries.

Colette lived, as every child of the picture-book stage sometimes imagines himself doing, in a house all her own. For company she had animals, all kinds. First there were the birds who didn't seem to mind in the least when Colette adopted a lost cat.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Scoring victories in five classes, Miss Jean Girdler of Montclair, a student at Mount Vernon Junior College, Washington, D.C., captured individual honors in the tenth annual Midwinter horse show tonight at the Montclair Riding Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The week-end was to be devoted by members of Congress to those undramatic but essential details of organization which accompany the opening of a new session. Neither branch of Congress met today, but both the Democrats and Republicans of the Senate held conferences to perfect their party organizations.
THE violent rhythms, beautiful melodic forms and dynamic obsessions of Brazilian folk-music reveal the influence of the African Negro.
PEARL BUCK'S new book is a collection of thirteen short stories which should be read straight through in direct sequence as if the book were a novel. That in a sense, is indeed what it is.

Helena Rubinstein, Inc., and subsidiaries, manufacturers of cosmetics, reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, last, net profit of $484,575 after depreciation, amortization, Federal and Canadian income taxes, Canadian exchange adjustments and other charges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission concluded today a hearing on an application under which the Aviation and Transportation Corporation proposes an exchange of stock with the Aviation Corporation, an affiliate, through which the former company eventually would be dissolved.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. Jan. 4 -- A Navy transport plane, carrying eleven persons, including four men who parachuted from a naval bomber in Texas last Thursday, was believed to have crashed tonight in mountainous country fifty miles southeast of here.

The need for additional workers in national defense industries is breaking down employer prejudice against the hiring of men past the age of 40, women and inexperienced young persons, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday in a preliminary report on the 1940 activities of her department.

The British War Relief Society has received more than $4,200,000 in cash contributions, or about one-fifth of the $20,000,000 set by the society as the goal that it hopes to reach by mid-1941, Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the society, announced yesterday.

The executive committee of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, from which William Allen White recently resigned as chairman, took up plans yesterday for enlarging the steering group and naming a successor to Mr. White.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan 1 (Delayed: via Jerusalem) -- Less strained relations between the French authorities and large groups of the population of Syria and Lebanon is expected to result from the policy of the new High Commissioner, General Henri Dentz. who has just arrived here.

The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear with hearing. BOOK OF ECCLESIASTES. VISUAL interpretation of music (with its inevitable corollary, the musical interpretation of phenomena associated with the sense of sight) has been widely, even heatedly, discussed of late -- ever since the advent of Walt Disney's "Fantasia."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Twelve bus passengers were injured, nine requiring hospital treatment, when the vehicle crashed into an electric light pole in Charlotte Plaza here at 7:30 o'clock tonight.

Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio is so far ahead of the rest of the 1940 field that there is no difficulty whatever in ranking her as the leader among the first ten women golfers in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- New regulations governing the "pre-examination" of aliens who wish to leave the United States temporarily in order to re-enter it for permanent residence were made public today.

The "Author's Note" informs us that "some of the characters in this book bear a singular resemblance to persons now living, not dead." Whether this frank admission will lessen the sting of the portraits or caricatures that Mr. Fuller has drawn remains to be seen.

With the object of keeping its members fit for their jobs and for any tasks they may be called upon to fill in a national emergency, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs has issued health examination blanks for use by its 74,000 members.

DEVELOPMENT of shortwave broadcasting during 1940 was divided into two phases. War abroad retarded progress during the first half of the year, while the latter months were marked by outstanding forward moves, most of them made by countries on the defensive.

The American people are ready to roll up their sleeves and go to work to speed production of guns, warplanes, tanks, warships and other essentials for rearmament, a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicates, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A more efficient and simplified "rhumbatron," a high frequency, electromagnetic wave producing tube, which brings a step closer to reality the transmission of electric power by wireless, has been developed in the research laboratories of Stanford University.
ROME, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

EVERY field of collecting engenders its own excitement, but none more conspicuously than that of sporting books. Collectors are by nature sportsmen, continually riding their hobby, shooting at, hunting or fishing for, some new trophy to add to their store, and then bragging about their conquests.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 4 -- Great satisfaction is felt here with an article in the Italian Foreign Office organ Relazione Internazionale referring to the press and radio feud between Hungary and Rumania.

The United States Government faces this year the most extensive peace-time financing program in its history. Developments in recent weeks, including the possibility of important financial aid to Great Birtain and the apparent lag in actual expenditures for defense by the government, have served to complicate somewhat the situation as to just what the actual requirements will be.
Miss Adelaide Eleanor Storer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Ellingwood Storer, was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her parents in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- The pilot of a British bomber that was seen to crash in flames over the Italian lines in Southern Albania twelve days ago has turned up to tell a thrilling tale of a parachute escape from his blazing plane while an Italian fighter strafed him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Although he said "a pretty good batch" of fighting ships would join the fleet this year, including two new 35,000-ton battleships, Representative Vinson, Georgia Democrat, chairman of the House Naval Committee, said today that the defense program would have to be both expanded and accelerated.

Charles Chaplin, the film star, who was designated a week ago by the New York Film Critics as the best screen actor of 1940 for his performance in "The Great Dictator," declined the award yesterday in a telegram to Bosley Crowther, film critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES and president of the critics' organization.
I have been here since Christmas Eve, but every hour has brought new hope and encouragement, not least THE TIMES'S editorial "Assurances From Hitler."

The sympathy which the promiscuous bombing of London by Germany has aroused in the United States has very greatly encouraged the citizens of London in their daily and nightly ordeal, and with them all Britain.

PILOT POET: Bedouins finally found the French pilot and his mechanic, almost dead of thirst. Four days before the airmen had crashed in the Sahara Desert. They had wandered miles in search of an oasis, but saw nothing but sand and sun and mirages.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 4 -- Looking beyond the day-by-day problems of a world in conflict, Bucknell University students have engaged during the last three months in concerted campus-wide discussion of the kind of international order needed to bring about more lasting peace and justice.

ATHENS, Jan. 4 -- Rain and snow storms beclouded most of Albania today and aerial activity was limited, but local reports say Greek troops captured a height of great importance west of Tepeleni and took other mountain positions 5,000 feet in altitude on the coastal sector and in the north somewhere west of Pogradec.

A survey of shipbuilding, covering both merchant construction and naval orders, shows that the country's shipyards started the new year with orders for two and a half times the figures of a year ago, according to Marine Engineering and Shipping Review, leading shipping journal.

PLAYS From 6 to 11 are the most impressionable ages of movie-going and radio-listening. says Gloria Chandler. "We can implant any idea in the minds of children; aren't we foolish if we don't implant the best ones?"

WHAT threatened for a brief spell to be a crisis in the relations between Bette Davis and Warners has been averted, and the star is starting work with James Cagney in "The Bride Came C.O.D.," her first comedy in three years.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The commodity year in Great Britain opened with a "tightening of the belt." At the end of the year a message from Lord Woolton, Food Minister, urged food economy by replacement of imported food by home food as in the use of potatoes for bread, and he predicted cuts in rations.

WHEN the new Airlines Terminal facing Grand Central Terminal across Forty-second Street slides smoothly into operation, the event --scheduled for Thursday -- will be something more than the inauguration of the world's first airways union station.

A DECADE ago Jose Ortega y Gasset gave us his illuminating "Revolt of the Masses." Here the why of the German, Russian, Italian and Spanish revolutions received clarification. Not that Ortega unlocked all the mysteries of the totalitarian victories, but he did throw strong light on the causes of Hitlerism and related tyrannies.

With agitation for enactment of the grocers' model bill certain to enliven the New York State Legislature's sessions this year, Edward M. Synan, executive president of the Massachusetts Food Council, Inc., which has been actively identified with a similar law in Massachusetts, outlined the experience of grocers there in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The roster of the season's books about China, an unusually excellent list, would not be complete without a mention of this new little picture book by the artist who gave us last year "Wu and Lu and Li."

CANADA will be turning out capable young pilots at the rate of 2,000 a month before Spring, in the opinion of William A. (Billy) Hughes, veteran American pilot, who has been engaged in instructing these lads since late March, 1940.

RUSSE, Bulgaria, Jan. 4 -- Rumors of a concentration of German troops in Bulgaria coming through the port of Russe have cause, this correspondent to make a trip to the Danube port to investigate their validity.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 -- After nearly two weeks of negotiations a new Finnish Cabinet to succeed that headed by Risto Ryti, now President of the Finnish Republic, was formed today by Johan Wilhelm Rangell.

OTTAWA, Jan. 4 -- After a three-day joint meeting the Canadian and United States Committees on the St. Lawrence waterway and power project reached today what was described as a final report and adjourned.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Paced by Captain Fred Maloon for the third straight night, the powerful Dartmouth College sextet defeated Williams College, 9 to 2, in the finale of the annual Playland hockey series before a capacity throng at the Ice Casino tonight.

Price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange in yesterday's 2-hour session were slightly irregular, but trading was quiet. With Bombay interests relatively inactive, probably because the Indian market was closed, initial prices were strong and 1 to 3 points net higher than Friday's close.

One of the chief difficulties in supplying material help to Britain is technical. The British Army uses a rifle of .303 caliber; the caliber of our own is .30. Cartridges used in each, if laid side by side, are practically indistinguishable one from another. But a British cartridge will not fit our rifle nor will our own fit theirs.

THE schedule of plays and musical shows, which are due on Broadway during the remainder of January, appears to be a fairly heavy one. More than that, reports from the provinces and from the rehearsal stages of New York say that on the list will be several shows that will be successes or better; the season, as they say, is looking up.

Forty debutantes of the season, many of them members of the debutante committee for the Polka Ball to be given Jan. 24 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Kosciuszko Foundation, will gather at the Waldorf Wednesday afternoon to rehearse polka measures they will dance as a special feature of the entertainment program at the ball.

MERIDA, Yucatan -- The 400th anniversary of the founding of this city is being celebrated with fiestas and public ceremonies this week. Low transportation rates and a special trip by steamer from Veracruz make it possible for visitors to see something of the life of the Yucatecos, whose country is still difficult of access except by air and steamship.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Army bomber which left here on a test flight tonight reported from Memphis that a 100-mile headwind had forced flying at 6,500 to 9,500 feet altitude instead of the 15,000 originally planned.
RIO DE JANIER0, Brazil, Jan. 4 -- Brazil is now looking to the United States to assist her with a supply of arms, both under conditions of peacetime preparation and in the event of war.

A spurt in sales in the last quarter of 1940 enabled the men's wear industry to bring to a favorable close what was otherwise an erratic year. The gain in production in men's suits during the year was small, but the 1939 output of overcoats was doubled.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 4 -- The post-holiday season reached its peak here this week-end at the Eastern Slope Inn, which has become of the principal focal points of skiing activities in Northern New England States. Many of the visitors, who include members of society from cities throughout the East, have remained over from Christmas and New Year's festivities.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 4 -- In a move that shocked undergraduates and alumni alike with surprise, Yale today replaced Raymond W. (Ducky) Pond with Emerson W. (Spike) Nelson as head coach of football.

Mrs. Ronald B. Balcom, executive chairman of the Medical and Surgical Supply Committee of America, 420 Lexington Avenue, disclosed yesterday that it had received $128,896 in merchandise and cash donations up to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The first anniversary of the signing of the agreement between the Dominican Government and the Dominican Republic Settlement Association for the colonizing of European refugees in the Caribbean republic will be observed by a meeting of representatives of the thirty-two nations holding membership in the Inter- governmental Committee on Refugees at Ciudad Trujillo from Jan. 30 to Feb. 3.

THERE are times, about halfway through the book, when one is puzzled to discover its theme. Is it about old Mrs. Mailing or her lovely grandchild Carla? All those long reminiscences of the wise old lady are interesting enough, but are they the main story or are they meant to light up Carla's problem or to supply contrast for it, or what in the world is the whole idea anyway?

Melvin H. Hayes, skipper of the Consolidated cruiser Co-Ed II, who knows from repeated voyages every drop of the waterway from Travers Island eastward to New London, Block Island and way stations and ports of call, is slated to head the New York Athletic Club Yachting Department for 1941.
ROME, Jan. 4 -- Giovanni Ansaldo in the Telegrafo today tries to destroy in his readers' minds any supposed misconception about the heroism of the British people.

THE New Year finds New York with a new title -- Fashion Center of the World -- and prepared to prove its right to the succession. Paris has been forced to abdicate, bowed down under the yoke of Nazidom. Excepting New York, there is not a fashion center of consequence left free for creative work.

A large subscription has been reported for the dinner dance of the First Reserve Aero Squadron Club to be held next Saturday in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. Mrs. Francis Rogers founded the beneficiary which maintains headquarters and recreational facilities at 283 Lexington Avenue for men in all branches of the service.

A.S. Cornhill topped the field at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, winning the high-over-all scratch cup with a card of 99 out of 100, gaining legs on the scratch and the handicap cup at doubles with 23 -- 6 -- 24, and taking the scratch and handicap legs in the event at 149 targets with a card of 144 -- 2 -- 146.

THE failure of National Art Week, reported by Mr. Jewell in these pages two weeks ago, seems to have been due primarily to the sheer bulk and density of the problems with which the program undertook to deal. In gallantly attempting to improve the economic position of the American artist through a week of publicity, exhibitions and sales, Art Week shot an arrow at a mountain.

The lag in defense production will not be overcome until business management generally is made to realize, through a great shock or otherwise, that the emergency is a real one, according to Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association.

TAYLOR, Texas, Jan. 4 -- Hans Ackerman, editor of The Texas Herold, said today in reply to a statement by the Dies Committee that he had "been advised by the Justice Department in Washington to sue those who continue to give such publicity to our actions."

IF there is any class of authors who should concern themselves about the quality of the English language it is surely our poets. Prose writers, it is true, use the same words for their material, but poetry suffers most if these words are employed in any but their proper and exact signification.

NORTHVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ted Ellenwood, 21-year-old shipping clerk, won his third successive Central Adirondack title today as New York opened its outdoor speed skating season with a field of more than 100 competitors.

British business may not be "as usual." The pressure of events put a quietus on that slogan some months ago. But it is continuing, with the same obstinate determination that sends Londoners to their daily occupations, no matter what havoc the air raid of the night before has wrought in the district where their work lies.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 -- Limitation of the number of permits for the sale of alcoholic liquor in Connecticut by giving wider discretionary powers to the State Control Commission will be sought in legislation to be offered at the forthcoming General Assembly session.

With an expanded stake program, capped once more by the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup Handicap, the annual forty-six-day race meeting at Hialeah Park will get under way on Wednesday under the direction of the new president, John C. Clark. Mr. Clark represents the interests of Joseph E. Widener, Peter A.B. Widener 2d and other stockholders, and is largely responsible for the greatly increased purses that have attracted horsemen from all parts of the country.
The British-American Art Center, Inc., 4.vill be opened to the public next Friday at 44 West Fifty-sixth Street, following a private viewing Thursday.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Although the Pinehurst Country Club calendar does not have any formal golf tournaments scheduled for this month, there will be seven informal ones. These will he contested by the Tin Whistles Club, men's golf organization, and by its feminine counterpart, the Silver Foils Club.

CLEVELAND, site of record-breaking attendances for the Metropolitan Opera every Spring, now has its own opera company. The organization intends to draw upon Cleveland artists and musicians for its casts and to present operas in English at popular prices.

THE science of lighting is in its infancy. That may seem a surprising statement to many who marveled at the breathtaking display staged nightly by the fountains of light at the New York World's Fair or who have seen the famous Navesink lighthouse in lower New York Bay, the most powerful light in the world, with a beam of 9,000,000 candlepower which can be seen twenty-two miles at sea.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O. unit, today informed James F. Dewey, Federal labor conciliator, that it accepted with some reservations the principle of arbitration for men laid off as a result of shifting a manufacturing unit from the Lincoln to the River Rouge plant.

Members of the Women's Chess Club of New York are concentrating their efforts this season toward producing a metropolitan champion. Every Tuesday afternoon they can be found in their clubroom at the Hotel Biltmore, preparing four of their players for the finals of the Marshall Chess Club tournament, which will take place late this month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Federal income tax blanks have been further streamlined this year to make them easier for the understanding of the taxpayers, but more importantly to bring into the tax rolls the large group of persons in the lower income brackets designated in the 1940 Revenue Act.

Plans for a Composers Theatre, intended to follow the musical trend in the American theatre today as a form of native opera, were proposed yesterday before the first national convention of the National Committee of the League of Composers, held at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Behind the White House walls President Roosevelt worked last week on the annual report on "the state of the Union" to be read tomorrow before the newly convened Seventy-seventh Congress of the United States. It was the eighth time he had written such a message.

Unfamiliarity with the provisions of the Federal old-age and survivors' insurance program is costing New Yorkers between $50,000 and $75,000 a month in unclaimed benefits, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, estimated yesterday.

THE story goes that Laird Cregar was "overlooked" by Hollywood producers for more than a year before he was assigned his first role. This unquestionably must have been a triumph in overlooking, since Mr. Cregar is several inches taller and a pound or so heavier than Man Mountain Dean.

Apparently of the firm conviction that hard work, and plenty of it, must play a vital part in lifting them out of the depths of the second division, the Giants, through their affable secretary, Eddie Brannick, yesterday announced an arduous and ambitious Spring training campaign for this year, which will include the playing of thirty-five exhibition games.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Climaxing nearly a decade of work, fifteen Colgate University faculty members published during the year just closed two more volumes meant to make adoption of the Colgate Plan of Education easier for other institutions.

Men who escaped to England from Austrian and German concentration camps and are serving with the pioneer corps of the British Army received high praise yesterday in a British broadcast recorded here by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Great Britain has already begun to invade the Continent -- giving the Germans a preview of the mass attack British generals have promised to deliver.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The War Department estimated today that the Army regulars and National Guardsmen actually under arms on Jan. 1 numbered 608,000, representing nearly a threefold increase in strength within a year.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 -- Johnny Bulla of Chicago and the veteran Denny Shute took the Riviera Country Club golf course apart today with spectacular scores of 66, but the Midwesterner had a better first-round score and took the lead at the halfway point of the annual $10,000 Los Angeles open tournament.

HONORE DE BALZAC, the "eagle hatched among geese," mirrored his state of soul when he dashed off Le Message during what was, perhaps, the most critical year in the life of this good-natured man of genius.

Miss Ethel Thomas, amateur detective and writer of mystery stories, is on the spot in more senses than one in this story of murder in Hollywood. She is so close to the scene of the crime when two murders are committed that the police look upon her with considerable suspicion, especially since it is perfectly apparent that she is not telling all that she knows.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 4 -- If there is any body of sentiment hereabouts which disagrees with President Roosevelt's over-all program for national defense, it has not been expressed.

DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 4 -- The President's declarations on the attitude of the United States toward the Axis powers and the nation's own defense plans voiced the overwhelming sentiment of the Southwest.

For good, all-around performance in the way of blooming Oxalis bowiei may be recommended as one of the most satisfactory. It is unusual in the fact that, though it comes from a warmish part of South Africa, it is fairly hardy in our gardens if planted in a sheltered, well-drained spot.

ABOUT a year ago Mr. and Mrs. North met murder, and Lieutenant Weigand of the New York City Police came to investigate it. The lieutenant had some difficulty at first in understanding Mrs. North because when she talked she touched only the high spots, leaving the rest to the imagination.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Jan. 4 -- "The most important contribution which Swarthmore can make is to continue to educate young men and women; in a very real sense this is work of national importance," stated John W. Nason, president of Swarthmore College, in his first annual report made public today.

Transportation facilities were heavily taxed yesterday as thousands of persons, ending a long Yuletide holiday, began returning to their homes and thousands of students started back to colleges throughout the country to resume their duties on Monday.

AFTER running up big increases over a year ago for the Christmas week, retail trade fell into its usual post-holiday lull. Some figures last week dropped under 1940 levels. However, retailers believed this was no forecast of January business and they looked for recent gains to be re-established soon.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Increasing protests against a sugar shortage throughout Mexico resulted today in Communist-inspired street demonstrations in Merida, Yucatan Province, it was reported. Order was said to have been restored quickly.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 4 (UP) -- State policemen went to Angola penitentiary today and removed John Swanson Jr., of East Aurora, N.Y., who says he was sentenced to three years for "stealing an apple."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- Contracts for defense plant expansion, construction and equipment totaling almost $700,000,000 have been awarded to date, according to a compilation published by the National Defense Commission.

TO many Americans a blue willow plate stands as a familiar symbol of a heritage of security and tradition. To Janie Larkin her plate meant all that and more, though she could only barely remember the home in Texas from which the drought and dust storm had driven her and her family.

The survey of traffic conditions on the so-called express streets established through midtown Manhattan three years ago has been referred to department heads for study and recommendation, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday.

Dr. Carlos N. Brin, recently appointed Ambassador from Panama to the United States, arrived yesterday on the Panama liner Ancon. He was accompanied by his wife and two children, Dora, 16 years old, and Carlos, 13.

The finding of Hebrew inscriptions, unnoticed for more than 400 years, on three models of sculptures by Leonardo da Vinci and Giofrancesco Rustici, distinguished artists of the Renaissance period in Italy, was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Paul Romanoff, curator of the Museum of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The American Legion's permanent draft program for youths of 18 to 21 gained Congressional support today and promises of immediate consideration by the House and Senate Military Affairs Committees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Wives of the Senate's two most outspoken isolationists have joined their husbands in the latest drive to keep America out of war.
