The problems of defense affecting the railways and their users will be discussed at the annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board in the Hotel Biltmore on Wednesday and Thursday.

A program of health education designed to bring about the growth of individual students in social, mental and emotional spheres as well as physically has been developed at City College during the last year, it was reported last week.
ATHENS, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Greek Ministry of Marine issued this communique today:

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 4 -- For 20 minutes tonight Northwestern's Wildcats looked like the challengers in the Western Conference basketball race that opens Monday night. For the next 11 minutes, however, the Wildcats failed to score from the field against Princeton's touring Tigers.

The C.I.O. is entitled to insist on a fair and thorough examination of its proposal to produce 500 pursuit planes a day within six months, by utilizing idle plant and adapting existing machines in the automobile industry. It must be said, however, that certain weaknesses in the plan have become more evident on examination.

In the meeting room of the House of Representative, at 1P.M. tomorrow, the doorkeeper will announce, "The Senate of the United States." Through the door will sweep a procession of legislators led by two page boys staggering under the weight of large mahogany boxes containing the votes of the Presidential electors chosen by the people last November.

Joseph Hidalgo Jr. of the High School of Commerce and Julius Jackson of Abraham Lincoln High School of Brooklyn finished in a tie for first place in the finals for the individual championship of the Interscholastic Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4 -- The newly installed Mexican Government was faced by its first serious labor crisis today when all the transport workers in the Federal District decided to strike next Saturday to show their solidarity with the tramway workers, who for months have been demanding higher wages and various other benefits.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 4 -- Making his first start since a successful Summer campaign on the West Coast, Mrs. W.C. Stroube's 8-to-1 shot, Exarch scored a surprise triumph in the $2,000 Seminole handicap at Tropical Park today.

Evidence of New York's ability to create, as well as to produce, fashions for women will be displayed in "Fashion Futures," the world's largest fashion show, to be held in the Astor Hotel on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, it was disclosed yesterday morning at interviews given by members of the directing and planning committees of The Fashion Group, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Stocks were able yesterday to extend the gains of Friday, but there was no carry-through to the early advances and the list closed heavy. The slackening of demand was a major factor in the late sell-off, for values were allowed to drift without support.

One gathers from the public prints that a girl who can't ski, or would rather stay home where it's warm than go off to the mountains in Winter, is a social pariah. Being able to slide neatly down a snowy incline on a pair of waxed sticks is as important, these days, as knowing how to behave suitably at parties.

THE Metropolitan keeps generally to its proud tradition of opera sung not only in its own language but with casts at least predominantly of the nationality of the composer. There are of course exceptions to this rule, and a considerable number of them.

RECENT announcements that at least 25 per cent of the nation's airports are now closed to private flying find William T. Piper protesting the need for many more small flying fields to be built at government expense.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 4 -- Instructions for teachers drawn up at the congress of German teachers in the part of Transylvania recently taken by Hungary from Rumania show how to impress the stamp of Adolf Hitler on German children who are forbidden to study the Old Testament, the French or Rumanian language, philosophy or morals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities recommended today, in another part of its preliminary report, the enactment of legislation which would bar from the benefits of reduced postage rates under the International Postal Union all printed propaganda directed against the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Young Jake Schaefer is trying to win the world three-cushion billiard championship the hard way, by beating the titleholder, Willie Hoppe, in a challenge match.

New York's team repeated its success of a year ago by vanquishing Philadelphia's representatives, 6 to 2, in the intercity court tennis matches at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday. Last year New York won by 9 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- As a result of criticism from American flag operators who asserted that they were unable, despite their need for more cargo vessels, to bid successfully against the British for laid-up ships of the United States Maritime Commission, three ships have been withdrawn from an approaching auction of twenty-four vessels, and preference will be given to American bidders in the sale of the twenty-one others.

Creation of a Smaller Business Commission to function as a clearing house for the distribution of at least 35 per cent of each major defense contract to smaller manufacturers will be urged this week upon Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, by a delegation representing the Smaller Business Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, it was announced yesterday by Henry Modell, president of the association.

Additional commercial banks reported yesterday their statements of condition as of Dec. 31. These reports reflected the general trend toward increased deposits and total resources for the quarter, in some instances to new record highs in the respective histories of the institutions.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 4 -- Praise for President Roosevelt's Sunday night radio speech probably has been more nearly unanimous in this section than in any other Dart of the country. This is true also of sentiment for Britain and willingness to take a chance on war in the game of all aid short of it.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 -- In full-page advertisements appearing in Detroit newspapers tomorrow, the Ford Motor Company will reiterate its assertion that there is no labor agitation within its plants on the part of the majority of its employes.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Jan. 4 -- William Weisman, alias Weiss, years old, of 1 Grumman Avenue, Newark, figure in North Jersey bootlegging circles during prohibition and reported to have financial interests in several New York night clubs, was found slain here today in a locked sedan, with three bullet holes in the side of his head and neck.

THE Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation announces its annual auditions for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and vocalists desiring to compete for its award of New York debut recitals during the 1941-42 season. Entrants must not be over 30 years old or under 16, and must not have given a New York recital reviewed by critics.

The United States National Defense series of stamps is currently being cited by British philatelic publications as an example of what Great Britain should do "for national propaganda." London stamp writers are urging Britain's Postmaster General to "tell the world," with new stamps, of Britain's "resolution and confidence in the hour of her supreme trial."

THE story of Robert Schumann and Clara Wieck is well known as one of the great historical romances. They met when she was a girl of 8, a child prodigy who already had given her first piano recital under her father's rigid musical guidance.

THE name Balkan means a mountain range, a part of Europe, the beginning of Asia and a strange mixture of romance and intrigue in musical comedy trappings. A strange medley is called a "Macedoine" after the mixed-up central strip of the peninsula. Graft, intrigue and political assassinations are frequently labeled "Balkan," because of their prominence in the history of the region, and generally the Continent as a whole tends to regard this segment condescendingly.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 4 -- Dartmouth College announced today the establishment of a student workshop and the appointment of a shop director, implementing the thesis that American colleges should teach students to use their hands as well as their heads.

Sixteen months of war in Europe have altered drastically the foreign trade of the United States. Data of our exports in 1940 are expected to show an increase of more than 25 per cent over 1939. Composition of the exports has changed greatly, however.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S message at the opening of the Seventy-seventh Congress tomorrow is scheduled to be broadcast from coast to coast by the major systems. WEAF, WOR, WJZ and WABC will be the local outlets. He is expected to begin speaking at 2 P.M.

SOUTHERN California's aircraft industry, accounting for slightly better than 50 per cent of the dollar-value airplane orders placed by the United States and British Governments with American companies, last week took its annual year-end inventory and discovered that its $1,290,000,000 backlog represents a 625 per cent gain over contracts as of Jan. 1, 1940.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries comprising the Bell System -- the largest single communications system in the world -- had a marked over-all increase in business in 1940. Substantial increases in the number of persons employed and in the outlay for plant construction throughout the system were noted in the year.

More than a dozen new courses will be offered to students in both the day and evening sessions of Hunter College in the Spring semester which will begin Feb. 10, it was announced yesterday by departmental officials of the college. Registration for these and other courses will be accepted in the evening and extension divisions from Feb. 3 to 6, and in the day session on Feb. 5.

Having met with widespread success in its first year, the important experiment in teacher testing, conducted by the National Committee on Teacher Examinations, will more than double its program in 1941. Tests will be given at sixty examining centers throughout the country early in the Spring.

IF the Nazis intended to subtract from the gayety of nations by holding P.G. Wodehouse in protective custody, they have not succeeded so far in stopping his effervescent flow of humor. For here is a new book, "Quick Service," a full-length novel this time, about a harum-scarum group of irresponsibles all more or less vitally interested in Paramount Hams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Labor's unstinted cooperation in the defense program may well depend upon the next moves in what appears to be a cause celebre, the awarding by the War Department of a contract to the Ford Motor Company for 1,500 light reconnaissance cars to cost $1,387,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Outstanding in the 1940 additions to Princeton University's changing curriculum is the six-week experimental course in the graphic arts presented last Fall by Elmer Adler, an authority on the subject and former typography consultant for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Society and the musical world will combine to present tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria an entertainment that is expected to be one of the most brilliant of the season -- the annual dinner and "musical soiree" for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

IN an article recently, Mr. Downes stressed "the importance to music of adequate interpretation." He rightly mentions that an inspired performer "reads far back of the signs of the printed page." But did many performers ever see a page printed in accordance with the original manuscript (Urtext)?

"COMING attractions" are big business, and if the trailer is occasionally better than the feature picture, that is the penultimate esthetic tribute to the ingenuity of the men who produce tile advance shorts. More solid tribute is the fact that trailers make money, because exhibitors rent them just like feature pictures.

YAPHANK, L.I., Jan. 4 -- Colonel C.W. Baird, commanding officer of Camp Upton, formally accepted today several of the buildings in the new reception center that will be placed in use Monday with the arrival of the first unit of the second quota of selective service trainees.

President Roosevelt's call for greater aid to Britain was praised by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Senator Vandenberg's plea for a negotiated peace, the new year, and Roger Williams were other sermon topics.

VIENNA, Jan. 4 -- Rumors here today that this week-end would bring another important Salzburg or Berchtesgaden conference appeared tonight to be confirmed. According to several usually well-informed sources, the Bulgarian Premier, Bogdan Philoff, tonight is either already in Salzburg or Munich or en route there in the same salon coach he used on his trip to Vienna from Sofia.

Much of the pruning of shrubs and trees that in most gardens is allowed to wait until Spring can be done quite as well during the next few weeks. Doing this work now has the further advantage of saving just that much time when the rush of Spring work opens up.

THERE was a problem that confronted me. I had written "The Cradle Will Rock." Through a series of incidents, which I won't go into here, it got produced and had a success. (I am unable to determine the proportion of accident and real merit which were responsible.)

PALM BEACH, Ma., Jan. 4 -- A large attendance marked the tea and reception for members and their friends of the Society of the Four Arts given today at the galleries by Dr. Daniel J. McCarthy, president, and Mrs. McCarthy. It introduced the second exhibition of this season, a members' show, of which committee Mrs. McCarthy is president.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

ANATOLE FRANCE advised writers to put the obvious in terms of the unusual. With many a doctor of philosophy and professor of something or other, the tendency is to put the obvious in terms of the unintelligible.

More than 71 per cent of a cross-section group of American citizens covered in a survey for the National Association of Manufacturers have expressed the belief that their personal liberty would be curtailed if government instead of private individuals operated business enterprises.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- "Escape" of six German sailors to Tokyo represented "a realization of the object in view," a Nazi spokesman commented today as British officials asserted they would not be "tricked" again.

POOLS Indoor swimming pools in the summertime are rather pathetic. People who swim in their green, chlorinated depths or lie on the hard tiles under the sun lamps are obviously underprivileged -- their little faces pressed against the bars wistfully seeking substitutes for thundering blue oceans and clear, sunlit lakes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- Now that President Roosevelt has called upon this country to become the "arsenal of democracy," the Philadelphia industrial area appeared thoroughly willing and even eager this week to produce to the maximum whatever may be expected of it in the line of defense contributions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Reaction to President Roosevelt's warning on the urgency of the defense situation seems to have evoked here a spirit of fatalism -- a feeling that the world crisis has taken on such momentum that the attitude of an individual now counts for little.

Retail trade here showed a post holiday reaction in the week just ended and volume of some distributors slipped behind the figures for the like week a year ago. Department store sales were estimated as about 5 per cent behind 1940, due chiefly to the fact that the night opening on Thursday, coming immediately after New Year's Day, failed to yield much volume.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- When told today of Mr. Woodrum's proposal of a super-budget committee, the Republican House leader, Joseph W. Martin Jr., said:
VICHY, France. Jan. 4 -- "The Ministers met this evening under the presidency of Admiral Darlan and discussed various administrative questions."

VICHY, France, Jan. 4 -- The French Republic ceased to exist officially today. The government newspaper that publishes laws and decrees and of official announcements appeared with its title altered to "Official Journal of the French State."

THE late Patrick Joseph Hayes, Cardinal Archbishop of New York, was called, with reverence and affection, the "Cardinal of Charity." His native spirit of simplicity, says Bishop Donohue in his preface to this book, brought him into intimate heart-to-heart contact with the least as well as the greatest of the faithful of his spiritual domain.

WITH THE BRITISH FLEET, in the Mediterranean, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The British Battle Fleet, after a thunderous four-hour bombardment of Bardia, Libya, during which Italian mechanized units disappeared as though swept from the cliffs by a great broom, was steaming slowly back out to sea patrol today, apparently satisfied that the way had been cleared for the fall of the Fascist base.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 4 -- This week saw the clearing away in Detroit of preliminaries to a trial of thirty-seven men, several of them once the possessors of high public office, on charges of graft and corruption. Circuit Judge Earl C. Pugsley of Hart, Mich., has been disposing of the usual motions preceding such a trial.

WASHINGTON -- Texas led and New York was second in apportionment last week of Federal aid funds for highway improvement in the fiscal year starting next July 1. Building of national defense roads was stressed in the split-up of $134,062,500, made on the basis of population, area and road mileage.

Army and Navy officials, William S. Knudsen, defense chief, and Sir Louis Beale of the British Purchasing Commission will picture the urgency of the present situation at national defense sessions of the Society of Automotive Engineers annnul meeting to begin tomorrow at the Book-Cadillac Hotel in Detroit and last four days.

Miss Madeline Dalton of the Salle d'Armes Vines, won the annual Mrs. Alice Wendt Voorhees senior fencing competition on the strips of the Fencers Club yesterday by annexing seven bouts and losing only one in the final round. The event, open also to intermediate and junior fencers, drew nineteen contestants.

THE Radisson controversy would seem to be nearing a revival, and old disputants, as well as new converts, may as well prepare for the fray. The discovery and publication in 1885 of three packets of Radisson diaries started the contention, and by 1900, under the leadership of Benjamin Sulte, joined with the ardent discipleship of Miss Agnes C. Laut, the verbal strife had become intense.

OTTAWA, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Treatment accorded the people of Luxembourg by the German civil administration is "disgusting," Grand Duchess Charlotte, exiled ruler of the little country, said in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- If there is such a thing as tense resignation, this is the mood of the Seventy-seventh Congress as it awaits the President's two messages -- one on the state of the nation, the other on the budget.

The American Export liner Siboney sailed from Jersey City yesterday for Lisbon, via Bermuda, with thirty-three passengers. She also had 1,800 sacks of mail and 350 tons of cargo. Thirteen passengers are to embark at Bermuda tomorrow, officials of the line said.

Mike Lerner, one of our top big-game anglers, is off again today, and for the sixth time he will lead an American Museum of Natural History expedition on a quest for additional knowledge on the subject of swordfish and marlin. This time the waters off Talara, Peru, will be the scene of the endeavor.

TO people who are really fond of cats there is nothing more attractive than one cat except possibly five or fifty or a hundred. Consequently, this is a big week for cat lovers, because they can go to Atlantic Cat Show, walk between the rows of cages and exclaim, endlessly. "Isn't he beautiful?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Donald H. Connolly, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, said today that on Jan. 1 there were 2,656 airports, landing fields and seaplane bases in the United States and Alaska, an increase of 205 in the year.

THOSE zanies John Siguard (Ole) Olsen and Harold Ogden (Chic) Johnson, plus the not so zany Harry A. Kaufman and Lee Shubert, are about to combine in the presentation of a third revue. The first was "Hellzapoppin," the second "The Streets of Paris," and coming up will be "Crazy House."

A lacquered and gilded temple statue of Kuan Yin, formerly owned by the estate of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, was among the art objects and furnishings sold yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, together with other pieces from the collection of Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard, eldest daughter of the late Mrs. McCormick.

JEAN THOMAS'S old Kentucky home was in a mill town in the lowlands, but it was the mountain folk who gave her the name of the "traipsin' woman" and it is in collecting the mountain songs that she has won fame.

It should be noted, first off, in any discussion of monetary and credit controls as put forth in a New Year's statement by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, that the plan now before Congress should not be characterized offhand as the "Eccles plan."

Harold O. Rugg, whose social science school books have been attacked in many parts of the country, writes his first article in his own defense in the January number of the Dartmouth Alumni Magazine, which reaches its subscribers this weekend.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- An experiment in education designed to give to college students a comprehensive introductory understanding of broad fields of knowledge is underway at Cornell University, with foul special study groups involving several hundred students meeting weekly.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Up from the Balkans, where the Greeks are fighting successfully for their independence against the Italians, where every little nation sleeps uneasily under German threat, there have been coming lately more and more reports of increasing German troop concentrations, more and more rumors of some sort of German activity either independently or in aid to the Italians.

EXPERT players change their bidding methods very slowly and very gradually. It is difficult at the end of any one year to point to any distinct change as having developed during that year. The end of the year 1940 found New York's top-ranking players bidding about the same as at the end of 1939, but with minor differences which become more apparent when traced over a period of four or five years.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4 -- The Montreal Canadiens, twice battling from behind, played a 3-3 draw with the New York Rangers tonight in a National Hockey League fixture, watched by a crowd of 12,000, largest of the season here.

Seed and nursery catalogues for the new year are now replacing Christmas gifts and New Year's greetings in weighing down the overworked sacks of mail carriers and the R.F.D. jalopies. Described therein in gay colors -- both printer's ink and verbal -- are dozens of "novelties," offered to gardeners, enthusiastic or skeptical, for the first time this season.

The German Foreign Office has told us that we had better not let England have the interned ships of Germany, Italy and the conquered countries, or Germany might declare war on us. The way in which that threat was delivered is familiar to any reader of the daily papers. The government-controlled press of Germany announced that a "most solemn" press conference was held by the official spokesman for the Foreign Office.

CHESTNUTS Early in the season the outlook for all of those nice chestnut dishes and stuffings was a little sad. The American trees suffered a severe blight a few years ago, and although there is promise of recovery, native chestnuts were around 75 cents a pound this Fall. Heretofore, those little, inexpensive Italian chestnuts have filled the gap, but this year, with the Italians being kept so busy, that crop has not reached this port.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The War Department has received from 150 concerns requests for certification for special tax privileges authorized by Congress for companies engaged in defense work.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- Official German quarters today quickly made it plain that the sending of German air units to Italy would not lessen the intensity of German air attacks on England. It was stated here today that "the extent and intensity of the immediate battle against England will not in the least be affected."

BUENOS AIRES -- The average New Yorker, buttoning his overcoat around him, wrapping a scarf about his neck and preparing generally for the onslaught of Winter, may find it a little hard to believe, but in South America every one is again getting ready for Summer.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Taking advantage of early scoring opportunities, Northwood School captured the fifth annual invitation prep school hockey tournament tonight with a 2-1 triumph over Andover. Williston took the consolation honors by beating Albany Academy, 2 -- 0.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Stations of the American Convent Mission in Hupeh Province "have been repeatedly bombed by Japanese fliers in the past eight months, despite the display of the American flag," Hjalmar Gravem of Minneapolis, Minn., a representative of the mission, said today.

RUTLAND, Vt. -- This is the season, ladies and gentlemen, when something peculiar happens to the no-nonsense people of Vermont, to the stately mountains and wide valleys of Vermont, even to the Republican air of Vermont. For the snows have already covered the uplands and it has come to pass of late that a few feet of snow alters the Vermonter's conservatism beyond recognition.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI is going to Hollywood again. We hear that one of the reasons is to make more recordings with Walt Disney, possibly to replace some of the present material in "Fantasia." As is well known by now, the two most disputed works in the film are Beethoven's Sixth symphony and Stravinsky's "Le Sacre du Printemps."

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 4 -- With the men of the Twenty-seventh Division preparing to begin a new intensive and realistic phase of training next week, the welfare and recreation officers redoubled efforts today to make the off-duty hours of the New York troops pleasant.

NOT quite twenty years ago Sinclair Lewis wrote the story of George F. Babbitt, the baby-faced, middle-aged realtor who "lived in a city built -- it seemed -- for giants," who had nothing of the giant about him, who "made nothing in particular, neither butter nor shoes nor poetry," but who was "nimble in the calling of selling houses for more than people could afford to pay."

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The President's radio speech increased sympathy here for the British cause without changing materially the strength of the groups already on record as to the extent of help to be extended.

IT is really a tonic, after some films we could mention, to hear of a picture being finished dead on schedule. Epic or no epic, Blitz or no Blitz, Warners' Disraeli film "An Empire Is Built" has been shot in the allotted forty-eight days at Teddington, for which we award the brothers' British representatives a large bouquet of primroses.

A wallpaper background need no longer imply that the room is simply hung with one type of paper on all four walls. Now one wall may be papered differently from the other three; a paper dado may give the lower part of the wall an accent; or even the ceiling may have an entirely different pattern.

Creation of a new Federal agency to adjust labor disputes in national defense industries was advocated yesterday by Professor Leo Wolman of Columbia University in a study published under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Promotions of January white sale merchandise increased in the advertising of New York stores last week, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Emphasis was also placed on cruise and resort wear, and response to these ads was fairly good.

IN life O. Henry was elusive. He had that reserve, that quiet, that often mark men who find better company in a glass than in a companion. A number of the people who have written about him claiming him as a friend, have proved his elusiveness by getting their facts wrong.

THE war in Europe will affect virtually everything in 1941, and its influence will become more noticeable in the world of records. Actually it has already left its mark on the recording industry, but that has not yet become apparent to the public.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- All New England accepted the President's Sunday night radio address as a state paper of enormous historic importance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- When the President, addressing Congress on Monday, specifies some of the immediate practical implications of his indictment of the Axis and his virtual proclamation of an emergency in his dramatic radio speech last Sunday, both the European war and American foreign policy probably will enter a new and perhaps decisive stage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Anti-propaganda will be a prominent feature at the "Inaugural Gala," a new name for the concert which the National Symphony Orchestra has been giving since 1933 for President Roosevelt's inaugurations.

NEVER before have children come into homes under quite the same circumstances as have the English children who have crossed the ocean to escape the nightmare of bombings. Never have American families taken on a task quite like that of caring for them.

Dean Thorndike Saville of the New York University College of Engineering yesterday decried the haphazard creation in the schools of defense courses which are not based on critical analysis of the work for which the educational system is best suited.

WAR abroad shrouds a philatelic forecast of the new year in more than the normal uncertainty. Obviously no one can foresee what prospects in the way of stamp issuing lie ahead for European lands occupied by the Nazis and for British, French, Dutch and Belgian colonies throughout the world.

Falla, an 8-month-old Scotch terrier, has become President Roosevelt's constant companion. He went along on his master's recent Caribbean cruise, got gifts at the White House Christmas party, and is mentioned in the First Lady's newspaper column.

DUBLIN, Jan. 4 -- Neutral Ireland laid new charges of bombing and the dropping of magnetic mines directly at the door of Germany today, and a newspaper close to the government declared "it is hardly conceivable" that the week's series of bombings was accidental.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 -- The Navy's use of "target boats" as "live" objectives for dive-bombing planes was disclosed today after two of the craft had made a brief stopover on their way down the Mississippi River.

GROUP shows, opening on the closing day of the year, afford good representations of the work of the artists associated with the Macbeth and Midtown Galleries. Both are made up of oils and water-colors and include recent work by the various painters.
ATHENS, Jan. 4 -- Germany is still playing the game of big brother and benefactor to the States of Southeastern Europe, but the role is not an outstanding success.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Emergency "iron rations" of corned beef were released today for sale in some London districts as the metropolis was faced with a week-end meat shortage due partly to a sell-out of meat supplies over the Christmas and New Year holidays.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 (Delayed) -- Questions affecting the Australian Imperial Force stationed in the Middle East are being discussed in Jerusalem by the Commonwealth's War Minister, P.C. Spender; the Chief of the Australian General Staff, Lieut. Gen. V.A.H. Sturdee and Lieut. Gen. Sir Thomas Blamey, commanding the Australian Imperial Force.

SOMEWHERE ON THE SOUTHERN ALABANIA BATTLEFIELD, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Commander in Chief of the Greek Army, voicing an appeal for speed in delivery of war materials ordered from the United States, declared tonight that "if Greece had 300 good airplanes perhaps the war would have been won before today."

Two performances of "The Talley Method," a new play by S.N. Behrman, with Ina Claire in the leading role, at the Henry Miller Theatre have been taken over to raise funds for philanthropic organizations. The first of these, on Jan. 28, the night after the opening performance of the production, has been taken over by members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement to further the organization's health and recreational programs.

WHEN, along with tin horns, hobby horses and rock candy, Santa Claus brought to town and thrust in Broadway's stocking one brightly beribboned wardrobe trunk labeled "Meet the People." Broadway didn't exactly clap its hands in gleeful anticipation. It was remembering several other express deliveries from Hollywood which had failed measurably to enrich this dour season.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 4 -- Although these farm States may have heard "nothing new" in the President's fireside talk on national security, they did hear something that stirred them. Folks turned from their radios or laid down their newspapers with a clearer notion of the gravity of the situation.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 4 -- Having completed two vocational training courses for national defense, Lafayette College is planning a technical training program to meet the shortage of engineers with specialized knowledge in essential fields, it was announced today by President William Mather Lewis.

The question of maintaining labor standards in the face of the requirement for greater industrial productivity in the present national emergency will come up for discussion at the forty-first annual meeting of the National Consumers League, called for Saturday at the Hotel Commodore.

NOW that the various observers have taken the usual delighted digs at the obstinate New York Film Critics and their annual choice of the past year's "bests," this member of that august assembly feels reasonably safe in coming out and making a few remarks intended to shed a ray of light.

AMONG all those writers who make up for us today what might be called The New England Worthies there is not one more fascinating, mysterious and inexplicable than Nathaniel Hawthorne. And that, assuredly, is why so many books and essays have been written about him.

It can truthfully be said that we as parents and teachers have done a rather good job in teaching our children how to think and care for themselves. In fact, we have done it so well that many of them think too much about their own welfare and are a little helpless when faced with the need of others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Senator Gillette of Iowa asked the State Department today to check reports that the Japanese Government was conscripting "American citizens of Japanese ancestry in Pacific Coast States and the Territory of Hawaii."

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The first event of its kind here this season will be an exhibition of rare Chinese jade carvings at the House of Jade, beginning Thursday. It will serve the double purpose of providing residents with an opportunity of viewing a collection valued at $5,000,000 and of raising more funds for war relief.

PRINCETON. N.J., Jan. 4 -- Princeton's hockey team swept its annual series against Harvard with a 6-2 victory in a penalty-ridden game in Hobey Baker Rink tonight. The Tigers won the first game last night, 10 -- 4.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 4 (AP) -- It was learned authoritatively tonight that Bulgaria has taken "certain military precautions" to prepare for her uncertain future in face of the growing German Army in the Balkans and increasing German-Russian rivalry within the country.

PANAMA CITY -- Under a decree by President Arnulfo Arias the postal authorities released on Jan. 2 a series of twelve stamps, all overprints, commemorating the new Constitution which became effective on that date. "Constitucion 1941" is the major overprint.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Under threat of a Supreme Court certiorari suit by Columbia University, the village of Irvington today was considering a compromise that would require the university to pay taxes on only parts of its estates, Glencoe and Nevis, here.

"SEVENTH AVENUE," as the title clearly suggests, is a novel about the New York garment trade. It is only incidentally a novel about the class struggle. Joe, who was a manufacturer of low-priced dresses, sympathized with the unions.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 4 -- Through cold going in a northwest clearing, thirty-one dinghies competed today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and the three class leaders were Edward Maxwell's B boat Tu Yung, Allan Clark's D craft Penguin and Forbes Morse's Penguin Class Puck.

THE Metropolitan Opera Guild and the Metropolitan Museum of Art will jointly present a lecture recital and exhibit concerning Gluck's "Alceste," Jan. 13, at 3:15 P.M. at the museum. Stanley Chapple, the English conductor, will speak on the background, text and score of the work, illustrating his talk at the harpsichord, and Helen Traubel, the Metropolitan soprano, will be the guest soloist.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 4 -- King Boris of Bulgaria is en route to Germany, it was reported reliably tonight. It was learned that the King left Sofia yesterday, reportedly to visit his father, former King Ferdinand, who is living near Vienna.

The British radio gave an outline yesterday of "a final reckoning of the enormous material damage done in Belgium, as assessed by. Belgium's commissariat of reconstruction in Brussels." The British Broadcasting Corporation's report, as recorded here by the Columbia Broadcasting System, said:

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- Mustafa Nahas Pasha, leader of the Wafd, Nationalist party, has presented to King Farouk a memorandum urging new general elections as a means of unifying the nation and obtaining from Britain definite commitments concerning Egypt's status after the war.

Progress in Army cantonment construction and basic equipment procurement has sent the selective military service machinery into full swing with New York City slated to furnish 5,085 men the second half of this month in addition to the 4,395 to be inducted begininng tomorrow.

AFTER a period of study, defense production experts in Washington last week reached the conclusion that the Reuther plan for the building of 500 planes a day by using idle automobile plants and machinery was impracticable.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 4 (UP) -- A British economic mission and the Argentine Government are said to have agreed in principle on a plan to ship British purchases of Argentine foodstuffs and other products to Cuba in neutral vessels, to be picked up there by British freighters.

When Franklin D. Roosevelt was Governor of New York, he chose as director of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration a social worker named Harry L. Hopkins. That was in 1931 when Mr. Hopkins, Iowa-born and educated, had just passed 40. The two men were beginning a close official relationship that was to ripen into close friendship.

The swimmers of Textile High School crushed Stuyvesant, 55 to 11, in the eighth series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League in the Textile pool yesterday and virtually made sure of retaining their divisional title.

HERSHEY, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP) -- A bill to set up a seven-man committee and give it $100,000 to investigate any un-American activities in Pennsylvania was approved today by the Pennsylvania Bar Association for submission to the 1941 Legislature convening Tuesday.

The usual year-end lull prevailed in the wholesale markets last week, but an exceptionally heavy buyer influx is expected from now on, according to a report prepared specially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

PROVIDENCE, R I., Jan. 4 -- Columbia defeated Brown, 49 to 36, before 1,000 persons in Marvel Gymnasium tonight. The Lions led, 28 to 21, at half-time, then pulled steadily away with a second period drive that netted 12 points while the Bruins were held scoreless.

THE gloom that has been hanging over the dramatic stage longer than the oldest inhabitant can recall has been partly lifted. As far as literary style, craftsmanship and interest in characters are concerned, John van Druten's "Old Acquaintance" has something genuine to offer, although the narrative is scanty and trifling.

Hitler's incendiary bombs over old London have taken toll of Johnson's Court and Bolt Court, north of Fleet Street, where Samuel Johnson spent the last twenty years of his life. Gone also is the Cheshire Cheese inn where, at least by tradition, Johnson foregathered with Goldsmith and with Boswell.

WITH the wind in their hair and the frost on their ears, young and old alike have tingled to the Winter thrill of the runnered plunge down a snow-packed hill. Even before skiing had made snow fashionable, there were thousands who eagerly awaited the first full-blown snowfall, for in its wake came the sleigh, the toboggan and the bobsled.

IT all depends on how a reader likes his historical biography, and whether he can take it straight from the source material put in narrative form with occasional commentary and asides, as to whether and how much he will enjoy this history of Joshua Barney, boy commander on the sea during the American Revolution, one of the naval heroes of the War of 1812, and adventurer at sea from the age of 13 until death.

The Original Ballet Russe last night added two works to its season's schedule at the Fifty-first Street Theatre, neither of them new, but both absent from the local scene for several years. The first was Leonide Massine's "Jeux d'Enfants," first seen here in 1933 and now retitled in English as "Children's Games," and the second was David Lichine's "Francesca da Rimini," which had its first and only previous presentations here in 1937.

AMONG the books dealing with America's duty in today's world crisis there is none in the present reviewer's opinion that quite compares with Professor Perry's little volume for a passionate belief persuasively stated.

THE frontier is nearer than we realize; close to the gates of our great cities, even of the greatest, the wilderness lies with its denizens (save for a few exceptions) much as they were when white men first reached these shores.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 5 -- Bristol on Friday night had as intense though perhaps not as continuous air raid as any city in these islands, it was learned yesterday. The attack was another fire raid followed by planes dropping explosives.
Two New York steamship concerns named officials to executive positions last week.

ONE of the characteristic features of our present literary landscape is the popularity of the autobiographical narrative. The public has eagerly read first-hand personal histories, not only of military heroes, adventurers or titled personages, but also of scientists, scholars, artists and doctors. The medical profession, averse to exposing its arcana, was at first somewhat slow to respond to the general demand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Dies committee charged tonight that the American taxpayer was being compelled to finance "a steady assault upon public opinion in this country" by "the printing presses oil Germany, Russia, Italy and Japan.''

Jerome Rappaport, New York pianist, who made his debut twenty-one years ago as an 8-year-old prodigy, gave the second recital of his maturity last night at the Town Hall. He confirmed the impression given by his recital a year ago that he had successfully made the difficult transition from prodigy to interpretative musician.

IN his discussion last week of the merits of programmatic music, Mr. Downes said; "Neither Debussy, Smetana, Wagner, nor a score of others felt ashamed to confess programmatic intention when it inspired them as musicians. And the music was none the worse for it."

A course in "How to Get Along With Other People's Families" has been prescribed for all visiting housekeepers in the Jewish Social Service Association, which supplies women to homes where the mother is ill or for some other reason must be temporarily replaced.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The British went to war because Nazi Germany had reached a point where she threatened to destroy the kind of world in which the British believe. They will call it off when that menace no longer exists, and not before then, unless they themselves are destroyed.

THE Museum of Modern Art has just announced the establishment of a Department of Photography, and by way of introduction it is now presenting an exhibition titled "Sixty Photographs: A Survey of Camera Esthetics." The exhibition will continue through next Sunday.

EXPERT: Henry Francis Grady is 58. For years he has divided his time between government posts and teaching jobs. He was once a professor of international trade at the University of California. Once he was on the United States Shipping Board. He has been on the Tariff Commission.

Under the Federal Estate Tax Law the proceeds of life insurance, like other property, must be included in the gross estate of a decedent. Such proceeds receivable by the executor, under policies taken out by the decedent upon his own life, are wholly taxable.

Long Island University's winning streak was ended at Madison Square Garden last night when a deliberate and painstaking Michigan State quintet staged a second-half rally that brought the Spartans a 31 -- 26 victory before 14,437 fans.

Fulfilling various predictions, education finds itself confronted with issues and controversies that promise to make the year not unexciting. The Coudert committee is investigating subversive activities in the New York schools. The National Association of Manufacturers has had prepared for distribution abstracts of 600 social science textbooks used in the public school systems of the United States.

WHEN L. Emmett Holt took his degree as a Doctor of Medicine in 1880, one-fourth of all the babies born in New York City died before the end of their first year. At the time of his death in 1924 the infant mortality rate had been reduced to less than one-third of the 1880 figure.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Red Wings drew even with the idle first-place Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-to-O victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Acquisition by the Library of Congress of eighty-six rare American children's books published between 1775 and 1850 was announced today by Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress.

The national defense program spurned a 28 per cent increase in the number of jobs offered to Columbia University men in the last academic year through the university's appointments office, Robert F. Moore, secretary of appointments, announced yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Society and distinguished artists of the opera and concert stage presented last night one of the most brilliant entertainments of the season, a musical soiree, that filled the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to capacity. It was the tenth anniversary jubilee dinner and musical for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Huntington Astor is acting president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- One out of every ten workers of a total labor force of 52,840,000 in the United States was unemployed when the census was taken on March 30. About one out of every twenty of those working was reported to be employed by the Federal Government on projects of the Works Progress Administration, National Youth Administration or Civilian Conservation Corps.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Farm prices, farm income and farm production costs are all likely to rise in 1941, according to a review of the agricultural situation issued today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

A good quantity of mail orders arrived in the wholesale markets last week for staples for January sales purposes. Retail stocks of piece goods, domestics, curtains, draperies and similar goods were reported exceptionally low, and the development of active response to January promotions was expected to result in a scramble for goods for spot delivery, a situation which the depleted condition of wholesale stocks should render even more acute. Advance buying of dresses

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. (UP) -- All Russian envoys to Balkan capitals have been summoned to Moscow for immediate consultation, it was understood tonight as reports spread of an impending German "peaceful occupation" of Bulgaria, perhaps within two or three days.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 5 -- Belgrade political and diplomatic circles were startled to learn today that the Soviet Minister, Victor Plotnikoff, had been called to Moscow suddenly. He left early this morning. There were reports from Bulgarian circles at the same time that the Soviet Minister to Bulgaria had received similar instructions and was leaving.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- A revival in the domestic demand for flour brought mills into the market here as buyers of wheat futures and sent the May delivery late last week into new ground since early in December. The buying movement was accompanied by a somewhat persistent reduction in the open interest in futures, and the total outstanding yesterday was the smallest in the twenty years for which official records are available.

Last week's foreign exchange market -- about evenly divided between the old and new year in trading sessions -- witnessed no new feature beyond the calendar change. Business was small and price variations as unimportant as they had been for many weeks preceding.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Actual physical difficulties, plus the psychological influence of last Sunday's fire raid on the City, reduced the week's business on the Stock Exchange to a mere shadow. Contributory factors in this spell of record stagnation were the New Year's holiday and preoccupation with year-end settlements in the business world generally.

While Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the British House of Lords, made a plea for aid to Britain yesterday at the opening of an international symposium at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, the congregation of 750 persons was unaware that a dozen detectives were sitting among them and that the building was surrounded by policemen.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 6 -- Prompt and heroic defense by the newly organized civilian "Fire-Bomb Fighters" last night reduced to a minimum the damage from another incendiary raid upon London.

ATHENS, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Italian forces, reinforced by troops rushed from Italy, have been driven back toward the Albanian Adriatic seaport of Valona after surrendering strategic positions to the Greeks and suffering heavy losses in dead, wounded and prisoners, it was stated officially tonight.

Whenever he can, Boris of Bulgaria puts on a pair of overalls and drives an engine. As a King he is intensely serious, but as a locomotive engineer he leaps to the cab as lightly as if he would gladly trade jobs -- and who wouldn't -- with the man who follows a straight track and is able to control the mechanism he runs.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Buffetted by high winds and forced to alter its course because of icing conditions over Texas, a four-motored Army Air Corps bomber returned here today after a 3,050-mile non-stop, non-refueling flight at an average speed of 190 miles an hour.

THIS is where Prof. Moe Berg of the Modern Language Department of the Rich Red Sox is put in his place. Professor Berg isn't so much after all. He merely went to Princeton, the Sorbonne and Columbia Law School in that order. And it took him some years to get around that far. Charley Peterson went to 218 colleges and universities last year.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 -- Cotton futures took a cue last week from the talk by the President to establish new high prices for the season. More determination by spot interests to fix prices and covering by shorts found the market with few offerings a good part of the period.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- The American meat-packing industry paid about $100,000,000 more for livestock in 1940 than in 1939, George A. Schmidt, chairman of the board of the American Meat Institute, said today. The increase was due partly to heavier marketings, he said.

BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Chicago gave Sam LoPresti, its rookie goalie, stout support while gaining a National Hockey League overtime tie with the Bruins, 2 -- 2, tonight before 12,000 persons at the Boston Garden.
As the problem of mobilizing the nation's skilled manpower becomes more urgent in the defense program, the experience of Britain in this matter is one to which Americans may well give heed.

David Sackson, formerly second violinist with the Gordon String Quartet, gave his second solo recital at the Town Hall at 5:30 yesterday afternoon. He played Handel's Sonata in A major and works by three Soviet composers.

WALES CENTER, N.Y., Jan. 5 (AP) -- A gayly decorated Christmas tree remained today in the home of Jack Swanson Jr., in the hope that the 15-year-old boy, sentenced in Louisiana to serve three years in prison for "stealing an apple," would return to see it.

BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- The progress of the political tug-of-war going on behind the scenes in Vichy is being watched in German official quarters with a curiosity that is not without a deep suspicion that a powerful clique in the Petain government is desperately determined to sabotage a French-German post-war rapprochement.

"Eight o'Clock Tuesday," a mystery play by Robert Wallsten and Mignon G. Eberhart, based on the latter's novel, "Fair Warning," opens tonight at Henry Miller's Theatre, with Pauline Lord starred. Miss Lord last was seen hereabout in another melodrama called "Suspect."

An appeal to American workers to help check "the brutal barbarism" of the Nazis by speeding up the production of planes and other war materials for Great Britain was sent to Matthew Well, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday by Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor and National Service in the British War Cabinet.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 5 -- A resolution barring Communists, Nazis and Fascists from national or local office in the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., was adopted here today by the union's general executive board.

VICHY, France, Jan. 5 -- Despite the vast expenditure proposed in the budget, the country is facing in the next six months the very worst of its rationing problem. Unlike Germany, which laid in stocks for more than a year in advance, France made no special preparations and did not even apply restrictions while the war was in progress.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 -- Long-hitting Jimmy Thomson moved back into the lead of the hotly contested $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today at the end f fifty-four holes. Gaining an advantage through another contender's hard luck, Thomson will go into tomorrow's final round with a one-stroke lead over Chicago's Johnny Bulla.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A policy of no strikes in the metal industries working on national defense orders was adopted here today by the chief officers of thirteen international unions in the metal trades affiliated with the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor.

My attention has been called to a reference to the Norwegian merchant fleet by Arthur Krock in an article on "The Ships in Our Waters the British Want." I regret to note that Mr. Krock has been misled.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 5 -Three alley tom cats that gathered outside a plate glass window of the ballroom of the Hotel Gramatan while the Eighth Annual Westchester Cat Show was being held this afternoon nearly disrupted the show. They loudly meowed and clawed at the window, so irritating the aristocrats on exhibition that hotel employes had to drive the marauders away with stones and sticks.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The "Free French" press service announced today that a "Free French" marine detachment had taken a "very active part in the British advance against the Italians" in Libya.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Lieut. Commander Stephen B. Cooke, one of four officers who were killed with seven others last night in the crash of a plane on a California mountain, had been approved by President Roosevelt on Friday for promotion to the rank of commander.

The board of directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers will consider today a plan for licensing radio advertisers directly for use of its music. Edwin Claude Mills, chairman of the ASCAP administrative committee, said that several agencies had requested licenses, but refused to name them until the board had considered their pleas.

Led by Nathaniel Lubell of the Salle d'Armes Vince, eight metropolitan fencers of a field of twenty-one survived the qualifying competition at the Fencers Club yesterday to enter the final of the All-Eastern intermediate foils championship.

B.M. Higginson and L.F. Sanman tied for the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, each with 96 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off, Higginson won, 23 to 22. The high handicap prize went to E.B. Horwath, who had a card of 90 -- 9 -- 99.

Conflict developed yesterday over the right of the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers to suspend the New York Teachers Union, which it has accused of practices "inimical to democracy."

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The New York State Legislature will convene on Wednesday of this week for its 164th regular session, to receive Governor Lehman's annual message, the ninth from him as Chief Executive, and to start on a course of which the trend of the war emergency is scheduled to be the guide.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The glory gained from tournament golf is nice, but the smartest thing a young professional can do is build a reputation, land a nice job and settle down. Thus speaks Willie Klein, Winter pro at the La Gorce Club here.

The Rev. John J. Considine, counselor of the Roman Catholic Foreign Missionary Society of America, discussed the activities of missionaries in the Orient at a meeting of the New York Province of the Newman Club Federation yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Corpus Christi Church, 535 West 121st Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Despite large British munitions orders in the United States in the first year of the war, only a small volume of liquidation of Canadian and English investments in the United States took place in the same period, according to a report on foreign investments in the United States by Paul D. Dickens and Milton Abelson of the finance division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

The Orchestra of the New Friends of Music gave its fourth concert of the season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. For this event an all-Mozart program had been prepared consisting of two familiar works, the symphony in E flat (K. 543) and "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik," which were followed by the rarely played piano concerto in F major (K. 459), with Hortense Monath as soloist.

When Hitler and his press fulminate against Mr. Roosevelt -- as they did last week -- some thoughtful Germans must ask themselves what the President really said to make the Leader so angry. It is a pretty safe prediction that they will not learn the answer to that question. Their dictator dares not let them read lest they begin to think.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Some steel companies are virtually out of the market because of their heavy backlogs of orders, but the majority are still putting orders on their books for delivery when material is available. The magazine Steel, publishing this appraisal today observed:

In the official chronicles of the Vichy Government the French Republic is no more and the "French State" takes its place, its framework and character still undetermined. The need for placating the German victors will doubtless figure largely in determining both. It seems tolerably certain, none the less, that appeasement and cooperation will go no farther than is rendered necessary by the duress under which the Government must operate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- The American League made history in 1940 -- a season which saw the establishment of the league's all-time attendance record and gave the fans one of the closest and most interesting pennant battles in all baseball history.

During the first year of legal betting at New York tracks under the parimutuel system none of the unpleasant developments predicted by opponents of State regulation appeared. The public indulged in no mad rush to gamble on the horses, though attendance increased moderately to about two million.
Wendell L. Willkie, who returned last night from vacation at Hobe Sound, Fla., had no comment to make on either war or polities when he arrived by an Eastern Airlines plane at La Guardia Field.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The capture of more than 25,000 Italian prisoners in the action against Bardia, Libya, means that Italian Marshal Rodolfo Graziani has lost some 80,000 of his North African force of 250,000 men since the British offensive began less than a month ago, British observers said tonight.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 5 -- The week's stock markets in the smaller Continental European countries, covering the end of 1940 and the beginning of the new year, showed an unexpectedly firm trend. Although, generally, trading remained highly restricted, a slight demand quite often sufficed to raise prices appreciably due a lack of selling urgency.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Assailing President Roosevelt as the leader of the "war party" in the United States, Phillip M. LaFollette, former Governor of Wisconsin, tonight declared that the President's foreign policy would carry this nation into a war "so gigantic in size and so terrible in cost that our efforts in the World War will look insignificant."

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 100.9 on Dec. 31, compared with 100.9 a fortnight before, 100.2 a month before, 92.1 a year ago, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- The Administrative Council of the Zionist Organization of America, the ruling Zionist body between annual conventions, met here this afternoon and unanimously endorsed the independent campaign by the United Palestine Appeal for $12,000,000 in 1941 to meet the growing and extraordinary war needs of immigration and colonization in Palestine.

The Hunter College chapter of Sigma Tau Delta, national English honor society, will initiate seventeen new members at a tea this afternoon in the lounge of the college's 695 Park Avenue building. The group, to be inducted by Miss Ethel Keresztes, president of the chapter, is the largest ever elected in one term.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Johnny Ray, manager of light heavyweight champion Billy Conn, said tonight he would sue promoters of the Melio Bettina-Anton Christo-foridis bout scheduled at Cleveland, Jan. 13, "If they don't stop advertising it as a light heavyweight title match."

Collector of Internal Revenue James J. Hoey expressed the belief in a statement issued yesterday that many taxpayers had been overpaying their Federal unemployment taxes because of a misunderstanding of the law.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Clyde Van Dusen, the Man O'War gelding who galloped to a muddy victory in the 1929 Kentucky Derby, soon will return to the races in the humble but important role of lead pony.

On Oct. 30, 1938, B. Charney Vladeck, labor leader and crusader for reform, died almost at the hour of realization of his greatest wish, the beginning of work in Corlears Hook of New York's first municipally subsidized housing project. Since then the development, now named Vladeck Houses, has risen on the site of the former slum, and 1,771 low-income families have moved in.

George McDonald, chairman of the board of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, central credit agency for thrift and home-financing institutions in the Second Federal Reserve District, reported yesterday that credits aggregating $1,142,695 were extenedd by the member institutions in this district in December. This makes total credits for 1940 $13,449,333, compared with $13,796,438 in 1939.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Harry L. Hopkins, personal and special envoy of President Roosevelt to Britain, will leave on tomorrow morning's Clipper from New York for Lisbon.

Armed with the experience gained in the first draft call, the city's Selective Service machinery will begin today its second induction period to supply to the Army men for whom cantonment construction has been pushed forward with increasing speed.

Contributions of $320.33 reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday from thirty-one donors, thereby increasing the total that has been received in response to this twenty-ninth annual appeal for the most needy persons in New York to $229,404.55.

The American Student Union, 381 Fourth Avenue, announced yesterday that a group of students in city colleges, who have been subpoenaed by the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating the public school system, will appear at 3 P.M. this afternoon at the committee's offices at 195 Broadway.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 5 -- Trapped in their burning apartment, Mrs. Cornelia Allerdice, 43 years old, and her son, Anthony, 7, died of suffocation today despite the efforts of another son, David Allerdice Jr., Princeton University football star, to save them.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The reported presence of a German secret police organizer and a former military governor of Berlin in Mexico, along with recent pro-Nazi, anti-Jewish manifestations, was said by responsible diplomatic sources today to have prompted a new investigation of Axis aims in Mexico.
Six Broadway cinemas will bring in new pictures during the week. The schedule shaped up yesterday as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Appointment of a National B'nai B'rith Defense Committee to assist the national defense program by making available to the government the man power and machinery of the 900 units of this national Jewis service and fraternal organization was announced here today.

The very fact that democracy is the most difficult form of government proves that it is the best, Dr. David Seville Muzzey declared in an address yesterday before the New York Society for Ethical Culture at its meeting house, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 5 -- The Fort Dix recruit reception center is prepared to receive 5,000 young men from civilian life in the next two weeks, outfit them as soldiers, give them rudimentary military training and send them to their proper niche in the nation's defense army.

New York City's first all-night school, with classes from 10:30 P.M. to 5 A.M., will open tonight at the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades, 50 Bedford Avenue, as part of the emergency training program for national defense, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

Beekman Street Hospital is described as a "basic necessity for the working and resident population of lower New York for clinic, emergency and first-aid requirements" in the nineteenth annual report of Howard S. Cullman, president, made public yesterday.

The fall of Bardia is another solar plexus blow to Italian prestige. It does not necessarily presage the conquest of Libya and the wiping out of Mussolini's African empire, nor is it likely to entail Italian withdrawal from the war. These are still beyond the horizon, though coming appreciably nearer.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The text of an Air Ministry communique:

Cotton prices, both spots and futures, strengthened last week and moved into new high ground for the season. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 10 to 15 points.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 5 -- Stiff by-the-numbers training for men of the Twenty-seventh Division will virtually end tomorrow when the eighth training week begins. That calisthenics formula which has characterized the training will give way to more flexible exercises.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan 5 (UP) -- Well-informed Thai (Siamese) quarters tonight were pessimistic about the possibility of a peaceful settlement of the Thai-Indo-Chinese border dispute, following a new and violent outbreak of fighting on the frontier, and predicted the outbreak of a "full-dress war" within a week.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 5 -- Political circles here continue to watch with interest the German propaganda efforts after their previous "calming" tactics have again caused disquiet in Southeastern Europe. Opinions are divided whether the objective is to divert British attention from Libya or increase Russian nervousness, or just to keep the populations of the Southeastern European States in a state of jitters.

Two silk flags, one the flag of the United States, the other the new flag of the Protestant Episcopal Church adopted at the 1940 general convention, were dedicated before the 11 o'clock service yesterday morning at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, by the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, rector.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 5 -- Under the sponsorship of a committee of citizens prominent in national life, medicine, education and journalism, Meharry Medical College of Nashville, the largest and only exclusively Negro medical college in the country, will begin this week a campaign to raise $1,700,000 to meet conditions attaching to General Education Board grants of $3,700,000 toward general endowment. Dr. Abraham Flexner of this city, national chairman of the drive, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, with a ruling that housing shortages exist in eleven areas where important national defense work is in progress, cleared the way today for government construction of 6,446 new family dwellings.

It will be tragic if the appeal of the Commander in Chief of the Greek Army for speed in delivery of war materials ordered from the United States does not meet with a quick response here. The decision we must make, however, is primarily a military, not a sentimental, one.

Acting under authority of the New Jersey Assembly, a committee of five members of the Legislature of that State, headed by Assemblyman Jacob S. Glickenhaus of Essex County, is studying the feasibility of a proposal to establish a system of toll parkways in New Jersey.

Placing air strength of the Axis at 41,000 planes, Britain's at 24,500 and ours at 6,000, T.P. Wright, vice president of engineering for the Curtis-Wright Corporation, in the current issue of Aviation Magazine, urges redoubling of American aircraft aid to Great Britain.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York reports deposits of $2,423,223,952 at Dec. 31, 1940, the highest in the history of the institution, compared with $2,291,011,486 on Sept. 30, 1940, and $2,088,427,346 at the end of 1939. Total resources likewise set a new high record at $2,718,966,013, against $2,584,742,898 three months before and $2,401,634,265 a year ago.

Mill shipments of all types of hosiery during November totaled 12,975,262 dozen pairs, an increase of 4.2 per cent over November, 1939, according to figures issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Women's full-fashioned hosiery shipments amounted to 4,717,517 dozen pairs, a gain of 7.8 per cent over a year ago.
ROME, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

The new year opened, as the old year closed, with prices steady on the Stock Exchange, but with volume of daily business after New Year's Day cut down nearly one-half from the million-share days with which this week began. Nothing in last week's war news changed the outlook.

The effort of the State Labor Department to stamp out unemployment insurance "chiseling" has resulted in the discovery of overpayments totaling $118,414 to 2,742 persons in the period since Aug. 1, 1939, officials of the division of placement and unemployment insurance reported yesterday.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 5 -- Blasts of the northwest wind which carried below-freezing temperatures to this section today wiped out the third and final session of the sailing dinghy regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, which was in celebration of the start of Winter dinghy windjamming.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 5 -- The Nazi organization here has taken advantage of the annual court vacation month of January to renew a desperate legal battle for the release under bond of eight leaders undergoing trial on charges of having plotted to seize Uruguay as an agricultural colony for Germany.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 5 -A 32-year-old woman was shot to death today in St. Andrew's Catholic Cathedral in downtown Grand Rapids and police are holding her estranged husband.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5 -- William Weisman, night club owner and former bootlegger, who was found slain, was linked today by investigators of the Essex County prosecutor's office to members of the Brooklyn murder ring. The police learned that Weisman had been active in bootlegging and narcotic peddling circles and that he had gambled considerably on sports events.

Austin J. Tobin, secretary of the Conference on State Defense, is issuing a statement today characterizing recent United States Treasury statements on Federal taxation of State and municipal securities as "misinforming and misleading."

Reporting on recent contributions to the United Hospital Campaign, Roy E. Larsen, general chairman, announced yesterday the receipt of anonymous contributions of $10,000 and $5,000, two of $300 each, two of $150 each, one of $126 and five of $100 each.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

Reuben Fine, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, and Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion, recorded brilliant triumphs in the opening round of the annual club title tournament yesterday. Fred Reinfeld won the shortest game, an encounter lasting seventeen moves.

The overwhelming majority of our people is convinced that a victory by Great Britain over the Nazis means security for us and the Americas. Some have no opinion; others believe that we need no help from any other country to protect America. Be that as it may.

The world needs less political philosophy and a new birth of old-fashioned Christian kindliness, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hasler entertained with a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club. In the party were Dr. and Mrs. Matthew T. Mellon and their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Armour; Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Drexler of Delray Beach, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Morrish, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald C. Rayner, Mrs. Flynn Stewart, Mrs. McAlpin Bell and E. Leonard Beard Jr.
OXFORD, Conn., Jan. 5 -- During the upland game season in Connecticut and New York one might question every bird and rabbit hunter encountered and hear not a word spoken in defense of the fox.

The Golden's rooming house on Sixth Avenue appeared tenanted by the furies. There was Ma Golden, who ran the joint, and Ruth, who was a nurse and should have been in love, and finally was in love. There was Tony, a gunman, and a building inspector, and Richard, a writer for the pulps who acted more like a Harvard man.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 -- Although the volume of incoming steel business last week continued to be affected by year-end influences, aggregate bookings were of sufficient magnitude almost to match capacity operations and current shipments.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 5 -- Japanese-occupied and free areas of China have become important sources of raw materials for Germany's continuation of the European war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Prices of corn held to within relatively narrow limits last week, but the market at one time went to the highest levels since late in November, and final sales on the Board of Trade yesterday were at gains of 1/4 cent a bushel on futures.

Men of science and men of letters should make special observance today of the Feast of the Epiphany because it is a festival peculiarly their own, the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- Bardia, the first big Italian stronghold in Libya, has fallen after the greatest British onslaught of the war thus far -- an onslaught in which Australian forces played a conspicuous part and in which the British Army, Navy and Air Force cooperated in simultaneous bombardment of Italian ports, batteries, ammunition depots and air bases.

Our hopes for 1941 must be for a complete, decisive and swift defeat of the totalitarian aggressors for the sake of all that gives dignity and sacredness to human life, for the sake of justice, reason, culture and religion, and for the sake of the aggressor nations themselves, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- William Holden, who walked out on his Paramount-Columbia contract two weeks ago in a salary dispute, will report for work at the latter studio tomorrow morning to prepare for "Texas," his next picture. The actor returned to Columbia yesterday to notify the company of his decision and his agent disclosed that his salary will remain at $350 a week.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Eleven Navy fliers, including four who parachuted from a storm-tossed Navy bomber in Texas on Thursday, perished last night in a flaming naval transport which crashed in a rainstorm on Mother Grundy Peak, thirty-five miles southeast of here.

VICHY, France, Jan. 5 -- The week's outstanding financial event was the publication of the budget covering only the first quarter of the year instead of the annual period. It is the first budget to be issued since the formation of the Republic which has not been submitted to Parliament.

The Tirana Realty Company, Henry M. Morgolis, president, representing a syndicate, has purchased from the 2660 Broadway Realty Corporation the ten-story and penthouse building at that address. There are nine stores and 300 rooms in the apartment house, which occupies a plot 126 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of West 101st Street.

VICHY, France, Monday, Jan. 6 -- In view of the icebound conditions in the South of France, possibly the greatest courtesy shown to Admiral William D. Leahy, the new United States Ambassador, on his first day in France was that the train to which his special car was attached steamed into the Vichy station exactly on scheduled time, two minutes before midnight.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Bad weather failed to keep British Royal Air Force planes at home either in daylight or dark yesterday.

Christmas will be celebrated at vespers tonight and high masses tomorrow morning by Eastern churches in what is one of the most colorful tributes to the birth of Christ. These churches follow the Julian calendar, hence Christmas comes thirteen days later than Dec. 25 on the Gregorian calendar.
