BERLIN, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Strong German bomber formations were reported today to have carried out "most successful" attacks agansit Avonmouth, British port and industrial center near Bristol, and other militarily important objectives along Bristol Channel.

The people of this country have made up their minds to devote their greatest energy and whatever money is necessary to the preparation of the nation for defense, and this includes the support of England during the emergency.

Homing pigeon fanciers in all parts of the country are being asked to register their lofts -- estimated to total 40,000 -- with Army Headquarters at Washington to facilitate the conscription of the birds in a national emergency, it was disclosed yesterday by Major John K. Shawvan, in charge of the pigeon service of the Army.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The steel supply is "ample" for a long European war, Vincent Delport, European editor of the magazine Steel, asserts in the current issue.

Although Marc Blitzstein describes his "No For An Answer" as an opera, no one need feel discouraged on that account. For it might just as well be put down as music drama, which has a less forbidding sound. Whatever it is academically, it is very exciting in performance, which is all that matters, and it is dramatically staged at Mecca Auditorium, where it had the first of three Sunday night performances last evening.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The quarrel between United States marines and the Japanese military in Peiping, regarding detention of five United States marines last Monday night after a cabaret quarrel, still was unsettled today but it is understood efforts for a local solution will be continued.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Two goals by Joe Boyle in the first six minutes enabled Brookhattan to administer to the Passon Phillies their first home defeat of the season today after five victories in the American Soccer League. The score was 2 -- 1.

With Phil Watson performing the hat trick, the Rangers had little trouble subduing their New York rivals, the Americans, in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Going into the lead early in the battle and profiting subsequently by their eager rivals' errors, the Blue Shirts set back Red Dutton's crew by the topheavy count of 6 to 2.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill has decided to create a "big four brain trust" to direct war production, according to morning newspapers.

A report protesting against the development of the St. Lawrence Waterway and Power project as a "national defense" measure was issued yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York. The report urged Governor Lehman and the State Legislature to reaffirm opposition to the undertaking.

Norman Thomas, chairman of the Socialist party, issued a statement yesterday warning all members of the party against association with the No Foreign War Committee, because of "reliable information" that the National Action Committee of the party had received reports "discreditable to its chairman, Verne Marshall, and certain of his associates."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh was described tonight by Mrs. Irving Berlin, the former Miss Ellin Mackay, as a "sensitive and gentle woman who has been bewildered and frightened by skillful German propaganda."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 5 -- Norway's Police Minister, Jonas Lie, published in yesterday's Oslo press a decree abolishing the professional secrecy of doctors, lawyers, clergymen and postal and telegraph workers.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, announced yesterday that Basil Harris, director of the United States Lines, had accepted the chairmanship of the Fordham University Council, an honorary group. Mr. Harris, a graduate of Princeton University, helped to establish the Fordham School of Social Service.

Holders of $8,060,000 of Republic of Panama 5 per cent bonds due on May 15, 1963, or approximately 71 1/4 per cent of the $11,313,500 bonds outstanding, have signified approval of the plan and deposit agreement for readjustment of the external indebtedness of Panama, according to C.F. Herb, chairman of the committee of bondholders for the 5 per cent issue.

Otto Klemperer, who in a series of three concerts last Fall transformed the orchestra of the New York City WPA Music Project from a group of average instrumentalists into a good symphony orchestra, last night took charge of the orchestra again and conducted it in a stirring and beautiful concert at Carnegie Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Viscount Cranley, 27-year-old heir of the Earl of Onslow, who has made a tour of thirty of London's public air-raid shelters, reported his findings for The London Sunday Times today.

Part of the program given by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall had the character of a vehicle for a virtuoso conductor rather than music of inherent importance.

Mild weather up to this last weekend, coupled perhaps with one of the still mysterious cycles in food crops, has brought an unusual bird population to New York and its environs this Winter. While the annual "bird census" conducted under the auspices of the National Association of Audubon Societies has not completed its tabulation, the suburban dweller has made some surprising observations of his own.
Professional tennis comes back into Madison Square Garden tonight after an interlude of almost two years.

A basketball thunderbolt struck in the metropolitan area and shattered two winning streaks last Saturday night. While Long Island University met its master in Michigan State at Madison Square Garden, the high-flying Panzer squad, which over a three-season span had forgot the meaning of the word "lose," bowed to John Marshall at Union City, N.J.

With thousands of persons leaving and returning to the city yesterday, railroads, bus lines and plane companies pressed extra sections into use to cope with what they termed one of the busiest days in recent years.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- "Ladies and gentlemen -- the champion, Willie Hoppe" . . .

ROME, Jan. 5 -- To the Roman patriciate and nobility who paid homage to him today as their ancestors have done to other Popes through many centuries, Pius XII repeated his prayer that 1941 might bring "a just and durable peace."

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- Japan's plans for a new world order are interwoven with her alliance with Germany, Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka declared in a radio address to Japanese communities abroad today. The address was first broadcast for the Americas, then for the army in China and a third time for Japanese in the South Seas.

Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, who made their debut here as a two-piano team twelve years ago, gave their annual New York recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Like previous recitals, it was characterized by excellent playing, an unhackneyed program and a friendly audience which revealed by its applause on their initial appearance that many of its members had heard and enjoyed them before.

An underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer today to the public a new issue of $15,000,000 of serial notes of Phillips Petroleum Company, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A campaign to scrap the WPA as a "relief program and replace it with a non-relief "Defend America Works Program," on the ground that WPA labor is being used on vital defense projects at rates of pay only half of those given to labor hired by normal procedure, will be started tomorrow by the American Security Union.
BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- An easy money market, lower interest rates for government borrowing and strong advances in both stocks and bonds were outstanding characteristics of the first days of the new year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Sir Hugh Dowding, former commander in chief of Britain's air fighters, arrived today to confer with government officials and aircraft experts on the problem of coordinating American plane production and equipment with Britain's needs.
Twenty-seven railroad presidents have accepted invitations to attend the annual meeting of the Atlantic States Advisory Board in the Biltmore Hotel on Wednesday and Thursday.

Resplendent in wide-brimmed ten gallon hats and high-heeled boots and laden down with other souvenirs of their trip to the New Year's Day Cotton Bowl game in Dallas, Fordham's footballers came home yesterday to receive a thunderous ovation at Pennsylvania Station from a milling crowd estimated at 10,000.
ROME, Jan. 5 -- Giovanni Ansaldo, authoritative Fascist editor, broadcast to the nation today that the fall of Bardia could be expected at any time and that this will be a "sad piece of news for us."

A denial that he was a backer of Verne Marshall and the No Foreign War Committee, although sympathetic with its aims, was made yesterday by William Rhodes Davis, the international oil operator who Mr. Marshall had said brought a German "agenda" for peace to the United States in 1939.

Verdi's "Otello" with Giovanni Martinelli in the title role and Lawrence Tibbett as Iago, the roles they sang when the opera was restored to the repertoire three seasons ago, will be performed for the first time this season next week at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Entering a show ring for the first time, Eldgyth Apollo was awarded the best-of-breed title in the competition for English springer spaniels which was the only breed completed yesterday in the opening judging of the twenty-fourth specialty show of the American Spaniel Club held in the Hotel Roosevelt.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Bud Washbond, son of an Olympic champion, and Adrian Aubin opened the 1941 bobsled season today by winning the half-mile novice race on the ice-banked Mount Van Hoevenberg run.

ATHENS, Jan. 5 -- The Athens radio predicts that within the next few days the Italian military situation will prove to be far worse than it appears even today as the result of the continued Greek advances and the British successes in Africa.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Ulster Unionist Council, which stands for continued union with the British Crown, declares that Southern Ireland's [Eire's] neutrality is "deliberately prejudicing Britain's prospects of success in a struggle which means as much for one country as the other."

The Bankers Trust Company, as trustee for Lukens Steel Company first mortgage twenty-year 8 per cent bonds (extended to Nov. 1, 1955, at 5 per cent) will receive at its corporate trust department up to Feb. 6 sealed proposals for the sale to it of sufficient of these bonds to exhaust the sum of $148,463 now in the sinking fund at prices not to exceed par and accrued interest.

In an action-jammed Easter a Hockey League battle enlivened by two fist fights in the second period the New York Rovers kept the River Vale Skeeters in the cellar position by drubbing their New Jersey foes, 4 to 2, in the star game of an amateur twin bill, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, at Bardia, Libya, Jan. 5 -- Yelling Australian shock troops who came 7,000 miles for this great desert battle against Premier Mussolini's legions triumphantly entered this gateway to Eastern Libya today after a fierce two-day final assault.
ROME, Jan. 5 -- The loss of "strong points" in Bardia is announced in today's Italian war bulletin. The communique was clearly intended to advise Italians that things were not going well in Bardia.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell contended in his sermon yesterday morning that the new world order of the Kingdom of God was opposed today by the new order that the Axis powers seek to impose upon the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A total of $103,807,000 in temporary-loan notes issued by local housing authorities will be sold to private bidders in January, the United States Housing Authority announced today.

Reactions upon Japanese industry are already apparent from the extension on Dec. 30 of the American steel scrap embargo to include other iron and steel products. A recent Tokyo dispatch reported a sharp expansion of the Japanese steel program in the effort to offset the loss of American supplies.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- The largest crowd in this park's thirty-year history, 15,000 persons, thrilled to the daring exploits of a record field of seventy "fliers" today when the inaugural United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association jump of the season was held.

Your editorial "Youth and the Timid Elders" hits a spot which has needed hitting for a long time, and we of the Youth Foundation rise to remark that we are on your side. We have been saying so ourselves in spite of the difficulty of being heard over the clamor of the youth "spokesmen."

The need for a positive faith coupled with positive action to combat the doctrines and practices of the totalitarians was stressed by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold to the 3860 Park Avenue Corporation the five-story factory building at that address near East 149th Street. The building, which contains about 40,000 square feet and is on a plot 125 by 150 feet, is assessed at $60,000.

A major factor in preventing substantial economic recovery in the United States during recent years has been the persistence of certain economic fallacies which have reflected themselves in legislation and in the thinking of many important groups in the nation, according to Malcolm Muir, president and publisher of Newsweek, in the foreword of a report to be published today by the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Roosevelt will go before a joint session of the two houses of the new Congress at 2 P.M. tomorrow to deliver what is expected to be an "all-out short-of-war" program for aid to Britain which will engage the national legislature for weeks to come.

Democracy can be undermined if citizens within it merely claim individual freedom but deny their personal responsibilities, the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams declared yesterday morning at Prospect Avenue Methodist Church, Greenwood Avenue, Brooklyn.

Deposits of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, N.J., amounted to $174,823,908 at Dec. 31, 1940, compared with $155,201,534 a year before, and total assets were $194,068,381, against $173,777,277. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $67,240,593, United States Government obligations to $39,284,612, and loans and discounts to $45,251,168, compared with $42,922,766, $43,602,388, and $42,519,131, respectively, a year before.

Add to the list of Broadway screen openings Warners' "The Case of the Black Parrot," which will arrive at the Palace on Thursday. The other film on the double-feature program will be "No, No, Nanette." . . . "Comrade X" will be held over for a third and final week on Thursday at the Capitol and will be followed by "Flight Command," which had been scheduled previously to open Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt today again defied the dictators, denounced appeasers, called for full material aid to the embattled democracies and, for the first time, outlined a four-point program for an eventual peace built upon "essential human freedoms."

The recent decision of the New York State Court of Appeals upholding the Burks Sharkey Price Posting Law was said yesterday by the Garage and Gasoline Station Operators Council as affording far greater protection to New York City motorists in their purchases of gasoline.

In preparation for the celebration of its hundredth year next season, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York is planning a star-studded program, it became known last night. There will be a parade of some of the world's most eminent conductors, and among those who have been invited to appear again with the orchestra are Arturo Toscanini and Leopold Stokowski.

A proclamation announcing plans for the observance of "Preparedness Through Production Week" from Jan. 19 to 25 for the purpose of rallying every manufacturer in the nation to the service of supply for "embattled democracy" was issued yesterday by Walter D. Fuller, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The owl, or lobster shift, something new in New York City's educational system, started last night in the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades at 50 Bedford Avenue, on the edge of Greenpoint. It is part of the defense plan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The two furniture and home furnishings markets opening here today developed into sellers' affairs, with prices firm and first-day buyer registration and orders breaking all records.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Michigan State ended Temple's six-game winning streak tonight by beating the Owls, 37 to 35, in an extra-period game that was the feature of a double-header basketball program at Convention Hall before 6,000.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the First Army, expressed yesterday "the utmost confidence" that the defense program on which the United States has embarked will bring the country eventually to that security for which it is planned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt's "lend-lease" plan for aiding Great Britain will mean more borrowing and taxing by the Treasury, Secretary Morgenthau said today at his press conference. He added that it would make a marked change in the original estimate of the Treasury regarding the scale of its fiscal program.

Criticism of the city administration "for its action which changed the dentists in the public school system from an annual basis to a per diem basis" was voiced last night by the incoming and outgoing presidents of the First District Dental Society of the State of New York at a meeting of the society at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Harry Gannes, former columnist and foreign editor of the Communist publication, The Daily Worker, died Saturday evening at his home here, it was disclosed yesterday. Mr. Gannes had been suffering from a brain tumor for more than a year. He was 40 years old.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Wheat futures resumed today the creeping advance which has been in evidence of late and went into new high ground since November. The May delivery sold at 88 1/2 cents a bushel at one time. Mills were credited with having bought the May around 88 cents early, and while commission houses appeared to have taken profits above that figure the selling was steadily absorbed.

EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., Jan. 6 -- A strike to begin Thursday evening at the plant of the Ranger Engineering Division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation was authorized by a unanimous vote at a meeting here tonight of the members of Local 661, Aircraft Division of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., Jan. 6 -- After fourteen weeks of fundamental training that accomplished the dual purpose of hardening the men and teaching them the rudiments of military life, the 1,700 officers and men of the 245th Coast Artillery (Harbor Defense) Regiment started today on an intensive schedule of specialized training designed to make them expert with the heavy guns that guard New York Harbor.

ISTANBUL, Jan. 6 -- Both the anti-Turkish campaign in the Italian press and the dispatch of German planes to help Italy against Greece are being treated here as signs of Italian imperial weakness. The German aerial assistance is regarded as being furnished to the tottering Fascist system rather than the Italian nation.

Lexington Avenue began going nautical yesterday with the early and unexpected arrival at the huge portals of the Grand Central Palace of a number of the displays for the National Motor Boat Show which will open Friday night.

VICHY, France, Jan. 6 -- There is a general presentiment here that decisions of great importance may develop before the week is out. In Vichy presentiments count for much, in view of the silence surrounding even minor events.

In advance of the opening of the New York Season of Ballet Theatre, an exhibition entitled "Ballet Art Since 1900" opened yesterday at the Junior League Club House, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to be current through Friday, Jan. 17. More than a hundred oils, watercolors, drawings and sketches have been assembled, with contemporary French and American artists and designers of decor represented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Federal Trade Commission has charged the Wire Rope and Strand Manufacturers Association, Inc., of Washington, D.C., three of its officers and sixteen member companies manufacturing 95 per cent of the country's production of wire rope with unlawful agreement, combination and conspiracy to eliminate competition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Treasury's gold stock today passed $22,000,000,000, roughly 80 per cent of all the monetary gold in the world.

Slightly more than five years ago the rapidly expanding Borough of Queens had very little in the way of municipal hospitals. Through an arrangement with the city, private hospitals in the borough had to carry the main load of acute cases, while chronic patients found themselves some distance from home on Welfare Island or in Kings County Hospital.

ROME, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today reported only "local actions" took place on the Albanian front, but said "considerable losses" were inflicted on the Greeks, and arms and prisoners were taken.

ROME, Jan. 6 -- The Italian communique does not admit the fall of Bardia today, nor has any commentator in the press given the news. However, the bulletin for the first time refrains from saying "the battle is still going on."

The forty-ninth annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors opened with a reception and preview last evening at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Violet Oakley, the well-known Philadelphia artist, was guest of honor.

As the years go by, they only deepen the sincerity and simplicity of Efrem Zimbalist. There was proof anew of the essential dignity of the man and the artist when he appeared at Carnegie Hall last night. Without fuss or mannerisms, Mr. Zimbalist gave a series of poised, musicianly performances.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 6 (AP) -- The minor leagues, which hold a numerical superiority over the major leagues by about 43 to 2, are going to ask the majors to grant them a voice in selecting "future" high commissioners of baseball.

Net earnings of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for 1940 amounted to $9,555,000, including profits from sale of United States Government securities, or more than three times the annual dividend requirements, Allan Sproul, president of the bank, announced yesterday.

S. Cristy Mead, secretary and administrative head of the Merchants Association for forty-four years, announced yesterday his retirement to become effective Jan. 15. He will continue to serve on the board of directors.

MOST Americans know that during the Civil War there was a great and bitter battle at a place called Fair Oaks, or, as it is sometimes listed, Seven Pines. Probably not one in a thousand knows that during another American civil war there was another battle, quite as bitter though much briefer, at a place called Seven Oaks.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in Bardia, Jan. 6 (UP) -- British cleanup squads roamed the byways of shell-wrecked Bardia today, clearing out isolated pockets of Italian "Terribili" still resisting in remote gullies around the Libyan coastal base.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Diplomatic sources regarded joint Russian-Turkish resistance to any German push through Bulgaria as still likely tonight despite German reports that the U.S.R.R. had agreed to let the Nazis enter and take over Bulgarian territory.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 7 -- London had three daylight attacks by German raiders yesterday -- something that had not happened in more than a month. The British Air Ministry said the Nazi fliers were apparently on reconnaissance; but a few planes dropped bombs, killing some persons, injuring others and wrecking homes in scattered sections of the metropolitan area.

HERE goes for the annual dive into matters aquatic. Once a year it is the custom in this corner to go overboard with a splash and kick vigorously, if ineffectively, against a curious custom in swimming circles.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 6 -- Coming from behind, Mrs. Stewart Iglehark, unattached, defeated Miss Helen Stone of Rockaway Hunting, 17 -- 18, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 8, in the second round of the tenth annual women's New York State squash racquets championship started at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 6 -- Excerpts from an address made by former President Theodore Roosevelt in Milwaukee in 1910, in which he envisioned the United States as a nation "which holds out the lamp of hope to all the other nations throughout the world," were read here today during the annual pilgrimage to the late President's grave in Youngs Memorial Cemetery.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The first major move to draft British labor was seen tonight in the powers granted the Production Executive. The reference in the official statement to allocation of labor was the first official intimation that the government might use the powers granted last May 22 to say where and how available man power should be used.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 3 per cent for the week ended Jan. 4, in comparison with the like week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop in volume chiefly reflected the poor results on the Thursday night opening last week, following the New Year holiday.

Arthur Whittemore of Vermilion, S.D., and Jack Lowe of Denver, who met as fellowship students at the Eastman School of Music in Rochester and began playing as a duo piano team four years ago while visiting in Puerto Rico, gave their second New York recital last night at the Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Congress officially confirmed today the outcome of the November Presidential election.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 6 -- The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, which has summoned officials controlling the purse strings of the major political parties of this State to appear at a hearing Wednesday in Washington, entertains more than a passing interest in a loan of $39,110 by the Democratic State Committee of New Jersey to the Democratic State Committee of New York, it was learned today.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Withdrawal of the application of George A. Hamid for a horse racing, pari-mutuel betting franchise at the Trenton Fair and submission of an additional track site by an Atlantic City group were highlights of today's meeting of the New Jersey Racing Commission.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- While the fall of Bardia can scarcely be interpreted as an Italian victory, the German press today is unstinting in its praise of the "heroic Italian resistance," which, it is implied, finally was forced to break under the pressure of superior forces.
Leases for several units of space along Madison Avenue in the Sixties were numbered among the latest commercial leasing transactions yesterday.
EMPORIA, Kan., Jan 6 -- Following is an editorial on President Roosevelt's message by William Allen White, appearing tomorrow in Mr. White's paper, The Emporia Gazette:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Continuance of the County Center here under the full management of the Westchester County Recreation Commission is essential to the county recreation program that now serves 25,000 to 30,000 persons, Mrs. Eugene Meyer of Mount Kisco and Washington, commission chairman, told the Board of Supervisors today in "refusing categorically" to share the management with a commercial tenant.

OTTAWA, Jan. 6 -- Everybody in Canada who could get near a radio listened to President Roosevelt's message to Congress this afternoon, and it is no exaggeration to say that business was halted virtually everywhere until the broadcast ended.

During 1940 Brooklyn, with a total population of 2,660,000, was the third largest population community in the country -- being exceeded only by the city as a whole and by Chicago -- the fourth largest manufacturing center and among the leading eight cities of the nation in building activity, the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce declared in a survey, made pubic yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Widespread raids on Paris libraries and bookstores by the German Gestapo, highly placed educational quarters disclosed today, have swept their shelves clean of anti-Nazi writings and much philosophical and historical literature.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 6 -- Flags were flown from buildings all over Australia today in a nationwide tribute to the Bardia victory. Prime Minister Robert Menzies announced that Australian casualties did not exceed 500 and added that the Australians clearly occupied the place of honor in the victory.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The University of Chicago basketball team took an overtime game from Princeton, 32 to 31, at the Midway Field House tonight. Chicago scored near the end of the extra period, Mike McMahon hooking in the winning basket.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 -- B.F. Whitaker's one-time stake performer Mythical King, who recently returned to winning form at Tropical Park, repeated that score today with a head triumph in the mile-and-seventy-yard Dania Purse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn of the House was 59 years old today but, despite a White House statement to the contrary, he said that had nothing to do with President Roosevelt choosing the day to present his annual message to Congress.

ATHENS, Jan. 6 -- It is learned from official sources that the Greek Army has now taken about 13,000 Italian prisoners since the war started and, in addition to this figure, a considerable number of casualties have been inflicted, rendering a sizable dent in the expeditionary force which was designed to occupy this country.

At this New Year season in this country the outlook for every enterprise scheduled for the coming year is more closely bound up with the outlook of the nation as a whole than ever before. We in the National League are preparing for an active season.

Albert S. Pinkus defeated Boris Blumin, former Canadian champion, in their adjourned game from the sixth round yesterday and regained the lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club.

Not content with her new glory as an earthquaker New Hampshire is whirling in an etymological dance. The Governor of that State feels it his duty in the last minutes of his term not to deny to the Legislature the need of some melodious parting words. Governor-that-was Murphy did this mournful duty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- How deeply the nation is concerned over possible consequences of the Executive policy of all-out aid to the victims of the Axis was revealed today by the behavior of members of Congress as they listened. In the opinion of many who watched from the galleries this behavior was more eloquent than the published comment.

Busily engaged in preparing for the Eastern States figure-skating championship, to be held Friday and Saturday at Rye, Miss Phebe Tucker, 18-year-old New Yorker, yesterday interrupted her training routine long enough to pass the high-ranking Gold Medal championship test.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- As if taking the cue from the attitude of President Roosevelt, a joint session of the Seventy-seventh Congress heard his address today in an atmosphere of solemnity reflecting the seriousness of the times. The vociferous applause that usually greets the "State of the Union" speech, was lacking.

Ten Brooklyn College students, members of the American Student Union, served with subpoenas last last week by the Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local school system, announced yesterday that they would not testify before the one-man private hearings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Reaction on Capitol Hill to President Roosevelt's message to the Congress calling for further material aid to Britain was predominantly favorable in the ranks of both major parties, although adverse comments came from Senators Wheeler, Taft and Shipstead and also from some members of both parties in the House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Supreme Court upheld the National Labor Relations Board in three rulings today, the principal one supporting the board's decision in the H.J. Heinz Company case, where the company was required to sign a written agreement with a union after both sides had arrived at an oral understanding.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Everybody in Europe except the Germans seemed to be talking about the Balkans tonight.

The Neediest Cases Fund rose to a total of $229,907.55 yesterday as forty-three gifts, aggregating $503, were received for the relief of the suffering men, women and children who have been adjudged as in the most acute distress known to exist in New York City.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 -- For the benefit of British refugee children, Lee Gron, pianist, appeared tonight in recital at the Everglades Club, arranged by the Marquis and Marquise George de Cuevas.
Day after day experts tell us that this or that plan to speed up the manufacture of planes or other war material is impossible.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A series of heavy explosions and bright flashes on the French coast, heard and seen across the Strait of Dover despite a muffling fall of snow, indicated last night that the R.A.F. again was smashing at the invasion ports.

Supplies of locally dressed fresh meats were moderate to light yesterday. Demand was fair to good and prices were strong to higher. Early kosher business was fair to good at steady to stronger prices. Conditions as reported by the Department of Agriculture follow:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Good news was announced today at Bear Mountain State Park by A.K. Morgan, general manager, who stated that instructions in skiing would be given Sunday and that the charge for renting equipment, skis and poles, would be nominal.

A tall young man with a frank manner and pleasant smile, who had obtained a job as a $2,100-a-year law clerk, reported to work yesterday at 8:45 A.M. -- fifteen minutes early -- at the law offices of Wright, Gordon, Zachry Parlin, 63 Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Highlights from President Roosevelt's message to Congress on "the state of the Union" follow:

MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Bill Cowley of the Bruins remained at the head of the parade of National Hockey League point-getters during the last week, but it was Phil Watson of the Rangers who made the big advance.

Notwithstanding an apparent trend to the offense in the game, most of the conversation at yesterday's luncheon of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln was devoted to defense.

A little more than a decade ago David Belasco produced a play by Lili Hatvany as adapted by Fredric and Fanny Hatton called "Tonight or Never," with Helen Gahagan and Melvyn Douglas in the leading roles. This evening J.J. Shubert will submit a musicalized version of it at the Hudson under the title of "Night of Love."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except interbank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 1 aggregated $10,608,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission told Congress today that the national defense program had raised the question whether the nation's transportation facilities "will be able to do their part adequately and effectively," but said the answer would have to come from the National Defense Council.

The chief officers of thirteen international unions in the metal trades affiliated with the American Federation of Labor have adopted a declaration of policy that there must be no strikes in the metal industries working on national defense. This is a wise and patriotic action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Paramount today purchased "Joan of Arkansas," a magazine story by David Garth. No players have been assigned to the picture, which will be a hill-billy comedy, but it is understood that the scenario will be designed for Betty Brower, the studio's new child actress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to the 77th Congress on the state of the Union as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The surrender of Bardia infused more cheerfulness into the stock markets today. Business, however, continued to feel the effects of the interruption to communications and the news of the Italian reverse, therefore, did not have its full effect on the market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The fight by Texas to sustain oil production pro-ration orders issued by the State Railroad Commission for the East Texas field was successful again in the Supreme Court today. Last June the court also supported the power of the State in this regard.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The total round-lot volume of the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 21 was 4,654,220 shares, compared with 4,578,980 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

GANNAT, France, Jan. 6 -- Captain Gaston Robert, a decorated officer of the French Foreign Legion, was acquitted today by the summary military court here of charges of serving with the British and of de Gaullist activities.

Affably but steadfastly declining to comment on the nature of his mission to London as the personal envoy of President Roosevelt, Harry L. Hopkins, close friend of the President and former Administrator of the Works Progress Administration and Secretary of Commerce, left for Lisbon yesterday morning at 9:23 o'clock aboard the Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways.
ROME, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Buyers representing stores in practically every section of the country began to arrive in large numbers here yesterday, presaging brisk activity in the wholesale markets this week and next. Optimism regarding prospects for Spring trade was general, reflecting the expectation that national defense expenditures and increased industrial activity will increase consumer purchasing in most areas.
Operators and investors were active in the realty trading reported yesterday, when holdings of residential and business parcels in several areas of the city went into new ownership.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Amy Johnson, British aviatrix, drowned in the frigid waters of the Thames estuary yesterday afternoon when her plane sank before ships steaming at full speed could reach her.

Miss Alice Marble, the world's foremost woman tennis player for the last two years, launched her career in professional competition at Madison Square Garden last night with a hard-earned victory over Miss Ruth Mary Hardwick of Great Britain.

By a four-to-one vote, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Board of Education could not interpret the dual-job law to mean that New York City school teachers could be employed in two positions for "1,000 clock hours of teaching" rather than "one school year."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The fares charged for transportation in the Hudson Tubes will be discussed before the Supreme Court through an order issued today granting tentative approval for such a hearing. Such approval is almost invariably tantamount to an outright agreement.

GRETNA, La., Jan. 6 (AP) -- The fate of Jack Swanson Jr., who pleaded guilty to stealing an apple, received a penitentiary sentence and then gained release from it because he is only 15 years old, was still in doubt today.

ROME, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Reports today from Bengazi, Italian headquarters in Libya, indicated that British forces, consisting mainly of mechanized Australian units, were spreading out fanwise beyond Bardia, apparently aiming at taking important oasis points in the desert preparatory to attacking Tobruk.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 31: A decrease of $121,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, an increase of $82,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, a decrease of $83,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and an increase of $146,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 97.2 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is the highest weekly rate recorded since weekly figures first were compiled, in the Fall of 1933, and exceeds all the monthly rates reported since 97.7 per cent for June, 1929.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Governor Lehman, in a statement issued here to day for the second anniversary of the establishment of savings-bank life insurance in the State, declared that to date more than $12,000,000 in insurance had been issued and that more than 14.000 policies had been taken out since the adoption of the law.

Few men -- one must think of such figures as Freud and Einstein for comparison -- have so deeply colored the thought of their generation as did Henri Bergson. He stepped into world fame with the publication of 'L'evolution creatrice" in 1907. The book immediately created a philosophic sensation.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- A Ministry to study problems of post-war reconstruction was foreshadowed tonight when Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced changes in the machinery of the Cabinet to cut red tape and assure more efficient handling of problems connected with winning the war.

P.C. Ralli, seeded-second player from the Princeton Club, was carried to five games before eliminating B.C. Durfee of the Bronxville Field Club, as competition in the first round continued in the Cornell Club's invitation Class B squash racquets tournament on the Squash Club courts last night.

President Roosevelt spoke directly to an audience of only a few hundred persons yesterday, but his words will ring around the world. They will be heard in Britain, where men and women who have faith in their own way of life, and ours, face with quiet courage the fifth month of a dreadful siege.

It was learned here yesterday that Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt resigned in mid-December as a sponsor of the American Rescue Ship Mission, administered by the United American Spanish Aid Committee, after the State Department had revoked a license issued to that committee under the Neutrality Act to collect relief funds here for application abroad.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 31 shows the following changes for the week, in thousands of marks:

Recently Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, declared that this country was now virtually independent of Europe in all library resources. The rapid growth of library holdings throughout the country has come about, according to Carl J. Cannon, through the passing of private collections either through gift or purchase to public institutions.

The cotton market experienced another sluggish and irregular trading session yesterday and final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 points up to 3 down. Movements were restricted to a range of 6 points, with the gains in the near months, the distant position closing lower than Friday's levels.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- British church bells did not ring out for the capture of Bardia, as they have rung for other victories, because they have a grimmer function now. They never will ring again until the war is over or until their brazen mouths tell of a German landing on this "sceptered isle."

A new issue of $1,500,000 of City of Pittsburgh, Pa., School District bonds was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising the Mellon Securities Corporation, the Union Trust Company of Pittsburgh, the Mellon National Bank and Drexel Co.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- Immediately after the broadcast of President Roosevelt's message to Congress, Arthur Nutt, president of the Society of Automotive Engineers, which is devoting its annual meeting this week to the theme of national defense, stated that the engineers were 100 per cent behind the defense program.

Refreshed by the swirling snows of New Hampshire but frankly admitting he preferred his own New York, Scout Paul Krichell returned to Yankee headquarters yesterday with encouraging news of the physical condition of Red Robert Rolfe. A week-end trip to Concord, N.H., revealed Rolfe confined to Margaret Pillsbury Hospital there, six miles from his Penacook home, convalescing after an operation for the removal of his tonsils.

The four-month French budget recently announced at Vichy gives an indication, if one were needed, of how precarious conditions now are in France. The budget calls for an expenditure of 40,000,000,000 francs. With the costs of the German army of occupation reputedly running at 400,000,000 francs a day, total Government expenditures for the period will apparently be close to 90,000,000,000 francs, or at the rate of around 260,000,000,000 francs a year.
FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 6 -- It was moving day at Fort Dix today. The cantonment type barracks were occupied at last by soldiers instead of artisans.

VICHY, France, Jan. 6 -- United States Ambassador William D. Leahy, who presented his credentials to Foreign Minister Pierre-Etienne Flandin this afternoon, will probably be accredited with all possible haste. Tomorrow or the next day he will be received with official ceremonial by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, it is understood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A large and distinguished audience turned out to welcome the capital debut today of Mme. Jarmila Novotna, the young Czech soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, who was presented by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at her 119th musical morning.

The heaviest first-day buying in ten years developed yesterday at the Spring opening of the New York floor-covering market. There was also a considerable increase over last year in the number of buyers attending the first day. Dealers found prices substantially the same as last year's, except for minor adjustments in both directions,

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6 -- Emerson (Spike) Nelson, newly appointed head football coach, said tonight that he had definite ideas about operation of the Yale attack but was not yet ready to divulge them in detail. Basically, Yale will use the single wing attack next Fall, he said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Further steps involving the expenditure of more than $83,000,000, to catch up with the shortage of airplane engines, were reported today by the War Department.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

Stocks suffered a sinking spell yesterday immediately after President Roosevelt had completed his message to Congress, and the moderate gains scored earlier by the leading issues were erased. The market was highly mixed from the start, and although the number of stocks to advance far outdistanced the losses, about 150 of the higher issues sold only once during the entire session.

Charles Erwin Wilson was elected yesterday president of the General Motors Corporation at a meeting of the directors held here, it was announced by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, following the meeting.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- King George, while on a tour of the bombed city of Sheffield with Queen Elizabeth today, added another precedent to his rapidly growing list by conferring a knighthood in a steel factory. The recipient was Allan Grant, managing director of the firm of Thomas Firth John Brown, Ltd.
It is a matter of great regret to admirers of true Austrian culture to find no mention of Austria as an invaded country along with Czecho-Slovakia, Poland, Norway, Denmark and the Low Countries.
J.J. Nance has been named vice president of Easy Washing Machine Corporation. He joined the company in August, 1939, as general sales manager.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- With the recently announced rationing restrictions, Britain is tightening her belt to save shipping space and, while dieting by American standards may seem meager, this island still can take up more notches before it descends to the standards of wartime Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Although eleven weeks have passed since the cases were argued, the Supreme Court remained silent again today on the question whether Harry Bridges and The Los Angeles Times shall be punished for contempt of a California court.

BRIDGEPORT, Jan. 6 -- General Electric Company will continue to offer its 1940 stripped six-foot refrigerator this year at a price $10 below last year's level, it was revealed today at a meeting of 400 dealers and department store executives from the New York metropolitan area at the General Electric Institute.

A total of 223 men were inducted into the Army yesterday in New York City with much more speed and efficiency than characterized the first selective service induction period in November. In all, 385 men were examined and forty-eight, or about 8 per cent, were rejected by Army examiners, almost all because of physical defects.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Senator Austin asserted tonight that the American people had enlisted on the side of "freedom" in the present world conflict and -- "touching elbows with the British" -- were prepared to fight if that becomes necessary.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 -- With the important Libyan seaport of Bardia safely in British hands after valiant fighting by the Australians, the British forces in Africa pressed forward today toward Tobruk, some seventy miles westward, where Royal Air Force planes carried out destructive bombing raids, in the course of which they downed eleven Italian machines without suffering any losses, according to various official announcements.

Renewal for ten years of the lease with Schrafft's for the major portion of the six-story building at 31 Broadway was announced yesterday by Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., brokers. The restaurant firm occupies the ground, second and third floors and basement in the structure, which covers a plot 42 by 117 feet in the heart of the financial district.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- William R. Davis, international oil operator, is expected to arrive in Mexico City Saturday together with Austin Taylor, described as his partner. His interest on this trip appears to be not oil, as in the past, but essential war metals, such as mercury, tungsten and molybdenum, that are produced in Mexico.

The New York Stock Exchange admitted yesterday to dealings "stamped modified" bonds of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company and suspended from dealings "assented and unassented" bonds of the company of the same series general consolidated mortgages 4s, 4 1/2s and 5s, due in 2003.

The vacant parcel of land 165 by 396 feet on the corner of Broadway and the Long Island Railroad right of way at Bethpage, L.I., was purchased by Warren Kessler and will be improved with a business building and a factory. The Nassau Suffolk B. M. Corporation were the sellers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 -- Foreseeing great increases in trade with the United States in the near future, Hussein Sirry Pasha, the Premier and Foreign Minister, today named a commercial attache and a commercial counselor to Egypt's Washington Legation, filling posts now vacant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt delivered to Congress his annual message on the state of the Union, sent to Congress the nominations of Guy J. Swope to be Governor of Puerto Rico and Charles Harwood to be Governor of the Virgin Islands, and conferred with William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman, members of the Advisory National Defense Commission; Senator Wagner and Harold D. Smith, Director of the Budget.

According to a report from some of the old tars along the Southern New Jersey coast, we are due for an early Spring whether or not the groundhog sees his shadow, for the shad are making an early spawning run this year.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 -- Johnny Bulla, a North Carolina boy who made good in the big city, Chicago, came from behind today and won a golf tournament for the first time in four years of major competition -- the $10,000 Los Angeles open.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt, declaring that "a dictator's peace" would bring "no security" to the United States, used a quotation today which is commonly attributed to Benjamin Franklin, but the authorship of which is disputed. It is as follows:

Although it was not Bank Nite and not a dish was given away, 3,000 men, women and children crowded into a theatre with a seating capacity of 2,352 last night at the R.K.O. Fordham, where the Fordham football squad was welcomed home from its game with Texas A. and M. in the Cotton Bowl at Dallas, Texas, on New Year's Day.

Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Harris gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. G. Beekman Hoppin, Mrs. Edwin Gould, Mrs. Frederick Prime Delafield, Mrs. Allen M. Thomas, Mrs. Dwight Miller Harris, Miss Gertrude Sampson, Prince Burhaneddin of Turkey, Dr. Preston Pope Satterwhite, Baron Maurice de Vaux, Guy Meek and Charles E. Sampson.

Asserting that Germany will soon declare war on the United States to prevent the sending of war supplies to Great Britain and that New York may be bombed within a month, Dr. Charles F. Bove said yesterday that we should "resort to the technique of cavemen and burrow into the hillsides."

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 6 (AP) -- With German troops massing in Southern Rumania less than 150 miles from Turkey's frontier, Premier Refik Saydam today assured the National Assembly that Turkish foreign policy aimed to secure the "safety of the nation * * * in complete reliance upon our Allies."

Nearly 1,000 worshipers, many of whom knew each other in Czarist days, gathered last night to usher in their Christmas, which is today, at the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour, 121st Street and Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The validity of awards of about $50,000,000 made by the German-American Mixed Claims Commission on claims arising from the explosions of World War munitions at Black Tom Island and Kingsland, N.J., in 1916-17, was unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today, thus ending many years of litigation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 6 -- German circles here talked freely today of an "understanding" with Bulgaria but declined to specify whether it had already been concluded through the Bulgarian Premier, Bogdan Philoff, or was still in preparation.

ROME, Jan. 6 (UP) -- The first impression created in Rome political circles by President Roosevelt's message to Congress was that it aimed at provoking Germany and Italy into a declaration of war against the United States.

The four-story apartment house at 55-57 Stegman Street, Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by Mrs. Cynthia G.D. Kuser Herbst to the Ten-Bore Realty Company of Newark. The building occupies a plot 50 by 90 feet, contains sixteen apartments, and is valued for taxation at $60,800.

Without ceremony and three months ahead of original schedule, the keel of another 45,000-ton battleship, the ninth capital ship now under construction in this country, was laid at 11 A.M. yesterday at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn while workmen were still reconstructing and enlarging the ways where the huge dreadnought is to be built.

The Dixie Clipper of Pan American Airways arrived here yesterday at 4:15 P.M., more than a week behind schedule because of bad weather over the Atlantic. The passengers included two members of the United States Maritime Commission who had been called to Washington from their posts in London.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- British military circles said today that mechanized patrols had established a "close blockade" of Italian forces at Tobruk, Marshal Rodolfo Graziani's next Libyan defense line west of fallen Bardia.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 (UP) -- Responsible American business quarters tonight said they were "positive" that Germany was obtaining a restricted but none the less important amount of United States war materials -- mostly metals -- in Pacific transshipments through Japan and Siberia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt is expected to sign and make public tomorrow afternoon an executive order which, unless last-minute changes are made, will set up the Office of Production Management, vesting coordinate powers over defense policy in four members, Secretaries Stimson and Knox and William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman.

New York hockey followers will get their first glimpse of the National League's latest goal-tending sensation in Madison Square Garden tonight when Lester Patrick's Rangers take to the ice, seeking their first victory of the season over the Chicago Black Hawks.

The Rev. Dr. Charles P. Fagnani, Professor Emeritus of Old Testament Literature at Union Theological Seminary, whose intense belief in the social value of religion brought him into bitter conflict with all German governments since 1914 and led to his expulsion from Germany in 1921, died in occupied France on Nov. 25 under circumstances that have not been clarified.

Trial got under way yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Waiter of consolidated actions brought by the trustees of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., and the Continental Securities Corporation for recovery of sums alleged to have been lost to the companies in connection with a transaction for the purchase of controlling interest in Reynolds Investing late in 1937.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The British could not fail to be overjoyed by President Roosevelt's message to Congress today. Virtually every word reflected what the British feel.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The possibility that British desert troops might sweep past the Italian seaport base at Tobruk and plunge on more than 250 miles across the Libyan sands to attack Bengazi arose tonight even as the advance guard of British motorized units threatened Tobruk's outer defenses.

Commenting on a report that a movement was under way in Queens to draft him for a third term, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that such activity was "most untimely" and indicated that there was plenty of time between now and the Fall to consider candidates.

An "amazing exploit" in which nine British soldiers captured an Italian ship on which they were prisoners and made captives of the 115 Fascisti aboard was related on the British radio yesterday and picked up here by the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station.
Passengers returning yesterday from South America on the American Republics liner Uruguay, which brought 198, asserted that Nazi activities continued to flourish in Argentina and Brazil.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- State Secretary Fritz Reinhardt of the Finance Ministry declared in the Steuer Zeitung today that there would be no increase in existing German taxes nor would there be new taxes in 1941.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- Contracts for large quantities of textile supplies for the Army were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today. Included were 1,350,000 yards of 36-inch wind-resistant poplin, and approximately 7,500,000 yards of various cotton and woolen cloth items for the Army clothing factory.

After weeks of negotiations between executives of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and representatives of the Rumanian Government, the telephone concern announced yesterday that it had sold the Rumanian Telephone Company to the National Bank of Rumania for $13,800,000.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 6 -- The best-informed Balkan sources here late this evening categorically denied that German negotiations with Bulgarian Premier Bogdan Philoff at Vienna had proceeded to a point where the Germans had seen the futility of further discussion and issued an ultimatum.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 6 -- Beginning an intensive "refresher" training course in preparation for 7,000 New York trainees coming here at the end of the month, Major Gen. William N. Haskell told 1,000 picked officers and non-commissioned officers that he wanted the Twenty-seventh Division to be the first organization in the Army ready for a combat assignment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Steel scrap dealers gathered today in Washington at the invitation of the National Defense Commission for a conference which commission officials expressly hoped would keep scrap prices down.

Robert Lehman, president of the Lehman Corporation, announced yesterday a net asset value of $29.64 a share on 2,068,380 shares of stock outstanding at the end of last year, compared with $27.46 each on 2,075,780 shares as of June 30, 1940 (the end of the company's fiscal year), end with $32.72 each on 2,081,580 shares as of Dec. 31, 1939.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Hogs tacked on further small gains today in a strong to 10-cent higher market, topping at $7.45. Fed steers and yearlings brought steady to 25 cents lower prices and lambs strong to 25 cents higher prices. Although opening slow, with bids weak to 10 cents off, demand picked up and the market firmed.

Now that another murder has been done Pauline Lord has come out of intermittent retirement long enough to take her chances with the suspects. In "Eight o'Clock Tuesday," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening, she is only one of several who might have plunged the paper knife into that foul beast.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $1,294,295 in United States currency after deductions for depreciation, interest, income and profits taxes, loss on disposal of capital assets and other charges.

It is not unfair to say of Anne Lindbergh's book, "The Wave of the Future," that it breathes the spirit of fatalism. The best of many replies to Mrs. Lindbergh is the one which denies that the future is a wave on the crest of which we must learn to ride or be submerged.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, 53-year-old New Yorker, became an almost prohibitive favorite to retain his world three-cushion billiard championship tonight by taking a 53-point lead on Jake Schaefer of Cleveland at the quarter mark in their 480-point match.

Six men, officials and members of Local 1, the Plumbers and Steamfitters Union, American Federation of Labor, went on trial yesterday before Judge Kennard Underwood of Auburn, N.Y., in Queens County Court, Long Island City, on charges of extortion and of conspiring with William J. Flynn, former Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, to control the plumbing trade in Queens.

Anxious to emphasize its full line of products so that if any of the major appliances slip others will be ready to take its place, the General Electric Company is shaping its enlarged 1941 campaign around the entire range of items, B.W. Bullock, advertising manager of the appliance division, said yesterday.
ROME, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress is bad news to the Italians, but it could be worse.
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Announcement of the appointment of six officials to work National Football League games in 1941 was made today by Carl L. Storck, president of the circuit.

YAPHANK, L.I., Jan. 6 -- While the 198th Coast Artillery band played lively tunes, seventy-four men, representing the first unit of the second quota of selective service trainees, alighted from a Long Island Railroad train at Camp Upton, shortly after dark today.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Passage by the Legislature of a compulsory automobile liability insurance law was urged today in a recommendation to the Joint Legislative Committee for Revision of the Insurance Law.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The State capital learned tonight that Mayor La Guardia has invited the leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature to visit him in New York and discuss informally some of the city's legislative needs in the session which opens Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Contract awards amounting to $87,760,093, including a $33,657,580 order for airplane engines from the Stude-baker Corporation and a $31,507,635 contract with Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company for trucks, were announced today by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Bills for the consideration of the new Congress began to flow into the Senate and House hoppers today immediately after President Roosevelt had read his message on the state of the Union. Several measures have an important bearing on national defense.

A questionnaire has been sent to members and member firms of the New York Stock Exchange asking their views on the various proposals for changes in the trading hours of the Exchange that have been discussed publicly and privately over a period of time.

Champion My Own Brucie, one of the few almost perfect cocker spaniels, was awarded the best in show title in the twenty-fourth specialty exhibition of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt last evening, scoring for the second time in the fixture.

Plans for the establishment of a "Free French" theatre in this country were discussed last night at a meeting of 300 men and women at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Those present included French refugees, members of the French colony here and men and women of the American theatre.

LIEGE, German-occupied Belgium, Jan. 6 -- Speaking before a mass meeting of 12,000 followers today, Leon Degrelle, leader of the Belgian Rexist party, declared, according to a German news agency report, that "Belgium [several words missing] only in a close cooperation with Germany."

The contract for construction of the low-rent public housing project known as Clason Point Houses in the Bronx has been awarded to Tobias Heller Co., it was announced yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.

When the British forces in Egypt began the offensive against the Italians they referred to the desert campaign as the Battle of the Nile. The Italians never saw the Nile; the fighting has taken place hundreds of miles away from the fertile valley which is "Egypt" to the natives.

Public disregard of regulations prohibiting parked automobiles on crosstown "express" streets in the theatrical district has brought back virtually the same congestion that existed three years ago when the Police Department banned parking to relieve the situation, a survey showed yesterday.

Judge Harwood has long been a personal friend of President Roosevelt. He served in the Assembly when Charles E. Hughes was Governor and in 1915 came into close contact with Mr. Roosevelt while active in the Brooklyn Democratic Club, one of the first independent Democratic organizations in New York State to support the candidacy of Woodrow Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt's demand in his annual message for a swift increase in the arming of the United States and measures to implement his policy of "all out" aid to the democracies is to be followed by a series of specific legislative proposals hardly matched in number and importance since the early days of participation by the United States in the first World War.

Fireman Harold Barker of 151-63 Twenty-ninth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, who was cited for bravery several times during his career, died in Flushing Hospital Sunday night of injuries suffered three hours earlier when he fell fifteen feet while descending a ladder at La Guardia Airport.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Amy Johnson, 32-year-old British aviatrix, former wife of Captain James A. Mollison, with whom she cracked up at Bridgeport, Conn., in 1933 while on a flight from Britain to New York, and heroine of many other long distance flights in various parts of the world, was reported today to have lost her life in a flying accident yesterday.

An exhibition of outstanding book jackets selected by the Trade Book Clinic of the Institute of Graphic Arts opened last night at the institute's galleries in the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

The excess-profits tax is theoretically unsound and will prove ineffective in practice by yielding an "unimpressive" return and leaving corporate profits of a size likely to arouse public indignation, the editors of the Harvard Law Review, the Columbia Law Review and the Yale Law Journal declare in a joint study of "Mobilization for Defense," appearing in the three publications.

The really big upturn in retail trade will undoubtedly come in the month of April, John Block of Kirby, Block Co., said at the fashion forum and style show held by this resident buying organization last night at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

Old World tradition was put aside yesterday, at least temporarily, when 300 East Side housewives, grandmothers and several great-grandmothers received their first lesson in scientific kosher cookery at the Essex Street Market.
VICHY, France, Jan. 7 -- United States Ambassador William D. Leahy will present his credentials to Marshal Henry Philippe Petain as Chief of the French State at noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- British authorities have agreed to relax the blockade, reliable sources said tonight, to permit the American Red Cross to send some condensed milk to unoccupied France and wheat to Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that the failure of the Republicans in Congress to applaud the President's message yesterday shocked her because it seemed to her to reflect a partisan reaction to the enunciation of principles deserving of applause by all.

A survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has revealed new evidence of the sacrifices which the American public is willing to make for the sake of national defense, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

Savings deposits in banks of the nation, including those in commercial banks, increased for the seventh consecutive year to a total of $25,750,050,000 on June 30, last, according to figures released yesterday by the savings division of the American Bankers Association. The total compared with the high record of $28,479,631,000 in 1930.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's speech was prominently displayed under large headlines in the Mexican press. It was read with the greatest interest by the Mexican people this morning.

With all the talk about defense and the great need for aviators, I believe that a thought may be given to the future. I have in mind a plan which I think should be looked into by our educators, which, if adopted, will provide thousands of new fliers for us each year.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Mercantile losses for the last week of the old year declined, the Admiralty said today. The figures were three British vessels lost, totaling 18,203 tons, and four Allied ships, totaling 19,348. No neutral ships were lost, for the very good reason that since the German Blitzkreig over-ran Europe there has been practically no neutral shipping left in the war zones.

More than 15,000 retail grocers in this city, organized in the United Independent and Food Dealers Association, affected by the strike called by Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L. affiliate, against the Greater New York Wholesale Grocers' Association, Inc., yesterday appealed by telegram to Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia asking that they intervene in the strike and prevail upon the union to arbitrate the dispute.

More than 5,000 persons, half in the afternoon and the rest in the evening, heard Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd recount the story yesterday of the second Byrd expedition to the Antarctic. Illustrated with motion pictures, both talks were given at the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center, 550 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

HONG KONG, Jan. 7 -- Major Evans F. Carlson, former United States Marine Corps officer, has arrived in Hong Kong after a four-month visit in nine Chinese Provinces of the West and Southwest. He said he was satisfied China's resistance was still formidable.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 (UP). -- Three destructive British air raids on Bremen last week were acknowledged today at the same time as Nazi sources were boasting of widespread successes in renewed daylight bombing attacks on London and other points in England.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 -- A thorough investigation by German authorities of the circumstances surrounding the bombing of Irish territory during the night of Jan. 2 and 3 has disclosed that no German planes could possibly have dropped bombs on Eire during that night, it was officially stated today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 7 -- Yugoslav Army circles and government sources preserved an air of calm readiness for all eventualities tonight as a host of rumors swept Belgrade of a German "zero hour" for Bulgaria and the Balkans.

Frank M. Bellanca, airplane designer, announced last night through the United Press that he would build a $2,000,000 airplane factory in Mexico City and establish another, which also will manufacture mosquito-type torpedo boats, in New Bedford, Mass.

A Brooklyn man charged with selling beer for off-the-premises consumption on Sunday was found technically guilty of a violation of the State laws in Long Island City Court yesterday to pave the way for a ruling on the question by the higher courts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Soviet Russia, which imported little United States copper before the outbreak of the present war, has become this country's third best copper customer, the Bureau of Mines of the Interior Department disclosed today in a survey of the copper industry in 1940.

It will be noted that, whereas the prescribed adjustments for the taxable year on the average earnings basis deal with exclusions from income, thus reducing the excess profits net income for the taxable year, the prescribed adjustments for the base period years 1936 through 1939 consist mainly of reductions or disallowances of deductions from income which also have the effect of reducing the excess profits tax net income.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- Progress toward equipping the Army mechanically for "Blitzkrieg" warfare was reported to the convention of the Society of Automotive Engineers tonight by Major Gen. E.B. Gregory, Quartermaster General.

"Old Acquaintance" has been chosen to give the so-called "command performance" in Washington as part of the program celebrating President Roosevelt's birthday, it was announced yesterday by Dwight Deere Wiman, producer of the John van Druten comedy co-starring Jane Cowl and Peggy Wood.

DENNIS PARRY'S "The Survivor,"* out today, is a dark and fascinating piece of hocus pocus that reads like a report concocted jointly by J.B. Priestley, J.B. Rhine, Freaud, Smollett and Poe. It is practically all hocus popus, with at most three or four grains of total weight, but Mr. Parry brings it off brilliantly. It starts like a comedy, ends like a tragedy and runs like a nightmare from beginning to end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The present shortage of aircraft engines will exist for at least another eighteen months, Rear Admiral John H. Towers, chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics of the Navy Department, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

Steve Belloise started his campaign for rehabilitation in the middleweight ranks in spectacular fashion last night at the Bronx Coliseum. Before a crowd estimated at 10,000, the Bronx middleweight knocked out Irwin (Kay) Kaplan of Los Angeles in the second round of what was scheduled as a ten-round bout.

Reflecting the largest demand in the goods market for more than two months, prices of both spot and futures cotton yesterday touched the highest levels for the season. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed near the day's best levels and 5 to 10 points above Monday's finals.

PANAMA, Jan. 7 -- President Arnulfo Arias of Panama felicitated President Roosevelt today in a cablegram referring to Mr. Roosevelt's speech before Congress. He offered the complete cooperation of Panama.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 8 (UP) -- A British advance guard is sounding out weak spots in the outer perimeter of Italian defenses at Tobruk, while the main imperial forces have moved up steadily to command the Hagrag Chargia Plateau overlooking the Libyan air and naval base, military authorities here reported today.

ROME, Jan. 7 -- Official indifference is being maintained here concerning President Roosevelt's message, which is said to have repeated the "usual themes" contained in previous statements. There is a definite tendency to minimize the speech, and the press with striking uniformity relegates to the back pages with inconspicuous headlines a 300-word incomplete account of it released only by the Stefani news agency.

William Rhodes Davis, international oil operator, who sold expropriated Mexican oil to Germany and Italy before the war and is reported to have brought a German "agenda" for peace to Washington in 1939, was subpoenaed yesterday to appear before a Federal grand jury that is investigating campaign expenditures in Washington.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,367,200 barrels daily, a decrease of 18,300 from the 3,385,500 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 223,800 barrels less than the calculation of 3,591,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for January.

Although everything else in the world is changing with alarming rapidity, Shubert operetta remains standard. "Night of Love," which was put on at the Hudson last evening, follows the formula with great skill. There is something almost admirable about the exact proportioning of the tawdriness to the trite.

Miss Anne Morgan, sister of J.P. Morgan and head of the American Friends of France, returned home yesterday after ten months in France, where she led her organization in civilian welfare and ambulance work and in other ways assisted the defeated army of France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Industrial activity and employment arising out of the defense program was reported today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, to have contributed materially to the placement in November by State employment offices of 295,000 workers in private industry, and to a further decline during this period in benefit claims and payments.

A pledge of full cooperation with the government in regulating the sale of liquor near Army or Navy camps was given here yesterday by the Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries at the groups's first annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Led by Harry Boykoff, who scored 28 points, the Thomas Jefferson High basketball team took the undisputed lead in the Brooklyn Section 1 of the P.S.A.L. by defeating Eastern District, 51 to 37, on its home floor yesterday. It was Jefferson's third league victory.

The three Symphonic Dances of Sergei Rachmaninoff, which had a first performance last night in Carnegie Hall by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, must be ranked among the best scores of the composer's later period. Composed within a short period last Summer, they bear the unmistakable stamp of his creative personality.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The sellers' market continued unabated at the National Shoe Fair here today, with orders booked conservatively estimated as running 10 to 15 per cent ahead of last year's event. One large shoe manufacturer was reported budgeting the 1941 production program for a 20 per cent increase in children's shoes and for 10 per cent more in adult shoes.
