In your issue of Dec. 26 you published a letter from W.S. Marsh pointing to the vast ignorance of Latin-American music, literature, etc., in this country, and urging the organization of some agency which would disseminate information on these subjects to the people of the United States.

An exhibition consisting of 100 prints, supplemented by thirty miniature prints -- work selected from the twenty-fifth annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, held recently at the National Arts Club -- opened yesterday at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries.

Mayor La Guardia, prominent journalists and friends of Ignace Jan Paderewski paid tribute to the musician and statesman and his sister, Mme. Antonina Wilkonska, who is visiting this country for the first time, at a luncheon given yesterday by a special committee at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street.

MONTREAL, Jan. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs broke their first-place tie with the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League by scoring a 4-3 overtime victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight after the Canadiens had twice come from behind to tie the count.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 7 -- After a dull opening, with prices lower on a wide front, Dutch issues rallied toward the close of today's Bourse session, finishing mostly with net changes of 2 points either way.

The "measles year" that was expected in 1940 arrived a little late, it became apparent yesterday when Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the Health Department, handed his weekly report of the city's health to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

A year of accelerated progress in Scouting's effort to "strengthen and invigorate democracy" was reported yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York in the Yale Club, at which J. Stewart Baker was re-elected president of the foundation.

Many leases for store space were among the contracts for commercial quarters reported by brokers yesterday. Among the types of organizations that signed contracts were an arbitration association, a number of clothing concerns and a small arms firm.

The Court of Appeals granted yesterday the request of Charles J. Hendley, president of the Teachers Union, to appeal to from the contempt citation incurred when he refused to exhibit the union's membership lists to the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local school system.

LUBBOCK, Texas, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Drawlin' Peter Willis Cawthon, maker of winning football teams and one of the most picturesque characters in the coaching profession, resigned today as athletic director and head coach of Texas Tech College to escape a de-emphasis movement.

An elaborate all-American fashion show, probably the largest ever to be held in the world, will be presented in the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel tonight in a bid of New York City to the nation for recognition as the new fashion center of the world.

Your recent editorial "Youth and the Timid Elders" is most timely. Over-emphasis on "youth" has caused considerable social and economic damage. Neither youth nor age is chronological. We all know youths today physiologically "older" than individuals twice their age lacking the oldsters' mentality and experience and sometimes the oldsters' courage as well.

Visiting buyer registrations last week totaled 1,199, as against 212 in the preceding week and 1,824 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 911, which compared with 96 for last Tuesday.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Fort Dix will send two companies of infantry to Washington for the inaugural parade Jan. 20, Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general of the Forty-fourth Division, announced here today. In making the announcement General Powell recalled that it was the prospect of a trip to Washington to march in the inaugural parade of Woodrow Wilson that induced him to enlist in the New Jersey National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The value of United States exports in November was $16,000,000 lower than the October total, principally because of the decline in shipments of a comparatively few items to Canada, the United Kingdom and Japan, the Department of Commerce made known today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt announced today that he had appointed Sherman Minton, recently defeated for re-election to the Senate from Indiana, as one of his six White House administrative assistants at a salary of $10,000 yearly.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- On the eve of the opening of the Legislature it was revealed tonight that Governor Lehman would devote his opening message to defense.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, undefeated in their last six starts, dropped out of a first-place National Hockey League deadlock with Toronto tonight as Boston's crippled Bruins held them to a 1-1 overtime tie before 11,000 at the Boston Garden.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 7 -- Alexander Alexandroff, the newly appointed 33-year-old counselor of the Russian Legation in Sofia, arrived here today, and the event was generally regarded as heralding a new and intensified phase of Soviet activity in this country.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 8 -- London and many other parts of Great Britain enjoyed a raid-free time of it this Winter morning after a day in which relays of single German planes swept over the Thames estuary and East Anglia in a drive toward the capital, while others carried out bombing attacks on Liverpool, the Midlands and the southeast coast.

The Most Rev. James Francis Aloysius McIntyre will be consecrated Titular Bishop of Cyrene and Auxiliary Bishop of New York in a solemn three-hour ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning. More than 5,000 members of the clergy and laity, including ten Archbishops, fifty-seven Bishops and an Abbot, are expected to witness the ritual.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 7 -- The bark of the artillery pieces was heard on this post today. The 156th Artillery, firing live ammunition for the first time since the Forty-fourth Division started training in September, was wiping out machine guns (heaps of brush) on the artillery range.

Officials of Distillers Corporation-Seagram, Ltd., yesterday announced that the corporation had acquired control of Browne Vintners Company, Inc.; the Wilson Distilling Company and the Hunter Baltimore Rye Distillery, Inc., all jointly owned.

A "Playtime Exhibition of the Art Directors Club" is being held in the reception room gallery of the New York School of Applied Design for Women, Thirtieth Street and Lexington Avenue, beginning today and continuing through Jan. 21.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Fed steer trade was slow today with prices steady on strictly good and choice grades, other ranging weak to 25 cents lower. Prime 1,200-pound steers topped the market at $15.40. Hogs were active and steady, sheep were active and steady. All other classes of cattle ruled steady to firm with the bulk of yearlings and steers selling at $9.75 to S14.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7 -- With Many Stings, last year's winner of the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, among the entrants, the annual Hialeah Park race meeting will get under way tomorrow, featured by the Inaugural Handicap, a six-furlong speed test.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 -- The advancing British forces have captured El Adem, the airdrome for Tobruk, Libya, and seized forty Italian airplanes, El Adem, which had been evacuated by the Italians, is only fifteen miles south of Tobruk. The captured planes, as well as the airdrome, had been badly damaged by Royal Air Force bombing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the second of the season's state receptions, entertaining in honor of officials of the Treasury, Postoffice, Interior. Agriculture, Commerce and Labor Departments and other Federal agencies.

A new order of the Salvation Army in recognition of distinguished auxiliary service was awarded yesterday for the first time to Henry W. Taft for his work during twenty years as chairman of the New York City Advisory Board of the Army, a post he resigned last August.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- This statement was issued today by the four members of the new Office of Production Management, William S. Knudsen, director general; Sidney Hillman, associate director general, and Secretaries Stimson and Knox:

DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- Officials of the Ford Motor Company and committees of the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.) will have no further meetings, I.A. Capizzi, chief counsel for the Ford company, said today.

The Cornell Club moved within striking distance of the leading Downtown A.C. in the Metropolitan League Class B squash racquets championship play last night as the result of a 4-to-1 triumph over the Union League Club on the Squash Club courts.

Sixty contributions aggregating $1,091.60 reached the leediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing the total amount that has been raeeived in response to the twentyninth annual appeal for suffering men, women and children to $2a0,999.15.

A majority of 64 per cent of Columbia College's senior class believes that the United States can keep out of a European or an Asiatic war in 1941, but 79 per cent hold the opinion that the country will be at war within five years, the results of the annual poll taken by The Columbian, senior yearbook, showed yesterday.

An old portrait entitled "The Banner Carrier of Amsterdam," placed on exhibition yesterday at the Brooklyn Contemporary Arts Gallery, 362 Livingston Street, has been pronounced by Henry L. Maloney, borough artist and director of the gallery, and others, an original masterpiece from the brush of Rembrandt.

The fact that teeth and mouth defects were the most prevalent causes for the rejection of local selective service registrants for military duty in the first call, as indicated by the recent report of Colonel S.J. Kopetzky, Chief of the New York City Medical Division, presents a serious challenge to the dental and medical professions and to the public.

Madeleine Boyd, who played a part in the bringing forth of Thomas Wolfe, has discovered another author who fits, in one big respect, the Wolfe tradition. He is William Davey, who has written a novel he calls "Dawn Breaks the Heart."
Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad Company first consolidated mortgage 6 per cent gold bonds due in 1934 have been suspended from New York Stock Exchange dealings. They have been paid.

Fireman George L. Lang of 2,126 Virgil Place, the Bronx, leads the list of 827 firemen eligible for the post of Fire Lieutenant with a mark of 91.350 per cent, according to the ratings published yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

Seventy-four major and minor letter and numeral awards to members of New York University varsity and freshman football and cross-country teams were announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics, following approval of the awards by the university's board of athletic control and the Undergraduate Athletic Association board.
West Side apartment properties were included in several of the Manhattan real estate deals reported yesterday.

Twenty of the thirty-one Fordham football players who made the trip to Dallas for the Rams' meeting with the Texas Aggies on Jan. 1; Joseph Brogan, student manager, and Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, were in bed yesterday under the care of Dr. Gerald Carroll, team physician, all victims of the influenza epidemic which struck the Cotton Bowl party.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 8 -- The Japanese Government has no opinion to express on President Roosevelt's and is concerned message only with how the policy indicated in the message will be worked out. This statement, published in Asahi, represents the only inkling of official views that has appeared.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- As befits a world champion team, the Cincinnati Reds placed three players today on the annual all-star major league team picked for The Sporting News by members of the Baseball Writers Association.

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. had a real scare yesterday at the Health Center in Hackensack, N.J., when Pat Comiskey, Paterson heavyweight, drilling for his ten-round bout with Lou Nova on Friday night in Madson Square Garden, collided head-on with Eddie Peirce, a spar-mate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- As the President today described the organization of the Office of Production Management (the OPM) it will have two coordinate chiefs, Mr. Knudsen and Mr. Hillman. Thus he again rejected insistent counsel that a single chief of armament production is essential to the success of the program, and thereby for the second time since the preparedness campaign began the New Deal advisers of the Administration triumphed over all others.

A more exact line on the relative strength of local college basketball teams may be obtained tonight, when a trio of intracity court clashes, two at Madison Square Garden and one at Morningside Heights, are presented. The Garden double-header, first of the season featuring New York quintets, will send unbeaten N.Y.U. against Manhattan and once-beaten St. John's against C.C.N.Y.
The former paint and varnish plant of the De Voe Reynolds Company, Inc., at Newark, N.J., has been sold to a client of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers in the transaction, it was announced yesterday.

Spring burst forth yesterday in flower-bedecked millinery to the accompaniment of the nostalgic tune of a hand-organ, in the Oval Room of the Ritz Hotel during the luncheon hour. The exhibitor was Walter Florell. The flower of the day was the carnation, which singly and en masse decorated walking and dressy hats, representing the designer's thoughts on Spring and Summer style.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Metro borrowed Ingrid Bergman today from David O. Selznick to play opposite Spencer Tracy in "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde," which Victor Fleming will direct. Miss Bergman will fill the role played by Miriam Hopkins in the 1932 version of the Robert Louis Stevenson story, which Paramount produced with Fredric March.

Plans for a new modern industrial high school, to be known as the Machine and Metal Trades Vocational High School, with instruction both for students and for trainees in the national defense program, were announce yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Headed by Captain Arthur W. Brandt, Superintendent of Public Works, a committee of three was named today by Governor Lehman to cooperate with the Federal authorities in matters concerning the transport of goods or troops on the highways and to compile information concerning the availability of commercial trucks and buses.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 7 -- The rumble of rising rebellion in Rumania, the massing of Russian troops along the Dniester and Pruth Rivers from Lwow to Odessa, and last, but not least, the reported adamant stand taken by King Boris of Bulgaria during the last three days were all seen here as contributory factors in a marked decrease in the general Balkan tension tonight.

In his first appearance as chairman of the 1941 drive of the Greater New York Fund, James A. Farley appealed last night to 600 labor unionists to better their last year's record in assisting the fund.

For the operating expenses of American Ambulance, Great Britain, whose 260 vehicles are in service twenty-four hours daily in England, the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had cabled $100,000 to London.

MADRID, Jan. 7 -- Most Madrid newspapers today gave great attention both to President Roosevelt's speech and to the capture of Bardia, although the Alcazar, in its survey of the week's military events, omitted mention of the British offensive.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Broadcasting House, headquarters of the empire and world-wide radio system that is becoming ever more important, has been "very seriously damaged" by bombs during recent raids, it is permissible to say at last.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 -- The Italians have lost more than 500 planes in the Middle East since the war started, a senior Royal Air Force officer said today, while the R.A.F. has lost only eighty. During this period, it was asserted, the R.A.F. carried out more than 2,000 raids on Italian bases, or an average of nine each day.

Yorkville Court, in Fifty-seventh Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, built in 1863 when "O Susanna" was a non-ASCAP hit and when the fishing was good in the East River, was posted yesterday with a "For Sale or Lease" sign.

Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, told The Associated Press last night that he would recommend the prompt reinstatement of any players in the New Year's Day East-West football game who communicated a desire to be reinstated as amateurs.

Ernest B. Lawton, assistant general manager and personnel director of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., has resigned, it was announced yesterday. The resignation is effective August, 1942. Mr. Lawton plans to devote his time to personal interests in the educational and literary fields.

The one-story taxpayer at the northwest corner of Thirty-seventh Avenue and Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, L.I., was sold by Shroder Koppel, builders, to an investing client of Bedros G. Terzian, attorney. The structure contains nine stores and was sold for cash above a $47,000 mortgage.

"Kitty Foyle," the RKO picturization of the Christopher Morley novel, will have its local premier this morning at the Rivoli. Ginger Rogers is starred in the title role of the drama, the setting of which is Philadelphia and New York. Dennis Morgan, James Craig, Eduardo Ciannelli, Ernest Cossart, Gladys Cooper and Odette Myrtil are featured in the supporting cast . . . Universal's "The Invisible Woman" is the new arrival today at the Rialto.

The New York State Public Service Commission made public yesterday a 400-page report covering its findings of an investigation into the activities and influence exercised by those formerly in control of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, through affiliated service and other companies, over the operating properties of the Associated system in New York State.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Williamstown, heavily campaigned gelding from Jake Freedman's barn, was the hero of the getaway card at Tropical Park today. The St. James 4-year-old, who won eight of his twenty-seven outings in 1940, chalked up his third triumph in four attempts at the meeting when he led eight rivals in the Ocala Purse, a six-furlong dash over a slow track.

Negotiations between the National Maritime Union and deep-sea shipping companies to consider wage increases of 25 per cent sought by the Union for 30,000 seamen on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts will begin here tomorrow at the office of the American Merchant Marine Institute, 11 Broadway.

The Montana-Dakota Utilities Company will vend today $10,000,000 of securities in the form of $7,500,000 of first 3 1/2 per cent bonds offered by a group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Merrill Lynch, E. A. Pierce Cassatt and $2,500,000 of first 2 1/2 per cent serial bonds offered by these two firms alone.

To hear that the German Secret Police is raiding French bookstores and seizing publications guilty of "anti-German character" cheers the comic spirit between the acts of the tragedy. The conqueror of so much of Europe is made to look a village Dogberry. After a night of wholesale murder comes the harrying of the booksellers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The headquarters of General Sir Archibald P. Wavell grappled tonight with the problem of accommodating upward of 70,000 prisoners taken by the British thus far in their lightning campaign against the Italians in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Executive Order establishing the Office of Production Management and defining its duties:

Graeber Smith have purchased from the Foran Holding Corporation, Herman Grossman, president, the blockfront on the south side of Broadway, between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, in Astoria, Queens, improved with a garage, dwelling and gasoline station.

Renewed efforts to bring about changes in realty tax valuations and in assessment methods in New York have been undertaken under the impetus of the studies of this problem now being conducted for the State Legislature by the so-called Bewley committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Several dinners were given tonight at the Everglades Club before the backgammon tournament. Mr. and Mrs. George McClellan entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Klotz, Mrs. Charles B. Hewes and A. Raimond Corini. Mr. and Mrs. John H. Perry gave a dinner for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Woodle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt gave co-equal powers today in direction of the mammoth defense program to William S. Knudsen, industrialist, and Sidney Hillman, labor leader, in issuing executive and administrative orders setting up the new four-man Office of Production Management to supervise the rearmament program.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Champion Willie Hoppe turned his three-cushion billiard match with Challenger Jake Schaefer of Celveland into an utter rout tonight, increasing his lead to 94 points in their four-day battle for the world title.

Two of the newest ski developments that should prove popular with metropolitan enthusiasts because of their accessibility are those located at the Clarence Fahnestock Memorial State Park, on the Eastern State Parkway in Putnam County and at Catamount Hill on the State line between Hillsdale, N.Y., and South Egremont, in the Massachusetts Berkshires.

The office of Lou Oshins at Brooklyn College was humming with activity yesterday. Oshins is football coach, freshman track coach, director of intercollegiate athletics, publicity director, equipment manager and also has charge of ticket sales at the college.

Among the projects called for by planes filed in the various boroughs yesterday were a four-story office and laboratory building and a group of twenty-eight dwellings in Brooklyn and a three-story factory in College Point, Queens.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 7 -- Once again, as we approach a new season, those of us engaged in the sport of professional baseball must reflect with pardonable pride upon the stability of the minor leagues, and upon that point base much of the hope which we hold for the 1941 season.

As the climax of a contest for the title of "Mrs. Typical Customer of 1941," Mrs. B.J. Thill, 36-year-old housewife of La Crosse, Wis., was announced yesterday as the winner by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians, James B. Schafer, its leader, and several of his associates have been permanently enjoined by the Supreme Court from selling transferable membership certificates in New York State, it was announced yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. Mr. Bennett obtained the injunction from Justice Philip J. McCook on Monday.

The percentage of selective service men rejected yesterday on the second day of the second full selective service call dropped sharply to indicate that local board examining physicians and Army medical men were reaching an agreement on what constitutes physical fitness for military service.

Among those reporied yesterday as having taken new residentinl quarters was Jsidore Soshnick, restauratem' and principal owner of Beefsteak Charlie's, who leased an apartment in Castle Village through Nehring Brothers. Inc., agents. Other leases follow:

THE widespread interest in the appointment of a new head football coach at Yale brings to mind once more the quiet lives led by the coaches of other sports on and around the campus. Of course the recent appointment of Spike Nelson at Yale had an added flavor in the way of news because, in naming Nelson, an Iowa football product, Old Eli was breaking with the graduate-coach tradition at New Haven.

TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- Japanese henceforth will be "in principle" the official language of the foreign press conferences, Ko Ishii, the Information Department's spokesman, told correspondents this morning. Japanese papers declare that the announcement is a manifestation of "autonomous diplomacy.

Good citizenship is our best defense against the internal enemies trying to undermine the structure of American democracy, J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declared at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where 300 persons gathered to honor Cecil Wetsel and Ellis Wood, the rescuers of the kidnapped son of Count Marc de Tristan last September.

Production of open-hearth and bessemer steel ingots in December amounted to 6,300,768 net tons, the second highest in the history of the industry and lifted total output for 1940 to a high record of 65,246,953 tons, according to The American Iron and Steel Institue.

Mrs. Elizabeth Auterhoff, a 56-year-old widow, whose barge Elizabeth, on the shore of Mill Basin, off Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, has been her home for many years, was ordered by Magistrate Jeannette G. Brill in Flatbush Court yesterday to leave the barge when the city provided a new home and relief for her.

Consumption of fibers in 1940 established records in three of the four major textile fields, according to estimates published yesterday in The Textile Organon. Cotton, wool and rayon use established new highs, but consumption of raw silk was the lowest in twenty years due, according to The Organon "to its replacement by rayon in many important consumer products."

TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka today protested to Sir Robert Craigie, the British Ambassador, against the action of British officials at Bermuda who on Dec. 23 seized money belonging to Japanese passengers proceeding to Germany via Lisbon.

Because Amy Johnson chose to live dangerously she died gallantly. A flier by instinct and a skillful navigator, she could have held her own with the pilots of the R.A.F. Being a woman, she had to content herself with the work of ferrying new planes from factory to fighting field.

Only the Bulgars, waiting nervously for the sword to fall, have nothing to say in regard to the fate that seems about to overtake them. They are a sturdy people, ruled but never subdued by the Turks, but by itself their stubborn independence is a poor shield against the powers that threaten them now.

NEWTON, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Common Pleas Judge John C. Losey of Sussex County upheld today the constitutionality of New Jersey's "race hatred" statutes, under which ten German-American Bund leaders and associates, including National Bundesfuehrer G. William Kunze, were indicted last October.
ROME, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Italian High Command today issued the following communique:

President Roosevelt is right when he says that the question of American aid for those nations everywhere now fighting in defense of their own freedom rises above all partisan considerations. He is right when he claims that this policy of American assistance has had the support of both great political parties in the United States and the endorsement of our people.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Contracts for 3,614,000 black wool neckties for the Army were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot today to fourteen manufacturers. The awards were made under negotiated contract No. 32, calling for 6,000,000 ties.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Jan. 7 -- Nassau County police and two surface craft and an airplane of the Coast Guard spent several hours this morning searching for a mirage -- a weird combination of smoke and reflected sunshine which created an illusion of a boat afire offshore.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt said yesterday that she had resigned from sponsorship of the American Rescue Ship Mission after an inquiry that did not extend to the indications that the organization was more interested in Communist propaganda and in rescuing Spanish Communists from France than in rescuing Spanish republicans in general.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., will soon turn over to President Roosevelt, members of the Cabinet and the defense agencies, a plan for the increased utilization of the productive capacities of the steel industry for defense purposes.

The unsatisfactory woodcock season of the past Fall has stimulated the Southern New York Fish and Game Association to carry a petition to the State Conservation Department and the United States Department of the Interior requesting that a full month of woodcock shooting be granted in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today filing by the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore of a registration statement covering $12,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent first refunding mortgage sinking fund bonds, Series Q, due Jan. 1, 1976.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Continuation for another year of the Rapp-Coudert Joint Legislative Committee investigating the State Public Education System, with particular emphasis on subversive activities in New York City schools, will be asked in a resolution to be submitted tomorrow at the opening session of the 1941 Legislature.

VICHY, Jan. 7 -- Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, United States Ambassador to France, said today there could be no minimizing of his country's war production effort in behalf of the democracies and sought to correct the existing impression in Europe that the United States had traded off a lot of scrap iron to Great Britain instead of fifty serviceable destroyers.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) -- With Johnny Adams up, Flying Streak dashed to victory in the feature offering at Santa Anita Park today. Transient and Cute Trick, coupled in the betting as the Mrs. V.S. Bragg entry, finished second and third as named.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 7 -- Mrs. Enos Throop Jr. of the home club reached the final round of the tenth annual women's New York State squash racquets championship by defeating -- Mrs. Stewart Iglehart, unattached, in four games, 15 -- 7, 18 -- 16, 15 -- 17, 15 -- 10, at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's address to Congress is regarded officially here as an inspiration to the people and leaders of this country to pursue their struggle, fully confident that no shortage of war materials will delay or hamper this country's efforts to make victory secure.

The need for quick State action to promote the national defense should, and probably will, take the partisan edge off the legislative session which opens today in Albany. Last year the Governor's budget precipitated a noisy dispute in which the Republican majority pushed the respectable pursuit of economy to partisan extremes.

The United Specialties Company, manufacturer of automobile engine accessories, reports a net profit of $146,525 for the quarter ended on Nov. 30, after interest, Federal and State income and excess-profits taxes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Four types of American airplanes were praised by Air Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding at a press conference today for their "valuable work" in the Royal Air Force.

Although he appeared wholly aware of the fact that baseball's outstanding academic minds scarcely would agree with him, Secretary Eddie Brannick of the Giants yesterday took his annual look into the crystal and professed to see only one team that could be rated a standout to win the 1941 National League pennant. No, it's not the Reds. Nor the Dodgers. The answer -- the Giants!

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The wheat market turned downward today to end a seven-day advance. Prices receded about 1 cent a bushel from the early top on profit-taking sales and in sympathy with a sharp break in soy beans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The value of licenses issued for the export of arms, ammunition and other implements of war to Great Britain fell of sharply in November, according to the monthly report issued by the State Department today. The total was $6,016,936, principally for planes, guns, howitzers and mortars, compared with $170,072,373 in October.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. was the high bidder yesterday for a new issue of $6,911,000 Oklahoma City, Okla., waterworks bonds, dated Jan. 15, 1941, and due serially from Jan. 15, 1944 to 1961. The bankers bid 100.069 for $1.920,000 of the bonds as 3s and $4,991,000 as 2s.
SOFIA, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Bulgaria looked to Russia again tonight for an answer to whether German troops massed along the northern frontier meant war or peace.

Alexander Kipnis gave a recital at the Town Hall last night that could come only from an extraordinary artist. Here was singing that was enkindled by a vivid imagination which played on every note and phrase and song. Here was the art of re-creation and projection of mood at its finest.

Flying fists and swinging sticks abounded as the Chicago Black Hawks fought their way to victory over the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The Windy City athletes, who have yet to lose to the New Yorkers in four National Hockey League games this season, made a fine closing rush to erase a Ranger lead and skate off with a 3-to-2 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Leaders of nineteen national unions affiliated with the Building Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor decided today upon a no-strike policy on defense construction. The unions represented a combined membership of 1,500,000, it was stated.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 (AP) -- British headquorters issued this communique today:

ATHENS, Jan. 7 -- The audacious Greek fleet, for the third time, has penetrated into the Adriatic Sea through the fifty-mile-wide Strait of Otranto despite the heavy Italian air and naval patrol of this channel and not only shelled the Albanian base of Valona, but also cannonaded the coast at several more southerly points, thus supporting Greek land efforts to advance in that sector.
SAC CITY, Iowa, Jan. 7 -- Earl Dew, the Iowa farm boy who piloted 287 winners to take the 1940 national jockey title, is near the realization of a lifelong dream -- to ride in the Kentucky Derby.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Reports were current in the trade today that the National Defense Commission may shortly devote its attention to the broad increase in prices of cotton yarns. The rumored inquiry probably will follow the same lines as the investigation into the wool situation, on which initial hearings were held in Washington today.

The first of the 1941 annual meetings of bank stockholders was held yesterday, that of the United States Trust Company. Owing to the fact that the stock of this old-line trust company is closely held, chiefly by estates, the shareholders were represented at the meeting by the mailed proxies.

The four-story apartment house on a plot 40 by 128 feet at 980 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Percy H. Kittle of Salt Lake City, Utah, to a client of R.M. Dinsmore Co., Inc., brokers. Sale of the property, which is assessed for $38,000, was for cash above a $24,500 mortgage.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The government announced tonight that an abortive conspiracy" had been put down last night. Following official assurances that foreign rumors of a disturbance were baseless, the Ministry of Interior issued this communique:

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 7 -- Young rookies from New York City, mobilized less than three months ago, did some excellent sub-caliber shooting today as the 105th Field Artillery tried direct fire at a moving target for the first time since the World War.

In an effort to combat usury, the Rev. Arthur A. O'Leary, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy, 2496 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, has taken the lead in the organization of a cooperative parish credit union, which will advance loans on the basis of the "good character" of the applicants.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 7 -- Most Brazilian newspapers today featured President Roosevelt's address to Congress under bold type headlines characterizing it as "a sensational, vehement message of alarm and threats menacing the nation."

HANOI, French Indo-China, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Representatives of all the kingdoms and provinces that compose this French colony are meeting at the government palace to consider a situation made precarious by border fighting with Thailand [Siam] and increasing Japanese pressure in the north.

ROME, Jan. 7. -- The Italian people were told today that Bardia had fallen with heavy losses in men and material. At the same time the Council of Ministers issued a solemn order of the day reaffirming the strength of the Axis and proclaiming Italy's determination to fight on.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The machine tool industry, through the National Machine Tool Builders Association, meeting here today, pledged to William S. Knudsen that it would enlarge its previously announced program for 1941.

The National Power and Light Company and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $9,280,233, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, according to its report made public yesterday.

Two brothers who operated a so called "Lester Plan" mythical loan agency in the midtown district through which they defrauded about 500 tradesmen and men and women city, State and Federal employes, including school teachers, of about $75,000, unexpectedly entered guilty pleas to petit larceny yesterday before Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Ernest T. Weir, president of the National Steel Corporation and an opponent of many Administration policies, declared himself today for President Roosevelt's program of national defense and of aid to Great Britain.

Our domestic Communists, full-fledged or fellow-traveler, overt or disguised, are, one may say, everywhere. Their numerous fronts, leagues, committees, congresses, infiltrations and other types of transmission belt constitute a national network. They are on the front page nearly every day.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Edward J. Flynn, Democratic national chairman, called tonight for moral and physical support of the national policy enunciated by President Roosevelt "because the whole world must know that the United States is united, firm and unafraid."

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- Now that the German comment on President Roosevelt's message to Congress has been released, there can be little doubt that both the press and official quarters regard the President's statements as "provocation."

Asserting that "greater enemies than crooked labor leaders are the crooked lawyers who advise them," Kings County Judge John J. Fitzgerald imposed yesterday a sentence of five to fifteen years in Sing Sing Prison on Joseph Feld, former counsel for Local 138, Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers Union, A.F. of L., for extorting $7,500 from a Brooklyn furniture store.

Net assets of the General American Investors Company, Inc., applicable to its outstanding securities totaled $25,533,047 on Dec. 31 against $29,158,239 a year earlier, according to the fourteenth annual report submitted yesterday by Frank Altschul, president.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 8 -- Miss Elizabeth Pearson of Philadelphia and Mrs. Enos Throop Jr. of the home club will battle for top honors in the women's tenth annual New York State squash racquets championship on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club tomorrow.

TOKYO, Jan. 8 -- Although the regular Parliamentary session will reopen on Jan. 21, the government has decided to discuss the national situation in advance of that date with an informal body selected by itself. Some members of both houses will be included in the group, together with business and financial leaders, prominent newspaper men and others.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Martial law was proclaimed today in the twenty-four Thai [Siamese] provinces bordering French Indo-China.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Young Jake Schaefer of Cleveland finally broke the winning streak of Willie Hoppe, world three-cushion billiard champion, by taking the sixth block of their 480-point challenge match tonight, 68 to 60, in seventy-six Innings.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, In Libya, Jan. 8 (AP) -- More and more Italians were rounded up today by the British north and west of Bardia, Libya, but the prize fugitive of them all General Annibale (Electric Whiskers) Bergonzoli, Commander of Bardia, was still among the missing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The United States has in effect rejected a French plea to take exceptional measures toward facilitating the migration of thousands of refugees of many races and nationalities now in France to this hemisphere at this time on the ground that no orderly procedure could be followed, particularly with governments under German domination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A policy of inviting the closest confidential cooperation of the foreign policy making officials of the Administration was adopted by the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate today at its first meeting of the Seventy-seventh Congress.

Lord Baden-Powell, dying at 83, lived to so great an age that he was able to watch an idea he had planted from the seed spread its foliage around the earth. It is only thirty-three years since the "Chief Scout of the World" organized his first camp of twenty-five boys on Brownslea Island, England.
The Murray Corporation of America reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Nov. 30, a net profit of $220,158 after depreciation. Federal income taxes and other charges.

Isaac Liberman, president of the Arnold Constable Corporation, announced yesterday that directors had declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on its stock, payable on Jan. 27 to holders of record of Jan. 16.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, 42 years old, who was sent to a Federal prison, in 1937, as the central figure in labor racketeering in Fulton Fish Market, was held in $50,000 bail in the Felony Court yesterday on a charge of extorting $120 weekly from a teamsters' local during his two years' imprisonment and since.
QUEBEC, Jan. 8 -- The church and State in the Province of Quebec joined today to proclaim Sunday, Feb. 9, as a "day of prayer or victory."

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt's budget message to Congress was interpreted here tonight as an implementation of his fireside talk. Officially, however, it was regarded as a matter of purely domestic concern in the United States.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Britain's mechanized desert cavalry rolled guns into place before Tobruk and other troops took up positions today for the siege of that virtually surrounded Italian base.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Ralph Nash, 19, of Somerville, Boston College sophomore substitute quarterback, who was stricken with convulsions, was transferred late today to St. Elizabeth's Hospital, where his condition was described as "satisfactory."
Following are the principal sections of Mayor La Guardia's report on City affairs before the City Council yesterday:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- William Powell and Myrna Loy will be teamed again by Metro in "Love Crazy," a marital comedy by David Hertz and William Ludwig, which will go before the cameras next week, the studio announced today. Jack Conway will direct and Pandro Barman will produce.

The Office of Production Management as set up under the President's new order marks a step forward in defense organization. For the OPM will now have executive and not merely advisory powers. At the same time, the four-man commission as constituted seems to leave a lot to be desired.
Reference here is to the communication of Thomas E. Doyle in THE TIMES of this date, "Eire's Neutrality Defended."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Harvard's fast-moving basketball team, as yet undefeated, made Army its fifth victim today in a closely contested game which went into an extra five-minute period for a decision. The score was 44 to 40. It was the opening game of the season for the cadets and was played in Army's big field house before 2,000 persons.

The youngest witness ever to appear in Homicide Court testified there yesterday and cleared city fireman William F. Kennedy, 35 years old, of 24-11 147th Street, Whitestone, Queens, of a charge of suspicion of homicide in connection with the death of Anthony Cara, 7 years old, of 451 Pearl Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The charge that some representatives of United States business concerns operating in Latin America are acting as propagandists of the Axis powers, and supporting anti-American objectives, was made today by Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations between the American Republics.

Disregard of the British blacklist by American manufacturers shipping to customers in Latin America and in other parts of the world is becoming an exception rather than the rule, according to comments yesterday by foreign traders who attended the round table discussion of foreign credit and exchange problems at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 -- Standing a long drive that ended in victory, Liberty Flight, carrying the colors of W.F. Mannagh, eked out a head victory today in the $6,980 Inaugural Handicap, opening day stake of the Miami Jockey Club's forty-six-day meeting, which will continue until March 1 at Hialeah Park.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 -- Warnings appeared today in the Ljubljana and Maribor newspapers that the population of Slovenia must go to air-raid shelters on hearing the sound of airplane engines.
VICHY, France, Jan. 8 -- After many hours of reflection, a summary of President Roosevelt's message to Congress has been allowed to appear in the French press.

The extent of the Italian defeats in the Mediterranean basin became evident yesterday as advance British units reached the outskirts of Tobruk in Libya and Greeks struggled through the mountains of Albania toward the port of Valona.

Columbia's basketball team suffered its first setback of the season last night, bowing by 41 -- 29 to a Fordham quintet which made certain of possession of the ball throughout most of the encounter before 1,000 spectators on the Morningside Heights floor.

J.D. Newson, who is director of the WPA Writers Project in Washington, sends further word on the schedule for the American State Guide Book Series, which is being hurried toward completion. Oklahoma University Press hopes to start printing on the Oklahoma book some time next month, which would put publication probably in April.

Publicly and in splendor, in glamour and gayety, an American couture was born last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor. Champagne flowed, color glowed, floodlights and "baby spots" bathed the scene in brilliance calculated to make memorable an historic event.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Lehman outlined today to a tense opening gathering of the Legislature steps which the State had taken to implement national defense and further steps which he thought should be taken to make sure that total war as waged by European dictatorships was met by total defense on the part of our democracy.

The potential military and naval menace of Fascist arms suffered again yesterday under the dispassionate appraisal of war risk insurance underwriters. The men who judge the dangers involved in moving cargo through waters where war risks exist and fix rates accordingly decided yesterday to cut premiums on shipments from Red Sea, Gulf of Suez and Gulf of Aden ports to this country 33 1-3 per cent, effective today.

A report strongly condemning the new proposals for a St. Lawrence River seaway and power development is to be presented today at the annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers advisory board in the Hotel Biltmore. The organization is one of thirteen similar groups which meet periodically to advise the railroads on requirements for freight cars in the future.

BEFORE he gets through with baseball, they will be calling him Marco Polo MacPhail. When he was with the Reds, he took them to Puerto Rico to warm up. Now that he has the Dodgers, he is going to take them to Cuba for a touch of the Antilles sun.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security early today said:
FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 8 -- Influenza has entered the camp of the Twenty-seventh Division.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 -- Westphalian industrial areas are receiving devastating aerial bombings that are seriously hampering production and undermining the morale of German workers, according to information given by a Slovene metal worker who has just returned from Essen in the Ruhr. Details of the interview were tele phoned to Belgrade by a Ljubljana correspondent tonight.

Plans for purchase by the city of the old Rhinelander Building on Duane Street for transformation into a structure to be known as the City Archives Building were revealed yesterday when it became known that the proposal to acquire the property was on the calendar of the Board of Estimate for consideration at its meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The totals in the President's budget message stunned Congress -- $10 billions for armament in the next fiscal year, representing 62 per cent of all Federal appropriations sought, and $25 billions over a three-year period. And to the $25 billions must yet be added $3 to $5 billions if Congress adopts the "garden hose" armament aid plan for Great Britain.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- The defense of Bardia is rated by all newspapers and Fascist commentators today as an episode of great heroism and as a virtual success for Italian arms. General Annibale Bergonzoli, the Italian commander, is hailed as the hero of the day, about whom the world is talking.

Pig iron production in 1940 amounted to 46,815,906 net tons, according to Iron Age calculations. The December total was 4,414,602 tons, compared with 4,403,230 in November. On a daily basis, output dropped 3 per cent last month, or from 146,774 tons to 142,407.

A policy of leaving well enough alone in yachting in these troublous times seemed to be the keynote yesterday afternoon at the sixteenth annual meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union, held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "Hudson's Bay" will open this morning at the Roxy. Paul Muni is starred in the adventure drama of colonial Canada and Gene Tierney, Laird Cregar, John Sutton, Virginia Field, Vincent Price, Nigel Bruce and Montagu Love are included in the supporting cast. . .

ONCE upon a time there was a young lady from Brooklyn who included among her admirers Rutherford B. Hayes and Grover Cleveland, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow and James Russell Lowell, the King of Sweden, the King of Saxony and the Emperor of Germany.
Playing the role of under dogs may be a factor in their favor as the New York Americans face the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

First place in the Metropolitan League Class A squash tennis play is still in the possession of the unbeaten New York A.C. team, but second place is divided three ways among the Bayside Tennis Club, the Yale and Columbia Clubs, as the result of last night's play.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 -- Sir Louis Beale, member of the British Purchasing Commission, told the Society of Automotive Engineers here tonight that "the hope for complete victory lies in the engineering industry of the United States."

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The first year of the European war and the consequent program for national defense in this country had no adverse effect on the intercollegiate athletic program. A major consequence was to focus attention on the manifold contributions to physical preparedness in national defense which have been made through the years by the health, physical education and athletic programs of the schools and colleges.

Emphasizing New York City's role in national defense, Mayor La Guardia disclosed in his annual message to the City Council yesterday that he would soon convene a newly formed City Defense Council to make definite plans to meet any emergency the city might have to face.

Mark A. McCloskey, director of recreational and community activities in the New York City school system, received a six-month leave of absence from the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday to serve as director of the recreational program of the Federal Security Agency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Collections of internal revenue taxes in the fiscal year ended last June amounted to $5,340,452,347, an increase of 3 per cent over the receipts of $5,181,578,953 in the previous fiscal year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today in its annual report.

The Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday announced the details of its annual matinee cycle of uncut performances of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen." The announcement brought a surprise. For the first season since the cycle was continuously instituted in the 1929-30 season, the two other operas which will round out the cycle of six will not be by Wagner.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, told stockholders of the bank at the annual meeting yesterday that net earnings in 1940 amounted to $6,460,446, equivalent to $3.92 a share on the common stock, compared with $3.71 a share in 1939.

The budget which Mr. Roosevelt submitted yesterday to Congress is, in his own words, "a reflection of a world at war." For the twelve-month period beginning next July the President proposes a total expenditure of seventeen and a half billion dollars. This sum has been exceeded only once in the whole history of the United States.

After more than six months of rumors, Lever Brothers Company yesterday confirmed its appointment of Young Rubicam, Inc., as agency for Swan a new white floating soap. According to the announcement, tentative plans include the use of newspapers, radio and twenty-four-sheet posters.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan denied yesterday an application for a certificate of incorporation for a "Grand Jurors Association of the Bronx, N.Y., Inc." He held such an association might tend to stifle freedom of thought and action in the grand jury room.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 -- The British advance forces operating in the Tobruk area of Libya were strengthened today by reinforcements concentrating in much the same manner as at Bardia in the interval between the first British contact and the actual assault.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 8 -- Prime Minister R.G. Menzies announced today that the War Cabinet had decided to form Australian armored corps embodying all the units raised in the Australian Imperial Force and the Home Defense Force. Authority also was given to form an armored division of the A.I.F.

Suffering from the grippe, Howard Lindsay, who has the title role in "Life With Father" at the Empire, was too ill to go on last night. The performance was not canceled, however, as A. H. Van Buren, who has a minor role and also serves as understudy and stage manager, substituted for Mr. Lindsay in the emergency.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 9 -- A day of comparative quiet overhead yesterday gave Great Britain a breathing spell.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- James S. Kemper, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, warned business men today of a trend which, he said, might involve the United States in war and called for the appointment of a special Congressional committee to reappraise the whole armament program and make a statement of its objectives.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 -- More than 15,000 persons today passed through the iron gates at Hialeah Park, one of the most beautiful of the tropical race courses in America for the opening day of its annual forty-six-day meet. The track was founded ten years ago by Joseph E. Widener, the president until he resigned because of illness, and now chairman of the board.

Mrs. Ely Jacques Kahn, who is retiring after six years as president of the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon given at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street. by the section's board of directors.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 -- Persistent rumors of the escape of Italian General Annibale Bergonzoli, who was in command of the garrison at Bardia, Libya, were confirmed today by official British sources.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Seward Webb gave a luncheon at Miradero for Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, guests of Mr. and Mrs. James Noyes Wallace. Also in the party were Mr. and Mrs. Wallace, Mr. and Mrs. H.T. Webster, Miss Anne M. Wall and Harvey Ladew.

The heavy program of new corporate bond financing is proceeding according to schedule. The reception given to recent offerings has stimulated activity among the underwriters. Yesterday's flotation of $10,000,000 of securities of the Montana-Dakota Utilities Company met with a brisk demand.

The operation of the Sixth Avenue subway has elicited praise from the Board of Transportation and certain department store owners. Nothing has been said of any disadvantages and inconveniences to the riders.

The notice served on the iron and steel scrap trade by the price-stabilization division of the National Defense Advisory Commission that prices must be reduced to not more than $20 a ton is "the most drastic action on prices that has been taken by any governmental authority since 1917-18," according to this week's Iron Age.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The value of retail sales in Great Britain for November was 0.3 per cent higher than in November, 1939. However, in view of price increases and the fact that the purchase tax began to operate in the latter part of October, money sales figures are no longer a guide to volume of business, which certainly declined considerably.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- A report from Washington that United States airplanes will be sent to Greece elicits taunts on the part of the Lavoro Fascista today, which says that Athens, unlike London, must pay cash for all United States supplies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- An appeal to all contractors to "farm out" part of their work to subcontractors in view of the "serious" situation regarding fulfillment of Navy contracts, was issued today by James Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

Fashion history was made last night when New York's Fashion Futures dramatically opened the style season of 1941. Trends were set that will influence not only the United States but the hemisphere, for New York is today the fashion leader of the world.

In the widest and most active market in three months, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange continued their advance into new high ground for the season. The close showed gains of 6 to 20 points. The heaviest gains were made in the distant months, with December at one time showing a 31-point rise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Standard Oil Company, Ohio, has filed a registration statement covering 150,000 shares of 4 per cent cumulative preferred $100 par stock.

The Neediest Cases Fund received forty-three gifts aggregating $466 yesterday and was thereby increased to a total of $231,465.15. Two gifts of $100 helped swell the total. One was from the Christian Associates, Inc., the other was made "In Memory of W.B.B."
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 8 -- Prime Minister Bogdan Philoff, who returned to Sofia from Vienna last night, saw King Boris today and presented his Christmas greetings in accordance with Orthodox custom.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 8 -- About five hours after he had been kidnapped from in front of a store here George Stubbs Jr., 2-month-old son of a restaurant proprietor, was back in his crib in his parents' home at 3019 Atlantic Avenue this evening.

Play reviewers continue to shake their heads over the flood of escapist entertainment on Broadway. Is it certain that the critics are using escapist correctly? It is escape to avoid the realities of life, but it is not escape to try to forget the realities for a little while.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Assailing the Teachers Union, as attempting to "defy" and "impede" the investigation into subversive activities in the New York City public school system, the Legislature adopted first in its opening session today, with only one dissenting vote, a resolution continuing for another year the Rapp-Coudert Joint Legislative Committee Investigating the State's Education set-up.

The business of getting everything shipshape for the opening of the thirty-sixth annual Motor Boat Show continued at Grand Central Palace yesterday. With the weather man still on the side of the show's sponsors and holding off the much-feared snow, the task of moving in the dozens of boats, engines and gadgets has been going along at a rapid pace in preparation for tomorrow night's preview.

Two Army induction centers, one in Manhattan and the other in Queens, yesterday processed 348 men from New York City, furnished for a year of military training under the Selective Service Act, and rejected sixty-five. Those accepted went to Fort Dix, N.J., and Camp Upton at Yaphank, L.I.

Dimitri Mitropoulos began his final week as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, and there were the usual amenities. The players arose when he entered on the stage for the beginning of the concert. When he was recalled for bows at the close of the first and last works, he asked the men to rise, but several times they refused, preferring to join the audience in applauding.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The Appellate Division affirmed today an order of the Albany County Supreme Court which dismissed the petition of the New York City Board of Education for a review of an order of the Commissioner of Education directing the appointment of Frank A. Craig as chief attendance officer.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Yale beat Amherst tonight, 35 to 31, as Captain Johnny Cobb hoisted into the basket 7 points in the last three minutes.

Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Eric J.H. Ericksen, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould, Mr. and Mrs. Julius Wentworth Noyes, Mr. and Mrs. J. Arthur Leve, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph de Castro, Mr. and Mrs. James Johnson, Dr. and Mrs. A. Mestre-Valenti, the Duchess de Talleyrand, Mrs. Frank Vance Storrs and Charles Fite.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP) -- He Said, a 6-to-1 shot, outgalloped ten others to capture the sixth race, an allowance test for 4-year-olds and upward, at Santa Anita Park today. Wilton was second and Gold Bubble third.

A City College quintet that had been rich in promise before the season started, but surprisingly poor in performance once it began, lived up to every early expectation before a gathering of 16,493 in Madison Square Garden last night as the Beavers upset St. John's, 41 to 38.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- Contracts for the manufacture from government materials of 836,200 wool service coats were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot today. Thirty-one concerns shared in the contract at prices ranging from $3.796 to $4.36. They were:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress the annual budget message and conferred with officials and other callers.

Come snow or not, the prospective skier and the "toe strapper" will have their sport at Bear Mountain State Park on Sunday when the first of what is expected to be a series of weekly "Dub Skiers' Days" will be held. Rental of 500 pairs of skis will be at a nominal price and instruction free, with Ole Hegge, one of Norway's most distinguished skiers ten years ago, teaching the fundamentals.

As a result of renewed attention to congestion in the crosstown express streets, it was observed yesterday that traffic had been speeded in the last few days in the theatrical section, although trucks were still snarled below that area.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Wheat prices were on the upgrade in the trading early today on buying induced by the strength in securities and by professional short covering. The bulge, however, was checked by profit taking sales, and later there was pressure from professionals, and the market dropped around 1 cent a bushel under the early high.

Three of the eight competitors in the world championship pocket billiard tourney, including Willie Mosconi, the leader, scored double victories yesterday. Andrew Ponzi, in second place, and George Kelly, the cellar occupant, achieved a stand-off in the day's play.

Banks and trust companies in the State of New York on Oct. 2, last, reported deposits at a record high level of $12,147,000,000, according to William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, in his annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

With many individual companies reporting all-time highs in Christmas trade, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 7 per cent for December over the corresponding month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Theh newly established American-British Art Center will open its quarters at 44 West Fifty-sixth Street this afternoon with a reception and invitation preview of the initial show, made up of work by British and American painters and sculptors.
Investors were active yesterday in the purchase of apartment properties in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The United States Navy was reorganized today into the Pacific, Atlantic and Asiatic Fleets, with the Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet also acting as Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet and prescribing standards and methods of training not only for all three fleets, but also for all other seagoing forces of the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Plans for sending food and medicine to unoccupied France and to Spain were announced today by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, after it had been announced in London that, at the personal request of President Roosevelt, one shipload of relief supplies would be permitted to pass through the blockade.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Republican members of the Legislature led the way today in introducing measures along the lines of the defense program outlined in Governor Lehman's message.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 -- The Yugoslav capital preserved its outward appearance of calm this evening, and there were even signs of lessening tension as reports from Sofia brought official reassurances that Bulgaria had made no commitments to the Reich during Bulgarian Premier Bogdan Philoff's visit to Vienna.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Bobby Riggs of Chicago, who lost his top-ranking position in American tennis a year ago, and Oklahoma City's Don McNeill, the youngster who displaced him, advanced easily today in the seventeenth annual Dixie tournament.

Patriotic anthems and marches recorded and played over a battery of amplifiers on a flag-decked pier heralded the approach of the Portuguese liner Carvalho Araujo which arrived from Lisbon yesterday at the foot of Richard Street, Brooklyn, with 148 passengers, including many war refugees.
ATHENS, Jan. 8 -- An attack by the Greek Army had been under way tonight for several hours over the entire front, with special emphasis on the central and northern sectors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The solidarity of the British and American peoples was emphasized in an exchange of New Year's greetings which took place between King George VI and President Roosevelt.

Sales by savings banks and the Home Owners Loan Corporation accounted for most of the activity in the Bronx realty field yesterday. Among three parcels disposed of by one institution was a large plot on Boston Road opposite Bronx Park, which the buyer plans to improve with an apartment house.

A new vitamin tablet, designed to protect British children from diseases resulting from undernourishment, was explained by a committee of New York doctors at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore, while William V.C. Ruxton, president of the British-American Ambulance Corps, outlined a plan whereby the generosity of United States citizens might contribute the funds necessary for shipment of millions of these concentrates to England.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Britain is still facing a "temporary" food shortage, especially in meat. Lord Woolton, the Food Minister, who is achieving something of a reputation as an after-dinner speaker, took further cognizance of it today. In speeches and orders he has decreed an elastic system of rationing and a halt to the double standard of diet for rich and poor.

Because authorities in Washington believe that any improvements made with relief labor in the Foreign Trade Zone at Stapleton, S.I., would accrue to the benefit of the private corporation that leases the free port area from the city, the WPA has discontinued work on three projects there, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The powerfully armed British submarine Tuna, a member of the Triton class, which includes the salvaged undersea boat Thunderbolt (the former Thetis), which recently distinguished herself in action against an Italian submarine, had a spirited engagement recently with a hostile submarine, it was announced today.

EAST ORANGE N.J., Jan. 8 -Four boys and a Great Dane dog returned to an apartment house here today crestfallen over the frustration of their plans to go somewhere in the wide open spaces out West where there would be no neighbors to complain about a big and healthy canine friend.

Herbert Hoover, honorary chairman of the National Committee on Food for the Five Small Democracies, expressed the hope yesterday that Britain's action in permitting certain food shipments to France and Spain would be followed by "similar constructive action" in Norway, the Netherlands, Belgium and Poland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- R.J. Reynolds, of the North Carolina Tobacco family, lent $100,000 to the New Jersey Democratic State Committee in the recent Presidential campaign at the suggestion of Oliver Quayle, then treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, Charles Quinn, secretary of the New Jersey Committee, testified today before the Senate Committee Investigating Campaign Expenditures.
ALBANY. Jan. 8 -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature today:

HARTFORD, Jan. 8 -- In his inaugural message to the Connecticut General Assembly today Governor Robert A. Hurley recommended the adoption of a program of social reforms and declared that the war emergency required a new morale and the subordination of partisanship.

The Spanish liner Marques de Comillas arrived at the foot of Columbia Street, Brooklyn, yesterday from Bilbao, Spain, Lisbon, Portugal, and Havana with 180 passengers representing nearly every country on the European continent. All but twenty-nine debarked here, the others having boarded the vessel at Havana to make the return trip to Spain.

Paying high tribute to the efforts of Pope Pius XII for peace, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York revealed for the first time some aspects of his own personal association with the Pontiff in a speech yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore following the consecration of Bishop J. Francis McIntyre in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The report of the International Match Realization Company, Ltd., for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, showed payment of a dividend of 2 per cent in August by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy of the International Match Corporation; the trustee had remaining about $1,700,000 in cash, plus about $1,500,000 held by the Vulcan Match Company, all of whose stock is owned by the trustee.

Dominance of the air as well as of the sea by "America and her friends" must become a fact if democracy is to prevail, Lewis W. Douglas, head of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, told 250 guests last night at a dinner marking the dedication of the new Airline Terminal south of Grand Central Station on Forty-second Street.

PANAMA, Jan. 8 -- The National Assembly adopted unanimously today a resolution in support of the message sent by President Arnuflo Arias yesterday to President Roosevelt offering the cooperation of Panama in hemisphere defense against totalitarian aggression.

VICHY, France, Jan. 8 -- "I am happy to be the representative of the United States to the government of Marshal Petain, who is highly regarded by the people of America," declared Ambassador William D. Leahy, speaking for the newsreels just after his official reception today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Commodity loan programs conducted by the Commodity Credit Corporation in the last seven years possibly have meant the difference between 5 and 9 cent cotton, 25 and 57 cent corn, 10 and 20 cent tobacco, 35 and 65 cent wheat and 15 and 25 cent butter, with similar differences in other crops, the corporation asserted today in its annual report.

ALBANY, Jan, 8 -- Bills to outlaw the Communist party in this State and providing for prompt removal from civil service positions of persons enrolled in that party or who had signed communist nominating petitions were introduced at the opening of the Legislature today by Senator John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the Senate.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Jan. 8 -- With a "show-down" conference between union officials and the management of the Ranger Engineering Corporation in East Farmingdale scheduled for 4:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, members of Local 661, United Automobile Workers of America, were busy at their headquarters here tonight planning picketing and other strike activities.
We have received a rather excited but joyous letter from Ernie Lyons of Stuart, Fla., concerning the "great sailfish run," which seems to be still under way off the St. Lucie Inlet.

Logic is not the guide to this war. Some completely irrational and implausible incident -- an intervention of nature, an accident, an unexpected human reaction -- may upset the sequences of reason and change the course of events. Logic does not rule, and we shall continue to be plagued and baffled by the unreasonable and irrelevant behavior of premises and conclusions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Five corporations primarily engaged in the production of vegetable oil had a combined volume of business in 1939 of $126,000,000, compared with $118,000,000 in the preceding year, the Securities and Exchange Commission made known today in a summary of the industry.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8 -- An improved game should result from the changes in college football rules, says Coach Jim Crowley of Fordham.

The 1,295 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $54,169,265,287 par value on Dec. 31, had a total market value of $50,831,283,315, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. On Nov. 3 there were 1,307 issues aggregating $54,237,356,842 par value, which had a total market value of $50,755,887,399.

Dorothy Maynor gave a recital at Town Hall last night as the fourth event in the season's endowment series of that institution. This appearance was granted to the soprano as winner of the Town Hall Endowment Series Award for 1940. Her program featured the world premiere of three of the "Five Rhymes From 'Peacock Pie'," a song cycle by the 39-year-old American composer Theodore Ward Chanler.

Tomorrow the American Sugar Refining Company will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary. Founded in 1891, it is now the world's largest refiner of cane sugar and produces more than a quarter of all the cane sugar refined in the United States.

CENTER MORICHES, L.I., Jan. 8 -- Because the long beams of the anti-aircraft searchlights of the 198th Coast Artillery disturb the domestic duck population in this vicinity, the range of the lights operated from Camp Upton has been restricted, it was learned today.

The greatest distance runner that America ever has produced, Greg Rice of the South Bend A. A., yesterday won the highest prize that amateur sports has to offer, the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy that annually is awarded to the one "who by his performance, example and influence as an amateur and as a man has done the most to advance the cause of sportsmanship."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Williams College tonight inflicted a 5 -- 3 hockey defeat upon Yale at the Arena on the Elis' return after victories over several Western colleges on their holiday trip.

To offset the continuing resignations headed by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, the American Rescue Ship Mission made public yesterday a number of "reaffirmations" of other sponsors who refused to believe the organization was more interested in Communist propaganda than in rescuing Spanish republicans now interned in France.

Some extension of the limited gray goods buying activity that had begun on Tuesday developed yesterday and brought sales for the week through last night to about 30,000,000 yards of printcloths, equal to about 150 per cent of a week's production.

Evidencing no outward appearance that the budget recommendations of the President were out of line with advance predictions, the stock market plodded along yesterday with a moderate improvement in the tenor of trading. The share list received most of its support from the rail section, where a diversified group of carriers added as much as a point.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- With wartime production taking up the slack, unemployment figures between November and December reached their lowest point in about twenty years. Statistics issued today by the Labor Ministry showed a total of 705,279 unemployed on Dec. 9, the smallest number since British officials began keeping unemployment records in 1921.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 8 (AP) -- Atlantic and Gulf shipping interests, called into conference today by the Maritime Commission, were directed unofficially to form a committee to see what might be done to improve coastwise services.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt's huge budget adds no concrete element to the question of United States aid to Great Britain, but it is expected to have a greater effect in Italy than his speeches, despite their forthright language. Italy now knows that the President and the United States mean business, at least up to a certain point.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company and Consolidated Aircraft Corporation will cooperate in production of big bombing planes for national defense.

Among the lessees of residential quarters listed yesterday by brokers and agents was Robert Fisher of the British Consulate General, who took a suite in 14 Sutton Place South through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- In today's stock markets, gilt-edge securities were fractionally lower all around but since it was this market's first dull day since the middle of last month the movement caused no surprise.

A more stringent check upon amateur tennis players by the United States Lawn Tennis Association appears in prospect, according to recommendations of the amateur rule committee of the organization which became known yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Federal Judge Ernest O'Brien assessed fines of $39,262 today on three electrical supply companies, ten Detroit electrical jobbers and nineteen individuals who pleaded nolo contendre to Sherman Anti-Trust Act violation charges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Opposition to certain phases of the Federal Reserve Board's recent proposals to forestall the threat of inflation through increase of its monetary and fiscal authority was voiced today by Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and Federal Loan Administrator.
