SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Two German nationals, one crying he was being "crucified," were removed from the Japanese liner Tatuta Maru today, evidently the result of British refusal to guarantee safe passage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Definite progress on the formula and set-up for financing American aid to Britain, Greece, China and other possible non-Axis Allies was reported today after a series of conferences in which Secretaries Hull and Morgenthau and Congressional leaders took part.

Mayor La Guardia will get a subpoena requiring the production of a confidential report from his files and will be made the object of contempt proceedings if he refuses to do so. Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A chart of Federal expenditures for the fiscal year 1942 (July 1, 1941, to June 30, 1942), calling for an outlay of a minimum of $17,485,528,049, of which $10,811,000,000 would go for national defense and the rest for fixed charges and regular functions of the government, was sent to Congress today by President Roosevelt in his annual budget message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Distinguished Flying Cross has been awarded to Second Lieutenant Willard W. Lazarus and Sergeant Thomas F. O'Malley, the War Department announced today, for their coolness and courage in an emergency during a flight from San Juan, Puerto Rico, to the Virgin Islands March 5.

NAIROBI, Kenya Colony, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Lord Baden-Powell, a military genius who devoted much of his life to a peace organization -- the Boy Scouts -- will be buried tomorrow on a sunny slope of Mt. Kenya, deep in the Africa he loved.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Down match point three times in the second set, Miss Alice Marble came back with a rush tonight and won her second straight match in her professional tennis series with Miss Ruth Mary Hardwick of England, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 9 -- 7.

ISTANBUL. Turkey, Jan. 8 -- General Ismet Inonu, the Turkish President, has returned from his visit to Thrace. The Turkish press still refrains from any reference to this visit, possibly owing to the desire to exercise tact toward Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Congress reacted in various ways today to President Roosevelt's $17,485,000,000 budget measure, most members expressing themselves in general terms, pending a closer study of the document.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A riddle is posed by an Admiralty report that a man was seen to hail out of the plane piloted by Amy Johnson and the statement of the Ministry of Aircraft Production that "it is established that when the plane left the airfield Sunday morning she was not accompanied by a passenger."

VICHY, France, Jan. 8 -- Conditions in Paris continue to cause concern to the government here. Today certain steps were taken by the economic committee to alleviate the rigors of the season there, especially as regards food and fuel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Members of the National Retail Furniture Association, meeting here today in connection with the two weeks' furniture and home furnishings market, heard predictions that their business would be at least 25 per cent better than in 1940 and were cautioned to tighten their installment terms a bit.

Officials of six New England communities announced yesterday plans to sell, during the next week, a series of short-term obligations in the aggregate amount of $2,800,000. Also, seven municipalities generally throughout the country announced actual sales of new securities with a total of $2,449,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Wage and Hour Administrator, emphasized tonight the need for continuing the time-and-a-half for overtime rates after forty hours.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The Forty-fourth Division of federalized National Guardsmen in training here will complete changes by the end of the week on the basis of the regular army square division. The reorganization has created vacancies for 130 additional officers and 2,980 men.

The word "express" as applied to streets in midtown Manhattan plainly doesn't mean what it means when applied to railway trains. When these streets were so designated two years ago the time required to drive a car from Third Avenue to Ninth Avenue was reduced about 60 per cent.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Prime steers sold here at $15.55 a hundredweight today, the highest price since last September. It was an active trade with choice stuff strong and other grades and classes uneven. Hogs were active and 10 to 20 cents higher, fat lambs steady to 10c lower. Order buyers and shippers were purchasing cattle freely if they were of the type to sell above $13.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Following is the text of the President's budget message:

As he knelt in the sanctuary of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, the Most Rev. James Francis Aloysius McIntyre was consecrated Titular Bishop of Cyrene and Bishop Auxiliary of New York, in the ancient rite that has preserved unbroken through twenty centuries the succession from the Apostles.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Leading links stylists of the country, with but few exceptions, will tee off tomorrow over the Sequoyah Club course in the first round of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 8 -- Indications that a final decision on sites for United States air and naval bases here is near were seen today in the arrival from Baltimore of Commander K.B. Bragg of the Navy's Civil Engineer Corps and Major Frank Gilman of the Marine Corps.

Curtailment and proration of new car manufacturing this year was forecast yesterday by Joseph W. Frazer, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., automobile and national defense products makers of Toledo. He said that "production facilities of the nation will be taxed as much as in 1917."

In reading the article in a recent issue of THE TIMES to the effect that fewer than 1,000 Canadians will be allowed to visit the United States this Winter for other than business reasons. I wonder if Americans appreciate the self-denial by Canadians that is involved.

A request that prices of velvets for the coming Fall season be adjusted to provide for a discount basis of 8-10 e.o.m. instead of the present terms of 2 per cent, fifteen days, has been sent to velvet producers by the Associated Merchandising Corporation.

Directors of National Steel Corporation have approved the construction of a new blast furnace and additional coke ovens to add about 300,000 tons to the annual pig-iron capacity of the Weirton Steel Company, its subsidiary, according to an announcement yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The Rutgers basketball team rallied in the second half to defeat Lehigh, 51 to 41, before 1,200 persons tonight. Trailing by 28 to 25 at the half, the Scarlet outscored its opponents, 26 to 13, in the second period for its fifth victory in seven starts.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The Tombs Prison in New York City, condemned by the authorities many times and which is soon to give way to a new building, presents a fire hazard, according to Commissioners John L. Schoenfeld and Edward R. Cass of the State Commission of Correction.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Some House Republicans criticized Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today for her remarks on their alleged failure to applaud the President's message to the joint session Monday.

United States Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico, speaking yesterday at the New York Board of Trade luncheon in the Hotel Astor, advocated a policy of cooperation among government, business and labor. His proposal was similar to one expressed by Arthur Snyder, presiding for the first time as head of the Board of Trade.
BERLIN, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The German High Command said in a communique today:

Slaughter-house supplies were normal to moderate yesterday. Demand was fair to good for non-kosher meats and prices were generally strong to higher. The kosher markets were uneven, demand for beef was good and prices were fully steady. Kosher-veal business was fair and prices were steady to strong.

Decision to resist the military influence on men's clothing and to "glamorize" fabrics by the adoption of color designations similar to those in the women's apparel field was reached yesterday by the members of the International Association of Clothing Designers, opening their sixty-second semi-annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (AP) -- President Laurence di Benedetto of the national A.A.U. today called his organization's expansion plan "the democratic answer to the dictators' athletic programs."

Determined to lose no time in making 1941 a record-smashing year for Brooklyn baseball, Larry MacPhail yesterday announced plans for a Spring training campaign which are almost certain to achieve one of two objectives. They should bring the Dodgers up to the starting line of the National League pennant race in the pink of condition or at the point of absolute exhaustion.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- The announcement of the $17,000,000,000 budget for the United States during the coming year, which followed President Roosevelt's message to Congress, is printed without comment in most sections of the German press today.

Although seventy-seven cases of influenza were recorded in New York City last week, compared with thirty-two in the preceding week and sixteen in the first week in January, 1940, Department of Health officials said yesterday that there was "no sign at present of an epidemic here."

Directors of Abraham Straus, Inc., voted yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, bringing payments for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1941, to $3.50 a share, or 50 cents more than the preceding year.

Commissioner of Parks Robert Moses received yesterday the award of the Advertising Club of New York as the "Man of the Month" in honor of his achievements for the city at a luncheon at the club, 23 Park Avenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Yale coaches with one exception received a year's "notice" of their discharge today, but Ogden Miller, director of athletics, tempered the action by intimating some might be retained.

Willie Mosconi, pace-setter in the world pocket billiard tournament, and Johnny Irish divided two games at McGirr's Academy yesterday. In the afternoon, Mosconi bowed to Irish, 125 to 84, in twelve innings but, aided by a high run of 90, squared accounts at night, 125 to 31, in nine frames.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Your editorial "A General Income Tax" is particularly gratifying. It is a matter which I have long felt should receive more attention from thoughtful citizens. As one of that large group earning a little better than the average and paying a small income tax, the trend of events during recent years has been such that I am hard put to it to maintain salary income large enough to keep up with the increases.

Movie actors, athletes and business men were included in the list of the twelve "most distinguished and well-hatted" men in the United States, announced last night at the annual hat trade dinner at the Hotel Commodore. Proceeds of the dinner, at which George L. Russell Jr., president of the John B. Stetson Company, was guest of honor, will go to the American Red Cross and Bundles for Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A letter expressing disapproval of President Roosevelt's foreign policy as one "which will inevitably lead to war and the destruction of democracy" has been sent to the President by a group of clergymen representing "all religious denominations and all sections of the country," the American Peace Mobilization stated today.

The Democratic enrollment in New York City exceeds the Republican enrollment by more than a million and a half, according to figures made public yesterday by the Board of Elections. The city enrollment for the three legal political parties is Democratic, 2,273, 367; Republican, 758,385; American Labor, 150,763.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Royal Air Force disclosed today the identities of its ten leading aces. Each has shot down from fifteen to thirty German planes. These are the top ten:

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Jan. 9 -- The National Defense Commission tonight asked for and obtained a forty-eight-hour postponement of the threatened strike at the plant of the Ranger Aircraft Engineering Corporation division of the Fairchild Airpane and Engine Corporation, set for 7:45 o'clock tonight.

The 1940 net operating earnings of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company amounted to $6,558,000, equivalent to $6.24 a share. William S. Gray, Jr., president, reported yesterday to stockholders at the annual meeting. He explained that this figure included $497,000 profit from the sale of securities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- An eventual bottleneck of merchant ship tonnage, which may do more than anything else to block American aid to Great Britain, is causing increasing concern in London and Washington. Experts in both capitals are studying the problem, but no single solution has been brought forward.

After a brief ownership, Henry Goelet, operator, has sold to an investing client of the Taylor Company, brokers, the four-story apartment house at 146-05 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, for cash above a first mortgage of $49,500.
A membership on the Chicago Board of Trade was sold on Wednesday for $550, or $25 less than the previous sale.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9 -- British mechanized patrols in Libya are operating west of Tobruk, virtually cutting off Italian communications, although the town is not yet completely surrounded. While British motorized cavalry held the Italians at bay, British transport worked furiously, bringing up more big guns for the artillery pounding necessary before an assault.

The shriek of a bosun's pipe will send a queue of sharp-eyed mariners rushing through the doors of Grand Central Palace tonight at 7 o'clock. The queue, which probably will wind around East Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets from Lexington Avenue, will be waiting eagerly for the shrill signal sounded by a boy wearing the uniform of the Sea Scouts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A registration statement for $50,000,000 was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Illinois Bell Telephone Company of Chicago.

"No for an Answer," the controversial left-wing opera by Marc Blitzstein, was not expected by its sponsors last night to give a performance next Sunday night because Paul Moss, License Commissioner, unexpectedly found that Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, the scene of performances, did not have a theatre license and that alleged building violations prevented the issuance of a permit.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 9 -- An immense strengthening of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and his National Government with regard to the Chinese Communist Armies that are supporting him is seen here as a result of spectacular political and other alliances engineered by General Chiang in the last few months.

A conference between representatives of the Bonneville Administration and executives of the Engineers Public Service Company concerning possible sale of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, subsidiary of Engineers Public Service, terminated yesterday without any definite date for a future meeting.

TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- Estimating that the cost of inaugurating Governor-elect Charles Edison on Jan. 21 will be less than one-fifth of the $2,500 the Legislature was prepared to appropriate, Senator Crawford Jamieson of this city, a member of the joint committee in charge of the event, said today that final arrangements had been completed.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- Eleven baking companies were indicted by the Federal Grand Jury in the Federal court today on charges of conspiring to fix prices of bread in Eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland. Thirty-three officials were named in the indictments.

Wanderlust, predicated chiefly on a dislike for school, reaches it peak among juveniles at the age of 15, it was pointed out yesterday in the annual report of the Bureau of Missing Persons of the Police Department.

Expressing confidence that his efforts to close the deal for purchase of the Yankees would soon meet with success, James A. Farley left yesterday for a two-month tour of South America. During this time, he said, he felt certain he would become the new owner of the former world champions.

How literally the designation of Ambassador Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary applies to the mission of Viscount Halifax to the United States was stressed by Mr. Churchill yesterday in a speech as solemn as the laying on of hands. Any doubt that the Prime Minister is sending to this country the best man he has is dispelled by the unprecedented position the new Ambassador is to occupy in relation to his own Government and to ours.

Attracted by the high levels of Wednesday, profit-taking sales yesterday resulted in a slightly irregular movement in the cotton market. After opening up 1 point to off 4 points, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange backed and filled and closed unchanged to 5 points up, with the greatest strength in July.

Joseph E. Davis was elected secretary and treasurer of the Jockey Club yesterday to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John E. Cowdin. Members in attendance at the annual meeting in the club's offices rose in a silent tribute to honor Mr. Cowdin's memory.

A client of Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers, sold for cash above a first mortgage of $37,360 to Lee-Hal Realty Corporation, Samuel Levy, president, the recently completed one-story taxpayer at 625 North Avenue, New Rochelle, Westchester.

The National Arts Club in Gramercy Park is holding its annual exhibition of work by members. This opened to the public yesterday and will continue through the month. Prizes are to be awarded by a jury consisting of Karl Anderson, John C. Johansen and Edward McCartan, but these will not be announced until the evening of Jan. 22, when the club's annual dinner honoring artist members is held.
New Yok Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Nathaniel S. Seeley to Shelby Cullom Davis and from Rupert H. Johnson to Philip W. Townsend.

Short interest in New York Stock Exchange stocks fell in December, cropping from 515,458 shares on Nov. 29 to 459,129 on Dec. 31, according to a compilation yesterday by the Exchange. These figures did not include short interest in all odd-lot dealers' odd-lot accounts, which were 69,396 shares on the first date and 68,568 on the second.

One of the most famous veterans of any sport was honored last night at the eighth annual banquet of the Touchdown Club of New York. Amos Alonzo Stagg, who recently completed his fifty-first season of football coaching, received the club's annual award, instituted two years ago and awarded posthumously first to Le Roy Mills, famous kicking coach, and last year to William S. Langford, for many years secretary of the Collegiate Football Rules Committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The New York State Conference of Mayors came out strongly today against Governor Lehman's recommendation that State and municipal employes who are called for military training receive the difference between Army pay and their salaries on the public payroll.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 9 -- Miss Elizabeth Pearson of Philadelphia won the New York State women's squash racquets championship for the second year in succession when she defeated Mrs. Enos Throop Jr. of the home club, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 11, at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- After a six-hour strike which "blacked out" traffic lights in the busy Loop district, cut off elevator service in public buildings and halted garbage collections in the country's second largest city, unionized municipal employes agreed this afternoon to a compromise schedule of wage cuts for all city workers earning more than $3,000 a year.

Ratification of a new "employer-employe pension fund," whereby employers will grant a rise in pay to apprentice electricians, who will turn over the money to a fund for members over 60 years of age, was voted yesterday by 4,000 members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, after details of the plan were outlined to them at their monthly meeting at the Manhattan Center.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- The introduction by Senator Farrell of Queens of a bill leading toward legislative reapportionment focused attention today on the fact that only preliminary steps can be taken at the current session of the Legislature.

A truce if not a settlement of the jurisdictional dispute between the United Telephone Organizations, an independent union, and Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an affiliate of the A.F. of L., which has held up the installation of some electrical wires in the Airlines Terminal at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street and delayed its opening, has been reached, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- An epidemic of influenza of a mild form has been moving eastward across the country in the last six weeks and has now reached most of the States on the Eastern seaboard. The Public Health Service stated today.

Twenty-nine additional contributions, amounting to $635.45, were received by the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the total to $232,100,60. These post-Christmas donations will be used, as will all contributions received in the future, for the relief of persons certified by eight leading charitable organizations, cooperating with THE NEW YORK TIMES in the appeal for the Neediest, as the most distressed individuals known in New York City.

In his budget message the President questioned the significance of a statutory debt limit, "except as it serves as a fiscal monitor." But this is stating precisely what the function of a statutory debt limit is; and that function is important. It is like a yellow "caution" traffic light, or a "slow down: steep hill ahead" sign.

Disappointed by the lack of snow the past two weeks, thousands of skiers will descend upon slopes and trails this week-end as the result of yesterday's encouraging reports from the north country. A week ago it was difficult to find a place that would provide good fun for the skier.

Colorful days along old Broadway at the time when the heart of the theatre district was below Thirty-fourth Street were brought to mind yesterday in connection with a realty deal involving the Hotel Grand, landmark at the southeast corner of Broadway and Thirty-first Street.

Investment trust officials were in Washington yesterday to ask the United States Treasury and Jesse H. Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, if they might expect government assistance in swinging one of the largest private financial deals in history.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- Oliver W. Birckhead, president of the People's National Bank and Trust Company of this city, was elected president of the Westchester County Clearing House Association this afternoon to succeed Ernest H. Watson of New Rochelle, who had served two years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The "farming out" of defense orders by primary contractors to smaller firms to speed the defense program already has enlisted the attention of 100 communities which are seeking to pool their available machine power, according to Morris L. Cooke, aide to Sidney Hillman, associate director-general of the Office of Production Management.

Hosiery producers were warned yesterday at their annual industry conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that, unless industry prevents too rapid price increases, it must face government regulation and control. On the other hand, they were told that, with an inflationary economy, price advances were inevitable and that "voluntary price controls" were doomed to fail unless the defense program was financed chiefly from taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Department store sales showed the customary sharp rise during the Christmas season, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, and as a result the board's seasonally adjusted index, based on the 1923-25 average, rose to 101 in December, compared with 100 in November, 94 in October and 95 in December, 1939.

ATHENS, Jan. 9 -- Extensive fighting continued today on all the Albanian fronts and the Greek initiative continued. While there is not yet much news available on the full extent of the development of operations, tonight's communique states that abundant material was taken as well as 200 prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- For the first time since early in February, 1938, the general level of wholesale prices climbed to above 80 per cent of the 1926 average, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.2 for the week ended on Jan. 4; 79.9, on Dec. 28; 79.7, on Dec. 21, and 79.5, on Jan. 6, 1940.

TORONTO, Jan. 9 -- Big Syl Apps broke up a National Hockey League contest in story-book fashion tonight when he scored with three seconds of play remaining, to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-2 overtime victory over the New York Rangers.

Former Senator Ernest W. Gibson of Vermont was elected chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies last night at the end of a four-and-a-half-hour meeting of the executive committee, national policy board and chapter heads in the Hotel Biltmore.
Contract for the construction of the large new main administration building for Roosevelt Hospital has been awarded to the Vermilya Brown Company, trustees of the hospital announced yesterday.

Every little while an additional piece of evidence turns up to remind us that news of the death of the family as an institution has been greatly exaggerated. Several months ago this column was impressed by a study of youth in New York, carried out under vigorous scientific conditions.

PORT MERCER, N.J., Jan. 8 -- We always look forward to a day's pheasant shooting with June Murray on his farm-preserve behind Princeton, and no matter what the weather man offers we are never disappointed. When we arrived this morning with Ray Webster it promised to be another grand day for shooting, and it was.

NEWARK, Jan. 9 -- Oscar B. Cintas of Havana, Cuba, a large stockholder in the American Car and Foundry Company, petitioned today the New Jersey Chancery Court to enjoin the company from merging with the Brill Corporation and the American Car and Foundry Motors Company, both controlled by the defendant corporation.

The stability and independence of the South American republics depend to a great extent on the United States, and without these two factors there is great danger of domination by anti-Americans and Nazi forces in some of the Latin American countries, Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of commercial and cultural relations between the American republics, declared yesterday in an address at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

VICHY, France, Jan. 9 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, the New United States Ambassador to France, was received this afternoon by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain for a survey of the general situation. The presenting of credentials yesterday had been purely ceremonial. Today the Ambassador and the Chief of the French State got down to business and conferred for about one hour.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 9 -- Sudden strength developed on today's Bourse, partly due to the expected resumption of Japanese and Netherlands Indies trade negotiations. Dutch issues rose as much as 8 points, closing generally at the day's best levels.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company announced yesterday that it had been designated by the United States Maritime Commission to build twenty-five ships as part of the construction program announced last Friday by President Roosevelt.

Back in top condition after a series of leg injuries which hampered his efforts last year, Herbert Thompson, Negro sprint star from Jersey City, will attempt to regain the metropolitan A.A.U. crown he won in 1938 and 1939 at the district title meet at the New York Coliseum a week from tomorrow night.

The American British Art Center, Inc., a non-profit organization which will provide relief to British artists, was officially declared "open for business" yesterday afternoon by Godfrey D.N. Haggard, British Consul General here, at a preview in the showrooms, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The State Department made public today the text of Secretary Hull's note of Dec. 27, 1940, to Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, refusing at this time to discuss suggestions of the Vichy government that arrangements be made for mass migration of refugees in unoccupied France to countries of the Western Hemisphere.

Several luncheon parties preceded the tea and lecture on gardens held yesterday afternoon in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the British War Relief Society to augment the organization's funds to purchase additional mobile kitchens for the bombed areas of Great Britain.

The American Rescue Ship Mission from which Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, James Truslow Adams and some eleven others have resigned as sponsors, moved yesterday to prove it was not under Communist control.

The 8,267-ton Portuguese liner Serpa Pinto, a ship with a load of trouble, docked at Staten Island yesterday with 628 passengers, many of whom had been trying to get out of various European countries for three or four years. According to estimates of ship officers, between 90 and 95 per cent of those on board were refugees.

Plans for the erection of an $8,500,000 hotel with 1,000 rooms on Sixteenth Street, between K and L Streets, in Washington, D.C., were announced yesterday at the New York offices of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc.
The large private residence of Mrs. Walter P. Bliss at 6 East Eighty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, has been leased by the Soviet Government and will be transformed into a Soviet private school.

The Pop Realty Corporation of 274 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, sold the four apartment houses at 5401-15 Park Avenue, West New York, N.J., to the Alkal Realty Corporation, of 16 Court Street, Brooklyn. The buildings cover the entire Park Avenue frontage from Fifty-fourth to Fifty-fifth Street and are valued for taxation purposes at $182,700,

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, tonight endorsed strike plans completed by the affiliated auto workers' union at the Ranger Engineering Company plant, in Farmingdale, L.I., and made caustic references to discussion among members of Congress to ban strikes in defense industries.

The United States liner Manhattan is to sail tonight for California via Cuba, Colon and Acapulco. Her passengers include Mrs. R.V. Mullany, Professor and Mrs. William A. Nitze, Mrs. Giles Stedman, Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Thomson, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. Reed, Mr. and Mrs. W.E. Farrell, Mr. and Airs. D.S. Colburn, Mrs. Thomas Meigan, Mrs. Raymond Hitchcock, the Rev. John Brosnan.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Edward Alloo of Rollins College, Winter Park, Fla., scored the first upset of the seventeenth annual Dixie tennis tournament today by eliminating John Kramer of Los Angeles, America's sixth-ranking star, by 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7.

The disappearance of "Strato Lizzie,'' the Transcontinental and Western Air's alley cat mascot yesterday was the principal topic of conversation at the opening of the Thirty-ninth annual championship cat show of the Atlantic Cat Club in the Hotel Taft, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 9 -- "Even Nasjonal Samling men [Norwegian Nazis] have a right to exist," writes one of Major Quisling's most trusted henchmen, Nils Flom. His article in Major Quisling's official organ, Fritt Folk, is one long appeal to Oslo for help for Quislingists in Western Norway, especially Bergen, to establish the "new order" and combat the opposition, which in that region, he says, "completely dominates the situation."

OTTAWA, Jan. 9 -- Controversy over and investigation of the Bren gun contract entered into by the Canadian Government with the John Inglis Company of Toronto have ended, it leaked out today, in the cancellation of the original contract and its replacement by two new contracts dated Oct. 31, 1940.

The new 34,500-ton liner America, which has operated in cruise service between New York and the West Indies since her maiden voyage on Aug. 10, 1940, has been equipped with magnetic mine-resisting cables by order of United States Navy officials.

Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, who has been commandant of the Third Naval District and of the navy yard in Brooklyn since 1937, will relinquish his post and retire from active service March 1, it was announced yesterday at his headquarters in the yard.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 10 -- Royal Air Force bombers delivered savage blows at Wilhelmshaven and Emden, two of Germany's most important naval bases, over Wednesday night, wreaking tremendous havoc in attacks that lasted nearly seven hours, the British Air Ministry said yesterday.

Out of the 280 local draft boards in New York City a singular problem in one area yesterday plagued the men who are administering the Selective Service Act in New York. All of the eligible males of a religious sect known as Jehovah's Witnesses claimed exemption as conscientious objectors.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Although wheat prices held within relatively narrow limits today the market showed a firm undertone. Mills were credited with having bought futures here and at Minneapolis in sufficient volume to indicate that possibly 100,000 barrels of flour had been sold in all positions.

Locally dressed supplies were normal to moderate yesterday. Demand for traefer meats was active to fair and prices were strong to higher. Trading in kosher meats, as usual for a Thursday, was light and prices were little changed from Wednesday's close.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- After the late Colonel House had been for a while in Europe, and enough was learned of his errand to justify the conclusion that he was President Wilson's personal reporter, there was much discussion of the effect his reports might have on Mr. Wilson's major decisions concerning the war.

The transfer of two Manhattan business concerns to the Port Morris section of the Bronx in response to the demands of increasing business was reported yesterday. Units of 15,000 feet each were taken by Karoff, Ltd., manufacturers of perfumery and chemicals, and Alpert Fuchs, shirt manufacturers, in 138 Willow Street, in transactions arranged by Michael Santori, broker.

Three parcels of vacant land have been sold and another improved property in the Bronx has been leased for the City of New York by Lee Thompson Smith, director of the bureau of real estate, through Henry G. Waltemade, auctioneer.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Prime Minister Churchill inspected his first Home Guard unit this morning and chose the only American detachment serving in the land forces of King George. The sole rival of this motorized unit is the Eagle Squadron, fighting with the Royal Air Force.

More than 200 ring followers paid tribute last night to James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, whose legislative bill restored legalized boxing in this State, and to Hammering Henry Armstrong, California Negro, the only boxer ever to hold three world championships at the same time, the featherweight, lightweight and welterweight titles.

Offering to the public of 62,342 shares of common stock of the Van Gorman Machine Tool Company to be made today by an underwriting group headed by Jackson Curtis. The stock will be priced at $15.25 a share. Proceeds of the issue will be used, in part, to redeem $540,000 of the company's 3 3/4 per cent serial notes, due 1941-1949; the balance will be used for additional working capital.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 9 -- Ernest W. Gibson issued the following statement tonight:

There is a great deal of frozen fish, from storage, in the markets this week at attractive prices. Many buyers think there is something wrong with fish from storage and fail to take advantage of it. But market experts at the Consumers Service of the Department of Markets and at the Fish and Wild Life Bureau of the Department of the Interior insist that storage fish, properly treated, is as good as fresh fish.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A bill to give "blank-check" authority for President Roosevelt to extend "all out" aid to the democracies in their fight against the totalitarian nations will be introduced in both houses of Congress tomorrow under strategy intended to rush it through to quick passage.

The first man to be accused of refusing to register in compliance with the Alien Registration Act here was brought before Judge Vincent L. Leibell in Federal court yesterday. The man, Harry Leventer, a 49-year-old Rumanian, admitted his refusal to register, declaring he "had a grievance."

Regarding your editorial "Guarding the Pedestrian" you stated that in a "disturbingly large number of cases carelessness and disobedience of signals on the part of the pedestrian himself are to blame." Aren't there other equally important reasons for the increasing rate of pedestrian accidents?
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum shot a sub-par 67 today to lead the field in the first round of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Roosevelt conferred with defense officials and Congressional leaders on proposed legislation to give him "blank check" authority to textend material aid to democratic countries at war with totalitarian powers.

S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, in his report at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday, said net operating earnings for 1940 were $8,399,166, equivalent to $3.36 a share. This compared with $6,988,506, or $2.80 a share, in 1939.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Steers and cows led an advance in the cattle market today with all other classes moderately strong to active and higher. The bulk of steers sold at $9.50 to $13. Hog trade was fairly active and 10 to 20 cents higher. Fed lambs gained, selling at $10 to $10.25, with a top of the latter price on four loads to packers and shippers.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address to the Pilgrims follows:
The post that President Roosevelt has offered Mayor La Guardia is executive assistant to the President in charge of co-ordination of national defense efforts, it was reported here yesterday.

John Hay Whitney has been elected president of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, to succeed Nelson A. Rockefeller, it was announced yesterday by Stephen C. Clark after a meeting of the hoard of trustees, of which he is chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The British Embassy sought today to remove misconceptions concerning the attitude of the London government toward Finland by pointing out in a statement that it was permitting the American Red Cross to send relief supplies to that country.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 9 -- Navigacion France admits that arrangements are being rushed at the French Embassy here to send five French steamships now in this port to Marseille with Argentine and Uruguayan hides, grains, wools and other products.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 -- American industry was warned by General Hugh S. Johnson tonight that failure of industrial mobilization would raise "one of the most sinister cries" ever heard in America -- the demand for government to take over industry.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Two infantry companies and an artillery battery here were under quarantine for scarlet fever, it was disclosed today. The patients, members of those units, are in an isolation ward in the hospital; their tent mates are in close quarantine in the company streets, and the rest of their units in working quarantine isolated from the remainder of the regiments.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Piano production in 1940 shattered all yearly records since 1927, William A. Mennie, secretary of the National Piano Manufacturers Association, announced here today. Of the 136,332 instruments produced last year, about 80 per cent were the small console types and the balance grands, or in about the same proportion as 1939.

Mayor La Guardia half-apologized to the City Council in his annual message on Wednesday for bothering them with problems which, "although important to us, really seem trivial and unimportant" in comparison with "world conditions and the problems confronting our country." He need not have done so. New York City is part of the battleground of democracy.

Heavy purchases of United States Government bonds and notes in periods of market weakness in the week ended on Wednesday were revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The New York City banks increased their holdings of government bonds by $47,000,000 to $2,899,000,000, a record high.

That book by Winston Churchill that Putnam's had hoped to have last Fall now may come through, it seems. An announcement reads that "we can now hope" for its publication in late February. Entitled "Blood, Sweat and Tears," the book is made up largely of the Prime Minister's public statements.

Keen interest in sports wear has been shown by the buyers arriving in the markets here this week, supporting the view that the coming Spring season will be the biggest yet for this type of merchandise. Indications were that. this merchandise would be promoted almost immediately and that it would have possibilities of active sale both before Eastern and after that holiday.

VICHY, France, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Rear Admiral Rene Platon, Minister of Colonies, asserted tonight that France would defy any challenge to her overseas empire, regardless of its source, and he accused Britain of wanting to appropriate French colonies for use as a "barter instrument."

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

The sure touch of a hand that knows how to pick clothes that conservative women like to wear was evident in the fashion showing held by The Tailored Woman at the luncheon hour in the Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza yesterday.

Slop, a 3-year-old unlicensed German shepherd dog, has been a visitor from time to time in the neighborhood of Bellevue Hospital and the adjacent East River for the last year. Where he came from, who was his owner, concerned no one. Nothing eventful ever happened to Slop.

Unusually heavy payments incident to the first of the month and year, swelled the volume of check transactions for major cities in the first full week of 1941 to the highest figure since the week of Oct. 8, 1931. The showing for cities outside of New York was fractionally below the recent high in the week of Nov. 20, 1940, but otherwise the best for any period since the week of Jan. 8, 1931.

Trailing by two goals at the end of the second period, the Americans staged a gallant rally in the third to draw even with Detroit at Madison Square Garden last night. After the overtime the teams were still tied. The score was 3 to 3.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Reports that the United States had sent troops to Greenland and had established air and naval bases there were denied by Secretary Hull at his press conference today.

The Fulton Theatre will be the scene tonight of Boris Karloff's long-awaited Broadway stage debut. He will impersonate himself in a mystery comedy, "Arsenic and Old Lace," written by Joseph O. Kesselring. The occasion also will mark the entry into the managerial ranks of two collaborators, Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, authors of the currently successful "Life With Father."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered tonight two elections within thirty days at the plant of the Whitall-Tatum division of the Armstrong Cork Corporation, at Millville, N.J., to determine the bargaining agent or agents for the workers.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 -- General Maximino Avila Camacho, the Mexican President's brother and the Governor of the State of Puebla, has accepted an invitation from the Duke of Windsor to visit him at Nassau, Bahamas.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold to William C. Deiss for manufacturing purposes the factory building at 8991 Bridge Street, adjoining the corner of York Street, Brooklyn, through the Cross Brown Company. The property is assessed at $22,000 and was sold for cash.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 9 -- One of the most comprehensive exhibits of rare Chinese jade carvings ever assembled opened this afternoon at the House of Jade with a reception followed by cocktails at the Chambord.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- The Eastern States figure skating championships, in which a record field of eighty-eight will participate, start tomorrow morning at the Playland rink at 8:30 o'clock.

The folks spent a long evening at Carnegie Hall last night with Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. For those who are allergic to contemporary works it was perhaps a longer evening, unless they departed early. For those who delight in testing their perceptions on compositions that are new and unfamiliar it was a provocative, often exciting, evening.

A Red Cross ship carrying whole-wheat flour, prepared milk, vitamin concentrates and drugs from this country to Spain and unoccupied France will be permitted to pass the British blockade at the end of this month, said a Washington announcement on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Immediate plans should be laid to insure that the United States preserve and enlarge "our economic gains when lasting peace is achieved," Senator Wagner of New York said today in a statement issued to accompany his introduction of a resolution to create a Post-Emergency Economic Advisory Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Roosevelt expressed the hope that the French people "may soon again enjoy the blessings of peace with liberty, equality and fraternity" in an exchange of New Year's greetings with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, made public by the State Department today.
ROME, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Stricken with a severe case of influenza, silver-haired Willie Hoppe, world three-cushion billiard champion, was forced to retire tonight in the final block of a challenge match with Jake Schaefer Jr. of Cleveland, and Schaefer relinquished all claims to the championship.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Hard-driving British and Australian armored units today pushed west of Italy's besieged Libyan base of Tobruk, while Fascist troops were reported to be evacuating the fortified oasis of Jarabub, far to the southeast.

The fact that for three successive weeks at the end of the old year British shipping losses fell below the average and in the last week comprised only three vessels of 18,203 total tonnage, the lowest record in ten weeks, is cause for satisfaction as the new year opens. It need not be inferred that some undisclosed invention is conquering the submarine menace, although experiments are constantly being made with new tactics and protective devices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Norwegian Legation today issued the following statement on the recent resignation of the Supreme Court of Norway:

SHANGHAI, Jan. 9 -- Germans and Italians are buying all kinds of properties in the Yangtze Valley and northern cities such as Tsingtao, Chefoo, Tientsin, Peiping and Peitaho. The Italians have 2,000,000 life in gold, handled through the Italian Chamber of Commerce while the Germans have special funds sent direct from Berlin.

Construction of a live poultry market in Long Island City to handle all the live poultry coming into the city was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate, which voted an issue of $460,000 in serial bonds to finance the new market.

OFFICER, they're in again! The heavyweights. Now it's Lou Nova who is about to tangle with Patrick Edward Comiskey. Furthermore, J. Shufflin' Louis, well and favorably known in the trade, has just started to train for his meeting with Red Burman in a few weeks. Or maybe he isn't worrying about Burman, but just wants to keep in shape.

Lou Nova comes back tonight to the scene of his greatest ring triumphs virtually to fight for his pugilistic existence. The California heavyweight is to battle Patrick Edward Comiskey of New Jersey at Madison Square Garden in a struggle scheduled for ten rounds.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Pilgrims bade Viscount Halifax godspeed today as the former Foreign Secretary prepared to leave for Washington on a mission Prime Minister Winston Churchill declared to be "as momentous as any the monarchy has entrusted to an Englishman in the lifetime of the oldest of us here."

RICHARD ALDINGTON'S "Life for Life's Sake"* is a book of personal reminiscences, more often tart than mellow, which, illustrates the lives of Europe's lost generationists from the days of the ivory tower to the days of the Anderson shelter. At the half-way mark they fought in a war that thereafter inevitably silhouetted the background of those who survived.

In a hectic radio debate on the question, "Is a Hitler Defeat Essential to the United States?" Verne Marshall, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, supporting the negative, declared last night in Town Hall that the Roosevelt Administration had it within its power to promote a just and lasting peace.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The United States Ambassador to Rome, William Phillips, on his arrival here early next week will find Italy irrevocably determined to beat Great Britain, says the Gazette del Popolo today.

The City Council has the power to obligate the city for the expenses of special Councilmanic investigating committees, even though the Board of Estimate refuses an appropriation, Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter ruled yesterday. He held also that the Council may hire outside attorneys to act as counsel for the investigating committees.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Bulgarian events tonight held the interest of local and foreign diplomatic circles, where the belief prevailed that Bulgaria soon would consent openly to the passage of German troops across her territory.

Warners' "Four Mothers," which arrives this morning at the Strand, is the sole newcomer to Broadway screens. The film, latest in the Lemp family series, again stars Priscilla, Rosemary and Lola Lane and Gale Page in the title roles and includes Claude Rains, May Robson, Jeffrey Lynn, Eddie Albert, Frank McHugh and Dick Foran in the supporting cast.

The American Merchant Marine Institute announced last night that the National Maritime Union has presented demands for war risk compensation, ranging from 750 per cent of the present war risk pay to as high as 1,500 per cent in some instances.

Standing up straight, and looking sprucer than he had at any time during his recent trial, Howard C. Hopson was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison. Half an hour after that brief procedure he was in an automobile, on his way to the penal institution at Lewisburg, Pa.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Bulgarian events tonight held the interest of local and foreign diplomatic circles, where the belief prevailed that Bulgaria soon would consent openly to the passage of German troops across her territory.

Warners' "Four Mothers," which arrives this morning at the Strand, is the sole newcomer to Broadway screens. The film, latest in the Lemp family series, again stars Priscilla, Rosemary and Lola Lane and Gale Page in the title roles and includes Claude Rains, May Robson, Jeffrey Lynn, Eddie Albert, Frank McHugh and Dick Foran in the supporting cast.

The American Merchant Marine Institute announced last night that the National Maritime Union has presented demands for war risk compensation, ranging from 750 per cent of the present war risk pay to as high as 1,500 per cent in some instances.

Standing up straight, and looking sprucer than he had at any time during his recent trial, Howard C. Hopson was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison. Half an hour after that brief procedure he was in an automobile, on his way to the penal institution at Lewisburg, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Secretary Morgenthau asserted at his press conference today that "a substantial and unwarranted" decline in the price of government bonds had been caused by publication of the Federal Reserve System's plan to increase its control over currency and credit as a precaution against inflation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Of nearly 1,900,000 WPA employes on Jan. 1, more than 400,000 were working on national defense projects, and Howard O. Hunter, acting WPA Commissioner, is counting on an estimated 2,000,000 increase in private employment to take care of those who will be dropped from WPA rolls in the coming year.

Miss Mary Beers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius H. Beers, gave a dinner last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Micheline B. Hardy, daughter of Lamar Hardy, and George Vandel, whose marriage will take place tomorrow in Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Rear Admiral John H. Towers, chief of the Bureau of Naval Aeronautics, said before the House Naval Affairs Committee today that no strikes had yet delayed the procurement of naval planes. Then he added:
Reporting to stockholders for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2, 1940, T. Henry Foster, president of John Morrell Co., said that despite a sales increase the company's net declined.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 9 -- German troop movements and flights of German bombers and troop transports from Southern Austria into Italy have been increased within the past twenty-four hours, according to information tonight from the Yugoslav-Italian frontier.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $220,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,840,000,000, within $100,000,000 of the high record established on Oct. 23. This is an increase of $440,000,000 in the last three weeks.

The board of directors of the Twenty-third Street Association will hold its first luncheon meeting of 1941 on Wednesday at the Hotel Parkside, 18 Gramercy Park South. The mortgage moratorium will be among the matters to be discussed.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The ramming of a British submarine by an Italian torpedo boat was announced by the High Command today, and the story of the battle, in which the submarine fired two torpedoes at the Italian vessel, was told to newspaper men by the torpedo boat's commander, Lieutenant Nicolo Nicolini.

Traffic congestion in the cross-town streets could be eliminated if the city had sufficient patrolmen to enforce "no parking" and other regulations, but it is impossible with the present force. Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine declared yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9 -- Time o' War and Liberty Franc were the winners of the Coral Reef Purse, split into two divisions, at Hialeah Park today, and the latter ran two-fifths of a second faster than Mrs. L. Lazare's son of Dress Parade.

James Carlo, 52-year-old ex-convict with a police record running back twenty-seven years, who is known along the North and East River fronts as Boss Jimmy, was lodged in the Tombs early yesterday as a material witness in default of $10,000 bail on suspicion of managing Joseph (Socks) Lanza's racketeering activities while the labor-rackets boss was serving a two-year sentence in Leavenworth Penitentiary.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Reserves of the Bank of England received an additional 5,304,000 in the week ended today, resulting from a decline of 5,402,000 in circulation and a decrease of 99,000 in gold holdings.

The long discussed advertising campaign of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association may get some impetus at the group's forthcoming annual convention in St. Louis Jan. 14 to 17. If the field supports the project fully, it is expected that the expenditure will range between $1,500,000 and $1,750,000.

All the news last week about the impending delivery of a German ultimatum to Bulgaria has not been confirmed so far by developments. But it ought not to be imagined that the German Government would find it necessary to issue a regular ultimatum to obtain for German troops a right-of-way across Bulgaria.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 9 -- Influenza cases in the Twenty-seventh Division increased sixty today to a total of 160. This is called "a mild epidemic," medical authorities here asserting that a real epidemic would develop daily by at least 100 cases.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A loan of $175,000 by R.J. Reynolds to the New York State Democratic Committee, in addition to his loan of $100,000 to the New Jersey committee, was revealed to the Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures today by Oliver A. Quayle, former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee.

A group headed by Phelps, Fenn $ Co. received yesterday the award of a total of $3,564,000 bonds of Minneapolis, Minn. The financing included $1,745,000 of refunding bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1942 to 1951, for which the group paid 100.255 as 1.70s.

The South is the section most willing to extend aid to England and to take the gamble of a possible war resulting from such aid, and the Middle West is the least willing, results of surveys conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion have shown, Dr. George Gallup, its irector, reports.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 10 -- Gunfire rolled over London last night soon after dark for the first time in four days. It was feared the barrage presaged a heavy German attack, but this did not materialize, although a continual stream of raiders kept anti-aircraft ground crews busy.

Because of the intricacies of law, Joseph Levy, 80 years old, of 317 Madison Avenue, who was arrested Wednesday on a charge of loitering on a Lower East Side street corner, cannot be released from the workhouse to which he was sentenced for ten days even though Magistrate Charles E. Hersimaki reduced the sentence to two days, which would have ended the incarceration at 4 P.M. yesterday.

I read with interest your editorial "Planes From Auto Plants." The really basic fact in the Reuther suggestion is that there is a large idle capacity capable of producing materials for planes. This could not be in Germany, and should not be in the United States under present circumstances.

Carrying signs and placards attacking the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating the local school system, 150 American Student Union members from seven New York City colleges picketed the committee's offices at 165 Broadway from 4 to 5 P.M. yesterday.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (UP) -- A belated but apparently reliable account of disorders in Paris last Armistice Day revealed today that German troops employed submachine guns to quell demonstrators, British sky-writing airplanes flew over the city and German authorities withdrew the city's meat rations for two days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Henry A. Wallace, Vice President-elect, said at a press conference today that he plans next to visit every country in Latin America during his term as Vice President, with the object of promoting peace in the Western Hemisphere.

HANOI, French Indo-China, Jan. 9 -- French military authorities reported tonight the destruction of at least forty Thai (Siamese) war planes as brisk border fighting shifted to air and artillery battles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Black Hawks, rallying brilliantly, scored a 3-1 victory over the Canadiens tonight in an overtime battle before 6,208 fans. Chicago thus tied Boston for third place in the National Hockey League.

Confidence that correlation of the efforts of the railroads and their users would meet the needs of rearmament was expressed yesterday by C.J. Goodyear, general chairman of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board, at the close of its annual meeting in the Hotel Biltmore.
BERLIN, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Today's German High, Command communique:

Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci" were both presented for the first time this season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The two popular works, which had not been performed together on a double bill on the Broadway stage since January. 1939, attracted a capacity audience, which was unstintingly demonstrative at each of the several curtains.

In your editorial "A General Income Tax" you stated that according to the latest Gallup survey a majority favored payment of an income tax on the family's earnings, no matter how little, by every American family not on relief. This proposal, in your opinion, deserves serious consideration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Renewed reports that John G. Winant, former Governor of New Hampshire, would be the new Ambassador to Great Britain, were circulated today and credited in diplomatic circles. No official confirmation was obtainable.

Mayor La Guardia was subpoenaed by the City Council Committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday, to appear at 10 o'clock Monday morning in the New York County Court House.

An overwhelming majority of the American people are convinced that the success of Britain in this war is essential to the security of the United States. They intend that the material resources of this nation shall be made available to Britain promptly enough, and on a large enough scale, to turn the tide of battle.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Stock corporations formed in the State in 1940 were seventy-three fewer than in 1939, Secretary of State Walsh reported today. The total was 16,040, compared with 16,113. Secretary Walsh said that "considering the unsettled conditions in the world today these figures of corporate organizations in the State for the last year are encouraging.

The New York County grand jury closed an investigation yesterday after indicting eight persons in about 400 parked automobile burglaries in the midtown district in the last three months in which $100,000 in garments, jewelry and other personal effects were stolen. Ordinary beer can openers were used as "burglars' tools." Assistant District Attorney Arnold Bauman presented the evidence.

I do not believe that the claim advanced by THE TIMES in its editorial "Above Partisanship," which is also advanced by other sources, that the foreign Policy outlined by President Roosevelt in his last two speeches was approved by both parties and their candidates in the last election, should be allowed to pass without challenge.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 10 -- Jockeys Don Meade and Wendell Eads, one a veteran and the other an apprentice, divided riding honors at Hialeah Park today, each getting a double on a program watched by 7,463 persons who wagered $310,316.

A hundred Brooklyn house burglaries were reported solved last night when police of the Vanderveer Park precinct booked Andrew Druven, 21 years old, of 44 Vermont Avenue, Brooklyn, on burglary charges, and Murray Gershman, 28, of 252 Powell Street, on a charge of receiving stolen goods. Both men will be arraigned in Felony Court today.

Coordination of the respective functions of retailers and coat and suit manufacturers in the observance of the wool labeling law was discussed yesterday at a meeting of committees representing the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board and the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The official German news agency, D.N.B., reported tonight that eight British planes were destroyed in today's daylight attack on Northern France. German planes were declared to have "intercepted energetically."
ROME, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:
Motorized little theatres, with stage, screen and radio stars entertaining "Mile o' Dimes" contributors, will be features in the "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign which starts Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A survey of the financial operations in 1939 of fourteen corporations manufacturing drugs and medicines, issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, shows volume of sales and percentage of profit were higher than in 1938.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- The Italian newspapers carry angry comments today regarding Prime Minister Winston Churchill's assertion in his speech of farewell to Viscount Halifax, the new British Ambassador to the United States, that "the hope of civilization" lies in the Anglo-Saxon countries.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 10 (AP) -Miss Alice Marble flashed the form that carried her to the top last year in women's tennis competition by breezing through two sets to defeat Miss Mary Hardwick tonight, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

Caribbean Architect-Engineer, a newly organized concern which has contracts covering work on four of the seven Caribbean defense bases leased by the United States from Great Britain, has taken large quarters in the Grand Central district for its New York offices.

The first session of the auction sale of English and American antique furniture and other articles, the property of Julian Armstrong of Chicago, Philip S. Dean of this city, and others, brought $15,727 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

A row of nine two-story buildings, comprising nearly an entire blockfront on Northern Boulevard in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Paul S. Hitlin, operator, from the Bank of the Manhattan Company and Arthur Jovis, trustees, for cash above a first mortgage of $77,500.

Glamour, largely a product of partial knowledge and misrepresentation, largely has disappeared from the stock market, and with it has disappeared the dominance of certain speculative favorites. The bellwethers tinkle less loudly. The days when United States Steel accounted for 60 per cent of the annual volume on the New York Stock Exchange have gone forever.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 10 -- The Forty-fourth Division cantonment construction here is virtually complete, but, according to Major Gen. Clifford R. Powell, commanding general, it will be at least March 1 before the buildings can be fully occupied by the 18,000 men in the division.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Prices of wheat futures held within narrow limits again today, the feature being selling of the May attributed to local professionals. Closing trades on the Board of Trade here were 1/8 cent a bushel lower on the May and 1/4 to 3/8 cent higher on the deferred futures:
LONDON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- British political quarters scanned the first summaries of President Roosevelt's defense bill today with mingled amazement and gratification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Secretary Perkins made public today estimates of strikes and time lost in recent years and asserted that, despite the increase in employment and expanding business during the past year, strikes in 1940 had been considerably fewer than in former years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The first week of the Winter furniture and home-furnishings market here ended with buyer attendance breaking all records for the event and sales at the Merchandise Mart and American Furniture Mart running as much as 40 per cent ahead of last year, depending on the line.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 (AP) --The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first eleven months of 1940, made public yesterday by Roy B. White, president, showed a net income of $2,850,587 after all expenses and charges. The net was equal to $2.72 each on the 1,045,592 shares of capital stock outstanding and compared with a net of $828,768, or 79 cents a share, earned in the first eleven months of 1939.

With the awarding of prizes to the finalists in the competition of its thirty-ninth annual championship cat show the Atlantic Cat Club last night closed the two-day exhibition in the Village Room of the Hotel Taft.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -Ford Frick, National Baseball League head, stepped into an off-season role as a substitute with the Boston Curling Club's rink in the seventh annual invitation bonspiel for the Archie Douglas Medal at the St. Andrews Club today.

Yesterday the papers carried a story of an encounter between a German troop train and a suburban train in the outskirts of Budapest. The soldiers apparently were in high spirits. They laughed, waved and shouted greetings to the commuters, sidetracked to make way for the military.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Although there was considerable outspoken criticism of the Administration's bill to aid the democracies after it was introduced in Congress today, it was impossible to gauge the strength of the opposition in Senate or House with accuracy.

Immediate dismissal of six faculty members of Brooklyn College was demanded in a brief filed in Supreme Court yesterday by former Magistrate Joseph Goldstein, acting in a taxpayers' suit, as an outgrowth of the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the local school system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Criticism of the Civil Aeronautics Board's civilian pilot-training program as of "no value to the Army, the Navy or civil airlines" was voiced today at a hearing of the House Naval Affairs Committee.

A majority of those American voters having opinions on the question think Hawaii should be admitted to the Union, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.
VICHY, France, Jan. 10 -- Rejection by the United States State Department of the French proposal for transfer of foreign refugees from France leaves the problem here in a very acute stage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The British Empire had $7,115,000,000 of gold and dollar resources in the United States when the war began, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 -- Several Italian cruisers possibly were damaged when bombs fell close to them during a heavy Royal Air Force raid on Messina, Sicily, last night. Several tons of bombs were dropped among naval vessels in the harbor and on wharves, docks and an oil-storage plant.

In Germany the Darwinian theory of the descent of man is under fire -- the theory that man evolved from an apelike ancestor. To be sure, biologists no longer accept the Darwinian view in all its pristine purity. In these more scientific days it is held that man and the ape sprang from some unknown, common ancestor.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 (AP) -Two advances against infantile paralysis were announced today by scientists at Stanford University and the University of California.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- The harried residents of Rockland County, who for months have been fighting a valiant but losing battle against "swarms" of deer that are eating up crops and crashing into cars, have appealed at last to the State Legislature for a new law.

The annual statement of Loew's, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, 1940, which includes wholly and partly owned subsidiary and affiliated corporations, shows a consolidated net income of $8,908,470 after intercompany eliminations except film rentals.

Mayor La Guardia informed his labor relations staff yesterday that he wanted all city efforts to mediate the strike of wholesale grocery drivers discontinued until a ruling is handed down in Brooklyn Supreme Court on employer charges that the striking union, Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., is a racket "founded for extortion purposes" and not a bona fide labor organization.

Government efforts to avoid a strike by men building aircraft engines for the Army and Navy at the Ranger plant in Farmingdale, L.I., continued yesterday afternoon with a conference by J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Airplane and Engine Corporation, of which the Ranger concern is a subsidiary, with representatives of the National Defense Commission and the Labor Department.

Twenty-one contributors, still anxious to help the most distressing cases known to exist in New York City, sent in gifts yesterday amounting to $250 to the Neediest Cases Fund, increasing to $232,351.10 the current total received during the twenty-ninth annual appeal sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, with the cooperation of leading charitable organizations.

Members of the Fire Department began preparations last night to exhibit their pet Dalmatian dogs in a special competition to be held on Feb. 12, the closing night of the Westminster Kennel Club's show in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 10 (AP) -- Encouraged by word that the St. Lawrence seaway proposal might, be presented to Congress early next month, a group of Congressional supporters outlined today a battle on its behalf.
LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

Charlie Cottar of Garfield County, Okla., who was hunting companion in British East Africa to Great Britain's now embattled King, to the Duke of Windsor; to the Americans, Phil Plant, Franklin Hutton, Woolworth Donohue and Martin Johnson, is dead in Nairobi.

Following his election Thursday as chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, former Senator Ernest W. Gibson of Vermont will come to New York tomorrow from his home in Brattleboro, Vt., to take over his new duties.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 -- British mechanized forces operating west of Tobruk, Libya, today rendered the communications of the besieged Italian garrison precarious. Other British units, protected by the activities of the advanced units, continued to concentrate on the task of bringing up sufficient tanks, guns and infantry to make an assault on Tobruk practicable.
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (UP) -- The official Tass news agency tonight issued the following agreements and texts on the new Soviet accords with Germany:...

TOKYO, Jan. 10 -- The Cabinet today approved urgent plans for defense against air raid presented by Lieut. Gen. Eiki Tojo, the War Minister. All important establishments are to be equipped with anti-aircraft defenses. Materials for them will receive priority.

Slaughter was normal to heavy yesterday. Trading was fairly active in most classes of traefer meats and prices were strong to sharply higher. Demand for kosher meats was fair to slow. Kosher beef opened steady to slightly higher; kosher veal, steady to strong; lamb, steady.

Administration of the best-known of the college rowing regattas, the Intercollegiate Rowing Association races at Poughkeepsie, henceforth will be directed by Asa Bushnell and the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

Two men who are concerned with news broadcasts of the two largest radio networks of the country have written books for Spring publication. They are Edd Johnson, who has been CBS's foreign news editor and is now in charge of the chain's shortwave listening station, and A.A. Schechter, director of news and special events for NBC.

Two attractions will shut up shop on Broadway tonight. They are "Night of Love," which will be sent to the storehouse, and the program of Ruth and Paul Draper, which was extended for a week beyond the original closing date.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10 -- Several thousand Federal employes paraded in this city this evening in protest against the dismissal of employes that has been going on in more than one Ministry since President Manuel Avila Camacho's inauguration and his reported intention of reforming the civil service law so as to prohibit employes organizing unions and striking.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- After nearly a year's argument and deliberation, the Securities and Exchange Commission refused today the application of the $367,000,000 Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for an overall approval of its voluntary plan for geographical integration and corporate simplification under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- The Society of Automotive Engineers was told at the close of its annual meeting here today that too many special engines requiring "prescription," or special lubricating oils and fuels had not only created an economically unsound situation in the industry but had presented a problem of national defense to the Army and Navy.

The financial records of the No Foreign War Committee, which Verne Marshall, the committee's chairman, had said Thursday night over the radio would be open "anytime, to any one," were refused yesterday to Dr. L.M. Birkhead, director Of the Friends of Democracy.

International code flags fluttered along Lexington Avenue last night, great, long halyards of them in front of Grand Central Palace. Other streamers upwind and down to leeward of the Palace stood out from the avenue's hotels, all signaling to throngs of New Yorkers and visitors that another National Motor Boat Show, thirty-sixth in the annual series, was on. A four-hour preview was given last night.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- Great Britain's agreement to permit shipments of some amounts of foodstuff and clothing by the American Red Cross to children in occupied France evokes bitter comment by the official organ of the German Foreign Office, the Deutsche Diplomatisch-Politische Korrespondenz.

This has been a relatively reticent season for Wagner at the Metropolitan Opera House. With last night's return to the repertory of "Siegfried," the season's record for Wagner thus far stood at four works; the other three have been "Tristan und Isolde," "Die Walkuere" and "Tannhaeuser."

AIKEN, S.C., Jan. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. Fitch Gilbert gave a dinner tonight at Red Top to Mr. and Mrs. Dunbar W. Bostwick and Mr. and Mrs. George Herbert Bostwick, who ! have arrived to spend the season.

Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo, former President of the Dominican Republic who donated a 26,000-acre estate at Sosua to the Dominican Republic Settlement Association as a haven for European refugees, has made available another tract of 50,000 acres adjacent to the Sosua land and also has presented a mountain preserve to the movement to be used by the refugees for rest and recreation.

A grave danger exists that evening trade schools and the emergency defense training program, conducted by the New York City school system, may have to close down as a result of the Appellate Division's ruling against dual job-holding by city-employed teachers, it was asserted yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

The first round of the seventh annual men's New York State amateur squash racquets singles championships was completed at the Downtown Athletic Club last night with the playing of eight matches. Two second-round events also were held.
Two parcels in areas to be improved with projects by the City Housing Authority have been purchased from the Central Savings Bank, it was announced yesterday.

It isn't merely a picturesque detail that the Australian troops in Africa have gone into battle yelling and singing a chorus from "The Wizard of Oz." It's hard to get a song out of a soldier in a retreat, or one who is on the defensive, or one who doesn't quite know what he is fighting for.

The Appellate Division denied unanimously yesterday the application of Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, for permission to carry to the Court of Appeals his fight against the contempt order requiring his imprisonment unless he testified at a private hearing of the City Council committee investigating him and the commission.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10 (UP) -- High Thai officials said tonight that the Thailand-Indo-China border conflict was "perilously near the status of a full-dress war" but insisted Thailand would seek a peaceful settlement if French officials sent plenipotentiaries to Bangkok.
