Rearmament has doubled the profits of the Panama Railroad, the company disclosed yesterday through issuance of its ninety-first annual report. The line has been distinguished for years as a government-owned utility which has operated at a profit, attributed to its ability to regulate or eliminate any competition with it on the Isthmus of Panama.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in December amounted to 1,544,623 net tons, a new high record for that month and a gain of 119,271 tons over November. In 1940 it was exceeded only by 1,572,408 tons, in October.

An undisclosed number of United States Army troops will sail from the Army Base in Brooklyn aboard the Edmund B. Alexander next Wednesday for the new naval base at Newfoundland, which is one of eight bases recently leased to the United States by Great Britain in exchange for fifty World War destroyers, it was announced here yesterday.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 11 -- In a swift, hard-hitting aerial attack marking their biggest daylight raid thus far strong forces of Royal Air Force bombers guarded by an escort of 100 fighter planes smashed Nazi-occupied air bases at midday yesterday, destroying three German machines that tried unsuccessfully to chase them off and damaging others on the ground, it was announced here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Roosevelt called today for swift action upon the bill granting him "blank-check" powers to obtain and transfer war supplies to Britain and her allies. Speed, he said, was essential if the democracies are to survive.

HAVANA, Jan. 10 -- Pessimism pervaded sugar circles here today as to the Cuban Government's attempt to finance through the Export-Import Bank of Washington the grinding of 500,000 tons of sugar in addition to the requirements of the United States and local markets.

In defiance of police regulations, trucks were backed diagonally to the curb and private ears stood as long as half an hour in "no parking" streets of the midtown area yesterday, while a veritable merry-go-round of taxicabs hugged the curb around a block in a feeding line at Radio City.
The State received $6,000,000 from horse racing in 1940. For horse players this is nothing to cheer about, but it is surprising how many point to it as one of the great "benefits" of mutuel betting.

Tomorrow will end the Universal Week of Prayer in which Protestants annually hold special meetings through the week, with special sermons preached on the opening and closing Sundays. The topics for tomorrow at the Protestant churches will cover faith and prayer in an age of struggle.

Urging every "red-blooded American" to support President Roosevelt's foreign policy, former Governor Alfred E. Smith predicted last night that the war would end sooner "than most people think," and that "if we give full aid to Britain, the empire of Hitler will fall to pieces as fast as it was put together."

The upturn of the current week in the stock market lost yesterday some of its zest although values were still able to edge a bit higher. The flair of the previous session was lacking as traders returned to less ambitious activity, and the gains scored before the noon hour were reduced in the afternoon period.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The time has come to place professional boxing under Federal supervision.

Some people see German troops crossing Bulgaria and attacking Greece almost any day. Others think the attack cannot come until Spring because of Winter in the mountains. Some are not so sure about a German move in the Balkans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A plea for more food for France beyond that provided for in the cargo that will be forwarded late this month to the unoccupied zone was made today by Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, at a conference with Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.

President Roosevelt's aid-to-democracies bill was criticized here yesterday by former President Hoover and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey. Wendell L. Willkie, who is planning a speech next week on defense, withheld comment.

The 118th annual meeting of the Woman's Branch of the New York City Mission Society will be held at 11 A.M., Monday, at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street. Brief reports of field work will be made by Miss Marietta Alfani, Mrs. Lawrence Blackman, Miss Sarah J. Shotwell and Mrs. R.C. Stevens.

Let's not exaggerate. At some time there may have been a funnier murder charade than "Arsenic and Old Lace," which was acted at the Fulton last evening. But the supposition is purely academic. For Joseph Kesselring has written one so funny that none of us will ever forget it and Bretaigne Windust has directed it like a man inspired.

An exhibit of reports to stockholders will be displayed at the conference of the finance division of the American Management Association to be held in the Hotel Roosevelt on Jan. 22 and 23. The reports were selected for general excellence, completeness, typography, illustrations and covers.

Probably $220,000,000 was spent in 1940 in the United States for all basic production research, according to the findings of a survey made by Dr. William A. Hamor, associate director of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, Pittsburgh, and reported to the American Chemical Society, the society announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -Joan Carroll, RKO's 8-year-old actress, who is appearing on Broadway in B.G. De Sylva's "Panama Hattie," was named today by the studio for a leading role in "Obliging Young Lady" by Arthur Herman.
Edward A. Ruhfel, as trustee for Willem van Marle, became a limited partner of Bendix, Lutweiler Co. on Dec. 16. Mr. van Marle retired as a partner on that date.
The City College swimming team defeated N.Y.U., 52 to 23, in the City College pool last night.

Two "living lithography" exhibitions will open in New York in February -- one at the New York Trade School, 312 East Sixty-seventh Street on Feb. 1; the second, a traveling exhibition sponsored by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, on Feb. 24.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 10 -- After a decidedly firm opening with prices considerably higher, under the lead of American issues, sudden selling developed on today's Bourse for no apparent reason. Dutch issues as a result closed mostly to 3 points, net, lower on the day.
Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry, attacked assertions made in a suit brought against his company by Oscar B. Cintas in a statement issued yesterday.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by fifty-five municipalities and local housing authorities aggregates $69,809,799, compared with $23,889,765 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $18,419,480.

Even though it sounds in the dead of night, when other folks are sleeping, the hum of the lathe must be music to the ears of the 180 WPA workers now fitting themselves for a return to industry in "refresher courses" at the Brooklyn High School of Automotive Trades.

New York City furnished 277 more men yesterday under the Selective Service Act for a year of military training. The completion of the first week of the current call showed that 1,422 men had been inducted into service and 364 rejected after physical examinations.

How seriously the war has affected sport in this country was emphasized by Adrian Van Sinderen, president of the American Horse Shows Association, in his address to the delegates to the annual meeting yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Major James V. Demarest, vice commander of the State American Legion, accompanied by thirty legionnaires, tested yesterday morning facilities for air defense at the observation tower atop the Empire State Building. The tower has been designated as a defense observation post.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A table on the population of New York State released today by the Census Bureau gave 1940 and 1930 figures as follows:

An apartment of eight rooms in the building at 410 Park Avenue has been leased by Captain Victor Egan through Frances R. Jaffin, broker. Mrs. Egan is the former Elsie Ferguson, stage and screen actress.

The Broadway screen roster remains unchanged today, with both "Night Train" at the Globe and "Hotel du Nord" at the Little Carnegie Playhouse entering their third weeks. . . . "I Married Adventure," the Columbia production starring Osa (Mrs. Martin) Johnson, which first was shown at the Plaza Theatre last September, will begin an engagement today at the Central Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The text of the measure introduced in Congress today to effect President Roosevelt's plan of lending or leasing military equipment to "democracies" was as follows:

An expanding demand for consumption goods and a higher standard of living generally will inevitably result from the huge governmental expenditures in connection with the national defense program, Emmett F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America declared yesterday.

MADRID, Spain, Jan. 10 -- In a mildly critical comment on President Roosevelt's message to Congress the newspaper Alcazar contrasts the "happy lot" of German workingmen with that of "millions of unemployed American laborers who are dying of hunger."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -Terming its treatment of the Negro the most striking flaw in American democracy, Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund of Chicago, said tonight at Yale University that the American attitude toward the Negro race was a threat to the whole practice and theory of democracy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 10--The Home Owners Loan and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporations were accused today by the Westchester County Village Officials Association of disrupting local tax assessment systems, hindering national defense and putting, communities to needless legal expense by filing "unjustified" certiorari suits for assessment reductions on real estate acquired by the Federal agencies through mortgage foreclosures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Preliminary estimates for December indicate a figure of about 136 for the Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production, compared with 133 in November and 129 in October, it was reported today.
With regard to the traffic problem, is it too much to expect the city to remove, say, 70 per cent of its obsolete signs so a motorist might understand where he could legally park?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 28 was 5,239,550 shares, compared with 4,654,220 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Here in Northampton Arthur Daley's anecdotes about Ed Lynch attracted a great deal of notice. He was a legend at St. Michael's High, which I attended. St. Michael's never had a football team, so it's true that Lynch never had formal football coaching in high school.

Over the bruised and bleeding figure of young Patrick Edward Comiskey of Paterson, N.J., stout-hearted Lou Nova last night catapulted back into the front ranks of heavyweight title challengers in Madison Square Garden.

New bond financing consummated in this market this week increased to $55,611,000, chiefly because of the appearance of several large blocks of municipal loans. This compares with $30,528,250 in new bonds placed on the market last week and with $38,500,000 offered during this week last year.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 10 -- Japan is sending a floating exposition of machinery to tour Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay in June in an effort to increase its exports of these products to South America, it was announced by Japanese circles here today.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- A bombing of Messina, the important Sicilian port just outside the Italian mainland, is reported in today's communique. This is the second time in two days that a Sicilian port has been attacked, for on Wednesday night Palermo was bombed.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Moving toward renewal of the tennis feud they waged last year, National Champion Don McNeill of Oklahoma City and Chicago's Bobby Riggs advanced today to the semi-finals of the seventeenth annual Dixie tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- R. J. Reynolds quietly told a Senate investigating committee today about supplying $300,000 to help re-elect President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The American Red Cross will accept contributions for packages for prisoners of war from individuals wishing to send food boxes to soldiers in European prison camps. The cost of each package is $2.20. The standard food package weighs eleven pounds and contains food and cigarettes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A bill to confer upon President Roosevelt practically unlimited personal power to place American war equipment, new and old, at the disposal of foreign nations in the interest of the defense of the United States was introduced in Congress today amid signs of a brewing legislative storm.

The track season has been rather slow to get under way because of the law prohibiting armories from being used for any purposes other than national defense. So it will get off with a resounding crash in Boston tonight with the staging of the Veterans of Foreign Wars show in the Boston Garden.
Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in 1940 amounted to $311,978,207,097, a gain of 2.5 per cent over 1939. The record is $727,848,371,330, established in 1929.

A fire of undetermined origin was discovered at 5:30 o'clock last night in a hold of the British freighter Black Heron at her berth at Pier 8 at the foot of Pineapple Street, Brooklyn, on the eve of the ship's sailing for an undisclosed port with a large cargo of war materials and Red Cross supplies.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -Syracuse ended Fordham's five-game winning streak in basketball tonight, 60 to 44, before an enthusiastic crowd of about 2,400.

The third-class proficiency test for metropolitan skiers will definitely be held this afternoon in conjunction with the New York City Ski Patrol examination on the Polar Bear Trail and practice slope at the Beartown State Forest in South Lee, Mass.

VICHY, France, Jan. 10 -- Much prominence is given in the French press to a speech by Walter H. Sholes, United States Consul General in Lyon, at the annual luncheon given by the consular corps in that city to the municipal authorities.

MALVERN, England, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Archbishop of York's Church Conference, meeting here, declared today that private ownership of the nation's main industrial resources may be a "stumbling block" to Christianity, making it more difficult for men to lead Christian lives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 10 -Suppression of the motion-picture "Citizen Kane," Orson Welles's first film venture, has been demanded of RKO Radio Pictures, Inc., by representatives of William Randolph Hearst the publisher.
ATHENS, Jan. 10 -- What may be regarded as one of the most significant successes achieved by Greek arms since the start of the Albanian campaign was announced here today -- the fall of Klisura.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -Cornell took the opening Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game from Yale tonight, 39 to 25. Yale held the lead for a brief period in the second half, and found Cornell's defense too strong in the later stages.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 10 -With twenty-five of the strongest teams in the East listed in the entry, which includes William E. Slack and Hunter Lott, the national champions from Philadelphia, the annual Greenwich-Apawamis invitation squash racquets doubles tournament got under way tonight.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP) -Long, lean E.J. (Dutch) Harrison, not the original Arkansas Traveler, but practically as methodical, rammed home an eighteen-foot putt on the final green today to chalk up a new low round of 66 and lead the field at the halfway mark of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 11 -Waves of Nazi bombers concentrated a heavy assault on a south coast town last night and early today after yesterday's daylight hours had passed without an air raid alarm in the British Isles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- More changes in naval commands were announced by the Navy Department today, the most important being the command of Battleship Division 3 of the Pacific Fleet.

Department store sales here turned upward this week. Estimates yesterday indicated average volume was running about 5 per cent ahead of the like week last yeast. Buying interest was reported well distributed over many store sections.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- The danger inherent now, more than at any other time, in a sales policy based on the philosophy of "let's get ours while the getting is good," was stressed here today by Henry J. Nichols, vice president of the National Shawmut Bank, Boston, and president of the Boston Chamber of Commerce, before 450 executives attending the annual New England Sales Conference.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

It is both expedient and imperative at this time to consider the very vital interest that the audience of radio listeners and the general public have in the current controversy between ASCAP and the large broadcasting systems. Entirely too prevalent is the tendency to regard this as a conflict affecting private groups, while the public, whose concern is paramount, is relegated to the position of a mere onlooker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Governor Lehman of New York conferred today with William S. Knudsen, director of the Office of Production Management, on plane to put idle plants, machinery and labor in New York State to work in the defense program.

The Philadelphia publishing house of J.B. Lippincott Company, one of the oldest book publishers in the country, is taking control of the three-year-old New York firm of Carrick Evans, it was announced yesterday. The two companies will be merged.

Outlawing or postponing strikes by law as a means of facilitating the defense program was opposed yesterday by William L. Leiserson, member of the National Labor Relations Board, in an address at the fifth annual Hosiery Industry Conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, sponsored by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 10 -- German and Italian war planes are flying in steadily increasing numbers between Southern Austria and Northern Italy, with most of the traffic moving in a southwesterly direction, according to information obtained in the frontier zone adjoining Austria and Italy today.

The one-man show of early work by Edward Hopper, at the Rehn, is important both because of the quality of much of the painting itself and because this work provides so abundant an index to the artist's subsequent development.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- New York State on April 1 had a population of 13,479,142, an increase of 891,076 over the 12,588,066 reported in 1930, according to the final figures of the Sixteenth Decennial Census announced today by William Lane Austin, director.

Mrs. William M.V. Hoffman gave a luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza yesterday for Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly. The other guests were Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, Mrs. Julian S.L. Humphrys, Mrs. Allen M. Thomas, Mrs. Lewis Gawtry, Mrs. Charles D. Hazen, Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, Mrs. William A. Kissam and Miss Angelica L. Gerry.

The recent action photograph printed in THE TIMES showing a group of excited hockey players mixing it up in a free-for-all might well give any one the impression that of all sports hockey is the one that least inspires brotherliness among its players.

The Florida National Bank of Jacksonville received yesterday the award of $1,100,000 of refunding bonds of Duval County, Fla., on a bid of 103.57 for 2 1/2s, which is at a net interest cost of 2.19 per cent. The bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1941, will mature serially on Sept. 1, 1942 to 1966.

Mischa Elman was in top form at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall and regaled his largo and demonstrative audience with a series of masterly performances. The violinist's program centered about Spohr's concerto, No. 9, in D minor. That principal offering was preceded by the Bach-Nachez partita in E minor and Faure's sonata in A major, Op. 13.

An expanded promotion program for Valspar varnish, including cooperative newspaper advertising and complete dealer merchandising material, was announced yesterday by Thurlow J. Campbell, president of Valentine Co., Inc., the manufacturer.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- City College of New York came from behind to defeat St. Joseph's, 40 -- 26, in a hard-fought game at Convention Hall tonight before 5,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Hogs were active and strong to 10 cents higher today, reaching a top of $7.75. All classes of cattle were steady in the week-end clean-up, and sheep followed the general trend, selling strong in most classes. Cutter and common beef cows predominated in the cattle run and sold actively at $6.50 down to $5.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 10 -Navy Minister W.M. Hughes, disclosing the closing of four commercial wireless stations today, revealed that the action had been taken at the request of the Navy Board and added that one station indicated the whereabouts of Australian ships which might have made them a prey to raiders.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 10 -Princeton broke a 2-2 tie midway in the second period and went on to defeat the Clarkson sextet, 5 -- 3, in a fast and rough game in Baker Rink tonight. Jim Sloane, with two goals and two assists, paced the Tigers' attack.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Roosevelt was a guest of the Women's National Press Club at its weekly luncheon today, and left immediately afterward with Mrs. Roosevelt for Hyde Park.

Reginald Stewart is primarily an orchestral conductor -- indeed, he shares with Sir Ernest MacMillan the distinction of being one of Canada's two leading conductors -- yet last night in his third recital at the Town Hall Mr. Stewart showed that he is also a pianist of the first rank.

Attendance at market events this week rose to record levels and ordering was well ahead of last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Retail sales events also drew heavy attendance. Industry reported new business in larger volume than usual for the season land producers resumed pre-holiday operating rates.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- The first important decisions of Giuseppe Tassinari as Italy's food and economic dictator were published today, when it was announced that an inventory would be taken of all stocks of flour, macaroni, wheat, corn, rice, oil, butter, lard and other basic foodstuffs held by farmers, industrialists and merchants.
FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 10 -- The outbreak of mild influenza in the Twenty-seventh Division is declining. The number of cases stood today at 150.

Reich Marshal Hermann Goering and other high Nazi officials have smuggled millions of dollars out of Germany, to be deposited for their personal use in banks here and in other countries, it was confirmed here yesterday. The cash was transported by a Rumanian, who used a fraudulently obtained United States passport in his trips back and forth across the German border, it was shown.

A painting of the official poster for the annual celebration of Brotherhood Week, Feb. 22 to 28, by the National Conference of Christians and Jews was unveiled yesterday at the conference's office, 300 Fourth Avenue.

The first for this season of the After-Dinner Dances, arranged for members of the young married set, debutantes of recent seasons and their guests, was held last night in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Many dinner parties preceded the event.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Informed sources reported tonight that a Soviet trade mission was en route here to negotiate a "giant trade agreement" based mainly on the export of Argentine grain to Russia.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday thirty-five additions to the City Defense Council, which he recently appointed at the request of Governor Lehman. He also revealed that the Council would hold its first meeting on Wednesday at City Hall.

Slipping ahead early in the initial half and never relinquishing command thereafter, Penn State's basketball forces upset previously unbeaten N.Y.U., 47 to 34, before a capacity crowd of 2,000 in the University Heights gymnasium last night.

Dr. Alfred Norton Goldsmith, New York radio engineer and inventor, received last night the 1941 medal of honor of the Institute of Radio Engineers at the annual dinner of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The dinner was held in connection with the institute's sixteenth annual convention, which ends today.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- A 13-year-old girl, Ann Robinson of New Haven, Conn., captured the women's Eastern States novice figure-skating crown from a field of twenty at the Playland Rink today.

The Federal Government bought from Eugene Newkirk, executor of Arianna Newkirk, as a site for a branch postoffice in the Bergen section of Jersey City the old George P. Newkirk homestead at 526-28 Bergen Avenue, southeast corner of Harrison Avenue.

The football rules changes which permit unlimited substitutions and which also allow substitutes to communicate with their team-mates immediately on entering the game should eliminate many of the protests which have arisen in the past against overwhelming victories scored because of superior manpower and against signaling from the sidelines.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- Soviet Russia agreed today to send to warring Germany quantities of food, especially grains, in a significant collaboration officially described as "an enlarged economic agreement."

The Australian banks as a group have increased greatly their liquidity since war began, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which is the central bank of the Commonwealth, reported yesterday, according to cabled advices received here by The Australian Press.

IT must be that Porky Oliver, the golfer of great girth, is a Man of Destiny. Things happen to him. Fate must have something special in store for a marked man like Porky, something big. But he that buckles himself in Porky's belt might reasonably expect no small thing to stand in his way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -Pierre S. du Pont paid back 47,000 shares of E.I. du Pont de Nemours common stock -- involving about $7,750,000 at current market prices -- in November, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its monthly summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal owners of corporations.

The amateur ichthyologists of the Atlantic City Tuna Club, who spent arduous days and nights during the past year in collecting live specimens of the genus pisces, no longer have an aquarium -- they have a large fish chowder.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -This Republican community will begin the construction soon of a new village hall, village green and library costing more than $165,000, but Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, the Mayor, announced today that financial aid for the work would not be sought nor accepted from the Federal Government.

Proposals that United States investment trusts take over outstanding British investments in the United States would involve between $1,000,000,000 and $2,000,000,000. On Aug. 31, after a year of war, British direct investments were estimated by the Department of Commerce at $856,000,000.
The British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, reported yesterday that contributions of $966,333 in December increased the year's total to $4,340,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., recognized as middle-weight champion by the National Boxing Association, decisively defeated Steve Mamakos of Washington in ten blistering rounds at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

A joint statement of four organizations cooperating in the transportation, resettlement and relief of political refugees was issued yesterday for the purpose of preventing confusion of their sponsorship and activities with those of the American Rescue Ship Mission, from which Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and others resigned recently.

One item in the Reichsbank's year-end statement is indicative of conditions in Germany today. Banknote circulation totaled over 14,000,000,000 marks, much the highest since the German currency was stabilized in 1924, and only 3,000,000,000 marks under the November, 1918, figure at the close of the World War.

WHEN "Oliver Wiswell" appeared, the theory was bruited about that Mr. Roberts's rambunctious defense of the Loyalist as against the Patriot side in the American Revolution might cause alarming fissures to appear in public monuments.

Recovering yesterday from the irregularity which had marked trading on Thursday, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange for the third time this week touched new high levels for the season and closed at net advances of 3 to 12 points.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Quieter conditions ruled in today's stock markets and with profit-taking in progress an irregular tendency developed.

Jarmila Novotna scored an emphatic triumph in the title role of Massenet's "Manon" at the season's first presentation yesterday afternoon of that work at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance, a special one, was given for the benefit of Barnard College.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today imposing strict export regulations upon copper, brass, bronze, zinc, nickel and potash, to become effective Feb. 3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Following is an official interpretation of President Roosevelt's aid-Britain bill prepared by Senator Barkley and Representative McCormack, majority leader, who introduced it today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Bernard M. Baruch, chairman of the War Industries Board during the World War, said tonight that in creating the new Office of Production Management "a long forward step" had been taken, although he preferred to have one man responsible for decisions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Army contracts for 431,000 rubberized and oil-treated raincoats, 100,000 yards of herringbone twill cloth and quantities of thread, tape and gimp were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today, as follows:
Comment in the press of the country on the bill for British aid ranged from cautious approval to sharp questioning. Here are some views as gathered by THE TIMES:

Asserting that the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians possesses none of the characteristics of a religious organization "except, possibly, the solicitation and receipt of funds," Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the group's retreat known as Peace Haven and Shangri La, a 110-room mansion at Oakdale, L.I., cannot be exempted from taxation.

Feeling is believing to Mark Shoesmith, a blind sculptor who was interviewed at Lauritz Melchior's apartment yesterday afternoon as he put the finishing touches on his portrait of the Metropolitan Opera singer.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Harry Hopkins had luncheon and a long talk with Prime Minister Winston Churchill at 10 Downing Street today after briefer conferences with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Viscount Halifax, the new Ambassador-Designate to Washington.
YOU'RE standing at rigid attention in front of the commanding officer. Khaki uniform all freshly pressed, hat on straight, tie tucked in, shoes sparkling like a pair of jewels.

YOU can depend on the Essandess boys to experiment with something new in the field of publishing. Having decided to publish a study of Bach by their ace popularizer, Mr. van Loon, they issue a companion album of music that will illustrate the text better than words or pictures can do.

In 1933 Robert L. Doughton, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, by authority of a House resolution appointed a subcommittee to study and report upon the income-tax laws with a view to improving and simplifying them. One of the major problems considered by the subcommittee was the treatment of capital gains and losses.

OTTAWA, Jan. 11 -- On Tuesday there will open in Ottawa a conference between the Dominion and the nine Provincial governments of Canada which is expected to result in the most far reaching changes in the financial and economic structure of the country since the Confederation of 1867.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The government and party press of the Soviet Union spoke out sharply today in justification of the new economic deal between Germany and Russia and rebuked British and United States statesmen who may consider it warlike.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Optimistic reports concerning the State's financial position appear to be based more on the prospect of continued good revenues during the fiscal year starting July 1 than on an actual balanced budget during the current fiscal year.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

SINCE bridge bidding habits change very slowly, most local experts during 1940 retained the very strong opening two-bid, and the strong opening one-no-trump bid, which they have used for several years. There were, however, a few groups and a few individual players who abandoned the accepted standards and experimented with new bids.

PROFESSOR MIMS, pupil, friend and colleague of Vanderbilt's great chancellor, has given us a vivid and vigorous account of the South's greatest educational statesman since the Civil War. There were others, to be sure, who, taking their cue from General Lee, looked forward, not back, in the dismal period that followed Appomattox -- Page, Alderman, Curry, to mention only three.

Dissension within the No Foreign War Committee over the policies being pursued by Verne Marshall of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, its chairman, was indicated yesterday in a report, which was not denied, that O.K. Armstrong, one of its organizers and its field director, planned to resign.

Evidence that Queens College, despite its relative youth, has arrived at a considerable degree of academic maturity was presented this week in an announcement by Professor Donald E. Lancefield, chairman of the Biology Department, that several scientific projects of more than ordinary importance are being conducted by faculty members and students in the department.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- There was unconcealed satisfaction in authoritative German quarters today over the signing in Moscow yesterday of a renewal of the first Soviet-German trade agreement until Aug. 1, 1942, as well as over the increased volume of exchange expected under the new treaty.

ROME, Jan. 11 -- Operations in Albania have begun again after a comparative lull of several days and it is expected that big battles will develop shortly, the Stefani correspondent with the Italian Army in Albania writes today. On the other hand, a communique merely says: "Actions of a local character continue to develop in the Eleventh Army sector. Enemy attacks in other sectors were repulsed."

WASHINGTON -- The national capital's great quadrennial ceremony -- the inauguration of the President of the United States -- is now only a week off and the city is beginning to assume a festive air. The elaborate inaugural stand has risen in front of the Capitol and thousands of grandstand seats have mushroomed below it in the broad Capitol Plaza.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Dartmouth captured every first place in defeating Pennsylvania, 59 -- 16, in the opening Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming meet at Weightman Hall pool today.
A new crusade is in order -- this time against the debunkers. I've stood all I can stand and my faith in everything is tottering.

Bruce Windward, crime reporter on The Informer, is promoted to foreign correspondent and sent to the mythical South American republic of Corcovado, where nothing important enough to make the front page has happened in years. With the arrival of Bruce all that is changed.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 -- A large attendance marked tonight the first of a series of dinner dances at Whitehall for which the Jardin Royal was transformed into a setting of silver and rose. An entertainment program was presented.

JULIEN GREEN has been known thus far for a novelist who carried the somber and tragic to the limits of the possible. His strongly mortised, shade-pervaded works had a quality of intensity which placed them in the domain of dark realism, where the perverse gets the upper hand and drives its victims to hopeless despondency or crime.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Princeton defeated Army, 31 to 27, at basketball today. It was the second overtime contest for the cadets this week and their second straight defeat, Harvard having defeated them in an extra-period game on Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Philadelphia's leading racquets players, Warren Ingersoll and E.M. (Ted) Edwards, beat the United States doubles champions today, but the New York squad came out on top by 4 -- 3 in the annual inter-city doubles tournament at the Racquet Club.

Responsible leaders of the steel industry are beginning to show open resentment over the continued flow from Washington of anonymous statements that the industry may not be able to supply all the steel required for national defense or for war.

MORE and more is being heard these days about standards for photographic supplies. About three years ago it was rumored that the government was looking into misstatements of product characteristics in advertising, shutter markings, etc.

Baseball's annual midwinter business of getting the hired help properly signed for the ensuing season opened in double-quick time for the Giants yesterday when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced the receipt of two accepted documents for 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Despite difficulties of international delivery of letters and parcels as a result of the war, Postmaster General Frank G. Walker reported today that postal revenues in the fiscal year ended last June reached an all-time high of $766,948,626, and that a net surplus of $18,609,036 was shown after making adjustment for the cost and lost revenue of the non-postal items.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A poll indicated today that the Administration could count on a majority of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to support its legislation giving President Roosevelt broad powers to send war supplies to nations resisting "aggressors."

AS stage and screen performances go, all our best Nazis seem to be refugees. Take Paul Hernried, for instance. He is the personable young Viennese actor who until recently was almost unknown in this country but has suddenly leaped into prominence for two biting performances in a stage and a screen vehicle, both current on Broadway.
A ten-day conference planned to form a program coordinating Y.W. C.A. work with national defense developments will open on Tuesday at the national headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

THE Washington Heights "Y" Symphony Orchestra, under Maxim Waldo, is a non-commercial musical group. It is the purpose of the organization to prepare youthful players for the country's symphonic orchestras. And it does this without the benefit of a budget.

THE latest work of the veteran story-teller A.S.M. Hutchinson is an earnest, old-fashioned novel whose purpose seems to be the presentation of the life of a twentieth-century saint. I say "seems to be," because although it is obvious that the author has some message in mind, I do not understand what it is.

Thirteen intercoastal steamship lines filed last week with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition to investigate transcontinental rate-making practices, asserting that the railroads, by unreasonably low charges, have attempted to deprive their water-line competitors of traffic, even though seriously depleting their own revenues by the practice.
The importance of moisture and aeration as growth factors in roses was emphasized by scientists from both the North and South at the last national meeting of the American Rose Society.

The records established in 1940 by the construction industry are a foretaste of what may be looked for in those industries directly affected by the defense program. Construction contracts awarded last year were reported by The Engineering News-Record to have reached almost $4,000,000,000, thus exceeding even the previous 1929 record.

THE first volume of Mr. Hockett's projected three-volume Constitutional History was properly called "The Blessings of Liberty." These, half a century after independence, had been substantially secured. Those other objectives so eloquently set forth in the Preamble, too, were in large measure attained: domestic tranquillity, common defense, and general welfare.

The United States liner America, the first American flag ship to be equipped by the United States Navy with a magnetic mine-repelling belt, sailed yesterday on a twelve-day cruise to the West Indies and Havana with 751 passengers.

The increasing demand for outboard motors continued during 1940. In fact, it is reported that the industry built and sold more than twice as many motors as in the big year of 1929. That the industry can look forward to another prosperous year is indicated by the crowds which inspect the various outboard displays at the Motor Boat Show.

Victor is excited about a new twelve-inch disk (75 cents) made by Artie Shaw and his orchestra. Concerto for Clarinet occupies both sides of the record. It stems from the new film, "Second Chorus," and it gives Mr. Shaw a chance to display his virtuosity as a clarinetist.
AUGUSTA, Ga. -- Formal opening of the Bon Air Hotel Wednesday will bring an additional group of Winter visitors to Augusta and the hotel's sports and social program will enliven the resort.

Russia remains the enigma and probable solution of the European War, it was asserted yesterday by William Henry Chamberlin, correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor, at a Foreign Policy Association luncheon discussion on "Europe Turns to the Mediterranean,'' held at the Hotel Astor before 800 persons.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Fordham's basketball team came back from its defeat last night by Syracuse to trounce Colgate tonight, 59 -- 32, in a game in which the New Yorkers were in command throughout. Colgate did not threaten once.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Eddie Alloo of Rollins College at Winter Park, Fla., today scored an upset to reach the final of the seventeenth annual Dixie tennis tournament.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 12 -- Rooftops all over London were set blazing by incendiary bombs last night and the whole city was shaken to its ancient foundations by the hail of steel and dynamite from German raiders carrying out a short, but widespread, raid.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Sheriffs of several counties have mobilized forces to throw the full force of their strength into the State's defense program.

Among the improvements shown in Chrysler engines is a combination flame-arrestor and air intake silencer for carburetors. Other refinements include tool steel exhaust valve inserts which eliminate frequent servicing. THE art of gardens has had integral place in the history of the Japanese people, as in that of the Chinese before them and through the ages back to at least two thousand years ago. And it is so that this art is studied and presented in this beautiful and richly informative book.

Reflecting the expansion of industry and trade generally, and to some extent the beginning of the national program of rearmament, loans and discounts of the leading Wall Street banks, according to the year-end figures now in hand, showed the widest gain in the final three months of 1940 of any quarterly period since that ended June 30, 1937.

RETURNING to its normal gains, retail trade in the week settled around a level of about 5 per cent above a year ago, with indications that this percentage will be improved once the usual post-holiday lull is passed. Some lack of promotional merchandise tends to keep down potential increases, but so far this is not a serious factor.

Details for this year's regatta of the Dad Vail Rowing Association were discussed yesterday by the board of stewards at the Biltmore Hotel. The event has been set for May 17 and will be held in the Middle West for the first time. Marietta College of Ohio will be host.

Figures showing the effects of extension of trading hours in Chicago, Toronto and Montreal are strangely meaningless. They indicate no important upward trend in business. They show only slight and perhaps negligible changes in the relative positions of these Exchanges in the financical life of the continent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Pennsylvania Company (controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad) as principal stockholder, has forwarded to the Interstate Commerce Commission suggested amendments to the receiver's proposed reorganization plan for the Wabash Railway Company, whose proposed purchase by the Wabash Railroad Company was the subject of a recent ICC hearing.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Jan. 11 (UP) -- Former Senator Ernest W. Gibson, chairman of the National Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, expressed unqualified approval today of President Roosevelt's "Lend-lease" Bill for aid to warring democracies as "a necessary step in preserving the peace of the nation."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Navy has awarded a $2,254,342 contract for a floating drydock at Galveston to the Todd Galveston Drydocks, Inc.

DETROIT -- There can be little question that the meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers held at the Book-Cadillac Hotel here last week indirectly will do much to spur efforts for national defense. At this meeting leading engineers from both the automotive and aviation industries had opportunity to discuss, in open session and in private, the problem they must face together.

The swimmers of Textile, Erasmus Hall and Andrew Jackson retained the borough senior high school championships of the P.S. A.L., all three concluding their series without suffering defeat. Textile again captured the Manhattan -Bronx honors, downing Seward Park, 38 to 29, in its final engagement yesterday, while Erasmus came through in the Brooklyn- Richmond tourney, defeating Boys High. 44 to 23.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- An inventor, an educator, a playwright and a politician are in a list of "the ten outstanding young men of 1940" selected by Future, the official publication of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- An undertone of uneasiness was apparent in the early operations on the Chicago Board of Trade today and this culminated in aggressive selling of wheat attributed to houses with Eastern connections which disclosed a lack of support.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Because the entire world is keyed up to the production of munitions and materials for war, pleasure boat utilization is being seriously affected. However, in the memorable words of Abraham Lincoln, "This, too, will pass away," and a greater utility of pleasure boats will result when the inevitable period of readjustment takes place.

When the President at his Friday press conference, after the details of the "garden hose" lease-lend bill for British, Greek and Chinese assistance became known, was asked about cloture of the forthcoming Senate debate, he answered that this was a matter for the Senate to decide. Cloture is the parliamentary means by which debate on a measure is limited to prevent the various forms of filibustering.

IN the course of its program of expansion, Columbia signed the Budapest String Quartet some months ago, which may turn out to be one of its most valuable acquisitions.
