MEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 11 -- Radical changes in the Tufts College curriculum proposed by President Leonard Carmichael soon after his inauguration in 1938 are to be introduced next Fall, Vice President George S. Miller, dean of the arts and science faculties, announced today following a meeting of the curriculum committee and a full faculty, which has just voted its approval.

THIS is the story of a show which cost $130,000 and closed after three performances on Broadway. It was probably the most expensive failure among musical revues in recent years -- the sum it lost would have financed ten more modest legitimate plays.

DURING the last days of the old year, current with the ludicrous adventure of Cantinflas, the comedian, in "Ahi Esta el Detalle," the Colonial Theatre in Mexico City was exhibiting a short known in the States as "London Can Take It."

HAVANA, Jan. 11 -- If theUnited States becomes involved in the war, Cuba would be found at its side in defense of the ideals of liberty, democracy and justice, Premier Carlos Saladrigas said today as spokesman for President Fulgencio Batista in comment on the Roosevelt program set forth at Washington this week.

Countless accessories for the assembling of a window garden are available from all parts of the country in a price range to suit any budget. Much can be said for the window garden, whether in a regulation size or in a bay window, for it not only assures plants of a maximum of light but is a decorative asset for the entire room.

A NEW one-act opera, "Victory Against Heaven," with music by George Kleinsinger and libretto by Winthrop Bushnell, will receive its world premiere Friday night at the Avery Memorial Museum, Hartford, Conn. The work, "an allegorical jazz opera in verse," concerns the effect, of speed and mechanization in "a world where man has permitted the machine to become his master."

Instruction in the prevention and control of occupational diseases in national-defense industries will be emphasized in a course to be conducted during the Spring term, beginning Feb. 3, at the New York University Center for Safety Education, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the center.

THREE Hungarian semi-postal stamps, issued to raise funds to aid the "Pro-Transylvania Movement" sponsored by the wife of Regent Horthy, paid postage on a letter received last week by Dr. Laszlo Telkes, director of the Hungarian Reference Library in New York.

I HAVE been interested in the many indications of concern about the high school and college student as theatre audience. The common note in all communications on the subject is one of disappointment that such a large potential audience has not been determinedly cultivated by play producers and managers.

SOME time in the first half of 1940 an eminent British scholar completed a history which was called in England "The Development of Modern France (1870-1939)." In preparation for American publication the volume was given a title which was to prove considerably more significant -- which was to have, that is, a significance that its author would not have guessed while his work was in progress.

According to reports, the Department of Agriculture has set up four regional centers to experiment on agricultural products with a view to discovering industrial uses for them. Impetus has been given to this activity on the part of government, it is said, by the needs of national defense.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Ted Ellenwood, 21-year-old Amsterdam stock clerk, streaked into the lead for the men's Eastern States speed skating championship today with a victory in the 220 and third place in the half-mile event.

Capping a drive that saw its greatest peak during the past season, the National Outboard Association has obtained signatures to its horsepower rating agreement that will bring 90 per cent of the outboard engines manufactured in the United States during 1941 within the scope of the pact.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., Jan. 11 -- Wendell (Chummy) Broomhall, 21-year-old Finnish star from the Chisholm Ski and Outing Club of Rumford, Me., flashed the form that established him as one of the country's outstanding performers last year by winning the nine-mile cross-country today at the Franconia S.C. meet.

Stephen G. Rich wrote to indicate some of his pet hates in word usage. One of these is "the above." Strange that, on the last page of the same section, in a full-page advertisement, the expression should appear with reference to "the above facts." "The foregoing" now and then is permissible.

Spring merchandise of all types was purchased in good volume in the New York wholesale markets last week, according to a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. "Showrooms were crowded and buyers arrivals were the heaviest in years," the report continues.

John J. Gordon, veteran police reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, was guest of honor last night at a dinner in the Hotel Lincoln, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, given by his colleagues. The affair marked Mr. Gordon's retirement from newspaper work after thirty-four years of covering Police Headquarters at night.

ONE-MAN shows of the week offered as wide a diversity as might well be expected. Watercolors by George Wharton Edwards may be seen during January at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries -- scenes of the New England coast and of Holland, Belgium and Italy.

It may seem incongruous, but the outstanding attraction for many sailing enthusiasts at the Motor Boat Show will be the engines. The marine motor manufacturers have planned extensive exhibits of gasoline and heavy oil propulsion units, most of them improved in great detail, and the owner of an auxiliary sailing craft will be able to form his conclusion as to which is best adapted to his use.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Behind the imposing facade of the national defense program, behind the construction of factories, the building of planes and tanks and the drafting of millions of young soldiers, the government is quietly conducting a program of youth training that may well prove, in the long haul, no less valuable than all the planes and tanks.

The release of a note sent by Secretary Hull on Dec. 27 to Ambassador Henry-Haye of the Vichy Government gives the public an insight into what our refugee policy now is and a diplomatically worded explanation of what some of its difficulties are.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Miss Charlotte Walther, leading competitor of the Skating Club of New York, won the women's senior figure-skating championship at the conclusion of one of the keenest tournaments in the history of the Eastern States event at the Playland rink today.

Increasingly the fields of psychology and religion are being seen as intimately related. Unfortunately it is still true, as Dr. Seabury complains, that "we find the churches and those who represent them lacking knowledge and application of psychology, and the average practicing psychologist antagonistic to man's need for religion."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Japan had no "improper" designs on the Netherlands Indies and the responsible heads of the Japanese Government were doing their untmost to avoid war with the United States, Britain and the Netherlands, Kenkichi Yoshizawa, head of the Japanese mission here, said today in an interview.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Miss Edith Stern, 18, refugee German girl, arriving here after an 18,000mile, forty-six-day journey from Sweden, expressed the hope today that she might continue studies of nursing interrupted by the war.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- There is not a single student on the Bard College campus at present, for all have started their Winter field and reading period, which they are to spend in some kind of useful activity off campus.
ROME, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

LOS ANGELES -- Opened to visitors recently for the first time, the ranch home of the late Will Rogers in Santa Monica Canyon is rapidly becoming one of Southern California's foremost tourist attractions. To date almost 20,000 persons, an average of 100 to 300 on weekdays and 500 to 700 on Sundays, have visited the home of America's beloved humorist.

THE financial burden that is Hollywood's is becoming increasingly heavy. In addition to the 35 per cent drop in European revenues since the war and the fluctuating domestic returns, the industry now is faced with threats of increased taxation in certain South American countries.

WHY should any one want to murder a harmless minor poet who writes of buttercups and daisies and the delights of rural life? John Appleby of Scotland Yard wonders about that and communicates his puzzlement to Mr. Hetherton, an archaeologist whose thoughts seldom stray from his chosen field.

Mr. Rihbany writes his brief summary of the five interpretations of Jesus from the liberal Unitarian point of view, as if they were mutually exclusive. Certainly the last interpretation, which he adopts, would totally fail to account either for the origin of Christianity or for its preservation.

New Yorkers contribute about $85,000,000 to private charity each year. Those who keep track of such things tell of one kindly woman who regularly each Christmas sent a check for $10 to an organization for the care of crippled children which had long since been disbanded.

The Coast Guard Reserve is a voluntary organization of boat owners which closely parallels the unique organization of the Coast Guard, in that it has a well defined scope for both peace and war time activities.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- Robot planes, controlled by radio from another airplane or from the ground, are being tested by the Army Air Corps at Selfridge Field, headquarters of the Sixth Pursuit Wing Squadron.

A TERMINAL should be planned for convenience; it should also be designed to impress. The new Airlines Terminal, on Park Avenue between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, is a modern city gateway of considerable symbolic importance.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 11 -- The 156th Field Artillery returned from the wars this morning in time to clean up equipment for the weekend inspection before leaves started at noon. The return to camp marked the end of a march problem that started in bright moonlight the night before.

In the rural quiet of Hyde Park President Roosevelt rested yesterday from the cares of official Washington. Behind him lay a week in which he had helped to make history, a week in which the United States had turned into new paths that led none knew quite where.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 -- A four-point program of education just adopted by the faculty of Yale College, the academic department of the university, is predicted as certain to exert far-reaching effects upon the undergraduate students.

Winter isn't a particularly propitious time for horse lovers, but they make out. If they don't want to canter through two feet of snow and ice they go indoors. And all through the Winter there are regularly scheduled polo games which, in their way, are as interesting to watch as anything that goes on in the Summer.

In a simple floral setting of white blossoms and ferns a wedding of international importance took place here yesterday afternoon when the Hon. Mildred Noreen Stonor, younger daughter of Lord and Lady Camoys of Stonor Park, Oxfordshire, England, and Newport, R.I., was married to John R. Drexel 3d, son of Mrs. Thompson Drexel of 30 East Sixtieth Street and of the late John R. Drexel Jr., in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

WITH the introduction of Joseph Szigeti, noted Hungarian violinist, last Sunday night in his first American series of concerts exclusively for radio, broadcasting's efforts to raise the standard of music on the air were carried into the new year by WOR.

Out of the growing expansion program in the interest of national defense and preparedness there will emerge a new kind of cruiser for pleasure boat skippers, made possible much sooner than would have been the case had not the lights of Europe been doused by the war.

Telling the 28-year-old fireman that he should be particularly proud to receive a medal from his own comrades of the uniformed force, Mayor La Guardia presented last night to Fireman First Grade Charles A. Merz of Hook and Ladder Company 168, the first of the Vincent J. Kane medals established by the Uniformed Firemens Association of Greater New York.

Establishment of a Bureau of Aviation within the Dock Department, to have full charge of administration and operations at La Guardia Field in Queens and Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.

The fire that caused an estimated damage of $150,000 aboard the steamship Black Heron at Pier 8, Brooklyn, was declared to have been of "accidental origin" yesterday by Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy after a two-hour hearing.

TORONTO, Jan. 11 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs collected 23 scoring points as they swamped the last-place New York Americans, 9 -- 0, in a lop-sided National Hockey League game tonight. Three players counted their first goals of the season.

AL LEWIS and Max Siegel have dropped everything else -- this includes the intimate musical referred to as "Seven Years With the Wrong Woman" -- in order to make an immediate production of a comedy called "Bundles From Britain."

If the sale of charts is any measure, then Great South 13ay is the playground for most local boat owners. Another year has shown this to be true. The Coast and Geodetic Survey receives more requests for charts of that area than for any other within commuting distance.

Twenty-seven additional contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund, amounting to $337.70, were received yesterday, increasing the total of the sum raised through the twenty-ninth annual appeal in THE NEW YORK TIMES to $232,688.80.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 11 -- Controversies regarding relations between Brazil and Britain must not be used as pretexts for attacks on the United States, Dr. Lourival Fontes, Director of the Press and Publicity Department, declared last night at a meeting in his office of Brazilian newspaper publishers, foreign news agency managers and correspondents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Yale tonight snapped its losing streak in hockey with a 3-2 victory over Clarkson Tech in a roughly played game. With both teams in brilliant shooting and skating form, Fred Kieckhefer's goal guarding turned the tide toward Yale.

While America in 1940 was having its busiest year of motor boat racing, Europe was having its worst. Over here we had ninety-two sanctioned outboard regattas and a large number of events for inboards and cruisers. Even Canada had two splendid regattas.

Fifty thousand volunteer workers will begin their activities in the city tomorrow in behalf of the 1941 Fight Infantile Paralysis campaign. The drive, which will start simultaneously throughout the nation, will close on Jan. 30 with the celebration of President Roosevelt's fifty-ninth birthday.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Lanky E.J. (Dutch) Harrison from Arkansas led the Parade, but Ben Hogan, a transplanted Texan, was beating the bass drum today in the third round of the 72-hole, $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 -- The races at Hialeah Park have been attracting crowds of race enthusiasts since the opening day, when more than 15,000 passed through the grilled iron entrance gates. Although not quite so many turned out the next day, due to the inclement weather, those who really enjoy racing were not deterred by the rain and saw an interesting card.

THE national theme song is defense, and in no phase of American life is this more apparent than in radio. Special events depots of the broadcasters have been turned into defense departments. Debates, talks -- even music and drama -- have taken on a national preparedness slant.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- When a belligerent elk, "traveling at the speed of a locomotive," comes charging down upon a peaceful citizen it is no laughing matter, at least not to the residents of Rockland County, who are demanding that something be done about the animals that are ruining crops and orchards as well as menacing life and limb.

AFTER a long career on the masochistic side of the footlights I am backing my first Broadway production this season. Well, I'm not exactly backing "Arsenic and Old Lace." I merely bought a small piece of it. It's a piece of the arsenic, I fancy.

The winner of the annual gold RC2 Merit Medal presented by the Regatta Circuit Riders Club, national group of motor boat officials, will be announced on Tuesday night at the Motor Boat Show. The presentation will be made at the organization's annual meeting and supper party to be held on the third floor of Grand Central Palace.

New York's State Capitol, set high on an Albany hill and spread out over three acres, looks at a distance like a swollen French chateau. Numerous designers had a hand in the massive granite structure that was over thirty years in the building. The result was a potpourri of architectural styles and tastes.

A former superintendent of the C.I.D. at Scotland Yard emerges from his retirement to undertake a difficult mission in Arabia. He is asked to find and capture the man who is posing as a descendant of Hassan, the infamous Old Man of the Mountains, and who has revived the cult or racket instituted by that wily old chieftain.
As a composer-publisher member of ASCAP, I should like to comment upon an open letter received this week by ASCAP authors and composers from the National Association of Broadcasters.

Dalies Frantz, young American pianist who appeared as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last Saturday night, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall which drew an audience that showed both by its size and its enthusiasm that the player has developed a large personal following since his debut eight years ago.

In preparation for the new informative grade labels which will soon appear on canned fruits and vegetables on grocery shelves, three national women's groups are planning ways of getting women generally acquainted with their meaning and usefulness.

A NEW publication that is expected to give increased incentive to the movement to establish uniform motor vehicle inspection standards in all of the States has just come off the press, sponsored jointly by the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators and the National Conservation Bureau.

Some years ago I envisioned power-boat hulls molded in plastics. Of course this is not yet a reality, but we are getting closer. Take, for instance, that "one-piece" dinghy that weighs next to nothing. And there's that seagoing auxiliary sloop with bonded resin plywood planking.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The twelfth annual Atlantic Coast squash racquet championship tournament will be held here next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

TARPON SPRINGS, Fla. -- The Right Rev. Athenagoras, Archbishop for North America of the Greek Orthodox Church, tossed a golden cross into this town's Spring Bayou last Monday. Twenty-four young Greek divers plunged after it.

THERE has been a genuine need for this book, a comprehensive review of the changing historical interpretations of Jesus during the past century of critical attempts to arrive at a satisfactory portrait of the "real" Jesus. Dr. McCown here contributes another volume to the growing International Library of Christian Knowledge.

About 4,500 city residents are expected to enroll in the forty-seventh session of the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division which will begin on Feb. 10, it was announced yesterday by Professor Broderick Cohen, director.

THIS newest novel by Storm Jameson, following so closely as it does upon the heels of "Europe to Let," must have been struck off at white heat. It was begun last Winter, she tells us, and finished just a week before the fall of the Reynaud government and the capitulation of France.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- While defense activity furnishes the primary preoccupation of the Federal Government, the beginning of 1941 finds this program still reflected in actual deliveries so small that they seem infinitesimal compared with the totals compiled from contracts and expectations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 - A crisis in the steel industry by Spring will require an increase in basic steel production of 15 to 20 per cent, according to a memorandum prepared as a result of discussion meetings held here by economists and executives in labor, business and government and by professors of economics and public administration.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. -- This year California's oldest city (San Diego was founded in 1769) is making a strong bid for first place on the visitor's itinerary. And a group of business men, sponsoring what they call "New Resident Service," has its own method of making the newcomer feel at home.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Jan. 11 -- German raiders carried out an intense attack on this famous naval base this morning and last night, dropping many hundreds of incendiary and explosive bombs that killed or injured many civilians, damaged or destroyed six churches, several movie theatres, stores and houses and rendered many persons homeless.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Science is playing an increasingly important role in the every-day life of Choate School undergraduates, according to figures and information made available today by the Department of Science. This year more than 300 undergraduates, or two out of every three boys in school, are taking some course in science.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A charge that both Democrats and Republicans employed devices to "evade and avoid" the $3,000,000 spending limit on political campaigns was made today by Chairman Gillette of the special Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 10 -- Prime Minister Bogdan Philoff left Sofia today for Ruschuk, where he is to deliver a speech explaining his government's foreign and domestic policies tomorrow. It is believed here that Mr. Philoff has chosen to speak at Ruschuk because it has been rumored so persistently and for so long that German troops will pass into Bulgaria through there and he hopes the reports will thus be killed.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill personally took the initiative this week to extend the war production drive. New committees for production, imports and post-war reconstruction were set up to regulate and cooperate the activities within the war plans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A plan to take care of the families of those who go into military service is being worked out for incorporation in the social security program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- With the acquiescence of the government of Trinidad in the United States selections of defense base sites there, Secretary Hull announced tonight that final agreement had been reached with Great Britain on the sites of eight United States naval and air bases in British possessions off the Atlantic Coast.

It is good to have another book by the eminent Sir Frederic Kenyon, formerly director and principal librarian of the British Museum and author of the scholarly work "Our Bible and the Ancient Manuscripts," recently revised and enlarged.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- American fighter planes tonight were reported in action on Great Britain's home front for the first time as new model British long-distance bombers and gun-bristling fighter craft stiffened the British air arm.
Memories of the grandeur of Imperial Russia will be revived on the night of Jan. 25 when the Russian Nobility Association, Inc., will hold its fourth "Soiree de St. Petersbourg" at Hampshire House.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- With national defense orders steadily mounting in the Detroit industrial area, the possibility of a labor shortage, especially in the skilled and semi-skilled manufacturing trades, is being discussed here.

The British War Relief Society tells this department that the bombing of English towns, especially London, is working hardship on sufferers from cancer because of the possible destruction of radium supplies in various hospitals.
ANNAPOLIS. Md., Jan. 11 -- The names of 399 prospective members of the graduating class of the Naval Academy were announced today by Rear Admiral Wilson Brown, superintendent.

New York clothing factories are turning out more than 100,000 Army overcoats and service jackets a week, and are prepared to produce even more if the government will give them the share of work to which they feel they are entitled, a survey disclosed yesterday.

DURING the early months of World War II many veterans of the 1914-18 conflict felt a deep anxiety regarding the quality of the individual soldiers of the Allied Armies. In the great battles to come would they prove themselves physically and morally the equal of their sires who fought on the Marne and the Somme?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Administration leaders in Congress displayed a conciliatory attitude toward the various limitations some members will seek to include in the "lend-lease" bill to convert the United States into the "arsenal of democracy" which President Roosevelt advocated in his annual message to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Prices are going up. Under the impact of British war orders and national defense demands -- and a bit of speculative activity here and there -- the whole level of wholesale prices has increased by about 6 1/2 per cent since the outbreak of the war, and government experts here expect that it may increase by possibly as much more in the next six or eight months.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Puerto Rico will soon don harlequin garb for the Ponce de Leon Carnival, and Winter tourists arriving in the next two months will find picturesque gayety.

The adult education program at New York University will be expanded during the Spring term, it was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn of the division of general education, to include afternoon as well as evening classes. The new term will begin Feb. 3.

A statement has been issued by the Westminster Kennel Club in an endcavor to clarify a number of points regarding its annual exhibition in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12, about which there has been no little misunderstanding.

Priorities are definitely scheduled to be put into effect on a number of steel and metal products soon, purchasing agents reported yesterday, and as a result many of them have stepped up their orders to cover an additional month or two. The buyers realize, of course, that when priorities are instituted their advance coverage will mean very little but they are hopeful of getting a break when an allocation plan starts.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Trailing at 9 -- 11 in the fifth game, William E. Slack and Hunter Lott, the national amateur squash racquets doubles champions from Philadelphia, narrowly averted a stunning defeat at the hands of a pick-up combination today in the Greenwich- Apawamis invitation tournament at the Greenwich Country Club.

Establishment of the National Council on Fair Labor Practices, a non-profit organization designed to create harmony between management and labor through industrial self-regulation, was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, former Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 11 -- The various commanding officers of the Twenty-seventh Division at an official lottery today chose one of the litter of eleven Irish setter pups which Major Gen. William N. Haskell bought several weeks ago as mascots for the eleven units of the organization.

BOSTON, Jan. 11 -- Achieving his first major success over the boards, John Munski, the Missouri graduate student, ran away from his rivals in the Mayor Maurice J. Tobin Mile, featured event of the third annual Veterans of Foreign Wars track meet which launched the 1941 indoor campaign before 5,000 spectators at the local Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Congressional approval of President Roosevelt's plan for "all-out" aid to democracies would give Great Britain and her allies access to some of the world's best shipyards.

Professor Cyrus Hatch, the eminent criminologist, has inherited a country newspaper and has obtained leave of absence from his post at Knickerbocker University in order that he may take charge of his legacy. When he arrives at Pennswick, where the paper is located, he finds that he has also inherited a headache in the form of a whacking libel suit brought against the paper by one of the town's leading citizens.

Secretary, National Outboard Assn. No year in the history of outboard motoring has been more eventful than the one just closed. A modern Rip Van Winkle, after only one year's hibernation, might find greater changes in the outboard scene than those witnessed in any ten years of early outboard history.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Jan. 11 -- The Marine Corps' first parachute jumpers, scheduled eventually to form the nucleus of a battalion of 400 men in the organization's two new mechanized divisions, have entered the second stage of their training here -- making actual parachute descents from a navy blimp at altitudes of more than 2,000 feet.

FLIGHT instruction, long a rough-and-ready game by which a pilot could earn an extra penny, is turning sophisticated and becoming a highbrow branch of the teaching profession. The recent spectacular gains in air safety are attributable largely to this trend, which has been forced upon the business by Uncle Sam himself.

SHIP carving was one of the first expressions of the plastic arts in this country, and represents an important phase, therefore, in the development of American sculpture. It was, moreover, not an "art" by accident: the men who carved the figureheads were no mere carpenters with an extra knack of skill, but "trained craftsmen devoted to creating a thing of form and beauty."
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Duke of Windsor, Governor of the Bahamas, came to town again today, and stopped Miami's mid-Winter air show for forty-five minutes.

THE Metropolitan Opera is making a break with the past this season, for it is introducing two Mozart operas into its annual matinee "Ring" cycle. After presenting the four music dramas of "Der Ring das Niebelungen," instead of completing the cycle with two other Wagnerian works, it is going to give "Don Giovanni" and "Le Nozze di Figaro."

ALL signs point to a banner season of air travel to Central and South America, to lands and islands in and adjacent to the Caribbean Sea. According to traffic managers who follow the airways, people fleeing the cold are crowding planes taking off for Havana, Nassau, Jamaica and Panama.

Sales of advertised merchandise showed gains in New York stores last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Printed dresses were heavily advertised, with fair to good response noted.

ALTHOUGH the girl of the title is foolish, weak, selfish and sometimes detestable, she has most of her author's attention and a lot of her admiration. Well, Judy was young, pretty and her parents had spoiled her.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Expecting Congress to authorize soon what is called "all-out" American aid to Britain -- aid which Winston Churchill said this week would decide the outcome of the war -- specialists in London and Washington are considering how that aid may be rendered effectively in the economic as well as the military sphere.
ROME, Jan. 11 -- In Libya the Italians are heavily engaged in the oasis of Jarabub and in Tobruk, where artillery duels and air battles are taking place, today's communique indicates.

If Winter follows its usual course, plenty of sloppy weather lies ahead. The stores are counting on it, anyhow, and are showing new raincoats and other dirty-weather gear. The stylists have a sound notion about raincoats and such. They take care to turn them out to be just as good looking as anything else in your wardrobe.
THUNDERBOLT, Ga. -- The most primitive Negroes in the United States are those who inhabit the islands in the marshes off the coasts of South Carolina and Georgia.

The way the New Dealers have disregarded the laws of the land and evaded the Constitution to accomplish their purposes is very disheartening to those of us who believe in our form of government and in the rule of law and not of men.

THIS is a surprisingly interesting book about food. The element of surprise is not due, of course, to any initial conception of food as an uninteresting subject, but to the fact that it is presented here from a scientific, not to say didactic, point of view, in a volume in which only nine pages are free from footnotes.

DETROIT -- Occupied with national defense needs for aircraft, munitions and military vehicles, the Society of Automotive Engineers took time last week at its five-day annual meeting here to forward its ever-present aim of bettering the civilian vehicles of motorized America.

B.M. Higginson was the high- over-all scratch gunner at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, breaking 96 out of 100 targets. He also won the scratch and the handicap legs in the shoot at 149 targets with a score of 139 -- 2 -- 141.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 11 -- Midwinter activities in the society colonies of both the North and South Shores center in outdoor sports this month, but fox hunts, drags, skating contests and beagle hunting are all followed by parties given indoors at country homes or clubs.

Once more there is a will that makes trouble for everybody concerned. Three persons are murdered because of it, and almost everybody, including the lawyer who drew the will, is under suspicion. The chief clue is a scrap of gold lame discovered by Attorney Chris Gibson's secretary and not turned over to the police.

FROM a group of child prodigies it is allowable to expect temperament, bad manners, egotism and a few other none-too-pleasant manifestations. However, the Quiz Kids, who are heard every Wednesday night over WJZ's network, did not follow the expected formula during their short visit in New York from Chicago.

THE newsreel business in Europe has become a chancy thing, but now it is probably more important than the production of entertainment films. The first report on the situation was brought to this country by David Rose, Paramount's British managing director, when he arrived here to spend Christmas amid the perils of Hollywood.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Great though Britain's need is for military planes, it would have been far greater but for the foresight of a group of government officials who, six years before the war broke out, carefully drew up a set of plans whereby planes could be built at top-speed in the event of a military conflict.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- National defense needs may force the utilization of the entire automobile industry for the production of airplane engines and parts. Representative Vinson of Georgia said today in announcing that he intended to introduce legislation which would require the curtailment of commercial production in any industry where necessary to produce the needed military supplies.

"WE take you now to Berlin. Come in, Berlin . . . ." Until recently those words were the set patter by which WABC's announcer in New York introduced William L. Shirer, Columbia's correspondent in the German capital.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- After a snowfall last week, and with the temperature experiencing a welcome drop, snows-port enthusiasts are enjoying the return of skiing, tobogganing, dog-sledding and skating at the leading resorts of the Poeono region.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Cornell's sharp-shooting quintet, sparked by Jim Bennett, easily defeated Pennsylvania, 51 -- 24, in the latter's opening Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the Palestra tonight, before 5,500 spectators. It was the Cornellians' second straight league victory.

A center of attraction in a varied line are two new reversing types of outboard motors, the completely restyled and redesigned two-horsepower Sportsman and the 3.3 horsepower Sportwin, being presented by Evinrude at the Motor Boat Show. The line exhibited covers the nine basic types ranging from 1/2 to 33.4 horsepower, six Evinrude-built Elto outboards and an array of optional types.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Major trends in the financing of America's great endowed educational and research institutions -- including rise in student fee income and a drastic general cut due to reduction in rate of return on endowment -- are revealed in the annual report today of Harvey C. Daines, controller of the University of Chicago.

FOR the first time in thirty-three years the friends of A. Edward Newton received no greeting from him this Christmas. With the passing of America's best-known book collector last Fall, the series of essays, which since the panic of 1907 had grown to be a familiar part of the American scene, has come to an end.

The first phase of January dry goods activity began last week with more than the usual early volume and with indications that successive phases will produce increased business over last year and a new crop of problems. The chief concern of selling agents was that the framework of price controls designed to prevent sharp advances in a period of improving sales would be subjected to strain before the end of the month.

What kind of antiques do persons with taste and a real sense of the past choose when it comes to furnishing a colonial house? One way of finding an answer to a question of this kind is to visit an auction gallery on one of those rare occasions when a lifetime's accumulation of important antiques is on view.

The girl is playing roulette in a Nevada gambling house, and she is winning. That is why she laughs. Peter Storm, observing her, cannot make up his mind whether she is beautiful or not. but he likes the way she laughs. Suddenly the girl catches sight of Peter and immediately gathers up her winnings and leaves the place.
Losing their tempers, showing off, or pretending not to care and saying there's no use trying -- these are familiar defenses among children who cannot learn to read.

COLLECTORS of war-censored envelopes -- or "covers," as they are known -- will be interested to learn the rules and regulations governing foreign mail issued in Nazi-occupied territory. An authoritative list of these, stricter than ever before, was recently issued by the Foreign Mail Inspection Office at Berlin.

AID: The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, founded last Spring by William Allen White, has a half-million members in 760 chapters. The organization has been credited with helping to arouse public opinion in favor of the destroyer-for- bases deal with Britain.

Another wildlife mystery has turned up to disturb the sleep of Bob Thompson, whose tales of the North Carolina "mountings" dwarf some of the tallest pines in that State. According to Bob, a Greene County hunter killed a full-grown cow moose while deer hunting, and no one can find any good reason why a moose should exist in any part of North Carolina.

BRUNO WALTER arrived here last week to take over two assignments, one familiar in this city and the other unfamiliar, for this time, besides conducting the Philharmonic - Symphony, he will also conduct at the Metropolitan Opera.

My husband was recalled the day before Italy came into the war, thereby necessitating a trip through Turkey, Syria, Palestine, Egypt, down the Red Sea to Colombo, up to Bombay, down again to Cape Town, and so home. Three hellish but extremely interesting months.

ANONYMOUS: President Roosevelt said last week he had found a man with a "passion for anonymity." The find was Sherman Minton, former Senator from Indiana, former Administration aide in the upper house. The President made him one of his administrative assistants, a job that pays $10,000 a year.

SOMEWHERE IN GREECE, Jan. 11 -- The peculiarity of hearing the German language spoken by Royal Air Force engineers unloading parts of bombers in an evergreen forest is something this correspondent, at least, had not foreseen as a development of a war whose ramifications already appear more than moderately complicated.

The international situation has some boat builders guessing and playing a "wait and see" game. The Wheeler Shipyard in Brooklyn, for instance, is working largely on filling orders for the national defense program.

OUTSTANDING among American phenomena is Mickey Rooney. That fact was emphasized recently when he was selected as the No. 1 box-office attraction of 1940, an honor also bestowed on him in 1939. Theatre operators reported that the 54,000,000 weekly moviegoers prefer him to all the rest of the screen dazzlers.

Price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange in yesterday's short session were narrow and the general trend was irregular. After opening unchanged to 2 points better than Friday and advancing as much as 2 points more, an easier tendency developed in the market, and final quotations were unchanged to 4 points down.

SAROYAN was fresh and new and strange, and his strangeness seemed most remarkable. Reading his stories, it was the strangeness that made the fog. Now that the strangeness is wearing off, other values appear.

THE valiant, fantastic story of the Mormons has been told again and again in history and biography. Only lately has it begun to seep into fiction. Last year Vardis Fisher's "Children of God" rehearsed the whole incredible drama and this year Maurine Whipple, a new writer, has carried the story farther.

THE Dukhobors were -- and are -- a Russian religious sect of non-resistants and general nonconformists whose beginnings go back to the seventeenth century but who are best known from the time of their migration to Canada in 1899.

NO doubt most of us are agreed that, as the saying goes, we wouldn't like to see the American farmer "reduced to the level of a European peasant." Without quoting this admirable sentiment Mr. Wilson does observe toward the end of his present volume that "about half of all our farms were in 1929 and are today below the earning power of peasant farms in Europe."

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Dr. C.W. Potapenko said today he had developed a generator which could produce electric pulses of extremely short duration -- down to nearly one-millionth of a second.

In the January issue of School Life, the official journal of the United States Office of Education, Dr. John W. Studebaker, the Federal Commissioner, makes the statement that it is possible to be resolved to defend democracy and yet be subject to sincere doubts and misgivings as to how that can best be done.

Bruno, a 185-pound St. Bernard dog that had been the mascot of the Coast Guard personnel at Floyd Bennett Field for a year and a half, received a military funeral yesterday attended by the eighty officers and enlisted men of the base. As taps sounded over the loudspeaker system, he was buried on the wind- swept shore of Jamaica Bay.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va. -- The post-holiday period in this historic section of tidewater Virginia finds many Northern visitors augmenting the numbers of Army and Navy folk brought hero by the increasing tempo of defense operations.

Closer cultural relationships between the Latin-American countries and the United States are necessary if our business men are to continue to hold front rank in trade with South America, Dr. Merle E. Frampton, Professor of Education at Teachers College and principal of the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, declared yesterday.

ONLY a rush of theatre events has delayed until today a proper salute in this space to "Meet the People." When it opened on Christmas night this playgoer was doing penance before "Pal Joey." But Mr. Nichols, who occupies the adjoining desk, picked "Meet the People," returned to the office in a glow and praised Hollywood from whom this blessing flows in the next morning's paper.

The largest educational group ever to visit the United States from South America will arrive here tomorrow on the Grace liner Santa Lucia. There are eighty-one professors and students from Chile, Peru, Ecuador and Colombia in the group, which will land from the liner early in the morning and go to City Hall, where they are to be welcomed by Mayor La Guardia.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 -- An organization as closely in touch with the pulse of the people in all sections of the nation as is the United States Power Squadrons should, under present conditions, face many and varied problems during the new year. Entering 1941 with 69 squadrons and approximately 7,000 members, it is very possible, under the present rate of growth, that the century mark in squadrons will be reached during the year.

THE current exhibition of water-colors, drawings and small oils by Ann Brockmann, at Kleemann's, is perhaps the best rounded show this versatile and steadily growing artist has yet held. Certainly the level of accomplishment is above that of any of her previous exhibitions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 11 -- While British artillery poured a steady fire into the defenses of the Italians besieged at Tobruk, Libya, Royal Air Force planes continued to protect the British reinforcing operations by constant patrol in the Tobruk-Derna area and by frequent bombing of all near-by Italian airdromes.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 11 -- Characterizing President Roosevelt's "lend and lease program" of aid to Great Britain as a "slick scheme" to fool the American taxpayers, Alfred M. Landon tonight renewed his suggestion of payment of subsidies to Great Britain.

Gardeners and flower lovers who have enjoyed the many services extended by the New York Botanical Garden to the public will be glad to learn that the Garden's extensive library is now open for reference on Sunday afternoons. . Many books on horticulture not available at ordinary sources may be found there.

STRIKES in defense industries have excited the public mind and many suggestions are being made to cope with labor disputes. They run from postponement of strike action for a cooling-off period to a strict ban against strikes in the defense industries, with compulsory arbitration.

William Hasslinger celebrated his twenty-first birthday by pasting Navy on the basketball court last night. Columbia's 6-foot-3-inch center ran riot against the midshipmen in the Morningside Heights gymnasium and when he was through the count was 54 to 35, with the Lions on the long side.

With the defense program and its effects upon retailing giving it the greatest importance since NRA days, the thirtieth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will open at the Hotel Pennsylvania tomorrow. Close to 5,000 merchants from all sections of the country are expected to attend the five-day gathering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- War Department plans for extensive defense preparations against poison gas attacks were disclosed today with an announcement that contracts for gas mask charcoal and other chemicals used in gas defensive appliances amount to about $10,000,000.
DALMATIANS The sine qua non of any self-respecting New York fire company, toward the end of the last century, was a fifty-pound, white-coated, black-spotted or liver-spotted Dalmatian dog.

FREDERICK NIVEN'S fine story of the settlement of the Red River colony in the second decade of the last century is more than fictional. It is a monument to a great man and a vivid re-enactment of a vital section of Canada's history.

On a yacht, as anywhere else, carelessness and neglect wait in the shadows to spoil a day's fun. Every precaution should be taken to prevent these arch villains from getting the upper hand. But when they do, elementary first aid immediately should come upon the scene.

Reports from Berlin say that the Nazis see in President Roosevelt's bill for further powers to deal with the international situation a possible direct violation of the Hague Convention of 1907. The point made relates to provisions which would permit the repair in American ports of warships of certain combatants.

AS Franklin Delano Roosevelt takes the oath of office as President of the United States for the third time Jan. 20 in Washington his words will be broadcast to a world-wide audience. The ceremonies, in addition to being picked up by the coast-to-coast facilities of the National, Columbia and Mutual broadcasting systems, also will be flashed overseas by powerful short-wave stations.

The canteen trailers used by the Women's Voluntary Service in the bombed areas of England are the product of the ingenuity of an American woman and of the enterprise of an Englishwoman who manufactures them.

HERE is a new book on Brazil of surprising interest and excellence. The surprise with which the reader may find himself genuinely absorbed from the first page, and richly informed when the book is finished, is due to the volume's lack of physical attractiveness.

BOMBING planes "growl across the night skies over Valencia. The city huddles in hushed darkness. A finger of light sweeps aloft. A flame leaps up with a roar of bursting bombs. Guns bark reply, and the earth shakes.

ROME, Jan. 11 -- The Italian Government considered it necessary this week to reaffirm its fidelity to the Axis and its determination to fight on "until victory." Under the circumstances that was an answer and a challenge.

A NEW Kodak print lacquer, designed to protect the surface of contact prints and enlargements from marks, dust, abrasion and atmospheric discoloration, and to allow thorough cleaning without injury to the print, is announced by Eastman.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan 12 -- Bombers of the British Royal Air Force over Friday night, with bad weather limiting their offensive, concentrated their attacks again on the naval base of Brest, used by the Nazis, and on the invasion port of Havre.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Owners of boats powered by gasoline motors will collect between $175,000 and $180,000 in New York State motor fuel tax refunds for the calendar year 1940, it is estimated by Louis H. Fuess, director of the Commodities Tax Bureau of the State Department of Taxation and Finance, on the basis of figures compiled for the first eleven months of the year.

Before 2,000 wildly enthusiastic fans who packed the Brooklyn College gymnasium far beyond its normal capacity, the Brooklyn College basketball team defeated St. John's University last night, 40 to 38.

NO recent literary import from America has received a warmer welcome here than Dr. Hans Zinsser's autobiography. The Times Literary Supplement, it is true, regrets his "dual personality" method of presentation, which, it thinks, has an unhappy effect.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (UP) -- All major Soviet newspapers covered their front pages today with news stories, editorials and photographs about the new trade agreement with Germany, and Pravda proclaimed "new conquests of Soviet foreign policy" achieved "despite efforts of the Soviet Union's enemies to drive a wedge between the U.S.S.R. and Germany."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 11 -- The fact that Germany is maintaining charges d'affaires in all Central American capitals, with a Minister resident in Guatemala accredited to other countries, when there is no trade of any kind with Germany and diplomatic relations are purely formal, has aroused the interest of official circles here.

Every Summer thousands of New York yachtsmen take aboard an extra load of charts, canned goods, friends and relatives, fill up the tank with gas and head away from their home mooring toward more or less distant harbors.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 11 -- Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, rang out the old year with advice to farmers to raise more hogs in 1941. The advice was so unexpected, so unusual, so contrary to what the farmer has been hearing from Washington during the past eight years that it created what amounted to a kind of agricultural sensation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Edward Weinfeld, New York Commissioner of Housing, has been appointed chairman of a special committee under the National Defense Advisory Commission to draft model legislation for State and local governments to help maintain fair rents in areas where the defense program may create housing difficulties.

BAYOU LAFOURCHE, La. -- Visitors to the Gulf Coast seeking a complete picture of the romance, glamour and unique charm of Louisiana will be rewarded by an explorative tour of that section known on old maps as the "Lafourche Interior."

The second and last session of the auction sale of English and American antique furniture and Queen Anne and Georgian silver, property of Julian Armstrong of Chicago, Philip S. Dean of New York, and others, realized $23,867 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Britain remains officially unperturbed by the new Russo-German trade agreement, believing that the treaty's effectiveness will be limited by transportation difficulties in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The invention of two Navy men may speed one detail in the production of warships, it is indicated in a patent (No. 2,227,476) issued here to Milo R. Williams and Allan L. Dunning of the Bureau of Navigation here.
KRAJNSKA GORA, Yugoslav-German Frontier, Jan. 11 -- The latest German Army contingents to enter Italy are "bound for Athens," according to information secured at the Yugoslav-German frontier today.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- With national athletic organizations stressing the importance of physical training in the development of a sturdy, well-disciplined youth, Cornell University this week launched an effort to provide new facilities for students participating in intercollegiate competition as well as for those engaging in informal sports.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 11 -- Australia already is committed to a war expenditure of more than 200,000,000 in the year ending next June 30. This compares with 270,000,000 spent in the whole of the last war. The new program has propelled Australia into an industrial revolution.

FOR lovers of the black-and-white two of the newly opened shows afford highly diverse entertainment. First of all, the selection of one hundred prints, supplemented by thirty miniature prints, from the annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, is on view (through Jan. 25) at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries.

Here are six admirably lucid and comprehensive lectures on the shift that has taken place between the thinking of Christian leaders of fifty years ago (the "yesterday" of the author's point of view) and that of many leading minds today.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Because there has been some misunderstanding regarding deferred classifications, Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Director of the Selective Service, reminded registrants today that deferments are temporary, some being for a definite time, others for a limited time, but all being subject to revision at all times.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- The Chicago Tribune will say tomorrow morning in a front page editorial captioned "A Bill to Destroy the Republic":
From powerful short-wave broadcasting stations in the United States last week went out words like these:

THE annual joint exhibition by members of the American Water Color Society and the New York Water Color Club will be held at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, from Feb. 7 to 23. A private view and reception will be held on Thursday evening, Feb. 6.

ELMER RICE did not look the rebel, the militant perfectionist, the man burdened with the world's troubles that he is as he sat behind the broad desk in the office of the Playwrights Company the other day. A pale blue fog washed against the windows as if the room had got detached from its building and were floating in space.

More than 100 officials of Camp Fire Girls from all parts of the country will open their biennial conference here today, the program closing with a dinner next Friday at the Hotel Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday.

REVIEWERS have consistently taken it for granted that Josephine Lawrence is a "popular" novelist. Actually, Miss Lawrence said, her books are not particularly popular. "They have a pretty good rental library sale, and I'm told that sometimes some one comes along who likes one and reads back through the list."

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, world three-cushion billiard champion who is in St. Luke's Hospital suffering from pneumonia, rallied strongly this afternoon. An attending physician reported his temperature had dropped from 104 to 100 degrees.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Mioland once again proved today that he will be a powerful contender in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on March 1, but he has yet to meet the champion, Challedon.

A TWO-CLASS trolley car takes the tourist from Guadalajara to San Pedro Tlaquepaque for ten centavos (2 cents American) and at the same time moves time back three centuries. For Tlaquepaque is the acknowledged Indian pottery center of Mexico: here the natives still paint earthenware with doghair brushes and in the same designs as their Tonaltec ancestors.

Members of the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design are now making plans for their annual costume dance and entertainment, which this year will replace the famous Beaux-Arts Ball, long an institution among the more colorful parties given here under the patronage of social and artistic circles.
Possible aid in American defense preparations is rapidly becoming one of the most important phases of recreational boating.

Executives of the Camp Fire Girls from many sections of the country will open this afternoon their biennial conference, which will be held at the Hotel Barbizon Plaza under direction of Lester F. Scott, national executive. The sessions will close on Friday with a dinner in honor of one of their number who has completed twenty-five years of service.

With the occupants of the lower half of the seeded list of eight players coming through without being extended, the thirteenth annual Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament was off to a fine start on the courts of the Yale Club yesterday.

Representatives of nearly 100 American colleges and universities will attend the third annual Conference on the Training of Recreation Leaders at New York University beginning Thursday, it was announced yesterday at the School of Education.

Arnold Lunn, author of books on history, philosophy and religion and a member of the faculty of the University of Notre Dame, will speak at a luncheon Tuesday at the Hotel Pierre for the benefit of the American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc., 843 Madison Avenue.

ROME, Jan. 11 -- What is believed here to be the end of the British Navy's more or less free passage between Sicily and North Africa was signalized yesterday when combined Italian and German squadrons of Picchiatelli and Stuka dive-bombers attacked a great enemy convoy.

The cultural and educational enterprises provided youth throughout the country by Junior Programs, Inc., will be furthered by a card party and tea to be given Jan. 20 in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the National Sponsoring Committee of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- While the Administration moved on many fronts this week in its campaign for all aid to the democracies, it kept its eyes on the tramp steamers of Great Britain, the busy little cargo vessels upon which now may rest the destiny of a nation.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Minister of Economic Warfare Hugh Dalton revealed to an audience tonight that "only in the last few days the navy has picked up a number of would-be blockade runners."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Dr. Ernest M. Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College and adviser to the government in the last war, has been appointed executive officer of a new Minerals and Metals Priority Section of the Division of Priorities in the Office of Production Management.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 11 -- Two new courses in the pre-engineering department, and one in the division of education are being added to the evening session curriculum at Hofstra College for the February-June semester, it has been announced by the curriculum committee.

A race committee chairman could get up a pretty fair regatta out of the small sailing craft on display in Grand Central Palace. As a matter of fact, some of the boats probably will be drifting around the Larchmont line next July, their skippers, if new, a bit bewildered about starting signals, courses and the committee's repeated exhortations: "Comet 2,895, please stay out of the restricted area."

For the boating esthusiasts who desire a twin cabin design below deck with an enclosed bridge and large aft cockpit, Matthews is showing its 38-foot standard sedan at the Grand Central Palace. This is a combination of last year's standard sedan and the twin cabin type.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- The Beach colony's interest in the movement to aid Great Britain will attain a local social climax at the Britannia Ball to be held Saturday night, Feb. 1, at the Surf Club.

Sentiment in the United States is in favor of the Irish Government turning over naval bases for the use of the British, a national survey conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion has revealed. Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, announced this fact last week.

Fifth Avenue will get two new examples of sculpture Tuesday afternoon when larger-than-life-size statues of Alexander Hamilton and DeWitt Clinton are unveiled in exterior niches in the wings of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets.

Alexander McKeon, deputy surveyor of customs in the Port of New York for many years and one of the men in the service best known to thousands of transatlantic travelers, was the guest of his associates and friends at a dinner given last week on the occasion of his retirement.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 11 -- With many members of Bermuda's American colony already in their homes for the Winter season and more planning to arrive shortly, social life in the islands is at its gayest. The usual round of dinners, cocktail parties and tennis teas, the latter an old Bermudian festive tradition, are now under way.

For his penultimate appearance of the season as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall Dimitri Mitropoulos arranged a program containing two works he had not directed here previously. These were the overture to Mozart's "The Magic Flute" and the late Albert Roussel's Third symphony.

IN times of stress, scientists of a hysterical frame of mind have scurried in two opposite, but equally futile, directions. Some have climbed higher and higher into their ivory towers and have turned to trivial issues as remote as possible from distasteful practice.

Apropos of the seventy-fifth birthday of Jean Sibelius, Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra devoted the entire program of their concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall to his music. The program was exceptional, even in these days of universal recognition of Sibelius and the nation-wide anniversary performances of his composition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A "friendly agreement" between the Iranian Government and the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions is announced by the State Department for termination of the board's educational work in Iran, but for its continuation by the Iranian Ministry of Education.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 11 -- Because existing conditions have rendered impossible, except as history, the Study of European governments, the Department of Politics of Princeton University is adopting a new approach to instruction in continental political systems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Danubian basin, chief granary of Europe and one of the focal military and political areas of the European war, will not be able this Winter to supply the Axis powers with the large quantities of food, feed and fibers formerly imported by the blockaded countries of the Continent, according to the Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations.

ATHENS, Jan. 11 -- Not a moment's respite did Italian troops get today in their northward and northwesterly flight from Klisura and the adjoining districts. The Greeks were on their heels and by a series of lightning advances they had achieved points along the uplands also and thus were able to harass the fleeing columns on either flank.

State directors of the General Federation of Women's Clubs will confer this week on ways in which clubwomen can work most effectively for the national welfare, and will hear suggestions from a number of speakers invited to address their midwinter board meeting in Washington.

A BROAD-BACKED Scotsman, George Chyne, was the friend and physician of the unlearned printer. Samuel Richardson, whose "Pamela'' is one of the progenitors of the English novel. From 1730 to 1740 this rotund contemporary of the Deists, who lived many years at Bath, as a kind of Father Confessor to Selina, Countess of Huntingdon, carried on a correspondence with that ardent Methodist lady of "no small mental powers" when she was busily "childing."

SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Battling blustery winds all the way, Jack Burke of Houston, Texas, and Eddie Williams of Chicago fired three-over-par 75s today to tie for the halfway lead in the National Professional Golfers Association senior championship.

EACH conflict or major disturbance in the world during the past decade has brought forward some unusual short-wave station or group of stations. When the incident was over the station sank into the background, leaving its mark in the history of broadcasting.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Clarence E. Martin, former president of the American Bar Association, was appointed United States Senator today by West Virginia's retiring Governor, threatening complications when the incoming administration announces its choice.

The British First Aid Nursing Yeomanry, has authorized the British American Ambulance Corps to act as its representative in the United States in a $25,000 fund drive for repairs and maintenance of its equipment. The nurses' headquarters in London was bombed recently and the organization was forced to find a new home.

IT is just a hundred years since the women of America first launched an organized move for suffrage and women's rights in general. When that movement was begun, in 1840, women had few legal rights. They could not vote. They could not hold public office. They had no legal control over their children, and if they worked they had no voice in their working conditions or wages.

The Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies called on Congress yesterday to act promptly in passing the bill to give President Roosevelt unlimited power to lend war equipment to England and her allies against aggressor nations.

Franklin Simon Co. will open a new store in Shaker Heights, a suburb of Cleveland, on or about May 1, it was announced yesterday by J. Howard Denny, president. The store, which will be located at the corner of South Moreland and Shaker Boulevards, will have a frontage of 172 feet and a total floor space of 17,400 feet.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10 -- Increasing aid given by the United States to Great Britain has caused the Germans to resume and intensify their activities in Mexico. Between July and the middle of November of last year there was a lull -- probably more apparent than real -- owing apparently to exposures in the American press which obliged Nazi agents to operate more cautiously for a time.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the hockey game between the New York Rangers and the Detroit Red Wings on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 11 -- Williams College this year plans to graduate fifty-eight men with honors degrees gained through independent study, an increase of twenty over last year and the highest number eligible since the honors work plan was instituted three years ago.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The London Trades Council went on record today protesting against the "scandal" in the muddled meat supplies of Britain. They were concerned specifically with price reduction and equal distribution through the removal from power of those linked with combines and the food trust.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Bruins extended their streak to seven straight games without defeat by beating the Canadiens tonight, 2 to 1, with a third-period drive. They went into third place alone in the National Hockey League standing, breaking a tie with the idle Black Hawks.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Democratic General Assembly, in an all-night session, refused to certify Forrest Donnell, a Republican, as Governor-elect and adopted a resolution calling for a joint House-Senate investigation of the November election.

With the introduction of the rolling mill seventy-five years ago white flour displaced whole-wheat. White flour keeps better, and its color is reflected in bread that pleases the eye. When it was discovered that such deficiency diseases as pellagra, beri-beri and scurvy are caused by the absence of vitamins in food, the nutrition experts properly began to rail at white flour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Defense leaders said tonight that they would confer with Governors of most of the States immediately after inauguration day in an effort to speed highway and utility construction needed to put new arms plants, Army cantonments and naval stations into full operation.
Brooklyn College's natators out-splashed the boys from Swarthmore in the Kingsmen's pool yesterday, 52 to 22, and in so doing tied one pool and collegiate record and established one pool record.

One of the few commodities for which the British Empire virtually depends completely on foreign sources of supply is mercury, more commonly known as quicksilver. An attempt has been made by Canada to develop the ores in British Columbia, but up to the present time no appreciable amount has been produced.

CAROLA OMAN tells the story of a great man and a great English king with imagination, accuracy and grace of style, and there is a fine sincerity in her writing which makes a far-away past real and appealing. For the most part we see Alfred and the events of his life through the eyes of Denewulf, a faithful follower of the king from the time they were both boys.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -- The inaugural parade this year will be smaller than usual, but will put emphasis on the defense theme.

A CASE for the fullest possible development of the commercial airline passenger and cargo systems as links in the chain of our national defense was presented last week by Grover Loening, one of America's pioneer aircraft engineers and builders.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 -- A national defense production partnership between some of the major automobile and airplane manufacturing plants took form today.

IF the Winter Motor Boat Show comes, to paraphrase freely, Spring can't be so far behind. The show is here, in Grand Central Palace, thronged as always with potential buyers and the merely wistful. Yacht-minded people being what they are, it is a certainty that when warm days arrive the legions of American pleasure-boat owners will be fitting out to cruise the coasts, bays and fresh-water courses in full strength, regardless of international developments.

SHIRLEY TEMPLE, for six years a box-office queen before being deposed in 1940 when she appeared below twenty-sixth place in The Motion Picture Herald's poll, will resume her career next month at Metro. While her salary at MGM will be reduced to less than half her earnings during her golden year, 1938, she still can not be ranked among the underprivileged one-third of a nation.

Twenty-two Brooklyn schoolboy football stars were guests of honor at a luncheon yesterday in the executive dining room of Abraham Straus, where Walter N. Rothschild, president of the organization, presented gold footballs to the lads.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 11 -- That a strong undercurrent of discontent is prevailing with the population of Syria and Lebanon is indicated in messages reaching here from Beirut, administrative capital of the French mandated territory.
Deep-sea yachtsmen of Britain, to their undying fame, helped make possible the miracle of Dunkerque. That fact is written in boldface type in the saga of those heroic days.

A CASE for the fullest possible development of the commercial airline passenger and cargo systems as links in the chain of our national defense was presented last week by Grover Loening, one of America's pioneer aircraft engineers and builders.

WHEN Hitler invaded Poland the inevitable question that arose in the United States was "Can we stay out?" Elsewhere in the world it was phrased "Will they stay out?" Now, as Congress begins consideration of the steps suggested by the President for full aid to Great Britain in the second year of the war, the variant of the question has come to be asked in this country.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 11 -- A British commercial mission headed by Sir Henry Chilton arrived tonight from Chile and was greeted by Foreign Minister General Alberto 0stria Gutierrez, President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo's personal secretary, other Cabinet members, the staff of the British Legation, British residents and a huge crowd of Bolivian sympathizers with Britain.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- On the eve of his forty-eighth birthday Reich Marshal Hermann Goering today received 568 miners and fifty-seven workers of the Hermann Goering Works in the Haus der Flieger [Fliers Club] here to give them medals for war production services.

The need of a long-term program of vocational training for national defense was emphasized yesterday at the Commodore Hotel by Layton S. Hawkins, chief of the Trade and Industrial Educational Service of the United States Office of Education.

A visitor to the Y.M.C.A. building on Governors Island will find, during a long day, from 1,400 to 1,800 men enjoying a varied program of recreation. Many of these activities are made possible through the interest of a group of fifty New York clubwomen.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- President Roosevelt started his week-end vacation in a happy mood, confident that Congress would act favorably on the "blank check" bill introduced yesterday to give him the broadest sort of powers in carrying out his plans for his aid to the democracies.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 -- A national defense production partnership between some of the major automobile and airplane manufacturing plants took form today.

IF the Winter Motor Boat Show comes, to paraphrase freely, Spring can't be so far behind. The show is here, in Grand Central Palace, thronged as always with potential buyers and the merely wistful. Yacht-minded people being what they are, it is a certainty that when warm days arrive the legions of American pleasure-boat owners will be fitting out to cruise the coasts, bays and fresh-water courses in full strength, regardless of international developments.

SHIRLEY TEMPLE, for six years a box-office queen before being deposed in 1940 when she appeared below twenty-sixth place in The Motion Picture Herald's poll, will resume her career next month at Metro. While her salary at MGM will be reduced to less than half her earnings during her golden year, 1938, she still can not be ranked among the underprivileged one-third of a nation.

Twenty-two Brooklyn schoolboy football stars were guests of honor at a luncheon yesterday in the executive dining room of Abraham Straus, where Walter N. Rothschild, president of the organization, presented gold footballs to the lads.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 11 -- That a strong undercurrent of discontent is prevailing with the population of Syria and Lebanon is indicated in messages reaching here from Beirut, administrative capital of the French mandated territory.
Deep-sea yachtsmen of Britain, to their undying fame, helped make possible the miracle of Dunkerque. That fact is written in boldface type in the saga of those heroic days.

WHAT are the forces which make democracy in America work? It is easy to describe the so-called "machinery" of government; the Constitution, the statutes, the hierarchy of offices, the uneasy balance among legislative, judicial and executive branches.

THE definitive life of William Henry Welch, one of the greatest figures in American medicine, is announced for publication this year by Viking Press. The authors are Simon Flexner and James Thomas Flexner.

For the first time since its consolidation more than forty years ago, the New York City school system, although still the largest in the world, has started to contract at an unexpectedly rapid rate. As a result, virtually no opening now remains for prospective teachers here.
Those fragrant, delicious cakes which make you forget calories and toss prudence over your shoulder may be either of two types -- with butter (or other shortening), or without.

Tchaiskovsky: Symphony No. 6 in B minor (Pathetique). Leopold Stokowski conducting the All-American Youth Orchestra. (Columbia, six twelve-inch records, $6.50.) If you wish to sample the Stokowski magic with an orchestra, try this recording.

Having dropped in for a look at how American democracy works, the Man from Mars first of all wanted to know what makes a Democrat with a capital D. He said some people thought Mr. La Guardia might resign as Mayor of New York to help out on President Roosevelt's defense program.

Most of the wholesale markets here got off to an active start on the Spring season last week. Many buyers representing stores throughout the country were here and peak arrivals of visiting merchants are scheduled for this week. While buying budgets were estimated as averaging about 7 per cent larger than a year ago, some unevenness was evident in the volume of commitments in the various lines.

A strike that would have halted production of $7,500,000 worth of Army and Navy airplane motors at the Ranger Engineering Corporation plant in East Farmingdale, L.I., was averted yesterday when Federal mediators effected a settlement of the dispute between the company and Local 661 of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O.

Displaying speed and aggressiveness unmatched since its encounter with Rice, the Long Island University basketball team defeated Albright College, 75 to 31, last night before a capacity crowd of 1,000 at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy. It was the Blackbirds' eleventh triumph in twelve starts.

BALTIMORE -- Many years ago, when women were causing consternation in business circles by an occasional invasion of the halls of finance, Miss Lulu M. Dryden surpassed general daring and moved into the masculine field of iron and steel.

BEAR MOUNTAIN PARK -- Today has been officially set aside as "Dubs' Day" at this great metropolitan Winter playground, and, weather permitting, thousands of novices as well as veterans are expected to participate in an exciting program of snow sports of every variety.

The annual Colonial Ball, which will be given jointly under the auspices of the Junior Group of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and the Continental Color Guard of the Sons of the American Revolution, will be held Feb. 15, in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
A serious bottleneck in shipping is definitely threatening the United States defense program and the efforts of Washington to mold our own defense resources into an "arsenal" for Great Britain.
