EVERY human being (more so, of course, in the case of those who have entered public life either in the arts or. say, politics) has two sets of memoirs to write, although not all of them take the trouble to set them down in black and white.

With Russia suddenly emerging as a large buyer of United States products, the foreign trade policy of the Soviet Union has become of increasing importance to this country, particularly when taken in conjunction with military developments. At present the trade policy of Russia is largely a mystery and probably not known officially outside that Kremlin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- General Robert E. Wood, national chairman of the America First Committee, appealed tonight to "Americans who still value their liberty" to flood Washington with protests against President Roosevelt's aid to Britain bill.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- A program listing many outstanding speakers has been announced for this season by the Palm Beach Round Table of the Students International Union. The young folk interested in world affairs hold bi-monthly meetings, usually at the homes of members and other gatherings at Bywater Lodge, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 11 -- Over the Balkans hangs a pall of smoke -- not yet the smoke of battle but the artificially generated smoke screen of Nazi propaganda pressing southward and eastward until it encounters the impenetrable curtain of censorship that masks the frontiers of Soviet Russia.
THIS ATOM IN THE AUDIENCE. A digest of reviews and comment by Percy Hammond, edited by John C. Hammond. 275 pages. Published by John C. Hammond, Newtown, Conn.

Rudolph Ganz, who last month introduced an 8-year-old prodigy at one of his Young People's Concerts, yesterday morning presented two prodigies at the third of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's concerts for children at Carnegie Hall. He promises still a fourth one --Rosaly Kruskal, 14-year-old clarinetist -- at his Town Hall concert tomorrow.

MADRID, Jan. 11 -- It is within the realm of possibility, it was reported tonight in certain circles, that Argentina will grant a credit to Spain of a very large total, perhaps as much as 1,000,000,000 pesetas [nominally valued at the official Spanish rate of exchange at $100,000,000, although the peseta is no longer quoted here].

ONCE more, the holiday quietus ended, our art season has struck, and promises to maintain, its normal gait. Last week's list of openings was long and diversified. In it figured several large group exhibitions, a quantity of one-man shows and at least three events that, without having connived to that end, address themselves, altogether or in preponderant degree, to a unique theme.

PLATINUM FOXES -- The platinum foxes imported from a small farm in Norway last year made a sensation. Only a certain strain could produce fur of the platinum variety. Dr. Agnes Fay of the University of California finds that simply by depriving ordinary silver foxes of one of the "B" group of vitamins she can obtain the platinum kind of fur every time.

THERE were fifty-three injury accidents, including one fatality reported over a period of three years along a one-block section of State Street in Schenectady, N.Y. Most of these accidents were caused by pedestrians attempting to cross in the middle of the block.

The campaign for statehood of Hawaii has been brewing for two years or more here in the islands, and now it is being considered seriously at Washington. But only one side of the picture has been presented, especially in Washington. Here in Hawaii there has been little or no opposition, due to political, economic, commercial and social forces.

CONCORD, N.C. -- Kannapolis, already known as the largest unincorporated town in North Carolina and the home of Cannon Mills, the world's largest producers of household textiles, is also becoming known as the "North Carolina Williamsburg."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 -- King Gustaf V opened today the ordinary session of the Riksdag [Parliament].

A new type of the Six-91 engine, Improvements in the firm's Fireball racing motor and various developments in its lightweight Diesels are to be observed in the Gray exhibit at the Motor Boat Show. In the line are twenty-seven gasoline engines besides five Diesels.

The latest news from Norway shows what is happening under Nazism to a mode of life very much like our own. It further confirms the standard of worthlessness fixed by previous performances upon Nazi pledges of every kind.

HERE is a story of romance and high adventure that follows a mighty and colorful caravan from Rome across the Roof of the World to fabulous China. It happened when Tiberius was the aging ruler of the sprawling Roman Empire and Christ was a young man teaching the new faith in one small corner of it.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 (UP) -- President Roosevelt's Full Powers Bill proposal for the repair of foreign warships in United States ports would be "a direct violation of the thirteenth Hague convention of 1907, which the United States joined," the newspaper Deutsche Allegemeine Zeitung said today.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- With one of the world's former great powers, France, prostrate and Nazi troops occupying the Atlantic coast of Europe from the northernmost tip of Norway to the Bay of Biscay as well as strategically important positions in Southeastern Europe extending to the Black Sea, the Germans feel confident that militarily their hold on Europe for the foreseeable future cannot be successfully assailed by any coalition of non-continental powers.

The importance of science in modern warfare is being amply demonstrated every day by airplanes, submarines, magnetic mines, incendiary bombs, etc. Our country is extremely fortunate in its scientific resources, but it is showing itself slow to organize them for defense.

VICHY, France, Jan. 11 -- News from Vichy for the present is negative. On the one hand the government here is still without a reply to the memorandum sent to the German authority more than two weeks ago. On the other hand there has been no Cabinet meeting for a week despite much talk or reorganization.

THE exquisite spire of the Hotel de Ville and the twin gray towers of Sainte Gudule still dominate the capital of Belgium, the gracefully affected eighteenth-century statues still brood over the lily-ponds of the Parc Royal, the flower venders still offer their wares at the Porte de Namur and in the Grand' Place; but the soul of Brussels is dead, frostbitten by nazism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- An appeal on grounds of patriotism and the "terrible urgency" of the situation to all of industry engaged on defense work to end the two-day week-end "blackout" and go on the six-day week will probably be made soon by the new Office of Production Management.

WALTERBORO, S.C. -- The metamorphosis of a sleepy county seat, devoid of natural resources and spurned as an industrial center because of its distance from necessary utilities, into a lively city and a stopover for Florida-bound citizens, 'is one which its citizens call the "miracle of Walterboro."

A fleet of fast freighters to be operated for the "common cause" of British and Allied shipping will be built at the Old Groton Iron Works Shipyards at Old Groton, Conn., Alfred Holter, a refugee Norwegian industrialist and head of a private American-Norwegian combine that acquired the yards, told The Associated Press yesterday.

THE decision by the authorities in the Cameroons in Africa to associate that French possession with the "Free France" movement headed by General Charles de Gaulle was postally acclaimed by the placing of an appropriate overprinting on some of the colony's stamps.

An educational program of "in-service" training courses for municipal employes who desire to improve their services and prepare themselves for advancement will be offered at the Division of Public Service Training of City College starting next month, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert Jahrling, director.

ROME, Jan. 11 (UP) -- Popolo di Roma, Fascist newspaper, said today that "the American people" were opposed to President Roosevelt's request for full powers to aid Britain and intimated that American workers would refuse to cooperate in intensification of military production.

THE recent removal of the remains of the son of Napoleon, known as L'Aiglon, or the Eaglet, from Vienna's Capuchin Church to Paris recalls a coin issued in 1816. This was a two-franc piece in silver on the obverse of which is shown a profile portrait of the young man facing left and about the edge is the inscription "Napoleon II Empereur."

While the numerous fashion shows last week held the keen interest of the large number of buyers who arrived in the wholesale apparel markets here, the possibility of delivery difficulties or higher prices did not spur advance orders to any considerable degree, according to the consensus here.

Manners, as the author says in her introduction, can never be completely standardized, but there are standards which it is wise for all to know, since people sometimes miss some of the fun they might have because they are not sure that their manners will be acceptable to others or because they come up against a social situation which they do not know how to handle.

AS was to be expected, the swimming clan clamor that this carping critic hit bottom when taking a recent dive into matters aquatic. At the moment, the culprit is up to his neck in hot water, poured on by the swimming adherents who insist that their game was traduced and maligned in the comment about a game that set up records for three different styles of swimming in tanks of three different lengths.

Were all daphnes hardy, they would be among our best-known garden shrubs. Unfortunately only two of the poorer-flowered among the taller evergreen types are so, and one of these does not possess even fragrance. But besides the fragrantly lovely deciduous Daphne mezereum, there are an increasing number of low-growing fragrant evergreen species finding their way slowly into our gardens.

Representative creations of Chris-Craft's array of 110 different types of runabouts, utility, racing and cruising boats are on exhibition at Grand Central Palace. This year's line covers a size range of from 151/2 to 55 feet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The North Carolina, first battleship to be built for the United States Navy in twenty years, will go into commission April 11.

An extensive revision of the regulations pertaining to amateur eligibility and the re-election of all officers for another year were the highlights of the United States Golf Association's meeting yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BIVOUACKED on this heath a couple of seasons ago, Burgess Meredith showed all the symptoms of growing up into an appeasement-age Melancholy Dane. A major principal in the doom-drenched dramas of Maxwell Anderson, he fretted about town with the air of a man who had recognized life for the bawd and bagatelle it was.

HIS publishers describe Dennis Parry's novel as a book "for the imagination." That it certainly is; and also for the intelligence. On the surface, a story of the supernatural, Algernon Blackwood type, treated in a way very unlike Mr. Blackwood's, it is, too, a study of the triumph of evil, and the manner in which people of different kinds react to that triumph when it confronts them in their own lives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Rear Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Navigation, has announced the adoption of a policy of assigning, where possible, to the same ship brothers serving in the enlisted ranks.

Among the many mechanisms over which engine enthusiasts spend their time at the show are three being exhibited for the first time. One of the trio is especially inspected. It is a two-cylinder 27-horsepower Diesel.

COVERING a period of slightly more than a century, this record of Chicago's underworld activities presents, with gusto a long and lurid career of crime. In a manner of speaking it is a worthy addition to the author's annals of sin in New Orleans, San Francisco and elsewhere, and, viewed with proper objectivity, might be called a valuable contribution to the history of American life.

Each of the five engines being exhibited at the Motor Boat Show by Sterling is a prototype of a motor being manufactured for either the United States Navy or the Coast Guard. Chief of the group is a new gasoline motor which is the most powerful one ever built by the firm.

There are 156 passenger ships, with a total of 1,100,356 gross tons, in the merchant marine. One hundred and forty-one ships of 1,039,360 gross tons are ocean-going and fifteen of 60,996 gross tons are Great Lakes vessels.

Educational measures for national defense must continue to serve the intellectual needs of individuals while contributing to military and industrial preparedness, Professor James C. Egbert, director of Columbia University's extension division, declared yesterday in announcing the division's program of 1,000 courses for the Spring semester that begins Feb. 5.

While the Fair Labor Standards Act, providing for minimum wages and maximum hours, has proved workable, uniform compliance will not be obtained until the government can make "fairly regular" inspections of every establishment subject to the law, Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division, United States Department of Labor, told the National Consumers League yesterday.

Easier prices yesterday brought to a close a week of irregular gains on the New York Stock Exchange. The market closed soft and mixed in the lightest Saturday session since Nov. 30. Only 361,440 shares were sold, compared with 384,970 on the previous Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- When President Roosevelt formally named two civilians, together with the Secretaries of War and Navy, to the newly created Office of Production Management, emphasis was placed by some people mainly on the ability of William S. Knudsen, automobile production authority, to get along with Sidney Hillman, "labor" representative.
BOSTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Hundreds of New England business firms carried on short-handed today as a grippe epidemic confined thousands to their beds and forced the closing of scores of schools.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Skip Francis Brooks's rink, from the Country Club, Brookline, Mass., ousted the defending Schenectady Curling Club team today, skipped by T.H. Lydgate, from the seventh annual invitation bonspiel at the St. Andrews Club tonight, 15 to 9.

WHEN the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra celebrates its centenary next season we should have some tall conducting. Who the conductors will be remains to be known in detail. The list is far from complete or established in its particulars at this time of writing.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- President Roosevelt made no comment tonight on the statement of Wendell L. Willkie supporting, in general, the Administration's "blank check" bill giving the Chief Executive authority to produce and transfer war supplies of all types to Great Britain and her allies.

Expressing hope that the debate in Congress would not be partisan, Wendell L. Willkie announced yesterday that he favored passage of the "lend-lease" bill for aid to Great Britain, "with modifications."
CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 (AP) -- What had seemed to be a scarcity in the supply of steel scrap "now, for the moment, appears as moderate plenty," the magazine Steel finds in its weekly survey issued today.

VICHY, France, Jan. 11 -- The Ministry of Finance for unoccupied France continues to be busy with devising every means to achieve a reduction in the volume of bank notes in circulation. New steps have just been taken toward this goal.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 12 -- The most striking statement on Bulgarian foreign policy so far was made today by Premier Bogdan Philoff in a speech at Ruschuk on the Danube, in which he once again reaffirmed that this country would continue its endeavors to keep out of the war.

Henry Ford started his crusade for a revival of the old-fashioned square dances such as the Virginia Reel, the Quadrille and the Lancers more than a decade ago. Slowly his idea gained favor in the Middle West, and now it is surging upward in the East of jitterbug and swing.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 -- The liner Manhattan, outbound from New York for San Francisco with 192 passengers, went aground tonight five miles north of Lake Worth Inlet, or ten miles north of Palm Beach.

A warning against "complacency and apathy" as the two "most paralyzing factors that can touch any nation or any social group," was sounded yesterday by Dr. Frank Kingdon, chairman of the New York Division of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, at the opening session of the Biennial Conference of Local Executives of Camp Fire Girls at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

Lea Karina, mezzo-soprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, where she was heard by a large and demonstrative gathering. Her program began with the Handel aria "Ah, mio cor," which led to numbers by Beethoven and Marcello.

" Night of the Mayas," a Mexican-made drama revolving around present-day descendants of the primitive Mayans and produced with the cooperation of the Government of Yucatan and the Carnegie Institute, will have its local premiere at noon today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse.

In a report reviewing the disastrous effects of the war upon 5,000,000 Jews in Europe, the executive committee of the American Jewish Committee expressed the belief yesterday that opposition to Germany was spreading in the occupied countries as a reaction to Nazi domination.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- With most of the Italian airdromes in Cyrenaica, Libya, cleared of serviceable Italian planes, Royal Air Force bombers yesterday morning concentrated on the two remaining fields, Berka and Benina, outside Bengazi, and caused large fires and several explosions near grounded aircraft.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (UP) -- If German troops are in Bulgaria or en route there, this action by Germany was without the knowledge or consent of Russia, it was asserted tonight in a communique released by the official Tass News Agency.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Legislature will reconvene tomorrow night for a busy two or three days before the usual early session lull sets in.

Last night a group gathered at the Educational Alliance in this city to do honor to the memory of Thomas Davidson. Who was Thomas Davidson? "A failure," according to the recent judgment of one writer. It is true that his books are not read today, and that even the Bread-Winners' College which he founded on the lower East Side is no longer in existence.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Gains of 4 to 379 per cent in value were shown by sixteen Alberta industries in the first ten months of 1940 over the corresponding period of 1939, according to figures released today by Ernest C. Manning, Minister of Trade and Industry.

The St. John's Prep swimming team, dual meet series champion, was upset by the St. Francis Prep mermen in the Brooklyn Catholic High Schools individual tournament sponsored by the Columbus Council, Knights Of Columbus, in the Columbus Club pool yesterday.

When the President asks for unlimited authority to dispose of American war equipment to "any country whose defense he deems vital to the defense of the United States," he raises many anxious questions. They can be heard in the subways and cafeterias as well as in the halls of Congress, and everywhere they are marked by the same hesitation and uncertainty.

To the giddy history of the late World's Fair there was added yesterday a post-mortem chapter that also served as a fanfare for the rising Flushing Meadow Park. A super-skating rink was opened in the old New York City Building, and it accomplished something that the Fair in all its glory was never able to do.

The League of Composers, which is not afraid to try something different, undertook a provocative experiment at the Museum of Modern Art last night. It presented an evening of "Music and Film." Excerpts from five documentary films and one complete work in its first performance were shown, and the music that six American composers wrote for them was heard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Appointment of a committee of seven engineers, each representing a national engineering organization, to advise on the defense of "vital civilian installations" in time of war was announced today by Secretary Stimson. Among the problems to be studied will be those pertaining to air raid shelters, water supply and power.

The only way in which the world can be rid of war is for all who profess to be Christians "to be thoroughly Christian in all of their relationships in life, 100 per cent of the time," the Rev. Ernest R. Palen, the pastor, said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 -- Aided by inflationary implications in President Roosevelt's budget message, which came right on top of supply-reducing implications of the government's loan policy, prices for Southern spot and future cotton reached new high levels for the season last week.

Although the basketball season has not yet reached the half-way mark, New York City already is without an unbeaten college team. Last year such an oddity did not occur until N.Y.U. bowed to C.C. N.Y. in the final game of the campaign, after the Violets had clicked off eighteen straight victories.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins ended the first half of their National Hockey League campaign by battling from behind for a 7-5 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight before 12,000.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The stock markets here again have amply demonstrated their ability to rise above the physical difficulties of conducting business, which continues to suffer from the effects of the second "great fire" in London's history.
ROME, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

It seems only yesterday that a mournful chorus of New Deal economists was telling us that our industrial plant was overbuilt. Reckless over-expansion of productive capacity in the face of the fact that our economy had become mature was the outstanding sin of our industrialists and financiers.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 12 -- The Twenty-seventh Division, which has a shortage of 188 officers, has received a contribution of thirty-nine young National Guardsmen who have been graduated from the Officers School of New York City's Old Seventh, which is now the 207th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft).
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 13 -- A great many German bombers have been trying to reach the heart of London last night and early this morning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- President Roosevelt today created by Executive Order a new Division of Defense Housing Coordination with broad powers in a move to assure efficient, adequate and speedy construction in connection with the rearmament and military training programs.

Warfare becomes total in deed when even the birds are called to the colors. A request has gone out from Army headquarters in Washington for the registration of all homing pigeons in the United States.

A prayer of thanksgiving that "we are citizens of a nation which is no longer neutral in the great struggle now raging among the peoples of the earth" was offered by the Rev. Ralph S. Meadowcroft, rector of All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, at yesterday morning's service.

ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- In the absence of exact figures that might indicate with greater precision the economic situation of Greece after two and one-half months of war, a statement in general terms published in the Athens Economist, which may be considered to have official sanction, indicates that the economic and financial structure of the country not only remains sound but has perhaps improved.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- The Country Club rink skipped by Francis Brooks, one of three quartets from Brookline, Mass., won the seventh annual invitation curling bonspiel at the St. Andrews indoor arena today, scoring a surprisingly one-sided victory over Sherry Curran's Utica team, 13 to 6, in the 17-end final to gain possession of the Archibald Douglas Medal.

Gluck's "Alceste" will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera Association next week. Not only will it be the first production of the opera at the historic Broadway house, but so far no records have been found to show that the work ever has received an operatic production in this country.

The third series of dance programs by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their company is now on view at their new home, 108 West Sixteenth Street, where it opened on Saturday evening and will be repeated next Saturday and Sunday.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 12 (UP) -- A high Turkish official told The United Press today that Turkey would declare war if German troops crossed the Rumanian frontier into Bulgaria.

SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Jack Burke used an old aluminum putter he had made back in Texas to stroke his way today to the National Professional Golfers Association senior championship with a total of 142 in the thirty-six-hole medal play tournament.

" Claudia," the Rose Franken play, is announced for Broadway the week of Feb. 10. John Golden, the producer, also announces a change in the tryout plans for the show. It will open Jan. 25 in Wilmington, Del., before passing the week of Jan. 27 in Washington.

Despite a gallant third-period rally which saw them record three goals to bring about a 4-all tie, the New York Rovers were subjected to their fourth straight Eastern Hockey League setback at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. A goal by Eddie Prokop in 16:41 of the last chapter broke the tie and gave the Atlantic City Sea Gulls a 5-4 decision.

Breaking 96 out of 100 targets L. F. Sanman took the high-over-all scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Three gunners, each with 100 full targets, tied for the handicap prize. They were T. N. Chatfield, H. W. Frank and B. D. Mannish.

Responsibility of the retail merchant in helping to prevent an inflation of retail prices growing out of the national defense effort and incidental shortages will be emphasized at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association opening tonight at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Students, teachers and their families will be encouraged to travel from the United States to Latin-American countries and from Latin-American countries to this country through reduced fares for steamship travel.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- S.L. Hutcheson annexed two of the three scratch prizes at the Westchester Country Club today. He was high gun in the singles with 47 out of 50, and took the skeet shoot with 48. The scratch cup at doubles went to C. M. Loeb, who had 46.

The questions of future government expenditures at home, of executive powers, and of control of bank reserves were uppermost last week. Whereas actual government expenditure was $9,127,373,806 in the fiscal year 1940, and will be about $13,302,000,000 in the current fiscal year, it was estimated for the fiscal year 1942, in last Wednesday's budget speech, at $17,585,528,049.

Now that the sandhogs have commenced digging the Battery Park tunnel under the East River we are witnesses to the loss of a golden opportunity. But there is still time for citizens to assert themselves.

MADRID, Spain, Jan. 12 -- Demanding in an address yesterday that certain unnamed countries furnish Spain with the food and raw materials that were essential to carry her through the present difficulties, Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner insisted they must not attach conditions that would compromise Spain's "honor."

The challenge we face today in a wartorn world may eventually bring us back to God, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer said yesterday at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity and St. James, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

The recurrent demand for a statement of the peace aims of Great Britain and her allies is seldom accompanied by a similar demand for a statement by Adolf Hitler of his peace objectives. This is not too surprising, for the Nazis and their apologists are well aware that the Fuehrer is not a man of his word.
Sales by estates were among deals reported in Brooklyn over the week-end.

Cotton prices again moved into new high ground last week. Active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange registered new high levels to date on the respective contracts. At the close of trading on Saturday, prices of futures on the Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 14 to 36 points, the best gains being in the 1941 crop deliveries.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 12 -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison and a couple of bantamweights of golf, Ben Hogan and Leonard Dodson, charged down the homestretch to a tie for the $5,000 Oakland open championship today. Each posted a seventy-two-hole total of 276, four under par for the Sequoyah course.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 12 -- Admitting it might be a case of crying wolf just once too often, well-informed diplomatic quarters nevertheless were inclined to scoff at Balkan reports here this evening that Reichsfuehrer Hitler again has set a "deadline," expiring at noon tomorrow, for Bulgarian permission for German troops to cross that country to go to the aid of Italy in Albania.

No one nowadays keeps a straight face in the presence of murder, least of all "Mr. and Mrs. North," who learned about it at the Belasco last evening. For these are the humorously vacuous characters that Richard Lockridge, drama critic of The Sun, first invented for The New Yorker several years ago, and that his wife, Frances, has conspired with him to put into crime fiction more recently.

The Willard Straight Post of the American Legion has adopted a resolution approving all aid to Great Britain, even if such aid should involve the United States in war, it was announced yesterday, by Dr. Carl Binger, Post Commander.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- There were 56,000 husbands in the United States in 1936 who, earning less than $5,000 a year of "net income," had wives who earned more. Thirty of them had wives who received between $100,000 and $500,000 of net income.

The west property consisting of fifty-six acres on Oceanside Road, Rockville Centre, L.I., has been purchased by Frederick E. Gibson, developer, for improvement with moderate-priced one-family homes on large plots. Financing has been arranged with the South Shore Trust Company of Rockville Centre and the subdivision will be laid out from plans by Chester Voorhis, engineer.

OUT of the tragic turmoil that overwhelmed Holland last May have come a calm statement of fact and a courageous statement of faith by the nation's Foreign Minister, Eelco Nicolaas van Kleffens. He calls his brief personal account of the invasion of the Netherlands "Juggernaut Over Holland."* Restrained as the book is, it will stir American readers, even though they are long since familiar with the main outline of the narrative.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Monday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Matthew M. Neely was sworn in as West Virginia's twenty-first Governor early today in a fast-moving jockeying revolving over the selection of Mr. Neely's successor as United States Senator.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Besides being a training ground for the Forty-fourth Division, Fort Dix is serving as a clearing point for the reception and transfer of trainees. By the end of June 75,000 men will have moved through Fort Dix to permanent assignments, 10,000 of them by the end of this month, it was announced here today.

Disciplinary action against seven undergraduate leaders in the evening session of Brooklyn College who were found guilty by the Faculty-Student Committee on Groups and Organizations of "subterfuge and misrepresentation" and of urging students to break regulations of the committee was announced yesterday through the office of Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Harold Clurman, founder and managing director for the last decade of New York's Group Theatre, will begin his second assault on Hollywood Wednesday as an associate producer at Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio announced.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Trading in corn was featured last week by persistent buying by a commission house, which brokers considered as possibly for distillers. Most of the grain was bought at around 62 1/2 cents a bushel for the May position, although an early upturn carried that future up to 63 1/2 cents, a new high level since November.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12 -- Only one of Canada's nine Provincial Premiers has so far declared himself forthrightly in favor of the recommendations of the Rowell-Sirois report for the reorganization of the financial structure of Canada which will come up for debate at a special conference between the Dominion and the Provincial Governments to be begun here on Tuesday, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Reorganization of the entire labor defense set-up is being charted by Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the newly created Office for Production Management, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard announced today a supplementary cotton program for voluntary reduction of cotton acreage below the 1941 national acreage amount and for increased consumption of cotton goods, to be brought about by compensation of farmers for their acreage reduction with stamps which may be used to buy cotton goods.

Two hundred members of the Thomas Davidson Society, some of whom had studied under him, gathered last night at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, to pay homage to a "scholar, philosopher and teacher," who was largely responsible for the establishment of night schools for adult education'.

Albert S. Pinkus and Arnold S. Denker, the titleholder, leaders in the annual title tournament of the Manhattan Chess Club, met in the seventh round yesterday, and after an even contest adjourned in thirty-eight moves. At that time the position appeared to be blocked, but Pinkus was of the opinion that he had a slight edge.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- A British cruiser was left sinking and two destroyers were hit in a naval battle Friday morning in the Sicily channel, says today's war bulletin. An Italian torpedo boat was sunk in this engagement, which preceded the series of bombing attacks by the combined Italian and German Air Forces described in yesterday's communique.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 13 -- High over France and high over the Alps late Saturday night flew big long-range British bombers and attacked the Royal Italian arsenal at Turin.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Supported by a new wave of money liquidity following on the heels of the new year coupon maturities, and reassured by an official statement that neither new taxes nor tax increases are contemplated for 1941, the security market maintained a firm tone this week.

No one can read eye-witness accounts of the fall of Bardia and of Sidi Barrani without being puzzled by the mass surrender of Italian troops which seemed to take place wherever the British got through the defending artillery barrage and approached within small-arms range.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Ted Ellenwood of Amsterdam, N.Y., captured his second consecutive Eastern States skating championship today by sweeping the 440-yard and mile races for a two-day total of 100 points.

STRUGA, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Reports from the Albanian frontier said that Italian troops, heavily reinforced by mechanized units from Valona, today recaptured the village of Dorza, which the Greeks took on Dec. 18. Dorza is fourteen miles northwest of Tepeleni, on the main Tepeleni-Valona highway.

ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- Still flushed by the outstanding success achieved by the capture of Klisura two days ago, it is stated here, Greek troops continued today to press on along the roads and mountain passes to the north and northwest of the Tepeleni-Klisura line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The new air and naval bases which the United States has acquired from Britain, in conjunction with Canadian-American arrangements for joint defense, "virtually remove the feasibility of invasion via Iceland, Greenland and Canada and diminish the likelihood o sporadic coastal raids."

Great Britain's most distinguished portrait painter, Sir John Lavery, and her foremost dramatist, George Bernard Shaw, were both born in the same year on John Bull's Other Island. Unlike Shaw, however, Sir John had no desire to upset anybody's applecart. His Irish brilliance, and perhaps that touch of Irish blarney apparent in his portraits of beautiful women, were tempered by a stern Scotch realism acquired in his difficult early days at Glasgow.

Exports, other than grain, through Atlantic and Gulf ports were about 41 per cent higher last year than in 1939, according to a report by the manager of port traffic of the Association of American Railroads. The report said that this traffic moved without congestion or delay as a result of the joint efforts of steamship lines, port authorities, exporters and shippers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A legislative program for 1941 putting the advancement of national defense above all other matters was set forth here today by the American Federation of Labor in a statement by William Green, its president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- President Roosevelt was warned tonight by the Civil Service Commission that lack of funds had prevented investigation of possible fifth-column associations of persons appointed to "many key posts" in the total defense program.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 10 -- The smaller Continental European markets, after opening the week in a hesitant mood, displayed later an all-round buying interest, but closed again irregular. Generally, purchases now are more selective than of late, but no signs of large liquidation are seen, while, on the contrary, continuing liquidity among enterprises and individuals forms the basis for renewed strength which is strongly checked, however, by official measures sterilizing floating buying power.

The Rev. Dr. James E. Walker closed a pastorate just two weeks short of eighteen years yesterday, giving his farewell message at the morning service of the Astoria Presbyterian Church, 31-40 Thirty-third Street, Queens, and becoming pastor emeritus.

Dr. Louis H. Bauer of Hempstead, L.I., has been chosen as the first recipient of the John Jeffries award, which will be presented by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at its honors night dinner here on Jan. 28.

Plans for the annual Sportsmen's Show, which is scheduled to run nine days this year, beginning on Feb. 15, are now nearly completed and a number of new competitions for show visitors will be opened for entry in the near future.

THE TIMES printed the news that Akron University is dropping the study of international law from its Spring semester because the "war-makers have reduced [it] to a farce." Such action is regretted, since it overlooks fundamental considerations of academic thought, of educational policy and of university standards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The American Red Cross, which has already supplied China with $1,500,000 worth of medical supplies and equipment to aid it in its struggle against the Japanese, is preparing to send more millions of dollars' worth. The decision followed word that the donations are being successfully transported to their destination.

Gale winds drove a fire along three blocks of frame and concrete construction work on the Rockaway grade-crossing elimination project in Arverne, Queens, early today and swept through eighteen dwellings beside the Far Rockaway branch of the Long Island Railroad, making eighteen families homeless before firemen, summoned on a borough-wide call, could bring the flames under control.

Establishment of a Protestant list of recommended books "and perhaps a list of proscribed books," somewhat similar to those maintained by the Catholic Church, was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale in his sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

Begun last May as a sustaining program of the Columbia Broadcasting Company, "Invitation to Learning" now has an estimated audience of 3,000,000 persons. Every week Huntington Cairns, Allen Tate and Mark Van Doren, joined occasionally by a specialist, discuss in round-table fashion a single classic.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., Jan. 12 -- Taking the interesting one-half mile Cannon Mountain course with a 600-foot drop without checking once, stout-hearted Selden Hannah, former intercollegiate star from Dartmouth, topped a field of sixty-three to win today's Giant Slalom, second half of the Franconia S.C.'s two-day ski meet, in 1 minute 5 seconds.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 12 -- A Minneapolis machine company has adopted an unusual "health conservation program," distributing daily vitamin pills to all workers in a move to keep manpower at a maximum for the national defense program.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Torger Tokle, 21-year-old ski jumping king in recent Eastern competitions, easily gained his twentieth victory in twenty-two starts today by pacing a field of eight Class A jumpers in a meet staged by the Norswift Ski Club of East White Plains and the Bear Mountain Sports Association.

The wholesale markets were active last week, with many buyers here viewing new lines. Response to openings of home furnishing lines, notably rugs, curtains and draperies, was unusually heavy. First Spring coat orders were placed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Providing there are no upsets due to unexpected defense demands or adverse crop conditions, the farm equipment industry is looking for 1941 sales to exceed 1940 by anywhere from 5 to 10 per cent, a check of trade sources indicated here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Senator Wheeler declared tonight that the lend-lease program of aid to Britain meant "open and complete" war and branded President Roosevelt definitely as war-minded.

With the exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, "Art in Industry," showing the work of pupils in the art department of New York's vocational high schools, one realizes what a gap exists between the classroom and the designer's office.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 12 -- In an all-Philadelphia final, William Slack and Hunter Loft defeated David McMullin and Mifflin Large today to win the ninth annual Greenwich-Apawamis invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Greenwich Country Club.
In your issue for today the following occurs: "The great majority thinks with England. Mrs. Lindbergh thinks is the discredited formulas of the recent past."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 12 -- The volume of incoming steel business returned last week to its pre-holiday levels as was expected with the raw steel output advancing one-half point to a new record level. Most attention in the industry, however, was centered on the iron and steel scrap situation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Tuffield Latour, Saranac Lake undertaker, with his new riding partner, Andy Fortune, drove through a heavy snowfall today to win the season's first big two-man bobsled event on Mount Van Hoevenberg's ice-coated chute.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Great Britain's food situation appeared tonight to be improved over a week ago after the government had shown its determination to crack down on food profiteers and bootleggers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 12 -- Freezing weather and a dull afternoon failed to deter the frostbite sailors at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. The Larsen brothers, Al and Will, captured Class B honors in the Blue Nose. They won two of the four races and placed third and fourth in the others.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks shook off the Detroit jinx that had hounded them all season and handed the high-flying Red Wings a 2-to-1 defeat tonight before an all-time National Hockey League record crowd of 19,386 spectators.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- The Reichsbank's note circulation at the year end reached a new war-time high record of 14,033,000,000 marks, which was 2,236,000,000 higher than on Dee. 31, 1939. The advance of more than 700,000,000 marks ir. the last week in December was due to the unusually large increase in the bank's bill portfolio from 13,556,000,000 marks to 15,419,000,000.

Because of plans he said had been made to disrupt a meeting at Lost Battalion Hall, Rego Park, Queens, Verne Marshall, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, last night made a nation-wide broadcast over the Mutual Network from the studios of WOR instead of from the hall.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Lieutenant John Golden and nine patrolmen, armed with dog-catcher nets, locked themselves in the Police Headquarters garage here this afternoon and after a hectic quarter-hour roundup put an end to an animal mixup that had begun four miles away, in Hoboken.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 12 -- Tomorrow's Oslo newspapers will carry on their front pages, under banner headlines, an appeal by Major Vidkun Quisling, chief of Norway's Nazi-sponsored regime, to all "national thinking Norwegians" to enlist in a Norwegian regiment which will be sent to Germany "to partake in the German-Norwegian fight against Britain."

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- A large trade was on in lard last week, with prices advancing to new high levels since October before realizing sales caused a reaction. January lard, which sold at $4.05 for 100 pounds on Dec. 17, touched $5.30 last week, an unusually sharp advance for that commodity.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- There was no apparent change in the outlook for the new Winter wheat crop last week, and official and trade reports indicate that the condition remains generally favorable. No damage has been reported as the result of several days of cold weather, although the plant is said to be showing a little growth in parts of the Southwest

LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The British Press Association's air correspondent said today that Germany's admission that six planes failed to return from Friday night's raids, in which the British claimed only two, might mean that "progress is being made in the search for a thoroughly convincing answer to the night bomber."

LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The British Treasury announced tonight that it had taken over all individual British holdings in another large block of United States dollar securities in an order dated yesterday, giving the prices to be paid their owners in six weeks. The list included forty-five stocks and sixty bonds.

Norm Larson of the New York Americans spoiled Davey Kerr's dream of registering his first shut-out triumph of the National Hockey League season for the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. Kerr held off the Dutton skaters for two periods and was doing well enough in the third until Larson scored on a short drive.

Recommending the continuance of all existing school services, the Board of Education's finance committee submitted yesterday a tentative budget estimate for the fiscal year 1941-42 of $152,008,302, an increase of $1,347,573 over the current operating budget.

Publicly announced gifts of $61,997,707 were made in 1940 for educational and charitable purposes in seven major cities in the United States, according to a study made public yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation, 150 Nassau Street.

A pioneer among athletic clubs and the largest in the world, the New York A.C. last year enjoyed one of the most successful years in its history, according to the seventy-second annual report issued by the retiring president, Orie R. Kelly.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- In a London park there is a great mound of bricks and stone already twenty feet high and fully a hundred yards in diameter -- millions of fragments of masonry gathered from the ruins of countless homes in which royalty, gentry and the common folk of London had lived for generations.

There is a fundamental disingenuousness in our foreign policy which politicians may find it difficult to face but which must be faced by those who want to think clearly about it. It is important enough to merit clarity.

A general description of the work to be financed this year by the Episcopal Church in the United States to Christianize the Eskimos and Indians of the Arctic was given by the Right Rev. Archibald L. Fleming, Bishop of the Arctic, in his sermon yesterday morning at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Tenth Street.

Dr. Charles P. Berkey, head of the Department of Geology and Mineralogy at Columbia University and a specialist in geology applied to engineering, will receive an honorary membership in the American Society of Civil Engineers on Wednesday morning at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Susanne Fisher, Metropolitan Opera soprano, appeared as the soloist last night with the New York City Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Otto Klemperer, at the second of the new series of popular-priced symphonic concerts being sponsored by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- On the edge of the storm sweeping up the coast, sailing dinghies at the Larchmont Yacht Club today went from almost a calm into a blow as Arthur Knapp, in his craft, Four Deuces, and Eddie Maxwell, in his Tu Yung, tied on points in Class B, while Bill Dodge, with his Moth Ball, led Class X.
Following is the statement issued by Wendell L. Willkie, supporting, with modifications, the "lend-lease" bill for aid to Great Britain:

The eerie silence of an evacuated port hung over Grand Central Palace, harbor for the thirty-sixth annual Motor Boat Show, yesterday. Once or twice the stillness was broken by the voice of an exhibitor who had dropped in for a hurried inspection of his wares or to show a boat to an out-of-town prospect who could not be on hand when the show opened again today.

A total of $143,937 has been raised so far in the Town Hall fiftieth anniversary fund campaign, Frederick H. Wood, campaign chairman, announced yesterday. Of this total, $77,338 in gifts and pledges has been raised since Oct. 23.

The small European nations that hope to stave off starvation through food sent by the United States are willing and able to pay for the food, W. Hallam Tuck, vice chairman of the National Committee on Food for Five Small Democracies, announced yesterday from the 420 Lexington Avenue offices of the organization, of which former President Herbert Hoover is honorary chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Administrative staffs of the American Red Cross-Harvard Hospital and the Harvard Public Health Unit which will cooperate in the study and treatment in England of communicable diseases under wartime conditions were announced here today in a statement by the Red Cross and Harvard University, which are joining forces in the project.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Communists, left wing Labor groups and others of strong liberal tendencies among the clergy and the professions launched today a countrywide movement to overthrow the present British Government and establish in its place a "people's government" that would bring peace by negotiating with the German masses, not with their leaders.

The British War Relief Society's thrift shop, formerly at 252 West Fifty-seventh Street, will open today at its new address, 956 Third Avenue, between Fifty-sixth Street and Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. E.J. Brousseau, organizer and director of the shop.

Total gross expenditures of all advertisers on National Broadcasting Company network facilities during 1940 amounted to $50,663,000, an increase of 12 per cent over the previous year, the company reports. There were 125 clients twenty-seven of whom were classified as political.

The foreign exchange market last week was as listless as any of its predecessor trading periods since last Fall, when the close supervision of the control boards began to limit turnover and fluctuations.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Developments thus far in the new legislative session indicate that two important questions relating to New York City finances will come to a head in the next few months.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The immensity of the United States financial and industrial preparation for the giving of all aid to Great Britain has deeply impressed the City, but, in all quarters, stress is laid on the fact that while American assistance certainly will prove the turning point for Britain, she must continue to rely on her own productive capacity while successfully facing the struggle which lies immediately ahead.

When we speak of this confused world we must remember that the confusion is not in the world, but in us, the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe declared yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

When the New Friends of Music held its opening concert on Nov. 8, 1936, the assisting artist was Mischa Levitzki, who died Jan. 2. Yesterday the "Friends" did him honor by altering its program and introducing Brahrns's Vier Ernste Gesange as a memorial to the pianist.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Jan. 12 -- John Behmer, 41-year-old knit goods manufacturer, killed his two sons with an axe in the nursery of their home at 8715 Third Avenue, here today and then attempted suicide by inhaling gas.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's Concert, Rudoph Ganz, conductor; Rosaly Kruskal, clarinet, soloist; Town Hall, 3:45 P.M. National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor; William Hain, soloist; Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M. Bach Circle of New York, Robert Hufstader, conductor, Town Hall, 8:45 P.M. Program of contemporary American music, Composers Press, Haubiel Studios, 853 Seventh Avenue, 9 P.M.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- There is much speculation here as to the effect the British victories in the Libyan desert will have in other parts of the Near East.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 85.8 from 85.4. Many changes occurred in commodities which had been quiet for several weeks; as, for example, the rise in the prices of pig iron and malleable castings. These increases, plus rises in naval-store and vegetable-oil prices, brought the semi-manufactured goods index up 1.4 per cent to 86.6.

Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler took exception yesterday to charges by the Real Estate Board of New York that the city is imposing, notably on small property owners, "confiscatory taxation through overassessment." The board's charges were set forth in a brief submitted to the joint legislative committee on assessing and reviewing (Bewley committee).

A funeral service for Albert J. Berwin, Republican leader for more than thirty-three years of the Seventh Assembly District, Manhattan, who died on Thursday in his home, 201 West Eighty-fifth Street, at the age of 73, was held yesterday morning in the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 12 -- Italian sources on the Yugoslav-Italian frontier declared tonight that the new German offensive, forecast from Berlin, would be launched "in an unexpected quarter" within the space of days or even hours.

Henri Bergson, French philosopher who died in Paris on Jan. 4, had embraced Catholicism, but chose not to let it be known during his lifetime, it is declared in an article by Raissa Maritain in the issue of The Commonweal to be published tomorrow.

STANHOPE, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Walden Smith of the Lakeside Ice Yacht Club won the Class E championship and William Harless of the Great South Bay Scooter Club took both the big and baby scooter class titles of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association on Lake Musconetcong today.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn dedicated a parochial school building at St. Gabriel's Church, Astoria Boulevard and Ninety-seventh Avenue, East Elmhurst, Queens, yesterday afternoon.

THE least that Postmaster General Frank Walker could do would be to waft an official letter in this direction thanking this battered bystander for stirring up the mail-carrying business no little. It wouldn't cost him anything but a minute's time in dictation. Frank could frank the letter as official business, which it would be under the circumstances.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Italy's military reverses in Egypt and Greece continue to be discussed with increasing frankness by the German press, indicating they are not being viewed apprehensively by the German High Command.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 12 -- Count Paul Teleki, the Hungarian Premier, today opened the campaign of the United Government party, similar to that being conducted in Bulgaria, by making a speech at Miskolc. He declared that in the present situation the nation must be prepared for anything.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Aluminum Company of America was accused today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, chairman of the Temporary National Economic Committee, of seriously delaying the manufacture of warplanes for the United States and Great Britain by "keeping supplies down in order to keep prices up."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A lanky, smiling Irishman from Findlay, Ohio, flying a rebuilt plane he had tested only four days ago, today closed Miami's annual midwinter air show by capturing one of the most prized trophies for precision aerobatics in American aeronautics.

Six contributions totaling $242, including a gift of $200 from the Newsom family, reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the total that has been received in response to the twenty-ninth annual appeal for the most needy persons in New York to $232,930.80.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- With full knowledge that he who enters the realm of predicting future events treads on dangerous ground, I still believe that sufficient evidence exists to warrant the statement that the harness racing sport may look forward to 1941 with confidence.

A veteran champion came back last night to capture the highest honors in the forty-seventh specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America in the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania. The best-in-show title was awarded to Champion Kims Tzu Shan of Orchard Hill, owned and shown in the ring by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lock Haven, Pa.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- While wheat prices had a range of around 1 3/4 cents a bushel last week, there was no definite trend in the market and, while an early upturn carried prices into new ground since last November, a selling movement which developed yesterday carried prices off quickly, and the decline of 3/4 to 1 cent for the day was the largest in about a month.

The Police Department, in response to an order issued by Mayor La Guardia, will begin tests of horns, motors and exhausts of the city's 11,876 taxicabs Wednesday morning in what was described as the "second phase" of the Mayor's anti-noise campaign, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Wendell L. Willkie's statement endorsing in principle the lend-lease bill met a mixed reception in Washington. Senators and Representatives who have taken a strong isolationist stand were critical of it. Those who favor President Roosevelt's course welcomed it.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 -- Provision must be made for hospitalization of 5 per cent of the 1,200,000 men who will be in the regular Army by June, according to Colonel N.T. Kirk, who arrived here today to attend the annual convention of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, opening tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Congressional controversy sharpened today over President Roosevelt's legislation program for "all out" aid to Britain and her allies and co-defenders of democracy through his lend-lease program as committees of both houses prepared to take up the sweeping proposal this week.

The other day in a discussion with a friend about the United States Government debt and interest rates he made the statement that during the Spanish-American War the United States Government sold bonds to finance this war and later reduced the interest rate to 1 per cent and finally paid them off.
Ernest W. Gibson came here yesterday from his home in Brattleboro, Vt., to take over the national chairmanship of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, vacated by William Allen White.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Flooding beach roads and undermining some ocean-front cottages, a heavy surf battered coastal Southern New England today as a violent storm passed northeastward far out to sea.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Philip M. Kleinfeld, Brooklyn Democrat and State Senator from the Fourth Senatorial District, was nominated tonight to serve on the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District, to fill the vacancy caused by the elevation of Albert Conway to the Court of Appeals.

On Sunday the Mayor and other city officials opened a glossy new ice-and-roller skating rink in the City of New York Building at the World's Fair grounds. The thousands that both attended and were turned away must have gladdened every heart that finds its reward in the public's enjoyment of its privileges.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The 8,000-ton French freighter Mendoza was reported steaming back to Montevideo tonight from an apparently frustrated second attempt to run home through the British Atlantic blockade.

As Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise campaign gathered momentum yesterday, 6,000 independent and fleet cab owners learned from the police that they may lose their licenses for unnecessary horn-blowing. During the day 104 motorists paid fines in Traffic Courts for violating antinoise laws.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13 -- War Bugle, a bay son of Man o' War owned by the Circle M Ranch of Mr. and Mrs. E.S. Moore of Sheridan, Wyo., brought joy to many fans at Hialeah Park today when he rallied to win the Indian Creek purse. The 8-to-5 choice outfinished the Shady Brook Farm's Agricole by half a length, running the seven furlongs in 1:24 2-5 under Red Howell.

Once the National Boat Show is well launched on its eight-day run, the solons of the sport of yachting, along with the associations that operate around the fringes of pleasure boating, begin their long list of meetings. These assemblages began last night, following the announcement by Manager Ira Hand that the first two show days had attracted a 30 per cent increase in attendance over last Winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt headed a large and distinguished audience which turned out today to hear the program given by Arthur Rubenstein, pianist, and Zlatko Balokovic, violinist, at the second of this season's series of Musical Mornings given by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court ruled today that a manufacturer selling goods to the Federal Government under a contract providing for reimbursement of Federal taxes "directly" imposed is not entitled to collect for processing taxes paid by others.
BERLIN, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The official news agency characterized as a "fable" today the charge that Isidore Lazarus had smuggled funds from Germany into the United States for German propaganda work.

TOKYO, Jan. 13 -- The government is launching another anti-spy campaign, but foreigners are not implicated this time, and the scare is mainly for the instruction of munition workers and "anti-espionage defense manoeuvres" are to be staged for three days beginning Friday in the populous industrial districts around Tokyo and Osaka.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- "No matter how greatly production facilities may be increased, no matter how many pilots may be trained, unless the aircraft that are built for action are at least equal in performance to those of any possible enemy, the whole effort will be largely wasted," stated the annual report of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Appointment of a joint legislative committee to study a "fair and just" legislative reapportionment and report to the Legislature by Feb. 1, 1942, was advocated in a resolution submitted tonight in the Senate by Seymour Halpern, Queens Republican.
DUBLIN, Jan. 13 -- About 5 per cent of the Irish people hope Germany will win the war. The rest prefer a British victory. But only about 1 per cent favor Ireland's entry into the war.

Secretary Stimson's appointment of a committee of distinguished engineers to study methods of protecting American cities open to air attack is a useful measure of precaution. To plan such defense with care and precision is obviously wiser than to improvise it under pressure, as London has had to do.

With the enactment of the new bill to promote defense, would it be possible to preserve a significant measure of Congressional control or influence? After passing such a bill Congress could hardly refuse or seriously restrict appropriations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that imports of gold set a new twelve-month record of $4,749,467,000 in 1940. Shipments of gold, swelled by large British Empire transfers for purchase of war materials, were about $1,200,000,000 larger in 1940 than in 1939, the previous high.

Rumors that civil war was imminent between Communist and Central Government troops in China and that the British and United States Ambassadors at Chungking had warned Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek that Anglo-American aid would cease if civil strife broke out, were declared yesterday by Dr. Tsune-chi Yu, Chinese Consul General in New York, to be without foundation.

Two new statues of celebrated New Yorkers will be unveiled in upper Fifth Avenue this afternoon. They are standing figures of Alexander Hamilton and De Witt Clinton, slightly over life-size, that will occupy white marble niches of the facades in the two wings of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets.

A total of 397 selective service men were inducted into the Army here yesterday in the second draft call as it was announced that 10,500 men from New York and New Jersey would be called in the Second Corps Area in the fourth induction, from Feb. 3 to Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Secretary Hull said today that he understands Wendell Willkie is going abroad solely as an individual citizen in order to observe war conditions at close range. He knew no more about it than what Mr. Willkie had announced and, if the former Republican Presidential candidate wanted to see him before he leaves that was for Mr. Willkie to decide.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Warren P. Edris, 54 years old, president of the Edris Service Corporation, New York City financial and insurance investigation concern, died this afternoon in the All Souls Hospital, Morristown, of hemorrhages resulting from a bullet wound over his right temple received earlier in the day.

Wendell L. Willkie's endorsement of the Administration's "lend-lease" bill, with amendments, appeared yesterday to have materially complicated the task of selecting a new Republican national chairman to succeed Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye and the highest army and navy officials met for four hours last night in a tea-house session that the press said was prompted by "the increased delicacy of United States-Japanese relations."

President William Green of the A.F.L. cites the right to strike as one of the "constitutional rights enjoyed by the American people." At the same time he points to twenty-five unions in his federation, including more than 2,500,000 workers, who "have voluntarily renounced strikes on defense projects, and have offered industry and the Government a practical plan for voluntary arbitration of industrial disputes."

Infantile paralysis is a virus disease, and about virus diseases as a class far too little is known. No visible organism is involved in any of them. Though experiments have dispelled some of the old notions -- it has recently been established, for example, that the mouth as well as the nose may be a portal of entry -- the approach is largely chemical and physical.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Leonard Dodson of Kansas City, Mo., won the play-off of a triple tie for $1,200 top money in the $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament today and maintained a record of never being beaten in a battle after the regular competition.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A communique issued today by the Air Ministry said:

It was not "the British People," as our local Russo-Nazi organ calls them, that met in convention in London on Sunday to make plans for overthrowing the present British Government. The British people were busy at other tasks, such as manufacturing war materials, guarding the coasts, restoring services cut by Nazi bomb attacks, rescuing victims buried in the ruins of their homes and shelters.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- Gallant little Lou Salica, from New York's Coney Island, fought the bravest battle of his career at the Arena tonight to retain his world bantamweight championship by beating Tommy Forte, sturdy local challenger, in fifteen rounds before a capacity crowd of 9,000.

Despite the boldness of the administration's bill to aid Britain, it is singularly sterile as far as political invention is concerned. Creative statesmanship is the ability to originate new and appropriate institutions to meet new and unprecedented situations. To solve this unprecedented problem, however, President Roosevelt has fallen back upon the already hackneyed device of delegating power to the Executive.

The late Thomas A. Edison obtained more than 1,000 patents in his lifetime, and a relatively obscure scientist, John O'Connor, received slightly less. These were the only inventors who owned more patents than Carleton Ellis, whose inventions ranged from an oilcracking process used by Standard Oil to a soap which left no rings around the bathtub.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Warning that the cost of military preparation would mean unprecedented taxes, Governor John W. Bricker began a second term today by calling on local governments to help shoulder the burden by reducing their expenditures.
Two of the building plans filed yesterday were for six-story apartment house projects costing $350,000 each. One is to occupy a site in Jackson Heights and the other will go up in Rego Park.

HAVANA, Jan. 13 -- Former Senator Modesto Maidique was shot and killed and his secretary, Andre Alpizar, was gravely wounded this morning on the third floor of the Metropolitan office building. The assailant confronted the two men in a corridor, fired a fusillade from a pistol and escaped down a stairway.

Work of blocking up the northeast corner of the Administration Building at La Guardia Field to remove stresses caused by settling of the filled-in site will be started in the near future, Commissioner of Docks John McKenzie said yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Greek soldiers, reporting scant resistance, stabbed deeper into Italian defense positions below Valona today and Greek spokesmen expressed the hope this might prove the greatest offensive of the war in Albania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The rapid growth of America's defense machinery was strikingly illustrated today in official statistics of the Army's civilian employes. They show a peace-time high record for the country at large, while here in Washington, the nerve center of the Army, conditions are like those at the peak of the World War.

The Erie Amusement Company has sold the Bayonne Opera House building on the southwest corner of Avenue C and West Twenty-sixth Street to the Bayonne Theatre Enterprises, Inc., of New York. The building is a three-story structure covering a plot 100 by 160 feet.
Reports of trading in three of the city's boroughs were submitted yesterday by brokers. A leading deal was the sale of a large Washington Heights apartment to a group of investors by an operator.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- A continuation of 10-cent tolls on the Cross County Parkway and an allocation of State funds for additions to Westchester parkways will be sought from the State Legislature this Winter, County Executive William F. Bleakley of Westchester declared here today in his annual message to the County Board of Supervisors.

There were high goings-on last night at the Fifty-first Street Theatre, where Argentinita, with her four colleagues, gave her only dance recital of the season, and a large audience undertook to tell her in its most flattering terms that it did not approve of such exclusiveness.

SAGINAW, Mich., Jan. 13 -- The plant of the Wilcox-Rich division of the Eaton Manufacturing Company, operated under a heavy guard of State police tonight, following a picket line clash which resulted in injuries to seven persons and halted activities temporarily early in the day.

The Neediest Cases Fund was increased to $234,211.44 yesterday by the receipt of nine gifts, totaling $1,280.64. Largest of the gifts was a $1,000 check from August Horrmann, given to the Fund through the Staten Island Social Service, one of the eight charitable organizations cooperating with THE NEW YORK TIMES in the appeal for the relief of victims of suffering in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- O.K. Armstrong, organizer and field director of the No Foreign War Committee, of which Verne Marshall of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, is chairman, announced his resignation today on the ground that the committee was not being conducted along lines he considered basic for any movement trying to lead and influence public opinion.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Minister of Supply Vaino Kotilainen told American correspondents today that Finland faces famine by next Summer unless food shipments from the United States are received to augment the nation's grain stocks, now down to a four-month supply.

ATLANTA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Governor Rivers granted a full pardon today to Richard G. Gallogly, 30-year-old member of a prominent Atlanta family serving life for the 1928 holdup slaying of a drug-store clerk.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- As a sign of good faith with reference to the aim of handling defense measures on a non-political basis, the Republican leaders of the Legislature assented tonight to Governor Lehman's suggestion that defense legislation be handled by newly created standing committees.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 13 -- Foreign Minister Manuel Bianchi of Chile has arrived by plane from Santiago for an official visit to Bolivia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that she favored deferring the drafting of young benedicts until the supply of young bachelors was exhausted.

With Clinton Stephens and his younger brother, Warren, accounting for three victories between them for a 5-0 victory over the Downtown A.C., Old Sixty-ninth went into a tie for first place with Central in the Metropolitan Badminton Association Class A tourney.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 13 -- Today's Bourse opened weak, but later buying caused a small rally.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- All classes of slaughter cattle sold actively and strong today, with steers strong to a shade higher.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today purchased screen rights to Edison Marshall's novel "Benjamin Blake," which will be published next month. The story deals with romantic adventure in eighteenth century England, according to the studio.

In a session whose only distinction might be its drabness, prices on the Stock Exchange eased yesterday in mixed movements with dealings the smallest since Dec. 3. Operations were barely visible at times as the turnover slumped to 474,770 shares against the total on Friday of 751,670.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 -- Official German quarters tonight had no comment to make on speeches of Bulgarian political leaders. The silence observed here since the visit of the Bul garian Premier, Bogdan Philoff, to Vienna and other points, therefore, remains unbroken.

IF Daniel Boone had been as handy with a pen as with a gun, he might have left a record of his wanderings in the American wilderness comparable to V.K. Arseniev's story of his travels in the wilds of Eastern Asia.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 13 -- Major Vidkun Quisling's official organ, Fritt Folk, gives today details about a regiment of Norwegian volunteers that will be sent to Germany to fight against Great Britain.
ROME, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Italian High, Command issued the following communique today:

The body of a man identified as Hyman Loew, 71 years old, of 248 Beach Seventy-fifth Street, Arverne, Queens, was found yesterday morning by policemen who searched the ruins of thirty-two buildings swept by fire earlier in the day.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Assemblyman Robert Doscher of Pearl River will sponsor legislation for an open season on deer to relieve distressed fruit growers and motorists in Rockland County who have encountered hordes of deer in truck gardens, apple orchards and on vehicular highways, it was learned here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Earle Lookabaugh, Chicago billiard instructor, scored the first upset of the world three-cushion championship tonight, defeating Joe Chamaco of Mexico City, 50 to 37, in fifty-four innings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A commercial aircraft priorities section, directed by Arthur D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was established today by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., director of the Priorities Division of the National Defense Advisory Commission.

Eleven small, swift "mosquito boats," new units of the Navy's recently formed "suicide" fleet, sailed from the lavy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday to patrol the waters off Key West, Fla., where they are expected to remain as a special auxiliary arm of the fleet.

A small but complete plant for producing spurious brandies and whiskies was uncovered by the police yesterday in an apartment on the second floor of 165 East 110th Street, across the hall from the spot where an East Side gangster was found stabbed to death Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Maritime Commission, responding to the President's order to build 200 ocean-going cargo vessels in the quickest possible time, today awarded three contracts, amounting to $14,233,000, for the construction of shipyard facilities to enable the building of twenty-two ships simultaneously.

An underwriting group headed by White, Weld Co. will offer to the public today $12,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent, Series Q, first refunding-mortgage bonds of the Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore. The bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1976, will be priced at 103 1/2 and accrued interest.

VINELAND, N.J., Jan. 13 -- An Army pursuit plane crashed in flames near here today and its pilot suffered a broken right ankle in parachuting to safety. He was Captain Romulus W. Puryear, commanding officer of the Thirty-third Pursuit Squadron.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 13 -- The first impression produced here by the speech of Premier Bogdan Philoff of Bulgaria, in the version furnished by the Italian Stefani Agency, was that it indicated the approach of grave events in Bulgaria.

Officials of the United States Lines were in communication by telephone all yesterday with Captain G.V. Richardson, master of the stranded liner Manhattan, which they hoped would be refloated at high tide last night.
