A banner entry of 321 athletes from twenty-one colleges and clubs has been received for the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championships at the New York Coliseum Saturday night, Pincus Sober, chairman of the meet, announced yesterday. All fifteen of last year's champions are on the list.

Pounded by heavy seas in the worst storm to sweep the Atlantic this Winter, two American freighters owned by the same line reported yesterday that they were in distress within 300 miles of each other off the east coast of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Prices of wheat held today within relatively narrow limits. They declined early only to rally late in the day and closed on the Board of Trade here unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel higher. There was aggressive buying of the May early, by houses with Eastern and milling connections, but this was offset by Southwestern selling.

ABOARD A BRITISH WARSHIP, in the Mediterranean, Jan. 10 -- (Via Alexandria, delayed) -- ((UP)) -- The German Air Force came to the assistance of Italy's faltering Mediterranean and North African forces today with an intensive attack on the British Fleet in the central Mediterranean after British warships sank an Italian destroyer in a spectacular running battle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Supreme Court supported today the position of the National Labor Relations Board in acting on five petitions for review of disputes between employers and workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Justice Jennings Bailey of the Federal District Court said today that he might enjoin temporarily a referendum called for next week in the New York milkshed while he studied arguments in injunction proceedings against the Secretary of Agriculture. The arguments will continue tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Anton Christoforidis, the spirited battler from Greece, won the National Boxing Association's recognition as world light-heavyweight champion tonight by pounding out a fifteen-round decision over Melio Bettina of Beacon, N.Y., a former titleholder.

MADRID, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Eberhard von Stohrer, German Ambassador to Spain, it was learned today, suddenly left Madrid for Berlin last Friday, one day before Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner, in his speech at Barcelona, revealed Spain's determination to get food from abroad without conditions -- or else.

Under the impressive title "Sixty Paintings That Won Sixty Prizes" the Grand Central Galleries in the Hotel Gotham today open an exhibition which puts forward the best food of that institution. Earliest in point of years is Leopold Seyffert's portrait of Fritz Kreisler, which received the Carol Beck Medal of the Pennsylvania Academy away back in 1918.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 13 per cent for the week ended Jan. 11, in comparison with the like week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise compared with a decrease of 4 per cent for the week ended Jan. 4.

While all the other teams are idle, the New York Rangers will be at home at Madison Square Garden tonight, clashing with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League encounter. The visitors, who suffered their first setback in eight games when they dropped a 2-1 decision to the Black Hawks at Chicago Sunday night, are in second place, four points behind the pace-setting Maple Leafs.

Michael Lerner of New York and Miami, who has been an active supporter of the American Museum of Natural History's survey of swordfish and marlin, was elected a trustee of the institution last night at the seventy-second annual meeting of the board of trustees.

Induction into the Army of additional National Guard units yesterday brought considerably more than half of the city Guard contingents' strength into Federal service for the year's training period prescribed by Congress.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A Reuters dispatch from Khartum, Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, today quoted Haile Selassie as saying the "time is not far distant" when he would lead an army of Ethiopian patriots against the Italians who drove him from his throne.

Long-range bombers capable of 300 miles an hour constitute this country's "fundamental first line of defense," Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines and former World War ace, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Intensive training in Germany's parachute corps has prevented Max Schmeling, former world heavyweight boxing champion, from defending his title as European champion against Heinz Lazek.

David O. Selznick's production of "Rebecca," directed by Alfred Hitchcock from the Daphne du Maurier novel, has been designated the leader of 1940's ten best films in a nationwide poll of motion picture critics conducted by the trade paper, The Film Daily.

If there was something ambiguous and enigmatic in Joyce's genius, the conflicting elements in it were the cause. He was naturalist, symbolist and fantast. He was steeped in medieval philosophy and in studies of the unconscious. In his later years pedantry possessed him.

New elements of cost, including packaging, sanitary precautions, taxes and transportation rather than any price controls or monopolistic practices have cut the farmer's share of consumers' food dollar from 56 cents in 1913 to 40 1/2 cents in 1938, A.C. Elliot, managing director of the New York Butter and Egg Council, Inc., asserted here yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 13 -- The Tass Agency statement that if German troops were now entering or would enter Bulgaria it would be without the Soviet's knowledge and the denial that Sofia had approached Moscow on the question have created a great deal of interest here.

As his statement disclosed, it was not any easier for Mr. Willkie to endorse the principle and most of the provisions of the Lend-Lease Bill than it was for some other leaders of the opposition to reject them. The great majority of the Republican and anti-New Deal Democratic spokesmen are not only strong partisans of the British in this war; they agree that British victory is essential to the American interest.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 13 -- Thirteen prominent Harvard graduates were nominated tonight as candidates for the five vacancies which will occur in June on the board of overseers.

A large audience attended Albert Morris Bagby's 428th Musical Morning yesterday in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Mme. Lotte Lehmann, soprano, and Richard Bonelli, baritone, of the Metropolitan Opera; and Moriz Rosenthal, pianist.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange elected yesterday a seven-man nominating committee for 1941, which at three meetings in March will hear suggestions from members, allied members and non-member limited partners for nominees for the offices and positions to be filled at the annual election of the Exchange on May 12.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee expressed the opinion today that the necessity of continually improving military and naval planes might prevent production of 50,000 craft annually, the goal set by the Administration.

Hailing Wendell L. Willkie's endorsement of the President's lend-lease bill, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, said yesterday that if the code of diplomacy of twenty-five years ago were in effect the United States would be officially at war today. He spoke at the luncheon of the Association of Buying Offices, held in conjunction with the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13 -- Coast Guardsmen, working in a moderately high sea kicked up by a brisk breeze, removed the last of 200 passengers from the liner Manhattan tonight.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 13 -- Major Gen. Frederic H. Smith, commander of the Seventh Corps, of which the Twenty-seventh Division is a part, was formally received today with ceremonies which had an Irish slant to them. Then he took up residence in the Officers Club temporarily, while he organizes a staff for this recently activated corps.

A funeral service for Dr. Emanuel Lasker, chess champion of the world from 1894 to 1921, was held at noon yesterday in the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Dr. Lasker died on Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 72.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Three airplane manufacturers who have or expect large government orders today told the House Naval Affairs Committee investigating the problem of speeding defense production that the parts of the program under their direction are going as well as can be expected.

Operations of Wilson Co., Inc., and domestic and foreign subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 26, 1940, resulted in a net profit of $3,624,645 after depreciation, interest, Federal and foreign income taxes, minority interest and other deductions.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The controversy over whether continued grade crossing elimination work or new highway and parkway construction is to have priority came officially before the Legislature tonight when Robert Moses, Chairman of the State Council of Parks, sponsored, through Assemblyman D. Mallory Stephens, a bill calling for the use of $30,000,000 for parkways out of the $60,000,000 proposed to be diverted from grade crossing work.

ATHENS, Jan. 13 -- It was officially stated tonight that according to information from the front the situation of the Greek Army remained "highly satisfactory." However, no details concerning the many engagements known to have taken place in the several sectors during the last twenty-four hours were disclosed and the practice of withholding place names was scrupulously followed.

The Hayes Manufacturing Company has negotiated a contract to manufacture $5,000,000 of outer wing panels for Brewster Aeronautical Corporation bombers, conditioned upon the sale by Hayes of sufficient stock to provide not less than $400,000 additional capital, additions to the board of directors and executive personnel approved by Brewster, and acquisition by F. William Zelcer and associates of not less than 100,000 shares of Hayes common stock.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Thirty-seven 3-year-old colts and fillies are eligible for the sixteenth trotting of the $40,000 Hambletonian Stake at Good Time Park in August, Will Gahagan, secretary of the Hambletonian Society, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The net income on the average corporate net worth investment of twelve leading concerns in the milk and milk products industry in 1939, after provision for income taxes, was 9.7 per cent of the stockholders' investment, according to a report today by the Federal Trade Commission.

James V. Mangano, Kings County Sheriff, with three assistants, brought back to Brooklyn City prison from Sing Sing yesterday five Brooklyn men who had been convicted of murders, but who recently won new trials from the Court of Appeals.

"Crazy With the Heat," a musical revue which had its origin on the Summer theatre circuit, opens this evening at the Forty-fourth Street as the initial offering of Kurt Kasznar, who directed the entire production. Willie Howard, appearing without his brother, Eugene, and Luella Gear top the cast, which also includes Gracie Barrie, Richard Kollmar, Luba Rostova and Carl Randall, Marie Nash, Betty Kean and Don Cummings.

Basketball's leading exponent of the offense, bluff and hearty Frank Keaney of Rhode Island State, cleared up some of the mystery behind those three-figure scores his teams frequently roll up when he spoke before local coaches and writers assembled for a luncheon at the Hotel Piccadilly yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13 -- Passengers of the grounded liner Manhattan were spending the night ashore after watching hours of efforts to free the vessel from Florida beach sand on which she had pounded since last evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A broad construction of the espionage laws which authorities say will make far easier the task of prosecuting foreign spies was announced in a unanimous opinion of the Supreme Court today. The court rejected contentions that the Espionage Act of 1917 was too vague and indefinite to be constitutional and that convictions of two men under the statute were impossible because they had not violated specific language of the law.

ROME, Jan. 13 -- Another change of Italian commanders in Albania was made today when General Ubaldo Soddu, "for reasons of health," was removed and the command taken over by General Ugo Cavallero, Chief of the General Staff. General Cavallero, who succeeded Marshal Pietro Badoglio on Dec. 6, retains his post on the General Staff.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 8, aggregated $10,701,000,000.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Decentralization and high taxes are only partly responsible for decreased metropolitan real estate values, William B. Baker, Boston real estate man, said today.

The annual campaign of the National Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday was launched yesterday in New York and the rest of the nation for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The total number of volunteer collectors was estimated at 50,000.

Among the new group exhibitions that opened yesterday are recent oils by American artists at the Kraushaar, 730 Fifth Avenue, and American water-colors at the Milch, 108 West Fifty-seventh Street. The former offering is to remain current until Jan. 25, the latter until Feb. 8.

The President, in his report to Congress, has made a startling proposal. He desires Congress to empower him, in general terms, to "lend" billions of the earnings and substance of our people to the peoples of other lands as he, not Congress, shall determine.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, Before Tobruk, Jan. 13 (UP) -- The shelling of besieged Tobruk was stepped up today by the addition of still more British guns, many of them dragged across the desert from Bardia by captured Italian trucks. An infantry assault on Tobruk was not expected for several days, however.

Prudent financial administration of national defense and a sound national economy to back up the effort were advocated by speakers at the opening session of the thirtieth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Eventual curtailment of production of consumer goods was forecast.

A significant shift in production of $1 dresses to the Northeast, particularly New England, was reported yesterday by Erwin Feldman, director of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, at the annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (UP) -- A newspaper campaign urging that Great Britain take over needed naval bases in Ireland [Eire] got under way today following disclosure of an alleged German plot to violate Irish neutrality.

Today, the seventieth anniversary of the birth of the late Felix M. Warburg, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will receive 228 of the most valuable prints and two books of prints from his famous collection. The gift, according to William M. Ivins Jr., curator of prints at the Metropolitan, is the most important the department has ever received.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that immigration agents had served a deportation warrant on Princess Stephanie Hohenlohe-Waldenburg Schillingsfurst in Palo Alto, Calif.

The American people are now fully aware that our foreign policy is definitely against aggression and oppression in any part of the world. In this connection there is no difference of opinion among the major political parties. Naturally our next step must be adequate defense -- including full aid to all nations forced to defend themselves from unlawful attacks.

Orders received by the General Electric Company in 1940 increased 81 per cent over the preceding year, aggregating $654,190,000, against $360,748,000 in 1939, Charles E. Wilson, president of the company, disclosed yesterday.

American sentiment for greater aid to Britain is so strong, and the Democratic party majorities in the House and Senate are so large, that if President Roosevelt stands firm he can probably win most of the powers sought in his new bill, over all Republican opposition in Congress and over the strong protest of such Republican leaders as Mr. Hoover, Governor Landon and Mr. Dewey.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13 -- Sir Norman Angell, writer, Nobel Prize winner and for years a Labor member of Parliament, was honor guest at a dinner given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Glasgow, whom he is visiting. In the afternon he addressed the members of the Palm Beach Round Table at their initial meeting of the season at the Everglades Club.

A tentative budget asking $10,924,758 for the four city colleges, two high schools, an elementary school and administrative offices under the Board of Higher Education for the year 1941-42 was made public last night by the finance committee of the board as an open hearing was held on the requests at Hunter College.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 13 -- Efforts in which it is understood that the United States Minister, C.E. Gauss, and R.G. Casey, Australian Minister to the United States, are greatly interested, are being made to induce the Commonwealth Government to establish a direct radio service between the United States and Australia.

ROME, Jan. 13. -- William Phillips, the United States Ambassador to Italy, will be in Rome on Wednesday to begin one of the most important missions in the American diplomatic service. He arrived at Genoa yesterday morning and today drove to Turin and Milan.

New court decisions may place all retailing within the scope of the National Labor Relations Act, Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Secretaries, being held concurrently with the gathering of the N.R.D.G.A. at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Three thousand American-born women who lost their citizenship through marriage to aliens prior to Sept. 22, 1922, have just filed applications for repatriation, it was reported yesterday. The applications, all of which involve residents of the Federal Southern District of New York, were revealed in a report by George J.H. Follmer, clerk of the Federal Court here.

Net earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company for 1940 amounted to $700,700, exclusive of profits on the sales of securities and recoveries charged off to loans, according to the report of George V. McLaughlin, president, at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Secretary Morgenthau, in announcing today that the British Treasury was "ready to do business" with American investment trusts, two groups of which were offering to negotiate, said that any other groups interested in the purchase also were welcome.

Establishment of a record for a trip between New York and San Francisco last Spring by Raymond (Slug) Bryan of Belleville, N.J., was one of the highlights of amateur cycling in 1940, according to data released yesterday by the Amateur Bicycle League of America.

Among the organizations reported yesterday by brokers as having taken new commercial quarters was the Opinion Research Corporation, conductor of public opinion surveys, which leased space on the twelfth floor of the Eastern Air Lines Building at Rockefeller Center.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 -- Today's Boerse was narrow and irregular in limits of less than 2 per cent for the entire session. Salzdetfurth lost 3 points and Wintershall, 3, while Braubank gained 3 and Dortmunder Brewery, 3. Fixed-interest securities, led by Reich Treasury bonds, were firm, but the demand could not be satisfied. Call money was quoted at 11-1% per cent.
The struggle between Verne Marshall, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, and Orland K. Armstrong, original promoter of the committee, has been going on for some weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The first definite move toward modifying the far-reaching grant of executive powers in President Roosevelt's Lend-Lease Allied-Aid Bill came today from friends of "all out" assistance to Great Britain and any other nations which may become objects of totalitarian aggression.

"The Philadelphia Story" will become the fifth film to play more than three weeks at the Radio City Music Hall when it enters its fourth week on Thursday. The comedy was seen by 434,396 persons during the first eighteen days of its engagement, breaking the records of the theatre for the last five years.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Four new members were added to the Assembly Rules Committee and five to the Ways and Means Committee in the list of assignments handed down by Speaker Heck tonight. Senate committees will not be made public until later this week.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- British air sources said today the Royal Air Force was winning a "slight edge" in the aerial conflict which they expected would decide the success or failure of any German invasion attempt.

A younger brother of William Faulkner, John, also of Oxford, Miss., has written a novel that Harcourt, Brace will publish this Spring as "Men Working." It deals with the Southern farmers who go to town to work on what they call the "WP and A."
Baseball activity yesterday was considerably varied atlhough not exactly earth-shaking.
Little direct news has been heard of General Soddu since he went to Albania, but his retirement recalled a series of resignations early in December after the Greek campaign had gone badly for weeks.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Jan. 13 -- Russo-German relations are steadily worsening and concentrations of German forces and those of the Red Army have been vastly increased on Russo-German frontiers within recent weeks, according to information disclosed by a high Slovene political figure who returned to Slovenia today after six months in Germany.

Delay in arrival of government checks in payment for defense equipment is causing some difficulty among small manufacturers in this area, an unofficial survey disclosed yesterday. Larger concerns, however, report government pay arriving on time despite hasty organization in Washington for the defense program.

A belief in advertising and "plenty of it" by Representative Jerry Voorhis of California, despite his sponsorship of a bill in the last Congress to tax advertising, was revealed yesterday in a report to the Advertising Federation of America by Charles E. Murphy, its counsel, based on a conference with the Congressman.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13 -- The great activity shown in recent months by agents of warring totalitarian powers in buying Mexican "war metals" such as mercury, tungsten, molybdenum and vanadium has caused the United States Government to investigate the possibility of killing this traffic at the source by obtaining the whole Mexican output for itself.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 13 (AP) -- In a ceremony lasting less than a minute Dwight H. Green of Chicago took the oath of office today as Governor of Illinois.

In the presence of Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday morning contracts were signed for the first county fair to be held in New York since 1897. To be conducted by the American Institute of the City of New York, the fair will be presented next Sept. 10 to 20 in Madison Square Garden.

Newburger, Loeb Co. announced yesterday that S. Frank Barager and John Ralph Watson, formerly customers' brokers of Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt, were now with their main office at 40 Wall Street.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 13 (AP) -- A plan to utilize every available manufacturing facility in the nation was outlined at a meeting of Central New York bankers and industrialists today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 14 -- Forty hours after Saturday's heavy raid London, yesterday afternoon, was still frantically digging out its dead from shelters crushed by high explosives, from buildings that had collapsed, flaming, and even from the streets themselves under which men, women and children had sought refuge.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- President Roosevelt today indirectly thanked Wendell Willkie for supporting the Administration bill to grant "blank check" powers to the Chief Executive to aid Great Britain and her allies. He made known, however, that he would not make a formal statement about the support of "any one individual."

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Robert Sherwood, playwright and author, who was recently appointed a member of the National Advisory Committee on Education, Recreation and Community Service for the United States Army, visited Fort Dix today. He was accompanied by Lieut. Col. Frank E. Bridgetts, Second Corps Area morale officer.

Murder and light comedy have apparently made a happy marriage on Broadway. The new plays just teem with corpses and shrieks of laughter. It is not maniacal laughter, emanating from homicidal operators on the stage.

In a recent column we discussed a day spent at Uncle Dan's place, comparing the accuracy of an old Kentucky rifle with that of a few modern rifles. The result was a flood of mail from shooters who wanted to know where they could buy one of these old guns in good condition.

N.J. Cladakis, milk market administrator here, announced yesterday that 60,193 farmers who supplied milk to the New York metropolitan area last month would divide a total of $8,223,677 for milk marketed through the administrator's pool, or $600,000 more than they received for November milk.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 -- Blinding sand storms, whipped up by a bitter cold gale, swept across Northern Africa yesterday, immobilizing the air forces of both Britain and Italy and putting a damper on army activities as well.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 13 -- In a tranquil ceremony sharply contrasting with the political manoeuvring of a few hours before, Governor Matthew M. Neely pledged himself today to advance industry, labor and education in the State to which he returned after twenty-five years in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The British Government is prepared to talk business with American investment trusts which are considering the organization of a syndicate to take over British direct investments in the United States, it was revealed by Secretary Morgenthau today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 14 -- Over the Alps, on the Danube, across the North Sea and into Norwegian waters and along the Channel coast of France, now occupied by the Germans, the British Royal Air Force carried out widespread successful raids over Sunday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 -- A Justice Department deportation warrant was served late today on Princess Stephanie Hohenlohe-Waldenburg Schillingsfurst in a Palo Alto apartment, which was rented under the name of "M.J. Hunter" on Dec. 20.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- The big Spring and Summer catalogue sent out to mail-order customers today by Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co. unexpectedly show reductions on a long list of items at a time when commodity prices and labor costs are advancing.

Officials of sixteen local housing authorities sold yesterday short-term notes amounting to $58,187,000. Of the total, a banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and including the Chase National Bank, the National City Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company, the Bankers Trust Company and the Manufacturers Trust Company bought $51,317,000.

For the first time since 1926, the American Iron and Steel Institute this week has included steel produced in crucible and electric furnaces and steel for castings in the data garnered in order to determine what the operating rate will be.

An indication of the importance attached to all-round skiing in this country was given yesterday by Roger Langley, president of the National Ski Association, when he announced that the dates of the national downhill and slalom championships, which had conflicted with the title jump, had been changed.

On the basis of last night's returns, the Bach Circle of New York ought to change its name to the Handel Circle. The one Bach composition on the program was done indifferently, if not worse, whereas two Handel scores were agreeably played.

Gathered to mark the seventeenth anniversary of the death of Lenin, 20,000 Communists and sympathizers made Madison Square Garden ring last night with denunciation of President Roosevelt's projected expansion of aid to Britain.

That hairlines and hatlines are topics that cannot be divorced, at least for the duration of the Spring and Summer, became self-evident at two showings held yesterday afternoon -- at Jay Thorpe's millinery department, and at the establishment of Madame Pauline, 6 East Fifty-third Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- The Army Quartermaster today awarded contracts for 1,118,600 khaki cotton (percale) shirts, out of 1,500,000 asked for on Jan. 2 under negotiated contract in formal bidding. Contractors are to furnish material as well as workmanship.
ROME, Jan. 13 -- Today's war bulletin tells of an attack by an Italian torpedo plane against "a large enemy unit in the Western Mediterranean" which is stated to have been torpedoed.

Sam Cochran of the Englewood Field Club, seeded sixth, was upset by B.H. Whitbeck of the Bronxville Field Club in a second-round match of the seventh annual New York State squash racquets singles championship at the Downtown Athletic Club last night.

After several days of activity the cotton market reverted yesterday to the comparative slowness which had characterized trading in previous weeks. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices ended 4 to 9 points lower than on Saturday.
The Presbytery of New York pledged itself to raise $50,000 within four months as its share of the $625,000 Presbyterian United World Emergency Fund.

The State of California awarded yesterday to Kaiser Co. a total of $5,244,709 of registered warrants at 0.75 per cent, plus a premium of $3,535. The financing consisted of $2,463,634 of general fund registered warrants and $2,781,075 of unemployment relief registered warrants, both to be payable on or about Oct. 29.

MONTREAL, Jan. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Back in action after a week's lay-off, Bill Cowley of the Boston Bruins picked up three assists during last week's National Hockey League competition and retained his leadership in the league scoring race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Kansas City Stockyards case in which Chief Justice Hughes two years ago criticized Henry A. Wallace for failure to give a "full and fair hearing," found its way back to the Supreme Court calendar today.

The Real Estate Board of New York yesterday accused Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler of a number of inaccuracies in his statement of Sunday concerning the review of property assessments, declaring that the "solution of public problems is rendered increasingly difficult when a high-ranking city official descends to such an expedient as a deliberate attempt to hoodwink the people."

Youth had its say last night in Carnegie Hall at the second concert of the Monday evening series of the National Orchestral Association. Not only were the 123 instrumentalists of the orchestra young, but the music was young, too. It included a new overture by Richard Arnell, 23-year-old British composer; "Psalm," for Orchestra, by David Diamond, 25-year-old American composer, and Prokofieff's music for a ballet based on "Romeo and Juliet."

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- Although better weather prevailed in Northern Libya today, little change occurred in the Tobruk area, where the British continued to bombard the Italian port. The British activity remains much as it was before the assault on Bardia and although, as at Bardia, the attack is likely to come suddenly, no signs of imminent action are yet apparent.
"Mrs. Typical Customer of 1941," in the person of blonde Mrs. Bernard J. Thill, 36-year-old mother of three children, of La Crosse, Wis., saw this metropolis for the first time yesterday.

"Certainly, this is an unexpected development of Christian art," is the dry comment of the Osservatore Romano on a model for a combined air raid shelter and church exhibited at the Vatican. Unexpected but not unknown, for the hills around Rome are mined with subterranean chambers and passages wherein the first Christians sought refuge from the totalitarian persecutors of their day.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 14 -- De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry, head football coach at Brown for fifteen years, accepted a similar berth today with Dartmouth.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Governor A. Harry Moore was chosen general counsel to the Bergen Trust Company here at the annual meeting of stockholders today. The Governor, who has a law office at 921 Bergen Avenue, was named shortly after he had made his farewell to the New Jersey Legislature this morning, preliminary to expiration of his third term as chief executive on Jan. 21, when Governor-elect Charles Edison will assume office.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Building owners and managers are urged to seek additional police protection when they feel that the activities or records of their tenants might prove attractive to fifth column agents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- William S. Knudsen, Director of the Office of Production Management, will lay the problem of State participation in the defense program directly before thirty or more Governors who will attend the inauguration of President Roosevelt on Monday.

An underwriting group headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation will offer today to the public $28,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, series C, of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation. The bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1961, will be priced at 100 and accrued interest.

The Federal Government's program for aiding vocational training, to provide millions of additional skilled workmen for defense industries, is sure to break the backbone of unemployment in this country, Layton S. Hawkins, chief of the Trade and Industrial Educational Service of the United States Office of Education, and Colonel Frank J. McSherry of the Army forecast yesterday.

The use of "psychology" in designing passenger buses to discourage "hitch riding" by children was advocated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address before ninety city officials, bus line operators, manufacturers and editors of trade publications at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.
Some of the sailfish that have been making life exciting for the anglers off Stuart, Fla., have moved south and are now giving the Palm Beach boys a taste of fast and furious fishing.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A new criminal syndicalism and anti-sabotage law was asked today by Senator Edward J. Coughlin, Brooklyn Democrat.

When men start shopping for their Spring wardrobes, New York stores will greet them with an array of new suiting and haberdashery shades, it was revealed yesterday at the Spring style and merchandising clinic of the Retail Men's Wear Council of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

In January, 1841, when Mr. Lincoln was serving his last term in the Legislature, No. 1 of The Union Agriculturist and Western Prairie Farmer appeared in Chicago. In January, 1843, the name was changed to Prairie Farmer. In a centennial edition this fruitful and prosperous century of life has found in Mr. Lloyd Lewis, dramatic critic, biographer, historian, an admirable recorder.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Two former champions, Tiff Denton of Kansas City and Art Thurnblad of Kenosha, Wis., and a two-time runner-up, Allen Hall of Chicago, made victorious debuts today in the three-cushion billiard tournament for the world championship.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 14 -- The French steamship Mendoza is anchored off Punta del Este tonight with the British auxiliary cruiser Asturias standing guard on the horizon while Uruguay is preparing to protest to London, charging that detention of the Mendoza Monday was a violation of Uruguayan sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The National Defense program can be financed without increasing the public debt and without imposing an unbearable tax burden if the national income can be increased to an annual average of $85,000,000,000 over the next three years, the Brookings Institution asserted today.

An undermanned group of Detroit Red Wings gave the New York Rangers as much as they could handle in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Starting with only twelve players and seeing their active forces reduced to ten before matters came to an end, the Detroit athletes nevertheless held the Stanley Cup champions to a 3-to-3 overtime deadlock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave at the White House today the first "home party" of the 1941 "fight infantile paralysis" campaign and tonight was the honor guest at a dinner given at the Carlton Hotel by the National Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday.

Bombs crash on Bengazi as the British advance in Libya. But for the Italians the most ominous sound in the Dark Continent may be the throb of the war drums across Ethiopia. They are heard now from Galla to the Harar Hills and even in the forts of Addis Ababa.

I read with interest the letter addressed to you by Clarke G. Dailey, which he starts by stating, "There seems to be misapprehension regarding the master plan which is now being considered by the City Planning Commission."

TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- "Jumping the gun," so to speak, on Governorelect Charles Edison, Democrat, who had said he would make similar proposals in his inaugural address next Tuesday, Senator Robert C. Hendrickson, Gloucester County Republican, whom Mr. Edison defeated in the Gubernatorial election, introduced today at the opening session of the 1941 Legislature bills for a constitutional convention and to give the executive power to investigate any State department.

One way in which the nation's retailers are supporting the national defense program is by easing the financial burdens of individuals called for military service, the National Retail Dry Goods Association was informed yesterday at its thirtieth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 -- No intimation was given out in Athens today concerning the fighting in Albania except that Italians retreating in several sectors turned to give battle. They were said to have fought furiously, but in each case were thrown back.

Private vehicles standing idle and unoccupied at the curb, particularly in "loading zone" areas reserved for trucks, not only violate police regulations, but are a direct cause of double parking of vans and the resulting traffic "bottlenecks" in crosstown streets, a survey showed yesterday.

Henry Armstrong, former world welterweight champion, who is to battle Fritzie Zivic of Pittsburgh, his conqueror, for the title Friday night in Madison Square Garden, yesterday survived perhaps the most searching medical examination he has ever undergone. Zivic also came through with flying colors.

The Haarlem Philharmonic Society of the City of New York will round out fifty years this week, and to mark the occasion will give one of its most important concerts. The program will be given tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria when the organization, now numbering 800 members, will hold its golden anniversary breakfast.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14 -- The new combination of the Calumet Farm and Wendell Eads did well at Hialeah Park today when the Blenheim II filly, Proud One, fought things out with such tenacity that she won by half a length at the end of a hard-run seven furlongs. Only yesterday Eads, the leading rider at Tropical Park and the top apprentice here, signed as Calumet's contract rider.

QUENTIN REYNOLDS played football for Brown. In New York he covered sports until he was sent to Berlin by the International News Service. There he wrote about the Nazis with such striking candor that they deported him. Presently he joined the staff of Collier's, and it is as their London correspondent that he has been gathering the material for this book.*
Information filed by leading industrial corporations with the Securities and Exchange Commission, as made public yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange, included the following new developments:

Flame from a kerosene burner licked up the side of a bucket of paint in a Brooklyn box factory shortly before noon yesterday, set the contents blazing and grew to a four-alarm fire that killed six men, injured ten, of whom four more may die, and left the plant a smoking shell.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 14 -- Residents of communities from Roslyn to Oyster Bay, who have been agitating for many years for electrification of the Oyster Bay branch of the Long Island Railroad, were disappointed again today when George LeBoutillier, vice president of the railroad, issued a statement saying that it had been found "unwise" to electrify the branch "at this time."

Ashes of roses, clear smoky gray, and shallow sea-green were among the soft colors featured for warm seasons by Jonai at a presentation of resort fashions at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel yesterday. Complementing the modest tone of evening shades was the subtle intricacy of draped line that appeared throughout the show.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday that it had declared effective a plan for the exchange of its holdings of common stock of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company for notes and debentures of Standard Gas and Electric.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- On the eve of the return to Rome of the United States Ambassador, William C. Phillips, one influential commentator announces that the Ambassador was not asked to come back and that he is wasting his time if he tries to separate Italy from Germany.

THE HAGUE, German-Occupied Netherlands, Jan. 14 (UP) -- German authorities have begun reprisals, "personal, financial or directed against businesses," for hostile acts against the army of occupation or any Nazi officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Representatives of three more New York investment trusts conferred with Secretary Morgenthau today on the matter of acquiring British-owned securities in American companies, which would provide the British Government with more dollar exchange for purchase of war needs.

In the forthcoming debate in Congress over the President's "lend-lease" bill to aid Britain there is bound to be discussion about Britain's capacity to continue, at least in part, the cash payment for purchases of war materials in this country.

A sharp upswing in the consumer demand for many types of musical instruments ranging from pianos to band instruments, coupled with a marked shortage of many imported items because of the war, was reported yesterday at the mid-year meeting of the executive committee of the National Association of Music Merchants at the Hotel New Yorker.

So eager to explore this strange new metropolis that they could not resist popping outside for quick peeks at the city, and so nearly congealed in the low temperature prevailing that they crept back all but congealed to the heat and comfort of the lounge, seventy-nine professors and students from South America arrived in New York yesterday on the Santa Lucia of the Grace lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A six-day week is essential now in defense industries and would increase production by as muck as 15 per cent, Glenn L. Martin of Baltimore, airplane manufacturer, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

"Second Chorus," starring Fred Astaire and Paulette Goddard, is the new screen attraction today at the Paramount. The comedy, which was produced by Boris Morros for Paramount release, also includes Burgess Meredith, Charles Butter-worth and Artie Shaw and his band in its cast. . . .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- With the Voorhis act requiring the registration of foreign-controlled organizations effective tomorrow, Attorney General Jackson today made public a list of 225 questions covering activities of the associations affected.

Whirlaway, Warren Wright's leading money-winning juvenile in 1940, received top weight in the Experimental Handicap of John B. Campbell, veteran secretary of metropolitan race tracks. In his annual tabulation, appearing yesterday in The Racing Calendar, official publication of the Jockey Club, Mr. Campbell alloted 126 pounds to the Calumet Farm racer.

MANILA, Jan. 14 -- A national welcome of unprecedented proportion was organized to greet Speaker of the Assembly Jose Yulo, who is being groomed to succeed President Manuel L. Quezon, upon his arrival this morning aboard the steamship President Taft.

George E. Roberts retired yesterday as editor of the monthly business review of the National City Bank of New York at the age of 83, after serving twenty-five years as editor of the publication, which is published in English and Spanish and has a circulation of more than 100,000.
A revised Manhattan basketball team beat Rider College last night by 49 -- 39 in the Manhattan gymnasium to record its seventh victory in nine starts.

The number of new cases of influenza reported in New York City continues the steady rise of the last few weeks but so far has not reached epidemic proportions, according to data submitted yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Responsible officers in the Army's Finance Department expressed doubt that there could be many cases of delay in payment for Army contracts, as reported by some small manufacturers in THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

Numbering among its twenty-one passengers the three New York City firemen who flew to London in October to study fire-fighting under war conditions, three officials of the Department of State who were recalled from the Paris Embassy by request of the German Government, and Ben Smith, Wall Street financier, who recently has spent much time in France and England, the Atlantic Clipper landed at the marine terminal of La Guardia Field at 10:28 A.M. yesterday.

Although there are women bank directors in various parts of the country and there is a woman bank president, Mrs. Mary G. Roebling, in Trenton, N.J., New York City was believed to have witnessed yesterday its first such invasion of the banking field.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Confidence that France is becoming friendlier toward Britain and might soon be counted on for support in the battle against Germany was voiced by Alfred Duff Cooper, Minister of Information, in a broadcast tonight.

Word has been circulating in Wall Street that the New York Stock Exchange is seriously concerned over the prevalence of off-the-market operations. Two more large blocks of stock were marketed in that manner yesterday, with complete success.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 14 -- The adherence of President Manuel Avila Camacho's government to continental solidarity in the event that war should reach this hemisphere was reiterated by Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla at a press conference this evening.

The Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries in a statement issued yesterday for the six months ended on Nov. 30, 1940, reported a net profit of $3,585,015 after charges for interest, depreciation, Federal income and excess-profits taxes and other deductions.
With one exception, the seeded players in the thirteenth annual Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament who saw action yesterday on the Yale Club courts reached the third round.

There was more than a perfunctory expression of good-will in Governor Lehman's reminder to the Legislature yesterday "that in these dark days there is more than ever the need for friendliness and unity of purpose, completely divorced from personal or partisan considerations."

With the formal casting of a single ballot, Henry W. Ryan was elected the thirty-first president of the New York Athletic Club at the annual meeting last night. His entire slate moved into office with him. All selections were made by the nominating committee on Dec. 16.

The Anti-Trust Division of the Justice Department is in favor of the future overproduction that is now a source of concern to many of the defense industries, and the division also is interested in "seeing that the mean chiseler gets into the picture" in industries where most producers are worried over the chiseler's propensity for cutting prices, according to Thurman W. Arnold, chief of the division.

Wendell L. Willkie received yesterday a telegram from Representative Hamilton Fish inviting him to testify before the Foreign Relations Committee of the House on the Administration's Aid-to-Britain Bill. He replied at once that he would be glad to appear if the committee wanted him, but could not fix a definite date until he had completed his arrangements for his projected trip to England.

Supplies yesterday of all classes of fresh meats were moderate to normal, with pork cutting relatively light. Demand for traefer meats was fair to good at steady to strong prices. Kosher beef opened about steady. Veal was steady at Monday's decline of around $1. Lamb was barely steady.

"At the first sign of a cold -- go to bed and stay there." This excellent advice, so difficult to follow and remain friends with employer and wife, comes direct from the United States Public Health Service, so the citizen can do naught but obey. The first sign of a cold is ordinarily no more ominous than a slight tickle of the throat, which used to be tackled hopefully with a lozenge.
The cotton market met yesterday a large volume of hedge selling and Southern liquidation and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed at the day's low level, off 7 to 9 points.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The growing importance of United States aid to Britain was reflected today when the British announced the establishment of a British Supply Council in North America, which will not only direct the work of the British Purchasing Commission but will "deal with all issues of policy concerning supply, including representations to be made to the United States Administration."

Antoine de St. Exupery, who was flying daily reconnaissance over the German lines a year ago when the award was first announced, caught up with time yesterday and received the National Book Award for the best non-fiction work of 1939 at the book and author luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Although Katharine Cornell has been unable to find a new play to her liking thus far, she will not be idle during the remainder of the season. This confirms a promise made by her staff that she would become active as soon as her husband, Guthrie McClintic, was done with the production, "

LONDON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- The fourday delay in today's Admiralty commun:qu6 announcing last week's Mediterranean air and naval battle indicated that the Illustrious and the Southampton as well as the Gallant had reached port for re
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Some profit-taking occurred in today's stock markets and made conditions irregular. Nevertheless, the volume of business was satisfactory.

May I request the publishing of a correction of a statement in your issue of Jan. 12 concerning the arrival in New York on Monday of a contingent of eighty-one students and professors from South America en route to the University of North Carolina for a six weeks' course in American civilization and culture.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The crew of a British motor boat, directed by patrolling aircraft, has snatched the Italian Blackshirt General Francesco Argentino from a hiding place by "the water's edge" in North Africa near Tobruk, Libya, British Middle East headquarters announced today.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Dr. Federico Pinedo, Argentine Minister of Finance, resigned tonight.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- The British have been sending heavy reinforcements into Greece, Virginio Gayda declared today in an article that contends the Greeks are exhausted and in a perilous situation. Part of the convoy that came through the Mediterranean last week and was so heavily attacked in the Sicilian channel went straight to Greece, Signor Gayda asserts.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- German aircraft, teamed up with the Italians, succeeded in damaging three British warships in the week ended yesday, the British acknowledged today. The damaged ships, which were part of British units covering the passage of convoys, are the Illustrious, one of the new aircraft carriers, the cruiser Southampton and the destroyer Gallant.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Greek in fantrymen were reported driving toward Berat, in South Central Albania, today while communiques told of a trading of blows by the British Royal Air Force and Italian bombers on targets in Albania and Greece.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 (AP) -- British Royal Air Force headquarters at Cairo today issued this communique:

Bronze statues of Alexander Hamilton and De Witt Clinton, slightly over lifesize, were unveiled late yesterday afternoon in white marble niches of the facades of the two wings of the Museum of the City of New York, facing Fifth Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets.

Warning against partisanship or unnecessary delay, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, urged yesterday that President Roosevelt's "lend-lease" program for aid to Great Britain receive "overwhelming support in Congress and throughout the country."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14 -- Paul Brown, who was too small to play with the Ohio State University's freshman football team thirteen years ago, today became the biggest gridiron figure on the Buckeye campus.

The new Brooklyn branch of Bundles for Britain, Inc., was formally opened yesterday morning by Borough President John Cashmore when he cut a strip of tape across the entrance to the gayly decorated store at 216 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Plans for a home-defense program in which every citizen can take part were made today by President Roosevelt at a conference with two Cabinet members and other government officials.

Several hundred German-Jewish refugees who obtained immigration visas for Central _,neriean and other Carribbean countries before they left Germany and German-dominated lands, may have to be returned to Europe, it was reported here yesterday by Mrs. Elsa Jaffe, l a refugee from Berlin, who has been traveling from Germany since Sept. 29.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- British merchant shipping losses for the first week of the new year were four vessels displacing a total of 14,687 tons, the Admiralty announced today. This is the fifth lowest aggregate for lost tonnage in any seven-day period since the war began and the lowest since May 5. There were no sinkings of Allied or neutral ships.

Erica Morini, Viennese violinist who has become a familiar figure on local concert stages since she made her debut here twenty years ago as a girl prodigy, gave a recital last night at the Town Hall. The spontaneous burst of applause that greeted her first appearance proved that her playing has won her warm admirers.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- Japan's relations with the United States following the conclusion of the Japan-Axis alliance received first place in Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye's address to eighty leading members of the House of Representatives this afternoon.

Harold W. McGraw, vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company and president of the Times Square Terminal, Inc., was re-elected president of the West Side Association of Commerce at the meeting of the board of directors of that organization yesterday.

Gifts totaling $121,000, the largest amount since 1928, were received by the New York Zoological Society last year, its president, Fairfield Osborn, announced last night at that organization's annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria. Two thousand persons attended the meeting, a feature of which was the showing of motion pictures of wild life recently made by experts on the society's staff.
BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- German political quarters said today that the great French Maginot Line, constructed at an estimated cost of $500,000,000, is being torn down.

HANOVER, N.H, Jan. 14 -- Tuss McLaughry of Brown slipped unobtrusively into Hanover today for a visit with his old friend, Earl Blaik, but by mid-afternoon Tuss was the focal point of a hundred curious eyes as he stood in the center of the basketball court.

A former Palitzer Prize winner in journalism, back in the days when he was a Chicago police reporter and covered the Leopold-Loeb case, was acclaimed by the motor-boat world last night at Grand Central Palace as the "individual who during 1940 made the most valuable contribution to the sport."

The recent assertion by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh that America must build bulwarks against "the inroads of the Mongol, Persian and Moor" and must preserve the purity of the "white race's culture" was challenged as racial theory fraught with danger to American culture at the annual dinner of the American Institute for Iranian Art and Archaeology, at the Hotel Plaza last night.
ROME, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 -Tommy Goodwin, medalist of the thirty-fourth annual Lake Worth golf championship, continued his fine golf today to defeat Hugh L. Willoughby Jr., Port Sewell, Fla., 9 and 8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A bill to break up bank holding companies was introduced today by Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, with the explanation that he did so at the request of the Department of the Treasury and with reservations on his own part.
ISTANUL, Turkey, Jan. 14 -- Sharp criticism of the United States was voiced by the newspaper Tasviri Efkar in its editorial today headed "They Talk a Lot and Do Very Little."

RIOM, France, Jan. 14 -- Although there are no outward signs of unwonted activity in this sleepy provincial town, it is learned from Vichy that the sittings of the Supreme Court here may open soon. This is the court created to try men indicted for such offenses as responsibility for the war and its disastrous prosecution.

Walter E. Frew, chairman of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting held in the offices of the bank, that a somewhat better demand for loans is anticipated for the coming year as a result of the huge spending program in connection with the national defense effort.

The estate of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl Stoeckel in Norfolk, Conn., which was for many years the home of the annual Norfolk Music Festival, is going to be converted into a Summer music school. It will be called the Norfolk Music School of Yale University, for Mrs. Stoeckel's will stipulated that it should be administered by the School of Music of Yale University.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature today:

BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- The United States Golf Association during 1940 made marked progress in a campaign intended to make golf a game in which skill and not special equipment will be the deciding factor in tournament competition.

VICHY, France, Jan. 14 (UP) -- French Government propagandists tonight fired at Britain their harshest criticism since the Dakar incident and the naval battle at Mers el-Kebir, shattering any hope that the breach between the former allies might be narrowing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Thomas H. Beacon Jr., Austin Jenner and Horace O. Wetmore, former assistant vice presidents, were elected today vice presidents of the First National Bank of Chicago. Raymond H. Becker, assistant cashier, was appointed assistant vice president and P.L. Stevenson and A.S. Thorwaldson were chosen as trust officers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Wheat dipped in the early trading on selling induced by reports of rain in parts of the West and Southwest and easiness in securities, but the activity was mainly of a professional character and was confined largely to the new crop months.
The New York State Joint Legislative Committee for the study of the pari-mutuel betting system will conduct hearings on Jan. 31, it was announced yesterday by Assemblyman Norman F. Penny, chairman.

Peter Dawson, a Midwesterner, graduate of the University of Illinois, former airplane salesman, former utilities salesman and a "good shot with a gun," is the winner of the Dodd, Mead-Western Story Magazine prize of $2,000 for the best-written Western novel. His winning manuscript will be published Jan. 21 as "The Crimson Horseshoe."

Mrs. William F. Spalding of Apawamis won two hard matches to reach the quarter-final round of the sixth annual women's metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship as two rounds were completed on the courts of the Junior League yesterday.

Ever since last Summer "Crazy With the Heat" has been crazy with the heat somewhere or other: During the coldest spell of the Winter it turned up, chapped a little in important places, at the Forty-fourth Street last evening. Among other things, it demonstrates the advisability of staging musical shows with taste and originality.

Most of the Manhattan sales reported yesterday involved properties in the upper part of the city. In one deal, a blockfront taxpayer on Washington Heights was disposed of by a bank. The property, known as 1221-39 St. Nicholas Avenue and occupying the entire west front on that thoroughfare between 171st and 172d Streets was purchased by a client of Nehring Bros., Inc., from the Central Savings Bank.
Mike Kaplan, 146, Boston, out-pointed Tony Ferrara, 146 3/4, Mount Vernon, in the eight-round feature bout before 8,000 fans at the Bronx Coliseum last night.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Representatives of Great Britain's land, air and sea forces conferred at Ankara today with the Turkish General Staff.
The icy winds that churned the Atlantic Ocean on Monday subsided yesterday, but not until the coldest weather of the Winter had been experienced in most of the East from Maine to Florida.
Commercial leases reported yesterday included the rental of showroom and sales space to a distributor of boats and many contracts to millinery and clothing firms.

Three hundred and thirty selective service men were inducted into the Army and sent to camp yesterday, and the fact that one of them refused to take the oath of allegiance to the United States did not have off his entrance into the Army by so much as a minute.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 14 -- James F. Dewey, Federal labor mediator, told the Eaton Manufacturing Company and the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers that unless the strike which has closed the company's five plants was ended immediately he would "take drastic action."

An estate comprising five acres of land and a large residence at the corner of Fenimore and Brewster Roads, Scarsdale, Westchester County, was sold by the Orion H. Cheney estate to the Tisdale Road Corporation, which will subdivide the land and erect several new houses there.

One of the marked differences between the 1940 excess profits tax and the World War profits and excess profits taxes is that the latter were levied on "the same net income as determined for the purpose of the income tax," whereas the present tax is imposed on an adjusted normal-tax net income.

The National City Bank of New York is actively participating in the financing of the national defense program at all of its various stages, it was declared by Gordon S. Rentschler, chairman of the board of directors, in his remarks to stockholders at the 129th annual meeting here yesterday noon.

The advertising campaign for Ruud-Monel gas water heaters for the first half of 1941 will be double that of 1940 and will be the largest magazine campaign ever put behind an automatic gas water heater, officials of the Ruud Manufacturing Company announced yesterday at a sales meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Two quintets that long have borne reputations as being among the best in the Midwest, De Paul of Chicago and Bradley Tech of Peoria, will match their skill against the two of New York's high scoring fives in Madison Square Garden tonight.

Two bondsmen whose futile efforts to "fix" a case in Federal Court developed into a case that figured importantly in the clarification of the law against use of wiretapped evidence were convicted in the court yesterday. The defendants, George Polakoff and Willie Alberts, were found guilty of conspiracy to obstruct justice after the jury had deliberated for twenty minutes.

In his annual message to shareholders yesterday Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, emphasized the need for avoiding as far as possible the financing of the Government's defense needs out of commercial bank credit. This is sound advice. The problem is not one of ability to meet the demands.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 14 -- The long-expected shake-up in the government appeared imminent tonight following the departure of Vladimir Matchek, Croat leader, and Father Fran Kulovetz, Slovene leader, for Belgrade.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A wife-murder charge was made today against Professor Arthur Lloyd James, 56, said to be one of the greatest living experts on the English language and its pronunciation, for the unexplained fatal stabbing of the violin virtuoso who taught and played as Elsie Owen.

TALLADEGA NATIONAL FOREST, Ala., Jan. 14 -- Camp fires threw lurid shadows on big guns here tonight and in a deep fold of the earth at the base of the peak of Horse Block Mountain soldiers were singing "Oh, Sweet Mystery of Life."

Crude oil production in the United States averaged last week 3,364,450 barrels daily, a decrease of 2,750 from the 3,367,200 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 226,550 barrels less than the calculation of 3,591,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for January.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Roosevelt denounced today the phrase "plow under every fourth American boy," employed by some opponents of the Administration's lend-lease bill, as "rotten" and "dastardly."

John E. Means of the Pennsylvania Retailers Association was elected president of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the annual convention of the organization yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. He succeeds Lewis W. Newell of Salem, Mass., who received a gavel in recognition of his services during the past year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Among possible changes in the Lease-Lend Bill discussed in Administration quarters at the Capitol today were these:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 15 -- British aerial scouts from an unidentified warship joined the British auxiliary cruiser Asturias tonight on sentry patrol to forestall the French freighter Mendoza's efforts to run home through the British blockade with sorely needed food.

Two more seeded players, T.L. Golibart of the Downtown A.C., No. 7, and S.E. Davenport of the Harvard Club, No. 8, were eliminated in third-round matches, while four of the favored performers, led by Stanley Galowin of Long Beach, defending champion, advanced into the quarter-finals in the seventh annual New York State amateur squash racquets singles championship at the Downtown A.C. last night.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 14 -Lieut. Col. Thomas P. Henderson, who with some companions tried to capture the Kaiser soon after the World War, has been relieved of active duty at Fort Jackson because of failure to meet the physical requirements.

Little Gregory Rice of the South Bend A.A., the man who is short in height but long in his finishing sprint, yesterday accepted the bid of the Millrose A.A. to compete in the two-mile run at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 1, it was announced by Director Fred Schmertz.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Secretary Hull was scheduled today as the first witness to appear in behalf of President Roosevelt's Lease-Lend Bill for aid to the Allies when the House Foreign Affairs Committee begins consideration of the measure tomorrow.

Attacks upon the propriety of methods used by the Federal Trade Commission in obtaining evidence against retail liquor package store groups and upon the credibility of Barnett Warner, commission investigator, consumed most of the second day's hearing into commission charges that liquor retailers of the country have conspired to fix prices and eliminate competition.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market last week totaled 1,867 as against 1,199 in the preceding week and 2,052 in the Corresponding period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TAMES listings. Visiting buyers recorded yesterday were 917, which compared with 911 for a week ago.
May I take exception to the following statement in the editorial "What Is 'Loitering'?": "The police certainly should not have the power to pick up persons like Joseph Levy."

Seventeen contributions, aggregating $225, reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as belated donors sought to add their help to that previously made available by generous spirited readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Their receipt brought the total that has been given in response to this twenty-ninth annual appeal to $234,436.44.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 15 -- With bad flying weather persisting over the Strait of Dover and German air bases in occupied France, this country enjoyed complete immunity from Nazi bombers all day yesterday and early today. Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security officials, when asked about raids on Great Britain, said there was nothing to report.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Jean Renoir, who collaborated on the scenario of "La Grande Illusion" and directed the film in France, was signed to a term directorial contract today by Twentieth Century-Fox. Since "Grande Illusion," which was produced in 1937, Renoir has directed "The Human Beast," "The Dregs" and "The Marseillaise," all French pictures.

Many sections of the city shared in the residential leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday. Among the areas in which leases were taken were the east and west sides of the midtown section, the Washington Heights neighborhood and Greenwich Village.

An eclipse of fashion in London in favor of utilitarian goods; government steps to curb inflation and profiteering, and a retail boom in Canada have been the outstanding effects of the war upon retail distribution, English and Canadian store executives said yesterday at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Although British authorities anticipated a minimum of 30,000 casualties a month among England's civilian population, the figure has never totaled more than 12,000 a month during the intensified Nazi air raids, Dr. Philip D. Wilson, chief surgeon of the Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled, 307 East Forty-second Street, reported yesterday.

Mrs. Samuel Seabury, national president of the Garden Club of America, was the guest of honor of officers, directors and regional chairmen at a luncheon held yesterday at Carlton House, 22 East Forty-seventh Street.

Net earnings of the First National Bank of New York from loans and investments amounted to $12,921,625 in 1940, exclusive of profits from the sale of securities and miscellaneous earnings and credits, Leon Fraser, president, reported at the annual meeting of shareholders yesterday.
The American European Securities Company reported yesterday that net assets available to common shares on Dec. 31 last were $8.17 a share, against $9.57 at the end of 1939.

American Catholics who are still undecided whether this country should help Great Britain were told yesterday by Arnold Lunn, British author and former Professor of History at the University of Notre Dame, that they should be in no doubt about wanting to prevent Hitler from destroying Christian civilization.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Frank A. Sieberling, the 81-year-old rubber magnate, lost today his suit to recover $634,000 from Edgar B. Davis, Texas oil man, in a dispute over a $500,000 loan with which Davis "rescued" Mr. Seiberling in 1927.

MADRID, Spain, Jan. 14 -- British bombing attacks on the Ruhr have been so successful that Germany is now importing considerable quantities of iron ore from Bilbao and in addition is drawing heavily on Swedish ore, it was learned today.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, will open to the public at 1 o'clock this afternoon its annual exhibition of sculpture, water-colors, drawings and prints. This evening from 9 to 11 a private view and reception will be held in the galleries in which the work selected has been installed.

VICHY, France, Jan. 14 -- Transfer of the ownership of Jewish-owned businesses to non-Jews is being carried out in the occupied zone of France under German regulations, according to an article in the Petite Gironde of Bordeaux, which is now on sale in the free zone.

BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- The resettlement treaty signed four days ago by Germany and Russia providing for the repatriation of Germans in Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia will affect some 57,000 persons, it was stated here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Twenty-one manufacturers of chemicals and fertilizers having assets of more than $10,000,000 each had a combined volume of business of $984,000,000 in 1939, compared with $799,000,000 in 1938, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Glasgow were luncheon hosts today at their villa for Sir Norman Angell who tonight gave the second of two talks for members of the Palm Beach Round Table, of which Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden is president, at the Breakers.

Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler, commenting yesterday on the charges made by the Real Estate Board of New York that his statement on the work of review realty tax assessments was a "deliberate attempt to hoodwing the people," in turn took the Real Estate Board to task and claimed it was "willfully distorting the facts."

MONTCLAIR, N.J. Jan. 14 -- T. Philip Reitinger of Westfield, a former New York banker, was elected president of the Montclair Savings Bank at the annual meeting here tonight. He succeeds Stanley R. Soverel, dean of Montclair bank executives, who is retiring after forty-three years of service with local banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- Miss Margit Bokor, a Hungarian mezzo-soprano, stepped into her first role with the Metropolitan Opera Association tonight on scarcely twenty-four hours' notice, substituting for Rise Stevens as Octavian in the company's performance of Richard Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" before a capacity audience in the Academy of Music.

HASTINGS-ON HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Reports that the County Trust Company of White Plains would acquire a branch in this village were confirmed this afternoon when six officers of the County Trust were elected directors of the First National Bank of Hastings at a meeting of stockholders of the First National.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 14 -Tragedy was averted during a night tactical problem early this morning when an officer discovered "live" ammunition, such as is used by men on guard duty, among the blank cartridges being issued to troops of the Seventy-first Regiment. Guard ammunition is loaded with a lead pellet instead of the steel-jacketed bullet of service ammunition.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A bill which would make it a misdemeanor for relief recipients or applicants not to notify relief authorities of any change in their circumstances was introduced today in the Senate by Pliny W. Williamson of Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today branded the strike by the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers against the Eaton Manufacturing Company as "a deliberate attempt to sabotage the national defense program."

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 14 -- A depressed tendency ruled in all Dutch issues on today's Bourse and the turnover was exceedingly small. These issues closed to 4 points lower. Amsterdam Rubber declined 3 points to 277; .4nsterdam Trading, 3 to 447; Royal Dutch, 1. to 266'74. Philips Lamps, 2 to 207.; Unilever, 13, to 126.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Highlights of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature:
Verne Marshall, editor of The Cedar Rapids (Iowa) Gazette, "purged" his No Foreign War Committee yesterday and got it a first board of directors.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 15 (UP) -- War Minister Lieut. Gen. Eike Tojo is meeting this afternoon with thirteen senior military leaders in an effort to obtain their "full support for the Army's determination to break through the difficult international situation which confronts the empire," the newspaper Nichi Nichi said today.

PARIS, Jan. 12 (Delayed) (via Berlin) (AP) -- The "Aryanization" of Jewish-owned concerns in Paris is going forward rapidly, officials said today. All establishments are expected to be in the hands of non-Jewish owners soon. Of the 11,000 businesses about 5,000 are retail stores. These are receiving first attention.

Official Washington has apparently concluded that the devil can be fought with firmament up to a point, but after this he must be fought with fire. The basis of the assertion is to be found in the "garden hose" or lease-lend British-aid bill, and its predecessor, the exchange with the British of fifty overage destroyers for nine air and naval bases in the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The first of a series of confidential defense conferences between members of Congress and the War Department was attended by a group of Senators this morning, but this evening members of the House, invited to a similar conference to-row, flatly balked.

The six-room Swiss-Chalet-type dwelling on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 112-21 178th Street, St. Albans, L.I., was sold by the Guaranteed Title and Mortgage Company to Elmer Schoebel, music arranger for Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc. Fred C. Schmidt was the broker.

Another drab performance was witnessed yesterday on the Stock Exchange, where values were further reduced slightly. Fractional changes predominated throughout the list, with the declines far surpassing the gains. With dealings on the Exchange at 468,910 shares and approximating the total on Monday of 474,770 shares, there were few if any out-and-out factors in the day's news to account for the continued lack of trading interest.

New York State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., in an opinion issued yesterday, ruled that two small-loan plans now being operated by two New York banks are illegal. He said that these plans, known as the "certified credit check plan" and the "cash order bank check plan," charge interest ranging from 21 per cent to more than 100 per cent.

John J. McHugh, who retired as field secretary of the Public Schools Athletic League last June after thirty-seven years of service, was honored at a luncheon given by the games committee of the P.S.A.L. at the Hotel Astor yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Several proposals designed to assist in the development of better business in the State were advanced by Governor Lehman in a message to the Legislature today.

VICHY, France, Jan. 14 -- There still remain in the unoccupied zone of France approximately 150,000 Spanish refugees who for one reason or another cannot or do not wish to return to Spain. Most of these refugees are free to go where they like in occupied territory and have found work.

Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island has notified the diocese of his forthcoming retirement in a letter dated Monday and made public yesterday by Raymond F. Barnes of Brooklyn, treasurer of the diocese.
