Exuding that spirit of ruggedness commonly associated with those who prefer to spend this time of season battling the rigors of the frost-bitten North, Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees came down from Buffalo yesterday to pay his annual midwinter visit to New York, complimented the town on its snappy weather and then put in four vigorous hours of business.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14. -- In a manner that was considered so categorical as to indicate the near futility of continuing the conference much farther at this time, three of Canada's nine Provincial Premiers, meeting in conference with the Dominion Government here today, declared that they were opposed to the implementation of the Rowell-Sirois report on Dominion-Provincial relations.

Soccer football is to be played in Madison Square Garden. A tripleheader, involving New York City's four major booting aggregations, was announced last night by Owner-Captain Erno Schwarcz of the New York Americans for the American Soccer League.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The Illinois Commerce Commission today authorized the Illinois Bell Telephone Company to proceed with its financing as proposed, after it heard a plea from Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., that the $50,000,000 refunding bond issue be thrown open to competitive bidding by underwriters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The first group of conscientious objectors whose creeds forbid military service of any sort will be called within thirty days for a year at abandoned Civilian Conservation Corps camps, where, under government supervision, they will spend their time on soil conservation, forestation and related work.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 14. -- The Bulgarian Government today issued an energetic denial of all rumors spread abroad and in this country that German troops had arrived in Bulgaria. This was done through the official Bulgarian Telegraphic Agency, whose statement reads as follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Choice hogs on the livestock market today brought $8.25 a hundred pounds, an increase of 15 cents over yesterday's peak and the highest price paid since Sept. 19, 1939, soon after the outbreak of the war in Europe. The wholesale price on choice fresh pork loins, which jumped 1/2 cent a pound yesterday, advanced a full cent today to 18 cents.

The Chicago Park District will be in the market on Jan. 28 with $5,300,000 of refunding bonds, Series H, it was announced yesterday. Proceeds from the sale are to be used to refund outstanding 4, 4 1/4, 4 1/2, 4 3/4 and 5 per cent bonds which will become optional for call on March 1.

Plans for an "industrial exploration" in which industrial research and banking executives will tour South America to investigate its potentialities as "the biggest industrial prize in the world," were announced here yesterday by Maurice Holland, director of the National Research Council's division of engineering and industrial research, which is sponsoring the tour.

Harvard University in cooperation with the American Red Cross has established in England the Harvard Public Health Unit for the study and control of communicable diseases. The Red Cross supplied and maintains the hospital; Harvard provides the staff, headed by John Everett Gordon, Professor of Preventive Medicine and Epidemiology.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in December amounted to 775,472 bales of lint and 104,536 of linters, compared with 744,088 of lint and 108,117 of linters in November last and 650,123 and 105,329 in December, 1939.

American primitive paintings will be placed on view at the 460 Park Avenue Galleries next week for the benefit of the Scottish Clans Evacuation Pl/h for the immediate removal of British children in bombed areas to the Highlands of Scotland.

Nobumi Ito, who is the Joseph Goebbels of Tokyo, might have phrased it a little more deftly in his exchange of felicitations with his Nazi colleague. Said Nobumi to Joseph, "Your Excellency knows how important it is in these hard times to maintain and reinforce the people's courage."

HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- The construction of a one-story windowless building spread over five acres for the Otis Elevator Company will begin here soon it was announced today. Cranckcases for airplane engines for the Wright Aeronautical Corporation will be produced at the plant.

Two brothers, both gunmen and former Sing Sing prison convicts, were captured at noon yesterday after a running fight with policemen and heroic civilians in the crowded shopping center at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. Before they were seized they had killed a man in a $649 hold-up, mortally wounded a traffic policeman who chased them and gravely wounded a cab driver who went to the policeman's assistance.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- Reports of improved earnings and few changes in boards of directors marked meetings today of stockholders of Philadelphia's sixteen national banks and two trust companies.
Reports of annual meetings of banks held here and in other places at which important changes were made follow. The national banking laws set the second Tuesday in January for such meetings.

Paced by the high-scoring Harry Boykoff and Hy Gotkin, who made 16 points apiece, the unbeaten Thomas Jefferson High tossers scored their ninth triumph of the season by beating Hamilton, 56 -- 22, on the former's floor yesterday. It was the fourth league victory for Jefferson, which is showing the way in Section 1 of the Brooklyn P.S.A.L. race.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- Fifty-six planes, piloted by amateur and professional fliers from all parts of the United States, landed today at the Camp Columbia Army air field on the fifth annual Miami-Havana air cruise. Two seaplanes alighted in Havana Harbor.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- In his first public utterance since the liner Manhattan piled up an a sand bar Sunday night, Captain G.V. Richardson said today that "no one is entirely to blame."

Rodolfo Michels, 46-year-old Chilean Ambassador to the United States, said on his arrival here yesterday that his country would never deviate from its position of hemisphere solidarity in facing the threat of totalitarian powers, and that the United States could count on the cooperation of Chile in its defense plans for the American republics.

Rodolfo Michels, 46-year-old Chilean Ambassador to the United States, said on his arrival here yesterday that his country would never deviate from its position of hemisphere solidarity in facing the threat of totalitarian powers, and that the United States could count on the cooperation of Chile in its defense plans for the American republics.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Fed steers sold strong and actively today, with other classes steady in a dependable trade. Prime 1,325-pound steers topped at $15.60. Hogs continued their advance, selling 10 to 25 cents higher, although the top of $8.25 was only a 15-cent increase. Fat lambs closed slow to 15 cents lower.

Two brothers, both gunmen and former Sing Sing prison convicts, were captured at noon yesterday after a running fight with policemen and heroic civilians in the crowded shopping center at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. Before they were seized they had killed a man in a $649 hold-up, mortally wounded a traffic policeman who chased them and gravely wounded a cab driver who went to the policeman's assistance.

From a snowy Vermont where the hills are thick with skiers, the Stephen Daye Press writes that "country dancing is fast outstripping skiing as an American sport." Usually loyal to skiing, since it has published several books on the subject, the Press admits that this new enthusiasm (and disregard for winter resort owners) is tied up with a forthcoming book called "Swing Your Partners: A Modern Manual of Country Dances," by Durwood Maddocks.

Inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8.4 per cent at the end of December, while sales gained 4.9 per cent for the month, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Although Kurt Kasznar, who made his entry into the Broadway producing ranks on Tuesday with the revue, "Crazy With the Heat," insisted yesterday afternoon that the show would remain at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre next week, a closing notice, signed by Mr. Kasznar and effective on Saturday, was posted on the call board just before last night's performance.

Officials of Dade County, Fla., disclosed yesterday that they will enter the market on Feb. 6 with an issue of $2,000,000 of park bonds. Prospective bidders were given no further details on the offering yesterday but will be informed of the terms at a later date.

The motion-picture theatres committee of the "fight infantile paralysis" campaign launched its drive for funds yesterday from a stage in Times Square erected at Broadway, Seventh Avenue, Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets, the intersection being designated for the occasion as "Dimes Square."

Cooperation among the countries of the Western Hemisphere is the strongest moral and defensive force for peace in the world today, Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Pan American Society, declared yesterday at the society's annual luncheon in honor of the Latin-American Consular Corps in New York.

In an effort to curb the general outbreaks of fighting among players, which have been getting out of hand recently, the board of governors of the National Hockey League, at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, passed a rule that will bring about an automatic fine of $25 to responsible players.

Newspaper advertising was declared vital to the operation of a department store by Frank M. Mayfield, president of Scruggs-Vandervoort-Barney, Inc., and of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in an address yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- United States-made bombers have achieved a breakfast-to-teatime schedule and set a transatlantic record in delivery flights to Britain, it was disclosed today.

IF he knows what is best for his health and longevity, "Sebastian Haffner" is now in distant exile from his native Reich. Why? Because this young German lawyer and publicist has written one of the most probing and unsparing critiques of his fellow-countrymen we have seen. It is called "Germany: Jekyll and Hyde,"* and it is published here after what is apparently a fairly longish interval since it first appeared abroad.

The third-place Bruins will skate against the Rangers in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. Unbeaten in their last eight starts, the Bruins will seek to increase that string at the expense of the local sextet, which battled the Red Wings to a 3-3 deadlock last Tuesday night.
When T.S. Eliot wrote,

LONDON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare said today that British information "tends to confirm in part" recent assertions that in some ways the United States was still aiding the Axis powers. The Ministry hastened to add, however, that British authorities believed such help was not deliberate.

There are two separate and distinct issues involved in the President's so-called Lease-Lend Bill, and there is grave danger that they will become confused. The bill involves (1) the question whether the United States shall extend aid to England out of its own governmental funds and (2) the question of the means by which this shall be done.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka's latest reference to the German-Italian-Japanese pact today did nothing to clear up the ambiguities with which his previous utterances have surrounded Japan's obligations.
PALM BEACH, Jan. 15 -- Tommy Goodwin, prominent metropolitan golfer, today ousted I.L. Merrill of Camden, Me., from the annual Lake Worth championship tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club, 3 and 2.

MADRID, Jan. 15 -- A unique system of rationing whereby the quantities of bread supplied to the well to do are drastically reduced and the poor receive slightly larger amounts will be introduced in Madrid tomorrow. The official explanation is that "the rich can afford to buy other, more expensive foods to satisfy their hunger."

William C. Potter, chairman of the board of the Guaranty Trust Company, announced his resignation at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. He has served twenty years as chairman and president. He explained that he had already passed the retirement age and wished to give way to younger men.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Medium and good grades of cattle showed a consistent upturn today, with fat steers and yearlings selling 25 cents higher than Tuesday's average. Hog prices continued to soar, with the market active and 50 to 75 cents higher. The top was $9. Fat lambs were mostly 10 to 20 cents higher, with other classes steady.

The First Boston Corporation and associates yesterday were the successful bidders for $11,925,000 of Pennsylvania Railroad 1 3/4 per cent, Series L, equipment trust certificates, receiving the award on their bid of 100.043. The certificates, maturing serially from 1942 to 1956, were immediately reoffered by the bankers at prices to yield from 0.25 to 2.15 per cent, according to maturity.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Lehman filled the three remaining vacancies on the Supreme Court today when he forwarded to the Senate for confirmation the following appointments:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Shell Union Oil Corporation of New York City had filed a registration statement covering $15,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent twenty-year sinking-fund debentures due on Jan. 15, 1961, and $10,000,000 of serial notes due on Jan. 15, 1942-53.

According to reports the Long Island University strategy for its basketball game with De Paul of Chicago at Madison Square Garden last night was to abandon its set-shooting tactics in favor of short, crisp flips from underneath. The Busy Bees shunned the long-range tosses for the first half -- and trailed at the intermission.

Real estate men and others in business were urged yesterday by Peter Grimm, president of William A. White Sons, to support the Federal Government's housing activities and to make constructive criticisms if they felt any criticism at all was necessary.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Bolivia and Chile will sign a non-aggression treaty here this week, well-informed quarters understood tonight, after an exchange of notes between the Foreign Ministers of the two countries.

The healthy appetites of the animals in city zoos arose yesterday to bedevil the makers of the city's next budget when the New York Zoological Society asked an increase of $5,650 in its appropriation for forage and veterinary expenses.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Jack Westrope rode five winners at Santa Anita Park today.

The top four favored competitors, Stanley Galowin of Long Beach, Donald Frame, Harvard Club; R.S. Rothschild, Downtown A.C., and A.H. Barker, Rockaway Hunt Club, moved into the semi-finals in the seventh annual New York State amateur squash racquets championship last night at the Downtown A.C. Judging from the earlier round play of this quartet, tonight's round of four matches should produce the finest squash of the season.

The building at 1 East Sixty-second Street. adjoining the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue, which was erected for the Drexel family of Philadeljhia and later was the home of the late Henry Clews before it was altered for apartments at a cost of $200,000, was sold yesterday by the Clews heirs to Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate operator.

A good many cruising skippers of pleasure craft were thrown into a dither of agitation and resentment yesterday on learning of proposed new legislation at Albany that would impose boating laws regarded as objectionable. The bombshell came at a national conference of power craft and sailing folk who took three hours away from the National Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace to attend a large morning and afternoon assembly at the Hotel Shelton.

Possibly the people of Brooklyn will experience a vague sense of unreality on Saturday, Feb. 1, when the doors of Ingersoll Memorial, the new Brooklyn Central Library building at Grand Army Plaza, are to be thrown open to the public for the first time. If that feeling of unreality is there, it will be easily explained.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 last, made public yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president, shows a consolidated net income after all charges of $204,253,916.

With some easing of pressure of Southern and hedge selling, prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed up 6 to 13 points. Initial prices were up 2 to 8 points on an active demand from trade shorts and spot and mill interests.
Victories by Curtis High and Erasmus Hall High in P.S.A.L. games featured scholastic basketball competition on New York City courts yesterday.

An unprecedented stratagem by a special investigator for the State Department of Education led to the arrest yesterday of the 25-year-old director of a ghost-writing bureau charged with preparing and selling for $55 a report required by a candidate for a master's degree at New York University.

In recognition of the part played by British yachtsmen late last May in the evacuation of Dunkerque by 400,000 soldiers, the Cruising Club of America awarded yesterday its Blue Water Medal to the survivors among this group of boatmen and in memory of those who lost their lives in the Heroic action.

It is only two months since the fifteenth anniversary of Bishop Stires's consecration into his Long Island diocese was celebrated. Now he announces his intention to retire next year and turn his work over to a younger man. Fifty active years in the church have entitled him to watch these changing times from a well-earned quietude.

The two-story business building at 85-05 Jamaica Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens, has been sold by the executors of Catherine Bohlmann to Martel's, Inc., sportswear and sweater firm. The building is assessed at $11,700 and occupies a plot 20 by 100 feet.

Zadel Skolovsky, 24-year-old Los Angeles pianist, who made his local debut at an afternoon recital at Town Hall a little more than a year ago, gave his second New York recital last night, appearing, in Carnegie Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Contracts for the manufacture for the Army of 1,703,000 khaki cotton trousers with finished bottoms were awarded at the Quatermaster Depot today under Neg. No. 88. Informal bids on the manufacture of 6,900,000 pairs were opened privately here on Jan. 2.

OXFORD, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Tom Carlin, who has some of the finest hounds that ever ran a fox or treed a coon, has been at us for the past two years to join him in a fox hunt. Three years ago we hunted with him up in Greene County, N.Y., and it was almost midnight before the last of the hounds came in.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 15 -- Swedish correspondents in different capitals examine the situation in the Balkans in the light of Moscow's denial of any agreement with Berlin in regard to Bulgaria, and they agree in general that there has been a real change in the situation, with Bulgaria momentarily out of danger, while Yugoslavia seems in greater peril of becoming the next object of German pressure.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5 -- The fastest rage of the Hialeah Park meeting was run today when the Paragon Stable's Great Albert ripped off six furlongs in 1:10 2-5 to capture the Grade A Handicap. Blazing fast as this is, it still is three-fifths of a second behind the track record of Whopper, which may never be equaled.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 15 -- Today's Bourse adopted a waiting attitude and the trading volume was small. Most prices crumbled, but toward the close resistance was shown.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The best Hal Surface of Kansas City had to offer wasn't good enough today, and National Champion Don Mc-Neill of Oklahoma City won by 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, to reach the semi-finals of the annual Orlando tennis tournament.

The machinery of Justice, geared to record speed, moved swiftly yesterday in the case of the brothers Esposito, alias Distefano. Within twenty minutes after it heard the evidence of twelve key witnesses the grand jury returned four first degree murder indictments.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat yesterday for $31,000 set another new low record since 1899, when a membership in the institution was sold for $29,500. It was the fourth sale so far this year, following two at $35,000 and one at $33,000.

Concern among members of the New York Stock Exchange over recent expansion in the practice of large-scale secondary distribution of listed securities "off the market" after the close of trading was emphasized yesterday when plans were disclosed for such an offering of a block of 500,000 shares of Standard Oil of Hew Jersey common stock scheduled for today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 15 -- The Italian transatlantic mail plane Ibayr sent out an SOS this afternoon after coming down on the Atlantic Ocean with ten persons aboard about 300 miles off Fernando de Noronha, Brazil.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The Foreign Office announced today that Sir Gerald Campbell, British High Commissioner to Canada, had been appointed Minister to Washington to take office when Viscount Halifax, the new Ambassador, arrives there.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 15 -- Agreeing to the introduction of fresh legislation covering imports of materials to be used in constructing United States air and naval bases here, the Assembly endorsed this afternoon a recommendation by the Governor that the laws authorizing exemptions from customs duty should be reconsidered every three months.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, first large concern to report operating results for 1940, shows in its annual statement, for release today, net earnings of $25,548,424 after taxes and all charges. The net was equivalent to $2.55 each on the combined 10,000,000 shares of common and Class B common stocks outstanding.

The outlines of flower blossoms as seen through a fluoroscope provided the motif for the outstanding design submitted in the sixth textile design competition conducted by the Museum of Costume Art, Rockefeller Center, 630 Fifth Avenue. Prize winners in nine classifications were announced there yesterday by judges selected from leading manufacturing concerns in the textile field.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Missouri's outgoing Democratic Governor vetoed today a legislative refusal to seat his Republican successor in a surprise "farewell" message which shocked the Assembly's Democratic majority into temporary silence and created still greater confusion in the muddied Gubernatorial dispute.

Arthur J. Morris, president of the Fulton Trust Company of New York, announced at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that net earnings for 1940 were $245,200, or $12.25 a share, against $241,700, or $12.08 a share in 1939. This did not include profits of $79,800 on securities sold, which sum was added to the reserve, enabling the baank to apply $54,000 toward reducing the book value of its uptown office property to $100,000.

An investigation of political activities in the 1940 campaign by insurance companies and executives disclosed no "flagrant" violations of the law forbidding this, but did reveal instances tending to undermine public confidence in life insurance, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, declared in a report to the State Legislature that was made public yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The stock markets had a cheerful session today and there were many bright features. There was a larger turnover due to the reinvestment of money released by the call up of dollar securities.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 15 -- The Forty-fourth Division has ski instructors and skiing equipment, and now all it needs is snow to begin Winter warfare training. If New Jersey weather does not produce snow, the unit may be sent to the Adirondacks to train, according to plans under discussion at the plans and training office here.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Bundles for Britain and the British Relief Overcoat Committee entertained jointly with a benefit tea and cocktail party today at Finchleys. The Hon. Mrs. Frederick E. Guest is regional president of bundles for Britain, and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer vice president.

THE coaching shift of Tuss McLaughry from Brown to Dartmouth was taken in stride, but the selection of a new coach for Ohio State was something else, as evidenced by the following exchange between two fervid followers of intercollegiate football:

The insistence of the United States Trucking Corporation that a truck driver who had five accidents in the last year have his eyes examined led to a strike of 300 union drivers last Friday, it became known yesterday when the company started a $100,000 damage suit in Supreme Court against Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L.

For three hours last night sixty-one speakers, representing ninety educational, professional, parent, civic and labor organizations, presented varied views on the 1941-42 proposed $152,008,302 Board of Education budget at an open hearing at board headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Net assets of Affiliated Fund, Inc., applicable to 4,535,421 shares of capital stock at the end of 1940, were $12,290,644, or $2.71 a share, against $2.15 a share at the end of June last, according to the report issued yesterday by Andrew J. Lord, president.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 15 -- The veil was lifted today from part of the mysterious working of German propaganda in Mexico when the police let it be known that large quantities of leaflets urging the streetcar workers to strike were found in the offices of Adolfo Leon Osorio, arrested yesterday on a charge of being the head of a gang whose specialty was to disturb the performance of American films with an anti-totalitarian slant.

PARIS, Jan. 6 (Delayed; via Berlin -- The first group of Americans to be repatriated since the invasion of France left Paris for Lisbon, Portugal, last night. There were forty-six, most of whom had lost their positions or were unable to cope with the high cost of living.

Two alleged hold-up men were pursued and captured by the police and bystanders following an attempted robbery of a 19-year-old office boy in Depew Place, an alley running from Forty-third to Forty-sixth Streets, between Park and Lexington Avenues, at noon today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Declaring an adequate military or defense highway system in this State to be a "vital part of any preparedness program," the Joint Legislative Highway Survey Committee urged in an interim report to the Legislature today that Federal funds on a large scale be devoted to that purpose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The existing economic order in the United States must make itself capable of providing stable employment for the masses, or "Big Government" will take over control, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming declared today in summing up the testimony which has been given before the Temporary National Economic Committee, of which he is chairman.

It is fitting that the most momentous debate on foreign policy in the history of this country should start off with a comprehensive picture of the international situation as it is and as it threatens the fundamental principles and assumptions on which American security and freedom are based. It is fitting that the first witness before the House committee should be the Secretary of State.

The operating profit of the Irving Trust Company in 1940 was $3,100,345, the best in three years, Harry E. Ward, president, told the stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. In 1939 the profit was $2,419,100 and in 1938 it was $681, 245.
Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a panel of architects qualified to handle city work, in accordance with the provisions of the City Charter.

Bent on keeping up a brisk pace of contract signing the Giants fetched up with two more contented athletes yesterday when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced that John Wittig, husky young right-hander, and Johnny McCarthy, the perennial first-base understudy, had come into the fold for 1941.

The National A.A.U. indoor swimming championships for women will be held at Buffalo from March 19 to 22 and for men at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, on April 4 and 5, it was announced yesterday by Secretary-Treasurer Dan Ferris.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco and Earle Lookabaugh of Chicago maintained their undefeated standing in the world three-cushion billiard championship today.

As the result of a 4.0 per cent rise in linage in December, newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records wound up 1940 with a total gain of 2.0 per cent. This compared with a 1.5 per cent increase in 1939 over 1938 and a decline in the latter year of 13 per cent from 1937.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Chick Harbert, 25-year-old Battle Creek, Mich., pro, fired a sizzling five-under-par 67 in the rain today to lead the field at the halfway mark of the thirty-six-hole qualifying trials of the $5,000 San Francisco match-play open golf tournament.

A resolution endorsing the price policy of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and its "buyers' pledge" to resist unwarranted and unreasonable price increases by wholesalers or manufacturers was unanimously approved by the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the conclusion of the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

In your issue of Jan. 11 Thomas E. Dewey is quoted as saying that the Defense Bill introduced on last Friday gives the President the absolute right "to seize any alien ship * * * and give it to any other country," and to "use the Navy to convoy belligerent ships any place in the world."

The Neediest Cases Fund received $8,964.06 yesterday from the estate of Herbert Baker, retired vice chairman of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, who died at Sayre, Pa., on July 4, 1939. With the aid of twelve other contributions aggregating $141 that were received yesterday, the current total of the fund was increased to $243,541.50.

Price reductions ranging from $5 to $20 on its line of electric refrigerators were announced yesterday by the Frigidaire Division, General Motors Sales Corporation at a sales meeting at the Hotel Astor. The special six-foot refrigerator, however, was offered at $114.75, unchanged from the 1940 level.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Submission of a membership list of the Teachers Union of New York City, as demanded by a subcommittee of the Joint Legislative Committee Investigating the Educational System of the State, might be of questionable value, William G. Mulligan, counsel for Charles Hendley, president of the union, told the Court of Appeals today.

A challenge by Mayor La Guardia of the right of the City Council to subpoena a Mayor at any time for any purpose or to call for any documents the Mayor considers confidential was submitted to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday for judicial decision.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- Faced with the flat refusal of the Premiers of the three Provinces of Ontario, British Columbia and Alberta to discuss alteration of Provincial-Dominion relations as a war measure on the basis of the Sirois report Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King this evening "postponed" the conference which began yesterday "until it may be that the Provinces themselves will ask for its resumption even before the war is over."

Gross earnings of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad last year were about $179,000,000, or $18,100,000 higher than in 1939, according to preliminary figures submitted to the directors at their meeting here yesterday. Net income was about $35,800,000, or sufficient to meet a full year's interest and leave a balance of $5,000,000.

Sixteen leases calling for a total of about 160,000 square feet of commercial space, including eleven full-floor units, were reported yesterday by one firm of realty brokers. This and other rental activity largely called for manufacturing space.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Roosevelt authorized today the issuance of general licenses for export control. Such a move had been recommended to him by Colonel Russell L. Maxwell, administrator of export control.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 15 -- Renewed Italian military activity in Istria, with considerable movement of infantry and materiel into the Gorizia sector, about thirty-five miles from the Yugoslav frontier, was reported tonight from Italian sources in Slovenia. More than 200 troop trucks, accompanied by armored cars, light artillery, anti-aircraft units and aviation, were reported to have been moved into Istria within the past thirty-six hours.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- German authorities have proclaimed that Vienna is now the world's style center, which, they say, supplanted Paris before the German occupation of that capital, the Commerce Department reported today.

A comprehensive program under which the Food Procurement Advisory Committee would take an active part in assisting the fighting services in purchase of goods has been agreed upon by representatives of the food industry and the Defense Commission, it was announced yesterday by Donald M. Nelson, director of the division of purchases of the Office of Production Management, following a meeting on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The State Department made public tonight this memorandum concerning Secretary Hull's statement to the House Foreign Affairs Committee today on the relation of the lease-lend bill to domestic and international laws:

DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- A Selective Service official said today that big Hank Greenberg, Detroit Tiger out-fielder and most valuable American League player last year, "probably will be in the Army by June 1."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- This formal statement on the financial position of Great Britain was presented to the House Foreign Affairs Committee today by Secretary Morgenthau during its hearings on the Lend-Lease Bill:

The United States dress liaison with Latin America received further endorsement last night when Russeks Fifth Avenue paraded a dozen or more gowns, many of them strongly flavored by South American trends, against the tropical background of the Copacabana Club.

ROME, Jan. 15 -- United States Ambassador to Italy William C. Phillips arrived in Rome this afternoon to open a new and critical diplomatic phase in Italo-American relations. He brought no message, he said, and has no special mission. But the mere fact that he has come here at this moment in American affairs has made his arrival the most sensational development in the diplomatic field since Italy entered the war.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 15 -- Seton Hall's high-flying basketball team, a slick group of ball-handlers that would bring credit to any school, clicked off its thirty-fifth consecutive victory tonight before a crowd of 6,000 in the Seton Hall gymnasium.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A bill to abolish the Communist party as a political party in New York State was introduced today in the Legislature under the sponsorship of the American Legion.

Unless there is an unexpected change, three of the metropolitan area's outstanding ski jumpers, Torger Tokle of the Norway S.C., Harald Sorensen of the Norfolk (Conn.) Winter Sports Association and Bjorn Lie of the Norsemen S.C. will be among those seeking honors in the thirty-fifth Norge S.C. jump at Fox River Grove, Ill., Sunday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Sources close to the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, said today that the Premier was pleased with his conferences with parliamentarians and leaders of business, finance and the press and was confident the Cabinet would weather the coming session of the Diet without "major embarrassment."
Wendell L. Willkie, who announced on Sunday that he would visit England, will leave for Lisbon Wednesday morning by Pan-American Clipper.

Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island will revert to its World War status as a regular Coast Artillery post when the Sixteenth and Eighteenth Infantry units leave the island fort for Fort Devens, Mass., in a few weeks, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Secretary Hull, in effect, told Congress today that the United States is faced with the grim necessity of subordinating the ideal of neutrality and the finer points of international law to the urgency of sheer self-defense against the tidal wave of totalitarian conquest pointed unmistakably toward the Western Hemisphere.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- James F. Dewey, Federal conciliator, announced tonight the settlement of the strike affecting 3,500 workers in five plants of the Eaton Manufacturing Company.

Polo in 1941, in company with all other sports and, indeed, all other forms of life in the country and in the world, does not pretend to know what changes may be made in its "way of life" by national emergency.

Fourteen of the twenty pilots, flight mechanics and radio engineers who flew five Consolidated PBY patrol bombers from Elizabeth City, N.C., to Bermuda last Tuesday, returned to New York yesterday aboard the Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways.

Fresh German threats of reprisals against individuals, institutions and entire communities in the Netherlands, if further anti-German "incidents" occur there, are merely a new manifestation of the difficulties that are being experienced in the occupation of that sturdy country. The Nazi puppet rulers, including the imported Seyss-Inquart, brought from Austria, are now finding out what has long been a popular maxim elsewhere -- "You can't beat the Dutch."

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Prices of wheat held within narrow limits today, but trade was at a minimum. The new crop months showed relative strength on a forecast for much colder weather in the West and Northwest and gained on the May. The latter appeared to be for sale through commission houses most of the day and Closed unchanged.

The ten most important books of non-fiction in 1940, chosen by Current History and Forum's advisory board of distinguished critics, were announced last night at a dinner given by the Booksellers League of New York at the Hotel Brevoort.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 15 -- Formation of Local 59, United Construction Workers, C.I.O., with jurisdiction in Monmouth County, where A.F. of L. men are at work on extensive defense construction at Fort Hancock and Fort Monmouth, is announced by James A. Murphy, regional director of C.I.O. unions in the building-trades field.

The 1941 Gold Cup regatta will be held on the Detroit River between Detroit and Belle Isle on Labor Day. This surprise decision was reached at a meeting of the Gold Cup Contest Board last night at the Hotel Lexington.

The American party system in general and Mr. La Guardia's party loyalties in particular are not the most logical arrangement in the world. Just the same, it is something of a shock to find the Mayor paying warm tribute to Alexander Hamilton and sharply rebuking Thomas Jefferson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was the guest of honor at luncheon today of Mrs. Frank Knox, wife of the Secretary of the Navy, held a reception late this afternoon at the White House for members of the board of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, and entertained a small party of friends informally at dinner tonight before going to see "The Cream in the Well" at the National Theatre.
The first United States soldiers assigned to protect the naval bases leased from Great Britain sailed yesterday for St. Johns, Nfld., The number of men sent was not disclosed.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Cornell consolidated its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by turning back Columbia, 38 -- 22, tonight after the Lions had made a close game of it for the first fourteen minutes.

Almost all steel companies are sold out for the first quarter of this year, virtually the only exceptions being defense requirements, which have preference over ordinary commercial orders, and the occasional small lots that can be fitted conveniently into a rolling schedule, Iron Age says this week.

Employe shortages caused by national defense needs, informative labels for merchandise that have come to be known as "silent salesmen," the crusade for honesty in fabric labeling and descriptions and the need for a readjustment of retailing to the American way of living were among the subjects discussed yesterday at the thirtieth annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The war in the Mediterranean and upon its shores has entered a new phase, the British communique on Monday revealed. For the first time German armed forces have struck a damaging blow against the British in the Mediterranean area.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, In Libya, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Heavy sandstorms subsided today after having lashed the North African desert for a week and British troops took quick advantage of the opportunity to hasten the movement of all equipment into positions surrounding Tobruk in preparation for an attack on that besieged Italian fortress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- An engineer for the Aluminum Corporation of America, said today that not only was there no general shortage of aluminum for the aircraft industry but that the industry was on the way to being geared for the peak load required for the airplane defense program of 3,000 craft a month.

Gains of 8 to 13 per cent in retail trade this year, with stores catering to wage earners likely to show the largest sales increases, were forecast yesterday by speakers at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A swindle that cost an elderly woman her entire fortune of $60,000, half of it in securities, was charged yesterday to four men. The securities had been sold to the woman in an earlier swindle, for which one of the four indicted yesterday is now serving a prison term of three and a half years.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- A strange murder case started unfolding in Hampstead Police Court today at the arraignment of Professor Arthur Lloyd James, a short and stocky man with thinning gray hair and black eyebrows.

Six concerns charged with participating in group showings of their lines were brought before the grievance committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at its offices at 450 Seventh Avenue yesterday and given a hearing. Taking of evidence was completed, and F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary of the board, said a decision and possible action would be forthcoming soon.

The power of the President further to devalue the dollar is "one of the gravest dangers," Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, warned its stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. Mr. Johnston urged that the country return to the gold standard "as the only effective brake on widespread inflation."

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 16 -After a day of quiet, German air attacks on Great Britain were resumed shortly before midnight last night, and continued into this morning, although apparently not on a large scale.

The first detailed account of the crippling by British naval forces of the 35,000-ton French battleship Richelieu in the harbor at Dakar last Summer was made public last night in the form of a letter from a nofficer of H.M.S. Hermes, aircraft carrier, who told how a "suicide'' crew of a British "clash boat" slipped under the Richelieu's stern in the dead of night and unloaded four depth bombs, then escaped after harrowing adventures.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 15 -- Presaging increased Japanese aerial activity against Chungking, Chengtu and other Szechwan Province cities and also the Chungking-Lanchow highway, at least 200 Japanese planes are being concentrated at various airfields near Hankow and Wuhu.
ATHENS, Jan. 15 -- The Athens radio tonight reported a "great Greek success" in the central sector, but the exact whereabouts was not revealed.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- Henry Ford said in a brief radio talk today that during the present crisis the Ford organization wanted "to do everything possible to help America and the President."

ATHENS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Greek soldiers in a surprise attack launched during a snowstorm have blasted the Italians out of important high positions in the central sector of the Albanian front and held them against several counter-attacks, the government spokesman declared tonight.
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has been admitted to membership in the American Life Convention.

The index of industrial production compiled by the Federal Reserve was 136 for December and 122 for the whole year 1940. As worked out under the new system of averages, these are both high records; the best showing for any previous full year being the 113 of 1937. In 1929 the highest monthly index was 114, and the full year's index 110.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The text of Secretary Hull's statement before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today was as follows:

LONDON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare, commenting today on the interception of the French freighter Mendoza outside Montevideo harbor by British warships, said the government of Uruguay had no ground for protest and that the question of violating Uruguayan waters had not arisen.

Intense dullness continued yesterday for the fourth consecutive session on the stock market, where, under the influence of the smallest volume since Oct. 21 last, prices continued to be whittled away. Transfers on the Stock Exchange were only 396,580 shares, compared with Tuesday's dealings of 468,910, and interest narrowed to 717 issues, with only 196 of these closing with gains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- An examiner recommended today that the Interstate Commerce Commission reject complaints by some new Jersey interests that railroad rates and practices favor the New York side of New York Harbor.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The National Machine Tool Builders Association calculated today the industry's capacity, based on payroll hours, has climbed 61.2 per cent since outbreak of the European war. The association also reported its index of operating activity, likewise figured on payroll hours, established another all-time record in December.

On Jan. 10 a group of seventy-five prominent Americans, representing all political viewpoints, addressed a plea to the President asking that our government strongly protest to General Franco against further reprisals in Spain, and further requesting that our Ambassador in France appeal to the Vichy authorities not to return any Spaniards to General Franco.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Opposing the granting of further powers to President Roosevelt, District Attorney Dewey of New York City declared here today that the President's Lease-Lend Armaments Bill "would bring an end to free government in the United States and would abolish Congress for all practical purposes."

At the opening session of the New Jersey Legislature for this year Senator Hendrickson, Republican candidate for Governor in 1940, introduced a bill for a constitutional convention. Mr. Charles Edison, who will be inducted as Governor on Jan. 21, proposed in his campaign to call a constitutional convention to bring the fundamental law up to date.

Henry Armstrong and Fritzie Zivic, who will meet in a fifteen-round bout for the world welter-weight championship at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, concluded their gymnasium workouts yesterday. Zivic, the defender, who dethroned Armstrong last October, boxed three rounds with Victor Troise at the Pioneer and weighed 147 pounds.

Ella Flesch Hungarian dramatic soprano, made her American debut last night in Town Hall. Miss Flesch, a niece of the eminent violinist, Karl Flesch, has appeared at the Vienna State Opera and the Munich Opera. She also has sung, both in opera and on the concert stage, in England, France, Beligum, the Netherlands and Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Replying to opponents of his proposal to build 500 airplanes a day in automotive plants, Walter F. Reuther of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) asserted today that contrary to the popular impression, less than 10 per cent of the automobile industry's potential capacity was being used or would be used under present plans for turning out planes.

At the opening session of the New Jersey Legislature for this year Senator Hendrickson, Republican candidate for Governor in 1940, introduced a bill for a constitutional convention. Mr. Charles Edison, who will be inducted as Governor on Jan. 21, proposed in his campaign to call a constitutional convention to bring the fundamental law up to date.

Henry Armstrong and Fritzie Zivic, who will meet in a fifteen-round bout for the world welter-weight championship at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, concluded their gymnasium workouts yesterday. Zivic, the defender, who dethroned Armstrong last October, boxed three rounds with Victor Troise at the Pioneer and weighed 147 pounds.

ALBANY, Jan. l5 -- Governor Lehman sent to the Legislature today a sharp message, demanding that there be no delay in starting work on legislative and Congressional reapportionment in the State and recommending that this be done through the appointment of a bipartisan legislative committee, to be set up at the start rather than at the end of the legislative session.

The two-year controversy over the merger of the Lincoln and Horace Mann Schools of Teachers College, Columbia University, was reopened last night, two months after the merger's enactment. At a late meeting the Parent-Teacher Association of the Lincoln School moved to obtain a court's judgment on the legality of the consolidation.

The defense of the city against a possible air bombardment was the theme of discussion yesterday at the first meeting of Mayor La Guardia's City Defense Council, which convened behind closed doors in the Council Chamber at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Joint training exercises involving units of the Navy, Army and Marine Corps will be held in Puerto Rican waters beginning about Jan. 21 and lasting to February, Secretary Knox announced today.

Lively exchanges between defense attorneys and Trial Examiner John Hornet featured yesterday's hearings into Federal Trade Commission charges that retail liquor pack-age-store groups of the country had conspired to fix retail prices and to eliminate competition.

Metro's "Flight Command," which stars Robert Taylor, is the new arrival at the Capitol this morning. The melodrama is concerned with naval aviation and includes Walter Pidgeon, Ruth Hussey, Paul Kelly, Shepperd Strudwick, Red Skelton and Nat Pendleton in its cast ....

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Plans were made public today for the establishment by the American Red Cross of a national defense blood plasma reservoir. The plasma will be put at the disposal of the Army and Navy, but in time of emergency will serve as an international bank to treat the victims of wars and disasters.
The unbeaten New York A.C. Class A squash tennis team added another triumph last night in the Metropolitan League series, winning, 5 to 0, from the Harvard Club at the latter's courts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased "Charley's Aunt" from the heirs of the author. Brandon Thomas, for a reported $110,000 and will use it as Jack Benny's first vehicle at the studio, it was announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 15 -- The Rome correspondent of the Stockholm newspaper Tidnigen transmits a report from "Vatican circles," that when the German Ambassador in Paris, Otto Abetz, visited Marshal Petain following Pierre Laval's ousting from the Vichy Cabinet, he emphasized that "German troops could within six hours occupy the remaining unoccupied part of France."
Holdings of the Home Owners Loan Corporation and of several private institutional owners figured largely in the Bronx realty deals reported yesterday by brokers.

As a site for improvement with several dwellings, a vacant plot of 140 by 144 feet at the northwest corner of Corbin Place and the Esplanade, in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn, has been bought by Esplanada Homes, Inc., from Josephine Shea through Joseph P. Day.

Tonight Gertrude Lawrence returns to a song-and-dance career in the musical play called "Lady in the Dark." As is generally known by now, Moss Hart wrote the words, Kurt Weill supplied the music and Ira Gershwin contributed the lyrics, all to be presented by Sam H. Harris.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Vincent Bendix, president of Bendix Aviation Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting today preliminary figures for the last quarter of 1940 indicated shipments were double those of a year earlier. In the first nine months of 1940, the increase in shipments averaged 65 per cent, he said.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Vincent Bendix, president of Bendix Aviation Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting today preliminary figures for the last quarter of 1940 indicated shipments were double those of a year earlier. In the first nine months of 1940, the increase in shipments averaged 65 per cent, he said.

Supplies of beef and lamb were moderate to normal and veal and pork light for yesterday's trading. Most classes of traefer meats sold at firm to higher prices, although the demand was somewhat uneven, ranging from only fair to good. Kosher steer beef opened barely steady, with some weakness in spots, particularly anything below strictly choice.

ABOARD AIRCRAFT CARRIER ILLUSTRIOUS, With British Mediterranean Fleet, Jan. 15 -- This scarred aircraft carrier, attacked for seven hours last Friday by German dive bombers, came into a Mediterranean port under her own power today.

The first indictment alleging violation of the United States neutrality laws was handed up here yesterday by a Federal grand jury. It accused Hector Leon Marie Vanderdonckt of serving as chief officer of a Belgian ship after President Roosevelt had proclaimed that Belgium was involved in a state of war.

New York City furnished yesterday 383 more men for a year of military training under the Selected Service Act, and the rate of rejections by United States Army physicians after examination dropped to 16.01 per cent, the lowest for any day since the draft was begun.

Larry Sartori, right guard, will captain Fordham's Rams during the 1941 gridiron season. Sartori, who comes from Shippton, Pa., was unanimously elected by the football letter men yesterday to succeed the retiring captain and center, Lou De Filippo.

The theatre had a day of woe yesterday. An increasing number of cases of grippe among stars and featured players was reported, causing the postponement of one premiere and a hurried call for understudies in some current attractions. Three other shows also deferred their premieres, one because a player suffered a fractured arm.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 17 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee is a "clear challenge short of an ultimatum to the Axis powers," says the newspaper Asahi this morning, declaring that Japan will adhere to the Axis alliance whether the United States likes it or not.

BERLIN, Friday, Jan. 17 -- Informed sources said early today that German dive bombers had attacked the 23,000-ton British aircraft carrier Illustrious yesterday for the second time in seven days and scored three direct hits. The attack was said to have taken place "in a British naval fortress in the Mediteranean, where a number of bombs were dropped."

The production of military tanks by the American Car and Foundry Company is expected to reach fifteen daily, F.A. Stevenson, vice president, told the New York Railroad Club in the Engineering Societies Building last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture canceled today plans for a referendum Tuesday among 60,000 dairymen in the New York milkshed after Justice Jennings Bailey in Federal District Court granted an injunction, sought by the Dairymen's League and a group of producers and handlers, against the balloting.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation and its subsidiaries had consolidated net income of $6,489,031, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, compared with $4,335,769 in the preceding comparable period, according to the report made public yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Lehman left Albany tonight to devote several days to defense activities in New York City and Washington. Before doing so, he made public, at a press conference, the inventory of idle manufacturing plants in New York City which might be used for defense purposes.

The First National Bank of New York bought yesterday $2,942,000 city of Rochester, N.Y., short-term notes at 0.11 per cent. The securities, dated Jan. 20, will be payable in installments on July 21 and Sept. 20.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, introduced today a bill which is designed to protect banks against suits by foreign depositors over "frozen" accounts. Legislation intended to accomplish the same purpose failed of passage through a parliamentary tangle at the last session of Congress.
Several articles have recently appeared relative to the extraordinarily large alien registration, a tabulation greatly in excess of what had been estimated.

Despite "glamorous profit possibilities" this year, retailers must prepare their stores for the inevitable readjustment which will follow and do no appeasing in the control of expenses, Leo C. Levin, treasurer and controller of Franklin Simon Co., said yesterday at the Controllers Congress session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Georgetown University continued its spectacular climb among the Eastern collegiate basketball powers by defeating New York University, 36 to 27, tonight before 3,000 fans in Riverside Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Metro announced assignments for two musical pictures today, both to be produced by Victor Saville. Rise Stevens, the studio's acquisition from the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Nelson Eddy were named for the leads in a screen version of Oscar Strauss's "The Chocolate Soldier" and James Stewart was assigned to play opposite Jeannette MacDonald in the studio's remake of "Smilin' Thru."

The Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx tomorrow night will be staged under conditions so different from those of the past that Chairman Pinky Sober yesterday predicted nine records for the eleven running events.

Dennis Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, sails today on the Grace liner Santa Lucia for a cruise to Colombia, Panama, Ecuador, Peru and Chile. Other members of the prelate's party are the Rev. George L. Leech, Bishop of Harrisburg, Pa.; Mgr. P.E. McGee of North Attleboro, Mass., and the Rev. S.H. Burgio, secretary to Cardinal Dougherty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States stands today in real and great danger of invasion by air in the contingency that the British Navy should be destroyed or surrendered, Secretary Stimson told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today in urging the speediest possible enactment of the principle of President Roosevelt's lend-lease bill for aid to the nations resisting the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Lake Superior District Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 35,000 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value.

Early amendment of the lend lease bill to define positively what powers it would confer upon the President was urged by former President Herbert Hoover in a letter to Representative Sol Bloom, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, which Mr. Hoover made public yesterday.

Proving that art can directly serve the purpose of fashion design, Helen Liebert resorted to and effectively used inspiration derived from the now-current exhibition of Mochi silhouettes at the Metropolitan Museum. She incorporated the cut-out silhouette in the brims of her smartest new Spring hats.

A brief asking the Supreme Court to deny the motion brought by ex-Magistrate Joseph Goldstein, in a taxpayer's suit, to dismiss six Brooklyn College members accused of subversive activities, was filed yesterday by Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress a request for an emergency appropriation of $350,000,000 for the construction of 200 cargo vessels and conferred with Secretaries Hull, Knox and Stimson, General George C. Marshall and Admiral Harold R. Stark on the foreign situation.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits decreased $13,841,000 to $19,475,000 in the week ended yesterday was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada. Chartered bank deposits decreased $5,019,000 to $222,064,000, while notes in circulation decreased $6,658,000 to $347,636,000.
CATANIA, Sicily, Jan. 16 (UP) -Funeral services were held today
Under the caption "Bond Depreciation Held Capital Loss" is a most interesting reference to the British plan of treating capital losses and gains in reporting income for taxation.

In his seventh annual talk to members of the City Club of New York, delivered yesterday in the clubrooms at 55 West Forty-fourth Street, Mayor La Guardia repeated land re-emphasized his previously expressed belief that the entire system of Federal, State and local taxation should be revised as early as possible to make it conform with existing conditions.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 -- The Joseph E. Widener colors were carried to a surprise victory at Hialeah Park today when Town Boy, by Haste -- Mademoiselle De Valois, captured the Miami Springs Handicap at $20.90 for $2. This gave the Hialeah owner his second victory of the session, and both winners are of the same breeding.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16 -- Belgrade's new afternoon newspaper, Vece, appeared today for the first time. The sixteen-page publication, which came off the presses of the semi-official Vreme and is edited by the Vreme staff, devotes its front page to the reports of Anglo-Turkish conversations and a dispatch from its Berlin correspondent discussing Rumanian Premier Ion Antonescu's reported journey from Bucharest to Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Department store sales during the week ended Jan. 11 were 16 per cent greater than for the corresponding week of last year, as compared with the Jan. 4 increase of 4 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

ROME, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The report of the Axis on its bomb and torpedo offensive against British sea power in the Mediterranean was further filled in today by the assertion of a Rome newspaper that the 22,600-ton aircraft carrier Eagle had been torpedoed.

With more than 200 major league officials casting a super-critical eye on the production, the American League gave its premiere showing of its seventh official motion picture in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore yesterday and received practically a 100 per cent endorsement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The final plea of Earl Russell Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, from his conviction for passport fraud was taken under cotsideration by the Supreme Court today after counsel for the Communist and the government debated the issue.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- The police tonight revealed the existence of a foiled murder plot against "a certain Japanese dignitary," who is unnamed but is presumed to have been the then Foreign Minister, Hachiro Arita.

Disavowal of any formal connection, now or previously, with the No Foreign War Committee was made yesterday by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who has been listed frequently among the committee's backers by its chairman, Verne Marshall.

OTTAWA, Jan. 16 -- Early elections in the three Provinces of Ontario, British Columbia and Manitoba are expected as one outcome of the failure of the Ottawa Conference yesterday even to begin examination of the recommendations of the Sirois report for the alteration of financial relations between the Dominion and the provinces.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 16 -- Today's Bourse again took on a dull tone. Dutch issues mostly declined to 4 points.

Bids were received yesterday by the Department of Parks for construction of a public swimming pool 200 feet long by 70 feet wide to accommodate 1,300 bathers on the site of the Aquacade at the former World's Fair, now Flushing Meadow Park.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. E. Steuart Davis were hosts at a cocktail party this afternoon at their home to Mrs. Davis's mother, Mrs. Cullen Bailey, and her brother, Cullen Bailey Jr., who will leave soon for the United States Naval Training School at Pensacola, Fla.

PARIS, Jan. 10 (delayed; via Berlin) -- The second group of Americans returning home through the American Red Cross left Paris for Lisbon last night. According to the list of the United States Embassy, this group, numbering forty-two, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for immediate funds for 200 new cargo vessels "to protect against the effect upon the United States of a possible world shortage of such ships." The Naval Affairs Committee at the same time rushed to the House bills calling for emergency authority for more naval ships, shipyards, armor and gun factories, and for protection of the fleet against air attacks.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Overlooked in the first round sub-par firing, Tony Penna of Dayton, Ohio, and Jimmy Hines of Great Neck, L.I. charged down the homestretch today to tie for the medal in the thirty-six-hole qualifying trials of the $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

The policyholders' service bureau of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has issued a report titled "The Annual Report to Stockholders," following a survey in which the bureau analyzed 216 corporate reports, consulted seventy-six companies and questioned seventy-one stockholders as to their opinions on annual reports.

Aviation hobbies developed among the nation's youth in schools and clubs are making an important contribution to national defense, Paul V. McNutt, Social Security Administrator, said last night at the second annual dinner of Air Youth of America, an organization devoted to interests of youth in aviation.

VICHY, France, Jan. 16 -- In reply to the assertion of the British Minister of Information, Alfred Duff Cooper, that "God Save the King" was sung in Paris on Armistice Day, an authorized statement explains that the British anthem was originally a French song and was plagiarized by the British.

The statement of Britain's present financial position presented to the House Foreign Affairs Committee by Secretary Morgenthau was startling. It showed beyond all question that the urgency of large-scale aid from this country has not been exaggerated.

The formation of the firm of D.T. Richardson Co., with offices at 135 South La Salle Street, Chicago, was announced yesterday by D.T. Richardson. From 1931 to 1939 Mr. Richardson was a partner in Kelley, Richardson Co. Mr. Richardson served for two years as chairman of the committee on municipal securities of the vestment Bankers Association of America and for three years he was treasurer of the association.

Following a series of examinations, called the most rigorous ever held for a New York City teaching candidate, seven out of an original group of 104 men and women have been passed by the Board of Examiners for high school principal posts, it was announced yesterday.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., head a nation-wide underwriting syndicate which will offer to the public today $46,250,000 of a total issue of $50,000,000 of first-mortgage 2 3/4 per cent bonds, Series A, of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company. The bonds, due Jan. 25, 1981, will be priced at 103 1/2, to yield 2.61 per cent to maturity and 2.60 per cent to the first date at which they are callable at par.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 17 -- The British carried out heavy concentrated raids Wednesday night on the big shipbuilding yards and drydocks in Wilhelmshaven, main base of the German North Sea fleet.

Making an unscheduled appearance last night at Town Hall to participate with 1,000 fellow-Americans in the weekly Town Hall of the Air radio program, Wendell Willkie declared that if the American people believed, "as I believe," that the collapse of Britain would mean the passing of a free way of life from America, then they would grant to President Roosevelt the extraordinary powers he has asked in the lease-lend bill.

Nothing that has been written or said on the subject of the American way gives so clear and complete a picture as the little colloquy between an A.F.L. union leader and a machine manufacturer in York, Pa. The exchange of sentiments was reported yesterday in THE TIMES by Byron Darnton in his vivid account of thriving war industry in York.
Arthur P. Caldwell Jr., an assistant vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, was appointed a vice president at the directors' annual organization meeting yesterday.

Miss Silvie Alexandrine Maxine DeGrasse-Fowler, great-grand-daughter of Admiral Francois Joseph Paul DeGrasse, who died at Grimaldi, Italy, Dec. 26, left her estate of less than $10,000 to a cousin, Isabel Stevens Lathrop of South Norwalk, Conn., after cutting off five other relatives with twenty-five cents each.

George Scalise, who is serving a ten-to-twenty-year sentence in Sing Sing Prison after conviction on a charge of stealing $60,000 from the International Building Service Employes Union, pleaded guilty yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to one count in a three-count indictment alleging income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Representative Fish started the questioning of Secretary Stimson today by asking whether the Secretary thought that, with this country's naval strength, any foreign nation could invade our shores.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 16 -- Britain's prospective curtailment of food ships from New Zealand and Australia to shorten the ships' haul, has been met without the slightest trace of resentment in New Zealand. The reaction, on the contrary, is one of sympathy for the food-short British people.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- A special dividend in addition to a regular quarterly disbursement was declared today by Swift Co., meat packers, at the annual meeting of stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The text of Secretary Stimson's statement before the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the Aid-to-Britain Bill was as follows:

The American Group of the Societe des Architectes Diplomes par le Gouvernment announced yesterday that it had awarded a gold medal to the University of Pennsylvania as "the American university whose School of Architecture has the best record of accomplishment in the teaching of architecture during the last year."

A further increase this Spring in the demand for knitted outerwear was predicted by I.P. Cohen at the third Wool-Knitted Outerwear Show presented to buyers and the fashion press yesterday in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton by Woolknit Associates, Inc. Mr. Cohen, a director of the organization, reported that demand for this type of apparel had increased about 75 per cent since last year, when the group started its promotion.

Twelve contributions totaling $111 reached the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and increased the sum that has been received in response to this twenty-ninth annual appeal for the most needy persons in New York City to $243,627.50.

Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh boxer, makes the first defense of his world welterweight championship tonight in Madison Square Garden against Hammering Henry Armstrong, the ring's perpetual motion machine, who will try to regain the title he held until last Oct. 4, when Zivic unceremoniously blasted the crown from his battle-scarred brow.

Contracts for building and engineering projects awarded last year in the thirty-seven Eastern states amounted to $4,003,957,000, the largest volume since 1930 and a 13 per cent increase over 1939. Construction volume increased in 1940 for the seventh consecutive year, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association voted unanimously yesterday to "support the present program before Congress for full implementation of our national defense and for maximum aid to Great Britain and its allied democracies in the struggle against totalitarianism."

The American Merchant Marine Institute, representing deep-sea ship owners along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, yesterday offered the National Maritime Union a temporary increase of $2.50 monthly for each of the 30,000 seamen employed by the associated lines during negotiations at the institute offices, 11 Broadway.

The grave crisis in England and the United States has demanded, and now demands, more than ever, the maximum production of war necessities as an aid to self-preservation. This necessitates the maximum hours of labor in war plants, which is a seven-day week of twenty-four hours a day.

As the climax of a six-week period in which forty-six separate blocks of listed stocks involving 1,622,482 shares have been sold "off the market" after the close of regular trading hours on the New York Stock Exchange, a large banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co. offered shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday a block of 500,000 shares of common stock of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

Prices of cotton futures worked irregularly lower yesterday in moderately active dealings. After opening off 6 points to up 3 points, closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 3 to 8 points. January showed the largest loss as the evening-up of the few remaining contracts in that position continued.

William and Anthony Esposito, ex-convict brothers charged with taking two men's lives in a sensational hold-up at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street last Tuesday, began sparring with the law yesterday in an attempt to save their own lives.
For a while last night it appeared that J.C. (Buster) Lyons of the New York A.C. was going to come through with the victory of his squash tennis career and the surprise of the season.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A strike of C.I.O. United Automobile Workers at the Ryan Aeronautical Company was set for next Tuesday after a peace meeting called today by a Federal conciliator failed to effect settlement of a wage dispute.

The number of new loans made on Manhattan realty last year was about even with 1939, but the dollar volume of these mortgages declined about 15 per cent, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York from reports of the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

PARIS, Jan. 4 (Delayed via Berlin) -- France's first "open" tennis tournament, recently finished here, resulted in a victory for the amateurs when the Davis Cup player, Christian Boussus, won the singles title in a choice field that included Henri Cochet, M. Plaa and Paul Feret.

A new aviation training center to equip men to work in national defense industries will open early in March in the building owned by THE NEW YORK TIMES at Dean Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday.

The loan exhibition of paintings by El Greco will open with a private view this afternoon, to the public tomorrow, at the Knoedler Gallery, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is directed by Stephan Bourgeois, who collected the pictures and prepared the illustrated catalogue.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16 -- The welfare of the individual soldier will be the first consideration of the Army in purchasing fresh fruits, vegetables and other foodstuffs for the draft army, but consumer, producer and trade considerations will also bulk large in such buying, John A. Martin, special adviser to the director of the division of purchases of the Office of Production Management, said here today.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Problems of production are still troubling the British. At first they did not work enough. Then in a burst of zeal following the collapse of France they cut out holidays and lengthened the work day. Now they are beginning to wonder if they did not go too far perhaps and defeat their own purpose by working so hard that they produced less.

ROME, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Humbert, Prince of Piedmont, the heir to the Italian throne, was promoted today to the rank of an Army General. Informed sources believed it likely that he would receive a command on an active front, but whether in Albania or Africa was not known.
Atop a mass of pipe scaffolding workmen yesterday were busy carrying out a redecoration and lighting plan in the lobby of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.
Ionel Cotnareanu, through Tishman Realty Construction Co., sixroom furnished penthouse in 14 E 75th St; Apartment Homes House Realty Co, broker.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- A warning to President Roosevelt that any British-inspired attempt on the part of the United States to detach Italy from Germany is doomed to failure was issued today by Italian political circles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Replying to a question as to whether the British Government had scraped the coffer clean of all its dollar resources, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau said at a press conference today that practically the whole $2,000,000,000 British Stabilization Fund had been used to pay for British munitions orders in the United States.

WITH BRITISH FORCES OUTSIDE TOBRUK, Libya, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Burrowed within the semi-circle of a thirty-mile defense line, which includes a ten-foot tank trap, the 30,000 Italian regulars at Tobruk apparently have been ordered to resist the pending British assault to the death.

THE TIMES editorial "For National Unity" exemplifies the best traditions of American newspaper leadership in great causes. National unity is the greatest cause today. We must have national unity if democracy is to live for our children and theirs.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- Premier Mussolini today completed a four-day tour of Apulia, the southern region facing Albania across the Adriatic, during which he visited troops, airports, industrial plants and soldiers wounded in Albania.

Net assets of National Investors Corporation slipped last year to $11,390,806 from $14,888,257, or to $5.31 a share from $6.05 a share, jaccording to a pamphlet report issued yesterday. Not counting a loss on security sales, the investment trust ahd a net profit of $468,072 for the year ended Dec. 31, 1940.
