WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A Federal Reserve Board summary of industrial conditions in the United States in December and the first half of January reports that new orders for steel were equal to or slightly greater than production, although steel ingot production had been sustained at about 96 per cent of full capacity.

A pair of goals by Lynn Patrick saved the Rangers from defeat at the hands of Boston in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The battering Bruins, after gaining a two-goal advantage, yielded two counters to Lynn within a minute and a half, and these counters brought about a deadlock that lasted through the overtime period.

Reporting to stockholders for last year. Charles C. Bowen, president of the Standard Accident Insurance Company, said net premiums written amounted to $14,751,724, a decrease of $103,218 compared with 1939. The year's gain from insurance or underwriting operations amounted to $928,175.

Germany will eventually lose the war because of the failure of her chemical industry, hitherto regarded as one of her most valuable assets, William O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, declared here yesterday. Mr. O'Neil was attending a distributor conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- A seventeen-point program designed to coordinate the State's public health facilities with State and national defense plans was presented today in a special report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature from Assemblyman Lee H. Mailler, chairman of the State Health Commission.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Art Rubin of New York came from behind in the last six innings tonight to hand Jake Schaefer of Cleveland his first defeat in the world three-cushion billiard tournament. The score was 50 to 44 and came in forty-two innings, the shortest game of the event.
Plans for remodeling were announced yesterday in connection with sales of several multi-family buildings in Manhattan.
Due mainly to the decline in New York clearings, check transactions this week fell sharply below the preceding week, and were 4.4 per cent under the amount for the corresponding period last year.

The manner in which the Selective Service Act has been administered in New York City was praised yesterday by Major Ernest M. Culligan, chief of the public relations staff of the National Selective Service Administration.

At her milinery showing yesterday afternoon Florence Reichman gave her audience the key to her trends by saying that "the collection we are presenting goes back to the early Nineteen Hundreds, just as many of the clothes do."

Another week-end of sport looms for the Eastern ski army, snow reports from the North Country last night showing conditions generally good. It was snowing at many points, and what turn the elements will take today will be a deciding factor in whether skiing will be on a large scale or of a limited variety tomorrow and Sunday.

The Real Estate Board of New York recommends creation of a State Board of Assessment Review, within the structure of the present State Tax Department, empowered to hear and determine appeals for review of assessment made on the part of persons who deem themselves aggrieved by any assessment for taxation of real property.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16 -- The Belgrade offices of the British news and propaganda agency, "Britanova," were closed and the doors sealed today by order of the Belgrade Prefect of Police. There was no official explanation of the order.

The population of New York City, which is 7,380,000 according to the 1940 census, will reach eventually a maximum of 8,600,000 to 9,000,000, according to T.T. McCrosky, director of planning of the New York City Department of Planning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- An all-Negro pursuit squadron is to be organized by the Army. It will consist of about thirty-three officer-pilots and a ground crew of about 400 men, all colored. The squadron will have twenty-seven planes.

A categorical denial was issued yesterday by Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., to the charge by Senator Wheeler that "the motion picture industry is carrying on a violent propaganda campaign intending to incite the American people to the point where they will become involved in war."
McCHORD FIELD, Wash., Jan. 16 (AP) -- McChord Field officers reported tonight that an Army bombing plane with seven men aboard was unreported since leaving the air base here at 10:20 A.M. today.

Lucrezia Bori, formerly a leading member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Benny Goodman, of "swing" fame, and Mrs. I. J. Fox as judges, unanimously voted yesterday that discretion was the better part of valor and agreed to a draw in a debate by two groups of youngsters on the respective merits of "swing" and "opera."

Supplies of locally dressed meats were moderate to normal yesterday. Demand for traefer meats was fair to good and the market had a generally firm undertone. Trading in kosher meats was light as usual for Thursday, and prices were generally unchanged from late Wednesday.

A bottleneck which threatens to disrupt the entire defense program is the dissatisfaction of labor. For the first time in over a decade the demand for skilled labor exceeds the supply and labor intends to take advantage of the situation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 16 -- Closely shadowed by the British auxiliary cruiser Asturias a vessel, "supposedly" the French steamship Mendoza, anchored this afternoon at Rio Grande do Sul bar, about two miles off shore. The Asturias could not be seen.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's defense of the government's British aid policy before the Congressional committee was only briefly recorded in the German press, which designates the Secretary's statements as "faithful reproductions of his master's voice."

DUE to the fact that the Reds and Tigers were engaged in an interesting world series last October, this observer was in Detroit the night that Fritzie of the zestful Zivics removed the welterweight crown from the dark brow of Hammering Henery Armstrong. It must have been a sad night for Armstrong in more ways than one.

Only two works figured on the program given by Bruno Walter when he made his initial appearance of the season as guest conductor with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Although still in a slight minority, many more American voters favor sending war materials to England in American ships today than did so when the war broke out, surveys by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicate, Dr. George Gallup, the institute's director, reports.

WITH THE BRITISH MEDITERRANEAN FLEET, Jan. 16 -- The United States, closely watching British Fleet operations in the Mediterranean, has boosted its staff of official observers to four, with a fifth expected to arrive soon.

Gross revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad in December were about $42,063,000, up 4.8 per cent from December, 1939, M.W. Clement, president, said yesterday. Freight revenues gained 4.7 per cent and passenger revenues 6.1 per cent.

THE publishers of Jan Valtin's "Out of the Night"* speak of it as an "incredible autobiography," and that seems a temperate enough way to describe this amazing and enormously overwritten account of a professional revolutionist's career in the violent reaches of the Long Armistice.

ATHENS, Jan. 16 -- Virtually no information concerning the fighting in Albania was given out here this evening, except by the Press Ministry, which issued a brief statement to the effect that all enemy attacks during the day had been beaten back, while the Greeks were able to continue their advance in all sectors.

Following the re-election of all its officers for one-year terms, the Outdoor Cleanliness Association of New York, Inc., heard reports yesterday on the results of its crusade for public sanitation, gave its annual award for "neatness of premises" to the Seward Park High School and formally opened a campaign to buy six convertible tractors for clearing away the wreckage and debris in London caused by German air raids.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The entire American Army of 1,418,097 enlisted men will be in camp by June 1, fully housed, with all its personal equipment and with basic weapons enough for training purposes, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, stated at a press conference today.

The drivers' strike that had cut off deliveries of wholesale groceries to 15,000 independent grocers and blocked food shipments to Great Britain since Jan. 6 was settled at 2 A.M. yesterday through the joint efforts of the State Mediation Board, Mayor La Guardia's labor relations staff and District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn.

Sales and earnings of the Interstate Home Equipment Company, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 2, 1940, established new records for the company. Net profit, according to the report issued yesterday, amounted to $1,079,463 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Any child in the London metropolitan area under 14 years old who is "suffering in mind or body as a result of hostile attacks or is in such a state of health as to be likely to suffer if he remains" is now ordered evacuated by Malcolm MacDonald, Minister of Health, acting upon recent defensee regulations.
Metropolitan Iron Foundry, Brooklyn, has advanced the price of castings 1 cent a pound, effective on Feb. 1.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 -- Last year the most significant development in American racing was the increased number of distance races. Actually this development was only in its experimental stage. The year 1941 should see the full flowering of races over extended distances, testing the complete Dowers of thoroughbred heart and stamina.

Nelson Hayes writes from South Norwalk, Conn., that after a year of background exploration, plotting and replotting, his new novel is "definitely under way." The story will be laid in the Caribbean with the leading character West Indian English, a man who spends his first fifteen years among the islands, goes north for his education and career and returns twenty years later intending to create a sense of social progress in the island society.

"Uncle Sam -- The Non-Belligerent," latest in the March of Time series. will be released nationally today. The picture presents scenes filmed by official German Army camera men in occupied France, which are being shown here for the first time.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A newspaper controlled by the Japanese Foreign Office today described the United States Pacific Fleet concentration as "a challenge and a threat" and advised President Roosevelt to withdraw the warships from Hawaii as the best way to keep American troops out of foreign wars.

A new approach to cooperative newspaper advertising with dealers will be undertaken this year by the General Tire and Rubber Company, it was announced yesterday at a meeting for distributors at the Hotel Roosevelt. In the past the company has borne 50 per cent of the cost of dealer newspaper campaigns, but under a new arrangement will pay the entire expense of dealers' copy.

Meat prices are still rising, and this week there are slight increases, not serious in themselves, on all varieties. However, pork is 26 per cent above what it was a year ago, beef is 20 per cent higher, veal is up by 12 per cent and lamb by 11 per cent.

Commodore Charles F. Chapman, veteran speed-boat official, referee of most important regattas in recent years and a Gold Cup pilot in his earlier days, stunned the motorboating fraternity last night at the Hotel Lexington when he made an unexpected announcement that he was going off watch after some twenty-seven years on the bridge and quitting his official duties.

The continued return flow of currency to the banks, which is the usual January experience, and the further increase in the nation's monetary gold stock were the principal factors in a further rise in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the statement made public yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Canadiens hung a 5-1 defeat on the Black Hawks tonight to snap their five-game National Hockey League losing streak and Chicago's string of four games without a defeat. The victory tightened Montreal's hold on sixth place in the standing.

The last Legislative apportionment in this State was in 1917; the last Congressional in 1911. In 1934 both parties cried for fair and equal representation. In 1933 and 1934 Governor Lehman recommended action on reapportionment in two special messages. In 1935 he was still earnest for reapportionment without delay.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau's disclosure of the financial resources of the British Empire, exclusive of Canada, presents a different picture from the more or less rough estimates made by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in August, 1939, just before the beginning of war in Europe.

Howard C. Sykes, former president and governor of the New York Curb Exchange, has arranged to buy the New York Stock Exchange seat of George Hepburn for $31,000, it was learned yesterday. Notice of his application will be posted on the floor of the Stock Exchange tomorrow and will be considered the committee on admissions on Jan. 30.
Indications multiplied last night that the New York area and adjacent parts of the Northeast were being revisited by an ice storm similar to the destructive one of March 3 and 4, 1940.
ROME, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Interest in wheat was limited today, with the market taking its cue from the action of securities. Professional sentiment was inclined to the bear side, and while there were several moderate rallies, scattered liquidation attributed to professional operators came into the market late in the session and the close on the Board of Trade here was at the bottom, with losses of 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- Because of the demands of the national defense program there will be no National Automobile Show this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The general level of wholesale prices remained unchanged in the week ended on Jan. 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 80.2, compared with 79.5 in the corresponding week a year ago.

For the twentieth consecutive time the current week's engineering awards, with a volume of $89,174,000 exceed the total for the corresponding week of last year, according to the Engineering News-Record. The 1941 aggregate is 116 per cent greater than that for 1940, but fails to reach the level attained last week by 43 per cent.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The possibility of asking the Americas for permission to establish some sort of contraband control at a West Indies base, such as Trinidad, is being considered here.

Charles Lawson, the truck driver whose refusal to have his eyes examined after a collision with a parked taxicab led to a strike and a $100,000 damage suit, appeared at the offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau yesterday in response to a subpoena and passed an eye test.
The standing in the world pocket billiard championship remained unchanged as a result of yesterday's play, each of the eight contestants winning one game and losing one.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- A bill carrying out Governor Lehman's recommendation that interest charges on small loans should be reduced was introduced today by Senator Gutman and Assemblyman Cariello, New York Democrats.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, has decided to revive his meat grading bill, which was killed by the City Council three years ago, he said yesterday. His decision is based on the rising price of meat, and a change, he believes, has taken place in the attitude of retail butchers since the first measure was presented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Joseph P. Kennedy, retiring Ambassador to Great Britain, conferred with President Roosevelt unexpectedly today. As he left the White House he said that his radio speech on Saturday night would accent "staying out of war."
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 17 -- London's sirens sounded earlier last night than Wednesday, but the alarm was followed by less bombing and gunfire.

An extra year-end distribution of 35 cents a share was voted yesterday by directors of the Emporium Capwell Company. This will bring total payments for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31 to $1.75 a share on the common stock, against $1.30 paid the year before.

In a hard-fought five-game encounter, Miss Helen Rice of the Cosmopolitan Club won the women's metropolitan Class B squash racquets championship by defeating Miss Eloise Greene of the Rockaway Hunting Club, 16 -- 13, 14 -- 18, 15 -- 6, 7 -- 15, 18 -- 15, at the Junior League yesterday.

A further addition to the group of firms in the diamond business which is springing up in the upper Forties near Fifth Avenue was announced yesterday with the leasing of an entire floor in 21 West Forty-sixth Street to David Lubelsky and Leon Raisky, diamond cutters and polishers, by Sol Stern Co., Inc., brokers.

A picture showing a group of 5-year-old children saluting the American flag, entitled "I Pledge Allegiance," was judged yesterday first prize winner in "American Close-Up," the Camp Fire Girls' National Photography Contest.
FARMINGTON, Conn., Jan. 16 -- Through this peaceful village, established in 1640, an alarum raced today: "The Curfew Fund is running low."
Public response to the 1941 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign was urged yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, New York City Health Commissioner.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 16 -- German communities in the Far East are now confidently predicting that within a month the activities of German raiders in the South Pacific will be at least doubled.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, who arrived here from war-torn Europe in November on his eightieth birthday because "the atmosphere in Europe was personally unbearable," thanked the people of the United States yesterday for the kindness and honor shown him and for the efforts now being pushed to extend aid to Polish sufferers.

W ASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board tonight dismissed a petition filed by the C.I.O.-United Automobile Workers for investigation and certification of bargaining representatives at the Saginaw, Mich., plant of the Eaton Manufacturing Company.

The breakdown of the conference of Canadian Provincial Premiers, called to consider the so-called Sirois report, was not surprising in view of the conflicting interests involved. The Royal commission or Dominion-Provincial Relations, which produced the Sirois report, was appointed for the purpose of seeking a solution to the chaotic relations of the Dominion and the Provinces, especially as to their respective rights and responsibilities in the fields of finance and of the social services.

Every year the Cruising Club of America awards its Blue Water Medal to mark some feat of seamanship and navigation by an amateur yachtsman. In peaceful years it may be a round-the-world cruise or a skillful deepwater operation. This year, however, the award goes to those yachtsmen of Britain who made history by evacuating 400,000 Allied soldiers from Dunkerque in May, 1940.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Kayak II, big black Argentine thoroughbred of the C.S. Howard stable, returned to the turf wars today after an enforced lay-off Since last September and finished second to Augury, speed-burning filly from the N.S. McCarthy barns at Santa Anita Park.

LONDON, Jan 16 (AP) -- The Bank of England withdrew 7,610,000 from circulation in the week ended yesterday, the Bank's weekly statement showed today, bringing the total down to 602,843,000, compared with a record peak of 616,904,000 reached at the Christmas holiday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Repeated border clashes on the Russo-Rumanian frontiers, cancellation of passenger rail traffic in Hungary and reports that Germany would formally take over Rumania combined tonight to keep the Balkans in a state of disturbed anxiety.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 16 -- "Love the Americas," was the order that President Manuel Avila Camacho today gave to the graduates of San Jacinto Military College, to whom he presented officers' swords and revolvers.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The 9,100-ton Southampton, one of the newest and best British cruisers, was so severely damaged by German dive bombers last Friday that she had to be abandoned by her crew and sunk by other British warships, the Admiralty announced today.

HAVANA, Jan. 16 -- No agreement has yet been reached between Cuba and the United States on the financing of surplus sugar production in Cuba during the crop milling now starting, it was learned from reliable sources today.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 16 -- The Walter P. Chrysler Jr. collection of modern art had a preview of its first complete showing tonight at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts here. Mr. Chrysler came down for the preview with a group of friends and entertained with a cocktail party at the Commonwealth Club before a dinner given in his honor at the Executive Mansion by the Governor of Virginia and Mrs. James H. Price.

Parks Commissioner Robert Moses and John S. Macdonald, chief engineer of the Walsh Construction Company, are the winners of the first annual awards for outstanding achievement in the heavy construction field awarded by The Moles, according to an announcement yesterday.

Convinced of the legality of merging the Lincoln and Horace Mann Schools of Teachers College, Columbia University, the college trustees will deny the request of the Lincoln Parent-Teacher Association for a court settlement of the legal issues in the merger of the two progressive schools, it was indicated yesterday by Dean William F. Russell of the college.

Truckmen, cab drivers and private car owners who paid little attention to regulations designed to clear the cross-town areas and speed up traffic, manoeuvred and parked in the midtown area yesterday with unusual disregard of warning signs, apparently in the belief that the police would he more lenient because of the disagreeable weather.

The third and last session of the auction sale of first editions, autograph letters and rare Americana brought $12,007 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, last night. The grand total of the three sales was $30,478.

It seems to me that the success of the David Mannes symphony concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art should encourage the City of New York to continue having free or inexpensive symphony concerts at the museum every Saturday night throughout the year.

The four-story apartment house at 773 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, has been sold for cash above a first mortgage of $25,000 by the Davwell Realty Corporation to the Bowling Real Estate Corporation through Samuel Hurwitz, broker. Assessed for $29,000, the building occupies a plot 37 by 129.10 feet.

The attack by German Stuka bombers on a strongly escorted British convoy in the Mediterranean offers further testimony on the issue of air power versus sea power, but its evidence is by no means conclusive. While the outcome may be claimed as a victory by the advocates of each side, the seven-hour battle seems actually to have been decisive for neither.
May I commend you for the recent editorial "The Refugee Problem"?

Despite its tremendous growth, the air transport industry has reached only 15 per cent of its potential market, W.A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, given in honor of the Airlines Terminal Corporation and the new Airlines Terminal at Park Avenue and Forty-second Stret.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 -- Tommy Goodwin of New York, who has been playing almost perfect golf since winning the medal in the thirty-fourth annual Lake Worth championship, reached the final today by defeating Briggs S. Cunningham of Green Farms, Conn., 4 and 3.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Royal Air Force headquarters today issued this communique:
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Royal Air Force headquarters today issued this communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 -- While the British forces consolidated their positions outside Tobruk under cover of a steady artillery barrage in the last few days, frequent Royal Air Force bombing and other flights ranged further into Libya, with concentrated attacks on Bengazi and vicinity, it was announced here today.

Wider use of quotas, more stringent anti-dumping laws, strict enforcement of regulations against unfair trade practices as they relate to imports and establishment of American rather than foreign value as the basis for duty assessments were among suggestions for a postwar tariff program advanced yesterday by William L. Monro, reelected president of the American Tariff League at the group's fifty-sixth annual meeting at the Union League Club.

Today's events: "Tannhaeuser," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; international children's festival, "Let's Sing for China," Stanley Chapple, director, presented for the benefit of the Chinese Medical Relief, Town Hall, 3:45; Bernardo Segall, piano, Town Hail, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- During the week ended Jan. 15 member bank reserve balances increased $130,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $86,000,000 in money in circulation and $8,000,000 in Treasury cash, and increases of $32,000,000 in gold stock, $17,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $4,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by an increase of $17,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 16 -- Meeting in an atmosphere of complete harmony, 1,200 Arab and Jewish citrus growers today discussed urgent problems facing Palestine's staple agricultural industry as a result of suspension of Mediterranean shipping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Eight motion-picture corporations, whose finances in 1939 are reviewed in a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission, paid out one-third less in dividends to stockholders in that year than in 1938.

Because young growing companies will have to bear the brunt of further excess profits taxes, as they have relatively small investments and enjoyed little or no profits in recent years, special tax relief for them was recommended last night by J.S. Seidman, C.P.A., at a forum meeting of the Pace Institute.

Sweeping with disastrous speed through an old three-story frame building at 6 and 8 Doyers Street and an adjoining three-story brick building at 10 and 12 Doyers Street, Chinatown, fire took the lives of three men a little after noon yesterday and covered much of Manhattan south of Canal Street with a thick pall of smoke.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Chinese dollar slumped sharply today because of heavy speculative buying in foreign currencies and closed at 5 1/4 United States cents, a drop of 1/4 cent. One reason assigned for the drop was the reduction by the Hong Kong Shanghai Bank, which operates the Chinese Government Stabilization Fund, of its buying rate.

Strong naval bases along the northeastastern coast of South America and among the Galapagos and Cocos Islands, added to existing bases, would make "the American defense position, already strong, nearly impregnable to attack from either the Atlantic or Pacific," according to Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District.

A separate campaign for funds to equip a shipwreck rescue fleet of fast motorboats, to operate off the shores of Great Britain, was opened yesterday by the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue. W.W. Aldrich, president of the society, said the initial goal of the drive would be $150,000, estimated to be enough to outfit thirty boats.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Executives of the National Football League laid the groundwork today for creation of a commissionership to govern their fast-growing sport.

The Department of Commerce of the City of New York is anxious to complete its survey of the effect on retail trade and employment of the change of the observance date of Thanksgiving in 1940 and 1939, it was made known yesterday. Questionnaires were sent during the latter part of December to 1,700 retail establishments in the five boroughs, but delay in the replies is hampering completion of the survey.

THE way to a Bemelmans art is through his stomach. Only infrequently is the thought of good food and drink far from the mind of the Splendide's laureate. High on an Ecuadorean mountain he paints a nostalgic portrait of a famous New York restaurant at dinner time, and deep in the jungle his mind repeats a litany the great dishes he has known.
Though it cannot be justified, John Kieran's recent postal plague may be explained by the sincere fanaticism engendered by the personality of the personnel of the Seton Hall basketball squad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Senator Wheeler of Montana, an isolationist leader, today demanded that the next edition of the March of Time omit photos of him in which he was represented as having answered President Roosevelt's "fireside chat" message advocating "all-out" aid to Britain.
Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a five-point range and closed 2 points lower to 2 points higher.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 17 (UP) -- General Chiang Kai-shek's national military council announced today that General Yeh Ting, commander of the Communist-controlled New Fourth Route Army, had been imprisoned and was awaiting court-martial following the suppression of a "revolt" of his troops.

Bernardo Segall, Brazilian pianist, who made his local debut four years ago, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. As at his previous appearances in this city, Mr. Segall was technically proficient and had at his disposal a tone capable of much that was charming in the way of coloring and nuance.

Zivic stuck several straight lefts in Armstrong's face, and in a clinch drove several rights to the face. Armstrong drove three rights to the ribs as Zivic continued to snap a straight left to the face. Zivic drove three hard rights to the face and Armstrong hooked a left to the head.

Addressing members of the Alumnae of the New York-School of Social Work at a dinner-meeting at the Hotel Irving last night, Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist of the American Museum of Natural History, emphasized the need to draw "on every possible source of strength so as to create, speedily and efficiently, new social institutions which will implement democracy in its struggle for existence."

The situation in the lumber transportation industry again has been reflected in rate increases, according to a new schedule of tariffs drawn up by the Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association, it was disclosed yesterday.

More than 2,000 volumes and papers, among them first editions and manuscripts of some of the most famous books in the world, will be sold here at public auction beginning April 8, it was announced yesterday.

The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries had a net income of $10,732,734 in 1940, according to the utility's annual report made public yesterday by Alfred C. Marshall, president. This net was equal to $8.43 a share on 1,272,260 capital shares outstanding, and compared with a net of $9,640,295, or $7.58 a share, earned in 1939.

Along with John Kieran I enjoy the somewhat dubious distinction of having been honored with many missiles pointing out the prowess of Seton Hall's basketball team and asking why wasn't somethtng done about having it play in Madison Square Garden.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe king of three-cushion billiards, was released from the hospital today, a fact which comes under the heading of bad news for his seventeen rivals for the world's championship in the current tournament.

Permit me to call attention to a photograph on Page 3 of THE TIMES today with the caption "American Tobacco for Soldiers of Greece." The photograph in itself is what arouses my ire and amazes me. The photograph shows two Grecian girls in native costume standing back of a table on which are displayed the American and Greek flags and resting on the colors is a box containing jars of tobacco.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Senator Byrnes declared tonight that if Great Britain can "hold Hitler for a year, we can hold him forever."

The Seventeenth Regiment of the New York Guard, with a personnel of 479 officers and enlisted men, was mustered into service last night in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-third Street, after a regimental parade and review.
BERLIN, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Today's German High Command communique:

Because Helen Traubel, the Bruennhilde-to-be, developed laryngitis and because the company's two other Bruennhildes, Kirsten Flagstad and Marjorie Lawrence, were occupied with recitals, the Metropolitan Opera last night was obliged to make its first change in a scheduled opera this season.

Members of all faiths are asked to go into their respective houses of worship on Monday when President Roosevelt will be inaugurated and pray for divine guidance for a world at war, the suggestion being made yesterday by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, the headquarters of which are at 300 Fourth Avenue.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, who has been unsuccessful in his attempt to have the Triborough Bridge Authority reduce the toll on the Bronx-Manhattan spur of the Triborough Bridge from 25 cents to 10 cents, in a statement issued yesterday proposed the building of a Bronx-Manhattan tunnel to relieve heavy traffic congestion of the Harlem River bridges.

George Lowe, 51 years old, a Chinatown roustabout with no fixed home since he came to this country from China thirty years ago, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate McGee in the Homicide Court on suspicion of having started the fire early Thursday morning at 6 to 12 Doyers Street which caused the deaths of three men, still not definitely identified.
The New York University swimming team gained its first victory this season when 1 defeated Manhattan College, 52 -- 23, last night at the Spence Natatorial Institute.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 18 -- After having pondered the matter for twelve hours, the Japanese Government has decided not to answer Wednesday's statement of Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States. The ostensible ground for the decision was that after Japan had ignored President Roosevelt's "fireside chat" and his message to Congress it was unnecessary to reply to Mr. Hull.

In the Jan. 4 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES there appeared an article captioned "East-West Stars Draw A.A.U. Ban." Evidently Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National Amateur Athletic Union is a sporting critic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A commercial Aircraft Priorities Committee to determine the needs of transport services in the face of the military air program was named today by E.R. Stettinius Jr., director of priorities of the Office of Production Management.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- The 31,100-ton British battleship Malaya was reported today by well-informed German quarters to have been towed into Gibraltar in a seriously damaged condition. It would appear from the German account that the Malaya, which was allegedly bombed in the attack on Jan. 10 that resulted in the sinking of the British cruiser Southampton and the crippling of the aircraft carrier Illustrious, will be out of action for some time.

President Ed Barrow sent 1941 contracts to thirty-five Yankee players yesterday. In view of the fact that almost the entire cast failed to come up to par last year, as the Bronx Bombers failed in their quest for a fifth straight world pennant and championship, it is generally believed the salary cuts exceeded the number of boosts.

Long before Germany invaded Poland it was freely predicted that civilians would not be spared in another war and that whole cities would be laid waste. Cities have indeed been subjected to ruthless bombardment, civilians are in even greater danger than are the armed forces -- at least in Great Britain -- but as yet the predictions have not been completely fulfilled.

The three major divisions of business operated much better than seasonally this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. Wholesale markets were extremely active, production maintained its peak rates and retail volume was well ahead of average.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Air Secretary Sir Archibald Sinclair declared in a speech today that the Royal Air Force would "blaze the way to victory in the coming year."

Long Island University's Blackbirds marked Bill (Dolly) King's last appearance with them on their home court at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night by routing the John Marshall College quintet of Jersey City, 60 to 33. King rose to the occasion by dropping in 18 points to lead both sides in scoring.

The Appellate Division, in a three-to-two decision yesterday, outlawed the system started last year by Police Commissioner Valentine under which men on the eligible list for patrolmen were used provisionally as telephone operators in the department.

The automobile industry has for years occupied a key position in our economy. Inevitably it has been called upon to play a major role in the great national defense effort. More than $1,000,000,000 of defense contracts are on the books of the automobile companies, which is about 10 per cent of the total defense program to date.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- The strike-threatened Ryan Aeronautical Company rejected a new wage proposal of the C.I.O.-United Automobile Workers today.

Prosperity in individual cities created by defense contracts has become the major theme of the bulk of newspaper promotion and advertising. Copy in advertising trade publications, research studies and promotion pieces of newspapers in the industrial areas all emphasize the volume of armament spending in those sections, the increased employment and consumer buying power and the expanded markets for national products.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill in a speech tonight in which he said Britain must have an avalanche of United States weapons, referred to a growing British belief that Italy may collapse in the not distant future, and that Herr Hitler's armies will march into the peninsula.
IN the wake of the recent Ranger-Bruin tie game this observer ran into M'sieu Lestairre Patrick and M'sieu Francois Boucher of the Ranger side. They were still breathing hard.

The major part of the vast art collection of William Randolph Hearst, valued at $15,000,000 to $50,000,000, will be placed on sale Feb. 3 on the fifth floor of Gimbel Brothers department store following a week's private display for the benefit of art dealers and collectors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today adoption of an amended form U 5s, which is used by registered public utility holding companies in filing annual reports with the commission. The principal substantive changes in the amended form follow:

Net assets of the Adams Express Company available to the common stock on Dec. 31 last were $11.12 a share, against $8.23 on June 30, 1940, and $12.64 on Dec. 31, 1939, according to a brochure report released today. Net assets before deduction of any securities were $28,753,885 at the end of 1940.

Reduction of the debts of the nation's 175,000 local governments is an essential part of the national defense program, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared in his monthly review of business sent out to members yesterday,

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 17 -- Today's Bourse developed a weak tone under the influence of the bond market, which on the announcement of the new Netherlands issue, dropped as much as 3 points, with large offerings.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, former labor racketeer in Fulton Fish Market, and two others were indicted yesterday on charges of having conspired during Lanza's imprisonment as a Sherman law violator to extort $120 weekly from Local 202 of the Teamsters Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Henry S. Morgan testified today at a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission that his father, J.P. Morgan, called him on the telephone one day and said that he was going to give him $500,000 in cash.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Southeastern Europe, already forced to eat stale black bread and pay exorbitant prices for essential foodstuffs, now is facing new shortages because, officials say, so many rail lines have been commandeered for Nazi troop movements and Italian and German shipments of war materials.

Buildings Commissioner William E. Wilson has dismissed nineteen elevator inspectors on charges brought by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, that they had accepted gratuities from building owners and elevator companies, it was learned yesterday.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Charles A. Munn gave a dinner tonight, followed by motion pictures at Amado, where Miss Marjory de Wardener of New York today joined his house party.

In sentencing two men to indeterminate terms in the penitentiary and suspending sentence during good behavior, Judge Kennard Underwood in Queens County Court yesterday declared from the bench that he felt another man was more responsible.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- Belief that the continued existence of the British Commonwealth of Nations is essential to the United States was assorted today by Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister to the United States, in an address at a Boston Chamber of Commerce luncheon, "just as the continued existence of the United States is essential to us.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- After a silence of two days the Italian press today printed a lengthy summary of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech. The Secretary's passages containing scathing criticism of the totalitarian States were not deleted. Mr. Hull's references to control of the sea by nations of good-will elicits in the Popolo di Roma the scornful remark that Washington once again brings forward a "formula of hypocritical Quakerism."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Following is the text of a statement made by Secretary Knox before the Foreign Affairs Committee today:

Many dinner parties were given before the second in the series of subscription dances, known as Three Nights of Dancing, sponsored by Miss Clementine Miller for youner married couples, debutantes of former seasons and their friends, which was held last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre.

More than sixty New York members of Kappa Alpha, Southern fraternity founded by General Robert E. Lee at Washington and Lee University in 1865, attended the annual Robert E. Lee dinner last night at the Hotel Warwick, 65 West Fifty- fourth Street, at which Dr. W.S. Hamilton, representative from the order's national headquarters at Atlanta, was guest of honor.

The local track season, delayed for two weeks because defense rules bar the use of armories by civilians, will open tonight, but it will be the fastest start it ever has had, since it will begin with the annual Metropolitan A.A.U. championships at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- With the bulk of the crop holdovers from earlier in the week, the cattle market was largely a cleanup today. Steers and yearlings were easy and showed a decline of 25 to 50 cents. Hogs closed unevenly and 10 to 20 cents lower, while sheep were scarce and nominally steady.

Infuriated by his mother's insistence that he drink some coffee, a youth on parole from a mental institution slashed her with a paring knife yesterday in their apartment at 100 West Sixty-seventh Street, struck down his father with a crowbar and after his parents had fled in terror, set the rooms afire.

The temperature continues to rise and fall in the Balkans like an intermittent fever. Day after day we hear contradictory rumors and alarms, interspersed with official statements from Sofia, Belgrade and Ankara, the three capitals under immediate pressure, which are clearly designed to reassure the jittery populations that up to the moment the situation remains unchanged.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Counsel for four General Motors Corporation concerns argued before the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today that a conviction on antitrust law violation charges was erroneous because a company could not conspire against itself.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17 -- Another heavy assault on Catania in Sicily, the Axis air base from which dive bombers have been attacking the British Mediterranean Fleet, was reported today by the Royal Air Force. Fires and explosions in the target area were described by returning pilots.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 -- Upsets were a "dime a dozen" today in the thrill-packed first and second rounds of the $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

For many years now the basketball teams at City College have rated with the best in the country. Despite a shortage of good material and the handicap of a rigorous curriculum and high admission standards, the team has been able to compete successfully with other schools from all parts of the nation.
VICHY, France, Jan. 17 -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot, speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, has arrived in Vichy and has seen important personages.

Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to a large group of real estate men in City Hall to support a bill in Albany which would permit the city to use some of its $71,000,000 revenue from emergency relief taxes for purposes allied to relief, such as old-age pensions, child welfare and hospitalization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 -- Harvard Observatory announced today the reported discovery of a new comet by an amateur astronomer in California who already has two other cometary discoveries to his credit.

I read with much surprise your Jan. 11 editorial "Peekskill's Budget Problem," in which you raise the question whether the provision of our city charter, which gives the people the right to say how their money shall be spent by voting on the budget, should be retained, and in which you also express doubt whether the people really know enough about budget-making to justify their voting upon it.

Torger Tokle, 21-year-old Norwegian sensation, and two of his compatriots, Herald Sorensen, Norfolk (Conn.) W.S.A. veteran, and Bjorn Lie of the Norsemen S.C., left yesterday for Fox River Grove, Ill., where they will compete in the thirty-fifth annual Norge S.C. jump tomorrow.

The board of directors of Brewster Aeronautical Corporation on Dec. 9, 1940, authorized the issuance and delivery of 50,000 shares of capital stock in the company upon private sale at $12 a share to F. William Zelcer, Alfred J. Miranda Jr. and I.J. Miranda, officers and directors of Brewster Export Corporation.

With an international song festival, "Let's Sing for China," attended by children from the city's schools, the Junior Division of the China Emergency Relief Committee launched its campaign for aid to the children of China yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Sales and buyer registrations at the two weeks' Winter furniture and home furnishings market here have shattered all previous records for the event. Attendance at the American Furniture Mart ran 12 per cent ahead and orders 18 per cent ahead of the 1940 market.
A reception to mark the opening of the Wood Dolson Company's new building at 241 West Seventy-second Street will be held by the realty firm today from 12 to 2 P.M.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- In an address during the Founder's Day program of the General Alumni Society of the University of Pennsylvania today, Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The London Times, asserted that all hope of world cooperation or of a negotiated peace was futile so long as "Nazi fanatics" continued to overrun and plunder free peoples.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Nineteen out of twenty-three eligibles have been named for the $5,000 added Palm Beach Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park tomorrow the second Saturday of this long meeting, which was plagued with mud again today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that members of the Boston, Chicago, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh Stock Exchanges would testify at its instance in connection with the public hearing here on Tuesday in regard to multiple trading, which has been forbidden by the rules of the New York Stock Exchange.

The commercial bribery law does not apply to labor unions and their representatives, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in reversing the conviction under the law of Milton Graf, a delegate of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association, Local 137.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- Yesterday's attack on Malta was the severest of the war there, it was asserted here today. The aircraft carrier Illustrious was again badly hit, as well as a cruiser and another ship, according to today's war bulletin, which adds that the arsenal and a power house were also damaged.

A total of $30,225 was realized last night at the auction sale of paintings of various schools from the fourteenth century to the present, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Indications that New York City may not go without its annual automobile show next Fall were apparent yesterday as automobile dealers read the Automobile Manufacturers Association's announcement that car makers on Thursday voted to abandon their annual national exhibit at Grand Central Palace to devote every effort to national defense output.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-nine municipalities and local housing authorities aggregate $42, 284,153, compared with $74,351,799 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date stands at $37,063,586.

The selective service administrations in New York State, New Jersey and Delaware have fallen short about 1,000 men in the second induction period quotas they were to furnish the Army, it was announced yesterday by Colonel L.B. Magruder, recruiting officer of the Second Corps Area, which covers these three States.

William and Anthony Esposito, the six-gun brothers indicted for the murder last Tuesday of a policeman and an office manager in a payroll hold-up at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, broadly indicated by their actions yesterday that their defense at trial may be insanity.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 17 -- Fort Dix's "honor companies" that are to march down Pennsylvania Avenue in the inaugural parade in Washington next Monday as temporary units of the Twelfth Infantry, "the President's Own," will receive a final rigorous inspection tomorrow morning.

Skippers who first learned their navigation indoors at the free instruction classes of the United States Power Squadrons and now have the distinction, unattainable as yet by other yachtsmen, of breaking out the unique vertical-striped blue-and-white burgee on the stern staff or starboard arm of their boats took over a good part of the National Motor Boat Show yesterday at Grand Central Palace.
TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Air Corps and commercial pilots were searching wilderness areas of the Pacific Coast today for an Army bomber with seven men missing for more than twenty-four hours.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- Frontier information from Slovenia continues to report flights of German aerial troop transports and light and heavy bombers from Southern Austria to Northern Italy. Italian sources from the frontier state that these planes are now stopping at Italian air bases, mainly at Campo Formio and Gorizia, only long enough for refueling, taking off again immediately for Southern Italy and Sicily.

With bad weather somewhat of a retarding factor, retail trade gains here this week will not be as sharp as those of the preceding week. Department store volume was estimated as running about 5 per cent ahead, against a 13 per cent rise last week.

Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia put himself and Robert Elliott Burns in the headlines yesterday by moving to extradite the author of "I Am a Fugitive From a Georgia Chain Gang" and then changing his mind about it in less than four hours.
Raymond Baumann, through Walter Samuels, Inc, brokers, 8-room suite in 1165 Park Ave; Tishman Realty Construction Co, agents.

The large life insurance companies, particularly those which have taken in recent years the bulk of new securities sold in private sales, continue to resist the pressure of lower coupon rates and diminishing yields. They apparently believe that rates money are scraping bottom and a reversal in the trend is inevitable.

TUSKEEGEE, Ala., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Disorders among striking Tuskeegee Institute students resulted today in one youth being slashed with a knife and the arrest of eleven before law enforcement officers succeeded in restoring quiet on the campus of the big Negro institution.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (UP) -- National Football League officials today approved drastic changes in their constitution designed eventually to bring all professional football into one organization ruled by a commissioner with powers similar to those of Kenesaw Mountain Landis in baseball.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 24 -- Persons recently arrived from Rome tell of encounters between police and civilians in that capital and indicate by their accounts that in other Italian cities, too, public order is being threatened by dissatisfied and disgruntled people.

Steady progress is being made in the revision of the Protestant Episcopal Church Hymnal, according to an announcement here yesterday by the Rev. Winfred Douglas, editorial chairman of the tunes committee of the joint commission on the revision of the hymnal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Britain, upon the survival of whose fleet the safety of the United States depends, faces the possibility of the greatest crisis in the island kingdom's history within the next sixty or ninety days, Secretaries Knox and Stimson testified today.
The State of New Jersey Building on the World's Fair Grounds was transferred to the City of New York yesterday at a ceremony on the porch of the building, attended by officials from both States.

Classify this remark by the head of the British public education system as grim humor. Citizens of Birmingham, indignant at the number of schoolhouses destroyed by Nazi bombs, suggested that German schools be bombed in reprisal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- All operations at the East Moline plant of the International Harvester Company halted today when members of the C.I.O. Farm Equipment Workers joined striking members of an independent union bargaining agency in forming picket lines.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- The United Automobile Workers (A.F. of L.) refused today to recognize a settlement ending strikes at five Eaton Manufacturing Company plants and promulgated conditions under which it said striking U.A.W.C.I.O. employes might regain their jobs at Saginaw.

F.C. Crawford, president of Thompson Products, Inc., announced yesterday that within thirty days it would begin construction of an $11,000,000 manufacturing unit to increase capacity for making aircraft valves and parts. The program will be financed by the Defense Plant Corporation, a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, he said.
VICHY, France, Jan. 17 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain received this correspondent today and for more than an hour talked for America of the condition of his country.

Supplies of locally dressed meats were moderate yesterday with the exception of veal and calf, which was light to moderate. Demand was fair to slow for traefer meats, with an easier undertone in spots. Trading in kosher meats was slow, with a weak undertone on lamb and beef. Kosher veal foresaddles were mostly steady to strong.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Roosevelt made clear today that he believed numerous suggestions publicly advanced for limiting powers given him in the lend-lease bill before Congress verged on the absurd. He said that he did not expect to transfer the American Navy to a foreign power.

The anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin 235 years ago was commemorated yesterday at exercises in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall conducted by representatives of the printing industry, who later hung wreaths on the Franklin statue in Printing House Square.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Two Yale football captains were among sixteen players on the 1940 varsity team who received "financial aid" from the university, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The triumph of totalitarianism would cost the United States dearly in restricted foreign markets, and possibly in domestic unemployment and lowered living standards, said Vice President-elect Wallace today in reporting for the last time in his former capacity as Secretary of Agriculture.

Escorted by the Countess Mercati as chairman of the event, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made a tour yesterday of the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, to view the masterpieces by El Greco, at the opening of the exhibit that will continue to Feb. 15.

Leontine Camprubi will hold her first solo Show of paintings (opening on Monday) at the Contemporary Arts Gallery, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street. The artist is the daughter of the founder and editor of La Prensa. Spanish language newspaper in New York.

According to the old English fox-hunters' song the Peterby fox was the smartest of his kind, but if you listen to Dick Pierpont of North Haven, up in Connecticut, he'll tell you the Peterby fox was a cinch compared to the Quanipaug fox he just nabbed.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- Yugoslavia's huge purchases from Germany of war materiel and heavy machinery and manufactured goods in 1940 reversed the clearing balance of the two countries, according to a survey today, for the first time in the history of the Third Reich.

The current week has been a record one for shipments abroad of war relief goods by the American Red Cross, according to a joint compilation made last night by William C. Gray, the organization's traffic representative, and Captain Granville Conway, district director of the United States Maritime Commission.

Katharine Cornell's pre-Broadway tour in the Shaw revival, "The Doctor's Dilemma," will get under way at the Cass Theatre, Detroit, on Feb. 17. Thereafter the production will be seen at the Hartman Theatre, Columbus, on Feb. 24; Cox Theatre, Cincinnati, on Feb. 27, and the Hanna Theatre, Cleveland, on March. 3.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 17 -- After Jehovah's Witnesses and associated organizations had been declared unlawful associations today, the police raided the sect's premises in all States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Maximum aluminum requirements for military and civilian purposes will reach their peak next December, but if the military program goes beyond that formulated last October, or if the number of heavier planes is greater than already scheduled, civilian use of aluminum will have to be restricted for a time.

A column of Army trucks and gun carriers fourteen miles long streamed through lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon with an undisclosed number of soldiers of the First Division, who completed their motorized journey from the Aberdeen Arsenal in Maryland at the Army base in Brooklyn, where they will remain until their departure early next week for Puerto Rico.

After as fine a match as has ever been played in all the years of the Clyde Martin Memorial tournament, annual squash tennis fixture at the Yale Club, Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club yesterday made his way into the semi-final round.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull expressed the hope today that diplomatic conversations that have been in progress with Mexico for months can be expanded to a point that all matters existing between the two countries will be settled by agreement.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 18 -- Wilhelmshaven, Nazi naval arsenal, was "heavily and successfully" attacked by Royal Air Force bombers Thursday night for the fourth time in a week in a raid which the Air Ministry said specifically was more than a mere follow-up of the previous night's assault when the Bauhafen was reported blasted and set afire.

MADRID, Jan. 17 -- Five out of the seven Madrid newspapers published today a communique announcing the gift of a shipload of wheat to Spain by the United States. There was no editorial comment but ABC printed the following at the end of the communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Secretary Hull informed C.H. Callaghan, manager of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, in a telegram today that export licenses covering products held essential to national defense were being issued at the rate of about 500 a day, but that in view of the defense requirements it had not been possible to postpone application of the licensing requirement.

A.L. Waldron, a director of the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association, was the sole witness yesterday at the resumption of hearings at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, into Federal Trade Commission charges that the national group and its State and city affiliates had conspired to fix prices and restrain competition.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

Fordham's swimming team met its second setback of the season and its first defeat in the home pool yesterday when the Rams were defeated, 49 -- 26, by Amherst. It was the third straight triumph for the visitors.

Joseph Warren Burden, 56 years old, who formerly conducted an investment management business at 30 Broad Street, where he was alleged to have defrauded numerous friends and customers of about $350,000, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to one count in a fourteen-count indictment, involving only $25,121.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The du Ponts of Delaware, the Rockefellers of New York and the Pews Pennsylvania contributed $276,725 to Republican Presidential campaign funds in the 1940 election, as compared with $1,060,000 reported by a Senate committee as their contribution to similar funds in the 1936 campaign.

Slowly rising temperatures and diminishing northeast winds yesterday put an end to the storm that snarled transportation, broke power lines and caused the death of six persons in the metropolitan area on Thursday.
A great fighter went over the pugilistic horizon last night in Madison Square Garden.

Pan American Airways has stripped each of its three transatlantic flying boats of twenty-five luxurious berths, of plush carpets, interior walls and even its glistening coat of aluminum paint so that with engineering changes the clippers can carry an additional load of 4,000 pounds, it became known last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Operations in wheat futures were restricted today and were mainly of a professional character, aside from moderate selling attributed to spreading operations with Kansas City. Prices held within narrow limits, with the May showing resistance to pressure, being bought by spreaders against sales of the July.

The extent to which business executives, labor leaders, educations authorities and others are aiding the advancement of distributive education was emphasized at the third annual conference of retailers and retail teachers yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Commenting editorially on what it calls Wendell L. Willkie's "complete endorsement of Mr. Roosevelt's war policy, his bill, and the absolute powers it would grant," The Chicago Tribune will say tomorrow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The House Naval Affairs Committee today approved a bill to increase the annual midshipman class at the Naval Academy by 595. This would increase the number named by each Congressman from four to five, increase the President's at-large appointments by ten and add fifty to the number appointed from the naval reserve.

Samuel Friedman has sold to the Daright Realty Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $245,900 held by the trustees of Bronx Certificated Mortgages the seventy-three family apartment house at 2187 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, in a transaction negotiated by G. Orlove.

In the Connecticut Farmington, beautiful with old trees and houses, the Congregational church with its tall steeple and open belfry is as choice a specimen of Georgian colonial as eye could wish. In that belfry a bell with singularly melodious voice has rung at 9 P.M. for years beyond memory.
SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Units of the French Asiatic squadron were reported today to have virtually wiped out a three-ship Thai [Siamese] flotilla.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Commenting on Prime Minister Churchill's Glasgow speech, Chairman Sol Bloom of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said today:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Union Electric Company of Missouri and Louis H. Egan, its president from 1920 to 1939, were indicted by a Federal Grand Jury today on a charge of conspiracy to violate the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Warners have opened negotiations with Tallulah Bankhead, the studio disclosed today, for the actress to come to the Coast to play the leading role in "Mr. Skeffington" by Elizabeth. The novel was purchased originally for Bette Davis and subsequently was scheduled for Irene Dunne.

Two Italian textbooks, one written by a local high school teacher, are to be barred from the New York City school system because they were found to be "excessively laudatory" of the Fascist point of view, Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the secondary division, disclosed yesterday.

The battle of the decibels -- the forthcoming and perhaps definitive phase of Mayor La Guardia's revived campaign against New York street noises -- will begin at 10 o'clock Monday morning, weather permitting, Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner Cornelius O'Leary, chief of the division of licenses, announced yesterday.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 17 -- Discovery of a secret German airfield in Haiti was reported here by Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Simms of Dayton, Ohio, who arrived after a three-week tour of the West Indies in a private plane.
W.E. Hutton Miller has been suspended from the New York Stock Exchange for non-payment of dues. Mr. Miller is connected with no Stock Exchange firm and is not in business with the general public.

ATHENS, Jan. 17 -- It was revealed here tonight that Italian prisoners had testified to the fact that two Italian transports, the Liguria, of 15,354 tons, and the Lombardia, of 20,006 tons, had been sunk as the result of submarine action.

ATLANTA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- John (Big Train) Moody, Morris Brown University fullback who led his school to a claim on the mythical Negro national football championship, was designated today as captain of an All-America honor squad.

Two classes of the smaller racing craft had their annual meeting here yesterday, the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association at the Hotel Belmont Plaza, and the Snipe Class International Racing Association at the Hotel Shelton. It was reported that there are 4,200 Snipes scattered in practically every country of the world, and 1,800 Comets in this country, Puerto Rico and British Columbia.

Close on the heels of the reaching of $22,000,000,000 by gold held in the Treasury, against $17,700,000,000 a year before, come statements of actual production of new gold during 1940. The United States produced more than in any previous calendar year, the increase in ounces over 1939 being 5 3/8 per cent.

Off-the-market sale of 127,000 shares of Socony-Vacuum Oil Company capital stock yesterday brought the total of sales of that type since Dec. 1 to 1,935,152 shares. By the close of business last night such sales of New York Stock Exchange issues had totaled 1,749,482 shares and of New York Curb Exchange issues 185,670 shares.

Harriet Beecher Stowe is alleged to have written "Uncle Tom's Cabin" in every place she lived from the cradle to the grave. While collecting data for "Saints, Sinners and Beechers" I visited these cities and towns and was told the circumstances under which she there wrote her story, and always appeared to swallow it, hook, line and sinker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- How Germany is using the British blockade of Europe to subordinate the Balkans to its economy is described in a review of the expansionist plans of the German chemical industry by the chemical division of the Commerce Department.

"Wendell Willkie has shown us by his recent decision the way we must follow, the manner in which we must rise above personal gain and see only the needs of our country," it was asserted yesterday by Mrs. Henry F. Breckenridge, chairman of the women's division of the former Associated Willkie Clubs of America, at the second day's meeting of the Republican Women of New York State at the Women's National Republican Club.

Captain John T. Prout Jr., who was cleared of all charges in the so-called Christian Front conspiracy trial in Brooklyn, and who was likewise cleared by a court-martial of Army charges growing out of the trial, has failed to pass his Army physical examinations, it was learned yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17 -- Sabotage of Rumanian oil shipments to Germany and Italy on Yugoslav State railway lines has been under way for nearly ninety days and three Yugoslav railway employes are under arrest as a consequence, according to information from Slovene sources this morning.
ROME, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:
In his column of Jan. 6 on swimming records, John Kieran distinctly showed that he is partial to some sports and hostile to others.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 17 -- The new ferryboat Gotham, which is to be used by the Brooklyn Richmond Ferry Company between Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, and St. George, S.I., was launched today at the Jakobson Shipyard, Inc., here.

Hearings before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce on revision of the Securities Acts are to be featured, it was learned yesterday, by a demand by the New York Stock Exchange for "equalization." This means that the Exchange will request Congress to iron out those features of the law which make over-the-counter securities and their issuers less subject to Federal supervision and to publicity requirements than Stock Exchange securities and their issuers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Roosevelt emphasized the "grave responsibilities" imposed by the Panama Canal in receiving today Dr. Carlos W. Brin, the new Ambassador of Panama, with whom he exchanged pledges of cooperation "in the great and important task of defense."

Verbal fireworks in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday between two opposing attorneys, one the son of Justice Jacob Panken, during the summing up of a negligence action before Jusitce Felix Benvenga and a Jury of men and women, resulted in a woman Juror's fainting; one counsel striking the other as they continued their argument in the corridor outside the courtroom and both being cited for criminal contempt.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- In Glasgow tonight a surprising scene was enacted. Prime Minister Winston Churchill made an unexpected appearance before a large audience and seated on the platform from which he spoke was Harry L. Hopkins, who is here as the personal representative of President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Four hundred new housing units to be constructed in the New York metropolitan area as a part of the defense program were provided by action taken here today.

The two four-story apartment houses known as 69 and 71 Monmouth Street, Newark, N.J., have been sold by the Foresters Building and Loan Association to Phyllisco, Inc., through Abe Lipstein, Inc., broker. The buildings contain a total of sixteen suites.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 4 was 3,996,770 shares, compared with 5,239,550 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Transactions by members for their own accounts in the week was 16.18 per cent of the total volume, compared with 12.12 per cent the week before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler said tonight he had learned from "several reliable sources" that Prime Minister Churchill has been "insisting on a declaration of war by this country" and that Harry Hopkins was sent to London as President Roosevelt's representative to determine "what immediate steps can be taken short of a war declaration."
Twenty years ago I played basketball at City College under Nat Holman. I have watched the game ever since with keen interest and anxiety.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted thirty-three persons today on charges of operating a giant liquor conspiracy and smuggling ring which is alleged to have defrauded the government of $2,500,000.

The first appearance of German bombers in the blue sky of the Mediterranean marks another turn in this whirling-dervish war. Viewed from the Italian, the British or the general European angle, the Stukas that have flown south to nest in Sicily are birds of ill omen.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 18 -- Winter weather hampered operations in the aerial warfare last night and this morning after a day in which raiders had appeared over East Anglia, the West Midlands, South Wales and Southeast England.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Two of the oldest newspapers in the country, The New Haven Journal-Courier and The Register, did not publish today because about 100 compositors struck for higher wages and vacations with pay.

Seventy years ago today King William of Prussia, proceeding in state into the Hall of Mirrors at Versailles, turned an unusually chilly eye on Prince Bismarck. The reason was that William, whose triumphant army was waiting to receive the surrender of Paris, had wished to be proclaimed Emperor of Germany, whereas Bismarck and his other advisers insisted on the subtly different title, German Emperor.

Five thousand persons working in the forty-five-story Transportation Building at 225 Broadway found themselves without vertical transportation yesterday when elevator operators and other service employes walked out on strike. The stoppage began during the lunch hour and was still in effect at quitting time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A declaration that a radio station could not be "an advocate," but must present "all sides of important public questions fairly, objectively and without bias," came today from the Federal Communications Commission.

The Corporation Counsel has attacked the accuracy of statements by the Real Estate Board of New York regarding the means available to a small property owner for review or correction of excessive assessed valuation. He makes a great point of the fact that such a property owner at slight expense can obtain a review of his case "within thirty days" of the making of the final assessment.

The conference of German naval and mercantile marine officers in the Far East called by Hitler's Ambassador in Tokyo may indicate an intention to organize and intensify sea-raiding activities in the Pacific. Hitherto the Nazi raiders in the Orient have acted as lone wolves. They will be more dangerous if their efforts are coordinated with set bases, well arranged supplies and communications.
Two art firms were among those leasing business quarters yesterday. A majority of the contracts, however, called for manufacturing space, largely in full-floor units.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 17 -- Brig. Gen. A.E. Anderson, acting commander of the Twenty-seventh Division, today advised 1,000 picked instructors that, by good example, they must instill the best traditions of the United States Army in the 7,000 New York trainees who will begin to join the division about Jan. 25.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17 (AP) -- State Tax Commissioner J.H. Thayer Martin asserted today that New York's liquor price war cost New Jersey well over half a million dollars in 1940, and pointed to sharply reduced tax collections in November and December as proof. December revenues from alcoholic beverage taxes dropped from $949,446 in 1939 to $642,647, after an approximate decrease of $250,000 in November's receipts as compared with the corresponding month a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered Joseph B. Ely, C. Brooks Stevens and Henry G. Wells, as trustees, to surrender for cancellation 2,500,000 shares of common stock and 1,000,000 shares of Class B stock of the International Hydro-Electric System which they hold in trust for the International Paper and Fewer Company and the International Paper Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- An agreement with Britain for the establishment of an American land plane base on the island of St. Lucia, British West Indies, twenty miles south of the French island of Martinique, was announced by Secretary Hull today.

Earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries for 1940 are estimated by William E. Levis, chairman, at $7,186,000, subject to final determination by auditors. The earnings, which are after all charges, but before excess profits taxes, equal approximately $2.70 a share on 2,661,204 common shares.

A resumption of corporate financing on a substantial scale, involving the appearance of four major loans in that classification, swelled the total of new bond offerings here this week to $110,375,000, the largest volume for any similar period since the week ended on Dec. 6 last year, when $248,113,000 in new bonds were placed on the market.

Trial of the government's anti-trust suit against the Western Union Telegraph Company began in Federal court here yesterday before Judge Robert R. Nevin. The action, which aims at an injunction to restrain alleged monopolistic practices by the company, was begun three years ago with the filing of a complaint.

Plans for the construction of new quarters for tubercular patients at Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island moved a step nearer completion last week when the city awarded contracts for a new pavilion at that institution.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- The old French expression "The more it changes the more it is the same" aptly fits the Balkans generally and Bulgaria particularly this week-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- In far more explicit terms than had been used before, Secretary Hull defined this week what may be called the new American foreign policy which has swiftly taken shape within the last month as a delayed consequence of the European events of last Summer and Autumn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 -- Two quick field goals and a pair of fouls in overtime enabled Columbia to defeat Yale tonight, 40 -- 38, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game. This was the Lions' first victory in two circuit starts.
Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, A.L. Cornwell won the high-overall scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the Now York Athletic Club yesterday.
