THE average book about immigrant contributions to American history recalls the story of the Irishman who was found indulging in melancholy reflections on an Oct. 12, and when questioned as to his sadness replied: "I was just thinking what a pity it is that a fine country like America was discovered by an Italian."

Trends in the legal basis of higher education in America are revealed in review of thirty-three decisions of the higher courts in 1939-40 affecting colleges and universities. The January number of the Educational Record, the quarterly journal published by the American Council on Education here carries a thirty-page article summarizing the cases in some details.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- The whole Norwegian situation is dominated by the fact that after having knocked out Norwegian armed resistance, the Germans left the work of despoiling Norway and bringing her, politically,, economically and spiritually, in harmony with Nazi ideals to Major Vidkun Quisling, who, as chief of the fifth column, paved the way for the German invasion of April 9.

ALEC HUDSON is the pen name for a naval officer, Lieutenant W.J. Holmes, whose previous realistic thriller of submarines at sea, "Battle Stations," like this a long short story, was received with acclaim last year by naval and lay reviewers alike.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Last Saturday an old lady, Mrs. Lilian Halle, put out an incendiary bomb. She did it on her ninety-ninth birthday.
The first performance of Miss Sonja Henie's 1941 Hollywood Ice Revue will be presented tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden before what undoubtedly will be a capacity crowd.

YES, Ludwig Bemelmans did encounter the headhunters of the Amazon in the jungle of wildest Ecuador -- an intelligent, healthy folk, with well-ordered fields and houses, high standards of cleanliness, and the friendliest hospitality.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Army broke into the winning column in basketball today, subduing Brown University by 30 to 19 after three defeats in a row by Harvard, Princeton and Georgetown. The cadets showed much improvement, with Reinbold and White both standing out.

Jaime Velez-Perez, former Consul General of Colombia, was killed instantly yesterday afternoon in a fall from the thirty-eighth floor of 40 Wall Street. His body landed on a fifth-floor set-back at the rear of the building.

All aid to Britain consistent with our own defense needs, but not to the point where our entry into the conflict becomes inevitable, was urged last night by Joseph P. Kennedy, retiring United States Ambassador to Great Britain, in a thirty-minute broadcast to the nation over a national network.

TIME and tide traditionally wait for no man, and there is a strong public impression to the effect that, what with modern-day methods, neither do motion pictures. There are, however, exceptions -- pictures which find themselves stymied to tardiness by what may or may not be acts of God.

Declaring that the battle against enemies of religion and democracy is "a common fight of all churches," Governor Lehman, speaking last night at the Cathedral Club of Brooklyn's forty-first annual dinner, warned that majority groups that persecute minorities "are tearing down the very democracy that protects them."

Mayor La Guardia told several hundred members of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday that if arbitration was going to be formalized and delayed by rules of procedure the purposes of arbitration would be defeated.

TWENTY-FOUR cars started and twenty-three finished the 1941 Gilmore Stock Car Economy Run on Jan. 9, according to results announced last week. Four-cylinder Willys Americar passenger vehicles finished first and second in miles-per-gallon ratings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The products exportable to Canada under the general licenses issued today by Secretary Hull are as follows:

Many plane flights were canceled, shipping was delayed and automobiles moved at reduced speeds yesterday as a thick fog reduced visibility in the Eastern States from Maine to Maryland. The fog was densest from Hartford, Conn., to Baltimore, Md.

The Great Red Border was the Red River lying between Texas and the Indian country. First to settle in the section north of the Brazos was Tom Hodnett, a little man with a big voice, luxuriant whiskers and abundant nerve. He was scrupulously and fanatically honest.

Wendell L. Willkie declared yesterday that if the Republican party, through blind opposition to the President's lend-lease bill for all-out aid to Britain and to defend democracy against the Axis powers, presented itself to the American people as the isolationist party, "it will never again gain control of the government."

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Defending its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title, Dartmouth took the circuit lead tonight with a 36 -- 33 victory over Cornell, hitherto undefeated in three league games. It was Dartmouth's third straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Under anything like ordinary circumstances the nature of public and Congressional reaction to President Roosevelt's lease-lend bill for aid to the non-Axis Allies would raise considerable question as to its final form and even cast a modicum of doubt as to its eventual passage.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 18 -- Dartmouth's varsity swimming team, winning all but one event, overpowered Columbia by 49 -- 26 today in Spaulding Pool. The Indians' victory was their third straight of the season and their second in Eastern Collegiate League competition.

Friday's late rally was extended yesterday but extended in hesitant fashion, for volume was only 249,180 shares and the weekly turnover was the smallest since September. The session was the dullest and narrowest trading session since Nov. 23.

The flags were going up last week on the lamp posts of Washington, visible evidence that preparations were about completed for the third inauguration tomorrow of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Before the White House, where the court of honor will be located and the inaugural parade reviewed, the flags of the Americas were to fly with the banner of the United States.

With inclement weather a retarding factor, gains in retail trade here last week were less marked than those of the preceding week. Department store volume was estimated at about 5 per cent higher than a year ago, against 13 per cent in the previous week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 -- Feats similar to those of Lawrence of Arabia are being duplicated in Ethiopia today by a daring British military mission, which since July has been eluding Italian patrols in the mountain fastnesses and jungles of Haile Selassie's erstwhile kingdom.

Boat Show memories went back to the days of '17 and '18 to find a precedent for the trend and attitude evident in this year's national exhibition which wound up an eight-day run at Grand Central Palace last night. If not war times, these are, to say the least, defense and preparedness days in America.

MONTREAL -- Decision of the Quebec Government to keep the highway to the Laurentian Mountains open throughout the Winter will enable motorists to drive their cars to the many skiing centers between Montreal and Mont Tremblant, a distance of approximately ninety miles.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 18 -- This was graduation day for more than 1,000 men who will have the task of training 7,000 selectees. They ended a two-week refresher course with a review in which fixed bayonets emphasized the smartness of their massed lines.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Harry L. Hopkins, President Roosevelt's personal envoy in Great Britain, broke his public silence last night to address a small group of Air Raid Precaution workers, it was learned tonight, but what he said was not specifically revealed.

The far-flung revisions of political boundaries in Europe in the first sixteen and a half months of the present war have resulted in the Soviet Union and Germany emerging with virtually complete control of the fuel resources of that Continent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- An early order of business for the Seventy-seventh Congress is the agricultural program for 1941. Consideration is to be given the loss of export markets for cotton, tobacco, wheat and deciduous fruits and also to the larger domestic demand being generated by increased industrial production and payrolls for national defense.

ATHENS, Jan. 18 -- The sinking by a Greek submarine of another Italian transport carrying reinforcements of men and materiel across the Adriatic Sea is announced tonight in a communique of the Ministry of Marine.

TORONTO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Dit Clapper's 200th National Hockey League goal gave Boston a 1-0 victory over the Maple Leafs tonight in a hard-fought game that attracted 14,745 spectators, the largest crowd of the season here.

EXETER, N.H., Jan. 18 -- As in most of the country's preparatory schools, the Phillips Exeter Academy continues its primary business of preparing students for college and for citizenship in a country more than ever convinced that the democratic way of life shall continue.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 18 -- Officials of Buick division of General Motors Corporation, on receiving word of War Department contract awards for building aircraft engines totaling $36,497,520, bringing total awards to the concern to date $61,810,670, stated that Buick would undertake construction of an aircraft engine plant for which awards have been approved totaling more than $24,000,000.

Writers of mystery stories long ago discarded the trick of turning a key from the outside by means of a metal bar and a piece of string. To make it plain that he has discarded this device Mr. Boucher introduces a solid key which cannot be manipulated in that manner, thus adding a new twist to the old locked-room problem.

In a general effort to tighten up the system of distribution through wholesalers and dealers, electrical appliance manufacturers this year will concentrate on two plans, full-line selling and distributor-dealer set-ups somewhat similar to voluntary chains, reports in the industry indicated last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- William S. Knudsen told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that he did not believe the Lease-Lend Bill would commit the United States to "policing the world," as suggested by Representative Rogers of Massachusetts.

CURRENT group shows of American painting include, among others not previously noticed here, the annual at the National Arts Club, composed of work by members. This remains through the month. It was reviewed, at greater length than will be possible now, when it opened (issue of Friday, Jan. 10).

A two-day vacation for twenty pigeons, during which they basked in the warmth of the shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, at Twenty-fourth Street and Avenue A, ended at noon yesterday, when they were released to their frigid haunts at Columbus Circle.

A well-merited recognition of outstanding talent came to Clarence (Ace) Parker yesterday when the Professional Football Writers' Association of America, through its president, Ken Smith of the New York Mirror, announced Ace had been voted the most valuable National Football League player of the 1940 season.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was feted yesterday by 200 Austrians and American citizens of Austrian descent during a Viennese musical jause, sponsored by the Committee for the Preservation of Austrian Art and Culture in the United States, which was held in the Continental Room of the Hotel St. Moritz.

With a few notable exceptions, all the crime problems with which Dr. Priestley has been concerned have been solved by remote control, with Superintendent Hanslet or Inspector Jimmy Waghorn or both doing the spade work. This case is no exception to the rule except in so far that Hanslet remains in the background, although he does sit in on some of those famous conferences in Dr. Priestley's study.

Kenneth Spencer, Negro bass, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. With Gordon Kushner at the piano Mr. Spencer presented a program containing arias by Bach and Handel; Italian selections by Secchi and Respighi; German Lieder by Brahms, Schubert and Wolf; French lyrics by Fourdrain and Debussy; Negro spirituals, and a group of songs in English featuring the first performance of Jacques Wolfe's "Cease Firing."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Women Democrats provided today's prelude in the national capital to the inauguration of 1941. Factional lines were obliterated as the groups which took over and made good on the slogan "Campaigns Are Won Between Elections" celebrated at various functions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18 -- Yale and the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York battled to a 3-3 overtime tie tonight in their annual meeting. The outcome left the St. Nicks undefeated in six starts this season. They have beaten four rivals, including Princeton and Harvard.

Against a colorful display of the red, white and blue flags of the United States, intermingled with the red and white banners of Poland, sixteen young women of Polish-American descent will be presented at the Polka Ball to be held on Friday night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Kosciuszko Foundation.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 18 -- At noon today soldiers from Fort Dix piled onto Trenton-bound buses or trudged along the muddy roads trying to thumb rides, thus dispelling a fog of rumor as thick as the actual fog hanging over the post.

The stresses of modern life are causing serious mental and physical harm because the average individual does not know how to take the best advantage of his leisure time, according to Carlton H. Reilly, director of the intramural athletic program at Brooklyn College, in his annual report made public yesterday.

I WAS saddened reading in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently the flippant condemnation accompanying the announcement of the removal of MacMonnies's fine sculpture, "Civic Virtue," from its site in City Hall Park.

Col. Lloyd B. Magruder, in charge of recruiting in the Second Corps Area, announced yesterday that Brig. Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, corps area commander, had requested directors of selective service in New York, New Jersey and Delaware to take steps to offset the shortages that existed Friday night at the close of the second induction period.
HELENA, Mont., Jan. 18 -- Senator Burton K. Wheeler presents Montana's most interesting political paradox.
Remarkable accuracy in caging free throws marked Brooklyn College's successful surge as the Kingsmen bagged a 38 to 31 basketball decision over Manhattan College in the latter's gymnasium last night.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 18 (AP) -- It's news when a man announces he didn't catch the largest fish, Colonel W.G. Schauffler Jr., big game fisherman of Lakewood, wants it understood he is not claiming a tuna record, although he caught a whopper of 664 pounds on 39-thread line off Bailey Island, Maine, last September.

ALFRED WALLENSTEIN tilted his chair back in his tiny, unmusical office at WOR, where for most of the year he reigns as music director, and confessed that he once had a "von" in front of his name. It was only poetic and musical justice that prompted him to remove the "von" several years ago.

Mrs. Marion Cardiff, 40 years old, wife of the superintendent of the apartment house at 1671 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, opened the door of her first floor apartment yesterday and found "a nice looking young couple" who said they were "about to be married" and wanted to secure a three-room apartment.

New and far-reaching methods of teaching science in the secondary schools of this country are being evolved through a nation-wide eight-year study in this field, made possible by a $160,000 General Education Board grant. How science is influencing society today and what place the subject should hold in the classroom are being explored at great length.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The War Department has decided, it was said today, that it was a question for Congress whether defense contracts should be denied to con cerns accused of violating the Wagner act.

Few flowers can compare with primroses for beauty in certain situations and associations. Their value for shaded areas has long been recognized. It is when dappled shade falls across their plantations that the soft and beautiful colorings of their blooms are loveliest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Jan. 11 amounted to 259,342,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, a decrease of 1,301,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,205,000 and 96,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

The chapters of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis last year increased from 649 to 1,048, it was reported yesterday by Keith Morgan, national chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday, who is leading the 1941 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign.

The annual benefit card party given by members of the Junior League of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Crippled and Delicate Children, Claverack, N.Y., will be held on Jan. 27 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Loring Christie, Canadian Minister to the United States, Mrs. Christie, and Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General at New York, and Mrs. Haggard have accepted invitations to attend the premiere showing of the motion picture "Virginia" on the night of Jan. 28 at the Paramount Theatre.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The sixth-place Montreal Canadiens, flashing a brilliant two-goal scoring attack in the initial period, outlasted Detroit's injury-riddled Red Wings for a 2-1 victory tonight in a National Hockey League fixture attended by 8,740 fans.

In the most notable victory to his credit, H. Robert Reeve Jr. of the Bayside Tennis Club defeated Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club yesterday in the Clyde Martin Memorial invitation squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Winter residents in the Park, their week-end guests and other visitors have found their outdoor sports limited thus far this season to ice-skating, due to the lack of snow. Skating parties and other special features are being held when weather permits at the rink situated in a cove on lower Wee Wah Lake.

Included in this volume are six short stories and one novelette, all dealing with episodes in the career of Dr. Colin Starr, physician and criminologist. It is his ability as a physician that enables him to diagnose murder where others see no indication of crime, and to place the guilt where it belongs in cases where the authorities are at fault.

The Sixth Annual North American Wildlife Conference will be held on Feb. 17, 18 and 19 at Memphis, Tenn., and will bring together the leading sportsmen, wildlife experts and conservationists. The annual meeting of the National Wildlife Federation will be held in conjunction with the conference.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Protection of American metropolitan centers from bombings and fire losses was discussed by directors of the National Fire Protection Association, holding their mid-Winter meeting at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall today.

EDINBURGH, Jan. 18 (on the kitchen front) -- This week I am in revolt. My revolutionary tendencies are mainly directed toward those "lords of distribution" who have the key to our national larder in their keeping.

THIS has been quite a season for plays and musical offerings abandoning their careers before even reaching New York, for giving up in Boston or Philadelphia, withdrawing for revision -- or just plain withdrawing. Since the season began -- speaking technically, since last June -- these are the discards pre-Broadway, the total losses being over $500,000:

THE "war" between ASCAP and BMI, if it has done nothing else, has zoomed the production of popular songs. According to the experts there are about 20,000,000 men and women in this country who try or have tried to write song hits. About 2,000 -- or one in every 10,000 -- succeed in making a more or less regular living out of it.

THE Orchestra of the New Friends of Music, under Fritz Stiedry, will be assisted by the Schola Cantorum in a performance of Bach's "St. John Passion," to be given Wednesday night, Feb. 26, in Carnegie Hall.

THIRD OFFENDERS: For years New York dog-lovers have complained about a part of the city sanitary code which condemns to death any dog thrice guilty of biting a human being. Last week the law was amended. Only those third offenders whose bites have been severe enough to force the wounded persons to seek medical aid will be sent to the pound.

An ice truck, out of control, mounted a sidewalk in the East New York section of Brooklyn at Glenmore Avenue and Cleveland Street yesterday afternoon, killing a 7-year-old boy and critically injuring two companions of the same age.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Havana, like Nassau in the Bahamas, is to be linked with Miami in yachting interests. An annual overseas race series, the first to be sailed on March 14, has been announced by Vivyan Hall of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club.

Despite disturbed international conditions and difficulties in obtaining satisfactory new investments, the net rate of interest earnings in 1940 was 3.69 per cent, against 3.71 per cent in 1939 and 1938, Elbert S. Brigham, president of the National Life Insurance Company, Montpelier, Vt., said in his report to policy holders.

A new method of publishing poetry, with the author recording his verse on phonographic disks as soon as possible after it has been written, has been developed at City College during the last six months, it was learned last week.

An expanded curriculum designed to satisfy the practical needs of the average citizen for vocational or cultural self-improvement will make up the Spring schedule of extension courses at Queens College, it was announced yesterday by Professor Harry Kurz, chairman of the college's extension committee.

The New York wholesale markets continued highly active last week, according to a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. A large number of buyers were in town and substantial orders were placed on the new Spring merchandise.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Harry Cooper of Chicago, one of the boys from the "two-step era," defeated another veteran, Jimmy Thomson of Chicopee, Mass., 2 up today in the feature match of the $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

SOME forty years ago Edward Elgar expressed the opinion that the musical center of England was not London but Manchester. He was not wrong. In those days London had no orchestra that could compare with the Halle Orchestra of Manchester, no conductor or the eminence of Hans Richter, then a Manchester resident, no quartet leader as distinguished as the principal of the Royal Manchester College of Music, Adolph Brodsky.

THROWING back his tan polo coat, Manager Joe Cronin of the rich Red Sox reached into his pocket and produced a cigar of a luxurious brand. With a flourish he offered it to this innocent bystander. Since Joe wasn't running for public office, it was felt that the cigar must have been tendered as a token of some Red Sox celebration.

TRUJILLO, Peru -- We arrived in Trujillo on the coast of Peru and rented an apartment -- an archaeologist and his wife from Connecticut. Our new abode consisted of four barren rooms, into which we induced our landlady to put two cots, two chairs and two tables.

Sir Louis Beale, associate director-general of the British Purchasing Commission in the United States, will be the principal speaker at the thirteenth annual midwinter dinner of the New York State Bankers Association, to be held tomorrow night at the Hotel Astor. Sir Louis will discuss "War and Trade."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- At the moment when bands blare out and soldiers begin the inaugural parade Monday, a man with white hair and thick eyebrows will board a train for Uvalde, Texas.

THE big news this week is that after more than three months of the dance season without a single performance in the Broadway district by a native American company, the spell is to be broken tomorrow evening by the appearance of Martha Graham and her company in a recital at the Mansfield Theatre.

Catholic welfare agencies must face realistically the new demands upon their services occasioned by economic and moral dislocations in communities with defense industries, the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, president, National Conference of Catholic Charities, told 350 social service workers yesterday in Keating Hall on the Fordham University campus, where they were assembled for a symposium on social work conducted by the Fordham School of Social Service.

An incident in 1840 started women to campaigning against what their leaders called "a barrier of law through which they could neither go nor come." An inventory in 1941 reveals what little is left of the old legal discriminations against women.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Jan. 18 -- As a corollary to the prevailing sentiment of the administration and faculty at Wellesley College against curricular changes this year, because of the war, there has been a strong feeling that extracurricular courses could be of considerable value to students.

Nora's mother and Cass's father gave polite but not cordial consent to the marriage of the young people. The Pembrokes had always been great swells and old Mr Pembroke still had his clothes, his manners and his friends.

Some ten years after the Civil War young Dan Shea, who had fought in the Union Army at the siege of Vicksburg, went out to New Mexico to make a fresh start. There he met huge Don Martin O'Connor, biggest sheep-rancher in the territory and father of a beautiful daughter.

TO counteract anti-American propaganda broadcast to South America by Germany, Representative Fred Bradley of Michigan has suggested that the United States erect a high-powered station in the Panama Canal Zone.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 18 -- New York University's quintet defeated North Carolina's Southern champions tonight, 53 -- 49, in one of the most exciting basketball games ever seen here. The score was tied six times, including 24 -- 24 at the half and 47 -- 47 with three minutes to go, and the lead changed hands ten times.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- In south-central Florida lies a wide expanse of open flat country along the shores of the Kissimmee River; this region is known as the Kissimmee Prairie. It is the center of the Florida cattle industry, and it is also known for its great variety of bird life, which includes certain species found there in greater numbers than anywhere else in the State.

NORTHFIELD, Mass. -- Youth-hosteling in America swings into its sixth Winter with fifty-four ski hostels numbered among the 243 throughout the nation. Now skis and ice skates come into their own, bicycles and saddles lying idle in storage.

BRITAIN under Hadrian's reign is the scene of Mrs. Snedeker's new book and she has invested it, through the eyes of a young Roman girl, with all the fresh sense of wonder of a new land. To the members of the Claudian family it represented only barren exile from the Rome which their people had known for three centuries, until Favonius had displeased the Emperor and was sent to the barbaric land as legatus.

AS the first speaker in a nine-week series of nonpartisan, nonpolitical broadcasts from the National Democratic Club, Senator Robert F. Wagner is scheduled to be heard Saturday at 2:30 P.M., over WOR and affiliated stations.

Six lawyers who will be paid from city funds were appointed yesterday to defend William and Anthony Esposito, the brothers who were indicted for the fatal shooting last Tuesday of a policeman and an executive of a linen concern at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street in a payroll holdup.

Some time after 6 A.M. Tuesday the ominous drone of "enemy" bombers will be heard in the skies over New York, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut as squadrons of fast, twin-engined planes, carrying crews of five to seven men each, attempt in a special air defense test to "invade" the New England-New York area.
The text of Joseph P. Kennedy's address last night over a National Broadcasting Company network follows:

AS a general rule this department keeps cautiously clear of the hustings, or the political arena, so-called. The quality of motion pictures, which is a film critic's main concern, should under normal circumstances, be as remote from that sector as the moon.
BERLIN, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Daylight dive-bombings of two airdromes on Malta, Britain's fortified Mediterranean island, were reported by informed German sources tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Wisconsin Public Service Corporation of Milwaukee filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issue of $26,500,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first-mortgage bonds, due in 1971, and 132,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

THERE was a time -- and the older ones among us remember it well -- when duets for pianists were the favorite "Hausmusik." Amateurs as well as professional players found pleasure in this noble art which enabled them not only to enlarge the field of their pianistic activity, but also to become better acquainted with orchestral literature.

WILD country in Siberia -- virgin forest and swamp and hill and lake -- forms the background here for incidents and characters from the memories of a Russian geographer. "Dersu the Trapper" is an interesting, and rather odd, book of adventure and observation which seems to come to us from a great many years ago.

DAYTON, Ohio -- To the long list of items carried across the continent in Douglas C-39 transport planes Patterson Field transport squadrons have added a variety of experimental equipment and -- parachute troops. The experimental equipment already has been thoroughly tested, if not actually developed, at Patterson's sister Army post, Wright Field.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- Almond Blossom Time in the San Jacinto Valley is the signal for the opening of one of the most attractive parts of the Great Southwest's tourist season. More than 1,000 acres of almond blossoms will be in bloom along the main highways of the valley for about three weeks early in February.
The text of Wendell L. Willkie's speech before the Women's National Republican Club luncheon at the Hotel Astor, as given out by Mr. Willkie from stenographic transcripts, follows:

NOT least among Blair Niles's numerous gifts as a writer is her astonishing versatility. Most writers who have scored, as she has, a brilliant success with one kind of material yield at some time or other to the temptation -- or perhaps to the demand of their publishers and public -- to repeat themselves.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- An American sailor ripped a huge swastika flag from its staff at the ninth-story offices of the German consulate today while thousands of spectators stood in the street and cheered.

Wendell L. Willkie's endorsement of President Roosevelt's pledge to give full aid to Britain was praised by Rabbi Max Felshin in a sermon at the Civic Center Synagogue, 10 Lafayette Street, yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Although Pennsylvania shook up its line-up, the Notre Dame quintet had no trouble winning at the Palestra tonight, 53 -- 37, before 5,500 spectators.

As the third album in its series, Night Life in New York, Musicraft presents Harlem Blues (three ten-inch records, $3.50). Joshua White plays the guitar and sings, and Wilson Myers plays the bass. They offer Careless Love, Prison Bound, Hard-Time Blues, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Motherless Children, the last on two sides.

Cotton prices drifted lower in the short session yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final quotations were off 2 to 4 points. Price movements were held within a 4-point range, the narrowest in more than a month. Trading activity was routine and largely featureless.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Activities at the Skytop Club this week-end are centering around the annual ice carnival, which includes skating exhibitions and contests by the Philadelphia Skating Club, the Figure Skating Club of Northern New Jersey and the Skate Sailing Association of America.

Further details of the program of the regional conference of the American Bankers Association, to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on March 5 to 7, were announced yesterday by Roy R. Marquardt, president of the association's savings division, who is vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance of New York University, will speak on "Bank Investments During the War."

WHEN a baby-boy was abandoned on his door-step the Mexican Antonio Perez, although he already had three sons, took the child in, named him Ricardo, and brought him up as his own. Ricardo had blue eyes and "hair like the red-gold of dancing flames."

Prophecies reaching us from the United States that "democracy is finished in England" have not unnaturally aroused considerable interest here. We are not altogether certain what these mean, for we do not know that the definition of democracy involved would coincide with the purposes for which we believe ourselves to be fighting.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 18 -- Fortified by what he interprets as a popular mandate to erase Georgia's $3,000,000 debt and stressing his campaign pledge that he would sanction no new taxes, Eugene Talmadge turned the Governorship into a practical dictatorship within few hours after his inauguration Tuesday for a third term.

THIS new travel book about Mexico follows the route of a painter's search for color -- and, surprisingly enough, it was a long road and an intricate quest. Addison Burbank had been painting among the Indians of Guatemala (his book, "Guatemala Profile," records his travels there), and when he sought the same pictorial brilliance among the Indians of Mexico he could not find it.

BEES and their mysterious ways seem never to fail of fascination for man -- even though the records of five millenniums ago are concerned with the price of honey rather than the puzzles of the hive. Apparently our appreciation of the marvels of bee life grows with our knowledge: the more we know the more we wonder.

CANEA, Crete, Jan. 12 (delayed; via Athens) -- The inhabitants of this mountainous island have seen during the course of its 5,000 years of civilized history, the invention of bath tubs, sewers, bull fights and radios; they have been visited or occupied by Egyptians, Phoenicians, Greeks, Turks, Venetians and Spaniards.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Roberto, the John Q. Citizen of Brazil, may have a pretty low income as Brazilian incomes go, but every chance he has he is putting away a milreis (about 5 cents) or two. Some of the milreis are for Roberto himself, some for his wife and his little boy; for soon, in fact, Feb. 23, 24 and 25, it will again be Carnival in his home city, Rio de Janeiro.

Once again financial and commercial interests are to carry their campaign to Albany for revision of the State tax on stock transfers, according to an announcement yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York. A similar drive last year led to passage by the Legislature of a bill repealing the "double-taxation" feature in sales of odd-lots, but the measure was vetoed by Governor Lehman for the second time.

We went into the last war in 1917 almost too late to win. When we finally got troops into the line more than a year later we would have been hopelessly handicapped if we had not gotten artillery and planes from the French and it is very doubtful that we could have gotten 2,000,000 men to Europe without the aid of the Allies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 18 -- The Belgrade offices of the British news and propaganda agency Britanova, which was closed two days ago after a police search and sealed by order of the Belgrade Prefect of Police, reopened today. However, the Britanova daily press release of news and information entitled Intercontinent Press was not mimeographed today and delivered to newspaper and legation subscribers in the capital.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 18 -- Penn State's basketball team came from behind in the closing minutes today to defeat Navy, 23 to 20, in a game marked by close guarding.

THE ten-day controversy over the possible suppression of "Citizen Kane," Orson Welles' first film venture, is developing into one of the most serious disputes in Hollywood's turbulent history. From evidence, factual and circumstantial, the town is threatened with embarrassing publicity unless the picture is withdrawn by RKO: if it is abandoned it appears that the repercussions will affect the lives and futures of several people.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Congressional reaction to the speech by Joseph P. Kennedy tonight followed previously indicated division of sentiment on the bill.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force Middle East Command today issued this communique:

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif. -- The present lag in the sales of house trailers seems mysterious at first glance, but there are reasons entirely tangible. Doubly mysterious is the lag when one considers the enthusiastic predictions of six or eight years ago.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 18 -- Grounds and equipment with an estimated value of more than $500,000 have been acquired during the last year by Washington and Jefferson College, President Ralph Cooper Hutchison announced today.

In the last twenty-two years the Board of Education has opened 494 new school buildings and additions in New York City at a cost of $378,356,267, providing seats for 641,000 children, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Federal order regulating the handling of milk in the metropolitan area of New York will be suspended on Feb. 28, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard announced today. The Federal-State Milk Control arrangements, designed to stabilize prices in the New York milkshed, have been a subject of controversy for several years.

There appeared in THE TIMES last Sunday a letter from Professor Erwin N. Griswold which discussed the need for reform in the tax system of the country. Professor Griswold argued that one of the major defects -- he listed it in first place -- is the continued issuance of tax-exempt securities.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The deficit in the State budget, estimated recently at about $8,000,000, is more likely to be about $14,000,000, according to reports today. Governor Lehman will put the final touches on the budget this coming week, prior to submitting it to the Legislature on Monday, Jan. 27.

This book is divided into two acts: "Death from the Past" and "Death from the Unseen." They are really separate stories about Don Diavolo, prestidigitateur and illusionist, who astonishes his audiences by causing a living elephant to vanish from before their eyes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont gave a dinner tonight at Sandrift Cottage, their guests including Mr. and Mrs. I Sheldon Tilney, Mr. and Mrs. Harper Sibley, Mme Ricardo de Soriano, Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. McClennan, Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. McCarthy and Dr. Joseph Jordan Eller.

IF you like a fantastic story told so circumstantially that you really believe it as it runs along, you will enjoy this latest from Mr. Yates. Readers who have followed the high-powered investigations of his Jonah Mansel will be glad to hear that the detective is on the job again.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 18 -- The French freighter Mendoza was seized this morning by the British auxiliary cruiser Asturias five miles off the Brazilian coast and headed out to sea with a British prize crew in charge.

Many beginners who would like to try the fascinating hobby of having a garden of wild flowers, or at least a nook devoted to these charming subjects, are discouraged by long lists of little known species with staggering botanical names and by imposing instructions about soil requirements.

Because the use of highways as transportation corridors is being emphasized in current defense discussions, supporters of restricted roadside advertising report more encouraging prospects for State regulation. This is the note being sounded in the opening of the legislative campaign of the New York State Roadside Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Secretary Hull announced today that he had agreed to issue passports for three officials of the American Legion, headed by Milo J. Warner, national commander, to go to Great Britain for a special survey.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 -- Bob Feller, a veteran at 22, is on his way to being the highest paid pitcher in baseball history with a 1941 salary approximating $30,000.

An exhibition of the work of the Pynson Printers will open next Wednesday at the galleries of the Architectural League at 115 East Fortieth Street, it was announced yesterday by The American Institute of Graphic Arts.

VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 18 -- There is not the slightest sign anywhere on this British island stronghold that the heavy attacks of German dive-bombers, appearing suddenly in the Mediterranean, are going to succeed in what the Italians failed to do -- make Malta give up.

FIRE The fires set raging night after night in London by German bombs are an instance -- one of many instances provided in Europe's present conflict -- of man's adaptation of ancient weapons. Primitive man, fighting the beasts of plain and jungle, quickly learned to use fire to sharpen and harden his carrying stick and very early to use flames against human enemies.

Jack Gorlin of the Salle Santelli, former intercollegiate champion from N.Y.U., led four other rivals in the metropolitan division qualifying round of the All-Eastern intermediate individual saber competition on the strips of the Salle Santelli yesterday.

An old method of doing business in Wall Street will go on the SEC griddle tomorrow when the nation's leading utility companies and investment banking houses will present to the Securities and Exchange Commission their answers and opinions on the highly controversial question of competitive bidding for utility securities.

THE Royal Italian Academy has for the first time opened its portals to a woman. The fact caused a certain surprise, as in Italy also the idea that academies are reserved to men is widespread. But, as it was explained in the press, the academy wanted to renew an old tradition largely adopted by ancient Italian academies of two centuries ago, in which female members were often elected.

HERBERT GRAF will be the stage director for the three operas that Bruno Walter will conduct at the Metropolitan. It will be a reunion for the two men, for they staged many operas together at the Salzburg Festival. The operas are "Don Giovanni," "Fidelio" and "The Bartered Bride," and they will bring Dr. Graf's record up to seven new productions for the season.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- The Middle Atlantic States speed skating championships, originally scheduled for New Year's Day but plagued by lack of ice until today, were finally settled tonight and when they were over Ted Ellenwood of the Fort Johnson, N.Y., A.A. was top man among the senior men and Miss Virginia Jahn of Cresskill, N.J., still reigned among the women.

With most of the offices in the forty-five-story Transportation Building at 225 Broadway closed for the week-end, the management was able to provide adequate elevator service yesterday despite continuation of the strike called at noon Friday by Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- As American industry gradually accelerates its giant effort for the national defense, the vigilance of government authorities to prevent sabotage in plants making airplanes, guns, powder and other war munitions likewise is keyed higher.

Refreshed after a week's rest, the New York Americans will strive for a new measure of vengeance in the National Hockey League game with the Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight. The New York skaters, who played their last game a week ago tonight, have been practicing regularly since then, and hope to acquit themselves well against the league-leading Leafs.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Charity Ball will open with a grand march in the ballroom of the Vinoy Park Hotel next Friday night. Visitors from neighboring resorts and Army, Navy and Coast Guard officers will be among the guests.

IN association with Paul Rosenberg, the Valentine Gallery presents a group of paintings by the distinguished French modernist, Georges Braque. These will be on view through the first week in February.

Bishop William T. Manning has appealed in a letter to the clergy in charge of the 280 congregations in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York for the immediate raising of funds to help carry on the missionary work of the Church of England in various parts of the world.

Customs and Coast Guard officials said last week they would make another attempt this year to obtain an appropriation in Congress for a new government barge office at South Ferry, a building that has long been outgrown by government agencies and is rapidly becoming more crowded as a result of renewed port activity.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- The high point of a full week's program of artistic, social and sports events in this deep South resort center will be the annual Camellia Show to be held next Saturday and Sunday by the Sand Hills Garden Club of Augusta.

FIVE years ago tomorrow King George V died peacefully at Sandringham and there succeeded to the greatest throne of the modern world his 41-year-old son, Edward Albert Christian George Andrew Patrick David, now first Duke of Windsor.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 19 -- Nazi fliers carried out scattered daylight raids yesterday on London, Northwest and Northeast England, the Midlands and East Anglia, where a train was machine-gunned and two passengers seriously wounded.

VICHY, France, Jan. 18 -- In the first attempt at concrete collaboration since the principle was decided between Adolf Hitler and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French and German representatives of the metal industries are meeting in Paris to discuss an agreement for dividing orders in the steel and allied industries and to apportion raw materials.

ROME, Jan. 18 -- A development of utmost importance to the Axis will take place tomorrow, when Premier Mussolini and Reichsfuehrer Hitler are scheduled to meet. Once again the course of events has brought about a situation that needs firm decisions from the highest quarters.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The chief difference between the powers Prime Minister Churchill holds and those President Roosevelt is seeking lies in the difference inherent in the British and American governmental systems. The powers Mr. Churchill wields are his to use only so long as he uses them in such a way as to please the Parliament and people of his country.

Defending the work of the legislative committee investigating subversive activities in the public school system, Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. charged yesterday that certain opponents of his committee were spreading "false and misleading propaganda" in an effort to destroy its usefulness.

SEVERAL interesting television demonstrations were held in New York during the past few days. An increased program of language, science, and administration courses has been planned for the adult education part of the Hunter College Evening and Extension Division during the Spring semester which begins on Feb. 10, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Broderick Cohen, director.

PARIS, Jan. 10 (via Berlin) -- Since Marshal Henri Philippe Petain named Lucien Lelong as absolute chief over groups of French couture, millinery, trimmings, made-to-order clothes for both men and women, laces, tulles, embroideries, etc., he has begun the reorganization of all of these branches from the roots up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A Diesel engine which is said to generate more than double the power of prior engines of similar type without any substantial increase in size or weight has been developed by the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of Chester, Pa.

Sharp gains in retail trade during the coming months, reflecting the expanding national defense program, will be counterbalanced by a wide variety of actual and potential problems demanding the utmost in retailing skill, according to the consensus at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here last week.

Consolidation of the Girl Scout Councils in the five boroughs under a single board of directors has been completed with Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. of Oyster Bay as president. The new executive head was formerly chairman of the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York.

New York's Governor Herbert H. Lehman divided his annual message this year into two unequal parts. The first part, 7,000 words, he read to the Legislature in joint session on Jan. 8. The second part, 10,000 words, was read last week by Senate and Assembly clerks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Master Sergeant A.C. Baty of Headquarters Company Provisional Brigade, highest ranking non-commissioned officer in the Army, will hold the President's flag in the official stand at the Capitol when President Roosevelt takes the oath of office on Monday.

THAT extraordinary movingly human graphic artist, Kaethe Kollwitz, is well represented again by etchings, lithographs and woodcuts at Kleeman's (till Jan. 25). ST. PAUL, Minn. -- Paul Bunyan, the legendary idol of the old-time lumberjacks who logged off the Great Lakes white pine region, will return in spirit to many Minnesota communities when they hold their annual Winter sports festivals this season.

The proposals put forward on Jan. 1 by the Federal Reserve System for guarding against a possible inflation in the period of heavy Government spending and industrial stimulation that lies ahead have not yet received the public discussion they deserve. A thirty-five-acre site stretching along six city blocks fronting the Hudson River, from Pier 22 at Jay Street to Pier 29 at Laight Street, has been chosen for the proposed union fruit and vegetable market terminal to replace the present Washington wholesale market district, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
MADRID, Jan. 18 -- Spain is negotiating with Great Britain for 50,000 tons of Argentine wheat to supplement the 15,000 tons of Canadian wheat provided under an agreement reached yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Not since the earliest, and for them unhappy days of the New Deal, have the Republicans in Congress been at such loose ends on the chief issues facing the nation as they are now. The divisions in Congress, where Republican prowess must, if ever, assert itself, have had a most definite effect, moreover, on the party's national organization.

Quick passage of the lend-lease bill and all possible aid to Britain as the best way to keep the United States out of war and assure a German defeat was urged last night by former United States Senator Ernest W. Gibson Jr., who was recently elected chairman of the Committee to Defend America by Aiding the Allies, in a radio address last night.

TEACHERS of the Culbertson bridge system will assemble in a convention here this week to learn of considerable changes being made this year in the Culbertson system of bidding, according to an announcement made last week by the Culbertson National Studios.

ROME, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Italian High Command said today that a "strong enemy attack supported by planes and tanks" had been "completely repulsed" by Italian troops on the Kenya front in East Africa. "Many losses" were inflicted on the British, the war bulletin stated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The complete subordination of Belgian economy to Germany's by methods that include the compulsory requisition of workers for labor in Germany, the dilution of Belgian currency by unbacked occupation marks, the amalgamation of Belgian and German firms, the rationing of foodstuffs and control of all production are described by the finance and regional information divisions of the Commerce Department in this week's Foreign Commerce Weekly.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Wheat prices held within narrow limits in early trading today, but late in the session pressure from local operators increased and disclosed only fair support in the new crop months. Closing trades were 1/8 to 1/2 cent lower, with the May showing the most strength.

Twenty-eight neutral ships, four of which are in the harbors of New York and Baltimore, are named in two recent blacklists issued by the British Ministry of Economic Warfare, a representative of the British Press Service, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, disclosed yesterday.

NOTWITHSTANDING wartime censorship and governmental edicts imposed against exportation of unused postal paper to foreign countries, dealers in Europe somehow manage to convey stocks of new issues to America for sale.

THE liveliest controversy in radio's twenty-year-old history, arising out of the question of whether network broadcasting practices constitute a monopoly, is flaring with renewed vigor as the Federal Communications Commission progresses with its investigation and legislators on Capitol Hill clamor for "a showdown on the entire radio situation."

Fruit growers in southern New Jersey in recent years have had much success in cultivating apricots and nectarines. ANTOINE DE SAINT EXUPERY, the French airline pilot and poet, author of "Wind, Sand and Stars" and "Night Flight," has that affability and eagerness of a man who has proved his luck and remained in perfect health.

PUNTA GORDA, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The favorites, headed by Miss Elizabeth Beth Hicks of Long Beach, Calif., came through in the first round of the Punta Gorda golf tournament today. Bad weather drove spectators to cover.

The Actors Equity Association is dissatisfied with the procedure adopted by Broadway managers in giving Sunday night performances, according to charges made by Paul Dullzell, Equity's executive secretary, in a report printed in the current issue of the Equity Magazine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Senator Glass said today that it was his personal view that the United States should declare war on Germany now, but he added that the question was one which should be determined primarily by policy experts in the State, War and Navy Departments.

A controversy between Verne Marshall, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, and the producers of The March of Time, arose yesterday when Mr. Marshall declared in a statement that his comment at a press conference on Dec. 31 had been incorporated into the sound track of the latest issue of the news film "without my personal knowledge or consent."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The British today captured and put a prize crew on board the 8,199-ton French freighter Mendoza, which for the last week had been trying to slip through the British South Atlantic patrols with a cargo of food for France.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 -- The British have added heavy aerial bombing to the artillery barrage that is pummeling the Italian defenses at Tobruk, Libya. Ten violent explosions and two large fires resulted when Royal Air Force fliers dropped missiles among military buildings early yesterday, a communique announced today.

Within the marble and granite walls of the New House Office Building, south of the Capitol in Washington, what promised to be a historic debate on American foreign policy last week got under way. The relation of the United States to Europe's war was the subject.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt will restrict his inaugural address Monday to about 1,000 words which will take him not more than twelve minutes to deliver, the White House stated today as the nation's capital prepared, under lowering skies but with a Weather Bureau prediction of crisp, clear weather, for the event.

The American Merchant Marine Institute and the National Maritime Union, representing 30,000 seamen employed on vessels owned and operated by institute members, have completed a week of negotiations on the question of wages, and have been unable to draw their widely separated demands and counter-offers much closer together than they were when the negotiations were begun early in the week.

Seventy-seven students from nine local colleges and universities have been named as research associates of the Department of Investigation, William B. Herlands, commissioner, announced yesterday. Japan's bombings of the Burma Road have been ineffectual in halting the movement of needed war materials into free China over that artery, exporters returning from that region said last week. At present the Chinese, utilizing a fleet of 1,500 trucks of five tons capacity or less, are moving 5,000 tons of imported supplies a month over the road and are confident of stepping the volume up to 20,000 tons in the very near future.

Plans to "freeze" all foreign assets in the United States, similar to the license system covering the American funds of invaded nations, have been completed, it became known here yesterday. The Treasury, with the cooperation of Federal Reserve officials here and in Washington, has carried the matter to the length of drafting an executive order which awaits the signature of President Roosevelt.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday, through its chairman, Frank C. Ferguson, its intention to complete the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel between Weehawken, N.J., and the west side of Manhattan. The job of finishing the tube will probably be started early in the Summer and should be completed late in 1942, Mr. Ferguson said.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- The second annual Bahamas Fair, which will be held in Nassau's Botanical Gardens from Feb. 10 to 15, will be the biggest exhibition of Bahamian handicrafts and products ever staged in the islands.

STEWS Stews have been warming the cockles even since the Middle Ages, when beef stew, with vegetables, was a dish to be served with pride and pomp and circumstance. A really good stew is a concoction to be proud of to this day, and one for which many a man would walk many a mile.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- In a survey to record their availability for national defense service, questionnaires have been sent to more than 100,000 nurses, both registered and practical, in the State, and returns are already coming in.

FROM J.P. Drossos in Athens comes information regarding stamps recently announced as having been issued by Greece to denote occupation of Albania. They are understood to have been placed in circulation late in 1940.

WITH a heavy backlog of orders from the armed services and Great Britain for airplanes, engines, propellers and accessories, American aircraft manufacturers have tremendously increased their working space and personnel during the last year and are now ready to start quantity production of military planes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Yale opened defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championship by overwhelming Pennsylvania in Hutchinson Pool today, 66 to 9. The Elis took every first place and all but one second.

WEATHER conditions in a large section of the East pulled down trade volume last week, but not before it was made clear that normal gains predicted for 1941 are likely to run higher than earlier forecasts. Sales figures are showing little of their usual post-holiday lull, and this is accepted as a sign that increases will be larger than expected.

Jim Herbert had the tenacity to hold fast to his lead in the home stretch last night and the New York U. alumnus beat Johnny Quigley of Manhattan for the 600-yard championship that featured the Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field meet at the Coliseum in the Bronx before a gathering of 5,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- The 5-year-old Beau James, slogging through deep mud, captured the first running of the Palm Beach Handicap by a head on the post at Hialeah Park today. Just up to nip Potranco in the last couple of strides, the son of Jamestown gave Warren Wright's Calumet Farm a double on the day.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP) -Dr. Walter M. Elsasser, a former German physicist, is working at the California Institute of Technology to enable the United States weather forecasting to excel that available to Adolf Hitler's air and ground forces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The physical condition of President Roosevelt, as he faces four more years in the White House, was described today as "the best in many years."

For the second time since the Twentieth Amendment was ratified on Feb. 6, 1933, the Presidential inauguration will occur on Jan. 20, tomorrow, instead of March 4, on which date all previous Presidential terms prior to 1932 began. The immediate purpose of the amendment -- to shorten the sometimes awkward interval between election and inauguration -- was achieved.

Eight-year-old Gloria Skelley sat on the bar of the Eagleton Bar and Restaurant, 248 West Fourteenth Street, yesterday and saw her father, Edward Skelley, a 41-year-old truck driver, shot and killed in a fight with a detective, Thomas Gorman of the West Twentieth Street station.
MAJOR WREN, whose fame rests on colorful tales of adventure and romance in the Foreign Legion with heroes

Although "Those Plummer Children" have, according to their creator, played their last prank between book covers, she has obligingly provided another lighthearted gang to take its own place in the affections of 9-to 12-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Fullest possible material assistance should be extended to Great Britain by the United States in the interest of her own self-defense, regardless of whether this country ever gets a dollar back in the transaction, William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

Henry Armstrong was nursing painful wounds in seclusion yesterday, while Fritzie Zivic, having battered the once cyclonic Armstrong out of pugilism, was looking for more worlds to conquer as holder of the world welterweight championship he won from Armstrong last October.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Running a well planned race, Frank Dixon, City P.S.A.L. indoor ruler, won the Hopkins-Tibbetts Memorial Mile Run, one of the standout attractions of the thirty-first annual Dickinson High School indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the Jersey City Armory tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- By decree of the German military authorities the population of the western part of Opland Province, including the town of Hamar, has been fined 100,000 kroner and an 8 P.M. curfew has been established. Gatherings on streets and in private homes have been forbidden.

YOUNG Michael Todd came back to his home town during the Christmas holidays and opened a theatre-cafe which has greatly enhanced his reputation as the "Old Hickory of the Entertainment World." Exceedingly low in its prices, plebeian in its color scheme and democratic in its conduct, his new venture is right out of Andy Jackson, although Mr. Todd indignantly denies ever having heard of the man.

BACKED by one of the most intensive and concentrated publicity campaigns in recent film history, the motion picture industry's first cooperative enterprise, "Land of Liberty," will go out this Friday to theatres around the country to spread the gospel of Americanism and to swell the funds of war emergency welfare organizations.

Six months ago the world waited in breathless horror for the Nazis' secret weapon. Now we know what it is. It is the belief in democratic countries, spread sometimes innocently, sometimes otherwise, that something beyond our control is happening to our civilization and that Nazism and Communism are expressions of the future.

Come what may, the Giants could put a ball club on the field tomorrow if exigencies demanded it. To be sure, it scarcely would be an array that would set the league on fire, but at least it would consist of the required nine men and a spare, for yesterday Secretary Eddie Brannick announced his tenth contract signer for the 1941 campaign.

The first performance of Verdi's "Otello" this season in the Metropolitan Opera House took place yesterday afternoon and the reception of the wonderful opera bore impressive testimony to the evolution of public taste in late years. For the time is but little past when "Otello" was a work for connoisseurs only.

IF ever a case required delicate handling, it is the one with which Reggie Fortune has to deal in this story. One can't very well demand of a Bishop or a dean that he explain where he was and what he was doing on the night of October 5th -- not unless one has definite reasons for the questions.
SENIOR MINISTER: Britain's Foreign Office last week announced that two Ministers as well as an Ambassador would hereafter have offices in the manor-like embassy on Washington's Massachusetts Avenue.
SO "it would take a pretty churlish theatregoer not to like the merriment and enthusiasm of these young people from Hollywood ...."
Reporters repeatedly use the word "crest" in designating a coat-of-arms of a private individual or prelate, so perhaps an explanation might be in order.
The Central Office is ready to conduct "business as usual" in 1941, but with an eye on the uncertainties of the future.

NEARLY 1,900 American-built military aircraft were turned over to Great Britain and Canada last year, as compared with about 300 in 1939, the Aviation News Committee of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America announced last week.

BEFORE long the wild fig trees and clambering vines will be cleared from the broken square tower of Old Panama, a landmark remembered by all tourists, and one that centers the site recently set aside by the Government of Panama for a national park.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- The arrival within the next day or so of the first turtle boat of the season is awaited by natives and visitors alike with much interest. The natives look forward to replenishing local stocks of turtle meat, and the tourists anticipate the arrival of the A.M. Adams, Captain Allie O. Ebanks in command, as the island's most unusual sight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Navy honored today distinguished men of the Navy and the Marine Corps in announcing the names selected by President Roosevelt for 115 new destroyers.

A forty-ton Diesel-powered tug, to be employed in dredging operations being carried out in the Canal Zone by the Navy Department, was shipped south last week on the deck of the Panama liner Panama, which sailed on Thursday for Cristobal via Haiti.

I HAVE been re-reading and thinking over the Book Review editorial of Jan. 5, on the novelist's dilemma in facing a world complexity which must be expressed in terms of individual character and relationship. Isn't the novelist's challenge given a new force by the world developments which have followed those apparently parallel lines to a point where they actually meet?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A new method of making steel by the open hearth process, which is said to produce a cleaner steel in a shorter heating time and with less consumption of added materials than heretofore, is the subject of a patent (No. 2,228,566) issued to Charles H. Herty Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa.

IN this imposing book Hoffman Nickerson, author of a remarkable study entitled "Can We Limit War," published six years ago, and of other scholarly works, deals with a subject which should attract the widest attention because of its military as well as social importance.

"THIS is our last chance. Will we take it?" With these grim words Mr. Carr concludes on page 311. By that time the thoughtful reader has had so many "we musts" thrown at him that he hangs limply on the ropes.

With three experts sent to London by the State Department to wind up the President's bases-for-destroyers deal, the Atlantic Chipper was scheduled yesterday by Pan American Airways to take off at 10 A.M. today from La Guardia Field after a pre-departure trial flight.

Classes in and lectures on flower arrangement, in preparation for the coming Spring shows, are still the order of the day and evening. Last week's annual course, sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York, at the Waldorf-Astoria drew a record-breaking attendance.

WEST POINT, N.Y. -- Long after taps have sounded over the parade ground, lights can be seen burning from the windows of the officers quarters at the United States Military Academy. In most instances it merely means that wives of the officers are adding another two or three inches to their war relief knitting.

THE greatest Winter sports season that the East has ever known is in full swing and for the next two months many thousands will find it hard to concentrate on anything not connected with carnivals, ski meets, weather snow queens, sled dogs, ice sculpture, barn dances, colored street lights and King Winter parades.

In his message to Congress on the state of the Union the President declared it to be the solemn purpose and pledge of the United States to give to democracies aid "to regain and maintain a free world." He refused to be intimidated by the threats of dictators that they will regard such aid as a breach of international law.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told the national officers of the C.I.O. at a closed meeting in Washington ten days ago that he believed the organization should take an unequivocal stand in support of material aid to Great Britain, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, D.C. -- Deep within the well-guarded halls of the Navy Department Building, in a small room filled with copies of known and little-known books, sits the woman who directs -- without fanfare -- 500 libraries in various parts of the world.

IN their new midtown office at 16 Rockefeller Plaza, Eastern Air Lines has installed a new reservation system which enables salesmen to handle 2,000 phone calls every day. The new set-up, now designed for twenty-four positions, one for each salesman, can be enlarged to fifty-seven positions.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- There were growing indications today that the government, which has maintained a double standard for the treatment of Leftists and Rightists, is about to crack down on the Communists and their sympathizers who are engaging in subversive propaganda.

In a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there was printed a letter from Stefan T. Possony which said in effect that it was impractical for Germany to feed her armies and her people with vitamin capsules or concentrates, thereby assuring complete nutrition to the German people.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Direct bomb hits were scored yesterday afternoon by Royal Air Force planes of the Coastal Command on four German ships off the Netherland shore, the British Air Ministry reported today.

Overcoming a faulty, lackadaisical start, for which both teams were equally to blame, St. John's and Fordham staged an intracity basketball thriller that resulted in a 51-46 victory for the Brooklyn Redmen before 2,500 persons in the Maroon gymnasium last night.
The American Export liner Excalibur sailed yesterday from Jersey City with seventy-eight passengers and 2,000 sacks of mail for Lisbon via Bermuda, to which twenty-two of the passengers were booked.

SHORTLY after the start of the new year this department conducted a survey among leading camera shops in New York City on the question: "What aspect of photography, as reflected by your business, showed the greatest increase during 1940?"

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Princeton University will offer a curriculum in economics, history and politics under the auspices of the School of Public and International Affairs next Summer, according to an announcement today by President Harold W. Dodd. The courses will be open not only to Princetonians, but to other men who have had the equivalent of two years of college work.

The Society of Women Geographers, composed of women who have done outstanding work in geographical lines, will open its first art exhibition here tomorrow at the Argent Galleries, 42 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Again this Winter, as in the fateful Winter of 1939-40, the European conflict has become a war of attrition with the two principal contestants trying to gather strength for the blows that are to come. Again this Winter there lies over Europe the dark shadow of impending events.

SEVERAL, letters received within a few hours of each other from American musicians of prominence show the concern the writers feel at one of the gravest problems of adjustment which has confronted the American musical community. It is the problem of the refugee musician from overseas and the place that he takes among his colleagues in the land of his adoption.

JOHN A. THOMASON is a practicing soldier who can both write and draw, as nobody needs to be told who has read his work in the magazines or who knows his books, including the famous biography of Jeb Stuart, which quite easily takes rank among the best of all the lives of Confederate officers.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- A score of delegates claiming to represent 7,500 employee of Westinghouse Electric Company in the New York metropolitan area and 3,500 employes of the General Electric Company in the same area, conferred here today on a proposed demand for wage increases of 10 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A proposed order published today by the National Labor Relations Board concerning charges against the Ford Motor Company would direct that company to reinstate immediately 975 former employes who were replaced after a shut-down of its Kansas City plant in 1937 and to offer re-employment to forty-six others who went on strike there several months ago.

In its first public ceremonial, the 43-year-old National Institute of Arts and Letters presented a specially created "Order of Merit" to Park Commissioner Robert Moses before an audience of 3,000 in Carnegie Hall last night. The order was "in recognition of his contribution to the beauty of New York."
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 18 -- A moderate recovery developed on today's Bourse, with the slight demand gradually developing. Dutch issues closed to 6 points higher.

A two-week examination period, during which 30,164 men and women students at New York University will take about 100,000 first-semester final tests, began yesterday in ten of the university's fourteen undergraduate and graduate divisions.

Joseph Richetsky, 42 years old, of 31-79 Thirty-fifth Street, Astoria, Queens, who, the police say, has had three previous convictions, was found guilty yesterday by a jury before Judge Charles Colden in the Queens County Court on three charges of burglary in the third degree, one charge of grand larceny in the second degree and two complaints of petit larceny.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- A change of plans in order to aid Britain has been made by the Garden Club of Palm Beach, which has decided to replace this year its annual three-day Flower Show with five conducted tours through the island's large estates.

A Nazi-controlled and coerced "plebiscite" will be used by Germany to "legalize" the absorption of Luxembourg into the Reich, according to information received yesterday by Matthew Woll, third vice president of the American Federation of Labor, a native of Luxembourg. Mr. Woll said his information had been conveyed by exiled officials of the former Grand Duchy and that it was of "unimpeachable" authenticity.

In the Mediterranean's gray dawn a star shell burst. It was 7:12 A.M. on Jan. 10, and a British destroyer accompanying a convoy had sighted two Italian destroyers. Battle was joined. At 8:13 one Italian destroyer went down in a smother of foam; the other escaped.

GUSTAV MAHLER had an unusual musical mind; he was a man of immense gifts. His influence on contemporaries and successors, especially among performers, is proof that the man and his work left a deep impress on many men and women. And the fact is that Mahler's scores still have passionate supporters, who will travel, argue and write letters to further the master's name and music.

ALTHOUGH popular opinion relegates scene designers to an auxiliary role in the theatre, they have actually been among its best critics and innovators. Adolphe Appia and Gordon Craig were quite as important to the collectively created experience which we call theatre as Ibsen and Shaw; in any sound appraisal of the American stage Robert Edmond Jones, Lee Simonson and Norman Bel Geddes would share honors with O'Neill and Maxwell Anderson.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Hunter Lott of Philadelphia advanced to the semi-final round in defense of his Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship today by defeating John McSorley of Pittsburgh, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 11, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 7, in the quarter-finals after drawing, a first-round bye.

A SERIES of four exhibitions of surrealist paintings accompanied by lectures will be held at the New School for Social Research, the first of the shows is to open on Wednesday evening with a lecture by Gordon M. On-slow-Ford.

TRAVEL LINES: The Beefeaters' Special leaves New York on Jan. 26 for Florida, where a series of dinners is being given to raise funds for airplane ambulances for the Royal Air Force. The Beefeaters of America is an auxiliary of the British American Ambulance Corps.

WITH eyes focused on the war map of Africa, few persons perhaps give a conscious thought to David Livingstone; yet there is a certain pertinence in the memory of those great journeys through one-third of the then almost unknown continent, which began a hundred years ago.

THE eighteenth-century case of Elizabeth Canning, reaching from London to Wethersfield, Conn., is one of those unsolved mysteries of justice which never lose their interest. In this little book a member of the New York bar has gone into the records of two Old Bailey trials, and has so sent his thought back to the puzzle of Elizabeth Canning's disappearance as to suggest a new solution of the mystery.

During the four months ending Dec. 31, contributions of Americans to Bundles for Britain to aid victims of total war in England topped $1,000,000, Mrs. Wales Latham, president of the organization, announced yesterday. Total administrative expenses were 10 per cent. Mrs. Latham's figures were based on the required report made to the Department of State.

Enmeshed for more than an hour in six high tension cables atop a ninety-foot electric tower, Daniel Callaghan, 15 years old, of 32-50 203 Street, Bayside, L.I., had a miraculous escape from death yesterday morning as a climax to a schoolboy's search for adventure.

THE first man ever to be three times President of the United States will ride down Washington's Pennsylvania Avenue tomorrow for his third inauguration on the steps of the Capitol. In a solemn hour of crisis comparable only to the crises attending the first inauguration of Abraham Lincoln and the second of Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Delano Roosevelt will take the oath of office.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Earle Lookabaugh, silver-haired billiard instructor, preserved his perfect rating in the $20,000 three-cushion tournament today by defeating Paul Lewin, 50 to 49, in a red-hot eighty-inning match. Both players are from Chicago.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Sir Arthur Salter, Parliamentary Secretary of the Ministry of Shipping, said tonight that it would require a United States shipbuilding program as big as that of the World War to relieve Britain of the threat of starvation because of the losses due to German submarines.
