Recently we Americans have been giving new thought to the word democracy. It seems to me that a restatement of the true meaning of that word would be timely. Democracy means that you, as a single citizen, have a voice in the way you are to live. It means that no one can govern you, tell you what to do, without your consent.

Cash contributions, surgical and medical supplies -- the latter including 100,000 vitamin capsules shipped to Great Britain a few days ago -- were accumulated to the value of nearly $10,000 last week by the Medical and Surgical Supply Committee of America, 420 Lexington Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Ronald B. Balcolm, executive chairman.
THE hurrying footsteps of a nation on the march echo through the long corridors of the War Department these days -- a War Department that is the focus of an unprecedented national effort.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 18 -- Some 125 skiers were busy tonight testing wax compounds for the Eastern Slope Ski Club's invitation men's and women's slalom races on near-by Cranmore Mountain tomorrow. A record field of thirty teams, representing twenty organizations, will participate in this outstanding event.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Outdoing more favored candidates, Mrs. Vera S. Bragg's entry cleaned up in the $10,000 Santa Susana Stakes at Santa Anita Park today, Cute Trick winning and Transient taking show money.

MAYOR LA GUARDIA says New York is now the fashion center of the world, and, taking him at his word, the industry asks two great fashion shows a year under municipal auspices. The Germans say that Berlin is to be the fashion center of the New Europe, and to reinforce that statement they are said to be transferring silk looms from Lyons to Germany and inviting the great dressmakers to move their workshops there.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 18 -- The regional conference of the River Plate will meet here next Saturday with delegations representing Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, the territories of which constitute the River Plate basin.

TREATING SHOCK. -- Everybody knows by this time that the hormone (corticin) obtained from the cortex or "bark" of the adrenals, two little glands that lie above the kidneys, is helpful in treating Addison's disease, which reveals itself by bronze color of the skin and which once invariably ended in death.

What the "new order" planned by a Hitlerized Germany for the world at large has meant in human hardship we know. The new ghettos in Poland, the concentration camps in Austria, Bohemia and even in Germany itself, the scant rations and forced labor tell that story.

IN a fortnight of intensive observation last Fall, the editor of PM studied England under aerial bombardment and the strange conditions of this total war. The series of articles which he wrote for his paper have now been rearranged and somewhat expanded to be given the permanence of book publication.

Not since your editors made their attack on Burgundy wines some fourteen months ago have I read in your columns anything to approach the gastronomic cruelty reported from California by Robert Foote in your Jan. 5 issue.

A NEW and cheerful prospect has unexpectedly opened before British authors in the midst of these dark days. In its current issue the literary monthly Horizon invites any reader who has particularly enjoyed some contribution to send to its author such a sum, between 2s 6d and 100, as he can afford and deems fitting.

JOSEPH SZIGETI will be heard as soloist in the Brahms violin concerto on a program devoted to works by that composer to be given by the Cleveland Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, this Thursday and Saturday nights in Cleveland.

THE "all clear" signal on travel to Mexico was sent by the American Automobile Association recently to its 725 affiliated motor clubs and branches throughout the country with the recommendation that these clubs resume active encouragement of Mexican touring.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt and Wendell L. Willkie are expected to meet tomorrow for the first time since they became rivals in last year's Presidential campaign.
Theodore I. Merseles of the Siwanoy Country Club at Bronxville yesterday was elected president of the New York State Golf Association, succeeding William B. Stark of the Bellevue Club in Syracuse.

SCARSDALE, Jan. 18 -- Overflowing baskets of scrap metals and old rubber were piling up in the Greenville Pumping Station this week as the women of that community, adjoining Scarsdale, held their first collection in the interests of conservation and war relief.

WHEN Elmer Rice produced "Flight to the West" about three weeks ago, some theatergoers complained that he had said nothing new. On the whole, the charge is a fair one. Whether or not it results in a dull play, however, depends upon a theatergoer's emotional responses to the devastating facts Mr. Rice has woven into his drama and to the human truths he discusses there.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 18 -- President Roosevelt's recent steps and proposals for helping Great Britain by making the United States "the arsenal of democracy" have been enthusiastically received throughout South America. Public opinion as expressed by leading newspapers and prominent speakers, official or otherwise, appears unanimous in the belief that if world democracy is to be saved it can be done only under the leadership of the United States and Mr. Roosevelt.

A luncheon program on "Women in Defense" has been planned as the final event of the annual mid-Winter conference of the Westchester County Federation of Women, to be held at the Contemporary Club of White Plains on Friday. Mrs. Horace Ritchie of Athens, Ga., recording secretary of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, will address the delegates on women's responsibility toward an understanding of the industrial problem.

IN all but the worst flying weather, the air over Ottawa resounds by day and night with the drone of practicing warplanes. The coming of Winter has made little difference in their volume. It is reminiscent of Berlin in the months before the war.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Surprise dive-bombings of two airports in Southeast England today caught British defenders off guard and destroyed Royal Air Force planes poised for a take-off from both fields, informed German sources reported tonight.

HAVANA -- Tourists here enjoy Cuban music partly because it generally comes from odd instruments, instruments that are hardly ever seen in an American orchestra. Cuban peasants have no money to buy American instruments, so they make their own from native woods and fruits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. l8 -- Here is the program for events connected with President Roosevelt's third inauguration (time is Eastern Standard):

Once again there are reports of friction between Chinese Communists and the Chinese Government. There have been such reports before, sometimes genuine and sometimes disseminated by the Japanese for effect on European and American opinion, especially when Great Britain and the United States are considering further assistance to China.
Jack is 5 years old, Betty is 3; they are playing with toys and Jack wants Betty's doll. Betty doesn't want him to have it. She cries.

In an address before the Canadian Society of New York at a dinner in the Hotel Biltmore last night, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox promised that the United States, "united in its hatred of aggressors," will help "more and more" to save Britain, Canada and the democratic way of life from destruction by the Nazis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Deft feminine touches can be applied to soothe the national defense headache in speeding production without relaxing labor standards.

When a cold snap comes, natural gas companies must prepare for sudden demands from factories and households. In the gas fields men turn valves and let more gas flow into the service lines. After the cold snap has passed the same men reverse the operation.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Housewives of London had a wider selection of meats for their week-end shopping today than they had last week, but many of them faced the difficulty of obtaining the quantity of food desired. It was rumored that there will be a further slight reduction in the amount available next week.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 18 -- There has been a fresh development in connection with the arrest of a number of persons engaged in placing counterfeit British banknotes in part of a German and Italian move against British currency.

Two new and spectacular features have been added to the program of the sixty-fifth annual all-breed dog show to be given by the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden Tuesday and Wednesday, Feb. 11 and 12. The first will be an obedience drill by a team of sixteen dogs from the New England Training Club, while the second will be a competition among Dalmatians, mascots at various fire stations in New York City.

An "automobile housing project" to build and operate publicly owned garages charging 25 cents a day in congested parts of Manhattan was proposed yesterday by John Howes Burton, 267 Fifth Avenue, as a means to overcome the city's worst parking problem.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 18 -- Although there is little fresh news here concerning Germany's intentions in Rumania and Bulgaria, interesting information has been received from several sources concerning Italian and German morale and the Nazi attitude toward the Soviet Union and the Communists.

The N.Y.U. fencing team, the most consistent winner of any Violet athletic group in the past decade, will waste no time opening its season following the end of the two-week examination period which begins tomorrow for 30,000 students at the university.

A SERIES of eight concerts devoted to the chamber music of Brahms is announced by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress, the first of which is slated for Thursday night in the Coolidge Auditorium of the library and the second for Saturday afternoon in the same surroundings. Participants include the Pro Arte String Quartet, Gunner Johansen, piano; Harold Klatz, viola; Lysbeth Le Fevre, 'cello; Gustave Langenus, clarinet, and Wendell Hoss, horn.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This resort is preparing special programs for visitors expected over the three Presidential birthdays.

Taxes which enter into the cost of production or sale of articles contracted for, levied after the contract was made, may spell the difference between profit and loss to the manufacturer. This element of cost is of no less importance in connection with government contracts than with private contracts.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 (UP) -- The Fifth United States Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed today the mail fraud conviction of Abraham Shushan, one-time lieutenant of Huey P. Long, and four others in the $476,000 Orleans Parish levee board refunding case.

A representative gathering of members of society will assemble in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow afternoon for the sixteenth annual gala concert under the auspices of the Bagby Music Lovers' Foundation. The net proceeds as in the past will be applied to the foundation's fund for granting honorary pensions to aged musicians of distinction and talent and for assisting dependent members of their families.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (UP) -- Compulsory mobilization of civilian males between the ages of 16 and 60, first of its kind in Great Britain's history, was announced today by Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison in a communique that said women would not be called up for the time being.

In a dispatch from Belgrade to THE TIMES a few days ago there appeared this comment: "The Berlin correspondent of the semi-official Vreme wrote today that high German circles were declaring that Germany has been 'leading journalists on' with rumors of impending trouble in the Balkans, so that now they had lost their orientation and had no idea where the expected 'decisive' blow from Germany was going to fall."

Meeting at the New York Athletic Club last night, the executive committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen awarded the 1941 national rowing championships to Minneapolis, the farthest point west to which the regatta ever has gone.

The "Fighting First" Division, one of the crack infantry outfits of the Regular Army, will have its full authorized strength of approximately 15,000 officers and men and almost all its equipment when the last of its units goes into field training at Fort Devens, Mass., on Feb. 5, it was disclosed here yesterday.
MANAGUA -- The Nicaraguan Government has made available a copy of President Somoza's decree which authorized the printing of stamps commemorating Great Britain's "Penny Black" of 1840.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 86.1 from 85.8. Farm products declined 1.6 per cent, decreases in eggs, apples, grains, poultry and cotton more than offsetting increases in the prices of livestock, milk and oranges.

The third induction period for the Army begins this morning, with 5,085 men scheduled to be supplied from the Second Corps Area, consisting of New York, New Jersey and Delaware. The quotas for each of New York City's 280 Local Selective Service Boards is expected to be announced soon by City Selective Service Headquarters at 331 Madison Avenue.

According to THE TIMES, a "ghostwriter" who for $55 had agreed to writs a master's thesis for a special investigator of the State Department of Education said nothing about the ethical aspects of his "profession" but merely claimed that he had been advised that his actions were "legal."

A conference of representative leaders of all religious faiths "to consider what is to follow this war" was proposed by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, in his sermon at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, yesterday morning.

Seventeen young English evacuees, nosy safe in the United States and Canada, spoke in voices unmistakably British, though traces of American slang already showed in some vocabularies, to their parents in embattled England yesterday in another two-way transatlantic broadcast such as took place last Christmas day.

VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 19 -- Fifteen Axis planes were shot down today in a spectacular mass air attack on this besieged British fortress in the Mediterranean. Considerable damage was done to civilian property. Malta's 400-year-old church was bombed for the second time in forty-eight hours.

The gangsters who used to inhabit Brooklyn apparently are finding other places to live and work. The 54-page annual report of District Attorney William O'Dwyer covering his first year in office shows that for the first time since the early Prohibition era there has been a full year without a "racket" killing in Brooklyn.

The members of the three-man commission appointed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull on Jan. 12 to complete final arrangements for the lease by the United States from Britain of eight air and naval bases in the Western Hemisphere were among eleven passengers for Europe, who departed yesterday morning from La Guardia Field on the Pan American flying boat, Yankee Clipper.

The Investment Bankers Association of America will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a sixty-two-page brief in protest to the proposal of the commission's public utilities division to compel compulsory competitive bidding in the sale of new securities of certain public utility holding companies and their subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Social Washington was engulfed today under a wave of teas. More pounds of the stuff than were dumped in Boston Harbor, it seemed, went into the brew that liquidated official obligations of hospitality at scores of functions, executive and individual, marking the imminence of the inaugural and the presence of galaxies of celebrities.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- A nation-wide survey to determine whether consumers prefer grade labeling for canned goods, as advocated by the mraketing division of the United States Department of Agriculture, or "informative labeling," which canners favor, was authorized today by directors of the National Canners' Association, meeting at the Hotel Stevens.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- One thousand persons looked on in the spacious riding hall today as the annual West Point midwinter horse show was staged under the direction of Lieut. Col. Marion Carson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Jake Schaefer of Cleveland started slowly tonight, then settled down to defeat Irving Crane of Livonia, N.Y., 50 to 41, for his second victory in three starts in the world three-cushion billiard tournament. The match went fifty-three innings.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Britain's super-fighter of the air for battles this Spring will be what one Royal Air Force officer called the "daddy of all Spitfires," The Daily Mail's air correspondent wrote tonight.

The "freezing" of all assets in the United States owned by foreigners, as proposed in the draft of an order prepared for the signature of President Roosevelt, probably will await further developments in the relations between this country and foreign powers, it was said in financial circles yesterday.
" The devil is having the greatest time he had had for centuries," the Rev. John Paul Jones said in a sermon at Union Church, Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

VICHY, France, Jan. 19 (UP) -- French stocks of vital medicines have reached a dangerously low point and the Ministry of Health has grave fears that the months of February and March may bring epidemics of influenza and pneumonia, a high official of the Ministry declared today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Plans for two John Steinbeck films were formulated over the week-end. Herbert Klein, who has been in Mexico since August producing and directing Steinbeck's first original scenario, "The Forgotten Village," disclosed that Spencer Tracy will deliver the commentary for the picture, which was made with Mexicans as actors.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The Legislature will reconvene tomorrow night for another week of "marking time," prior to the introduction by Governor Lehman of his budget on Jan. 27. Introduction of bills, completion of organization, and other preliminary matters will be taken up, so that no real time is being lost.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Husky Francis Tyler and his Sno-Bird crew of Lake Placid successfully fought a swirling snowstorm today to win both the Lithgow Osborne and Samuel Packer four-man bobsled races on Mount Van Hoevenberg's run.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters will put in effect today a "comprehensive" liability insurance scheme, which, it was asserted, "represents another important step forward in meeting the needs of the insuring public by making available, in addition to the forms of policies already in use, comprehensive liability policies which afford broader protection at the lowest possible cost."

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A "lack of unified policy" on important problems of national defense was blamed today by T. Claude Ryan, airplane manufacturer, for the industrial strife which he said endangered the country's aircraft industry.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 19 -- Hundreds of men of the Twenty-seventh Division wound up a warbling week-end this afternoon with an open-air divisional sing on the parade ground under the direction of Hugh Ross, conductor of the Schola Cantorum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Leaders of three of the most important C.I.O. unions, in a radio discussion here today of labor's part in the defense program, pledged their unions to "all-out" cooperation and asserted that there was no occasion for labor's rights to be infringed.

On the surface, the figure of airplane production given out by John D. Biggers, director of production of OPM, seems reassuring. Mr. Biggers reports that 799 airplanes "of military type" were turned out in December, or ninety-nine more than had been predicted for that month by Mr. Knudsen.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 20 (UP) -- The government has completed its conferences with leaders of Parliament, business, finance and the press, in advance of the reopening of the Diet tomorrow, and is confident it will weather all attacks, informants close to Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye said today.
DETROIT, Jan. 19 -- The New York Rangers pushed through two last-period scores tonight to defeat the crippled Detroit Red Wings, 2 to 1, for their first victory on Olympia ice since Feb. 23, 1939.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- After an early strong upward movement, last week, with the leading shares gaining 6 to 10 points, the stock market here slumped toward the end of the period in what was generally considered healthy downward reaction.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Robert P. Patterson, Assistant Secretary of War, today called upon American labor for full cooperation to prepare the United States for all emergencies and "to see that maximum help reaches England."

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Corn developed a much firmer undertone last week than in the preceding sessions, and, as a result, prices advanced to new high levels since last November. A rapid rise in the price of hogs exerted a strong influence on sentiment as also did only a small movement of cash grain to the terminal markets.

VERPLANCK, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Dick Werner of Haledon, N.J., won the men's senior title in the Southern New York outdoor speed skating championships today on Bleakley's Lake amid poor ice conditions and a strong wind.

Preaching on "Indestructible Things," the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church at 114th Street, declared last night that "even though Hitler might succeed in conquering England, he can never succeed in destroying the Jew or the Bible-believing church of Jesus Christ."

The Greater New York Industrial Union Council of the C.I.O. announced yesterday its adoption of a resolution supporting the efforts of the National Maritime Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, to obtain a general wage increase of 25 per cent and increased war risk compensation for seamen employed by Atlantic and Gulf Coast deep-sea ship owners.

BERLIN, Monday, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Authorized German sources said today that the German Charge d'Affaires at Washington had been instructed to ask for punishment of the United States sailors who tore down the Nazi flag from the German Consulate in San Francisco and assurance of the right to hoist the flag again with American protection.

A new plane of decent and fair living is needed today to fulfill the requirements of society in accordance with the purposes of God, declared the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee in his sermon yesterday morning at Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.

Many must have a fervent belief in God if he is to achieve a world at peace, the Rev. William John Villaume declared in his farewell sermon as assistant pastor yesterday morning at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

CLINTON, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- A belief that President Roosevelt was "feeling his way" toward an Anglo-American political union was voiced here today by Dr. Felix Morley, president of Haverford College, in an address after receiving the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from Hamilton College.

The Lynn Riggs play, "The Cream in the Well," opens this evening at the Booth Theatre under the aegis of Mrs. Carly Wharton and Martin Gabel. Against an Oklahoma background Mr. Riggs relates the tragedy of a "group of people who psychologically destroy themselves."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Headed by Governor Herbert H. Lehman, scores of New Yorkers joined inaugural crowds here today for the inauguration.

Pierre A. Bernard became known as "ecru the Omnipotent" when a police investigation in 1910 disclosed charges that he was running a love cult embroidered with lIindu philosophy in a West Side flat. The following year he reopened in business as the operator of the "New York Sanskrit College," giving yogi exercises, health and religious talks to classes of girls and tired business r.Ln,

BAY SHORE, L.I., Jan. 19 -- Captured by State police early this morning after a wild ninety-mile-an-hour chase, Wesley Wood, 22-year-old member of the 198th Field Artillery, National Guard, in training at Camp Upton, said he had gone A.W.O.L. and stolen three automobiles because he was "tired of Army life" and wanted to go home to Felton, Del.
Victories were scored by the Bronxville Field Club and the Sleepy Hollow Country Club yesterday in the Westchester division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association team competition.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A competent diplomatic authority said today that the British had drawn up detailed plans for bombing Rumania's oil fields and rail lines, but were holding their execution in abeyance for fear of the effect on the Greek war.
Representatives of the Salle Santelli triumphed in the John Allaire Memorial Trophy fencing competition yesterday at the New York A.C. The event was a three-weapon team affair.

Suspension of The Beacon, Brooklyn College evening session student newspaper, the dropping of its editor from student rolls and the voluntary cessation of publication by the literary magazine. The Kaleidoscope, took place during the last few days, less than a week after seven student leaders had been placed on disciplinary probation, it was announced yesterday by the office of Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- About the war's progress there are few doubts, though the way will still be difficult and hazardous, but about taxation there are very reasonable doubts and fears, tempered to some extent by signs that the Chancellor of the Exchequer seems disposed to give more sympathetic attention to the present inequalities of taxation of industry and business generally.

With workers in national defense industries "only 30 to 40 per cent unionized" and aggressive organizing campaigns under way or projected in most fields, many strikes are likely to develop unless adequate facilities for outside mediation are available, a special committee of the Twentieth Century Fund reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 -- Increased hedging pressure with lack of buying impetus accounted for some weakening of the price structure in cotton futures here last week. Net results to Friday's closing were declines of 60 to 70 cents a bale in the active options, while spot middling eased 13 points despite an increased turnover.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 19 -- David McElroy and George Cummings of the University Club won the Nassau Country Club's first amateur-professional squash racquets tournament today when they beat Frank Rogers and Ed Standing of the Yale Club, 13 -- 15, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 7.

During 1940 the number of occupied old-law tenements requiring fire-retarding was reduced by 73 per cent, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in summing up the accomplishments of his Committee on Property Improvement.

Voluntary evacuation of British children from crowded areas imperiled by German bombs has not been the success the authorities expected, and through no fault of the authorities. In the early days of the war almost two million children, expectant mothers and old people were sent out of the cities to safe areas in the British countryside.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Administration supporters, organizing their forces for what many of them predicted would be an extended Senate fight over the Lease-Lend Bill, said today that a preliminary canvass indicated they could count on passage of the measure by a substantial majority.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- The wheat market continues in a rut, prices having held to within a range of 2 1/2 cents a bushel this year to date, and in grain circles here there is a growing belief that a change to more active business is, perhaps, not far off.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., marched over a rain-flooded course today to give a remarkable exhibition of chipping and putting and defeated Harry Cooper of Chicago, 7 and 6, in the thirty-six hole final of the $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A high government official said today that President Manuel Avila Camacho's administration would welcome an exclusive arrangement with the United States that would dry up the stream of essential war metals now flowing to the Axis from Mexico.

The ratio of department store advertising to total advertising in newspapers, which has been increasing steadily since 1929, remained static last year in comparison with 1939, according to an analysis of Media Records figures. In 1939 the ratio was 24.57 and last year it was 24.55.

The Commonwealth Fund appropriated $2,009,685, chiefly to aid medical research, medical education and public health work, during the year ended Sept. 30, 1940, the fund announced yesterday at its office, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Rallying with two goals, the Black Hawks gained a 4-4 tie in their National Hockey League game with Boston tonight before 17,306 spectators.

THE swimming enthusiasts, who have such fun in the water, certainly know how to pour it on -- and hot' , Apparently some of them would make it boiling oil if they could. For what offense ? Why, for the high crime of commenting lightly on the curious custom in swimming circles of making six records grow where one would be simpler and better.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 19 -- A. Harry Moore, first man to serve three terms as Governor of New Jersey, prepared today to relinquish the Chief Executive's chair for the saddle of an Arizona mustang.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Philip Murray, head of the C.I.O., summarily ended tonight what he described as an unauthorized strike which threatened for a time to paralyze operations at the vast Irvin works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

Refusing to admit defeat at the hands of a heavily favored opponent, the New York Americans salvaged a merited tie out of their National Hockey League game with Toronto at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's skaters, trailing by two goals at the end of the second period, flashed a thrilling, overpowering rally that enabled them to tie the score at 3-all and send activities into overtime.

World-wide broadcast by short-wave of the third inauguration of President Roosevelt has been arranged for Monday. About 525 network stations in this country will carry the ceremonies and there will be local-station relays in Canada, in the British Isles and in Latin America.

As the site for a group of one-family homes, a vacant plot 181 by 100 feet on the north side of Lowell Street, 100 feet east of Eastchester Road, the Bronx, has been bought for cash by Solomon Friedman. It was the first turnover of the property in fifteen years, according to Albert Pfeifer broker in the deal.

An Italian-American youth joined four young Greek-Americans in a plunge into the frigid waters of New York Harbor yesterday to recover a cross of gold tossed off Pier A at the Battery by Bishop Arsenios of the Greek Orthodox Church.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- A sensational advance in the price of hogs to the highest level since September, 1939, had considerable influence on lard last week, and all deliveries except January sold at new seasonal high prices. While the top figures were not maintained, because of realizing sales and a reaction in hogs, closing trades on futures on the Board of Trade yesterday showed gains of 17 1/2 to 25 cents for 100 pounds.

The difficulties of buying materials for city use under war conditions at the rate of $150,000,000 a year were described yesterday by Purchase Commissioner Russell Forbes in a report to Mayor La Guardia covering the eighteen-month period from Jan. 1, 1939, to June 30, 1940.

The Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation reports for last year consolidated earnings of $1,280,799, after provisions for Federal income and excess profits taxes, equivalent to $1.28 a share on the 926,000 shares of common stock outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The United States expressed to Germany today its regret over an American sailor's ripping a swastika flag from the German Consulate in San Francisco.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- In the face of predictions that air raids and crowded shelters would cause epidemics, the most recent public health statistics show that Britain in 1940 was healthier than it was the year before the war started, especially in relation to contagious diseases.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 66 by 92 feet at 50 West Seventeenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to David W. Frankel, operator. It is assessed at $200,000 and was sold for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $126,000 for ten years at 3 and 4 per cent.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Jay Rand, a Sno-Bird from Lake Placid, succeeded today in doing what he has been trying to do for some time. He won a major ski jump, the fourteenth annual tournament of the Norway Ski Club on the Bear Mountain State Park hill.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reports that its net assets on Dec. 31 last were $105,801,503, equal to $18.10 a share, against $16.90 a share on June 30 last, and $20.98 a share on Dec. 31, 1939. Shares outstanding fell in 1940 by 41,479 to 5,846,857.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 101.8 on Jan. 7, compared with 100.9 on Dec. 31, 1940, 100.9 on Dec. 17, 92.4 on Jan. 16, 1940, 70.3 at the end of August, 1939, and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Because of the indisposition of Otto Klemperer, last night's concert of the New York Symphony Orchestra, the third in the current series given under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project in Carnegie Hall, was led by John Barnett, the orchestra's assistant conductor.

The serious difficulties that beset Christian missions everywhere today present a challenge the church is determined to meet by maintaining and advancing its mission activities, the Rev. Dr. James Thayer Addison, vice president of the National Council of the Episcopal Church, said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

The sheer beauty of last week's ice storm could be appreciated only from a high place and across a sweep of open country. These freezes which sheathe everything in crystal often sparkle in the sun and take on prismatic tints, transforming woods into groves of Chinese jeweltrees.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Mrs. Frank Osgood Butler gave a luncheon at the Seminole Club today. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. McQuesten, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan D. Bill, Mrs. James H. Kennedy, Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff, Mrs. McAlpin Bell, Mrs. Grace Edward Miller, Raymond G. Noble, Harry Skillman. Harry C. Radon, Joseph K. Love and Ira S. Dunkle.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Following the conclusion of the Russo-German trade agreement the British Government has been making a close study of Russian purchases of commodities in the United States. The agreement covers the delivery of huge tonnages of various raw materials not available in Russia.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 20 -- German bombers returned to Britain last night after leaving the island alone the best part of the previous twenty-four hours.
Miss Sonja Henie and her 1941 Hollywood Ice Revue will make their New York debut tonight at Madison Square Garden, probably before a capacity crowd.
Mary, the Mother of Jesus, is the most powerful intercessor the human race has before the throne of God, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Fearful of the consequences of a British defeat, Matthew Woll, third vice president of the American Federation of Labor and chairman of the Trade Union Committee to Aid Great Britain, urged 3,000 members of the New York Photo-Engravers Union, Local 1, yesterday to give all possible support to the government's defense program while bearing in mind the impossibility of American isolation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Jesse Jones. Federal loan administrator, reported to Congress today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries had made commitments totaling $1,099,298,848 to provide reserves of rubber, metals and other strategic and critical materials, to construct defense plants and acquire equipment and to make loans directly to manufacturers to enable them to carry out defense contracts.

Housing is in two ways a part of the national defense: first, as an emergency necessity when war-material industries bring new workers into their communities; second, as a lasting contribution toward a healthier population. Since the emergency housing is mainly for families living on good wages, it need not except in special cases demand a Federal subsidy.

For the first time in our history a President is today inducted into office for a third term. This breaking of precedents might be expected to invest the occasion with exceptional interest. Actually, however, this inaugural attracts less attention than usual, far less than Mr. Roosevelt's first inauguration.

Bernt Balchen, the famous pilot, is back at his hazardous business again, according to the North American Newspaper Alliance. A friend of Balchen arrived recently in New York from Bermuda and reported that he was flying Consolidated Aircraft patrol bombers from Bermuda to England as head pilot.

Among the proposals to amend the Lease-Lend Bill there is one that restricts the time for which the power to be conferred on the President should be valid. Some speak of two years. The proposers of this amendment find it dangerous to give some one power for an unlimited time.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 19 -- Further gains in the volume of incoming steel business, a downward adjustment of certain scrap quotations, a slight expansion in the raw steel output and a continuation of relatively heavy export purchases were highlights in news of the steel industry last week.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 19 -- The Bourses of the small Continental European countries last week showed no uniform trend; Brussels and Zurich markets being firm and Amsterdam and Scandinavian depressed. The reason for this was not so much due to heavy liquidation as it was to the public and operators adopting a waiting attitude, which, under present circumstances, leads to the crumbling of prices and small trading volume.
TOKYO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Kazuma Suzuki today described the United States as the "decisive factor" in both the European and Asiatic conflicts.

For the first time since early Prohibition days a year has passed In which there was not a "racket" killing in Brooklyn and for the first time in the borough's history there was only one unsolved murder in a year, according to the report for 1940 made public yesterday by Kings County District Attorney William O'Dwyer.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Captured enemy aircraft undergoing the closest scrutiny at a certain Royal Air Force station where research is carried out show beyond question that German materials are first class and that the workmanship is still of the highest order, it was stated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The arts of the theatre were combined here tonight in an Inauguration Gala, honoring the President and the Vice President, who will be inducted into office tomorrow, which set in its own way a notable precedent as part of the third-term ceremonies.

At the halfway mark of the college basketball campaign Long Island University, New York University, City College and Brooklyn College in the metropolitan area, Dartmouth and Cornell in the Eastern League and Georgetown, Duquesne, Rhole Island and Seton Hall in other parts of the East stand out as the leaders.

Once the trout fishing is over for the year there is no telling just where Sparse Gray Hackle will turn up. One day you will see him peering through the plate-glass window of a Chambers Street gun shop, the next day you may run him to earth in an easy chair in front of the fireplace at the Anglers' Club.
BERLIN. Jan. 19 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Although still contending with physical difficulties, which fortunately diminished last week, the stock market advanced well over a comparatively broad front.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 (AP) -- British motorized units pursuing fleeing Italian soldiers along a wide Sudanese front were believed tonight to have crossed the border into Italian East Africa after having forced the Fascisti from Kassala, fifteen miles from Italian Eritrea.

Two issues seem to be confused in the controversy concerning the Lease-Lend Bill. There are those isolationists in varying degrees who do not wish to go too far in giving aid to Britain and other nations, for fear of our becoming fully involved in the war. There are others who hesitate, even in time of emergency, to give such full powers to the President.

Boston Day at Madison Square Garden yesterday was a huge success -- it was for the Bostonians, anyway. The Boston Olympics nosed out the New York Rovers, 5 to 4, in the Eastern Hockey League battle, and the Boston Olympic Juniors blanked the Jamaica Hawks, 5 to 0, in the intercity series for the Lester Patrick Trophy.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 19 -- On a bright clear Sunday after the rain and mists of the last few days visitors and sight-seers swarmed into this post today. At the intersection of the Wrightstown, Pointville and Fort Dix roads the sentry on duty estimated the traffic volume at 1,000 cars an hour with the peak coming at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.
Only five new films are scheduled to open in local houses this week. They are:

There is no sound reason at present why there should be any forebodings regarding the effect of substantial borrowings for defense purposes, A.D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., declares in Dun's Review, published today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) -- The total defense program is threatened by a dangerous shortage of airports throughout the country, the National Aeronautic Association warned tonight.

An average reduction of 7.8 per cent in insurance rates for Passenger and commercial automobiles in New York State will go into effect today, according to an announcement by Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent. The cut will also be applied retroactively to policies written since last Dec. 1.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Nazi dive-bombers delivered another smashing attack on the crippled British aircraft carrier Illustrious at Valletta, Malta, today, and the High Command reported that the air force had extended its Mediterranean operations more than 1,000 miles eastward from Italy to the Suez Canal.

Singing as refined, sincere and sensitive as that heard from Ishbel Mutch, Canadian soprano, at her first New York recital, yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, was not long in awakening the interest and enthusiastic approval of her large audience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Charles L. Mitchell, senior weather forecaster for the Department of Commerce, decided tonight that President Roosevelt could say that the heavens had been unusually kind to him at his three inaugurations.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 19 (UP) -Relatives of Walter Groebli, who is accused of wounding his employer, Percival W. Whittlesey, at South Nyack, N.Y., tonight expressed surprise at description of him as an ardent pro-Nazi.

A SHORT time after President Roosevelt was inaugurated for a second term he delivered his famous message to Congress on the Supreme Court. Now on the inauguration day of his third term comes an aftermath of that controversial act. It is a book by Robert H. Jackson, Attorney General of the United States, called "The Struggle for Judicial Supremacy -- A Study of a Crisis in American Power Politics."*

It was the track rather than the track meet that had the footracing gentry talking yesterday. The Metropolitan A.A.U. championships were staged at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx on Saturday only because armory sites were no longer available. It was with mild trepidation that the A.A.U. group selected the Coliseum, since it had no other place to go.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Wendell L. Willkie conferred with President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull here this afternoon and received from the President a personal note of introduction to Prime Minister Churchill which he will carry when he leaves by Clipper plane Wednesday for a visit to bomb-torn England.

The following statement, issued by Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, shows receipts and payments for December, 1940 and 1939, together with receipts and payments from July 1 to Dec. 31, 1940, and for the same period of 1939.
BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Verne Marshall, chairman of the No Foreign War Committee, asserted tonight that reports of Britain's exhaustion of her dollar credits in the United States was "baby talk."

The largest number of retail buyers of the season was in the market last week, many of them with budget increases of 10 per cent. Orders for future delivery in many cases ran farther ahead than in former years on semi-staple and staple merchandise, but style goods were bought for relatively near-by selling.

Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" and "Lohengrin" both will be presented for the first time this season next week at the Metropolitan Opera House. The week, which will be the ninth one of the season, also will mark John Brownlee's first local appearance as the father in "Louise," and the return to the company of Bruno Landi, Italian tenor, who has been absent for three years.

VICHY, France, Jan. 19 -- "Marshal Petain, the Chief of State, yesterday met President Laval. They had a long conversation in the course of which the misunderstandings that had brought about the events of Dec. 13 were dispelled."

Young women headed by Miss Patricia Suydam are aiding in the plans for the Children's Carnival to be held next Saturday afternoon in the new auditorium of Hunter College for the benefit of the Health and Personal Service Committee of Greenwich House.

RUMSON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Many luncheons were given at the Rumson Country Club today before the concert given by the Monmouth Oratorio Society at St. George's Church-by-the-River. Contributions were received for the fund which is being raised by the Monmouth War Relief, Inc., to provide a rolling kitchen to be sent to England.

Worthington Court, a thirty-two-family apartment house at 160-64 Summit Avenue, Summit, N.J., has been purchased by Howard B. Bishop, as trustee for his children, Vernon, H. Berkey and Ann, from the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, trustee for certificate holders.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Two Navy seamen who tore a Nazi flag from the German Consulate Saturday were ordered released from jail tonight on a writ of habeas corpus obtained by two American Legion officials.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 19 -- The question whether the continued reinforcement of German troops in Rumania is connected with the reported statement of German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels just before the process began that Germany was preparing to give the world a lesson as to how an offensive should be conducted and would shortly show the world what she was capable of is discussed by the leading publicist Yalchin in today's newspaper Yeni Sabah.

SUDA, Crete, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- This is the tale of the more pleasant side of the war. A party took place in the house of the Mayor of a hamlet near the mouth of Suda Bay. When it started, the full moon was coming out of the Aegean, and when it ended it was falling through the olive groves to Africa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Harry Parker, whose grandfather was body servant to George Washington, first President of the United States, will sit by a window in the Capitol tomorrow to watch another inauguration in the long list he has witnessed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Democracy can better protect itself by specific restriction of abuse of the right to assembly than by its blanket suppression, but only minority meetings which are free to those who differ from the purpose for which they are held are entitled to the right of free assembly, declares the Council for Democracy in a memorandum issued today through the American Council on Public Affairs.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 19 (UP) -- Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif., today defeated Bobby Riggs of Chicago, in the quarter-finals of the Florida State tennis tournament.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- In a puffy northwest wind that just would not end its capers, nineteen sailing dinghies swept around the harbor hero this afternoon in four races. Only two of them capsized, which was surprising, the spectators watching from the Larchmont Yacht Club grounds expecting momentarily that other boats would turn bottom up, spilling their occupants into the cold water.

MANILA, Monday, Jan. 20 -- Ninety-eight Filipino seamen from the holds of three German sea raiders in the South Pacific arrived in Manila last night aboard the Kamo Maru with the report that twelve German raiders were operating in this area and that a dozen more were outfitting in Japanese ports.
The sinking of the first modern armored ship ever lost in war as a result of air attack was, in the long view, one of the most important events of the European conflict.

There is no solution to the present European situation except that possessed by the Catholic church -- return from neo-paganism to Christianity, Alfred Noyes, British poet, told 1,400 members of the Carroll Club of New York, an organization for Catholic business and professional women, at the club's twenty-first annual communion breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, the only member of the Board of Education who voted against excusing pupils from school for religious instruction, defended her action yesterday and declared her "unalterable opposition" to the measure, which, she said, would inevitably cause disunity among the children in the school system.

After showing a steady upward trend over the previous fortnight, cotton prices last week turned easier. On the New York Cotton Exchange active future deliveries, from March through July, were down 14 to 18 points in the week, October and December were off only 6 and 9 points, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- William S. Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, called on industry today for an "'all-out' performance of American ingenuity, backed by every machine and piece of equipment available," to supply the guns, tanks, planes and ships needed for defense.

The Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "our modern world has lost its sense of values and the church needs to do some serious advertising for the return of lost American virtues."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Solemnly though briefly, under a bright sun that failed to temper the keen-edged breezes sweeping the city, three religious leaders joined this afternoon in a public service in recognition of the significance of tomorrow's impending ritual of inauguration of an American President.

Specific means of dealing with the problem of Negro unemployment were considered yesterday afternoon at a discussion of "Employment Opportunities for the Negro," held by the Catholic Interracial Council in the chapel of St. Peter's Church, Barclay and Church Streets.

The Institute for Propaganda I Analysis made public yesterday results of a study showing that organized pacifism in the church is "much stronger today" than it was in 1917. Virtually every church body in the country, the study found, is on record as favoring non-combatant duty for the conscientious objector.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The note to Prime Minister Churchill given by President Roosevelt to Wendell L. Willkie, it was learned, introduces Mr. Willkie with the comment that he has been trying to keep politics out of the American defense situation and expresses wishes for British success.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 19 -- Uruguayan authorities refused to permit the landing here today of fifteen Jewish passengers who arrived on the Japanese steamer Montevideo Maru after several months of wandering, in which they have almost encircled the globe.

Revision of the National Labor Relations Act, broadening of the State and Federal income tax base and opposition to the St. Lawrence waterway and power project as a defense measure were among the objectives announced yesterday as on the program of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York for 1941.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UP) -- Representatives of the American Hockey Association today proposed that a "czar" or commission be set up to settle disputes between minor leagues and the National Hockey League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Efforts either to modify or to block action on the Administration's Lease-Lend Bill will be the major business of Congress in the next six days.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- 1Vfr Arnold was to have entered the University of Pennsylvania Hospital here after having been flown from Mexico City in an oxygen tent. Besides his xvife, the former Theresa Deusel of Lebanon, Pa.. a nurse and two friends, lir. and Mrs. William I-Iamer of Mexico City, accompanied him.

VICHY, Jan. 19 -- The French economic situation appears less satisfactory. It is true that in the last months of 1940 there was an appreciable reduction of unemployment. According to the official statement, the total number of unemployed was 583,000 in the Paris region on Oct. 19 and it fell to 414,000 on Jan. 4, a decline of 15 per cent.

GUAQAQUIL, Ecuador, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Western Hemisphere deal in which the United States would cooperate with Ecuador in building air and naval bases in the Galapagos Islands and help arbitrate the long-standing border dispute between Ecuador and Peru was reported under consideration tonight.

Although employment increased under the national defense program, the State paid out $18,770,000 more in unemployment insurance last year than it did in 1939, Official statistics disclosed yesterday. Total benefit payments for 1940 were $98,789,000, an increase of 23.5 per cent over the 1939 figure of $80,019, 000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- W.G. Batchelder, who was 100 years old last Sept. 24, decided today that he would not leave the United States Soldiers' Home for the Inauguration tomorrow. He was afraid the could might be too much for him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The benefits which totalitarian dictators promise their people will be theirs after victory in a long and hard war have already been vouchsafed to the peoples of the world's democracies, Attorney General Robert H. Jackson said tonight in a speech to the Presidential electors which was read by Solicitor General Francis Biddle.

In Washington today History lifts her pen and pauses. For the first time we shall have a Third Inaugural Address from a President of the United States. It will be made at a critical moment in the life of the American people. As in 1933, we face what, the President then called "dark realities."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Wendell L. Willkie, on departing from the White House today, said that he had had "a pleasant chat" with President Roosevelt and that the meeting was "delightful."

Locked in each other's arms, Mrs. Caroline Hartwell Patterson, 27 years old, and Israel Hurvitz, 41, both formerly of Boston, Jumped underneath a train of the IND division at the Third Avenue and Fifty-third Street Station at 8:42 A.M. yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Franklin Delano Roosevelt of New York will be inaugurated tomorrow as the first third-term President in the history of the United States.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 19 -- Sweden is determined to fight, if necessary, for the freedom of this country, and the consequent necessity of adding further strength to the nation's defenses was voiced tonight by Foreign Minister Christian E. Guenther.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Miss Carmelita Landry, 23, of Fitchburg retained her New England women's speed skating championship today and Leo Lavalley of Pawtucket, R.I., regained the men's title he first won two years ago.

If trends in education help to shape the destiny of nations an examination of these trends should throw some light on the future of the peoples now engaged in the titanic struggle which shakes the world. In the thirty-fifth annual report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, Dr. Walter Jessup, its president, offers such a study of higher education in Germany, France, Great Britain and the United States.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The High Command said today that the Thai [Siamese] flag was raised yesterday over the French protectorate of Cambodia, in French Indo-China, for the first time in more than fifty years.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Jan. 19 -- An English clergyman is running a night club for British sailors at this great African base because he doesn't want them to get "gypped."

CLEVELAND, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The steel market has entered a more orderly phase, with consumers, realizing the impossibility of spot deliveries in the jammed industry, carefully examining their future requirements and placing orders as far ahead as the fourth quarter, the magazine Steel reported today.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- The heavy banks of fog with which the German authorities envelop the capital whenever important diplomatic consultations or military actions are in progress or imminent descended on Berlin tonight. Whether Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini had actually met today and if so, where; whether they were going to meet, or whether any other developments were occurring behind the thick moist clouds could not positively be ascertained.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The radio debate on the Lease-Lend Bill, in which Senator Wheeler angered President Roosevelt last week by calling it a scheme to "plow under every fourth American boy," was continued this evening in Theodore Granik's American Forum of the Air.

That financial markets should have turned reactionary last week, after their steady advance since the turn of the year--an advance scored in face of the huge estimates of expenditure in the budget speech, also in face of a proposal for unlimited executive discretion in the use of funds appropriated for defense --was not perhaps surprising.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 19 -- The Appalachian Mountain Club of Boston, whose skiers have won fame for this pioneer organization throughout North America, dominated the men's and women's team invitation slalom held today by the Eastern Slope Ski Club at Cranmore Mountain.

HAVANA, Jan. 19 -- The threeday air carnival, in which aviators from all parts of the United States participated under the auspices of the National Sports Commission at Camp Columbia Army Airfield, closed this afternoon.

The only incident in the trading in foreign exchanges last week to disturb the even tenor of the markets of the last four months was the abrupt decline in the Chinese currencies as a direct result of the withdrawal of support by the control fund.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, prepared yesterday for the public opening Wednesday of the most elaborate exhibition it has ever held, the exhibition of American Indian art, sponsored jointly by the museum and the Department of the Interior.

Residents of Broad Channel, the Queens island community in Jamaica Bay, were awakened at about 4 A.M. yesterday by a series of explosions and flares of flame that lighted the sky along Cross Bay Boulevard, which is being widened by the WPA.

SOUTH NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Percival W. Whittlesey, who for twelve years was secretary of the Clarkstown Country Club Corporation headed by Dr. Pierre A. Bernard (once known to his distaste as "Oom the Omnipotent"), was shot in his home here this morning by a hitch-hiker he had befriended and employed.

A cabled appeal for food, or for United States dollars with which to buy emergency supplies from Soviet Russia, signed by seventeen prominent Norwegians, was made public yesterday by former President Hoover, honorary chairman of the National Committee on Food for the Five Small Democracies, 420 Lexington Avenue.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 -- The press announced, today that since the commencement of Italo-Greek hostilities 105 Italian planes had been downed by Allied anti-aircraft guns and air forces and that the combined effort of the Royal Air Force and Greek air arm had caused such destruction to Italian landing fields in Albania that scarcely any facilities were left.

The Primrose Quartet played the late Frank Bridge's Quartet in E minor yesterday afternoon at Town Hall at the tenth chamber music concert this season of the New Friends of Music. Though not originally planned as such, it served as a memorial to the British composer who died nine days ago in England.

German bombs have destroyed few London buildings, but a great many social barriers, and have been ineffectual against the morale of the inhabitants, Mrs. Rosita Forbes, British explorer and writer, said yesterday in an interview upon her arrival here from the British capital.

Higher education in Germany, France and England between 1920 and 1940 are contrasted with higher education in the United States in the thirty-fifth annual report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, made public today.

Testimony before the House Naval Affairs Committee in Washington, noted in THE TIMES today, places new emphasis on the fact that Navy strategists consider that air-bombing attacks seriously threaten the security of the fleet, and thai the Navy is finding it a problem to equip destroyers against such attacks owing to the prohibitive weight involved in applying protective armor to these craft.

The audience which attended the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall had the good fortune to hear Bruno Walter's interpretation of Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony. This was one of the greatest readings we have heard from Mr. Walter.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 (AP) -- This communique was issued tonight by the British Middle East Command:

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 -- The Italians have given up, temporarily at least, their dreams of an offensive on the Sudanese frontier. On Friday they abandoned Kassala, the Sudanese border city that once was considered to be the probable springboard for a Fascist drive on Khartum.

A cabled appeal for food, or for United States dollars with which to buy emergency supplies from Soviet Russia, signed by seventeen prominent Norwegians, was made public yesterday by former President Hoover, honorary chairman of the National Committee on Food for the Five Small Democracies, 420 Lexington Avenue.

Asserting that the real world economic problem vas not redistribution of what was in existence but the creation of more goods for mass consumption, Frank E. Mullen, vice president and general manager of the National Broadcasting Company, said yesterday that the answer was to be found in the scientific laboratory from which were emerging new services, new products and new employment for both men and capital.

Reports that a few United States' shippers selling in the Latin-American market were reviving the type of commercial tactics which alienated customers there for years after the last war caused deep concern among exporters here last week.

The possibility of extensive changes in displays at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was forecast in the annual report of the new director, Francis Henry Taylor, to the corporation of the museum at its annual meeting yesterday afternoon.

There is a gap, a yawning gap in the very interesting talk of Jay Allen with Marshal Henri Phillipe Petain, issued last Friday by the North American Newspaper Alliance. Is Marshal Petain still convinced that Germany will win the war?

American publishers probably issued more books in 1940 than in any other year, according to a survey released by Publishers Weekly. New books and new editions totaled 11,328 titles, certainly a record for recent years. Because prior to 1921 paper-covered material was included in publishers' output compilations, the book totals for preceding years are not exactly known.

The four-story brick apartment house at 318-320 Forty-fourth Street, Union City, assessed for $52,000, was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark to Morris Breakstone. Revenue stamps on the deed indicate a consideration of $38,000. The new owner gave back in part payment a purchase-money mortgage for $25,500.

VICHY, France, Jan. 20 -- "Henceforth there is no longer any censorship so far as foreign correspondents are concerned, except as regards the person of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and items bearing on military matters." Pierre-Etienne Flandin, Minister of Foreign Affairs, who has charge also of information and propaganda, made this announcement at a press conference this evening.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 20 -- Today's Bourse opened steady, but some liquidation followed; Dutch issues closing depressed to 6 points lower.
Heavier traffic is expected on the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad this year, C. McD. Davis, executive vice president, said yesterday.

A five-point program to help the smaller business men to participate in national defense production was presented to members of the Smaller Business Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut last night by Albert W. Clurman, executive secretary, at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Henry L. Rosenfeld Jr. of Salomon Brothers Hutzler and Francis T. Greene, assistant director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will start today a series of meetings with securities dealers in important financial centers for the purpose of explaining and clarifying rules and regulations of the SEC, the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The largest first day attendance in the history of the New York Furniture Exchange was recorded yesterday at the opening of the Spring market here. The event marked the fiftieth anniversary of the exchange.

Why? If Lynn Riggs's "The Cream in the Well" were not written in such good prose and with so many overtones of serious thought, it would not be necessary to begin a review by asking what he has in the back of his mind, why he is torturing his characters, why he is enveloping the audience in gloom.
MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Members of the United States -- Canada joint permanent defense board held a three-hour meeting here today and planned to confer again tomorrow.

The Kolisch Quartet gave the world premiere of Bela Bartok's Sixth String Quartet in its concert at the Town Hall last night. As if to make the competition tough, the new work was preceded by Mozart's Quartet in C, K. 465, and followed by Schubert's "Death and the Maiden" Quartet in D minor.
In a resolution adopted unanimously last night the Board of Higher Education threatened to take disciplinary action against teachers who refuse in future to testify before the Rapp-Coudert inquiry.

The need for community hospitality to soldiers, sailors and marines on leave was stressed yesterday by high officers of the Army and Navy, speaking at the annual luncheon of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, at the Plaza Hotel.

An old familiar friendly face, long pointed at from the galleries of Congress, has left the show. After swearing in his successor, Mr. Garner made tracks for Texas, reviving for a moment those once common symbols, GTT, Gone to Texas. He has been in Congress thirty-eight years, from before the elective term of Roosevelt the First to the beginning of the third term of Roosevelt the Second.
Boxing has climbed off Joe Louis's back and is getting along very nicely on its own this Winter.
The leading city realty transaction reported yesterday was the sale of the twelve-story Hotel Peter Stuyvesant, at 2 West Eighty-sixth Street, on the southwest corner of Central Park West.

SINCE our fish and fowl have no votes, the problem of wildlife conservation in this country has not provoked the volume of radio oratory that it merits, but it has just produced an informative and readable book that deserves the attention of all citizens alert to their country's welfare.

ROME, Jan. 20 -- An official announcement that Premier Mussolini and Reichsfuehrer Hitler had held one of their fateful conferences was made in Rome this evening in terms identical with those of the communique issued in Berlin a few hours earlier.

Millinery traditions were broken last night when John and Fred of John-Frederics entered the field of costume design. They not only undertook to indicate the path of fashion in hats and dresses, but rounded out their picture with shoes, gloves, bags and all the accesories that complete the attire of a woman.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (UP) -- President Roosevelt's personal envoy, Harry L. Hopkins, it was revealed today, told Glasgow Air Raid Precautions workers last Friday night that the "vast majority" of Americans felt confidence in Britain's ultimate victory.

Commercial credit and collection conditions in Latin-American markets and in the British, French and Netherlands possessions in the West Indies showed a decided improvement in the last half of 1940, according to the results of a survey released yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- For the second time since the beginning of the legislative session both houses reaffirmed tonight their faith in the Rapp-Coudert investigation of subversive activities in New York City schools.

VICHY, France, Jan. 20 -- Through the rather imperfect window of fragmentary press reports France is watching and endeavoring to interpret events and trends in the United States. Only a few of the American dispatches received here are released for publication.

An active week in the accessories markets was indicated here yesterday with the arrival of retailers from many parts of the country to view Spring merchandise. Corset buying got off to a good start, while the show tonight at the Hotel Astor will launch the new millinery season. Showings of corsets were held yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin and the Vanderbilt Hotel, and additional lines will be opened today.

The brief, published yesterday, of the Investment Bankers Association in protest to the proposal of the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission to compel compulsory competitive bidding for new issues of utility securities brought quick response from the investment banking firm of Otis Co., Cleveland, long an advocate of the competitive bidding principle.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 2 per cent for the week ended Jan. 18, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain, reduced by the inclement weather last week, was substantially under that for the previous week, when the increase was 13 per cent over the like week last year.

An organization meeting of the Greater New York Division of the $12,000,000 War Emergency Campaign for Palestine, which is to collect funds for increased colonization and for the defense of the Jewish National Home in Palestine, was held yesterday at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

Army purchases of textiles in the fiscal year 1942 are dependent upon Congressional appropriations not yet made, but unless there are further increases in the Army, the 1942 purchases will be less than those for the 1941 fiscal year, according to Major Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, Quartermaster General.

The men's Central A outfit registered its fifth straight triumph in the Metropolitan Badminton Association tournament, turning back the Downtown A.C., 4 -- 1. Central's women's Class B team also won, defeating New York, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Ten manufacturers of men's, youths' and boys' clothing whose combined financial reports for 1939 are reviewed today by the Federal Trade Commission had a net income in that year on stockholders' investment after provision for income taxes of 10 per cent.

Only on the American continent does travel continue under the pleasant conditions of the pre-war era. Elsewhere, whether you go by land or sea, you "ride hard" in the Russian sense. Steamships are small compared with the floating cities of peacetime and usually overcrowded.

Officials of fourteen local housing authorities sold yesterday a total of $34,015,000 of short-term note obligations. Of the total, a banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and including the Chase National Bank, the National City Bank, the Guaranty Trust Company, the Bankers Trust Company and the Manufacturers Trust Company, purchased $19,020,000 of various maturities.

The eloquence of which Mr. Roosevelt is master was never used to better advantage than in his inaugural message yesterday. This was a straight-forward and a deeply stirring reaffirmation of faith in democracy. It spoke for the millions upon millions of Americans whose confidence in our own form of government is just as strong today as it ever was.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Bill Cowley, great play-making center of the Boston Bruins, provided the passes for three goals last week and thus made his lead in the National Hockey League's scoring race bigger than ever.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 20 (AP) - South African forces, part of the southern jaw of a British pincer campaign against the Italians in East Africa, reported today the capture of prisoners in clashes on the Kenya-Italian Somaliland and Kenya-Ethiopian borders.

Robert W. Baird, president of the Wisconsin Company, Milwaukee, was elected yesterday chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. George W. Davis of Davis, Skaggs Co., San Francisco, and Lee M. Limbert of Blyth Co., Inc., were elected first vice chairman and second vice chairman respectively and Laurence M. Marks of Laurence M. Marks Co. of this city was elected treasurer.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Although his term does not expire until midnight, Governor A. Harry Moore "called it a day" early this afternoon, taking the 2:38 o'clock train for his home in Jersey City.

The vacant land comprising the block front on the north side of 109th Avenue, between 120th and 121st Streets, Richmond Hill, L.I., was sold by the estate of Joseph Cohen to Waldron Homes, Inc., and will be improved with a two-story garden-type apartment house containing ninety-four apartments, The John J. Forshaw Company, Inc., negotiated the sale and, in conjunction with Slawson Hobbs, Inc., arranged a $75,000 mortgage on the property.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The C.I.O. Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee called a strike today at another plant of the International Harvester Company when emplye members walked out of the Rock Falls, Ill., works and formed a picket line.

Price-fixing operations in the near months and Bombay selling in the distant positions made the cotton market irregular yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange final proces were 1 to 8 points net lower.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two Italian divisions, including two Black-shirt battalions, have been routed in actions around Kassala, in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, authoritative military circles reported today. The Italians were said to have suffered 2,000 casualties.

An exhibition of English and French landscapes by nineteenth century French painters has been installed at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is being held for the benefit of the Old New York Chapter, British War Relief Society, Inc., and will be officially opened by Raymond Massey at 3:30 this afternoon.
In a brilliant setting, before 16,000, the 1941 Hollywood Ice Revue, featuring Miss Sonja Henie, was presented at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The hundreds of thousands of Americans who crowded downtown Washington today to see President Roosevelt's inauguration and the subsequent parade were thrilled by the display of the nation's military might.

A tribute to President Roosevelt on the occasion of his inauguration was heard last night over the National Broadcasting Company's blue network with international speakers discussing the general subject "One Nation Indivisible."

The building leased by the Noma Electric Company through Adams Co., Inc., is the nine-story structure at 147-51 West Fifteenth Street, not 79 Seventh Avenue, as stated yesterday in a report based upon incomplete information from the brokers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 20 -- Italian troops continued an orderly retreat from Kassala into Eritrea today, closely followed by British mobile forces, which continually harassed the Fascist rear guard. Fortifications around Sabderat and Tesenei were occupied yesterday without opposition, thus again making the results of many months' labor useless to the Italians.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Continuing an upward sweep that began last Spring, the average weekly earnings of factory workers in Pennsylvania in December rose to the highest point in seventeen years, according to a report today by the Federal Reserve Bank here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A crowd believed to be the largest which ever witnessed a Presidential inauguration listened today to President Roosevelt's speech in grave silence, with only a few interruptions for cheers. The packed throng was sympathetic, but the display of enthusiasm which usually marks such an event was lacking.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Acting in the interests of defense, the State government made today the first move in many years to ease the burdens of the State income tax.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 20 -- Leading newspapers throughout South America hailed President Roosevelt's inauguration for his third term today as an event of utmost significance in the history of humanity, describing him as the undisputed leader of democracy and free people in a struggle that is to decide whether the democratic way of life is to continue.

Problems poised by the international situation found no answer yesterday as President Roosevelt made his third inaugural address and the stock market continued to edge lower. Another meeting between Signor Mussolini and Herr Hitler started all sorts of speculation concerning the "secret" questions they discussed.

As part of Mayor La Guardia's revived campaign to eliminate unnecessary noises in the city's streets, the first of a series of tests to determine the decibel rating of taxicab horns was held yesterday along New York's clamorous Hudson River waterfront, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Continuing the cycle of anti-Nazi action melodramas, Metro today purchased "Reunion," a screen story by Ladislaus Bus-Fekete dealing with a Frenchman who organizes a plot to help his conquered country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's inaugural address:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Vermont schoolmaster eyed the long left arm of Johnny Gee and said he reckoned the Pittsburgh Pirates would get some returns this year on the $75,000 invested in the 6 foot 9 inch pitcher.
