The American International Corporation announced yesterday net assets of $16,146,579 at the end of 1940, equivalent to 170 per cent of the amount of outstanding debentures and, after providing for these, to $6.66 each on 1,000,000 shares of common stock, compared with $4.53 a share on June 30, 1940, and $8.66 a share on Dec. 31, 1939.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Assembly tonight unanimously adopted a resolution urging Secretary Wickard to withhold his contemplated suspension of the Federal order regulating the handling of milk in the metropolitan area until it is superseded by a new order which has been approved by dairy farmers.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 20 -- Conflicting reports regarding the seriousness of the breach between the Chinese Government, headed by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and the Fourth and Eighth Communist armies continue to reach Shanghai. Although there has long been dissension between the two major parties in Chinese resistance to Japan, such dissension has not flared up to such an extent since the Communists agreed to accept General Chiang's orders for anti-Japanese activities and warfare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Two American war veterans who apparently were too anxious to protect President Roosevelt and one man who bellowed his disapproval of the President as he drove up Pennsylvania Avenue toward the Capitol caused mild disturbances during the inaugural ceremonies today and all were arrested for investigation.
ROME, Jan. 20 -- The German Air Corps still is concentrating on Malta and pounding away at the damaged British aircraft carrier Illustrious, according to today's war bulletin.

Europe's fate will ultimately be determined by planes, but the intermediate decisions are being made on trains. Hitler and Mussolini often travel to their happy reunions by armored train. Marshal Petain and Pierre Laval meet in the former's railway car.

The Board of Education, at an adjourned meeting yesterday, adopted unanimously its budget for the fiscal year 1941-42 of $152,006,271. An adjustment made to conform with figures of the Budget Director brought the total to $2,031 less than that originally announced, but no item was dropped to make this possible.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The quantity of Army clothing already contracted for will be sufficient for the 1,418,097 men who are expected to be under arms in June, officials disclosed today.

Hearings will open in Washington today before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the issue of "multiple trading," which is the practice by which members of one exchange make markets in shares listed on their exchange on the floors of other exchanges.
A newly acquired room of the Italian Renaissance will be opened to the public tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Three New York City boroughs -- Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens -- sent 310 more selective service men to Army training points yesterday for a year's military service on the first day of the third trainee requisition period. The second call was completed last week. Men from the Bronx and Richmond will be called later in the week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt became the first third-term President today before the admiring eyes of hundreds of New Yorkers jammed in the wind-swept plaza before the Capitol.

The semi-final bracket in the women's Class B championship of the Metropolitan Badminton Association was completed last night at the Fifth Avenue Country Club. Miss Elizabeth Peck of Garden City, seeded first, was among those advancing.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 15 shows the following changes from the report of Dec. 31, in thousands of marks:
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Two young Navy seamen on leave from a psychopathic ward were convicted today of ripping a Nazi flag from its staff at the German Consulate.

Senator O'Mahoney, chairman of the Temporary National Economic Committee, harshly criticized the existing economic order in the United States. He said, "If we are frank with ourselves we must realize that if the democratic world had succeeded in the past in distributing the products of commerce and industry among the masses * * * there would never have been such a thing as the rise of a totalitarian State."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- One word describes the way the first American President to win a third term felt on the first day of his third Administration -- exhilaration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The inaugural parade which marched "the historic mile" down Pennsylvania Avenue today and past the White House to salute President Roosevelt for the third time provided a dramatic foretaste of things to come in the military program of the United States.
Tony Marteliano, East Sider, carried the attack to earn the decision over Maxie Berger of the Bronx in the feature eight-rounder at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

From a source that is unquestionably authentic but must be kept secret, it was learned yesterday that Seton Hall's basketball team, winner of thirty-six straight, had received a direct offer to appear at Madison Square Garden. The plan was to pit the Pirates against Georgetown in one game of a special double-header on the night of Feb. 10 at the Eighth Avenue arena.
HAVANA, Jan. 20 -- The Cuban Government is considering a plan for internal financing of a surplus production of 400,000 tons of sugar in the current crop.

Steve Belloise, Bronx middleweight who twice failed to dethrone Ken Overlin, returns to the small-club battle area tonight in his campaign to re-establish himself as challenger for the 160-pound title. The hardhitting Bronx boxer is to battle Andre Jessurun, Harlem middleweight, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- While the condition of Percival W. Whittlesey was said in Nyack Hospital to be "fairly good" and his supposed assailant, Walter Groebli, was still at large, District Attorney George V. Dorsey made public here tonight excerpts from the diary believed to throw light on Groebli's state of mind during the fortnight preceding yesterday's shooting.

Courtney Burr announces the purchase of a comedy entitled "The Night Before Christmas," by Laura and S.J. Perelman, and expects to start rehearsals late this month. The play concerns a gang of robbers who rent a Sixth Avenue luggage store in the hope of tunneling their way through to the bank vaults next door.

The "freezing" of the assets in the United States of German and Russian-invaded nations by Presidential order has put these assets under the control of the Treasury's system of licenses. Not only have the interests of the United States been served but the rightful owners have been protected against the invaders.

EVERY so often, possibly just to keep themselves warm in cold weather, such men as Branch the Non-Alcoholic Rickey, Laughing Larry MacPhail, J.A. Robert Quinn and Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick give their opinions of what will come in the National League baseball race of 1941. There are fluent speakers for the American League side too.

Two more indictments obtained by Thurman Arnold's anti-trust forces resulted yesterday in the fining of the defendants who pleaded nolo contendere. The indictments were those obtained against companies and individuals that had combined to fix prices of spectacle lenses and frames, respectively.
ROME, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

Britain has received no real "aid" from the United States so far, Mlle. Eve Curie, daughter of Mme. Marie Curie, co-discoverer of radium, declared when she arrived here from Lisbon yesterday on the American Export liner Excambion.

One hundred and seventy-five business executives, representing eighty industries, returned to "school" yesterday and for five hours, broken only by a dinner session, listened to ten specialists in public relations explain the knack of "getting along" with employes and the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Milk Cap Statistical Bureau of Philadelphia and twelve manufacturers representing more than 75 per cent of the total business of the paper disc milk bottle cap industry have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with conspiracy to prevent price competition and restrain trade.

ATHENS, Jan. 20 -- It is now becoming apparent that the Axis is commencing a strong effort to attack from the air British communication lines and air bases in the Mediterranean and today this new phase of the war was extended on a considerable scale.
Mrs. Reginald Townsend gave a luncheon yesterday at the Cafe du Parc. Her guests were Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell, Mrs. Morris de Peyster, Miss Sylvia R. Hillhouse and Miss Susette Enthoven.

Supplies of locally dressed meats were normal yesterday, with lamb slaughter somewhat smaller than a week ago. Demand for traefer meats was fair, with asking prices higher than at the end of last week, although trading was quiet. The kosher market opened with asking prices slightly higher than Friday's average on veal and lamb and steady on kosher beef.

RKO's "Let's Make Music" will open this morning at the Palace instead of on Thursday as was announced previously. The picture features Bob Crosby, Jean Rogers, Elizabeth Risdon, Joseph Buloff and Joyce Compton. "Santa Fe Trail" is the other attraction on the double feature program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Notwithstanding the complications due to wars on two continents, all the countries having diplomats in Washington were represented officially at the inauguration of President Roosevelt.

DARWIN, Australia, Jan. 20 -- Lieut. Gen. V.A.H. Sturdee, Chief of the Australian General Staff, who has just returned from the Middle East, said today that the British forces in the western desert were fighting geographical conditions, not Italians.

In making public the annual statement of the Minnesota Mutual Life Insurance Company, T.A. Phillips, president, said the gain in insurance in force in 1940 was more than twice that of 1939. The 1939 gain in coverage was $4,468,538, while in 1940 it was $10,457,320, bringing the total in force on Jan. 1 to $240,460,689.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 20 -- Syracuse and Notre Dame maintained their reputation for basketball thrillers as the Irish won a 54-to-49 overtime contest before a capacity crowd of 3,000 tonight. It was the third extra-period game in the last four played here by the two rivals.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- The third time proved the charm for Paul Codd's gray 5-year-old Gino Rex at Hialeah Park today. After finishing second in his two previous races of the Winter season, the son of Gino made the grade in the Inauguration Purse, named by the Miami Jockey Club in honor of President Roosevelt's third-term inauguration.

Tragic events have now forced an ancient and mysterious land into the international puzzle we call the war. Bangkok announces that the flag of Thailand flies again over a district in Cambodia. From France come hints that the Vichy government is tiring of the unwelcome struggle and willing to discuss terms.

Andrew Ponzi took a firmer hold on second place in the Pocket Billiard League world title tournament by beating Johnny Irish twice at Julian's Fourteenth Street Academy yesterday. Ponzi won in the afternoon by 125 to 6, in six innings, and took the night engagement, 125 to 99, in seventeen frames.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 20 -- The career of Billy Soose, the middleweight boxer who has beaten both recognized champions of his class without a title to show for his handiwork, closely parallels the ring path of his college coach -- but the tutor hopes the similarity soon will end.

The phenomenal virtuosity of Shura Cherkassky, the young pianist who gave his second New York recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, is scarcely a matter of news any longer. What is more interesting and more problematic, too, is the development of Mr. Cherkassky as an interpreter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Prime 1.215 pound average steers topped at $15.75 today, highest level in more than three years. Choice medium weight and weighty steers were weak, however, and 15 to 25 cents lower. Hogs opened 15 to 25 cents higher with an early top of $8.75, but closed with part of the advance lost.

The extent to which the Federal Government is building up its strategic materials reserve for national defense was indicated yesterday by the disclosure that between 25,000 and 35,000 bales of raw rubber had been landed at Staten Island in the last four weeks by ships arriving from Singapore.

ROME, Jan. 20 (UP) -- Thirty-five German experts arrived in Rome today for two weeks of conferences expected to tighten up the economic liaison of the Axis partners and to provide a more flexible exchange of goods, particularly those vital to war industries.

The annual influx of wholesale dry goods buyers began yesterday, as many of them arrived a day ahead of the annual convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, which opens today at the Hotel New Yorker. A number of buyers ran immediately into a scramble for merchandise as several leading producers opened their Fall lines of men's underwear.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Otto Reiselt, 51-year-old veteran from Philadelphia, scored his fourth successive victory in the world three- cushion billiard championship tournament by defeating Herbert Peterson of St. Louis, 50 to 26, in fifty- three innings today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A three-judge Federal court in the middle Pennsylvania district held the Pennsylvania Alien Registration Law unconstitutional on the ground that it attempted "to usurp power [to regulate aliens] confided by the Constitution to the Federal Government."

The Franklin Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of Newark, N.J., in a report to stockholders, states that its outstanding mortgage loan guarantees at the end of 1940 amounted to $272,000, compared with $17,000,000 at the time of the bank holiday in March, 1933, of which $11,000,000 was held by four life insurance companies and the balance by miscellaneous investors.

FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 20 -- Brigade and regimental commanders of the Twenty-seventh Division were told today that their men must train more intensively and go on fifteen-mile marches for further toughening up in the next three weeks.

VICHY, France, Jan. 20 -- Echoes have reached Vichy of the surprise caused abroad by the reference to "President Laval" in the Vichy communique relating to the meeting between the "deposed heir apparent" -- that is still his style today -- and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain.

High-ranking Army officers from Washington, including Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commander of the GHQ air force, arrived at Mitchel Field by plane yesterday as the approaching "zero hour" for an "enemy" bombing attack at 6 o'clock this morning, placed 10,000 civilian air defense observers throughout Rhode Island, Connecticut, Massachusetts and all of New York east of the Hudson River "on the alert" to ward off the mock air raid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The third inaugural of Franklin D. Roosevelt wrote today into the 152-year record of the United States a new kind of chapter illustrating the extraordinary symbolism attaching to this office.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Four emaciated seamen told tonight how twelve fellow-sailors from a torpedoed British freighter had died in a lifeboat as they drifted eighteen days on the Atlantic in bitterly cold weather.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Prayers for President Roosevelt in guiding the nation to peace and for a united people were made at the inauguration today, the invocation by the Rev. Ze Barney T. Phillips, Chaplain of the Senate, and the benediction by Mgr. Michael J. Beady, General Secretary of the National Catholic Welfare Conference. The texts were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- John Nance Garner, leaving a borrowed silk hat on the seat behind him, stepped to the rostrum of the inaugural platform today to swear in Henry Agard Wallace as his successor in the Vice Presidency and thus wind up his own 38-year career in the nation's legislative halls.

INTERVALE, N.H., Jan. 20 -- Chester Emerson, known throughout the American snowbelt as just plain Chuck, and who is occupying an important role in the development of junior skiing in this part of the country, told today with pride of the fine progress among the boys and girls during the past four years.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Trainees of the third selective service call arrived at the Fort Dix recruit reception center at 4:40 P.M. today. There were 433 young citizen soldiers, 188 from New York City, 162 from Newark, and eighty-three from the Trenton induction center.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 20 -- Limited to April 30, 1941, the United States base [customs duties remission] bill was read for the first time in the Assembly today. The second reading was set down as the order of the day for the next meeting.

In these days when editorial attention must, perforce, be focused to such a great extent on national and international problems, it is heartening indeed to those interested in realty to find THE NEW YORK TIMES exploring the problem of assessments and overtaxation -- as evidenced by the editorial "Relief for Realty."

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- The demand of Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn of Ontario for an expansion of new currency to take care of increasing wartime needs drew from Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley today the retort that the Dominion Government would have nothing to do with "rubber money."

One of the reassuring features of this troubled time is the serene conviction with which the great foundations pursue their work of healing and enlightenment in the face of destruction and chaos. The Commonwealth Fund has just reported the expenditure last year of some two million dollars, a substantial part of it in the zone of suffering caused by the war, but most of it to confirm and advance the welfare of our own people.

SAIGON, French Indo-China, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Admiral Terraux, its commander, declared tonight that the French Asiatic squadron had destroyed the main force of the Thai Navy in his surprise attack in the Gulf of Siam on the night of Jan. 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The State Department will reject legislative demands that the department make public the diplomatic reports of Joseph P. Kennedy and William C. Bullitt, according to rumors on Capitol Hill. Mr. Kennedy, who will retire soon as Ambassador to Great Britain, and Mr. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France, were said by senator Wheeler of Montana to have disagreed sharply on the course the United States should pursue in the European war.

When Marshal Henri Philippe Petain declares that France has discarded the "obsolete and outworn order" of democracy and is united in a desire to collaborate in the new order being dictated by Germany, he does not speak for the French people, Eugene J. Houdry, president of France Forever, declared yesterday.

The trend toward informative labels and tags, started in 1940, is expected to continue at a more rapid pace this year, according to executives in the advertising field. Once a leader in any industry adopts such a policy, it was pointed out, competitors are generally forced to follow suit.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 20 -- Jack Ryerson, 42-year-old star of Cooperstown, N.Y., and young Bobby Walker of Jacksonville shot brilliant sub-par 71's today to share medal honors in the Winter golf championship of Florida on the St. Augustine links.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The fiscal and monetary affairs of the government are in "a very satisfactory condition" as it embarks upon the costly defense program, Secretary Morgenthau said today in an Inauguration Day statement; the American dollar has become the standard currency of the world and Americans are welcoming rather than refusing to make the sacrifices necessary to maintain their democracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Grimness and solemnity set the underlying mood for today's inauguration, but human nature, unpredictable factor that it is, allowed quaint and humorous situations here and there.

Norwood (Barney) Ewell, Penn State's great Negro sprinter, yesterday forwarded his entry for the Millrose Games, thus assuring a continuance of his spectacular duel with Harold Davis of Salinas Junior College, California, in New York's first major indoor meet at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday.

PARIS, Jan. 16 (Delayed, via Berlin) -- According to the Noveaux Temps correspondent at Abbeville, on the French coast, "half the population" has recently disappeared in a strange suicidal wave that has caused the inhabitants of the once prosperous Picardy city of 20,000 to throw themselves into the Somme River, which divides the town, or else disappear without leaving any trace.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- Before a meeting of the German Academy at Prague today, the Reich's press chief, Otto Dietrich, spoke on "The Spiritual Foundations of the New Europe" as projected by Adolf Hitler. Leading personalities of the Bohemia-Moravia Protectorate as well as German academic leaders were reported present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- On the exact spot on the Capitol steps where, with few exceptions, Presidents have taken the oath since the time of James Monroe, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was inaugurated again today as President of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- At no time today were prices of wheat above the close of last week and with rather persistent commission house and local selling the market on the Board of Trade here developed an easy undertone and closed at the bottom, with losses of 3/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Except for a fire in the Capitol, there were remarkably few accidents today considering that probably 500,000 people were massed downtown in the immediate neighborhood of the inauguration ceremonies.
VICHY, Jan. 20 (UP) -- French naval forces won a major victory in their encounter with Thai warships in the Gulf of Siam on Friday, according to an official communique today.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- John G. Winant will be the next United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, it was learned today. He is expected to be accompanied by a business man who will have the rank of Minister and liaison duties in connection with the United States' production of war materials, which is becoming more essential to Great Britain daily.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- For the first time since 1928 New York had a Republican today as Acting Governor.
LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 21 -- Bad flying weather, with an overcast sky and a gale reported at the Strait of Dover, apparently held off any German raiders last night.

The ex-convict Esposito brothers pleaded not guilty yesterday in separate arraignments in the killing of Patrolman Edward F. Maher last Tuesday after their alleged killing of Alfred V. Klausman in a $649 payroll hold-up.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- Germany's reaction to the flag incident in San Francisco Saturday was immediate and sharp. All sections of the press today contribute to the sum of indignation manifested editorially as well as in government quarters. The Wilhelmstrasse officials roundly denounced the incident as "scandalous," stating that it had made "the worst possible impression on the German people."

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- The veil of secrecy that shrouded the movements of Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini for forty-eight hours was lifted slightly this afternoon when the official German news agency released a communique declaring that a meeting between the two leaders and their Foreign Ministers had taken place.

Refugees coming to this country are now about 60 per cent Christian and 40 per cent Jewish, compared to a 75 per cent Jewish refugee influx four years ago, according to K. Brent Woodruff, executive director of the American Committee for Christian Refugees, Inc. Mr. Woorduff spoke last night at a dinner and meeting of the board of directors of the committee at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had too crowded a schedule today to spend any time pondering the historic significance of the date to the nation or to herself. She was much too engrossed in being the wife of the President, the mother of a reunited family, and last but not least, hostess to surging throngs of visitors at the White House, none the less hungry for being polite about it.

The first section of elevated structure of the Long Island Railroad between Rockaway Park and Far Rockaway, Queens, constructed at a cost of $2,225,000 in connection with the elimination of grade crossings in the Rockaways, was placed in service at 11:20 A.M. yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 20 -- The German Government refused a Vatican request to facilitate attendance at religious functions by Catholic populations in German-occupied territories, the Osservatore Romano discloses today.

Two prominent South American journalists took the occasion of President Roosevelt's inauguration to pay tribute today to the Chief Executive for laying the foundation for "permanent Western Hemisphere solidarity" with his good neighbor policy.

The eight-story apartment house at 1 East Sixty-second Street which Webb Knapp purchased for cash last week from the Clews heirs has again changed hands, passing to an investor who paid cash above a first mortgage of $105,000. Mrs. Roberta F. Castleman was the broker and Davis, Symmes Schreiber represented the purchasers.

Another unlawful combination among United States and German concerns, affecting a vital defense material -- steel, this time -- was Charged yesterday in an indictment returned by a grand jury investigating suspected bottlenecks in the national armament program. Seven companies and seven men engaged in producing magnesite, an essential material in steel manufacture, were accused in the true bill, which alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-trust and Wilson Tariff Acts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Today's Presidential inaugural was the thirty-eighth in American history, but Franklin D. Roosevelt is only the twenty-seventh man to go through the public ceremony.

The feud between Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and the City Council committee investigating him and the commission turned the committee's first public hearing of the year yesterday into a continuous round of contempt citations, threats of ejection and of arrest for disorderly conduct, and personal wrangles between Mr. Kern and Emil J. Ellis, committee counsel.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Never in the history of the United States has an inauguration attracted so much attention here. The British Broadcasting Corporation picked up not only the text of the speech by short wave from Washington, it even interrupted its sacred 6 P.M. news program to do so.

Among the contracts for commercial quarters reported by brokers yesterday was one signed by the Delehanty Institute renewing its lease on 24-26 East Fourteenth Street, where it occupies about 15,000 square feet of space. The James McCreery Realty Corporation are the lessors. Holman Holman negotiated the deal.

PARIS, Jan. 14 (Delayed; via Berlin) -- In an editorial headed "Our prisoners will have to suffer for it," L'Oeuvre today expresses the conviction that the Germans will take it out on the 2,000,000 French war prisoners as hostages for the continued intransigeance on the part of the Vichy Government in regard to the Franco-German negotiations.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Mayor Frank Hague, in a bold move to preserve Jersey City as a stronghold of his Democratic machine, aimed a blow today at his political adversaries, who admitted that if it lands, it may smash all organized opposition to his regime.

In connection with a renewed British plea of "immense urgency of material aid," about 1,000 members and guests of the New York State Bankers Association at their mid-Winter dinner in the Hotel Astor last night, heard Sir Louis Beale of the British Purchasing Commission explain why Britain "should not be forced to part with the bulk of our overseas investments."

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 21 -- Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka told the Japanese Diet today that Japan, Germany and Italy certainly would accomplish their goal of a new world order "if only given time" and expressed hope that the United States "will bend her utmost efforts to allay the impending crisis of civilization."
Plans for an alteration project costing about $500,000 in the electric generating station at 320-6 West 201st Street were filed yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.

The Southern Natural Gas Company will offer today to its stockholders 484,379 shares of common stock of $7.50 par value through issuance of warrants to buy stock in the ratio of seven-tenths of one share for each share held. The price to the stockholders will be $10 a share.

The Bureau of Biological Survey, or, if you must be modern, the Fish and Wildlife Service, continues to advance the theory that by continuing what sportsmen are inclined to term "rigid conservation regulations" on waterfowl the ducks, geese and shore birds may eventually be as plentiful as they were in the good old days.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- Police hunted a man or men today who may have waited ten years to rob Mrs. Evelyn Ide of more than $4,000 in jewelry.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Four new national shuffleboard champions were crowned today as the annual mid-Winter tournament drew to a close after being delayed for four days by rain.

A large audience filled the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon when the sixteenth annual concert, arranged by Albert Morris Bagby, was given for the benefit of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, an organization established to grant honorary pensions to needy aged musicians and to aid dependent members of their families.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Colonel William J. Donovan, United States war observer, had only completed his first round of unofficial calls today when usually reliable sources stated that an effort was being made to bring Greece, Turkey and Bulgaria into a Balkan entente.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Holding that the Federal Government is paramount in its power over aliens and noting that a law for registration of foreign born was enacted last year, the Supreme Court declared today that a Pennsylvania alien registration law was illegal.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Mayor George E. Brunner appointed a new Camden Housing Authority today to replace the five-man board that resigned on Dec. 23 at the demand of Nathan Straus, head of the United States Housing Administration.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The conference which Mayor La Guardia is to have with the Republican leaders of the Legislature has been set for 2 o'clock Thursday afternoon at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street, New York City. The Mayor recently request the conference so that he could lay the city's fiscal problems before Speaker Heck and Joe R. Hanley, the Senate majority leader, in the hope of getting legislative relief.

The board of directors of Broadcast Music, Inc., which the radio industry established to compete with the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, will consider today an agreement that would settle out of the court the anti-trust suit that the Department of Justice has threatened to file in Milwaukee, Wis.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 20 -- A British naval plane that alighted on Maldonado Bay last Tuesday night when it ran out of fuel while keeping watch over the French steamship Mendoza, anchored at Punta del Este, will be released to the British Legation tomorrow.

Successful adjustment to the problem of replacing the large variety of imports formerly used in lamp manufacture here has now been accomplished and the resulting lines were shown yesterday at the opening of the New York Lamp Show at the Hotel New Yorker, where exhibits occupying six floors were viewed by a fairly large number of buyers.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 20 -- Shanghai's Bund this morning, especially around what was the old Central Bank of China, witnessed a colorful ceremony as Wang Ching-wei's Nanking-sponsored Central Reserve Bank opened its doors and proclaimed its readiness for business.

The estimated profit of Dome Mines, Ltd., according to the preliminary report for 1940 issued yesterday, amounted to $4,088,633 after expenses, municipal, provincial, Federal and United States income taxes and other charges, but before depreciation, depletion and adjustment of surplus or contingent reserve accounts.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Senator Hanley, Republican majority leader, named tonight as member of a new Senate committee on national defense Messrs. Page, Wicks, Desmond, Feinberg, Warner, Williamson, Hastings, Mahoney, Coudert and James, Republicans, and Twomey, Quinn, Buckley, Esquirol, Joseph and Corning, Democrats.

Playing before a gallery that packed all the available space at the Yale Club courts, Robert H. Reeve Jr. of the Bayside Tennis Club registered one of the greatest surprises of the local season when he defeated Joseph J. Lordi, New York A.C. star, in a semi-final round match of the Clyde Martin Memorial invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday.

The volume of trading in the foreign exchange market increased considerably yesterday, although the aggregate of transactions was only a shadow of pre-war totals. The market was erratic following the disclosure over the week-end that machinery had been set up for "freezing" all foreign funds in the United States when and if President Roosevelt decides to sign an executive order.

VICHY, France, Jan. 20 -- France refuses to turn over her immobilized fleet to Germany for use against Great Britain and insists upon full observance of the French-German armistice, despite the reconciliation of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval, an official spokesman said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Reports that a German general staff officer had been shot dead in Bucharest deepened Balkan anxiety tonight as military observers agreed that a so-called Nazi "expeditionary force" of about 200,000 men was ready to move south, east or west at a moment's notice.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Pilots of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command patrolling the sea lanes from Iceland to Gibraltar have provided escorts for 4,700 convoys since the beginning of the war. Many of them, it was said officially today, are assigned to flying American bombers across the Atlantic.
Wayne Johnson of Johnson Shores was elected yesterday a director of the West Indies Sugar Corporation to fill a vacancy.

Plans ,ere filed yesterday for two new six-story apartment houses in the Bronx and one in Queens. In the latter borough and in Brooklyn architects also submitted the specifications for several groups of emall dwellings.
Ralph A. Powers of the Racquet and Tennis Club, defending titleholder, gained the semi-final round of the veterans' metropolitan squash racquets championship at the University Club courts yesterday.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Blair Co., Inc., and Graham, Parsons Co., received yesterday the award of $1,045,000 of public works, public welfare and refunding bonds of the city of Schenectady, N.Y., on a bid of 100.078 for 1.30s.

The contribution that Boy Scout training makes toward fostering a loyalty to democratic principles among the youth of all races in the city was stressed last night at a rally of 2,500 Scout leaders and friends of the Scout movement at the Hotel Commodore that officially launched a drive for $430,400 to expand Scout activities here this year.

The department of floor procedure of the Near York Stock Exchange yesterday announced new rules governing deliveries of Canadian stocks listed on the Exchange that will become effective on Jan. 27, on the same date that new instructions issued by the office of the Canadian custodian of enemy property will take effect.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 (UP) -- British and United States aid to China will not restrain Japan's program, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, the Premier, told the Diet today after Foreign Minister Yosuke Matsuoka, outlining Japan's foreign policy, had spoken frankly of danger of war with the United States.
Operations that may become commonplace to citizens of the Eastern Seaboard were started yesterday as the Army began a four-day experimental test of the nation's first Air Defense Command.

A small but select field began competition yesterday for the Women's Metropolitan Class A squash racquets title, left vacant by the four-time winner, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of the Apawamis Club, with two seeded players reaching the semi-final round on the courts of the Junior League Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted the application of International Utilities Corporation for permission to pay out of capital, or unearned surplus on Feb. 1, a regular quarterly dividend on this $3.50 preferred stock at the rate of 87 1/2 cents on the 98,908 shares outstanding.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- The fall of Kassala was admitted today by the Italian High Command in a war bulletin announcing that "strategic necessities have forced the command to evacuate" that captured base in the Sudan, just over the Eritrean border.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Four of the principal corporations engaged in the manufacture of tin cans and tinware had consolidated sales in 1939 of $302,657,213, or about 81 per cent of the total value of such products manufactured in that year, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Robert Montgomery will play the male lead opposite Irene Dunne in Universal's "Unfinished Business" if present negotiations to borrow the actor from Metro are successful, it was learned today. The deal probably will be concluded late this week.

Nothing could more dramatically illustrate what "total war" means today than the announcement of Labor Minister Bevin that the British Government has decided to register working men and women for drafting into war factories.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Senate Finance Committee withheld action today on the reappointment by Governor Lehman of Herbert Bayard Swope to the State Racing Commission pending at least the public hearings in New York City Jan. 31 and Feb. 1 by the Penny Legislative Committee, investigating the operations of the State's pari-mutuel law.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped 20 to 35 cents today, erasing yesterday's gains. Practical top was $8.40, with the bulk of choice 160 to 240 pound hogs selling at $8.15 to $8.35. Fat cattle trade was again generally slow to steady on all classes. The bulk of steers sold at $9.50 to S13, with prime 1,314-pounders topping at $15.60.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- How to defeat Great Britain before what is here regarded as likely American intervention in the European conflict was the main topic of the Mussolini-Hitler conversation, press and officially inspired comment made clear today.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- Charles Edison, former Secretary of the Navy and son of the inventor Thomas Alva Edison, was inaugurated here today as the fifty-second Governor of New Jersey in a ceremony stripped of all pomp in the interest of economy.

Magistrate Charles Solomon gave strong support to Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise campaign in Brooklyn Traffic Court yesterday when he issued a set of ten commandments for quiet automobile driving. Copies of Magistrate Solomon's decalogue were presented to twenty violators of the city's ban on unnecessary automobile horn tooting.

Steve Belloise's campaign to reestablish himself as a contender for the world middleweight title was halted on a strange decision last night at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn. The Bronx youth pounded the veteran, Andre Jessurun, a borough rival, through most of an eight-round slugfest that thrilled 4,000 excited fans -- and then stood aghast as he heard the decision announced in Jessurun's favor.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation reports net assets of $30,966,754 at Dec. 31, 1940, equivalent to about $159 a share on 194,517 shares of first preferred stock, the same amount as shown three months before and comparing with $172 a share on the first preferred stock at the end of 1939.

Mrs. Benjamin J. Garfunkel, former vice president of the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women and chairman of its United Refugee Appeal drive, was elected president of the council yesterday at its forty-seventh annual meeting in the Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The British Government cracked down today on two publications that had been sniping at the British war effort from the Left. They were The Daily Worker, Communist party newspaper, and The Week, a mimeographed news letter edited by Claude Cockburn and distributed to subscribers only.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 21 (UP) -- The reports of the rioting in Rumania, already occupied by thousands of German troops, gave bolder significance to Balkan reports bearing on the mysterious course of Germany's relations with Russia.

A majority of voters throughout the country endorse in principle President Roosevelt's proposal to lease or lend war materials to the British, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion has shown, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 21 -- "Two men coming to Fort Dix to cause a disturbance" was advanced today by Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, acting post commander, as the reason for the methodical search made of all automobiles and buses entering the fort from the north last night and Sunday night.

Visiting buyers reported in town last week numbered 1,340 as against 1,867 in the preceding week and 1,435 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations were 641 which compared with 917 for last Tuesday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 -- After only a few hours' fighting, British imperial troops that had launched their assault at dawn broke through the outer and inner Tobruk defenses about noon today and penetrated a semicircular area within the Italian lines to a depth of five miles on a broad front, the Middle East Command announced here tonight.

Trapped by a warped door in a public telephone booth in the main waiting room of the Administration Building at La Guardia Field yesterday, Paul B. Coffman, vice president of the Standard Statistics Company of New York, was rescued by an airport employe just in time to catch his United Air Lines plane for Chicago.

Miss Fredericka L. Allen, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Lathrop Allen of New Canaan, Conn., gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge. Among her guests were Mrs. Bradford A. Warner, Mrs. William C. Blind, Mrs. Braman B. Adams 2d, Mrs. Allen H. Minor and Miss Josephine Adams.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Internal revenue collections last month amounted to $654,095,220, compared with the December (1939) total of $498,993,133, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

Lyman Beecher Stowe in a letter in THE TIMES this morning comments on how Harriet Beecher Stowe is said to have written "Uncle Tom's Cabin" in "every place she lived from the cradle to the grave," and goes on to state that the book was written in Brunswick, Me.

A BOOMERANG comes back. So does a boomeranger, if that's the proper term to be applied to the thrower of such aboriginal Australian weapons. It may have been the recent inaugural ceremonies that caused Mr. M.P. Greenwood-Adams, native of and lecturer on Australia, to drop around and sound off on his favorite topic again.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Immediate construction of a $700,5000 building for the School of Chemical Engineering in Cornell University, the gift of Franklin W. Olin of Alton, Ill., president of the Western Cartridge Company, was announced today by President Edmund E. Day.
ATHENS, Greece, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Greek command issued the following communique tonight:

A resolution accepting with "deepest regret" the resignation of Dr. Nelson P. Mead as acting president of City College has been adopted by the Board of Higher Education, it was announced yesterday. On Monday night the board appointed Dr, Harry N. Wright, director of the college's evening and Summer sessions, to succeed Dr. Mead after the latter had submitted his resignation.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 21 -- The second day of Colonel William J. Donovan's stay in Sofia was a very active one. In the morning he had a long interview with the Bulgarian Foreign Minister, Ivan Popoff, and in the afternoon he was received by the Premier, Bogdan Philoff.
According to THE TIMES the New York City Board of Education has barred certain elementary Italian textbooks because of "excessively laudatory" description of fascism.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Jake Schaefer of Cleveland, scoring 13 billiards in the final four innings, turned, in the fastest game of the world's three-cushion tournament today by defeating John Fitzpatrick of Los Angeles, 50 to 38, in 38 innings.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 21 -- A tribute to the late Dr. W.A.R. Goodwin, "father of the restoration," was paid today when the new restoration office building was dedicated. It is named the Goodwin Building, in honor of the churchman and historian who died more than a year ago, and will house all general offices of restoration.

A capacity attendance is expected at the special cocktail party to be given Friday afternoon at El Morocco to raise funds for Irvington House, a non-sectarian sanatorium at Irvington-on-Hudson, which provides specialized care for needy children crippled by rheumatic heart disease.

Dudley L. Parsons, manager of the public relations department of the New York Trust Company, was elected yesterday president of the New York Financial Advertisers at the annual meeting in the Lawyers Club. Mr. Parsons, who is also editor of The Index, the bank's quarterly publication, succeeds as president Joseph Bame of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Senate unanimously adopted a resolution today calling on the Legislature to send a message to the British people expressing the hope and belief of the State that "they will win through to the final victory they so highly deserve."

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Lord Chatfield, Admiral of the Fleet, said today that the "sea situation shows a continual improvement" and expressed no concern over the menace of German air attacks -- citing the case of the cruiser Southampton, bombed last week in the Mediterranean, as the only loss of a large ship from this cause since the war began.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that he had never considered using American naval vessels to convoy ships bearing supplies to Great Britain. Sources close to the White House indicated the official view to be that such convoying might lead to war.

Packages of food and clothing are now being sent from Lisbon by the American Auxiliary Committee of the Union des Femmes de France to French prisoners of war whose families are too poor to help them, the committee announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The moral embargo against the sale by Americans to Soviet Russia of airplanes and materials essential to their manufacture, as well as patent processes for making high quality aviation gasoline, was removed by the United States Government today.

Except for future changes in the 1940 Excess Profits Tax Law, the amount of a corporation's income credit for the base period years, as determined for the first taxable year in which this method is employed, will obviously also be the measure of such credit for subsequent years.

Magistrate William E. Ringel yesterday in the Felony Court dismissed a charge that Michael Marcello of 10-45 115th Street, College Point, Queens, had brought contraband coal into this city from Pennsylvania, holding that the City Administrative Code, requiring drivers to carry certificates of origin for their loads, when drawn from beyond five miles of the city limits, was unconstitutional.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Eclipsing Woof Woof's sparkling victory in the feature event, Red Flannels captured the second race at Santa Anita park today and paid off at new high figures for the current season, $178.40, $54.20 and $23.20 for $2 mutuel tickets.

Charges of undue favoritism to one candidate in the civil service examination for radio traffic assistant at the municipal station, WNYC, were aired yesterday before the City Council committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission and its president, Paul J. Kern, at a public hearing in the County Court House in Foley Square.

Several hundred members of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association were advised at their forty-seventh annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday that the peak of defense construction would be passed by July and that in the latter part of this year or the first part of next year they should concentrate off selling lumber in other markets.

There was a full house at the Lincoln yesterday when the Metropolitan Basketball Writers convened. A quick glance around the room showed the coaches in attendance were Nat Holman of C.C.N.Y., Clair Bee of L.I.U., Joe Lapchick of St. John's, Ed Kelleher of Fordham, Paul Mooney of Columbia, Artie Musicant of Brooklyn, Frank Cappon of Princeton, Arthur Meinhold of Brooklyn Poly, Jack MacDonald of Hofstra, Rody Cooney of St. Francis and Babe Spotts of Pratt.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation will redeem on Feb. 21 all its first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series B, due on July 1, 1940 to 1946, and first mortgage 4 1/4s, Series B, due on July 1, 1947 to 1950, and on March 1 all its first mortgage 4 1/4s, Series A, due on March 1, 1961, H.E. Lewis, president, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The intelligent cooperation given by business in the Government's tremendous spending program has been one of three major factors in maintaining prices at a stable level, Leon Henderson, in charge of price stabilization for the advisory commission to the Council of National Defense, told more than 400,000 grocery wholesalers, manufacturers, brokers and retailers here today.

A British philatelic expert and another art concern soon will join the roster of firms occupying quarters along Fifty-seventh Street. Leases with both organizations and with firms in the apparel industries, many of whom took full-floor units, also were reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the wheat market and at one time prices were off about 1 cent a bushel and at a new low since Dec. 23. Continued easiness in securities, lack of aggressive support and favorable crop comments combined with growing uneasiness as to proposed changes in the farm program furnished the background for the selling, brokers said.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Robert Boothby sent Prime Minister Winston Churchill his resignation as Parliamentary Secretary for the Food Ministry today after a committee of the House of Commons had charged him with conduct "derogatory to the dignity of the House."

EHRHARDT, S.C., Jan. 21 -- Quail shooting, like duck shooting, depends a lot on the weather, but the strong wind and driving rain that bring ducks into the decoys drive the quail hunter to the fire. For the past few days the quail shooters in most of the areas of North and South Carolina through which we passed have been spending a good part of their time around the fire.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, and Clarence (Red) Burman of Baltimore, who will box for the title in Madison Square Garden on Jan. 31, yesterday were summoned to appear before the State Athletic Commission on Friday to sign contracts and submit to the usual pre-battle physical examination.

The signed entry of Paul Moore, former Stanford ace, for the Wanamaker Mile, featured event on the program of the Millrose Games, which will launch the Madison Square Garden track season on Feb. 1, was announced yesterday by Meet Director Fred Schmerz.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Big Steve Owen was talking straight from the shoulder, and this hefty coach of the New York Giants' professional football team has very large and very wide shoulders.

Net operating profits of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company in 1940 amounted to $23,471, compared with $3,706 in the preceding year, George McAneny, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. Gross income for the year was $2,890,169, of which the title department contributed $1,662,194; income from invested assets was $608,527; gross income of the banking and trust departments was $573,049 and service fees and other income amounted to $46,400.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Great Britain must adopt industrial registration by age groups and prepare to draft workers from non-essential employment into production of war materials, Minister of Labor Ernest Bevin told the House of Commons today.

With film companies admitting a shortage of good script material literary scouts never have been more active around New York, it is reported. Publishers say they can scarcely keep up with the demand for galley proofs of unpublished books.
Leases involving large apartments featured the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

The first ambulance constructed in this country for desert warfare, to be delivered to the Anzac forces of the British Army fighting in Egypt and Libya, was presented to the British-American Ambulance Corps by the Women's League for Palestine at a luncheon yesterday attended by 1,000 members of the latter organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The trials and tribulations that beset August Ruggiere, 32-year-old former pugilist who collected $98,000 after winning first prize in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes last April, were revealed yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court where several suits Were consolidated so they could be heard before Justice Aron Steuer and a jury of eleven men and one woman.

FORT M'CLELLAN, Ala., Jan. 21 -- Published reports that he was only 15 years old will mean the discharge from the Army of Private Edward H. Miller Jr. of the 165th Field Artillery. Gerard W. Kelley, adjutant general of the Twenty-seventh Division, directed today that the youth be separated from the service.

If Hilda Ohlin, who appeared in her first Town Hall recital last night, had the voice to match her taste, intelligence and discrimination, she would be an uncommonly fine soprano. As it is, she brings many cherishable qualities to her work as a singer.
The prevalence of influenza in New York City continues its steady, but slow, rise of the last month or more, according to data obtained yesterday at the Health Department.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 21 (.zP) -- Fighting between heavily armed Rumanian Iron Guards and the Rumanian Army was reported i spreading tonight to many parts of that country. Diplomatic advices out of Bucharest said, too, that General Ion Antonescu, the Rumanian Chief of State, was forming a military dictatorship in an effort to restore order.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Organized labor in the United States is opposed to drafting workmen, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who said today that the announcement by Labor Minister Ernest Bevin in London that the drafting of labor would be undertaken meant that a desperate state had been reached in that country.

The Canadian dollar again was subjected to strong pressure in the free market yesterday, though it was largely a case of increased offerings against the normally slack demand. The Dominion rate touched a low point of 83.00 cents during the session, the bottom since Sept. 18.

Moved by a desire to give financial compensation to citizens injured while aiding the police in their duties, the City Council proceeded rapidly yesterday toward approval of a measure introduced by Council President Newbold Morris to accomplish that end.

A drop in the number of persons on WPA rolls by June 30 was forecast by Oliver A. Gottschalk, acting WPA Administrator here. He estimated about 20,000 would have left the rolls for jobs in private industry and as a result of the eighteen-month ruling under which a WPA employe must be dropped after a year and a half's employment.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Despite the fact that this country is at war the antique issue of the "old school tie" managed to occupy a portion of Parliament's time today.

William Stanley Miller, who has served for more than seven years as president of the Tax Commission, has been named by Mayor La Guardia to fill a new post as justice of the Court of Special Sessions, it was learned yesterday.

A.W. Robertson, chairman of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday that the company, which delivered approximately $18,000,000 worth of national defense materials in 1940, would at least treble its defense production in 1941.

Libby, McNeill Libby and its domestic subsidiaries showed a consolidated net income of $1,818,844 after taxes and all charges for the period covering March 2 to Nov. 2, 1940, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Total net sales were $36,822,282.

To expand its activities under the national defense shipbuilding program the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Kearny, N.J., plans to acquire 15 1/4 acres of adjoining land, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The House passed without a dissenting vote today the bill to authorize the Navy to spend $300,000,000 for modern anti-aircraft defenses for the fleet. The speed with which the House acted to send the measure to the Senate drew commendation from President Roosevelt, who has urged that the fleet be put into first-class condition ms quickly as possible.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 21 -- After a comparatively weak opening, Dutch shares rallied today on the Bourse and closed slightly irregular.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Robert Jackson, the Attorney General, told the General Assembly of the Council of State Governors tonight that German owners of patents and processes exerted a direct influence on the development of the defense program of the United States, and asserted that legislation might be necessary to free American business of obligations that were inadvertently aiding Germany.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Questioning winnowed ten acceptable jurors, five women and five men, from twenty-four tales-men today for the trial of Joseph Spell, 31-year-old Negro butler accused of attacking Mrs. Eleanor Strubing of Greenwich.

In THE TIMES of Aug. 24 last there appeared a letter in which I mentioned certain reminiscences of the work of the Commission for Relief in Belgium during the last war. To my astonishment and regret I find that certain parts of this letter are being used as an argument against the extending of relief to the populations of occupied countries in Continental Europe.

A greater degree of harmony between business men and government officials, with less sniping or "back-seat driving" on the part of both, was urged yesterday by Dr. Edwin G. Nourse of the Brookings Institution as one way of getting better teamwork in this country.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- Persistent rumors that Spain's critical food shortage was due to continued exports to Germany reached such a point today that Dr. Eberhard von Stohrer, the German Ambassador, issued a public denial.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 21 -- Invasion of this hemisphere is possible, said Sir Gordon Lethem, Governor of the British Leeward Islands, who is here today on his way to London by air to join in conferences on the United States defense bases on British possessions in the hemisphere.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Announcement that Great Britain's war government has reached the point where it must conscript men and women for arms factories, by compulsion if necessary, tonight roused a storm of protests from both the Conservative and Leftist ranks of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The housewives of the United States are soon to receive the most thorough education in how to feed their families ever provided by any nation in the world.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 21 -- Colonel William J. Donovan will arrive, in Belgrade tomorrow night for a two-day visit, during which he is expected to confer with Regent Prince Paul, Premier Dragisha Cvetkovitch and Foreign Minister Dr. Alexander Cincar-Markovitch and many other Yugoslav Government leaders.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security issued this communique today:
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The British General Headquarters at Cairo today issued the following communique:

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook dismissed yesterday after argument a writ of habeas corpus sought by Jacob (Jack) Bernoff, 34 years old, of 160 Thatford Avenue, Brooklyn, for his release from custody as a material witness. District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, who caused Bernoff's arrest in his investigation of the milk racket involving shakedowns of small tradesmen and truckmen, appeared personally to ask dismissal of the writ.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Jan. 21 -- After a survey of the recently organized corporations in New York State that sell medical expense insurance to the public, the medical economics committee of the Westchester County Medical Society reported tonight to the society that it approved the plan of the Medical Expense Fund of New York, Inc., but disapproved several others because of inadequate assurances that physicians would receive proper compensation.

Harold N. Milbank, 56 years old, lawyer and champion wrestler and fencer at Yale in his student days, was sentenced yesterday to eighteen months to two and one half years in Sing Sing by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions.

The first President of the United States to serve a third term comes from a city which dislikes to swap chief executives. When the present term of Mayor La Guardia expires on Dec. 31, we in New York will have lived under the same Mayor for eight years; under the same Governor for nine years, and under the same President for nine years less a couple of months.

The chief purpose of the government's export control division is a maximum of conservation with a minimum of restriction and regulation, Colonel Russell L. Maxwell, director of the division of export control of the State Department, yesterday told a gathering of 300 members and guests of the Export Managers Club at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ROME, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Italian High Command communique today follows:

Stocks gave a short-lived show of strength in the trading before noon yesterday, but the demand was not sufficient to outbalance the selling which appeared at midday, and prices closed lower. While the volume on the Stock Exchange was 577,990 shares, against 377,280 on Monday, the trading was spread too thinly to give the list any material lift.

ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- New Italian efforts to launch a counter-offensive in Albania have been checked before they got under way, according to reports from the front reaching here today. Attempted reconnaisance operations also were frustrated at their outset, it is said.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 21 -- The Turkish attitude toward Germany is well set forth today in a vigorous article in which Hussein Caid Yalcin replies to a German propagandist's article on Turkey that has just been published in the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung by a traveling correspondent who was recently here.

Although the editorial in THE TIMES for Jan. 15, "Bedding Down a Cold," was written in a facetious vein, yet it commented on the most important point in the several items of advice issued by the United States Public Health Service concerning the prevention of influenza.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The State Tax Department sponsored in the Legislature today a series of ten bills, making important changes in the personal income, corporation and corporate franchise tax laws. The bills were introduced by Senator Bewley, chairman of the Committee on Taxation, and Assemblyman Whitney, chairman of the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Debits to deposit accounts (except inter-bank accounts), as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 15, aggregated $9,111,000,000.

A large and distinguished assembly attended the opening of the exhibition of English and French landscapes by the great nineteenth-century French painters at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

Secretary of War Stimson has told the country that the United States stands in real danger of aerial invasion, should the British fleet be destroyed or surrendered. Mayor La Guardia has already taken steps to set up a City Defense Council to lay plans for civilian defense in the event of an air raid upon New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Lehman's recommendation to the Legislature, that interest charges on small loans under $100 be reduced from the present 3 per cent a month to 2 1/2 per cent, was assailed today in the Senate by Senator Williamson of Westchester, chairman of the Committee on Banks.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (UP) -- A warning that Russia must bolster her defenses against grave eventualities of the war," toward which the Soviet Union cannot remain indifferent," was issued tonight by Alexander Sherbakoff, secretary of the Moscow Communist Party.
UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York sent this telegram from Montreal today to Holland Foster, chairman of Dairy Farmers Union:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was described today as "delighted" with the reaction to his inaugural message and with the congratulations coming to the White House from this country and abroad.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 22 -- Rip cord paralysis, a form of fear likely to make a parachute leap the jumper's last, does not worry members of the 501st Parachute Battalion in training at this post. Some 412 enlisted men and thirty-four officers are undergoing the training required of parachute troops.

VICHY, France, Jan. 21 -- There was no change in the situation here today. None is expected until Fernand de Brinon, still officially the French representative in Paris, has arrived. He is not expected until the end of the week.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Frank Allan of Pittston, Pa., was the only two-time winner of the trophy still in the running after the first round of match play in the Winter championship of Florida was completed on the St. Augustine Links today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 21 -- Speculation on the possibility of the setting up of a single command for the Axis forces was rife as diplomatic military quarters here today examined reports of the most recent Hitler-Mussolini meeting.

In an effort to prevent the dissolution of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, Mayor La Guardia addressed yesterday a letter to the city's business executives urging them to assist the committee in its drive for funds.

With the budget balanced and reports showing an increase of 44 per cent during 1940 in the membership of registered Girl Scouts in Greater New York, the newly formed central board of directors for the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York held its first meeting yesterday in the council's headquarters, 670 Lexington Avenue, to coordinate reports and discuss the program of the new unit.

Harry Cykman, 19-year-old violinist who made his debut in San Francisco at the age of 7, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation, whose prize he won last April.

New York was acclaimed the world center of millinery fashions last night when some 1,500 retailers, manufacturers and other trade executives viewed 132 styles created by American designers at the style show held under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission at the Hotel Astor.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Eighteen fishermen were drowned today, almost within sight of their homes, as the Boston schooner Mary E. O'Hara, homeward bound from a week on the fishing banks, was split open in a collision as it approached Boston Harbor and sank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Roosevelt indicated at his press conference today that he might have an announcement to make tomorrow concerning the appointment of an Ambassador to the Court of St. James.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Apparently freshened by an overnight stay on the farm, Herb Cain paced the Boston Bruins to a 4 -- 3 overtime victory over the New York Rangers by scoring twice and assisting for a tying goal tonight before more than 15,000 fans at the Boston Garden.

Dry goods wholesalers were warned yesterday that 1941 may be the last year in which it will be possible for them to convert increasing purchasing power into substantial business, and they were advised to make the most of this opportunity and the chance now offered to make their position clear to the rest of the country through close cooperation with defense officials.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 22I -- Telephone service between Belgrade and Bucharest was interrupted today and there was an unconfirmed report tonight that the Nugoslav-Rumanian frontier would be closed at midnight. Sources on the border reported German troops quartered in the lumanian Banat were being sent to Bucharest to join the German garrison and Ru~ martian troops in the capital in suppressing street demonstrations and rioting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 15:

Selling by Bombay in the distant months exerted an unsettling influence on cotton prices yesterday. Final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 2 to 15 points, with the exception of January, which closed nominally at a net decline of 18 points.

Joey Iannotti, 128 1/4, Bronx, scored a technical knockout over Aaron Seltzer, 127 3/4, Bronx, after 1:29 of the third in the scheduled eight-round feature bout before 10,000 fans at the Bronx Coliseum last night.

The overwhelming margin of superiority displayed by Yale in its debut with Penn and the Dartmouth triumph over Columbia, the second straight of the season for the Hanover squad, featured the second week of competition in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Philip Murray, C. I. O. head, began today informal negotiations with the United States Steel Corporation for wage increases and other revisions of the union's bargaining contract. Representing the steel company was William Beye, director of the company's industrial relations.

The 5 1/2-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 130 feet at 2719-21 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Alfin Operating Company, Louis Susman, attorney, to a client of Barnett J. Monka, attorney. The structure contains fifty-three apartments and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $144,000.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Moffat of London gave a cocktail party today at their Everglades Club apartment.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,611,900 barrels daily, an increase of 247,450 over the 3,364,450 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 20,900 barrels more than the calculation of 3,591,000 daily for January by the Bureau of Mines.

Playing a Guarnerius violin which was presented to him after a benefit concert in Havana, Angelo Reyes, 21-year-old Cuban violinist, made his New York debut last night at Carnegie Hall. His father, Angelo Reyes Sr., a composer, was in the audience, and the violinist played three of his father's Cuban dances in the last part of his program.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Bench warrants charging conspiracy to defraud the government were issued today for the arrest of Vincent J. Sullivan of Bridgeport, former WPA Administrator for Connecticut, and eight other former WPA officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Educators and recreational experts of the country were urged by Mrs. Roosevelt today to make more and better use of public school buildings, not only as "instruments of academic education but as centers of community life."

CLEVELAND, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Bob Feller, poised and confident in sharp contrast to the awkward country boy who shambled in six years ago to sign his first contract with Cleveland, became the highest paid pitcher in the history of baseball today when he agreed to give the Indians $30,000 worth of his services this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Texas Company and the Shell Oil Company, Inc., both of New York City, denied today charges of the Federal Trade Commission that they had violated the Robinson-Patman act in the sale of gasoline in the Detroit area.

LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 22 -- German activity over the eastern part of England was maintained on a considerable scale in yesterday's daylight hours, yet nowhere did an important attack develop. A few bombs fell on the capital in the course of London's three alarms and towns and villages in surrounding counties were damaged.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- Russia has changed enormously in the last year. When this correspondent came to Moscow from Riga at this time last January conditions were admittedly difficult, but, although I have known the Soviet Union with its surprising ups and downs for twenty years, I never thought that twelve months could make such a difference of atmosphere, tone and fact.

Governor Edison's inaugural address is bare of rhetoric and goes to the point. If he is caught in a contradiction it is one almost universal among executives. Thus he wants to enlarge the benefits of social security. He also wants to reduce expenses and opposes new taxes. It is scarcely for outsiders to express an opinion on his specific proposals of legislation.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 21 -- A. W. Thompson Norman and M.H. Baillieu, owners of the famous racer Ajax, have decided to retire him for breeding purposes. Ajax is the record stake winning stallion of Australasia. He ran in forty-six races and won thirty-six times, was second seven times and third twice.

Wendell L. Willkie, defeated Republican presidential candidate, leaves today for England aboard the Yankee Clipper of Pan American Airways to make a first-hand investigation of the effects of the war on Britain and to get some idea of the British hopes for Europe in the post-war period.
DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation announced today the completion of plans for a monthly output of 1,500 aviation engines and parts and subassemblies for 200 bombing planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Full enforcement of the New York Stock Exchange ban on "multiple trading" would cost the Boston Stock Exchange fully 25 per cent of the issues now traded there, John E. Yerxa, president, told the Securities and Exchange Commission at the opening of hearings on the question today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 -- The Hialeah Park meeting hit its full stride today, an upward surge of both attendance and betting marking a session which was featured by the victories of long shots, including the Tallyho Stable's Topee in the Tavanier Purse.

State Senator Joe R. Hanley's conduct as Acting Governor on Monday, while Mr. Lehman and Mr. Poletti were in Washington for the inauguration, deserves commendation as a pattern for all officeholders. Not since 1928 had a Republican been called upon to occupy even briefly the State's highest office, so the Senate majority leader was forced to make his own rules of etiquette.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UP) -- Army officials were quoted by Mrs. Roosevelt today as believing that married men should receive draft deferments whether or not their families were dependent on their earnings.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Analysis of orders received during December by Massachusetts mills and factories, compiled by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts and released today, indicates that the demand for machine equipment, tools and other products of the metal-working industries has reached such proportions that larger orders are now being reported by small concerns which heretofore have not shared appreciably in the general business increase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Coincident with White House assurances that President Roosevelt contemplated no act so obviously warlike as the convoying of supply ships to England, Joseph P. Kennedy, retiring Ambassador to Great Britain and stanch non-interventionist, cast his lot today with those urging greater executive powers to enable President Roosevelt to aid the foes of the Axis in the interest of American defense.

The exhibition of Indian art described as "the largest and most representative of its kind ever held" opened with a preview last evening at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It is to continue until April 27.

The theatrical unions having made concessions, "Crazy With the Heat" is expected to resume its Broadway career, probably on Thursday night of next week, at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, where it was taken off last Saturday night after giving only seven performances.

A further drastic shake-up in the executive personnel of the Associated Gas and Electric Company system is under consideration, it was learned yesterday. Latest changes contemplated by the trustees of the system involve the appointment of Alexander Speer, formerly chief power engineer of the power division of the Public Works Administration, as president of the Virginia Public Service Company, an important subsidiary of Associated Gas serving a large part of Virginia.

A suit charging that Communist influence pervaded certain district relief offices of the Welfare Department, protecting inefficient employes who are Communists and causing the dismissal of the plaintiff because of her anti-Communist activity, is scheduled to go to trial today before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.

Sharper competition and increased advertising in two important fields, cigarettes and soaps, are expected this year, as a result of recent developments in these industries. Introduction of Swan, a new white floating soap by Lever Brothers, will spur activity in that field, while new campaigns and account changes will serve to stimulate the tobacco industry.

Paramount's "A Night at Earl Carroll's," which opens at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone screen arrival. Featured in the picture, which has a Hollywood night club background, are Ken Murray, Rose Hobart, J. Carrol Naish, Lillian Cornell, Brenda and Cobina and Earl Carroll. . . . "Second Chorus" enters its second and final week today at the Paramount. . . . "Rebecca" will begin a second week today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The British Empire has taken not only the Belgian Congo but also French Cameroons into virtual full partnership, it appears from an announcement today.

A united China, her internal factions postponing their differences and standing together in a mighty effort to drive out the Japanese invader, has achieved such marvels of resistance that reports of a breach between Chiang Kai-shek's government and two Communist armies hitherto supporting it can only be regarded as deplorable, if true.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The stock markets had a dull session today and even the announcement of the shrinkage in shipping losses failed to bring about an improvement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Vice President Wallace took over his constitutional function as presiding officer of the Senate today at a session of an hour wherein his parliamentary duties were of the lightest. Mrs. Wallace watched the proceedings from the members' gallery, as did several friends.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary Hull made public today notes concerning the tearing down of the German Reich flag at San Francisco Saturday. A note from Dr. Hans Thomsen, charge d'affaires of the German Embassy, dated Saturday, expressed a "most emphatic protest."

At a large cocktail party given yesterday afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Miller at their home, 814 Fifth Avenue plans were discussed for the sale of a miniature bronze horse, by Herbert Haseltine, sculptor, to aid British War Relief. The statue is a sculptural likeness of the champion "George Fifth, Field Marshal of the Shires," belonging to the British royal family.

Only Joe Procita of Boston was able to score a double in the world title pocket billiard tourney yesterday, with Johnny Irish of Syracuse as his victim. Procita, playing at Boston, beat Irish, 125 -- 33 and 125 -- 64, in eighteen and six innings, respectively, making high runs of 61 and 64.

SEATTLE, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Vacancy of one of the nation's most attractive minor league baseball posts started a flood of conjecture today over who would succeed John Frank (Jack) Lelivelt, 53, manager of the champion Seattle nine of the Pacific Coast League.

Frank M. Patterson, general counsel for the Union News Company and former chairman of the State Banking Commission, who died on April 10, 1939, left a gross estate of $2,155,666, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Wednesday, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Widespread disorders in Rumania, including the slaying of a German officer, prompted Premier General Ion Antonescu to put the army in charge of the State police, militarize eighty-seven important industries, and make a desperate appeal last night to dissident Iron Guards to "forget hatreds" and aid him in re-establishing order.
A large business property on Sixth Avenue changed hands in a leading realty transaction yesterday, the purchaser paying an all-cash consideration.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A British consular official's advice to certain British residents to leave Japan "before the impending crisis in American-Japanese relations comes to a head" was disclosed by reliable informants today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -- Serious street fighting occurred throughout Rumania all day today, according to information reaching this city. There were three large demonstrations in Bucharest, one of which became a riot in which many were seriously hurt when a "spontaneous" pro-Nazi procession was attacked by the Codreanist "Communist" faction of the Iron Guard.

Supplies of most classes of fresh meats were below normal yesterday. Lamb slaughter was reduced compared with the first two days of last week. Demand was slow for all classes, although relatively light veal supplies had a fair outlet. Demand for kosher meats was slow at the opening. Veal prices were steady to firm; lamb, weak; other classes about steady.
